Wow.I was not expecting too much -- the Amazon seller who offered me a large quantity for reviewing purposes was new, they said, to Amazon, and I wondered why so generous.Well, I don't care what their motivation. This is really very high quality coconut oil, delicious in smoothies, excellent for chapped hands on the trail, even good when I give my companion her favorite back rub -- both her and my skin feel great.I did a bit of research on how to judge a high quality coconut oil -- the same sort of process I suppose that foodies like me get obsessive about. A Doctor Fife gave me some insights as noted in the attachment; this oil passed all the tests with flying colors.Robert C. RossOctober 2015How can a person identify a good quality coconut oil? There is a way you can tell a high quality coconut oil from the rest. There are four things you can look for in a quality coconut oil. I’ll discuss each one briefly. The first thing to look for is a Virgin coconut oil. I recommend virgin coconut oil over non-virgin or RBD oil. RBD stands for refined, bleached, and deodorized. The less processing a food undergoes the higher the nutrient content and the healthier it is. Processing removes and destroys nutrients. Virgin coconut oil is made from fresh coconut without high heat or chemicals. The resulting product is less refined than RBD oil and retains more of its natural phytonutrients, which give coconut its distinctive aroma and flavor. In RBD oil all the phytonutrients have been removed so it is tasteless and odorless. Although virgin coconut oils, in general, are superior to RBD oils, not all virgin oils are of equal quality. In fact, there is a wide range of quality among them. There are many different ways to make virgin coconut oil. The methods and care used in the process determines the final quality of the product. To be honest with you, I have tasted some very poor quality coconut oils. In fact, some have been so bad I had to spit them out. Oils like this give the coconut oil industry a bad name. I won’t tell which brands to avoid, but I will give you some guidelines to distinguish the good from the not-so-good. I have tasted many good quality and a few extraordinary quality coconut oils. How do you tell the difference? How can you avoid the “not-so-good” ones? Appearances can be deceiving, that is if you don’t know what to look for. When looking for the best quality oil the appearance is very important. The second thing you look for in a high quality coconut oil is purity. If you are familiar with coconut oil you know it naturally has a high melting point. At 76 degrees F and lower it become solid, at higher temperatures it turns into a liquid. It’s much like butter, when it’s in the refrigerator its solid but if left out on a hot day it melts. High quality virgin coconut oil should be snow white in color when it is solid and water clear when liquid. If you see any shade of yellow or gray it is of an inferior quality. Pure coconut oil is colorless. Any discoloration is a sign of contamination. Contamination can be from mold or smoke residue. If old or sun-dried coconuts are used to make oil it will almost always contain mold. The mold isn’t considered harmful because temperatures used in processing are high enough to essentially sterilize it. If the heat used comes from open flames from wood or gas fuel smoke can be absorbed into the oil. The third thing to look for in a high quality coconut oil is aroma and flavor. Virgin coconut oils should always retain a coconut smell and taste. If not, they have been highly refined. If they have no flavor they are essentially RBD oil, even if they did come from fresh coconut. Some virgin coconut oils have a very strong flavor or smell. These are almost always of poor quality. The smell and taste comes primarily from contaminates and not coconut. If the oil does not taste and smell like fresh coconut beware. Some of the nastiest oils I have tasted were strong flavored and did not taste like coconut. Most virgin coconut oils use some type of heat in processing. Often smoke from the heating process contaminates the oil giving it a toasted or smoky smell and taste. Some oils when I open the jar smell like roasted coconut, which I like, but tastes like smoke, which I don’t like. The very best virgin coconut oils do not have a strong roasted or smoky taste or smell. They should have a very mild coconut aroma and flavor. The flavor should not be overpowering, but just mild enough to enjoy without altering the flavor of the foods it’s used with. The fourth criteria is price. You get what you pay for. Obviously, a very inexpensive oil is going to be of inferior quality. From my experience the cheapest oils are the most disagreeable tasting, and usually tainted with residual contaminants. The way to judge an oil is: 1) source, 2) appearance, 3) taste and aroma, and 4) price.

This is one of the most cockeyed "books" I've ever read. Simple, filled with icons, almost incomprehensible.I have it on my iPhone 6 so that I can dip back into it from time to time to see if I am intellectually capable of figuring it out. So far, I'm way behind the necessary curve, disheartening, really, because the author claims that only TV slugs will miss its import. Haven't watched TV for nine months and it still doesn't click in my mind.On example involves the author. He quotes his Wikipedia page which includes 98% about his and his brother's football careers, mentions a diet book, but has nothing about this literary effort.The other authors and their biographies are even more opaque.The section on the wall around the earth in Antarctica is baffling. I took a cruise there, went ashore for awhile, but saw no sign of the military who will arrest at or shot at gunpoint if you do not obey. "And the military surrounds the entire outer wall." How long has that been going on? What military was doing that before there was a United States. I just can't get my mind around that concept, having seen how cold it was during their summer in December.The picture of the map in the book is good, but you can see a much better version on Wikipedia at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Orlando-Ferguson-flat-earth-map_edit.jpg You can read the entire scripture condemnation of the round earth theory on the map itself:"SCRIPTURE THAT CONDEMNS THE GLOBE THEORYAnd his hands were steady until the going down of the sun—Ex. 17: 12. And the sun stood still, and the moon stayed.—Joshua 10: 12–13. The world also shall be stable that it not be moved.—Chron. 16: 30. To him that stretched out the earth, and made great lights (not worlds).—Ps. 136: 6–7. The sun shall be darkened in his going forth.—Isaiah 12: 10. The four corners of the Earth.—Isaiah 11: 12. The whole earth is at rest.—Isaiah 14: 7. The prophecy concerning the globe theory.—Isaiah: 29th chapter. Woe to the rebellious children, sayeth the Lord, that take counsel, but not of me.—Isaiah 30: 1. So the sun returned ten degrees.—Isaiah 38: 8–9. It is he that sitteth upon the circle of the earth.—Isaiah 40: 22. He that spreads forth the earth.—Isaiah 52: 5. That spreadeth abroad the earth by myself.—Isaiah 54: 24. My hand also hath laid the foundation of the earth.—Isaiah 58: 13. Thus sayeth the Lord, which giveth the sun for a light by day, and the moon and stars for a light by night (not worlds).—Jer. 31: 35–36. The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood.—Acts 2: 20.Another footnote reads: Send 25 cents to the Author, Prof. Orlando Ferguson, for a book explaining this Square and Stationary Earth. It Knocks the Globe Theory Clean Out. It will Teach You How to Foretell Eclipses. It is Worth Its Weight in Gold.Where did professor Orlando Ferguson stand to draw that map?I realized that it might be necessary to see a better version of the map; luckily there is a very good one right here on Amazon -- Map of the Square and Stationary Earth. Four Hundred Passages in the Bible That Condemn the Globe Theory or the Flying Earth, and None Sustain It. This Map Is the Bible Map of the World. By Orlando Ferguson Reproduction. 16.5 X 24 Inches.Right now, I'm struggling why with those four big angels  it is necessary for "the military" to also guard the wall. Puzzlement.Well, I will keep plugging and in time may be able to give others some idea of the substance here. Wish me luck please.Robert C. RossOctober 2015I'm sorry to keep focusing on this particular passage but the author emphasizes that this map is entirely accurate. If so, the Aussies are also in on guarding the perimeter:ATMs -- automated teller machines -- have become a ubiquitous feature in the lives of most people in developed nations. There are so many of them that, if you need cash, there's probably one somewhere nearby. Even if you go to your own bank to deposit a check, it's pretty common to go to the ATM instead of the flesh-and-blood teller. It would be downright weird to be somewhere without same-day access to a cash machine. And Antarctica is no exception.According to Australian government's Antarctic division, there are a few hundred to a few thousand people living on the southernmost continent at any given time, with more during the summer than the winter. Most of the people on Antarctica live at McMurdo Station, a U.S.-run research facility. McMurdo Station doesn't have all the amenities that you'd find in most other places, of course, but it's not all work and no play. McMurdo has a general store which sells all sorts of souvenirs, movies, and of course, liquor. (Here are some pictures.) There was once a bowling alley (pics) but it was dismantled in 2009. There's a cafeteria-style dining hall and a handful of bars and clubs, too. (It should be of no surprise that alcoholism is a major problem in the area, but that's another story.) Most of that requires money and often, cash is a good option. But storing months-worth of money in your Antarctic apartment is impractical and kind of dumb, so those living at McMurdo need access to cash on demand. There are no banks at the station, so the solution is comes in the form of two ATM provided by Wells Fargo. Only one of the machines is operational at any point in time, with the other serving as a backup -- a necessary redundancy due to the machines' remote location. Serving the ATMs is, to put it lightly, difficult. After all, you can't simply tell a mechanic that he or she has to grab a coat and go off to Antarctica. In 2010, David Parker, a vice president in Wells Fargo's ATM division, spoke with blog NeedCoffee.com about the process of maintaining and fixing the machines -- and the risks involved:You know, the other thing too that you may find interesting--I don't know how much you know about folks that need to go down to Antarctica--it's a huge process to do it. So when we're preparing for the vendor visit, it's like a ten-month process. [. . .] The reason being is, they obviously go in the off-season when it's obviously warmer because no planes fly onto the ice in their winter months. And so anybody that goes to Antarctica has to be cleared with a physical, a dental, and a psychological evaluation, because if for some reason the plane can't get out, you're trapped down there until the next season.Despite the difficulties of providing banking services to the Antarctic, there's no reason for people living there to open up accounts with Wells Fargo. According to NCR, the vendor who services the machines on behalf of the bank, there are no fees for using the ATMs.Credit: "Now I Know" blog

This wonderful cushion arrived yesterday, and I have already tried it in several different locations:1. Front seat of my Infiniti M35X -- after 100,000 miles the stuffing is worn out a bit and this cushion brought it back to life.2. On a hard kitchen chair at the table in the apartment of She Who Must Be Obeyed -- perfecto.3. On one of those "comfortable" seats at a theater on 14th Street -- the type they make for 6 foot 6 giants -- my 5 foot 6 inch frame was comfortable for the very first time.4. As a foot rest -- tootsies loving the soft caresses.5. Under my knees lying in bed -- almost as good as another more vigorous activity I could mention.6. In a plastic bag, out on the trail, leaning against a 15 inch diameter oak tree and waiting for the chickadee flock to find me -- nirvana for butt and mind.This wonderful cushion, offered me by the Amazon Seller in return for this review, has a permanent place in my backpack -- I would dump everything else to carry it in the future.Robert C. RossOctober 2015Unasked for advice. In reading the other reviews, many folks mention sitting for long periods at desks or elsewhere. Two important health points:1. Get up and walk around every hour for at least five minutes. Clears the mind and exercises the body and will pay great dividends.2. Better yet, stand ... and even better stand on one leg at a time. The Stork Exercise will greatly improve your balance and give you some exercise as well.My doctor prescribed the Stork four years ago, and this 78 year old codger has only fallen once since -- a young lady pushed her viola case between my legs from behind, and I almost caught myself anyone. Dr. Postley called it "life saving" and older folks with broken bones are in real trouble.But when you have to sit, this wonderful support provides Butt Nirvana -- bravo!Bob

I was delighted to receive a generous sample of hemp protein from Viva Labs, a company I have come to trust, having tried and reviewed several of their products.This sample had a lovely nutty flavor, and is a great addition to several of my favorite dishes, including oat groats and oat milk at breakfast, as a source of protein in almost any smoothie, and even sprinkled over popcorn,Foods can be classified as complete, partial, or incomplete sources of proteins. In order for a food to be classified as complete, it must contain all eight essential amino acids. Hemp is considered a complete protein because it contains all eight essential amino acids in sufficient quantities to meet the body’s needs. This also makes hemp a good alternative source of protein for vegetarians and vegans.Hemp protein is easy to digest. It contains two types of proteins, edestin and albumin, which are known as globular proteins. Globular proteins dissolve easily so they are readily accessible for the body to use. This is in contrast to soy protein, for example, which can be more difficult for the body to digest. Soy contains inhibitors that block the action of trypsin and other enzymes that are needed to break down protein. This can often result in unwanted bloating and gas.A fascinating back story on hemp is that George Washington grew it at Mount Vernon, although not for food.Robert C. RossOctober 2015Addendum: "I am very glad to hear that the Gardener has saved so much of the St. foin seed, and that of the India Hemp. Make the most you can of both, by sowing them again in drills. . . Let the ground be well prepared, and the Seed (St. loin) be sown in April. The Hemp may be sown any where. " George Washington to William Pearce, 24 February 1794.Throughout his lifetime, George Washington cultivated hemp at Mount Vernon for industrial uses.  The fibers from hemp held excellent properties for the making of rope and sail canvas, which was a major need in the age of the sailing ship.  In addition, hemp fibers could be spun into thread for clothing or, as indicated in Mount Vernon records, for use in repairing the large seine fishing nets that Washington used in his fishing operation along the Potomac.At one point in the 1760’s Washington considered whether hemp would be a more lucrative cash crop than tobacco but determined that wheat would be a better alternative. During the period when he was considering hemp, he wrote to his agents in England in the hope of determining the costs involved in production and shipping.

Both my late wife and the new lady in my life were and are firm believers in the power of cranberries, and it was real pleasure that I was able to pick this excellent version from Vine from a very reputable supplier.One caution: Memorial Sloan Kettering maintains an up-to-date website on herbs and their usefulness in cancer prevention and other uses. It is well researched and a superb source of information for all supplements that it covers. Here is what it says about cranberry products like this one:"Cranberry juice or extracts have not been shown to treat or prevent cancer. It may be helpful for urinary tract infections (UTIs) in limited populations, but there is not enough evidence to recommend it for UTI prevention."Cranberries contain compounds known as proanthocyanidins that have been shown to prevent bacteria from attaching to the bladder wall, which could cause UTIs. Human studies suggest it may be helpful for this purpose in some limited populations, including prostate cancer patients, but overall evidence is conflicting. Cranberry may also prevent bacteria from attaching to the stomach lining and areas in the mouth. Although lab studies suggest activity with several types of cancer cells, this has yet to be confirmed in human studies."In patients who are prone to kidney stones, regular use of cranberry should be limited as it contains oxalates, a compound found in the most common form of kidney stones."As a husband caring for my late wife, there was nothing more terrifying than the risk -- and during one very difficult period -- the reality of UTI. This product may be a placebo, but it brings peace of mind to both patient and caregiver and that is a very good thing.Robert C. Ross

A very high quality of an iconic moment in American history.Following is a fascinating back story about the picture from the wonderful blog "Now I Know".Robert C. RossOctober 2015The image above, often referred to "V-J Day in Times Square" or simply "The Kiss," is iconic. The photo was taken in New York City on August 14, 1945, shortly after President Harry S. Truman announced that the United States has prevailed over Japan in World War II. The photographer, Alfred Eisenstaedt, was on the staff of Life Magazine at the time, and the photo was first published in that magazine in a section of photos chronicling victory celebrations. The image became famous quickly, but the people depicted did not share in that fame. Eisenstaedt was taking picture after picture on the 14th and didn't stop to ask any of his subjects who they were, and as one can see, neither the man's or woman's face is clearly visible in the image. But eventually, the identity of the man who is likely shown in The Kiss came to light. Unfortunately, it turned out the kiss wasn't romantic. It was, by contemporary terms, probably assault. The guy most likely to be the sailor is a man named George Mendonsa. According to a profile in the New York Post from 2015, Mendonsa was on date that afternoon -- a first date -- with a young lady named Rita Petry. The two attended a movie together at nearby Radio City Music Hall. Before the film ended, though, news spread throughout the city and the theater alike that the Japanese were surrendering. Manhattan (and for that matter much of America) turned into an impromptu party. People took to the streets, cheering, with alcohol flowing in celebration. Mendonsa told the Post that he himself had "quite a few drinks" before the pair made their way to Times Square. The Post explains what happened next:As they crossed Seventh Avenue at 44th Street, George caught sight of a woman in a nurse’s uniform: “What I remembered about the nurses from five months earlier . . .”Actually, George has it wrong. It had been three months before, out in the Pacific, aboard the USS The Sullivans. He’d watched on the morning of May 11 as two Japanese kamikaze planes, one after the other, smashed into the nearby USS Bunker Hill, setting off a series of explosions and killing 346 sailors (43 bodies were never recovered). George helped pull hundreds of men, some horribly burned, out of the water, and watched with awe as nurses went to work on them. So on this joyous and unbelievable afternoon, George ran from Rita — the most beautiful girl he’d ever seen — grabbed the first nurse he saw, spun her around, dipped her and kissed her.The two had never met before they locked lips -- which means that he didn't have the nurse's permission to give her the now-famous kiss. We can't be sure how the nurse reacted, though, because her identity is unclear. There are a few theories as to who she is -- the Post and CNN share a few of them -- but there simply isn't a lot of evidence to support any one woman's claim. But we're pretty sure that it's Mendonsa in the sailor's uniform. The best piece of evidence? In another photo of the kiss, Rita Petry is standing in the background, clearly identifiable and smiling at her date as he dips and kisses a complete stranger. And Rita has kept in contact with George since V-J Day -- the two ended up getting married, and should be celebrating their 70th anniversary this month.Bonus Fact: The identities of the kissing "couple" isn't the only mystery of The Kiss. Because Eisenstaedt took so many photos that day, he wasn't sure what time the photo was taken. A physics professor named Donald Olson cracked that one, though, using shadows and other clues to figure out that the image was taken at 5:51 P.M. that day. Olson, as Wired explains, has made similar investigations into a bit of a hobby: "he’s figured out what time it was when Van Gogh painted Moonrise (9:08 p.m.), identified what inspired Walt Whitman’s “Year of Meteors” (an Earth-grazing meteor procession), and determined just when Ansel Adams shot Autumn Moon, The High Sierra From Glacier Point (7:03 p.m. on September 15, 1948)."

What a great multi-purpose scale!It's billed for food deliveries, and works very well for that; the folks at Market Basket here in Franklin Lakes were nice enough to let me test it on their incoming fresh produce, and my readings were within 1% of theirs in over 20 samples ranging from apples, to melons, to lettuce. And, of course, I was just curious; their scales are regularly calibrated to be sure they are not over-paying.It is very portable, and we used it at the Headquarters of the Trail Conference in Mahwah as a quick and dirty way to check the accuracy of incoming books and our "Trail Walker" newspaper -- much easier than counting. :)As long as I stay under 250 pounds, works great as a personal scale.Excellent quality, and I love the lock-in feature when the display is hidden by the boxes.Robert C. RossOctober 2015

Danny Lyon was granted extraordinary access over 14 months interacting with prisoners in six Texas prisons in the late 1960s ago.His interactions with prisoners were sometimes fierce, sometimes quite calm, always interesting. His photographs capture incredible insights into prison life, some of the most remarkable photographs I've ever seen in a lifetime of going to photography exhibitions all over the world.He recently described his collection in these words: “I’ve tried with whatever power I had to make this picture of imprisonment as distressing as it is in reality. The few times I doubted the wisdom of my attitude, I had only to visit someone in his cell to straighten out my mind. And the material collected here doesn’t approach for a moment the feeling you get standing for two minutes in the corridor of Ellis.”The book, a guide to an exhibit at Rice, is well made on good stock, and is well worth perusing if you love photography, or want to learn more about prison life, a modern form of slavery for many Americans.Phaidon has published an excellent facsimile of this powerful, disturbing book, released this month: Conversations with the Dead. You may find it too powerful to own but you should seriously consider finding a copy to browse through.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015You can see an exceptional collection online at magnumphotos.com.

There was The Catcher in the Rye, a classic coming of age story for young Americans in New York City and the East Coast.Red Sky at Morning: A Novel (Perennial Classics) is an equally compelling coming of age story for a young American from the South moving to the incredibly complex of world of New Mexico.Josh Arnold and 18 other major characters are beautifully drawn, and Josh's journey from childhood to adulthood is a superb description of how a young person becomes a man by having the responsibility of becoming the head of the household thrust upon him by World War II.My wife loved New Mexico -- we had a second home there and travelled back and forth many times during the last ten years of her life -- and so much of this book rang completely true for me.It's rare to find a book where characters and setting are so beautifully interwoven. Bradford accomplishes some, but not all of that in his So Far From Heaven -- a tale of an adult finding himself in the wonders of New Mexico. "Red Sky" is a significantly stronger novel, but together they make perfect companion pieces to describe some of the wonders of New Mexico, by an author who clearly knows and loves that fantastic place.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

New York Society LibraryWhat a marvelous book.The Dioramas have very specific and often fascinating histories of their own, and this wonderful book describes not only the contents but the incredible ways they were assembled and built. Details abound. How did the artists blend the foreground -- often dirt and stones from the original site -- seamlessly into the painted background? How did they arrange the lighting so that the shadows are natural but the animals and plants are beautifully lit?A year ago, I attended a lecture by Ross D. E. MacPhee, a curator in the Mammalogy Department and supervising curator of the restoration of the Hall of North American Mammals. It was absolutely amazing the incredible detail that he and his team of employees and volunteers employ in restoring the exhibits. The bison never looked more beautiful!This book is a perfect companion to at least two other fabulous books about the Museum and its collections:Dinosaurs in the Attic: An Excursion into the American Museum of Natural History -- two main sections: collecting expeditions, including adventures in creating the  28 extraordinary dioramas in the Akeley Hall of African Mammals, recreated from paintings, photographs, data, and specimens collected in the field by the explorer and taxidermist Carl Akeley, his wife and his team on expeditions in the 1920s; anda second set of journeys through specific areas of the museum, all beautifully reported by Douglas J. Preston.American Museum of Natural History: 125 Years of Expedition and Discovery -- a coffee table version of the various expeditions assembling the vast collections in the museum, with more photographs and many additional details.Wonderful reading and exploring.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

This calendar will find significant use at the new headquarters of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference in Mahwah, New Jersey.We unrolled it -- it lays very flat -- and tried it out for several minutes with four of us adding and changing hypothetical dates for meetings, etc. Very easy to clean and no confusion with new entries.One question: why key this to a specific year? Since it can be erased, it would work well for any year -- the laminate appears a bit thin and perhaps the manufacturer's experience is that it will wear out in one year?In any event, it will become a useful tool for many of us at the Headquarters.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

I found this thermometer to be very easy to use for a 78 year old codger, and it was very accurate when checked against the thermometer in my urologist office during my regular six month visit yesterday.I found the following information from the Mayo Clinic very helpful.Regular digital thermometers use electronic heat sensors to record body temperature. These thermometers can be used in the rectum, mouth or armpit. Armpit temperatures are usually the least accurate. Rectal temperatures provide the best readings for infants, especially those 3 months or younger, as well as children up to age 3. For older children and adults, oral readings are usually accurate — as long as the mouth is closed while the thermometer is in place.If you plan to use a digital thermometer to take both oral and rectal temperatures, you'll need to get two digital thermometers and label one for oral use and one for rectal use. Don't use the same thermometer in both places. [I like this one so much that I have ordered a second and will mark them for oral or rectal use, as Mayo suggests.]The pros:•Most digital thermometers can record temperatures from the mouth, armpit or rectum — often in a minute or less.•A digital thermometer is appropriate for newborns, infants, children and adults.The cons:•Parents may worry about causing discomfort when taking a child's temperature rectally.•You need to wait 15 minutes after eating or drinking to take an oral temperature. Otherwise, the temperature of your food or drink might affect the thermometer reading.•It can be difficult for children — or anyone who breathes through the mouth — to keep their mouths closed long enough to get an accurate oral reading.Thankfully, my kid temperature taking days are long past, so I include that information for those still in the trenches. For me, two of these will do admirably.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015Note: Review copy provided free by Amazon seller.

Lett's has made excellent calendars for many years, a type that my companion has used for the past six years. It was a great pleasure to buy this one for her for next year -- I plan to continue to do so for many more years.She likes this particular style because "with you in my life, there is so much to do, I need a week at a time on display."She used to use a black week/month at a glance type by another maker -- I use the Month at a Glance type -- but she finds that style "not elegant." As a Parisian, valid criticism, and high praise for this alternative.This series is elegant, the covers are beautiful, the pages well attached and sturdy, and the surface smooth and accepting of many different inks. One caution: the diary looks more blue on Amazon than the actual purple on the real thing. It looks richer in real life, the way the royalty of English diaries should.This product made me feel really good -- a double whammy from a gift that gave to both giver and receiver.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

I have never used knee supports before, but these wonderful sleeves have made me a believer. They make an excellent supplement to the bone on bone arthritis course of therapy I have been following. My story follows; the glucosamine continues to help manage my pain, but the strong support avoids or at least lessens the pain of my hiking --  about 50 miles a week these days.Wonderfully easy to pull on or off, even when I am sweaty, easy to rinse out and dry over night, time to buy another pair for backup -- don't ever want to be with them.Review based on a pair supplied by the Amazon seller in exchange for this Review -- thank you.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015This is a copy of my review for Viva Labs TRIPLE STRENGTH Glucosamine, Chondroitin and MSM, GUARANTEED Joint Agony Relief, 240 Capsules:A few days after my wife died, both of my knees started to ache with varying amounts of pain, from 4 to 8 or 9 on my personal 1 to 10 pain scale. Nothing seemed to help, and my GP suggested seeing a doctor at the NYU Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan.We chose Dr. Halpern, author of The Knee Crisis Handbook: Understanding Pain, Preventing Trauma, Recovering from Knee Injury, and Building Healthy Knees for Life, and a very experienced knee expert (among other things, he was team doctor for the Jets for a number of years). Dr. Halpern diagnosed advanced arthritis, and he suggested I try Glucosamine. He said that my case was fairly well advanced -- he couldn't explain why the pain was presenting so late in the disease's progression -- and that some patients had good results from Glucosamine. In any event, side effects were minimal and alternatives were much more "heroic". (And, also, perhaps unavailing as I learned while representing a major company that made artificial hips and knees.)I did a bit of research and learned that reports of effectiveness range from 10% to 70%, depending on the population being surveyed; "Consumer Union" has historically been on the low end of that range, although more recently "CU's medical and nutritional consultants have identified and tested a few products ... with possible benefits and sufficiently low risks to recommend for general use, including: saw palmetto for benign enlarged prostate in men, glucosamine and chondroitin for arthritis, and fish-oil capsules (omega-3 fatty acids) for heart disease."Glucosamine is often sold in combination with other supplements such as chondroitin sulfate and methylsulfonylmethane. Of the three commonly available forms of glucosamine, only glucosamine sulfate is given a "likely effective" rating for treating osteoarthritis.In my case, I started taking three of these tablets a day, and the pain subsided only three days later. Today, ten months later, it is rarely more than a 1 or 2 on my pain scale, and when it kicks up I take one to three more tablets. They actually taste good, and work very well.My brother-in-law has had a similar problem for the past five years, and his pain is also controlled by this product. Based on the reports of others, it may not help everyone, but it sure helped both of us.I've tried a number of different brands, all of which provided the same relief. The bottle, sent to me free for review purposes, has worked great for me for over a week and a half. Moreover, I have had very positive experiences with several of Viva's products and have also relied on their literature and enjoyed interesting discussion with their customer service people.

Work great at our headquarters of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference with both staff and volunteers -- easy to teach and flawless in operation.Stop by during business hours and see our beautifully restored headquarters and volunteer to try out the labels. :)Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

Work great at our headquarters of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference with both staff and volunteers -- easy to teach and flawless in operation.Stop by during business hours and see our beautifully restored headquarters and volunteer to try out the labels. :)Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

Lloyd Ultan obviously loves the Bronx and his knowledge of this mainland part of New York City is encyclopedic and easily accessible.This book is available in hard cover so it is primarily useful in the library if you are a walker like myself. But, it is superb at describing possible excursions and destinations.I carry the iBook version of Ultan's The Bronx: The Ultimate Guide to New York City's Beautiful Borough (Rivergate Regionals Collection) on my iPhone for walking purposes.I also carry the excellent The Encyclopedia of New York City: Second Edition on my iPhone to double check details, or to fill in additional information.A triple threat, a triple triumph -- Well Done, Mr. Ultan.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

This waist support had a harsh chemical scent when it first arrived, but I put it in my dryer for an hour on the coolest setting and delicate fabric setting -- the scent was all gone, except for a bit when I am really huffing and puffing up Tall Mountain near Franklin Lakes, for example.It works very well under my L.L.Bean Day Trekker 25 Pack With Boa Gray Medium / Large, where it adds some comfort -- I like wearing my pack very high, and this belt helps to bring the weight down to my hips, off my back and onto my legs.Be sure you check the actual length -- I didn't measure but my waist is 40 inches and I doubt it would be secure at 44 inches.68 miles over some difficult terrain -- a useful addition to my hiking arsenal.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015Free review sample provided by the Amazon seller.

What a marvelous machine.I'm a 78 year old codger, moving to smaller digs, who  has been using a wonderful machine from Jura, current equivalent model Jura 15006 Impressa C60 Automatic Coffee Center -- it was able to keep up with demand from over 50 guests at several different events, ground its own beans on demand, but seems too big for any of the kitchens in the apartments I'm seriously considering.Then, Vine came up with this excellent machine. Capsules seem to run about $.80 per cup, and I am sure there are cleaning chemicals that will have to be used in the future. But the size and the quality of the brew are both excellent for my use, and my apartment of the future certainly won't be big enough for 50 people.Down sizing, sure, but my quality of life will continue at a high rate of satisfaction.The capsules called for are the Nespresso Variety Pack Capsules, 50 Count; the pack I bought worked great, almost as well as the fresh ground from the Jura. There may be other capsules that will work as well or better, but time will tell. Everything looks great at get go.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

My companion is an explainer at the American Museum of Natural History, and is now embarking on becoming a French language guide to help French speakers enjoy this fantastic museum.Two of the books that are required reading for guides -- not so for explainers who tend to be assigned to special exhibits or to a single hall -- are the Rexer tome and Dinosaurs in the Attic: An Excursion into the American Museum of Natural History by Douglas J. Preston.Preston's book is beautifully written, a bit better than Rexer's, but the photographs are grainy and almost useless, except to add a bit of interest.The photographs and other illustrations in the Rexer are superb, and the book can be greatly enjoyed by simply looking at the pictures and reading the captions.If you have any interest in museums in general, or this one in particular, read either or both -- you will enjoy the excursions, either in the library or before or after actually going there on tour.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

Who knew?I've walked thousands of miles in New York City over the past 40 years -- the Bronx was only Yankee Stadium (both of them), the Zoo, the Botanic Garden, an Irish football stadium, Arthur Avenue for Italian cuisine, City Island, the Harlem River, the High Bridge, the Croton Aqueduct and Woodlawn Cemetery. Treasures all of course.But under Lloyd Ultan's superb guidance, just the tip of a wonderful world of wonders -- 25% of the Bronx is parkland, and there are miles and miles to walk before I truly have even a superficial understanding of this under-appreciated part of New York City.Based on another Review, here, I immediately bought a copy of The Beautiful Bronx 1920-1950,j and spent ten hours reading and making bucket lists of places to visit. Here is an author who not only loves his subject, but who has a superb ability to write about his subject well and with great passion and accuracy.The iBook works well enough on my iPhone for walking purposes, and I also carry the excellent The Encyclopedia of New York City: Second Edition on my iPhone to double check details, or to fill in additional information.A triumph, actually three triumphs, for anyone who loves New York City and each of its boroughs.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

As a lover of New York City and a hiker who has walked several thousand miles over the years through its streets and byways, I have found that the best guide books have both great information and a personal point of view. In a few rare cases, an excellent guide is spoiled a bit by the intrusion of too much of the author's point of view; the excellent writer Pete Hamill weakens his otherwise superb guide/memoir in that way: Downtown: My Manhattan.Robin Lynn has triumphantly found the perfect balance for this reader. Her guide is filled with interesting, well researched information, some of it totally new to me, while maintaining a well expressed point of view, consistent throughout the book. She does it so well that I started to dip and sample, and then went back and read the entire book cover to cover.I can carry it on my iPhone as well, so that as I perambulate, I can dip into the relevant section after exploring what's on the ground and forming my own opinion. Sometimes we agree, rarely we disagree, sometimes I have to go back two or even three times to really understand what she is telling me -- my failure to read carefully almost invariably.I also carry the superb The Encyclopedia of New York City: Second Edition on my iPhone, and often check facts against Lynn against Ross -- a deeply satisfying experience that makes the miles melt away in a sort of urban wonder.Robin Lynn is a wonderful guide to the landscapes of this great city.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

I accepted this review sample device out of curiosity rather than any real medical need, and found to my delight that my readings are all in the normal range -- "all" being 50 readings over a month of use.The instructions are terribly confusing and poorly written -- I went to Wikipedia and found a better description of how to use the device.One thing I cannot figure out -- does the device read correctly for people wearing fingernail polish?As a male codger, I don't often wear nail polish -- rarely a clear type for fancy dinners -- but I asked a manicurist to apply some red polish to one nail -- the before and after readings were somewhat different. So, if you wear nail polish, check readings from more expensive machines to be sure you are getting the real news from the oxygen front.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

We recently took a wonderful tour of the Hard Hat section of Ellis Island, and our tour guide through this abandoned hospital, once on a par with Columbia Presbyterian and Memorial Sloan Kettering, was wonderfully knowledgeable about lower Manhattan. He said that he found Hamill book essential for anyone wanting a very readable, fact filled, and exciting history of that part of Manhattan Island.I bought a copy as soon as I got home, it arrived in 24 hours, and I devoured it in about three hours. Wonderful stuff -- excellent writing and very reliable -- I checked it against the superb The Encyclopedia of New York City: Second Edition about 20 times. Incidentally, that encyclopedia comes in an ibook and I often check for more information when hiking around NYC or when reading a hard copy book like Hamill's -- an essential companion while exploring this fantastic city.I've taken off one star, a bit reluctantly, but I found Hamill's personal stories distracting. I think a more careful editor might have move those personal sections into either a Forward or preferably an Afterword, and referenced Hamill's experience with footnotes in the main text.Nevertheless, this is superb history, very well told, and highly reliable.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

We recently took the grand tour of the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and the recently opened Hard Hat tour of the abandoned hospital on the southern, New Jersey sitde of Ellis Island.We had an absolutely splendid volunteer guide whose father had passed through Ellis Island when he was 18, and Doug gives the tours in memory of his father. He said that all of the volunteer and paid guides on Ellis Island consider this book required reading, and re-reading -- it is perhaps heavy on officials and a little light on individual histories. But that history is essential to understand how so many people were processed so quickly.On statistic: over 98% of the immigrants passed through to either New York or New Jersey; the great majority who were detained and sometimes returned to Europe were denied entry for health reasons. An average of seven seconds per immigrant, but they "cheated". After the baggage hall, and immigrants rarely gave up their worldly possessions for a slip of paper and a promise, the immigrants had to climb three flights of stairs.Doctors closely watched the flow and marked people who were laboring with chalk on their coats -- "TB", "PG", etc. The marked people were then examined more closely. And, if an immigrant was returned to Europe, the steamship company was forced to pay for the return journey -- so there was careful screening by the shippers in Europe before the ships sailed.An essential book for anyone planning a visit or for anyone to read after their return from this fascinating place so crucial to American history.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

After four months, I am happy to report that these batteries have provided excellent service.They charge in about four hours as promised in the literature  and have worked for as long as eight hours straight while I was struggling with some leaky pipes one dark and stormy night.Go to for me in  the future.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015Review samples provided by the Amazon seller.

I'm not really sure how to review dog food received from Vine, given the requirement to review within 30 days. I plan to check back in every week while my loaner dog eats this four pound sample.Today, I mixed it half and half, and he scarfed it down in his usual 25 second thoughtful way. So far so good.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

Great little knife for handing out to others on the hiking trails. I promote the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference while out hiking and give maps, literature and these little knives out to folks who look like likely members.Works about 25% of the time!Great for cutting open envelopes, tape, twine, samples of twigs and other precious things on the trail. Even punctured a blister after sterilizing the blade with a match. Healed beautifully.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

I have taken three one-week courses at the Culinary Institute of America on the Hudson River: Boot Camp, Appetizers, and Italian food -- all excellent and all of which made for significant improvements in my cooking.Each instructor gave us a 15 minute lecture on the importance of checking temperatures, and each had two thermometers aboard, just in case.They also used them many times a day, during demonstrations and when auditing our efforts -- proof that we should do as they said and as they did.They also taught us how to test our thermometers and suggested we should do so on a regular basis. Before testing, though, read this important note from a Commentator on my Review (many thanks):When calibrating using the boiling point method they should have told you that you need to take your altitude into account. This is because the boiling point of water is going to change dependent upon your altitude.For example, here near Denver, CO you would not be able to get the water to 212 because water boils here at 203º so any additional energy dumped into the water after that goes into evaporation. (That's why it takes longer to cook pasta up here) So if we calibrate using the boiling point method, we have to calibrate to 203º.Freezing method doesn't have this constraint as the freezing point stays the same regardless of altitude.The CIA technique:1. Ice Water MethodMaterials needed: one large glass, crushed ice and clean waterAfter filling a large glass with finely crushed ice, pour clean tap water on top of the ice and stir well. Dip the food thermometer stem two inches into the glass of ice water without touching the bottom or the sides of the glass. Wait 30 seconds to see if the thermometer reads 32 degrees Fahrenheit.2. Boiling Water MethodMaterials needed: one deep pot and water In a deep pot, bring water to a rolling boil. Dip the thermometer stem two inches into the boiling water without touching the bottom. Wait for 30 seconds and the thermometer should read 212º F.***This Thermometer passed the initial test with flying colors.Our instructors told us that the actual mechanism doesn't matter much -- this is a digital thermometer -- the crucial thing is that it easy to use and is accurate -- and accuracy is the most important.Nevertheless, this thermometer has several other bells and whistles that will make cooking even more fun. I've tested a couple and will revert in a month with more experience under my belt.I'll check for accuracy in a couple of months, but for now, this is a fine kitchen assistant. :)Robert C. RossSeptember 2015Note: free review sample furnished for an Amazon review by the manufacturer/distributor

Several people have complained about these Goji berries being too dry and tough.I sort of like this version, especially when hiking, when sucking on a berry or two -- they break my hunger pangs very quickly.But, for day to day eating, I soak them over night with my oat groats, and they plump up just as good as those that are more moist -- example my personal favorite supplier is Viva who sells Viva Labs #1 Premium Himalayan Organic Goji Berries, Noticeably Larger and Juicier.In a taste test, neither my companion nor I -- both fairly sophisticated foodies and food tasters -- could tell the difference.The only gnawing issue: goji berries are apparently being grown now in the US and in Canada. There have been some reports that the Chinese are using some chemicals to aid in growing their exported berries. But, I haven't found them from the US or Canada, either on Amazon or elsewhere.So, dry for hiking and these are fine. Soak them over night in cold water, and they are fine as well.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015Review 8 ounce sample provided by the Amazon seller for this Review.Addendum: I like to add these to a smoothie to add a bit of sweetness.Here's a basic recipe that I like playing with. If a guest doesn't like the taste of kale, this works great:Serves 1Ingredients 3/4 cup chopped kale, ribs and thick stems removed 1 small stalk celery, chopped 1/2 banana 1/2 cup apple juice or one small apple 1/2 cup ice 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juiceAdd Goji berries to taste, about quarter of a cupDirections1.Place the kale, celery, banana, apple juice, ice, and lemon juice in a blender.2.Blend until smooth and frothy.Leave out the banana and apple if you like the taste of kale as I do; substitute oat milk for water for better heart health.Let your imagination be your guide; you can't really go wrong. :)And, maybe you should move from a glass and straw to a bowl; the Cleveland Clinic makes the case:The authoritative Cleveland Clinic has some good advice:For on-the go meals, smoothies have been an option for years. From the franchises you see around town to the make-at-home versions you’ve tried in your own blender, these thick drinks — when made properly and enjoyed in appropriate portions — provide a healthy meal alternative.But lately the trend is shifting from portable glasses to hearty bowls — and from grab and go to sit and enjoy. The “smoothie bowls” you’ve seen on Instagram or Pinterest take basic components of a smoothie, add less liquid and more thickening ingredients, and are topped with nutrient-dense, fiber-filled superfoods. Swap the straw for a spoon, and you’ve got a hearty dish.“You end up with a combination of protein and fiber that leaves you feeling full without an intense spike in blood sugar.”Why choose a bowl?For one thing, making a smoothie bowl instead of an on-the-go drink encourages you to slow down and practice mindful eating.But perhaps more important, the bowl promotes variety in the form of toppings such as nuts, seeds and fruit. You end up with a combination of protein and fiber that leaves you feeling full without an intense spike in blood sugar.One note of caution: The toppings you’ll see below are nutritional powerhouses such as nuts, seeds and grains. Those are ingredients you need, but an accidental over pour can leave you with more calories than you want. To prevent over-packing your bowl, use recipes and measuring spoons to limit your toppings and know just how much is going in your body.Where to startIf you’ve made a smoothie, the basics below will look familiar.The biggest difference is that for a bowl, you’ll increase the amount of thickeners and decrease the amount of liquids. Start by following recipes such as the ones listed below. If you’re adventurous, you can tinker with recipes to get just the right texture for you. In addition, rather than blending in nuts, seeds or other items for added nutrition, you’ll add them on top of the blended base and proteins — and enjoy their crunch with a spoon rather than through a straw.Recipes will vary, but here’s a basic guide to bowls:The Base•Liquid: Unsweetened milk of your choice (almond, cow’s, rice, soy, coconut, [for me, oat milk])•Thickener: Plain, unsweetened yogurt (Greek is a great, high-protein option) or avocado•Sweeteners: Fruit (frozen provides a thicker texture, typically ¼ to ½ cup), dried medjool dates, pumpkin puree•Fiber: Veggies such as spinach, kale and carrots, or psyllium husks•Ice: Optional, based on how you like your textureProtein•Powder: Choose an option with no added sugar, such as spirulina powder or pea protein•Nut butters: Unsweetened peanut butter, almond butter, sun butter, etc. (2 tablespoons is a good rule of thumb)Toppings•Seeds: Chia, ground flax, pumpkin seeds, hemp hearts, pomegranate seeds•Nuts: Walnuts, almonds, hazelnuts•Grains: Granola, quinoa puffs, soaked oats, muesli•Flavors: Cinnamon, ginger, cocoa nibs•Texture: Unsweetened coconut flakes, raisins, goji berriesYou can experiment with turning your favorite smoothie recipes into bowls, but here are two recipes to get you started.•The Go Green Smoothie Bowl: This tasty bowl includes mango, banana and spinach as part of the base, plus superfood toppings such as hemp seeds and goji berries.•The Berry Bowl: Berries of your choice help form the base of this recipe, with a helping of chia and pomegranate seeds on top.health.clevelandclinic.org/2015/04/how-to-turn-a-smoothie-into-a-hearty-healthy-bowl/Robert C. Ross

My companion:"Easy to wear. Adaptable to any background. Creative design with interesting contrasts. That's it. Thank you."If she is happy, I am happy.I was very impressed with the way the little V hangs inside the bigger V.Addendum: another Reviewer has suggested that I add a note about my background in assessing jewelry. When my late wife and I were first married we were in debt and every penny counted. She loved small, hand crafted objects, and we went to 30 to 40 auction houses every year for the pre-viewings, where potential bidders are encouraged to handle the objects. We learned about many different types of art but in the world of jewelry, I am sure that I have handled over $500 million worth of jewels and jewelry, not only at the auction houses but at fine jewelers around the world. Always, I had a loupe on hand, used for postage stamps which I collect and other small objects like netsuke and jewelry. My current favorite is a Ade Advanced Optics Premium Lighted 10x21 Triplet Lens Color Jeweler's Loupe with Leather Case. My impressions of this jewelry is based on an examination under that glass and the expertize I have built up over the years.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015Sample provided for this review on Amazon by the Amazon seller.

I was very pleased with the doorbell -- it was dead easy to install and it has worked beautifully for the past three weeks. It looks very modern and covers the hole where the old door bell -- hard wired -- button and holder used to sit.[This review reminds me of my friend Teodoro and me installing a new door bell and button on a rental building in Ridgewood New Jersey several years ago. It was also "wireless", but it was on the same frequency as a house five doors down the street. When we tested our doorbell, it worked perfectly in my house -- but also at the house down the street. :)Of course we had to replace it -- after all, folks calling on the people down the street would ring our tenant's bell as wellRobert C. RossSeptember 2015

Works great here. I use it to transfer photos from my iPhone 6 to my computer and to charge my iPhone from my computer.Flawless performance over the past two days, and I love the four inch length. I'm too cheap to have my own WIFI so I go to Starbucks and set up on one of the round, taller tables, where I can practice standing on one leg to improve stability.The phone is much safer now that the cord is so short -- neither passerbys -- nor this sometimes clumsy codger, can get entangled in it.Thanks, Vine -- you made my life better.Robert C. RossSeptember 2015

From the first lines to colorized drawing, this is a great tutorial book. You will find help with the sketch and the colors. Both beginners and intermediate Manga artists will benefit from this wide ranging book.

This is the biggest and heaviest shredder I've ever had. This is designed for office volume shredding, not occasional home use.I have a Fellowes cross cut shredder that I love. I like the confetti size shreds. This Sentinel makes larger strips but it is still far more secure than the full length strips that come out of standard shredders.I like being able to leave it “on” all the time and the height advantage over the Fellowes so I don’t have to bend over as much. Since it will shred more pages at once, I can either feed more pages or not remove staples. Also I like my credit cards to be cross cut rather than just sliced in thirds like another shredder does.If your office has several employees who need to shred documents, the FX1800P should definitely be considered.

This was the TV version of X-Men. As a group, they had to use their individual abilities to solve situations and learn to work together. The stories were varied and kept my interest. I got disgusted with the government idiots but that reflects the reality we live in.

Or was it really a crime? The story is captivating, the acting is superb, and the result is a movie I watch over and over again.There are multiple messages in the story. Corruptible people either continue to manipulate (Jody Foster) or try to make amends while covering up (Christopher Plummer). Paranoid people (the policemen) are more dangerous than criminals sometimes. When people are ordered to do something, some will alwaysdo the opposite (some of the hostages).The multiple twists keep you guessing as to how it will all work out. That’s a major part of the fun watching the movie. You have to see it several times to pick up all the clues of what is really going on.

They fit my hands perfectly but they were a slight struggle to get on. They were so tight that it trapped air in my palm. The texture on the fingers really grips anything you pick up. I would compare these with Playtex gloves.I have been using latex medical gloves for house cleaning using cleaners, craft projects, and yard spraying. But I would usually get a break through around one or more fingernails before I was done. These gloves were strong enough to protect my hands all the way to the end.

Years ago I used to do a lot of work that required using gloves. At first I used Latex but then moved to vinyl out of fear of getting a latex allergy. I don’t like that vinyl gloves don’t stretch, but they get the job done.These gloves are advertised to be anti-microbial which interested me, so I decided to give this brand of vinyl gloves a try.They are a perfect fit for my hands, but they did break with my thumbnail test (I applied a little pressure and my thumb broke through). The non-vinyl gloves seemed to far better with my thumbnail test so I think I will use these up and then revert to the Nitrile gloves that I have been using lately.

For years I used latex gloves when I worked. They got the job done, but I didn’t like how easily they tore when I put them on, plus I was afraid of getting a latex allergy with constant use. So I moved to vinyl gloves. They too worked fine, but there wasn’t much stretch to them. I recently came across Nitrile gloves, so I decided to give them a try.I have long fingernails, so I did a test of pulling at the wrist with my thumb. I am please to say it didn’t rip.Evaluation:I like the feel and elasticity of these gloves, they feel a little thicker than my old latex gloves, I like that they are powder-free - when I took off my old latex gloves, my hands were covered in powder that needed to be washed off. But not with these gloves. I like that! I tried

I guess I missed it in the product description, so it surprised me that this was built out of wood (I was expecting the traditional plastic toy). The edges have been beveled so there are no sharp edges and there is a nice hand-grip for the kids to use to move it from room to room. This is a nice toy that kids can use their imaginations with (versus all of the powered toys that kids just sit back and watch “do their thing”).Kids watch mom and pop fill-up and wash the family car all the time. Now they can pretend that they are doing the same thing too. It’s lots of fun for them.

For years I used latex gloves when I worked. They got the job done, but I didn’t like how easily they tore when I put them on, plus I was afraid of getting a latex allergy with constant use. So I moved to vinyl gloves. They too worked fine, but there wasn’t much stretch to them. I recently came across Nitrile gloves, so I decided to give them a try.I was surprised that the Nitrile material has some stretch to them - this is a plus in my mind. Both small and medium sizes worked OK on my hands, though I did have a little more play-room in the medium sizes.I have long fingernails, so I did a test of pulling at the wrist with my thumb. I am please to say it didn’t rip.Evaluation:I like the feel and elasticity of these gloves, they feel a little thicker than my old latex gloves, plus I like the texturing at the ends of the fingertips - this helps prevent slippage when the gloves are wet. I like that they are powder-free - when I took off my old latex gloves, my hands were covered in powder that needed to be washed off. But not with these gloves. I like that!

I've used Wingtips as dress shoes for more than 20 years. I still haven't worn them out. I'll compare this new pair with my old pair of brown (I also have black ones).The old have at least twice the leather thickness and it is very stiff. The new ones are very flexible. The interior bottom is hard while the new ones are soft. The old ones have shorter but more gripping laces. The new ones come undone easily and are longer. The old style is much more elegant with bumpy instead of smooth sides and more defined small circles. The color of the new ones is one tone which is less eye catching then the multi-tone old style (of course this doesn't apply to the black wingtips).Conclusion: If you are wearing the new style for all day, your feet are not going to get tired and sore. If you usually buy a half size larger because you wear thick socks, you'll probably find this style better than the old ones. The new ones have slight stretchability but not the old style.

It tastes like Kool-Aid with some melted ice but not as sweet. Its not a distinct flavor although you would definitely say that it is fruity. I would put it in the category of a Gatorade- wet, and thirst quenching after physical activity.
