I like clothes that stretch and was pleased that there was some stretch to the material of this blouse. It fit perfectly and the buttons unbuttoned easily. I am glad that I got this blouse.

I loved Physics in High School. If you don’t use it, you lose it. The book is a reminder of how much I’ve forgotten the details or formulas even though I’ve used virtually all the various concepts of Physics as an adult.The book defines the terms as you begin each chapter. It talks you through the concept and then explains how the formula is derived at. Practical tests to see if you understand what you’ve just read are followed by how the correct answer was arrived at. I wonder why this approach isn’t used in more public schools.

For years I used latex gloves when I worked. They got the job done, but I didn’t like how easily they tore when I put them on, plus I was afraid of getting a latex allergy with constant use. So I moved to vinyl gloves. They too worked fine, but there wasn’t much stretch to them. I recently came across Nitrile gloves, so I decided to give them a try.To be a thorough test, I decided to try a variety of and brands of Nitrile gloves. Here is what I thought about the Nitrile material and this glove in particular:I was surprised that the Nitrile material has some stretch to them - this is a plus in my mind. Both small and medium sizes worked OK on my hands, though I did have a little more play-room in the medium sizes.Evaluation:I like the feel and elasticity of these gloves, they feel a little thicker than my old latex gloves, plus I like the texturing at the ends of the fingertips - this helps prevent slippage when the gloves are wet. I also like that they are powder-free - when I took off my old latex gloves, my hands were covered in powder that needed to be washed off. But not with these gloves. I like that!

UP2 by Jawbone Activity + Sleep TrackerI currently own a Basis health tracker. It does a fairly good job at tracking my sleep, steps, etc. But there are several things I don’t like about it e.g. it’s huge (like a man’s watch and band), I could get it to sync with my iPod, but not the computer, and the heart beat feature isn’t always accurate (which is probably why they discontinued it in favor of a newer model). So I decided to give the UP2 a try.The UP2 is different than the Basis in several ways - one being with the Basis, you can read the stats on the face of the tracker itself, whereas with the UP2, you need to go to your iPod etc. device to read all of the stats. Also, the Basis has a heart beat tracker but the UP2 doesn’t. On the plus side, the UP2 lets you log in what you have eaten for your meals and then gives you an estimation of your calorie count and the amount of calories you have left for the day.The UP2’s charging function is different - instead of a micro USB cable (which would be for both charging and data transmission), there is a 4” charging cable that attaches to the back of the UP2 via magnets. I have the cable permanently attached to a flat 4-port charging station and since the cable is so stiff and the magnets so strong, the cable stands vertically and the tracker remains attached (up in the air). BTW: the cable is only for charging, all tracked info is transmitted via Bluetooth connection.After a short charge that lasts a week, you must link the tracker to your iPod, Android, etc. device via Bluetooth (which is very simple to do). Afterward you are guided through the steps to set up an account on the Jawbone web site.Once you have an account, you must specify your gender, height, weight (later you can tell it your desired weight goal), and date of birth. Once everything is set up you can start wearing your tracker.If you wish, during the course of the day, you can input your Activity type, Effort level, Start time, and Duration. You can also enter your mood, though I don’t know how this effects your tracking.Every once in a while the UP2’s Coach will send you motivational advise on how to reach your goals. For example, today it advised me to eat a handful of Pistachios to boost my fiber intake. The Coach is a nice feature since it will mention things that you might not have thought about.After wearing the tracker for a day, you can go to your Bluetooth devise and see: the number of steps that you have taken, the amount of calories that you have eaten for that day, a graph showing your weight loss/gain (if you entered the new weight), the amount of time you spent sleeping (including showing sleep patterns - a bar graph that shows when you were sleeping sound or light throughout the night), and the percentages that you had currently reached in your daily goals.EvaluationI like how small the UP2 tracker is (it is about a third of the size of the Basis). I also like that the band is A LOT smaller than the Basis band. But on the negative side, I don’t like the rubber spaghetti straps e.g. the straps consist of a spaghetti sized bands (with loops at each end) that are permanently connected to the UP2. The end (of the first strap) has a small hook that you sting through the end loop of second strap and then fasten to an attached bar back on the first strap. Being rubber and very flexible, I find it a bit of a hassle to get them to stay in-place to align perfectly so I can hook them together. This isn’t a deal-breaker, just a slight irritant. For those of you that will leave the tracker on 24/7 - it shouldn’t be a problem.One more thing about the material used with the tracker - I am allergic to plastic so I was wondering if I would have a skin reaction to this band? I am please to say that I have used it for a while and I have had no itchy skin or any other allergic reaction.I like that it will track your calories. I just wish it would track your heartbeat, though in looking at the Jawbone web site I recently discovered that that feature is available with the UP3 tracker.Finally, I like that the UP2 iOS app shows the amount of days that you have left on your battery charge (I was wondering how to figure this out without a read-out on the UP2 tracker).So which health tracker will I use? I think for 99% of the time I will use the UP2 since it is much smaller and has the Coach and other nice features. I think I will reserve the Basis for any time that I need to keep track of my heart rate (hopefully never).

They fit my hands perfectly but they were a slight struggle to get on. They were so tight that it trapped air in my palm. They are thicker than medical gloves so not quite as touch sensitive but not much of a difference.I have been using latex medical gloves for house cleaning using cleaners, craft projects, and yard spraying. But I would usually get a break through around one or more fingernails before I was done. These gloves were strong enough to protect my hands all the way to the end.

My husband is jealous. He wants one in a man’s watch size. I keep sticking it in front of his face. LOLFor the last 30+ years I have used digital watches. I like how much information and things you can do with them, but they seem to be disappearing from the market. So I decided to give this dial watch a try. My first impression was that this is a nice looking watch, but I found it a bit heavy compared to my other watches. The size of the watch case and look of the thickness of the watch band seems reminiscent of a man’s watch, but the watch face definitely looks feminine.I was surprised at how long the band was when clasped. I could easily pull it over and then off of my hand (I would like to see the woman that has a wrist that large). This isn’t a deal-breaker since I have had to have links taken out of some of my previous watches for it to fit - but just not this many. I guess they made it this large so that there is no doubt that it will fit any woman’s wrist, no matter how large it is.Final thoughtsThis is a sturdy watch that is advertised as having a “water resistant depth of 165 feet”. Though I haven’t tested this statement, this is a real plus for the times you get caught in the rain or you wash something in a sink full of water and it goes below the surface. I think the old “waterproof” watches could probably make the same claim. So will I wear this watch - definitely, once I get the extra links removed.

I have thyroid issues, such as feeling cold, and have been using Gaia Thyroid Support. The price has doubled since my last order so I was looking at competitors. New Way had the same core ingredients that were the reason I originally started using Gaia. My research identified Kelp, Bladderwrack, and Ashwagandha as important items in addition to those that everyone seems to add. Many thyroid supplements have lists of vitamins and minerals but lack these key ingredients. I am pleased with the Thyroid Support and the lower price.

Michael’s song was outstanding. But as an instrumental, it is even better. If you know the words, sing along. If not, enjoy the rhythm.This band plays a set of instruments that not only clearly convey the original melody, but capture your attention. Featured instruments include flute, xylophone, electric keyboard, guitar, bass, bassoon, oboe, and lots of percussion. I was unable to identify some of the “medieval” sounding instruments. Its great background music but you can also jack the volume up and be completely immersed in the beat.

He loves it so much that he just wants to sit in it for hours. He's already figured out that pushing the buttons gets the songs to play. It makes me think that this is a learning toy that advances your child beyond his years.I like that he can be left alone for a few minutes without worrying about him getting into something he shouldn't. Its like a built-in babysitter. Kids like playing with it and pretending to drive like their parents. The car also comes with balls and shapes that your child can push through holes in the car doors. The sing-along songs and phrases are a nice added touch.

I have quite a few gadgets that need to be powered using a USB port on my computer. I have to play a dancing game, switching out one for another to get them all charged. So when I came across this standalone 4-port charging station - I had to get it.The first thing I noticed was how heavy both the charger and the attachable power cord were. This was a sure sign that this is a heavy-duty unit versus those light-weight el-cheapo units on the market that have a hard time charging more than one USB gadget.Testing PhaseA true test of a charger is whether it will charge an iPad (since iPads require more power to charge). So not only did I attach an iPad Air 2 to the charger, but I also attached an iPod Touch, a camera and a USB power block. Both the iPod and iPad made the familiar charging chime accompanied with the green charging icon - so far so good. Both the camera and the charging block’s lights lit up - again a good sign. But how long would it take to fully charge all four items. Would it take all day - No! All four charged very quickly. In fact, the iPod finished charging before the others (it was already at a 50% charge before attaching it to this hub), so I detached its cord and plugged in the cord for my iPad’s keyboard. It started charging right away.EvaluationBoy, it sure is nice to charge so many at the same time! This is exactly what I wanted - it does a good job and frees a USB port on my computer. I am pleased!

I love blueberry and these bars are nice and potent. What I like is that with just a half of a bar for a snack or as a dessert I am satisfied. I did not find them overly sweet.I would equate the flavor and satisfaction with an expensive chocolate covered filled cream.

Besides being fun to play with, Play-Doh is a good creativity tool. Kids can make all sorts of one to six (or more) legged creatures, etc. If they have multiple colors, they can experiment with mixing the colors to create new ones, etc.This set comes with not only tubs of Play-Doh, but also cooky-cutter molds that kids can use to cut out little shapes. This is a nice added touch over what I had when I was a kid e.g. the Play-Doh only.I believe Play-Doh eventually drys out. So I like that this Play-Doh set comes not only in small resealable tubs, but also in a large sealable square tub. So hopefully these will help keep the Play-Doh soft and supple for quite a while (provided the kids remember to put the Play-Doh away in these containers when they are done playing with it).

When boys and girls know how to use hand tools, they are not helpless when it comes to assembling or repairing basic items in the house. This tool set will take away the mystery and give them a start in doing basic mechanical work.I’ve noticed how adult tech and social people have to hire others to get simple things done because they are lost when it comes to hardware of any kind. And I’ve worked with adults who are scarred of tools. Since parents no longer teach their children how to do things, these kinds of “toys” fill a major vacuum in the learning process.

There are easy to duplicate tutorials using geometric shapes and then adding details. After drawing a basic dragon, you add eyes, jaw, ears, horns, wings, scales, limbs, bridles, and saddles.Medieval dragons and Asian dragons are next. They are followed by drawing hatchlings and sea dragons. So there is a much larger variety then you may have been exposed to.The book provides views from all sides so you can get the overall proportions correct. If you are using a 3D graphics program that rotates your drawing, this will quicken your successful conclusion.

The book begins with telling about how lacquer boxes are made by hand. Then it details the differences between the 4 villages who paint the scenes on lacquer boxes. The 19 stories related in the book show scenes that are painted on the boxes that depict episodes in the story. The photos are in color. At the back are other examples from each village.I love these very long stories. That would be great to read to children and then you can show the photos when you get to that scene so they can picture it in their mind.As an owner of a lacquer box, the real gold and silver glistens in the light. The quality of the detailed scene reflects the craftsmanship of the box itself- flawless.

With all of the video connections (VGA, DVI, HDMI, Thunderbolt) and data connections (USB, USB 2,USB 3, Firewire, Thunderbolt, Lightning) plus mini-this and micro-that, the poor consumer has a hard time connecting hardware.Belkin has really come up with an alternative here. Even though I purchase cables with different connectors so my devices can communicate, sometimes I need another quick-and-ready adaptor for temporary use. This is will one of my go-to choices.My Sony camcorders have an aux. HDMI port and my Viewsonic projector has VGA ports. Now I can connect directly.

Patriot is a possible look into the future. Pentagon war-gaming has already anticipated some of this but they won’t tell you. So if you fancy yourself a “cold warrior”, see what you think of Ted Bell’s scenario.The gripping story is a series of “chess moves” against a wimpy American President. It involves both military and black ops. More action and intrigue than James Bond. Notice how private military contractors hold the outcome in the balance.You’re going to observe the current news reports differently after reading this novel. Enjoy.

The newest Apple products are using USB-C. And I seem to be acquiring Mini-B devices. So this is a real help. I'm looking forward to Belkin's USB 3 cable for my new stuff.Belkin has really come up with an alternative here. Even though I purchase cables with different connectors so my devices can communicate, sometimes I need another quick-and-ready adaptor for temporary use. This is will one of my go-to choices.

This is a good tool for teaching young ones how to turn pages, spin cogs, dials, etc. It’s nice that there are different play areas/toys to keep your child engaged /interested. Little ones will get a kick out of using the steering wheel to move the bear around the table.I like that you can keep the legs off so the table can sit directly on the floor which is better for babies, but you can add the legs for toddlers that like to stand.

I use the size waist I ordered. Its snug. If you carry items in your pants pockets you definitely need to go to the next waist size. Likewise, if you normally use a belt, again get the larger size.If like me you are using these around the house, then having them ride below the belly button and almost tight enough to feel like your briefs will still be comfortable.The legs are fine but not loose- fairly form-fitted. If you have skinny thighs and legs, you will probably find them just right. But thicker thighs are going to make you feel like you’re wearing a wetsuit. Again, a larger waist size will solve this.Finally, if you wash in hot water and tumble dry hot, you’ll be putting on a girdle. Now you know how females feel. Tighty whitey? No, tighty bluey.

Again, a larger waist size will solve this.Finally, if you wash in hot water and tumble dry hot, you’ll be putting on a girdle. Now you know how females feel. Tighty whitey? No, tighty bluey.

I send gifts to children of relatives. Even if the gift is in a large box, the nice looking label stands out- indicating this is something special.While its a small label, I regularly receive boxes with the address in small print on a shipping label. Since I’m not placing a barcode on the label, the size works fine for me.Another idea is to only write the child’s name on the label larger and the address on the box. The recipient sees that it is especially addressed to them.

This is another toy that promotes hand-eye coordination and imagination. Can’t knock having fun while learning.I am going to link this up with VTech’s Smart Wheels Park & Play Deluxe Garage that I already got from Amazon. The only down side is that this makes a huge track that takes up a lot of floor space.As with VTechs other toys, this is very colorful which will catch children’s eye. The steering wheel is a nice touch. It lets kids feel like they are driving just like daddy.As I said, this is a huge set and it will take an adult around 30 minutes - 1 hour to put together.

This is a collection of international classical music. It is softer and smoother than straight classical and would be better defined as mood music. A person who loves classical would better appreciate this ensemble over a person who likes love song lyrics.

This is the trap I’ve always wanted. I hated the old style wire with the crook in it. It was about the most successful style. But you had to be careful that it did not snap on your fingers when you were setting it and sometimes the mouse eat the bait without triggering it. And after 2 snaps or a couple of weeks of waiting, it usually would not trigger.This trap just requires that you pull the U-shaped wire back until it snaps into place. Armed. Ready to go. I love it. And the kicker is that it is reusable.

I don’t have symptoms that would point to a deficiency in B-12. But I take vitamins and minerals as a precaution in case I’m not getting what my body needs from my diet. I got the Jarrow B-12 because it claims to absorb easily and the current multi-vitamin I am taking does not include B-12.

I have been using Kodak and Fuji batteries and they have been worn out from constant use. I was hesitant about buying this brand because I’ve never used them and they were so cheap.But they all charged up and I tested them. They worked as well as my first group in my Fujifilm 800 EXR camera. I am very satisfied.

These curtains feel like velvet. They hang beautifully and look like they are more expensive than they are. The two-tone look is very fashionable and the chocolate brown hides soiling and dirty air coming in through the windows.Their ability to block light, noise, heat, and cold is all you could want in this category (I have all 4 problems where I live). They are washable so you don’t have to send them to the dry cleaners. I have other black out curtains and these are better looking and seem to be more durable. They are washable so you don’t have to send them to the dry cleaners.The grommets (eyelets) are a strong plastic circle that will not tear or wear out for years. If you want to mount the curtains on a traverse rod for easy opening and closing, there is enough material to attach the hook into the material or if you have a valance you can put the hook through the circle.

I am not a gaming person so I didn’t get it for that purpose. I got this headset so I could connect it to my Mac, iPad, or iPod to do dictation.Test 1: I played some music (on my iPod) and adjusted the volume of the speaker (using the controls on the headset’s cord) - it worked perfectly. Afterwards, I opened a voice recorder App and recorded some dictation - again it worked perfectly.Test 2: I plugged it in to the headphone port on my Mac and tested it with QuickTime - once I had the correct input device selected in the Sound Preferences - it again worked perfectly.Test 3: I plugged it into the microphone port of my “Syba SD-CM-UAUD USB Stereo Audio Adapter” that I use on an older Mac (that has the microphone jack on the back which to too far away for the cord to reach). It worked, but the sound was very faint - which is surprising since my other headset works fine with this adapter.Evaluation: It does what I want - recording dictation when it is plugged directly in to my Mac or iPad (with no adapter used). So I am thoroughly satisfied with its performance - though I think if I really wanted to listen to music, I would opt for a headset with two earphones to get a stereo effect.

This is just like my professional reusable coverall for when I sprayed insect poison on flowers in a greenhouse. I no longer have it nor do I work in the greenhouse anymore. I went ahead and got this disposable coverall just in case I have to do something very messy like painting a wall, etc.I like the long sleeves and the attached hood for maximum protection. Being disposable, it is definitely thinner than my first pair. But it seems rugged enough for one use, maybe more if it doesn’t get too soiled.

I have other shorter USB extension cords that work just fine. But I got this much longer cord for the times I want to plug in something (like a keyboard, printer, or speakers) that I want to use on the other side of the room from my computer.At first I was a little skeptical that something as small and non-powered as a thumb-drive would work over such a long length of cord. So I tested it - it worked perfectly. I can now use it for attaching my camera and other USB items that sit on the other side of the room.

I like that the Mirror’s “Micro Suction” backing will stick on different surfaces, so it is very versatile (I have it stuck to the side of my computer desk’s wood veneered hutch). It’s nice to be able to place a mirror wherever I want.The only con is that it is a cheap mirror that came with a small blemish.

It is mechanical but inspires imagination. Toys that do everything stifle imagination and get boring. The Garage has lots of possibilities and you can buy additional items to grow this into a much larger play area.I really like that it is plastic so it won’t break from rough play. It’s a great brain development too because it can be dis-assembled and then reassembled to let your kid practice memorizing how to put it together and experience the joy of success.It’s large and younger kids will find it easier to handle the pieces- eye- hand coordination. Older kids will use other toys to supplement their play.

I particularly enjoyed the “Lost Episodes”. They were early shows in black and white with long melodramas. I’ve been to many live melodrama performances. Its always great when the actors say another’s line in mistake and they have to ad-lib to get the story back on track. And sometimes the lines crack up the cast. That’s what you will see on these episodes.Red’s guests who were leading men in the movies show you their versatile talents. After you see these programs, you’ll be aware of how much talent has been lost. Today, good-looking actors and actresses spout lines in a monotone and the special effects dominate the storyline. “Character” rarely is the focus anymore.

I have powered USB hubs for my desktop computer at home. I got this unpowered hub for the times when I travel and need extra USB ports (since it is small). I can plug it into my keyboard and have more ports.It worked straight out of the box with no drivers needed which was nice.BTW: Since it’s not powered, it works best if the USB item doesn’t require much power like a thumb-drive or with something that has its own power source.

I am always looking for that missing pen when I am at my computer desk. So I thought this would be a great way to keep track of my pens by attaching it the the side of my computer desk.The first thing I noticed when it arrived was how small it was - I was expecting a 6 x 8.9 x 1.4 inch cup (as mentioned in the Technical Details). In reality, it is only: 4 x 2.5 x 1”.I followed the instructions to adhere the sticky “Micro Suction” pad (with a nub on the reverse side) to the side of my desk and then waited an hour for it to set. Afterward I slid the cup’s back hole over the nub. It fit fine, so I grabbed a few pens and my Wacom stylus and placed them in the cup - instantly the weight of the pens and stylus made the cup top-heavy and tip to the side (but not enough for it to spill to the floor). So I had to reposition the pens so the weight would be balanced and the cup would remain vertical.Solution: I took a strip of cardboard, folded it in half, and shoved it behind the cup. So it’s nice and snug agains the side of my desk. Now it doesn’t tip when I place all of my pens in the cup - problem solved!Evaluation: The cup would be great for keeping track of short things like paper clips, erasers, etc. But for holding longer pens, pencils, full sized scissors, etc, I think Elmer should have made the hole/nub a little tighter so the cup wouldn’t tip to the side under the weight or made the cup deeper so it wouldn’t be top-heavy.

I have tons of USB drives, printers, etc connected to my computer so I ran out of USB ports. It’s nice to have a powered hub so I can connect anything. Its nice and small so I can position it anywhere.It worked straight out of the box with no drivers needed. I don’t have any way to double-check its speed, so I can’t comment other than to say it seems to be fast.

This is a nice gadget for kids that like to color with crayons and who like to tinker with things. Besides giving kids a lot of fun, adding their names to their crayons removes any doubts on who’s crayons these are (when friends come by or if they take their crayons to school).

3:01 Mins I only came across these waterproof cool white lights this year and these are the highest quality that I've ever tried thus far. In this video, I show each component that comes in this solar light set.The solar panel is shaped like a sunflower or sun, depending on your perspective...There's a stake that slides into the back and allows you to adjust the angle to capture the most sunlight that you can.There's 8 modes that are super smooth and diverse...They can be still, dimming, dancing, sparkling, alternating or a combination of any/all of these.I highly recommend this cool white color--they look like snowflakes or stars...It's such a calming color that even my teenaged son loved falling asleep with cool white lights in his room.This color paired with the smooth (instead of jerky) rhythm of the lights easily makes this set one of the highlights of my holiday season.*Complimentary lights provided by Icicle for testing and review

2:20 Mins This is a heat resistant wig that is surprisingly very natural looking due to the cut and fullness of it. The look is sleek and stylish with a bit of softness that isn't typically easy to achieve with a synthetic black wig.I particularly appreciate that the bangs aren't cut straight across the forehead, but they fall in a feathered way. In the video, I show the inside of this wig and even drop it. Surprisingly, it maintains a very natural appearance. I've tried a couple wigs that could not achieve this. I would have to groom it before wearing again.Sure, I comb it with my fingers. However, I haven't experienced any real tangles thus far. It's not stiff, but flows with you...This is perfect for cosplay. My teenagers are into anime and told me that the style looks like Naomi Misora from Death Note.*Complimentary wig provided by VOROSY for testing and review.

This is small packing cube that can hold only one pair of our adult sneakers at a time. So, the usefulness is limited for our upcoming move (unless you purchase the 3 pack). It comes with an illustrated card that shows you how to fold clothing to fit as much as you can inside of it.There's a triangle of mesh built into both the front and back that takes up a third of each side. It appears to be well made. It may be a good choice if you need to section off a small piece of luggage in a stylish way, like to separate baby clothes. For us, it would take the place of some of the disposable grocery bags that we typically use for separating shoes or dirty clothes.I give it a 4 for the quality construction and attention to detail. I would highly recommend purchasing the 3 pack over the single.Note: In one photo, it shows the cube sitting in my smaller rolling piece of luggage.*Purchased at a deep discount for testing and review.

4:23 MinsThis jump rope appears to be an updated version of the Aoneky that we already have, except ours has different handles and method of adjusting the height. It also has a built-in counter that keeps track of rotations.The blue "rope" appears to be the mostly the same (one is slightly thicker, which makes it feel a tad bit softer) but the handles are very different. Our old green handles are larger and lighter in color, so it's easier for dirt and oils to show (in one photo, my daughter used permanent marker to make the darkening ends look "more pretty").The newer black handles are more attractive with an ergonomic style. The look is sleek once set to a desired length, though it takes a little longer to adjust.You have to use your nail or some other object to pry off the black rounded caps on the bottom of the handles. This allows you to pull the rope through, knot and stuff the remaining length back in. These handles are more compact than the older jump rope, making the insides more narrow as well...The smaller you need to make the jump rope, the harder this process may become.This is something to consider if you'll be sharing with others and adjusting it often to accommodate different heights. Still, it's not too difficult to set the rope to one length and it's nice not having the excess bits flapping as you jump (like with the older green one).*Complimentary jump rope provided by Aoneky for testing and review.

This 6 bag set is comprised of 3 extra large and 3 travel roll ups. Since I'm currently in the process of packing for an upcoming move, I appreciate how helpful they are in containing my wardrobe for shipping.These extra large bags are so huge that I was able to fill one of them with 7 jumbo beach-sized towels along with a good chunk of my summer clothes.  After unscrewing the top and sucking the air out with a vacuum, each becomes a heavy, condensed mass.In one photo, I show how you can even stand them up to lean against a wall. However, since I stuffed mine completely full, I did notice that some of the air seeps in when positioned this way.Also, the sliding clips are easier for me to use on the smaller bags. The larger bags require me to go back over with my fingers to reseal them. I've had similar bags in the past that had thinner seals (see photo of the clear older bag I compared with one of these blue double sealed bags). The wide blue double seals make resealing by hand much easier.I needed to completely fill the smaller bags with clothes, so I opted to forgo the rolling aspect. I included a photo of these smaller bags (both empty and full) to show how big they are as well.*Complimentary bags provided by HomeIdeas for testing and review.

3:35 Mins This is a wonderful 23 piece set that is a must-have for any of the beginner sets. I have a glow-in-the dark starter set and these are really ideal. In this video, I further explain how these pieces increase its playability.The prongs along the rim of the shallow molds make them extremely easy to form--just set them down flat and give the tops a tap for good measure...I have not had to redo ANY of the molds that you see here--they're that good. This high success rate is especially nice if you're working with children that seem to get quickly frustrated.I also demonstrate how different colors of Sands Alive! can heighten the fun when playing with related pieces (ex. blue ocean life and pink pastries).  The texture of this sand-like substance allows for such great control, that I was also able to selectively mix colors (keep mixed sand separate since the blend can't be undone).In addition to the molds, you get a number of interesting hand tools for cutting, rolling, mixing, moving...This is a fun, well-rounded set that helps to make your sand come alive.*Complimentary mold set provided for testing and review.

2:48 Mins I have come to appreciate these battery operated 40 LED stringed lights (permanently encased in clear cystal balls) for those times when I can't move my tree up against the window to get a good charge with my solar lights. The warm white/yellow casts the perfect glow...It's much easier to recharge the required 3 AA batteries in the wall. The battery box has a clear sliding panel that requires you to read a clear (raised) "OPEN" with an arrow going the opposite direction one would assume. It's a good deterrent for little ones that want to open the box.I love how these lights don't limit where I place the tree or how big a tree I use them on (our 4 foot tree is about the biggest I want to carry to a window to recharge solar lights). I'm not tethered to an outlet with plug-ins. It's wonderful being able to use this tree to illuminate a dark, windowless corner of our apartment that may not have an outlet nearby.This light strand is roughly 175 inches long, so I would recommend two for completely covering a tree this size (if the tree isn't being placed against a wall and you need the lights to go all the way around).*Complimentary light strand provided by Cmyk for testing and review.

These metal cutters are thick enough to create shapes of various thickness (see photo of pink Sands Alive! with cutters to simulate pastries). They make clean and consistent cuts.I was relieved to find that the red silicone tops are easy to remove for cleaning, yet they aren't flimsy. They are even firm enough to put back on with only one hand. Yes, I did this and was surprised that I didn't have any trouble.I also photographed where the metal is soldered (both inside and out). Note how the inside is not straight across, but dips in. Hopefully, it's an improvement on the traditional design. I try to pay careful attention to this area (where cutters of this type occasionally fail).  So far, so good...*Complimentary cutter set provided for testing and review.

2:20 Mins This is a heat resistant wig that is surprisingly very natural looking due to the cut and fullness of it. The look is sleek and stylish with a bit of softness that isn't typically easy to achieve with a synthetic black wig.I particularly appreciate that the bangs aren't cut straight across the forehead, but they fall in a feathered way. In the video, I show the inside of this wig and even drop it. Surprisingly, it maintains a very natural appearance. I've tried a couple wigs that could not achieve this. I would have to groom it before wearing again.Sure, I comb it with my fingers. However, I haven't experienced any real tangles thus far. It's not stiff, but flows with you...This is perfect for cosplay. My teenagers are into anime and told me that the style looks like Naomi Misora from Death Note.*Complimentary wig provided by VOROSY for testing and review.

2:33 Mins Sometimes a product comes along that totally redefines an aspect of a way that I live. This belt truly does...I thought that the safest, most convenient way to travel would be to have my valuables contained in a "fanny pack." Yes, it made me look a little pregnant, but I was willing to sacrifice style for security.I also thought that I couldn't run without my cell phone and keys jangling about. Pouches rub against my body/clothing, which strangely always made me feel nauseous.This Eazymate belt is made of comfortable spandex lycra and I forget that I'm wearing it. The product details state that this belt is wider than competitors, yet I couldn't imagine it being more narrow--this is the ideal width. The belt is like a second skin, with everything gently hugging against my body without shifting unless I purposely move the articles myself.The size was very accurate as well. I just used a tape measure to see in what category I belonged and ordered accordingly.Note: The belt was roomy enough for me to fit all of my essentials. The zippered back pocket is an extra place to store even more items. When traveling, I definitely plan on adding my passport. The photo where I'm clasping my hands is how I look when the belt filled with every item that you see here.*Complimentary belt provided by EAZYMATE USA INC. for testing and review.

This is a beautiful set of maple leaf socks that looks great with our winter clothing. The socks perfectly fit both my daughter (women's 8) and me (9.5) with room to spare. They are comfortable with a good degree of stretch.Though I personally find this pattern more attractive than the wool/nylon blend from the same company, the inside thread is woven loosely enough to allow my pinky toe to occasionally catch on one of the inner loops when sliding them on (see photo of sock turned inside out after such an occurrence).When wearing a purple sock of each type on both feet (see pic where I'm comparing the two), the other sock seems to be a tad more dense/warmer--likely due to the greater percentage of wool in its blend.These socks are fine for lounging around the house when it's cold outside, but they may not be ideal for outside winter wear (hence the word "fashion" in the name on product page). Still, they're thin enough to keep me covered without getting overheated.*I bought these socks (at a discount for testing and review) as an add-on with our yearly winter clothes purchase.

We have the windows open, so the crisp autumn air has filled the front room. These socks seemed a bit thin, but surprisingly they keep our feet quite warm.The fit is perfect for BOTH me and my daughter (she is a women's 8 and I am an 9.5). That is partially due to the fact that this wool is blended with nylon. It helps to provide a good amount of stretch where needed.I don't like tight socks and these are not tight on me in any way. Note my ankles on the picture where I'm lounging in my couch pouch--plenty of room.Though these are quite attractive on the outside, the inside is a flurry of string set in rows--organized chaos. Fortunately, it's all very soft and there are no holes. However, when I tugged on the inside hanging string, little pieces of it came off in my hands. I showed my husband and he said that was normal for wool and told me to stop pulling at it.The pair I'm wearing is the only one where a sock had an obvious irregularity (note the inside heel where a white stitch was sewn straight through the brown).*I bought these socks (at a discount for testing and review) as an add-on with our yearly winter clothes purchase.

I have a Macbook Pro and I wanted to be able to stream my favorite online shows onto our Samsung TV via an HDMI cable.When first plugging this attachment to my Macbook Pro and connecting the other end to the HDMI, I had to to drag the picture over to the TV screen (using the Mac's track pad). At this point, I could only SEE the show on our TV.In order to also HEAR it through the TV (instead of through my computer), I had to go to my SYSTEM PREFERENCES then into SOUND to change the output. My Samsung popped up on the list and I just selected it.I haven't had any problems since my teenagers showed me how to do this. It's great not having to watch my show on a small monitor. I can now comfortably enjoy it on the TV with our entire family.*Complimentary adapter provided by VicTsing for testing and review.

4:32 Mins At over 6 1/2 feet, this is a great set for transforming flat spaces into fun, chalkboard surfaces. This PVC vinyl material is made to firmly adhere without bubbling. It can also be easily removed without leaving any residue.It comes with a set of five pieces of chalk that is a higher quality than what I usually buy at the store. I can tell that it's better since it doesn't smudge as easily and barely leaves a trace after erasing.In this video, I explain how I tested this roll and found that my first choice of surfaces was less than ideal for installation. Since it's reusable, I want to wait until after my upcoming move to stick it on something else that won't peel or have a bumpy surface that makes it harder to write. I love the freedom that comes with being able to change my mind about the placement.It's a relief not having to deal with messy and permanent chalk paint. This chalkboard roll is ideal for quick customization. The back of the roll has a grid for easy, accurate cutting. You can also make smaller labels with the scraps.Note: Like their labels, this wall decal is one of those rare items that comes with a lifetime, no questions asked (money back) guarantee.*Complimentary chalkboard wall decal provided by Life of the Party for testing and review.

These mugs are remarkable in that they have the ability to keep my hot food (usually soup) hot and my cold beverages very chilly.This is an especially decorative vessel that holds a good amount of food and drink. The rim is curled over, which lends a different feeling to get used to when drinking from it.The design of the handle has jagged ends that remind me of lightning (like it could be a cup from Thor's home in Asgard). However, I wish it was a bit more ergonomic. My hand gets sore when holding it by the handle, so I've been mainly resting it on a hard surface that will support the weight.An included picture shows how I am able to handle it. I only wish the handle opening was a little wider and more rounded. The bright copper colored laquer coating keeps the dimpled pattern from looking dated like some older (darker) versions of this type of cup.*Complimentary mug provided by Livin' Well for testing and review.

3:18 MinsI already have a couple copper mugs. I was so impressed by how they insulate anything I eat or drink out of them. This one does the same while looking especially stunning. The copper is very bright with decorative indentations. The inside is stainless steel (natural color--a stark contrast).Though it adds to the design, the rounded lip of the cup feels a little weird to my mouth. Still, I mostly enjoy eating hot soup out of these types of mugs (with a spoon), so that's not a problem for me. The soup stays hot until the very last drop...it's wonderful.I also appreciate that the handle on this one is large enough for me to comfortably fit my fingers through without placing much stress on my hand when the cup is full. It's very ergonomic that way.*Complimentary mug provided by Livin' Well for testing and review.

I try not to take off my case while I'm out, since I tend to have a bad habit of dropping my phone. Due to this, I appreciate that the black clips are flexible enough for me to fit them onto my phone case (this set goes even further by including two clips).Two out of the three lenses work fine for my Note 4. However, my camera can't figure out the wide angle lens when it's fitted onto my case. I only see a blur as it keeps trying to refocus...As much as I'd like my phone to cooperate with the wide lens while my waterproof case is on, I know that it's not meant to. Still, I was able to get the lens to sit flush onto my case. Each lens can slide up/down the length of the clip for easy adjustments.The three lenses that are included: the big fish eye with cover and similarly covered wide lens with macro stack--unscrew the two in order to separate for use. You also get a drawstring carrying pouch for all the pieces.The directions are clear (provided both in English and Chinese) and the product works very well.Note: I attached photographs from my Note 4 taking a close shot of a blanket with the macro lens and a fish eye photo of a part of my front room. Both were taken with each lens mounted OVER the case--awesome.*Complimentary set provided by VicTsing for testing and review.

4:20 Mins I grew up a serious Star Wars fan, so glowsticks always bring the lightsaber imagery to mind. This set is different than a nearly identical glowstick (8 inch 100 count) tube that I've reviewed in the past. Instead of orange, this set has RED (lightsaber color used by the Sith).Alternately, red is great for color coordinating for holidays like Christmas and Valentine's...This is my favorite way to wear the thick glowsticks (hanging by their hooks rather than having string threaded through). You simply snap these down the entire length of the stick, shake and connect ends with the included bits of plastic tube.I did notice a slight smell in the canister with these sticks compared to the other brand, but most of the colors appear identical: blue (starts off clear before activation), green (initially pale yellow), yellow (noticeably darker yellow) and pink (hot pink).Note: It's a challenge to clearly tell which sticks are red or pink in low lighting. If accurate nighttime color selection is a priority, you may want to carefully separate these beforehand and reinsert them in the tube sectioned off with a cardboard divider.Also, I recommend transferring connectors to a zippered baggie after opening to prevent them from spilling during the excitement...After an evening of fun, place activated sticks in the freezer to extend their glow time.*Complimentary glow sticks provided by Etekcity for testing and review.

4:32 Mins At over 6 1/2 feet, this is a great set for transforming flat spaces into fun, chalkboard surfaces. This PVC vinyl material is made to firmly adhere without bubbling. It can also be easily removed without leaving any residue.It comes with a set of five pieces of chalk that is a higher quality than what I usually buy at the store. I can tell that it's better since it doesn't smudge as easily and barely leaves a trace after erasing.In this video, I explain how I tested this roll and found that my first choice of surfaces was less than ideal for installation. Since it's reusable, I want to wait until after my upcoming move to stick it on something else that won't peel or have a bumpy surface that makes it harder to write. I love the freedom that comes with being able to change my mind about the placement.It's a relief not having to deal with messy and permanent chalk paint. This chalkboard roll is ideal for quick customization. The back of the roll has a grid for easy, accurate cutting. You can also make smaller labels with the scraps.Note: Like their labels, this wall decal is one of those rare items that comes with a lifetime, no questions asked (money back) guarantee.*Complimentary chalkboard wall decal provided by Life of the Party for testing and review.

4:30 MinsI'm currently preparing for an upcoming move. It's the first time that my storage boxes aren't going to be covered with grimy tape and permanent marker...This set of 60 labels (10 pages with 6 on a page) include 3 pages of the classy FLOURISH design (my favorite), 3 pages of ovals and 4 pages of rectangles.These PVC labels allow me to have the freedom to change my mind when packing and to easily erase and rewrite. Since I'm very visual, I also enjoy drawing something on the label that immediately indicates what's inside the box.There's something wonderful about looking at neat stacks of pretty labeled containers...It really lifts my mood and makes me feel more upbeat during this stressful transition.Alternately, I love the idea of using these labels for decorating canisters or jars of homemade goods. The labels are both dishwasher AND freezer safe. Considering this, they also make a good choice for covering surfaces that get exposed to the elements (like adding a chalkboard surface to an outside playhouse or jungle gym).Note: In this video, I'm using some chalk that I picked up on sale a couple years ago. it seems that my brand is very powdery in comparison to the set of chalk that's included in the "Mr. Big Chalk" (#1 Chalkboard Wall Decal) offered by this same company. That chalk doesn't smudge as easily, and it wipes clean without leaving much residue.*Complimentary pack of labels provided by Life of the Party for testing and review.

This is truly the freshest container of coconut oil that I've ever opened. I'm in a colder climate, so naturally it arrived opaque. However, it wasn't as solid as a number of brands that I've tried in the past. It's soft and smooth...It tasted so delicious in it's BPA Free tub, that I spread it on a piece of bread and ate it plain! As much as I have use coconut oil in the past, I can't recall EVER doing that before. I couldn't wait to whip up a batch of wheat biscuits with it.I rely on organic, virgin coconut oil (cold-pressed) for SO many things. It's the best coconut oil that you can buy and a must-have in our home. Like shortening, it provides the same flaky texture in my cookies, biscuits and pie crusts. Yet, using coconut oil is MUCH healthier for you.In addition, I use this to maintain healthy skin and good dental hygiene. If you look up "Oil Pulling with Coconut Oil," you'll find an incredible wealth of information regarding all the wonderful benefits of oil pulling. I use a little less than 1 TBSP. at a time and swish it around my mouth for 15-20 minutes before spitting it out in the toilet--not the sink!  I then usually brush with baking soda after that. The difference in cleanliness/ gradual whitening is stunning.I usually order my coconut oil through Amazon for the year, so the fact that this current batch of oil has an expiration of August 2017 is perfect for our household. I'm definitely ready to switch brands ASAP.*Complimentary tub provided by Island Fresh for testing and review.

5:40 Mins This face paint gives dramatic results without my face feeling heavy or tight. It's non-irritating, so I can wear it for extended periods of time (I've already worn the paint on half of my face for several hours). It is a perfect choice for sensitive skin since it's an FDA approved non-toxic, hypoallergenic food grade coloring. This doesn't even have any odor!I was thrilled that the set includes cosmetic glitter (it doesn't damage eyes--unlike our regular glitter that we use for art projects) and has both a flat and round brush. I explain how the sponges worked better for me over time (9 colors--at 2 dry grams a piece). My husband and I have eliminated meat (except for seafood) from our diets. I thought that I would give this set a try in order to bring more variety into our cooking.Injector & Meat ClawsThe injector worked quite well with the eggplant and squash that I used. I recommend only cutting one (long) side of the disposable plastic holder that carries the syringe. This way, I can keep it to easily slide all the pieces back in for an enclosed, safer storage (the attachments are sharp).When I injected a small cup of soy sauce, I screwed on the single hole attachment. It works well when injected in uncut vegetables that are allowed to sit for a little bit before cooking--I cut the eggplant before stringing one of the two included kebab cables.To slice fresh pineapple for the kebab, I used a plastic "meat claw" to hold a large piece in place. Once can pierce a pineapple, but can't even begin to tear at its sides (so your meat should be tender if attempting to use them to shred).Kebab Skewers & BBQ SheetsThe two skewers make it easy to pan sear kebabs, which was a welcome change from serving up one of my bean-based recipes. I love that the skewer didn't get too hot to hold and manipulate in the pan (warning: it can get VERY hot on a grill), and that the ends weren't as sharp as my conventional stick skewers.Still, I could quickly thread a skewer with fruit, shrimp, injected veggies and squid patty pieces with no problems, whatsoever. I then arranged it all inside my large pan. The skewer also makes the kebab easy to store in a container INTACT for reheating the next day. I just threw the whole kebab back into the pan to warm it up. Since it was still intact, it seemed less like boring leftovers.The nonstick BBQ sheets are easy to clean since they're made with PTFE (like Teflon). They should never touch an open flame, because it starts to smoke and release a chemical smell. This also makes a darker black imprint on the material. ---------Silicone MittsThe biggest issue I've had with several other oven mitts, is that they eventually get nasty looking. Many washes in hard water fade them or they start to fray, or they get charred in some way...That's not a problem with these black silicone mitts. They don't need to ever look old--just rinse them off if they get dirty.However, they didn't consistently provide the best protection (it seems to partially depend on where you're clutching the pan)...The first time I used them to pull some toasted bread pizza out of the oven, I couldn't feel any heat--I was SO impressed. However, when I used one to grab a hot pan of brownies last night, my hand got surprisingly VERY warm. I should not have been able to feel that at all.They also each have a hole for easy hanging. TEIKIS is also printed on one side in orange (it's a nice printing--no scratching, peeling or fading).*Complimentary BBQ set provided by TEIKIS for testing and review.

I love how fragrant and long-lasting essential oils are. This well written and somewhat innovative survey of colonial N. America is the first volume in a projected 5 volume Penguin History of the USA.  I don't think other volumes are published yet.  Drawing on a great deal of recent scholarship, Taylor provides a considerably broader perspective on the early history of the USA by discussing the whole history of colonization in North America, including Spanish and French colonization, and a great deal of attention to the experiences of Native Americans.  As part of his effort to cover all of what is now the USA, Taylor also uses a larger temporal frame as he concludes in the early 19th century with some narrative of the Russian exploitation of Alaska, the Spanish colonization of California, and the early impact of Europeans on Hawaii.This book is divided into 3 sections; Encounters, Colonies, and Empires.  Encounters covers the early explorations and the history of the early colonizations by the Spanish and French.  This section provides concise but useful discussions of the native peoples of North America, the dynamics of early exploration and colonization, the European background of the European conquest of the Western Hemisphere, and the enormous impacts of the European invasion on Native Americans.  Colonies is a somewhat more traditional section describing the histories of the different British colonies, including New England, the Carolinas, the Middle Colonies, and also including the British Caribbean.  Taylor discusses the distinctive histories of these colonies, but also some of their common features.Empires includes much of the traditional history of British North America, including the effects of British politics and the expanding imperial state and economy, the great conflicts with the French Empire, and important cultural events like the first Great Awakening.  The experiences of native peoples and African slaves are important components of the story.  Taylor also includes good discussions of French North America, the great impact of contact with Europeans across the whole continent via the fur trade and other interactions, and sets the stage for the next volume on the American Revolution.In many ways, this is a very fine book.  The breadth of topics is impressive and the quality of writing, like all of Taylor's books, is excellent.  Each section is well worth reading in its own right and there is reasonably good integration of the sections.  Taylor's effort to broaden the perspective of early American history beyond a focus on the British colonies is successful.  Drawbacks include less specific political history of the colonies and the complex events leading to the great rupture of the Revolution.  This is probably an unavoidable consequence of Taylor's well justified decision to expand the scope of the narrative.  Each section has a nice bibliography for further reading.  My only substantial criticism is that this book should have finished with an overview interpretative chapter in which Taylor discusses some of the important themes - the impact of the European invasion on native peoples, the diverse and ambiguous relationships between colonies and their metropoli, the impact of successful colonization on the imperial success of Britain, and the colonization of North America as a specific example of the general phenomenon of expanding European capitalism-imperialism.

An very good and well written alternative history novel.  In this world-line, Byron becomes a successful politician, the crisis of 1830 leads not to modest electoral reform but to a bourgeois-technocratic revolution, and Charles Babbage's Difference Engine is built and becomes the cornerstone of an early information technology revolution.  Like all good alternative history books, there is an imaginative use of real historical figures and fictional figures.  The plot, focused on a search for what is essentially a piece of software, does a nice job of taking readers through the fictional world constructed by Gibson and Sterling.  The plot is a bit cryptic with its resolution presented rather indirectly. The authors introduce a quite a few relatively modern scientific ideas, such as Godel's Incompleteness Theorem and the Cambrian Radiation.

This useful and concise book is an analytically oriented survey of the social and economic history of WWI Russia.  This book will be useful primarily to individuals with prior knowledge of the basic political history.  An important feature of this book is Gatrell's synthesis of considerable secondary literature, much of it in Russian and unavailable to English language readers.  As stated by the subtitle, Gatrell focuses on the effects of the war on Russian society and on the Russian economy.  Using a somewhat chronological approach, Gatrell addresses social and economic changes at each major phase of the war from the outbreak of hostilities to the aftermath of the Bolshevik takeover.  Social and demographic impacts are addressed for each strata of Russian society; the aristocracy, peasantry, urban workforce, and middle classes. There is a fairly detailed description and analysis of the economic changes and dislocations imposed by the war effort, resulting ultimately in disintegration of the economy.  Unlike many historians, Gatrell makes good use of tabular data, so this book has considerably more information than its length would suggest.Gatrell is a thoughtful and articulate analyst.  A major theme of this book is the way that the events of WWI exacerbated many of the social conflicts in Russian society.  The tensions between the Tsarist state and liberal-parliamentary reformers, between business interests and the state bureaucracy, and between classes were considerable exacerbated by the war, particularly with serial defeats and a failing economy.  Military and economic failure, and Nicholas II's disastrous decision to assume personal responsibility ultimately discredited the regime.  In a very nice comparative analysis that concludes the book, Gatrell makes the interesting point that the Tsarist state was the only one of the major belligerents not to make significant concessions to labor during the war.Gatrell also makes some other interesting points.  He discusses how aspects of Tsarist policy during the war tended to encourage ethnic-nationalist unrest.  He points also to some technocratic efforts to manage the economy that would be influential for the subsequent Bolshevik state.  Finally, in his concluding and comparative analysis, Gatrell has a particularly nice analysis of the common features of social and economic effects of WWI in all the major belligerents.

This is probably Anderson's most ambitious novel.  Its longer, has more characters, and a more complex plot than many of his books.  Set in a post Nuclear Holocaust world centuries from now, this books displays many of the best and worst features of Anderson's writing.  Like his best books, its quite imaginative.  The future world that Anderson sketches out is interesting with an imaginative depiction of future societies.  Like many of his books, the plot centers on an enjoyable adventure story that allows Anderson to explore several aspects of his fictional world.  The basic plot idea, an effort to develop a nuclear bomb powered spaceship, is clever and used well.  But, as is also the case with a number of Anderson's books, character development is not always particularly deep and Anderson has a fair amount of gushy prose.  Nonetheless, despite these drawbacks, this is one of his best books and an enjoyable read - much better than the usual run of novels in this genre.  I read this book when published in the early 1980s and recently re-read it, and its worth re-reading.This book is also a thinly disguised allegory containing Anderson's response to contemporary events, including a strong criticism of the environmental movement and a full-throated, but rather odd defense of nuclear power.  These allegorical aspects are handled relatively well and revealing of Anderson's ideological preoccupations, including his somewhat naive libertarianism and belief that expansion was needed to avoid social decay.

This concise,clear book is primarily an interpretative analysis of the Weimar experience.  It is not a narrative introduction and to get the most out of this book, knowledge of the basic narrative history is required.  The book has a hybrid but effective organization, it alternates between chronologically organized sections covering the different periods of Weimar and sections discussing major themes in social, economic, and political history of Weimar.  The chronologically based sections contain some narrative but are primarily analytic is the sense that Peukert identifies major trends and features of events and ties them to his broader analytic sections.  Peukert also has some nice sections placing the Weimar experience in the larger frame of German history.This book has 2 major themes.  One is that the Weimar experience was partly a specific manifestation of general conflicts arising over modernization.  The turbulence of Weimar was partly the consequence of industrialization, urbanization, and massive social change.  The second is that this crisis occurred under particularly difficult circumstances in the aftermath of the German defeat in WWI.  Peukert demonstrates that the Weimar founders attempted to address quite a few of the challenges of modernization but that the constricted economic and political environment of the 1920s, culminated by the Great Depression, severely undermined the Weimar experiment.  Perhaps the most surprising point is that Weimar lasted as long as it did.Peukert has a large number of insightful analyses.  His discussion, for example, of the erosion of legitimacy resulting from the inability of the Weimar state to achieve the social goals set out in the constitution and the limitations of Streseman's foreign policy are really interesting.  I'm not sure that all of his analyses are on target.  I think some knowledgeable scholars would disagree with his discussion of the genesis of the Dawes plan.  At least one prominent historian has described Hitler's accession to power in more contingent terms.For readers interested in understanding the Weimar experience, I recommend reading a good narrative history and then this book.

A well written, conventional narrative of the success of Norman emigres in Medieval Southern Italy and Sicily.  In the 11th and 12th centuries, emigre Norman knights became involved in the chaotic politics of Southern Italy and Sicily.  Originally serving as mercenaries, a number of these emigres, notably the sons of the minor noble Tancred of Hauteville, became important and independent actors.  Two of them, Robert Guiscard (translated variously as the "cunning" or as the "weasel") and his half-brother, Roger the Great Count, became dominant figures in Southern Italy and Sicily, and important figures in the Mediterranean & European worlds.  Focusing on the careers of the Hauteville brothers, Norwich narrates their careers as warlords and eventual success.  Southern Italy and Sicily were politically complex and violent, with the Byzantine Greeks, local Italian lords, the Papacy, the Holy Roman Empire, and local Muslim emirs all important actors in this turbulent environment.  The literally crowning achievement was the establishment of the Kingdom of Sicily, encompassing both Sicily proper and much of Southern Italy by Roger II.  This remarkably tolerant, for its time, society was built in good part on Roger's continuation of Muslim administrations and his adoption of a Byzantine style of monarchy.

This is probably the best of Stirling's recent books.  His recent books in this cycle have been relatively short LPUs (least publishable units) that appeared designed to string out as many books as possible.  While this story is repeating important elements of the prior installment of this cycle, this book is longer and better developed than other recent books in the cycle.  The plot line is better developed and there is a richer background development.

A well written and interesting exploration of the nature of politics in the early American republic. Freeman focuses on the nature of politics prior to the emergence of the party system that is such an important and persistent feature of American life.  This is book is essentially a set of closely related essays on the role of a traditional conception of "honor" in political life.  Freeman's strategy is to select an interesting and often somewhat neglected text or set of documents, and use it as a point of departure to explore her theme.  John Adams' letters to the Boston Patriot, written in retirement and to justify his administration, are an example.Freeman argues very well that a traditional concept of personal "honor" was a crucial element of political life.  Inspired by traditional aristocratic ideals, the concept of personal honor strongly influenced political interactions, organization, and leadership in the early Republic.  She argues as well that this code had a specific "grammer' that dictated certain forms of personal and political behavior, and that it is difficult to understand early American politics without knowing these structural features.  The most famous example is the fatal Burr-Hamilton duel.  Freeman makes the very interesting argument that the public and republican nature of American politics actually exacerbated aspects of the "honor" code.  Only with the emergence of a party system, a somewhat painful process, was it possible to dissociate some personal and public aspects of conduct, quenching the importance of "honor."  While this argument doesn't replace  the traditional interpretation of the importance of the development of a party system in the early Republic, it certainly deepens it.

This well organized and well written book explores the basis for the often spectacular phenomenon of adaptive radiations.  Schluter, who has made major contributions in this area, adopts a useful approach to discussing adaptive radiations.  His point of departure is the basic theory developed by prominent biologists in the mid -20th century.  This theory is the "ecological theory" in which radiations are driven by selective advantages of adapting to differentiated environmental niches.  Schluter isolates the basic features of the theory and systematically moves through the recent evidence for or against these features.  This is often an impressive combination of basic theory, natural history, and some intervention experiments.  For generally all features of the theory, Schluter finds that the available data, though often incomplete, favors the initial theory.  He is successful as well in identifying future areas for research.

A very well research and well written history of radioisotope use in the post-WWII era.  Creager's goals are to illuminate the relationship between the major Federal vendor of radioisotopes, the Atomic Energy Commission (AEC), and the scientific community, and to illustrate the importance of radioisotopes as key tools in post-WWII biology and medicine.  This is, consequently and sensibly, an essentially topical though roughly chronological set of chapters on themes.While prefigured by some uses of radioisotopes generated by cyclotron technology in the interwar period, widespread use of radioisotopes was, likely many aspects of American science, a direct produce of WWII, the Manhattan Project, and the Cold War.  Wide use of radioisotopes was driven by a convergence of factors.  The AEC was eager to promote a peaceful use of nuclear technology, a number of prescient scientists recognized the potential of radioisotopes, and  a major reactor at what became the Oak Ridge National Laboratory had become redundant, allowing its use for radioisotope generation.  Creager discusses the AEC's efforts to expand use of radioisotopes, its entanglement with its military mission and Cold War politics, and provides some nice examples of the impact of using radioisotope tracers as tools in  basic research.  The latter include reconstructing the pathways of photosynthesis and the famous Hershey-Chase experiment.  Applications in medical research are discussed  as well - a much more ambiguous story featuring some real triumphs like the development of RIAs and some actually shocking experiments involving the unwitting participation of pregnant women.  Creager also discusses the role of the AEC in developing radiotherapy and to some extent, new imaging methods.  There is a good chapter on the importance of radiotracer methods in large scale ecological studies.An important aspect of several chapters is what was sometimes convergence and sometimes tension between the AEC's military mission and scientific-clinical work.  The AEC support for developing better radiotherapy methods was driven partly by military interest in the effects of radiation exposure.  Support for ecological experiments was driven in part by concerns about contamination secondary to weapons production.  Another important aspect is the often inconsistent and irregular approach (and lack of same) towards safety and ethics of experiments.  Many features of this work, not revealed until years later, will be very disturbing to modern readers.

A dystopian novel set in a near future USA, probably the early 22nd century, when many of the feared consequences of global warming have occurred.  The action takes place in an American Southwest in the grip of a megadrought and the background clearly includes much of the coastal USA lost to sea level rise.  This is a chaotic USA with states semi-independent and engaged in thinly disguised warfare over access to water.  Despite this, the basic legal framework of rights to water in the western USA, first in has rights in perpetuity, still governs access to water.  The plot centers around the pursuit of a long lost document that would markedly alter the legal balance of power.  This is a relatively conventional thriller plot with relatively conventional character development.  Bacigalupi is a competent writer and the overarching metaphor of the book, water (or more properly, access to water) as a source of social division is clever, but the plotting and character development are clunky and predictable.  As commented by other readers, there is a fair amount of rather stark violence in this book, arguably and perhaps unfortunately, the best writing in the book.  On the important criterion of the plausibility of Bacigalupi's projected future, I'd say the results are uneven.  The dismal future he describes is plausible but as seems to be common, he has China doing relatively well.  This is unlikely as China is even more vulnerable to water depletion, weather pattern changes, and sea level rise than the USA.

A truly outstanding work of scholarship.  Miller set out to capture the world view of the dominant figures of the 17th century New England Puritan world - its theologians and ministers.  The thoughts of this relatively small and self-selected group is at the root of many important features of subsequent American history.  This is not a typical chronological survey but rather an attempt at a systematic description and synthesis of the fundamental features of Puritan theology.  Miller divides this book into 4 sections - Religion and Learning, Cosmology, Anthropology, and Sociology.  He proceeds from the basic conception of God through Puritan attempts to categorize and understand the natural world, then their conception of human nature, and as a final consequence, their essentially religious conception of society.A major theme is the Puritan effort to utilize the large and not always compatible intellectual heritage of Medieval and Renaissance Europe.  Miller starts with the essentially Augustinian-Calvinist view of an infinitely powerful and mysterious God, a corrupted humanity, and the unmerited gift of Grace.  At the same time, the Puritans aimed to avoid the abandonment of reason and drew on a varied intellectual inheritance to produce a rational way of understanding theology and the natural world.  He particularly emphasizes the role of the "logic," really a system of classification, of the French scholar Petrus Ramus.  In their studies of scripture and attempts to erect a way to understand the world, they constructed an elaborate system that they believed reconstructed divine structure.  As Miller demonstrates, this was a not always consistent compound of Calvinism, medieval scholasticism, humanist scholarship, Aristotle, and Plato. With time, some of the contradictions of this system would become problematic but in its time, this was an impressive achievement.  The Puritan view of man was a similar effort to unify faith and reason, holding onto the Calvinist view of corrupted humanity and undeserved Grace but also describing ways in which reason and human capacity could participate in salvation.In the final section of this book, Miller provides a fascinating discussion of the major New England Puritan innovation; Covenant theology.  This approach pulled the sting of the remote Calvinist God by binding him in a voluntary contract that allowed some scope for human action.  Miller demonstrates how this system developed under the stimulus of other Protestant theological challenges, as well as the specific political circumstances of early 17th century England.  There is a particularly interesting following discussion of how the covenant concept was expanded to political and church government covenants, accounting for a number of the unique features of New England life.  As with other features of Puritan thought, this one contained some internal contradictions that would have ironic consequences in the future.While intellectually demanding, this book is a pleasure to read.  Miller was not only a remarkably insightful scholar but also a brilliant writer.  Among 20th century American historians, no one wrote better.

A pretty conventional potboiler based on the idea that Himmler's pursuit of ancient occult weapons actually led somewhere.  This is hardly a new idea and there are a number of books involving supernatural conflicts accompanying WWII, not to mention Raiders of the Lost Ark.  Richards introduces little that is novel.  The quality of writing is pedestrian.  It reads like a mediocre TV series, not surprising as the author has apparently written quite a bit for TV.  I suspect this book is a knockoff of a considerably more successful series pursuing the same general idea, Charles Stross' entertaining Laundry series.  If you're intrigued by this general concept and looking for a much superior effort along these lines, try Stross.

An interesting, very well researched, and generally solidly written book on the apparently narrow topic of musket manufacture in France before and during the French Revolution.  This is a very ambitious book.  Alder is interested in writing history of technology as a form of social and political history.  A recurrent and much discussed theme in this book is that technologies do not occur in a vacuum but rather reflect social and political realities and sometime embody the objectives and needs of their makers.  Musket manufacture in this context has several interesting dimensions.  Efforts to reform and improve manufacture was spearheaded by French artillery engineers, a early effort at a meritocratic managerial elite.  A good deal of this book is about the status and efforts of this group under Ancien Regime, and their interactions with traditional institutions of the Ancien Regime, including the royal bureaucracy and established craft-based manufacturing.  Alder presents this as an aspect of the Enlightenment in a military form.  These efforts continue after the Revolution, particularly in the form of what Alder terms techno-Jacobinism as part of an effort to transform French society, particularly under the threat of internal disunion and external threat.Intertwined with this story is another theme, that of recurrent and ultimately failed efforts to develop manufacturing based on mechanization and interchangeable parts, something that would only be achieved in the USA decades later under the stimulus of Ordnance Department efforts.  Alder argues well that the up and downs of these efforts were more related to social and political factors than technical obstacles per se.  Alder has some interesting discussion of the nature of proto-industrialization in France and differences with Britain and the USA.Parts of the book are somewhat repetitive as Alder revisits some issues from different perspectives.  Alder tends to belabor the social-political nature of the history of technology, making fairly obvious points repeatedly.  There is a bit too much discussion of theoretical-historiographic issues, again somewhat repetitive discussion of fairly obvious points.

An anthology of stories based in SM Stirling's future history of the The Change, a world in which all industrial and some pre-industrial technologies no longer work.  Quite variable, both in terms of quality of writing and the degree of imagination in each story.  The principal interest of fiction like this is the articulation of the imagined future history.  A few of these stories add something to Stirling's vision, most do not.  Most are adventure stories of varying degrees of competence.
