This very interesting book is worth reading for 2 reasons.  First, the authors' list of major transitions in evolution concisely identified a series of particularly important research areas.  Second, the authors' discussions of each of these transitions are nice analyses of information about and potential explanations for each of the transitions.  The framework erected by the list of major transitions apparently has had durable value in guiding a good deal of research.  Some of the individual sections are now unavoidably dated, as their has been significant additional research and real progress in some of these areas.  The authors focus on major transitions that involve the development of or major changes in the way information is transmitted between generations, for example the emergence of chromosomes or sexual reproduction.  Another major theme is the emergence of increasing complexity, in particular, the recurrent phenomenon of independently replicating entities evolving into entities that replicate only as part of a larger whole.  Examples are the development of multicellularity and sociality.  All the transitions are discussed in the context of evolutionary theory and selective advantage, which is key to understanding the transitions.  For some of the transitions, such as the origin of compartmentalization, the discussions are about plausible reconstructions.  For others, such as the evolution of sex, there is considerable data to discuss.  While this book was written with biologists in mind (the authors also wrote a corresponding popular book), the arguments are laid out clearly and there are abundant, useful charts and diagrams to illustrate the authors' arguments.While it was written about 20 years ago, many aspects of this book have a strongly contemporary flavor.  The authors discuss, for example, the origins of eukaryotes and the root phylogeny of life.  An important discovery was recently made on this topic.  In their section on development, there is a discussion of Turing's model for development, which the authors discuss as a theoretical construct.  Evidence for the reality of Turing-like mechanisms in development was published in Science within the last couple of years.  In their discussion of the development of human sociality, the authors suggest that important social mechanisms emerged initially in the context of kin selection and then were extended to non-kin.  Again, this idea is supported by some interesting, recently published research.  Maynard Smith and Szathmary clearly identified a series of important research areas and provide a nice way of thinking about these problems generally, a substantial achievement.

An interesting and enjoyable collection of short stories. Death and historical memory are recurrent themes in these stories.  These are generally written in what might be called a Borgesian style, with a mixture of the fabulous and the mundane, pursuit of the themes in what might be called a metaphysical manner, pseudohistorical vignettes, and parodies of scholarship. The best stories, such as the one that provides the title for the collection, are very interesting.  All are at least interesting.

This well written, very well researched, and thoughtful book is an excellent biography of the great abolitionist leader William Lloyd Garrison.  One of Mayer's goals was to rescue Garrison from relative obscurity and demonstrate his central role in the great controversies that led to the Civil War.  Mayer succeeds admirably, partly because Garrison is a generally attractive and in important respects modern figure.  The child of a father who abandoned his family, Garrison had a somewhat difficult childhood and youth.  While he was the beneficiary of the New England commitment to primary education, the talented Garrison was very much an autodidact.  Apprenticed to a printer as teen, he acquired the skills that would permit his career as a pioneering abolitionist journalist.  Mayer is particularly good on the motivations for Garrison's commitments to human rights; a combination of heterodox and fervent religious beliefs with a Romantic belief in individual capacity.  Garrison's expansive view of humanity led him to the anti-slavery cause.  One of the few Americans who really believed in the equality of African-Americans, he followed this principles logically to become an early advocate of women's rights.Mayer shows Garrison's commitment and diligence in what must have appeared initially a hopeless cause.  Over the course of decades, Garrison and his colleagues, many of them the first women to be important figures in American politics, were significant factors in the transformation of Northern political opinion.  Mayer is particularly good on important and interesting aspects of Garrison's life and the abolitionist movement. Garrison aimed at a moral, not political transformation of American life.  His moral perfectionism drove his pacifism, his skepticism towards the established churches that he saw as compromising with evil, and his suspicion of conventional politics.  Garrison's famous attack on the Constitution and advocacy of peaceful disunion was a logical result of his perfectionism.  Garrison's life, which included participation in spiritualism and anti-sabbatarianism, was in some respects a characteristic manifestation of the radical religious experimentation of 19th century American life.  Mayer also narrates the complex internal politics of the anti-slavery movement quite well.Garrison was not, however, dogmatic.  With the outbreak of the Civil War, the life long pacifist supported the Republican government.  He saw the war correctly as an opportunity for emancipation.  Initially quite skeptical of Lincoln, over the course of the war, he became a de facto Radical Republican.  He was, however, deeply disappointed by the failure of Reconstruction and the collapse of the Republican commitment to equal rights for African-Americans.  His reputation suffered after the war as an increasingly conservative and racist America came to view abolitionist "fanaticism" as one of the causes of the war.While this is an excellent biography, I think there is at least one point that Mayer gets wrong.  He emphasizes Garrison's role in the gradual transformation of Northern opinion towards slavery.  I suspect this is correct but incomplete.  In some ways, Garrison's most important audience was not in the North but in the South.  Garrison and other abolitionists were regarded with actual fear by many Southerners.  The greatest act of censorship in American history was the ban, enforced by the Federal government, on circulation of abolitionist publications in the South.  Abolitionists were a fringe political movement in the North but apparently frightened Southerners in a manner out of proportion to their actual influence.  Southern insecurity about their Peculiar Institution drove much of the relatively aggressive political behavior of Southern politicians, leading to increasing resentment on the part of the Northern public. The transformation of Northern political opinion was partly an ironic result of abolitionist activities.

A bit disappointing because of the quality of Cambias' last book.  This is a fairly straightforward action thriller based on the premise of Moon based mining to support fusion reactors on Earth and a form of space piracy.  The technical aspects are clever but the plotting and quality of writing are pedestrian.

A well written and thoroughly researched account of the Zionist terrorist campaign against British rule in Palestine.  Hoffman, an authority on contemporary terrorism, is interested in rebutting the commonly held notion that terrorism inevitably fails.  Hoffman's clear and detailed narrative demonstrates well that the Zionist terrorist campaign played a significant role in undermining British rule in Palestine.  Initiated by disciples of the Revisionist Zionist Jabotinsky and later gaining considerable support among the Jewish community of Palestine, the terrorist campaign made Palestine harder to govern, become an enormous drain on scarce British resources, and considerably complicated the crucial US-British relationship.  The exhausted British eventually washed their hands of Palestine and turned the problem over to the nascent UN.  Hoffman is careful not to portray the terrorist campaign as decisive but it clearly had a significant impact.  He doesn't dwell on the irony of terrorism being part of the foundation of the state of Israel, but then, he doesn't have to.The strengths of this book, based on extensive and novel archival research, is the narrative of the terrorist campaigns, the detailed description of British policies, and the responses of the mainstream of the Jewish community in Palestine.  Hoffman is quite critical of British policies, faulting the British for lack of a clear strategic focus, poor tactics, and general incompetence in intelligence gathering and other aspects of counter-terrorism.  Hoffman's critique appears to be correct but sometimes a bit shallow.  He criticizes the British correctly for not being able to formulate clear policy but never explicitly links this fact to the basic contradiction of British rule in Palestine; the inherent impossibility of satisfying both the Jewish and Arab populations.  The very detailed focus is both the strength of the book and weakness as Hoffman doesn't include important context.  Zionist terrorism was not the first successful terrorist campaign in the British Empire - that would be the Irish revolt.  Nationalist terrorism was fairly widespread in the interwar Empire with successful terrorism in Ireland and some Indian nationalists pursuing terrorist activities.  Hoffman occasionally mentions the successful Irish revolt against Britain, which was broadly known and must have been influential.  Hoffman several times expresses surprise at fluctuating British troop levels in the interwar period but there is no apparent awareness of the strains faced by the British in the interwar period.  Is there any relationship between the uprising in Iraq, unrest in India, revolt in Burma, and widespread labor unrest in Malaya, and the oscillations of British troop commitments in Palestine.  Similarly, Hoffman omits a crucial fact about post-WWII British-US relations.  He presents the American lack of support for British efforts and frequent support for the Zionist cause as primarily a matter of internal US politics and success of Zionist lobbying.  These were undoubtedly significant contributing factors but its also true that the Roosevelt-Truman administration had a generally negative attitude towards colonial empires and supported decolonialization in the postwar period.

Probably the best of NIven's novels.  This book is set in a particularly ingenious solar system in which there is a livable zero-low gravity biosphere.  As is typical for this type of book, the plot is primarily designed to advance exploration of the novel world.  In contrast to most of Niven's work, which features technology beyond our present capabilities, the human characters in this book are at an essentially neolithic level of technology.

This book appears to have been marketed in the USA as a thriller or crime novel.  It is, in fact, a serious effort to examine the nature of evil.  It contains 3 components; a police procedural narrative of the hunt for a serial killer in WWII Berlin, a narrative of an effort to prosecute German war criminals in the late 50s and early 60s, and an autobiographical account by the principal character of his participation in numerous war crimes in WWII Minsk.  The latter is about 1/2 the book.  Inspired by an actual case of a German policeman prosecuted in the early 1960s, Thomas drew on the documentary record and other sources such as Christopher Browning's excellent books.  Thomas is a competent, as opposed to gifted, writer but his unornamented descriptions of atrocities are powerful.  Thomas is interested in the relationship between careerism and evil, how crimes are defined, and the amnesia of 1950s Germany.  None of these topics are explored in depth but this is a surprisingly effective book.

This well written  and thoughtful analysis argues convincingly for the emergence of a form of nationalism in France during the 18th century.  Bell demonstrates that French intellectuals and politicians, including many of the initial figures of the Revolution, had a conception of France as a nation in something approximating the modern sense and also appreciated that this was a goal, not the reality of the existing France.  Bell traces the roots of the emerging French conception of the nation to several sources.  Increasing irreligion, fostered inadvertently by the Jansenist conception of a remote God, led to a search of an alternative, secular way to organize political society.  Expanding commerce, urbanization, literacy, and a secular public sphere created opportunities for alternative, irreligious concepts of society.  The French monarchy cultivated nascent nationalism, particularly under the stresses of imperial rivalry of Britain, often using the British as the proverbial "Other."  In the greatest irony, when the Revolutionaries and others needed to actualize the secular nation, their primary organizational model was the effort of the Counter-Reformation Church to reinvigorate Catholicism, particularly in the countryside, often giving nationalism the structural features of a religious cult.  Bell's arguments for his analysis are generally convincing and based on analysis of primary documents, the large secondary literatures on the Revolution and 18th century France, and a thoughtful appraisal of the literature on nationalism.  There is a nice concluding section summarizing the arguments and emphasizing the subsequent continuity of French nationalism.  One thing that surprised me was relatively little discussion of Britain as a model for France.  My impression is that a useful way to think about the earliest phase of the Revolution is that it was an effort to mimic important features of the British polity.  An unregulated internal market, uniform legal code, legislature as an at least equal power for the monarchy, aggressive external mercantilism, church subordinated to the state - all features of Britain and implemented under the early Revolution.
The first volume of a projected space opera trilogy.  Several conventional devices are used but not in an original way.  The quality of writing is below mediocre.

An interesting, well written, and analytically strong book describing the emergence of the Gilded Age plutocracy as a self-conscious class.  Beckert describes this group as bourgeoisie, using the term in a restricted way to denote individuals possessing a significant amount of capital, and focuses on the epicenter of Gilded Age capitalism, New York City (NYC).  By the 1850s, NYC was the dominant American commercial center and contained a substantial bourgeoisie.  This group, however, was politically and socially divided.  Most important were the more traditional mercantile interests thriving on NYC's great success as an entrepot driven by booming American cotton exports.  These individuals were economically and politically aligned with southern slaveholders, and supported the Democratic party.  The smaller group of emerging manufacturers tended to support the Republican Party, its Free Soil-Free Labor ideology, and containment of slavery.  The outbreak of the Civil War transformed the NYC bourgeoisie, which became rapidly committed to the survival of the Union and crucial partners for the Federal government.  With the huge burst of Federal expenditures driven by the war effort and the Republican commitment to tariff protection and economic development, manufacturing boomed.  The manufacturers became increasingly important though the more traditional mercantile interests also found ways, particularly in finance, to benefit from the new political economy.  But increasing manufacturing brought increased proletarianization and class conflict, staring with the 1863 Draft Riots, contributing significantly to the class consciousness of the bourgeoisie.  Many of these trends continued after the war.  With the booming American economy and expanding industry, NYC became even more economically powerful, more populous, and socially stratified.  Beckert shows the ways in which the NYC bourgeoisie essentially co-opted the Federal government to become the dominant group in the US.  The account of bourgeoisie political and economic dominance is accompanied by interesting discussions of the other ways in which the NYC (and increasingly national) bourgeoisie developed as a self-conscious class, including local politics and cultural activities.  A good deal of the analysis is quite interesting.  Beckert makes the interesting point that in the absence of a native aristocracy, the American bourgeoisie has little competition in their efforts to dominate the central government.  Implicit in some of his discussions is the idea that the American bourgeoisie were particularly successful in suppressing the American labor movement and this may account for the failure of a strong socialist movement in the USA.

This well written book is a fine overview of Hume's philosophy from a leading Hume scholar.  The book's organization is notable and effective.  Garrett opens with a nice biographical chapter and concludes with an equally nice, concise chapter on Hume's influence from his death to the present.  The intervening 8 chapters offer a very useful description and analysis of the major themes of Hume's philosophy.  Garrett stresses the unity of Hume's work throughout his life by avoilding a chronological approach but rather cites both earller (the Treatise) and later (the Enquiries) work as he works through the major aspects of Hume's philosophy.  Hume's empirical "Science of Man" is the starting point with chapters on Hume's analysis of how the mind works, followed by chapters on how the human (and Humean) mind generates normativity.  This is folllowed by chapters on Hume's well known treatments of induction & causation, skepticism, morality, and religion.  Garrett writes clearly, explains topics well, and is, I think, rigorous in his interpretations.  He particularly emphasizes Hume's naturalism as the key feature of his thought, downplaying interpretations that tend to emphasize skeptical aspects of Hume's thought.  I think this book can be read profitably by neophytes and those with some experience in reading Hume.  This is a well produced book with a nice introduction, a useful glossary, and solid bibliography.  My only criticism is that I wish Garrett would have included a chapter on Hume's other important writings, specifically political theory, political economy. and history.

A well written and unusual but somewhat uneven fantasy novel from this talented writer.  Gilman bases his plot on Victorian spiritualism and attempts to use magic to penetrate "higher spheres."  The basic idea is ingenious and the quality of writing and character development is strong.  The second half of the book, however, tends to meander a bit, and the conclusion is somewhat unsatisfactory.  This is definitely better than the great run of fantasty novels but not at the level of Gilman's last 2 books.

Written for a broad audience, this is a very effective exposition of an interesting hypothesis put forward several years ago by the author.  Ruddiman argues that major anthropenic effects on the climate system system started millenia ago with the spread of agriculture.  He opens with a nice overview of oscillations between glacial and interglacial periods over the past several million years.  He then follows with a similarly nice overview of human prehistory.  Ruddiman then lays out his hypothesis; he argues that the natural history of interglacials is initial warming and greenhouse gas rise, followed by a slow decline in both and global temperatures until reglaciation begins. About 7K years ago, however, our interglacial deviated from this pattern with a rise in methane and CO2 interrupting global cooling.  He suggests that this greenhouse gas rise was due to the spread of agriculture and based on widespread deforestation and methane production secondary particularly to paddy agriculture and livestock farming.  Much of the following text is devoted to a critical evaluation of this idea in which Ruddiman discussing the implications of his hypothesis, supporting data, alternative explanations, and the general state of knowledge about this concept. Ruddiman has very nice and concise expositions, with generally useful illustrations, of a great deal of recent climate data and methods.  While Ruddiman is obviously a partisan of this idea, I think he is admirably fair in terms of discussing objections and alternatives.  He continues to refer to this idea as a hypothesis and suggests further analyses to test the idea.  Overall, I found his ideas convincing.  He also discusses some plausible extensions of the core idea.  He suggests that if the emergence of agriculture aborted a slide towards the next Ice Age, the more recent industrial increase in greenhouse gases has essentially "reset" the global climate sequence, derailing the oscillatory glacial-interglacial pattern.  He suggests also that some historically important climate fluctuations, the end of Roman Warm Period and the Little Ice Age, were the result of changes in human populations.I think there are a couple of relatively minor problems with this book.  Ruddiman ventures into philosophy of science by using his experience to examine different versions of scientific progression, essentially Popper versus Kuhn.  I think this section is misleading in the sense that he mischaracterizes both Popper's and Kuhn's arguments.  As is commonly the case with scientists, he latches onto the idea that his hypothesis represents a new "paradigm."  In fact, Kuhn's model is likely wrong and Ruddiman's work is a nice example of the functioning of Kuhn's "normal science."  I'm also a bit skeptical about his ideas that human population changes drove the end of the Roman Warm period and Little Ice Age, though he could be correct.

This is not the best of Le Carre's book but is still considerably better than the general run of thrillers.  This book expresses Le Carre's general disgust with British foreign policy, other aspects of British life, and the so-called war on terror.  The quality of writing and character development is quite good, and the plotting is reasonably suspenseful.

A model of concise exposition and analysis, this well written and thoughtful book characterizes the essential features and history of the development of the concept of distributive justice.  Fleischacker's essential point is that distributive justice is a relatively new concept.  Fleischacker opens by developing a fairly strict definition of distributive justice, emphasizing its essentially secular nature and redistributive features.  He then shows, contrary to quite a few other assertions, that this concept differs considerably from Classical, Medieval, and Early Modern European concepts of justice.  These earlier concepts associate forms of justice with merit, emphasize forms of redistribution with charity, and generally exhibit a disparaging attitude towards the poor.  By the end of the 18th century, attitudes begin to change.  Fleischacker identifies Hume, and particularly Adam Smith, as key figures with their treatments of the poor as moral equals.  Over the course of the 19th and 20th centuries, a variety of other thinkers, including Utilitarians and Marx, contribute different concepts that were later used to formulate the modern concept of distributive justice.  John Rawls is credited with both the initial modern formulation and the prominence that distributive justice assumed in subsequent discussions.  There is a nice discussion of subsequent criticisms of Rawls and further developments.  There are excellent endnotes and bibliography.

An interesting but somewhat specialized short book, originally a set of lectures, by the great Classicist Arnaldo Momigliano on the topic of the Hellenistic encounter with other cultures.  To a considerable extent, this is an effort to maximize the information available from a relatively limited set of texts.  Its impressive how often Momigliano discusses authors whom we know only from fragmentary quotations in surviving works.  Momigliano's basic theme is the relative lack of interest displayed by Greek intellectuals in important surrounding cultures such as the Celts, Jews, Iranians, and even Romans.  This is despite a tradition of geographic and ethnographic works such as some of Herodotus.  Some of these non-Greek cultures, in contrast, most famously the Romans and even the Jews showed a significant interest in and ability to utilize the Greek intellectual tradition.  Momigliano connects this intellectual tendency with the ultimate subordination of Hellenistic states by the Romans.

An interesting and well written monograph on the antebellum Southern debate over re-opening the trans-Atlantic slave trade.  In the 1850s, a number of radical Southerners proposed allowing slave importation.  Takaki shows nicely that this was largely a debate among Southerners with pro-slave trade arguments motivated by different and sometimes conflicting impulses.  In general, the driving force was the general Southern insecurity and moral unease about the Peculiar Institution.  Some pro-slave trade advocates saw it as a way to generate an issue provoking a final division from the North, others as a way of boosting the waning political power of the South, others as boosting the economy of the South and reducing class tensions, and others, in a rather bizarre way, as a form of moral balm.  Takaki describes the motivations and arguments of both pro-slave trade and anti-slave trade Southerners quite well.  The latter included pragmatic arguments from those with a vested interest in the internal slave trade, as well as arguments that remaining within the Union was the best way to safeguard slavery.  Well documented, this book provides a useful view of antebellum Southern politics and life.

An excellent combination of analysis, narrative, and revealing anecdote, this book is essential for understanding for the state of many American cities and of the fraught relationships between white and black Americans.  At the end of WWII, Detroit was a dynamic industrial center.  Emerging from the largest municipal bankruptcy in American history, Detroit today is the epitome of post-industrial failure and is, to a considerable extent, an enormous ghetto populated by immiserated African-Americans.  Sugrue traces the downfall of Detroit, starting in the late 1940s, and emphasizing the synergistic effects of several negative factors on African-American Detroiters.  While African-Americans benefited considerably from the re-energization of the American economy during WWII, and anticipated continued progress in the post-WWII period, they entered the late 40s in highly disadvantaged positions.  Both residential and occupational segregation worked to the considerable disadvantage of African-Americans. A combination of formal, considerable bias in Federal mortgage support, and informal, frank racial prejudice on the part of employers and working class whites, restricted the opportunities of African-Americans.  Sugrue then points to a third crucial factor, the early de-industrialization of Detroit.  In a harbinger of things to come, the major auto firms began to automate to shed workers and also moved plants to areas with lower labor costs and less potential for aggressive unionization - particularly smaller cities in Ohio and Indiana, and the South.  African-American workers were hit particularly hard by these job losses, and suffered disproportionately as shrinking work opportunities restricted entry level jobs. Whites, with greater labor mobility, suffered considerably less.  Sugrue also shows the depth and dynamics of residential segregation particularly well.  White resistance to integration was a combination of overtly racist politics and frequent physical violence, explaining much of the subsequent bitterness of politics in Detroit.  The ultimate result was a self-reinforcing downward spiral, which while probably not inevitable, was likely hard to derail.  Two aspects of Sugrue's analysis are particularly noteworthy.  The first, mentioned above, is his identification of early de-industrialization.  The second is his recurrent point that to a considerable extent, this was an intramural conflict between different components of the New Deal coalition in which race trumped class.  Quite well written, this book is notable for Sugrue's smooth integration (no pun intended) of quantitative data, narrative, and telling individual stories.  His combination of primary archival research and analysis of prior secondary literature is excellent.  This edition contains a concise and thoughtful Preface that brings the story up to the recent bankrupcy and traces the continued effects of processes occurring decades earlier.

An interesting set of essays, presented originally as the Sather lectures in the early 1960s.  Momigliano explores how the work of classical historians like Herodotus, Thucydides, Tacitus, and others became the foundation of modern historical writing.  In particular, he credits Greek intellectuals with developing the critical approach that characterizes our conception of historical writing.  These essays deal mainly with nature of the work of classical historians, including the originator of Church history, Eusebius.  By his own admission, Momigliano doesn't really deal with why these Classical writers became so influential in early modern Europe.  A number of interesting aspects are discussed.  Herodotus as the founder of a tradition that included ethnography and a broader perspective on the past, Thucydides as the exemplar of what came to be in many ways the standard of political-military history, and the Romans as the originators of national histories.  These essays contain a good deal of insightful commentary and feature Momigliano's impressive erudition.

A really impressive work of scholarship from a leading expert on 17th century thought.  This is the first of a planned series of 5 volumes describing the emergence of modern scientific culture.  Gaukroger's goal is to understand how the Western natural scientific approach became the paradigmatic way of understanding the world, a decisive break with all prior forms of human approaches to understanding the world.  In this detailed volume, Gaukroger lays out the crucial intellectual developments that led to the emergence of modern scientific culture in 17th century Europe.  In particular, Gaukroger seeks to understand how this nascent approach developed and became legitimized.  It was not, he stresses, because it necessarily produces more useful technologies (though it would eventually).  Gaukroger argues that it developed as part of efforts to support Christian theology.  Looking back to medieval theology, and even farther back to Patristic and Classical thought, Gaurkroger argues that the Thomistic-Aristotelian synthesis encountered considerable difficulties in early modern Europe and ultimately became unsatisfactory as a prop for Christianity.  The Neoplatonically inspired competitor of Augustinian thought was also unsatisfactory and the increasing awareness of and interest in other Classical schools of thought such as Stoicism and Epicurianism fed considerable intellectual ferment.  These complex interactions began to incorporate other influences, such as a nascent experimental tradition and increased emphasis on quantification.  Emerging from these many complex interactions towards the end of 17th century was the precursor of modern science, including a whole new conception of the role of an active investigator.  In the long run, these processes would drive considerable challenges to religion but in the period discussed, religious motivations were a key to legitimizing this new approach to the world.Written primarily for other scholars, this is not an easy book to read.  Gaukroger is a clear writer but is discussing at a high level a lot of fairly abstruse early modern and premodern thought which will be unfamiliar to many readers.  Its worth persevering with reading this book because of the impressive depth of the analysis.  There is, however, a bit of losing the forest for the trees quality.  Because of his detailed analysis of many thinkers and their work, its easy to lose sight of the basic pattern of Gaukroger's argument.  I recommend reading his concise Conclusion section at the end first and then going on with the rest of the book.This is very much "internal" intellectual history and broader events only rarely make their appearance.  I'm not sure that the word Reformation is ever used, even though many of the thinkers discussed were embedded in the intellectual context of the Reformation.  A broader point that might be extracted from this work are the important roles of contingent events.  It appears that the Thomistic-Aristotelian synthesis had the power that it did in part because Platonic thought came to Europe later than Aristotelian thought.  Similarly, this book might be considered as evidence of the importance of intellectual conflict and interactions in European history - conflict between features of Christianity and the Classical heritage, and conflict between Aristotle and Plato.

A generally strong and well presented history of slavery in the American South from 1783 to the outbreak of the Civil War and with a short coda on subsequent events.  This is a very ambitious book using a combination of original research and the extensive secondary literature on this topic.  Baptist's aim is to delineate the major features of American slavery, provide a narrative of its evolution over this period, and to address how it fits into the larger frame of American, and indeed, world history.  At the same time, he wants to give readers a more vivid impression of the actual experience of slavery.  The result is a combination of some reasonably quantititive analysis, narrative, and individual vignettes.  For the latter, Baptist draws on 19th century memoirs and accounts compiled by the WPA in the 1930s.  While generally following a chronologic sequence, each chapter explores a different thematic aspect of Southern slavery using a combination of analysis and anecdotes.  This is largely quite successful, as Baptist's analyses are often illuminating and the anecdotes are quite telling.  Baptist describes the many of the major features of American slavery very well.  The great importance of American slavery in the development of the US and emerging world industrial economy, the enormous domestic slave trade, the crucial role of slavery in the American political system, the brutality of the plantation regime (which Baptist unconventionally but accurately calls slave labor camps), and the nature of African-American resistance.Knowledgeable readers of American history will recognize much of Baptist's narrative and analysis from other works.  With some exceptions, a good deal of what he describes has been discussed in other work.  One of the virtues of this book is that he has synthesized a great deal of prior scholarship into a more coherent whole.  There is more, however, here than a synthesis of prior scholarship.  Some of his analysis, notably the discussion of slave productivity in cotton production and the nature of financing slavery expansion prior to the mid-1830s crash, strike me as relatively novel.There are some potential defects.  Its possible that Baptist has under-emphasized some points.  For example, he regards Southern arguments about expansion being necessary to diffuse slavery and reduce its impact as window dressing.  Perhaps, but it may be that many Southerners wished to avoid concentration of slaves in the Deep South because of fears of a Haitian type of slave insurrection.  He discusses that the drive for slavery expansion was prompted in part by Southern desire for additional slave states that could contribute to Southern power in Congress, which is certainly correct. Baptist doesn't mention, however, William Freehling's argument that the erosion of slavery in the Upper South was driving Southern insecurity and fears of border states becoming like Northern states.  An arguably bigger defect is Baptist's style.  Baptist is generally a clear writer but employs a self-consciously literary device; he uses Ralph Ellison's image of "...American life as a drama enacted on the body of a giant Negro..." to organize the book.  Individual chapters are titled, Heart, Feet, Heads, etc.  This works reasonably well but Baptist sometimes extends the metaphor too far, resulting in some fairly purple prose.  This is a matter of taste, but in my opinion, literary devices tend to obscure understanding.

A ingenious and thoughtful fantasy novel based on the idea of trying to reproduce Plato's Republic.  Walton has a clever plot using the actual existence of the Olympian gods and a variety of real historical figures collaborating to start a city-state based on Plato's Republic.  As the Just City evolves, problems and contradictions in Plato's system emerge.  In a particularly nice touch, Walton then brings about a climactic crisis by introducing Sokrates into the Just City.

A well written and somewhat polemical overview of the nature of empires.  Parsons, an expert on the British Empire, appears to have been motivated to write this book by disgust with the attempts of some intellectuals and pundits to justify our disastrous decision to invade Iraq by offering highly misleading versions of the benefits of imperialism In this book, Parsons presents a series of counter-examples by reviewing the histories of several imperial adventures.  Parsons' counter-examples include Roman Britain, Umayyad Spain, Spanish Peru, British India, Napoleonic Italy, British Kenya, and German occupied France.  Basic features of the imperial experience are conquest, subjugation, and exploitation.  Dependence of the imperial powers on local elites for governance, corruption of the imperial powers, and local resistance contributing to ultimate failure of the imperial power are recurring themes. All of this is quite different from the rosy picture of "liberal imperialism," which is usually exploitation disguised as a civilizing mission, described by Bush II apologists.  Parsons finishes with a short chapter describing our experience in Iraq which he shows exhibits all the negative features of imperial adventures, with the added dimension that the Bush administration was particularly incompetent as a pseudo-imperial power.

This concise book is a useful and surprisingly pertinent narrative of efforts by Anglo-American thinkers to develop an ethics based on evolutionary biology.  Farber begins with Darwin himself, who was primarily concerned with what we would now call the meta-ethical issue of whether human morality as a phenomenon could be reconciled with natural selection.  Farber then proceeds to the very influential Herbert Spencer who attempted to erect an actual ethical system on the base of his own, rather teleological and Lamarckian, version of evolution.  The efforts of Spencer and other Victorian thinkers who attempted to build evolutionary ethical systems to fill the void left by declines in religious authority were met with sharp and devastating criticism from several quarters, including prominent biologists like Huxley and Wallace.  Professional philosophers like Henry Sidgwick and TH Green, though coming from very different philosophical perspectives, offered particularly trenchant criticisms.  None of the evolutionary ethical formulations, for example, were able to escape the is/ought problem posed by Hume.  As Farber shows, efforts at evolutionary ethics continued among biologists and popularizers in the US and Britain, and continued to exhibit many of the same defects.  These efforts received a boost with the great success of the Modern Synthesis of evolutionary theory in the mid-20th century and elicited much the same kind of critical reaction from critical biologists and philosophers.  In his concluding chapters, Farber offers a sympathetic but critical discussion of the sociobiology controversy provoked by EO Wilson's famous book, which has similar features.  As Farber remarks, its as if no one has been aware of the prior discussion dating back to the second half of the 19th century.  The pertinent part of this book is that we're now seeing virtually identical discussions with some scientists and popularizers putting forth fairly naive arguments about "evolutionary psychology" and neuroscience as bases for ethics.

An enjoyable combination of "hard" SF and a political novel.  The quality of writing is above average for this genre and the plot is something more than a convenient armature for Bear's clever ideas.  Bear uses the traditional device of following the maturation of the heroine, an effective method for introducing readers to the novel future world he constructs.  Like many SF novels, this one perhaps tries to pack too many novel ideas into a single book.

An anthology of the later work of the noted Irish poet Seamus Heaney.  This book is primarily a selection of his original work but includes selections of some translations, notably from his powerful translation of Beowulf.  There are many striking poems in this collection.  Important themes are death and remembered connections with deceased family and friends.

An interesting effort combining historical analysis and political theory, aimed at defending or perhaps modernizing the concept of equality.  The author is a well known French historian and political theorist.  I suspect this book is an effort to produce a shorter, more popular account of a larger body of work.  Rosanvallon opens with a short description of the concept of equality in the French and American Revolutions.  Rosanvallon argues well that equality was an important goal of both revolutions.  This was rooted in the Enlightenment attack on privilege and in Rosanvallon's analysis, aimed at producing a society of "similars," characterized by individual autonomy and citizenship.  In this construct, market relations were crucial to undermining established privilege and producing a society in which individuals could interact on a more or less equal footing.  I was initially skeptical about some of Rosanvallon's analysis of Enlightenment equalitarianism but this book was favorably reviewed by a real expert on this topic, Gordon Wood, in the American Historical Review.  This interesting section is followed by 3 chapters on the historical evolution of equality.  Rosanvallon sees the Enlightenment-Revolutionary emphasis on and concepts of equality as undermined by the emergence of industrial capitalism (Rosanvallon uses the term capitalism) which led to novel forms of inequality.  In turn, this leads to what he terms of pathologies of equality; ideologies that attempted to use different aspects of the concept of equality to either justify (classical liberalism) or attack (Marxism) or defend (nationalism and economic protectionism) the inequalities of industrial society.  At the end of 19th century, there is at least partial success with attempts to restore important aspects of equality via progressive taxation, social insurance, and unionization.  These efforts are promoted, at least in Europe, by some of the traumatic events of the 20th century, notably the 2 world wars and the Great Depression.  The next chapter deals with the more recent neo-liberal erosion of equality.  I found this section to be the least satisfactory in terms of analysis. Towards the end of this chapter, Rosanvallon takes on what is probably his real target, the need for a new adequate theory of equality that updates the Enlightenment-Revolutionary concept and restores equality to its central position.  This analysis includes a critique of theories of equality like those developed by the American philosopher Ronald Dworkin.  Rosanvallon suggests, in particular, that existing ideas about equality don't take into account the importance of individuals developing their own unique capacities.  In a complement to the Enlightenment-Revolutionary concept, he suggests that the 3 pillars of equality should be "singularity, reciprocity, and commonality."  What does this mean in practical terms?  Rosanvallon is pretty vague, and while he states in the opening of the book that there is no going back to the older welfare state, I suspect this means the return of aggressively progressive taxation and more investment in the social safety net, important features of the welfare state.

A very good and mildly polemical overview of the Enlightenment.  In this well written book, Pagden emphasizes the Enlightenment pursuit of a "science of man" and its ethical, political, and social implication.  Major themes include the skepticism towards dogma, irreligion, naturalism, emulation of the methods of the natural sciences, and increasing emphasis on both the autonomy and power of human capacities.  Pagden uses a combined historical and thematic approach,  In initial chapters he defines the features of the Enlightenment and outlines its historical origins in the Reformation, the collapse of religious consensus in Europe, the destruction of the Aristotleian-Thomistic synthesis, and the emergence of modern science in the 17th century.  This is followed by a series of thematic chapters discussing moral psychology, ecularism, the unity of humanity, ethics, political theory, and other aspects of 18th Enlightenment thought.  A key concept for Pagden is cosmopolitanism, the recognition of universal human nature coupled with a healthy respect for many important varying aspects of human behavior and social organization.  Driven by intrinsic human sociability, cosmopolitanism involves the recognition of fundamental human equality, universal human rights, broad tolerance, and a liberal political order.  While Pagden defends many aspects of Enlightenment thought, he is not shy about criticizing failings of many important figures, such as Kant's notorious misogyny.  In the final chapter, Pagden offers a useful defense of the Enlightenment against some modern critics.There is an important aspect that Pagden may have omitted.  In some ways, this is a fairly traditional account with Pagden focusing on philosophers and literary figures, though the work of the great biologist Buffon is discussed.  Advances in 18th century science and some advances in technology should be considered an important aspect of the Enlightenment, and may well have played an important role in sustaining the credibility and power of the movement.

An average procedural attempting drawing on Swedish political events during the Cold War.  The author's intent is clearly to produce some social commentary on recent Swedish history.  Much of this will probably be of interest only to Swedish audiences and the general quality of writing is workmanlike, as opposed to good.  Some readers may pick up these books because they are described as the inspiration for recent American TV series (Backstrom).  This book, at least, is quite different from the TV series and anyone looking for something similar will be disappointed.

A well written narrative and analysis of how the US and Canadian health care systems diverged in the 1960s.  Maioni points out the considerable similarities between the US and Canada in health care delivery and overall social structure up through the 1930s.  Why then were divergent paths pursued?  Maioni focuses on a set of structural features and at least one major contingent process.  The structural features are differences in political systems, notably the parliamentary system and relatively stronger degree of federalism in Canada.  These features favored the development of strong regional and third parties, with the consequent emergence of a viable social democratic party supported strongly by the Canadian labor movement.  Unlike the USA, where the Federal government was the most dynamic actor responding the crisis of the Great Depression, the Canadian Federal government was relatively inert during the 1930s, and emerging from WWII, there was considerable pressure across the political spectrum to pursue social welfare reforms.  With the social democratic CCF-NDP pulling the debate to the left and with the Canadian parliamentary system less susceptible to legislative lobbying, national health insurance emerged as a Canadian institution.  In the US, the labor movement and other advocates of more sweeping reform had to function within the broad coalition of the Democratic Party, which significantly constrained achievable goals, and led to the more limited implementation of Medicare and Medicaid.This book is interesting in the context of the recent experience of the Affordable Care Act, which appears in many ways to be a continuation of prior reform efforts focused on plugging gaps rather than any systemic reform.  Maioni's work also raises the old question of why the USA never developed a viable social democratic party or stronger reform movements within the Democratic Party?  There have been a number of answers to this question.  Many of these explanations point to long term trends in American life, others, like the historical analysis of Eric Rauchway, look to the experience of 19th century industrialization.  A very strong analysis by Ira Katznelson in his book Fear Itself points to more recent phenomena, specifically the constraining effects of Southern Democratic politicians committed to maintaining the racial and economic structure of the Jim Crow South.Finally, its been almost 50 years since the USA and Canada parted company in health policy, a long enough period to make some reasonable judgments about the outcomes.  It appears that the Canadians, overall, made the better choice.  Canada spends considerably less on health care, gets at least approximately equivalent aggregate results, avoids the deplorable consequences of inadequate access to care that is common in the USA, and probably gets an additional benefit in terms of a greater sense of social solidarity.

Outstanding performances of this very interesting group of Shostakovich symphonies.  This recording features the great 4th symphony, Shostakovich's remarikable depiction of the brutal transformation of the Soviet Union in the early years of Stalin's dictatorship.  The Mariinsky is simply superb in these demanding pieces.

A well written and well illustrated book on an important issue in biology.  Nosil aimed this book at a broad audience; anyone with a basic knowledge of evolutionary biology and genetics can read this book profitably.  This is a well organized book with 3 major sections.  In the first part, Nosil starts with concise discussion of the nature of speciation and how to define ecological speciation.  This followed by an excellent review of evidence for ecological speciation featuring a strong analysis of criteria for successful experiments in this area. The next section deals with the 3 major components of ecological speciation; divergent selection, reproductive isolation, and genetic mechanisms linking these two.  The last section of the book discusses several important unresolved issues including the relationships between geography and speciation, genomics, and speciation, and the nature of the speciation continuum in relationship to ecological speciation.  Nosil identifies areas for future research.  In addition to the systematic approach and clear presentation, strong features of this book are Nosil's ability to discuss field, experimental, and theoretical studies in a complementary way, and his use of a number of interesting examples.

An effort by the talented Jim Harrison to use the procedural genre.  Harrison is a gifted writer and this book displays some of this strong points; notably his ability to depict and use landscape and his comedic writing skills.  As a procedural-mystery, this book is a bit of dud.  Its mainly a character study of the hero, a recently retired and moderately alcoholic detective trying to make sense of his somewhat messy life.  Harrison's ability to depict character is excellent but this dimension of the book is repetitive.  Unfortunately, despite Harrison's talent, this book falls between two stools.  Its neither successful as a procedural nor as a character study.

A very well performed set of choral works by the British composer Hubert Parry.  This disc includes some of his best known works such as the famous Jerusalem hymn.  The most important feature of this set is the lovely Songs of Farewell, Parry's lovely settings of a series of somewhat elegiac poems.  These works feature Parry's great gift at setting English texts to lovely music.

This is an excellent set of recordings of Brahms chamber music.  Given the high quality of the performances and the large number of pieces in this set, this is a tremendous bargain.  Different listeners will have different favorites, but I particularly recommend the Piano and Clarinet Quintets.

This very well written and exhaustively researched book is a first-rate narrative and analysis of the development of our modern economy.  Beckert focuses on what was arguably the most important industry in the genesis of the modern world economy - cotton textiles.  Because of the global distribution of suitable cotton species, cotton domestication and use was widespread in the pre-modern world.  The great majority of cotton production was handicraft production for local or at best regional consumption.  Over time, signficant proto-industrialization related to production of cotton yarn and cloth emerged in several regions with suitable climatic conditions, notably the Indian subcontinent and China.  As Beckert points out, Europe was something of an exception because of inadequate climactic conditions for cotton cultivation.  In the early modern period, however, expanding European-based international trade and prior proto-industrialization of cloth production for other fibers brought increasing amounts of cotton yarn and cloth production to Europe.The expanding cotton industry in Europe was based squarely on considerable success of European expansion and imperialism.  The ability of Europeans to insert themselves violently into the traditional trade networks of Asia, the acquisition of the "ghost acres" of the western hemisphere, and access to servile labor from Africa made possible the great expansion of cotton manufacturing.  This introduces one of Beckert's main themes.  This form of economic expansion was made possible the emergent powers of European states.  Beckert stresses repeatedly the importance of state backing and power in the European economic expansion, particularly the expropriation of the western hemisphere from its native peoples and the trans-Atlantic slave trade.  Beckert terms this combination of expanding mercantile activity supported by the state "war capitalism."  A major theme of this book is the recurrent importance of state support for early modern, 19th century, and modern capitalism.  This interpretation is opposed to the common view of the emergence of capitalism as based on relatively non-interventionist states.  To the extent that cotton industrialization is typical of capitalist development over the last few centuries, and it certainly is, Beckert's interpretation is very well supported.This form of war capitalism then intersects with the emerging industrialization in Britain to create the beginnings of the modern industrial economy.  This cotton complex is based on aggressive imperialism-colonialism to produce cheap fiber, reorganization of labor in the form of early factories in Britain, and the increasing articulation of a sophisticated global system of transport and credit.  Beckert stresses the importance of state support in all these features.  The key role of the US South is stressed.  By the mid-19th century, American producers dominate cotton fiber production, forming the base for the most important European industry.  The US Civil War then precipitated a global economic crisis.  The loss of American cotton production and the end of American slavery resulted in wholesale economic changes.These changes are partly responsible for the transition from war capitalism to what Beckert terms "industrial capitalism."  The abandonment of slave labor, increasing mechanization in Europe, and formation of the modern working class are features of this transition.  Beckert produces a particularly interesting analysis of the international correlates of this process.  Again, with strong state support, there was a wholesale transformation of the countryside in many regions, India being a notable example, with the destruction of traditional peasantry and household production and its replacement by cash crops and rural consumers of factory goods.  Beckert shows the often negative consequences, particularly the loss of food security that accompanied this process.But, this process contained some of the seeds of its own destruction.  Proletarianization in Europe was followed by the development of labor movements and increasingly democratic societies.  This eventually results in rising labor costs and movement of factories to the low labor cost zones.  With some state support, Japanese industrialization being an excellent example, non-European states or proto-states (India) develop their own cotton industries.  Again, state support is a key to this process of the spread of industrialization.  In an ironic way, this is true even of the industrialization fostered by Communist states such as the Soviet Union and China, whose policies mirrored many aspects of the colonial transformation of the countryside in the 19th and early 20th centuries.  Beckert concludes with an interesting commentary on more recent developments in the post-WWII era.  He makes the interesting point that the spread of global capitalism, with its relatively uniform legal and financial systems, allows large firms a certain amount of freedom from the state.As mentioned above, this is a very well written book and the depth of research is impressive.  Beckert's general interpretations are supported well and he has many shrewd observations about aspects of this process.  The bibliography is excellent.  There are a couple of minor points where Beckert is, I think, a bit off target.  He correctly stresses the role of aggressive imperialism in acquiring the lands needed for cotton cultivation in the western hemisphere.  He never mentions, however, that the European dominance of the Americas was a windfall made possible by the epidemiologic isolation of Native American peoples.  Partly because he is focused on the economics of cotton textiles and the development of modern capitalism, I think he underestimates the at least semi-independent role played by the western scientific tradition in the emergence of industrialization.

This very thorough book is an effort to describe the considerable crimes that were part of the Spanish Civil War.  Readers should be aware that this is not a general history of the Civil War but focused on politically-ideologically motivated killings during and after the war.  Preston is drawing on a large volume of scholarship, mainly from Spanish scholars, that accumulated over the past generation.  As can be seen from some of the comments posted about this book, this remains a controversial topic.  Preston attempts to present, and I think is largely successful in this respect, a fair account.  The book is organized in a mixed chronological-thematic structure.  He deals initially with some of the background of the Civil War, particularly the eliminationalist rhetoric and tendencies of the Spanish military and right.  His basic position is that this somewhat heterogeneous group was all unified in believing themselves in engaged in an existensial struggle with a Marxist-Jewish-Masonic international conspiracy aimed at exterminating traditional Spanish society.  This section is followed by a thorough account of the atrocities perpetuated by the military rebels and their numerous allies, which Preston presents as attempt to purge Spanish society of undesirable elements.  The latter often included members of leftist parties, Freemasons, political and economic rivals, unionists, Basque and Catalan nationalists, and even Protestant clergy.  Preston emphasizes the linkage between the brutal colonialism and counter-insurgency tactics practiced by the Spanish army in Morocco and their behavior in Spain.  These sections are followed by thorough accounts of the crimes committed by leftists, mainly but not exclusively by Anarcho-Syndicalist militias, in regions where the military revolt failed.  The narratives of events in Catalonia and Madrid, presumably because of good documentation, are especially systematic.  These have some clear analogies with the actions of Franco's troops and their allies.  The remainder of the book alternates similarly between events in rebel controlled areas and the shrinking portions of Spain in the Republican zone.  Each military conquest by Franco's troops was accompanied by new purges.  Preston describes aspects of the diminishing civil violence in the Republican zone as more moderate elements of the governing coalition asserted control (often with Communist-Soviet assistance), the civil war within the civil war between the radical and more moderate left in the Republican zone, and the Communist-Soviet campaign against the dissident communists.  Some episodes, such as the notorious mass execution of Spanish Army officers in Madrid, are discussed in great detail.  Preston concludes with an extensive discussion of the brutal post-war repression, including the Franco government's considerable collaboration with the Nazis.Preston has a clear interpretation of events and draws distinctions between the Francoist and Republican sides.  One major distinction is quantitative.  Older literature suggested parity between the Francoist and Republican sides in terms of these types of atrocities. See, for example, the concluding section of Stanley Payne's thoughtful book, The Franco Regime.  Preston points to recent estimates that the ratio of these types atrocities committed by the rebels and Republican elements is closer to 3 or 4 to 1.  Perhaps more important is Preston's argument that these types of crimes were deliberately encouraged by the leaders of the rebellion, sometimes with the explicit support of the Spanish Catholic hierarchy.  On the Republican side, the rebellion resulted in a collapse  of public order that allowed far left militias, usually Anarcho-Syndicalists, to carry out analogous purges.  Preston demonstrates that more moderate elements of the Republican coalition worked hard to restrain violence and impose public order, including a functioning judiciary.Overall, I think Preston's interpretation is a generally fair assessment.  There are some aspects, however, which are arguable.  Preston refers to the far leftist crimes as "spontaneous" which is correct in the sense that they would not have occurred without the collapse of order that followed the revolt.  Many aspects of the behavior the leftist militias in their efforts to purge the areas under their control were similar to the actions of the right wing death squads, to which Preston attributes strong elements of premeditation.  While Preston writes quite a bit about the eliminationist ideology of the Spanish right, he never discusses what must have been analogous ideology of the Spanish far Left.  In the opening sections, while Preston does mention the "irresponsibility" of some of the leadership of the Spanish Left, he puts the blame for the Civil War squarely on the shoulders of the Spanish Right.  Readers should know, however, that this impression isn't shared by all scholars in this field.  Stanley Payne, for example, has argued strenuously that the Spanish Left deserves blame for the Civil War.  My impression is that Preston's assessment is considerably closer to the mark than Payne's interpretation but I don't think he is completely on target.There are some defects in terms of construction of the book.  As is commonly the case, Preston primarily uses narrative.  There are some useful charts of atrocities, but they are at the back of the book and should be featured earlier.  Similarly, there are some useful maps placed at the back which should have been featured in the relevant narrative sections.  This could easily and arguably should have been a shorter book featuring a combination of the quantitative data with selected narrative examples.

This is somewhat impassioned, if not to say angry, book.  Gotzsche is a well known clinical reseacher with considerable experience in large scale analyses of therapeutic interventions.  In this book, Gotzsche documents many of the serious misdeeds committed by the pharmaceutical industry, often abetted by inadequate regulation by governments and considerable complicity on the part of many physicians.  Many of Gotzsche's points, including serious problems with the construction and analysis of clinical trials, inadequate surveillance of drug complications, conflicts of interest, and generally poor regulation, are unimpeachable.  It makes no sense, for example, to allow new trials of "me too" compounds solely against placebos.  That said, the quality of this book is somewhat uneven.  Many parts, particularly those where Gotzsche can draw on his considerable research experience, are solid.  Other parts betray a lack of in depth knowledge.  I suspect this book was written rather quickly, as there are some careless errors.  Gotzsche some a number of suggestions for reform, which vary from the unlikely, such as eliminating for profit companies, to a number of sensible regulatory changes.

This short book is an extension of an essay published by the authors sketching out a future where nothing is done about global warming.  The authors use the fictional device of a historical overview written by a scholar some centuries from now.  This future history features some of the pessimistic but quite plausible outcomes including massive sea level rise, a bit of a Venus effect due to some unexpected feedbacks, and collapse of civilization.  Oreskes and Conway also provide some analysis of why we've had no response to the overwhelming evidence for global warming and parallel environmental problems, pointing particularly to neo-liberal ideology and political systems highly susceptible to lobbying from powerful industrial interests.  This is generally well done and fairly imaginative.  A false note is the authors' excessive focus on scientists' use of conventional statistical thresholds.  This is a real but relatively minor issue.

This book is either too short or too long.  Tooze has set himself the ambitious goal of describing and analyzing the major changes in the world order that occurred during and after WWI.  The basic theme is the emergence of the USA as a hegemonic world power and its reluctance to fully participate in that role.  About 2/3s to 3/4s of this book cover the period from the middle of WWI to the early 20s with the remainder of the book devoted to selected important aspects of the 20s and the outbreak of the Great Depression and its impact.  To really do justice to this topic, however, Tooze would have had to devote as much text to the 20s and onset of the Great Depression as he does to WWI and its immediate aftermath.  A more coherent alternative would have been to end this book with the Dawes plan revision of the Versailles settlement.Tooze does very well in describing the dynamics of the American entry and the complex power politics around the globe.  He does very well in trying to provide a global perspective by discussing events in the USA, Russia, and China.  Many of these sections are excellent.  Tooze does particularly well with the financing of the war, complex events in Eastern Europe and the Brest-Litovsk process, the role of Japan, and features of post-war events, such as the deflation induced by the USA. In general, Tooze provides a nice analysis of how the USA supplanted the European powers as the major world power and the complexities of Wilson's diplomacy.  Its fair to remark, however, that little of Tooze's analysis is actually novel.  Much of what he describes is well known to scholars in this area and likely to knowledgeable readers as well.

A series of stories by various writers set in fictional worlds developed by the late Poul Anderson.  A few of these stories are good but most are mediocre and a couple are actually poor.  In an odd way, this volume actually demonstrates demonstrates Anderson's skill as a writer.  The apparent inability of other professional writers to be effective with the same kind of fictional tools is an indication of Anderson's originality and talent.

This relatively short and very well written book is an interesting history of the Imperial War Graves Commission (IWGC) responsible for the impressive cemetaries and memorials for Commonwealth soldiers in the afternath of WWI.  The book is built around the work of its guiding force, Sir Fabian Ware.  A successful journalist, educator, and colonial administrator in the pre-war period, Ware was an acolyte of the "Liberal Imperialist" and one-time proconsul of South Africa Afred Milner.  Ware developed the IWGC as a vehicle for Imperial solidarity and a certain type of democratic idealism.  As Crane points out, Ware pursued his objectives with what amounted to a sense of religious mission, a partial reflection of his upbringing in the Plymouth Brethen.  An unusually diligent and effective administrator, Ware was also a skillful bureaucratic politician whose connections in the British establishment provided him with the allies to out-manuever rivals and achieve what were sometimes controversial goals.  Ware was able to recruit an unusually talented group of architects, landscape designers, and other subordinates to to provide dignified and often quite beautiful burials and memorials for hundreds of thousands of casualties in locations around the globe.  While Ware's artists were a rather contentious team, they were also quite talented and shared a joint background in the Arts and Crafts movement.Crane does very well  in describing the essential features of the evolution of the IWGC, its relatively complex history, and its major achievements.  While this book is not profusely illustrated, enough good images are provided to give a good idea of the success of the IWGC.  Parts of this book also provide real insight into the enormous impact of WWI on British society and give some moving examples of the tragedies that affected so many British families.  Crane provides a nice analysis of Ware's personality and the relationship of his goals to pre-war liberal imperialism.  A point that Crane may overlook is that the Empire was under considerable strain in the aftermath of the war and the success of the IWGC should be seen against the background of the centripetal forces challenging the structure of the Empire.  Crane points to Ware's zeal as being to some extent a form of displaced religious commitment, which may be a feature of the way dissenting Protestantism spilled over into other aspects of British life.

A Hugo-winning novella in which Stross pursues time travel paradoxes in a fairly ambitious way.  This is a version of ideas pioneered by Robert Heinlein is his All You Zombies and By His Bootstraps short stories.  While not particularly original, this novella is written well and Stross expands the time travel and paradox aspects across a good part of the history of the universe.

This book is primarily a narrative of the Thirty Years War with a significant analytic component.  The depth and breadth of scholarship are really impressive.  Wilson offers a detailed narrative of the complex military and political history of the Thirty Years War accompanied by analyses of the major underlying structural features of the war and even some historiographic analysis.  The comprehensive narrative of the Thirty Years War is complemented by appropriate narratives of important related and parallel phenomena such as the Spanish-Dutch conflicts, the Franco-Spanish conflicts, the Swedish attempts to dominate the Baltic, and even some information about the Ottomans.  Wilson focuses, however, on the Holy Roman Empire, especially its German component, and events within the Empire.  A relatively distinctive feature of this book is Wilson's emphasis on the constitutional structure of the Empire and the way it channeled or failed to channel conflcts in the years leading up to the outbreak of war, and the ways in which the traditional constitutional strucure contained to frame efforts to contain conflicts during the war, and set some of the structure of the eventual peace settlements.The constitutional structure of the Empire is shown to be particularly important in the outbreak of the war.  As with almost all important historical phenomena, there is a complex set of causes, incluidng confessional differences, dynastic concerns, and economic considerations.  The inability of the Empire's structure to resolve ambiguities inherent in the Peace of Augsburg coupled with Rudolf II's personal inadequacies as Emperor and inability to use the Imperial system competently, contributed significanlty to the ourbreak of the war.  There is also a particularly good discussion of the nature and consequences of the final settlement at Westphalia.Wilson's narrative sections are generally excellent.  These are clearly written and he makes considerable efforts to complement the narratives by discussing them in larger European context and with some critical analysis of prior work. The publisher has, as usual, skimped on maps, which is an obstacle to following much of the detailed narrative.  The endnotes, on the other hand, are excellent, though a separate bibliography would have been very useful  While the detailed narrative sections are a real strengh of the book, the narrative sometimes tend to be overpowering.  Wilson, probably unavoidably, does some cross-cutting between chapters, which also complicates the narrative.  An overview section laying out some basic periodization of the war and major themes might have been helpful.

This well written and illustrated book is aimed at presenting the history of geology to a broad audience.  Martin Rudwick is a leading scholar in this area and this book contains concise summaries of his outstanding work.  Rudwick provides a nice narrative of how the great sweep of geologic time was discovered and how sequence of Earth's history was reconstructed.  This is very much the story of the gradual accumulation of understanding over a period of centuries by an increasingly active and diverse scientific community.  Rudwick's major theme is the historical character of this reconstruction; not merely the expression of underlying, universal laws, but the existence of dynamic and contingent events leading to a unique trajectory.  Rudwick emphasizes the important role of historical investigations in early modern Europe as a model for geological inquiry and how the Christian tradition "pre-adapted" (exapted would be the more accurate term) European intellectuals to historical-progressive narratives.  Another major theme is Rudwick's persistent criticism of the naive and highly inaccurate model of scientific progression as an opposition between science and relilgion.  Indeed, he shows the close relationship between some aspects of religious scholarship and motivations and the history of geology.Rudwick opens with an interesting description of the efforts of early modern European scholars to construct chronologies of world history and how developments in historical scholarship and textual criticism, including biblical criticism, became a model for explorations of geologic history.  This is followed by the emergence of modern geology in the 18th and early 19th centuries, a story told superbly in his magisterial books, Bursting the Limits of Time and Worlds Before Adam.  Subsequent chapters deal with the development of geochronology, plate tectonics, the early history of life, and the modern understanding of the importance of catastrophic events.  The incremental character of the accumulation of geologic knowledge (in opposition to the popular and facile application of Kuhn's theories to plate tectonics) and essentially historical-contingent character of Earth's past are the major themes.  Rudwick concludes with a short and effective section on young Earth creationism, emphasizing its scientific inadequacy, relatively shallow historical roots, and theological shortcomings.The fine narrative is complemented with nicely chosen illustrations (a feature of all Rudwick's books) and good recommendations for further reading.  One minor deficiency stems from Rudwick's discussions of the relationship of religious belief to geologic research.  Overall, this is a strong feature of this book but Rudwick, perhaps in an effort to reassure theistically inclined readers, is excessively harsh towards contemporary atheists, whom he derides as dogmatic and tends to lump with fundamentalists, an unfair criticism of the intellectual strength of contemporary atheism.  Some of Rudwick's statements about 19th century Darwinism and its relationship to atheism are arguably inaccurate.

I took interest in Alpha Lipoic Acid after being told by a friend how it helped her. Since it was a natural supplement the doctor was not opposed to me trying it.Alpha-Lipoic Acid is a naturally occurring vitamin-like chemical called an antioxidant. Alpha-Lipoic Acid is a powerful antioxidant made by the body. It is found in every cell in the body where it helps turn glucose into energy. Antioxidants attack "free radicals," waste products created when the body turns food into energy. Other antioxidants work only in water or fatty tissues, but alpha-lipoic acid is both fat and water soluble making it a valuable asset throughout the body.Amazing Nutrition's Alpha Lipoic Acid is a high potency supplement with 600 mg per capsule.
