A.M.Curiel and Daniel M. Arroyo craftily spin a fanciful tale of intrigue that keeps the pages turning and those bed lamps burning to the end of the very last page. No matter what your age you will enjoy this story. I found myself flipping page after page and I'm nowhere near the book's targeted age group. The age group targeted by this book will be on the edge of their seats with anticipation as they go with Lemed on his futuristic journey from planet to planet with the help of his animal friends.It is a fascinating story about a king, a queen, their young prince, his animal friends and a newly discovered fairy princess that help them along their adventures to save the planet from a surprising evil. Lemed, the young prince, is faced with an impossible choice that requires him to face his fears and move into action even in the midst of those fears. He has to face evil and decide what he can do to change the hate that is evil into love and acceptance.Lemed takes a journey through his world learning important life lessons along the way. Lessons that all human beings should embrace. He faces uncertainty and evil but does he have the courage to tackle evil and get the result they all want.The Magic Butterfly is a very intriguing, thought-provoking, wild ride with Lemed going from one world to the next and back again in his race to complete the journey in time to help the people of Ark.This book weaves a tale that touches on the emotions we all must deal with in your lives from love/hate, sad/happy, scared/brave, to help/not help, suspicion/trust and leaving us with the greatest of all of these being L-O-V-E.I highly recommend this children's book. As adult it was a page turner for me so don't be surprised if you pick this up and can't put it down. It's a great life lesson for us all.I ordered this product for little to no cost for the purpose of testing and evaluation, and subsequently providing my unbiased opinion. Cedarwood Essential Oil is extracted through the process of steam distillation from the wood pieces of the Cedar Wood tree. Cedarwood is a plant basically native to cold climates and found in higher altitudes.The chief components of Cedarwood Essential Oil are:• Alpha Cedrene• Beta Cedrene• Cedrol• Widdrol• Thujopsene• A group of SesquiterpenesCedarwood is a new oil to my essential oil collection, and one I admit I knew little about. My first thoughts had it relegated to being a holiday fragrance, that is until I did some research and found out how useful this "tree-named" oil can be.In researching the health benefits of Cedarwood Essential Oil, I was surprised at the extent it can be used. The health properties attributed to Cedarwood Oil are:• Antiseborrhoeic-helps cure Seborrhoea or Seborrheic Eczema, a malfunction of the sebaceous glands, an infection of the epidermal cells particularly of the skin, scalp, eyebrows, inner ear or anywhere else there are hair follicles.• Antiseptic-Prevents wounds from becoming septic, as well as,  defending the body from toxins. It can safely be applied externally to wounds; boosts white blood cells and the body's immunity• Anti-inflammatory-lessens  the inflammation of arthritis on the joints and tissues when inhaled or applied topically• Antispasmodic-relieves spasms that affect the respiratory system, intestines, muscles, heart and nerves. Also shown to relieve restless leg syndrome, respiratory seizures, asthma, and other spasmodic conditions.• Tonic-can be used as a general health tonic because it tones the organ systems, stimulates metabolism, tightens and tones muscles, skin, nervous system, stomach, digestive system and brain functions; boosts kidney and liver function• Astringent-is useful for protecting the skin from toxins and bacteria; causes skin proteins to coagulate• Diuretic-it increases the frequency of urination serving as a medium for the removal of fat, excess water and toxins like uric acid from the body. Can be beneficial in helping cure a number of ailments including obesity, hypertension, high blood pressure, rheumatism, arthritis, gout, urinary tract infections and the accumulation of toxins in the blood.• Emmenagogue-it stimulates and bring about menstruation, while also regularizing the cycle; lessens the pain and side effects like nausea, fatigue, and mood swings• Expectorant-efficiently eliminates coughs and removes phlegm from the respiratory tract and lungs; relieves congestion; relieves headaches, red and watery eyes, and other symptom of coughs and colds.• Insecticidal-When used in vaporizers, it drives away mosquitoes, flies and other insects in a large area around the house. It is regularly sprinkled on pillows or sheets at night so mosquitoes and other similarly irritating bugs and pests are driven away while you sleep.• Sedative-has a great soothing and calming effect on the mind; cures inflammation; relieves skin itching;  relieves tension and anxiety; promotes healthy, restorative, and uninterrupted sleep. Cedarwood aromatherapy is also recommended for people with chronic anxiety, stress, and depression• Fungicidal- Can be used to cure both external and internal fungal infections; inhaling can protect the body against various types of food poisoning, as well as plant, animal, and human fungal pathogensAdditional Benefits Include:• Curing acne• Arthritis• Bronchitis• Cystitis• Dandruff• Dermatitis• Stress• Kidney disorders• Treatment for oily skin---------A Word of Caution-----------PLEASE CAREFULLY READ AND HEED ALL PACKAGE CAUTIONS, INSERTS AND WARNINGS-------------------------------------------DO NOT USE IF YOU'RE PREGNANT-------------------------------------------DO NOT INGESTTHIS OIL IS HIGHLY POTENT-------------------------------------------PLEASE CONSULT YOUR PHYSICIAN REGARDING THE USE OF THIS OIL, ESPECIALLY IF YOU EXPERIENCE NAUSEA, VOMITING, AND EXCESSIVE THIRST.-------------------------------------------Some of the most popular essential oils to blend with Cedarwood are:• Bergamot• Benzoin• Cypress• Cinnamon• Frankincense• Juniper• Jasmine• Lemon• Lime• Lavender• Rose• Neroli• RosemaryThis is a very versatile and helpful essential oil and one definitively worth having in your medicine chest.This is a potent oil and a little goes a very long way. This bottle comes in the convenient 2-ounce size.I like combining my Cedarwood Oil with some of my other essential oils such as:• Lavender• Lime• Lemon• CinnamonOne of my favorite things to do with this Cedarwood is put it in the humidifier/aromatherapy machine and inhale the fumes. Since Cedarwood has a calming effect I love to combine it with Lavender, it is sooo relaxing. When my head is stuffy I put some in the humidifier to relieve sinus congestion, sinus and tension headaches. This does a great job of that.From the list of its uses and benefits, it is wholly evident to me that this is an essential oil worth having in my medicine chest and certainly would recommend it to anyone.I purchased this product for minimal to no cost for the purposes of testing and evaluation, and subsequently to provide my unbiased opinion of it. My kids are often jealous of the gadgets I get and curious about them. I admit though sometimes I am jealous of their gadgets and wish I had more time to sit and just play with them. A recent gadget I got for my kids to check out is New VTech Kidizoom Action Cam.  Seriously it is super cool!  Think of it like a GoPro built for kids!Features of the Kidizoom Action Cam:Video capturePhoto captureGamesBuilt-in Rechargeable Li-ion Polymer BatteryExpandable Memory via a MicroSD card up to 32GB (you will definitely want to have one of these on hand)Comes with lots of fun accessories including a waterproof case, mounting kit and wrist strapBuilt to withstand drops and bumps1.4 inch color LCD screenBefore I even got this out of the box, my kids were excited just looking at the box. I was impressed first off with all the accessories included. Usually accessories are extra but not with this camera.The camera is perfect for kids. I honestly keep the waterproof case on it all the time, for extra protection and my kids take the camera everywhere. I love seeing what they created! The Kidizoom is both a camera and video camera in one, and its very easy to know which button to click as there are pictures on the buttons. My kids had this camera figured out before I had everything out of the box. They knew exactly what to push, how to add fun stuff to the pictures, how to play games and they even figured out how to mount it to their bikes by looking at the box! My one son had the idea to tie string on it so they could wear it around their neck rather than mounting it to their bike or something flat.And the waterproof case, that I use for extra durability overall.For a flat mount like a skateboard, you do need to use the adhesive sticker included and they didn’t want to do that. The string works great for us and the waterproof camera case does have two spots where the stick fits through perfectly. I will say that is the only thing I wish the camera came with is a way to easily (and more neatly) wear it, like a strap or necklace chain (which would be a lot better than the string I used!)Overall though this camera is awesome for its price of $60.  We have a big VTech camera my kids use but honestly never really take it anywhere because of how bulky it is. Now I don’t know how the megapixels on this camera compares to the megapixels on the bigger VTech cameras but I do think they are good enough. My kids are happy and this camera is built to withstand their abuse. We are even bringing this camera with us when we go on vacation soon as my boys can’t wait to use it on the cruise we are going on and with the waterproof case, I feel even better with using it! Definitely worth the price and perfect for summer fun!I received this to review in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

What I love about the Potty Surprise Doll is she does not require any liquids. You feed her the included food which is a dough and twist her belly button for her to poop. These bags come at a great price and work great. I love that I get so many bags in this as I tend to go through a lot of them in my house. I got this razor for my husband who is always complaining about his electric razor and disposables. He loves this razor. First off, it cleans itself which is amazing. Overall, he doesn't have any issues and I appreciate how well it works. I am not sure how well it will be for traveling as it doesn't include a traveling container but it is pretty compact. So we have a lot of parties at my house year-round and I have quite the collection of trays and containers to store and display the food. Winter usually isn't bad because we are inside but summertime means the food is outside along with bugs. One year we had a huge pig roast but it was so buggy and gross outside that we had to keep all the food inside. While the party was supposed to be primarily outside, we had people going in and out for food. I tried keeping it outside but the plastic wrap was a pain to keep covering up the trays of food.Then I heard about "The Cater Dome" and I seriously was amazed. It is a simple container but it has so many great features it makes you think "Why didn't I think of that?"Stay-open lidDurable acrylic buildCan hold a half-sized aluminum pan (yep like the ones from catering companies)Microwaveable and freezer safe food grade inner tray (BPA Free)StackableEasy to carryComes in a variety of colorsEasily washed, even in the dishwasher!When I saw these trays I immediately envisioned how easy a picnic and BBQ would be thanks to The Cater Dome. I absolutely love that I can pop aluminum trays in them and that I can have the lid easily opened and closed. It is such a genius invention! There are times when its just the five of us and we bring some food to eat outside on the deck but again I have to worry about keeping it bug free - these would be perfect for that too!While these may seem like a summer product I can see them being useful year-round as well. I am thinking for Christmas it will be nice for displaying our Christmas cookies. The Cater Dome is not sealed around so you can't leave food in it that might get stale but for a party it is easy enough to pop out and wrap for storage.The Cater Dome would make a great gift too for those that often host parties or even for someone to keep if you bring a dish to their house for the holidays. Its priced at just $20 a container and it is definitely worth it.I received this product complimentary in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

Well Osmo is a unique accessory for the iPad that has not only changed the way iPads are used but also how kids can learn. Osmo includes a tablet stand and mirror piece and then game pieces. You just download the free apps and then your ready to go with Osmo. There are currently five games with three of them requiring pieces you get with the Osmo Genius Kit and the other two you use pieces you already have at home.So I will say at first, when I heard of Osmo I wasn't sure my kids would get the hang of it or it would be a lasting "toy" for my family. Osmo has become that and more for us. My three kids all use Osmo and I will say even my husband and I have been found playing on it. It is hard to describe just how awesome Osmo is but I will try.Osmo uses a mirror that clips onto the top of the iPad. You use the pieces on your table and they reflect onto the screen of the iPad. It is pretty amazing how it works and seems so high tech!I received the Osmo Genius Kit as I mentioned. It is a kit that features everything you need, other than the iPad and free apps you need to download.I cannot believe I hadn't heard of Osmo until recently, it is something I really think everyone with kids and an iPad should own. There is so much you can do with Osmo and they do have plans to create more games and an Android version eventually. For now though the five games are keeping us busy and my kids don't even realize they are learning. From exploring creativity to engineering to problem solving and even words and math. My kids think they are just playing games but they are learning so much and the games seem to grow with them starting with Easy and then moving up.Overall though I cannot say even good things about Osmo. You can even make your own Osmo experience by uploading your own words and pictures! I really like though that you don't need to put pieces on or touch the iPad screen, which sometimes makes me nervous with my kids. These pieces are used strictly on the table rather than on the tablet.I received this product to review in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

My Friend Cayla is a new doll that is actually the world’s first real talking doll.  She knows millions of things, once you connect her to the app via bluetooth. Her knowledge is based off a cloud based encyclopedia and she can also answer over 1,000 questions about herself. Cayla can even spell words and solve math problems!My Friend Cayla is not just an online-connected doll. She can be used offline as well, perfect for if your on-the-go with her without an internet connection. Offline she can still talk and interact, play games, tell bedtime stories and more as long as she is connected via bluetooth to your tablet.Honestly My Friend Cayla is a pretty amazing doll.  She can do so much that I feel like we haven’t even scratched the surface of her yet. My 4 year old is amazed every time we use her and thinks she is the coolest doll ever. I did obviously have to get her set up for my daughter but otherwise she can do everything on her own. She kind of reminds me of Siri for Apple devices but in the form of a doll that can really interact with someone rather than just answer a question here and there. She is not always 100% perfect but I think that is more of a communication mis-understanding of what my daughter is asking. I haven’t had a problem with anything I have asked yet.To set up My Friend Cayla you do need to pair her with your Android or Apple device (tablet or a smartphone) just like you’d pair a bluetooth headset or speaker. Most of Cayla’s conversational features can be used while she is offline but other features like asking specific questions and such do require a WiFi connection. Cayla herself also required 3 AA batteries but other than that she is ready to go.It did take me a few tries to pair her correctly but ever since she has connected just fine automatically, it was just the first initial setup that I had to try a few times. Her necklace even lights up when she’s connected and ready so you know.Now the one thing I really couldn’t believe about My Friend Cayla is that there is no monthly service fee to use her. I assumed that in addition to the cost of the doll there would be a monthly fee to pay but nope she is free after you buy her! The app is free as well. This is nice because too often I find something super cool only to realize there is a monthly fee that I wasn’t anticipating.Cayla really can be a great friend for a child and keep them socially engaged. I haven’t heard anything inappropriate from her and I like that I have the option to be able to add words I’d rather her not mention or answer questions about. There is a dictionary-type page on the app you input words in you want Cayla to say are inappropriate. Not necessarily for swear words but even if you don’t want your child to ask about something like guns or war. Cayla does have a kid-safe proprietary software called Violet installed that protects your child from any offensive or sensitive words.Cayla can even be customized right down to her name which you can change and you can input personalized items that are your child’s favorite so Cayla can have a “real” conversation with your child. My daughter’s favorite feature is the story time. She can read stories aloud and display on the device for your child to follow along.Looking for a Spanish? You can download the My Friend Cayla Spanish version on your smart device as well!Want to change her clothes? My Friend Cayla is a standard 18 inch doll size and can wear most of any 18 doll’s clothes if you have any. She basically is like other 18 inch dolls from her appearance but she has the added bonus of the app and talking.I think My Friend Cayla is going to be a hot Christmas item this year so I would definitely pick it up sooner than later as Christmas is going to be here before we know it! I will say too that I tried Cayla both via an Android device and an Apple device and there were less hiccups with the Apple device via bluetooth. Not sure if it was just my connection or phone in general but our iPad Mini worked better with her rather than my Android smartphone. For $60 she is definitely a very cool and amazing doll that like I said we have barely scratched the service of because there is so much to her.I received this product to review in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

What makes the Mini Lalalopsy Super Silly Party Musical Cake Playset so fun?Well it is a playset that allows the Lalaloopsy Mini dolls to play in a spinning cake, walk across a cookie bridge, have a picnic, go down a slide, swing on a doughnut swing or even blow out a light-up candle! It even comes with a Mini Lalaloopsy character: Surprise Party Curls.My 4 year old daughter loves this silly set. She sits with all her Mini Lalaloopsy dolls and they play all around it. You do only get one Lalaloopsy Mini doll so you may want to pick up a few extra, especially if you are giving this as a gift. It doesn't fold up or hold the pieces for clean up which would have been nice. Otherwise it is a typical playset perfect for any Lalaloopsy fan.I received this product to review in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

Got this for my older dog, who thinks he is still a puppy, and he enjoyed it. I obviously can't vouch for the taste other than to say he didn't turn his nose up at it. He chewed this Dent for awhile and keeps going back to it. I admit we don't do anything for his teeth so when I find something that he can enjoy while working his teeth, I go for it. These are an expensive treat so I'd probably only buy once a month or so as a really special treat.

While I am not pregnant, my youngest is 4 years old, I do like everything you get from a pre-natal vitamin. These are jam packed like a multi-vitamin but I love that they are geared towards women, especially women pre/post baby. The gummy taste is good and easy to chew. The dosage is 2 a day so this bottle will last just over a month which is not bad for the cost. I like that they have an Energy Metabolism Support, which as a mom of three I need all the energy help I can get! These even have Fish Oil so I am not taking a separate pill for that which is nice. I would recommend these for any woman.

Well Rockboard Scooters are nothing like we have ever tried. They are a traditional kick scooter but with more uses and actually features increased exercise. They are the perfect alternative to bikes, roller blades, and skateboards.What makes the Rockboard Scooter unique?Well instead of using the same foot and leg to move forward by kicking off the ground, the rider rocks back and forth on the board to achieve a forward motion. So the rider is exercising both legs aerobically! It sounds complicated and strange but it is seriously fun. Yes I have tried ours and I didn't even feel like I was exercising.Propulsion is achieved with each rock, wasting zero energy and allowing the scooter to reach speeds up to 10 mph.Can't decide between a traditional scooter or Rockboard?Well the Rockboard Original offers the best of both worlds. You can use it as a Rockboard Scooter where you rock back and forth to go or lower the board with a few knob twists to a traditional scooter mode.You can even fold up the scooter for easy storage and transportation! It even came with a bag for storage.Wether you want a scooter for fun or transportation, Rockboard has you covered and there is one for all ages starting at 5 years old. Rockboard Scooters offer a way to get around, burn off a few extra calories and have fun. I will say it did take me a few tries to get used to it but now I don't have a problem. My boys had absolutely no problem from the get go and fight over this scooter! It is such a smooth and amazing ride and we get lots of looks when riding around the neighborhood. It is 100% rider-powered, no charging it. There is just nothing like it! It is more expensive than traditional scooters but if you think about how it is like two scooters in one then it really is a good deal and you will be the envy of others by how cool your ride is.

This is an adorable DVD where the Lalaloopsy girls star as a band who go on tour and of course has some fun adventures. The animation is adorable and the songs are super silly and cute. The movie is about 45 minutes long. There are even some new characters in this movie that my daughter was excited to see. With this DVD you also get the Digital copy which you can add to your account and watch anywhere - TV, computer, smartphone or tablet. This would be a great title for any Lalaloopsy fan or just a child who loves music!I received this DVD to review in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

I got this for our Disney World magic bands to hold them on. Last year my son lost a magic band and while Disney easily replaced it, I figured these would be nice to avoid that trouble! I don't have a FitBit to try them on but they do work on the Disney Magic Bands. Super easy to slide on and it comes with a good amount, less than $1 a piece for peace of mind!I received these complimentary in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

My kids have wanted a marble playset forever and now at ages 7 and 8 years old I got them one. This set comes with 82 plastic pieces to build a marble run and then 50 marbles so right out of the box you are ready to go. I love that it comes with 50 marbles because of course we will loose them. Inside is an included guide for building the marble runs although my kids like to create their own. I would post a video but so many reviewers have already. I really appreciate how the pieces are easy enough for my kids to snap together. We've never owned a marble set before so I don't have anything to compare it to but I am happy with this one. It is a great starter set and can be combined with other marble playsets.I received this product complimentary in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

For the $10 you get 8 razors, which is a good price especially since you'll be throwing these away. This is 8 actual razors rather than razor refills so it is perfect if you prefer whole razors rather than dealing with changing the razor heads. The BIC Flex 3 is the lowest on the quality of BIC Flex razors but they do the job. There is only 3 blades whereas more expensive ones usually have at least five. It does have a nice lubricating strip for an easy shave. I have used these on my legs and underarms and they work just fine. I did get the occasional nick and not a completely smooth shave but for a quick job they work.

This is a disposable razor with 12 razors that after you use up all the razors you throw the razor handle away. It is a three blade razor which honestly is fine. There is a lubricating strip that helps to soften as you go and the head does help glide down as you shave. With this set being disposable it is not the best quality but for the affordable price it does the job. For $12 its like getting 12 razors in one so even if you only use it for a few days before changing the head its worth it. I have been using these for my legs and underarms rather than giving them to my husband! I would recommend them for the price and quality - they are good enough especially if you can't afford the high quality expensive razors.

This is an amazing, big hardcover book full of LEGO ideas. It is not LEGO instructions but rather pictures that kids could follow to build creations. The ideas in this book are a little of everything from cars to creatures to desks and even food! The creations are amazing. They go from simple to complicated. My boys love browsing the book laying on the toyroom floor and I can see their little minds working over how they are going to build the items. I admit even though I am not a LEGO builder, this book makes me want to start building! It is perfect for all ages as younger kids can enjoy the pictures and older kids (adults) will appreciate the ideas on what to build!

This pillow is super soft and cuddly. My 7 year old son has claimed it and can't wait to take it on vacation with us. For now, he uses it in bed, although it does make me nervous with him sleeping on it as it is around his neck so I usually remove it when I check on him. To stay in place on your neck or even luggage it has a nice snap so it doesn't fall off. Very easily washed - I have just surface washed it so far but it does have a zipper so I'd assume you can zip it off to machine wash. Very luxurious and great for adults and kids!I received this product complimentary/discounted to review in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

This is a great travel pillow that I can't wait to take on vacation with us. My 8 year old son claimed it already. It is super soft and he likes to cuddle with it when he's sleeping! Its a sturdy pillow that seems like it is built to last and stand up to frequent use. The book it comes with is an e-book, not an actual book. Easily cleaned as well which is a must especially when traveling - you can actually throw the cover in the washing machine! To make sure it stays on you just hook the latch on the bottom so it stays in place. I would recommend especially for the great value.I received this product complimentary/discounted in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

This is a great set of three tweezers and a carrying pouch. I love that they vary in their design so if you want to just tweeze one hair or or a bunch or even some at a weird angle, you can. Great value for three tweezers and the nice pouch they come in. I am actually keeping these in my car for when I find those stray hairs and I may pick up a few as gifts!I received this product complimentary/discounted in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

I love these stroller hooks. Honestly I use them more often than just on my strollers as they are great to carry bags as you can hook them all on the hook and just carry the hook. I also like them for hooking tote bags on to store them. The grip makes it nice to carry and they do hold a lot. Great deal since you get two of these.I received this product complimentary/discounted in exchange for sharing my honest opinion.

I used Luvs with all three of my kids. These diapers I found work amazingly and are affordable. I do like to pay less than $0.40 a diaper, the cheaper the better without obviously sacrificing quality. I mean if a diaper leaks or falls off then what is it really worth? I haven't had any problems with them and actually buy them as baby shower gifts. Size 3 diapers fit a decent size weight range and my boys used them pretty much until they were potty trained - the smaller the diaper you buy the more you get in the package so the better the value. Perfect for night and day and even active toddlers/preschoolers.

This expansion includes alternative versions of the Warlock (which was originally released in the base Mage Wars Game) and the Warlord (which was originally released in the Mage Wars Forcemaster vs. Warlord Expansion Board Game. In addition to the two new mage cards and their corresponding ability cards, the expansion includes 158 spell cards. There are 41 different spells, with multiple copies of each spell card so you can have multiples of each spell when applicable.Like it's predecessor, the Warlock is trained in the Dark and Fire schools (and Holy spells cost triple). Once per round after her action phase she can move a Burn marker from one object to another object in in the same zone (up to two zones away).  She also has "Smoldering Curses," which gives enemy creatures with a curse she controls Flame +1.  Finally, she has "Demonic Reward," which allows demons that damage an enemy with a burn token to heal one damage once per round.Like it's predecessor the Warlord is trained in the War and Earth schools (and Arcane spells cost triple). He has the "Runesmithing," which allows him to pay 1 mana to attach a Rune token to his equipment (this token can be used to make an opponent pay 2 extra mana to destroy that piece of equipment).  He also has "Battle Orders," which once per round allows him to cast a quick command spell that gives one of the following to all friendly soldiers in his zone: Piercing +2, Fast, or Armor +1 and Tough -2.  Finally, he also has the Tough -2 trait.On the one hand, I liked the original Warlock and Warlord quite a bit, and I would rather have gotten new mages than different versions of existing mages (the reasons for 4 rather than 5 stars). On the other hand there are lots of new spells in this set making it a worthwhile addition in general, and for any Warlock or Warlord in particular.  Plus, it's always nice to have variety (especially since this also strengthens some of the previously weaker schools), and what's included will increase the games replayability even further.

This expansion includes alternative versions of the Beastmaster and Priest(ess) that came with the Mage Wars Game base set.  In addition to the two mage cards and their corresponding ability cards, the expansion includes 106 spell cards. There are 26 different spells, with 2 to 6 copies of each spell card so you can have multiples of each spell when applicable.Like it's predecessor, the Beastmaster is trained in the Nature school (and Fire spells cost triple).  Once per round she can place a "Wounded Prey" marker on a wounded non-mage living enemy creature (everyone who attacks that creature gets Melee +1). She also has the Fast trait, and Ranged +1 for all non-spell ranged attacks.Like it's predecessor the Priestess, the Priest is trained in the Holy school (and Dark spells cost triple). He has the "Holy Avenger" special ability,  which is similar to the Beastmaster's "Pet" and the Durid's "Treebond" except it works on an Holy rather than an animal or plant. Once per round he can pay 1 mana to place a Burn token on a creature he damages with an attack.On the one hand, I liked the original Beastmaster and Priestess quite a bit and a little better than these, and I would rather have gotten new mages than different versions of existing mages (the reasons for 4 rather than 5 stars). On the other hand there are lots of new spells in this set making it a worthwhile addition in general, and for any Beastmaster and Priest(ess) in particular; it's always nice to have variety, and what's included will increase the games replayability even further.

This is the second action maker set released for Mage Wars (the first included green and yellow marker and can be found here:bMage Wars: Action Marker Set.There are two key reasons to buy this expansion.(1) You want to play a 3-4 player version of the game. The base game includes just two colors (red and blue), and you will need additional/different colors action markers (and additional quickcast markers) if you want to play with more than two players. This set includes 10 markers of each color, plus 2 quickcast markers). As others have noted you also need another board for the 3-4 player game, but if you are playing with someone else who has the game that will not be a problem (but, you'll definitely want additional colors to play with more than two players regardless).(2) You like the color purple. As noted above, the base set only includes the colors red and blue (and you can get green and yellow in the first action marker set). But, if someone else has already selected green (my favorite color), I like to use the color purple (my backup choice when possible).  So, this was a must have for me. The other color it includes is gray, so I suppose the same could be said if you like to play gray.Note, you only need one extra set of action markers to play with 3-4 player.  So, if you like green and/or yellow the first one will be a better choice for you, if you like purple and/or gray, this one will be a better choice.  I bought both because I like both green and purple, and wanted to have lots of options when playing.  But, I don't think you really need both and that one will do for most people.

There are two key reasons to buy this expansion.(1) You want to play a 3-4 player version of the game.  The base game includes just two colors (red and blue), and you will need additional/different colors action markers (and additional quickcast markers)  if you want to play with more than two players.  This set includes 10 markers of each color, plus 2 quickcast markers). As others have noted you also need another board for the 3-4 player game, but if you are playing with someone else who has the game that will not be a problem (but, you'll definitely want additional colors to play with more than two players regardless).(2) You like the color green. As noted above, the base set only includes the colors red and blue. But, I like to use the color green when playing games. So, this was a must have for me.  The other color it includes is yellow, so I suppose the same could be said if you like to play yellow.Note, this was out of print for a while and went up in price quite a bit on the secondary market.  But, it was reprinted around the time this review was written so it was possible to get or regular retail price, and sometimes a little below if you shop around online.  So, be sure to look around before you spend on too much on this marker. Might go out of print again, but it is worth looking around first.  My reprinted set are very slightly bigger and greener than the original run.

Druid vs. Necromancer is the second two-mage xpansion for Mage Wars Game (the first was Mage Wars Forcemaster vs. Warlord Expansion Board Game).  It includes two new mages (Druid & Necromancer).  In addition to the two mage cards and their corresponding ability cards, the expansion includes 116 spell cards.  There are 60 different spells, with 1 to 6 copies of each spell card so you can have multiples of each spell when applicable.The Druid is trained in the Nature school AND Level 1 Water spells (Fire and War spells cost triple).  During the deployment phase place a Vine marker that spread across the game board (and later in the game when she casts a Vine spell she can cast it in any location with a Vine marker). She also has "Treebond," which is similar to the Beastmaster's "Pet" except it works with a tree rather than an animal.The Necromancer is trained in the Dark school (Holy spells cost triple). He has the "Plague Master" special ability which allows him to damage a creature with a poison marker on it.  He also has "Eternal Servant," which is similar to the Beastmaster's "Pet" and the Durid's "Treebond" except it works on an undead rather than an animal or plant.I think the base game already offered a fair amount of variety and replayability, and this expansion adds meaningfully to both (especially since lots of the new spells can also be used to strengthen already existing mage spellbooks).

Forcemaster vs. Warlord is a nice expansion for Mage Wars Game. It includes two new mages (Forcemaster and Warlord) that focus on two schools of magic not emphasized in the core set (i.e., Mind & War).  In addition to the two mage cards and their corresponding ability cards, the expansion includes 116 spell cards.  There are 71 different spells, with 1 to 6 copies of each spell card so you can have multiples of each spell when applicable.The Forcemaster is trained in the Mind school (non-Mind creature spells cost triple).  She can "Deflect" 1 attack per round on a 7+ for one mana.  She can also force PULL someone a creature that is at range 1-2 toward her as a quick cast action.The Warlord is trained in the War and Earth schools (Arcane spells cost triple). He has the "Veterans" special ability which gives friendly creatures that have destroyed an enemy creature Melee +1 and Armor +1.  Once per round he may pay 1 manna to cast one of three quickspells that affects all friendly soldiers in his zone (i.e., Charge +1, Ranged +1, or Melee +1 AND Armor +1). he also has Melee +1.I think the base game already offered a fair amount of variety and replayability, and this expansion adds meaningfully to both (especially since lots of the new spells can also be used to strengthen already existing mage spellbooks).

Tzolk'in is a wonderful game. It has great components, and I especially liked the innovative dynamic worker placement mechanic (i.e., players put their workers on connected gears, and as the gears rotate they take the workers to different action spots). I also liked that it comes with enough building, monument, and starting wealth tiles to add lots of replayability to the game. And, if you add the Tzolk'in: Tribes and Prophecies you get even more tiles, and more importantly, a few NEW ways to play (see my review of Tribes & Prophecies for a list of what it adds).The main thing we did not like abut it is that it has a pretty steep learning curve (both in terms of the mechanic and good strategies for winning).  To give you a few points of reference, I think it is harder to learn than both Lords of Waterdeep: A Dungeons & Dragons Board Game and The Castles Of Burgundy -- two other fairly complex board game that we also love (and, it is much harder to learn than Stone Age Board Game, another worker placement game that is less complex that we also like quite a bit). So, it's not a great candidate for novice board game players. But, if you like Castles of Burgundy or Lords of Waterdeep (or similar games), and don't mind spending a little more time than usual learning a new game, I think you'll find Tzolk'in is definitely worth the effort.

Zombie Dogz are an interesting addition to Zombicide.  You get 20 dogs total, or 5 each in 4 different poses. You also get 12 spawn cards to add to the zombie deck so you'll know when to place the dogs. As usual, the minis look great, but like their Dog Companion set, the dogs come off of their bases pretty easily (all of mine have come off their bases at one point or another; not ideal, but not a huge deal either since this can be fixed with a little glue).Zombie Dogz are fast and vicious.  They get three actions so they can (1) move, move, move, (2) attack, attack, attack, or (3) just about any other move / attack combo you can think of.  They are also targeted LAST in the target priority order (one of my lease favorite parts of the game in general, and something that makes the dogs particularly nasty).I find the base Zombicide game to be a tough game to win that can be very chaotic. Neither of these things is bad in and of itself, especially since that's what you'd expect from a zombie apocalypse game.  But, Zombie Dogz made it harder and more hectic (especially given the target priority rules mentioned above), which took a little too much away from the game for me to use them very often or at all at this point (thus the reason for my 3 star rating, which on Amazon means, "it's ok").I've bee told using the Zombicide Box of Dogs Set #6: Dog Companions expansion with Zombie Dogz can help even things out at least a little.  But, while I have used them separately I have not yet used them together so cannot say for sure.

This set comes with 6 dogs... 2 German Shepherd (2 attack dice, 3+ to hit, 1 damage), 2 Blue Heeler (3 attack dice, 4+ to hit, 1 damage), and 2 America Bulldog (1 attack dice, 3+ to hit, 2 damage).Some key dog rules: (1) Dogs do not get actions -- instead their handeler can spend their actions to command a dog do do something, (2) dogs can move (up to 3 squares for an action -- or freely with their handler), melee attack, make noise, and get into or out of a car (and the German Shepard and Blue Heeler can also search), and (3) dogs die when they receive their first wound. Also, You can put dogs in the equipment pile and draw them at random, or you can assign dogs to survivors at the beginning of the game.In sum, companion dogs add some nice variety to the game, and also make the game a little easier because they can reach and attack zombies before they get to the survivor's zone, can take damage instead of a survivor, can draw zombies in a different direction, or slow zombies down while they attack the dogs. These are all good thing in a game that is otherwise very tough to win.  The minis look great, but as others have noted they fall off the base pretty easy (all of mine eventually came lose from the base); not ideal, but not too had to fix either.

These are the same zombies that come in the Zombicide Season 2: Prison Outbreak. They are the brown BERSERKER zombies, NOT the grey regular zombies (extra regular zombies are available here Zombicide Box of Zombies Set #1: Walk of the Dead and here Zombicide Box of Zombies Set #4: Walk of the Dead 2]. I like that they included some new sculpts for the berserker walkers and berserker fatties. As usual, all the minis look amazing.  Given that I have yet to play a game where I don't run out of one type of zombie or another (in which case all the zombies of that type get an extra activation... an effect that is both cumulative and deadly), having some extra zombies -- especially berserker zombies -- can really come in handy.

These are the same zombies that come in the Zombicide Season 2: Prison Outbreak. They are the grey REGULAR zombies, NOT the brown berserker zombies (extra berserker zombies are available here Zombicide Box of Zombies Set #3: Angry Zombies. I like that they included some new sculpts for the walkers and fatties. As usual, all the minis look amazing.  Given that I have yet to play a game where I don't run out of one type of zombie or another (in which case all the zombies of that type get an extra activation... an effect that is both cumulative and deadly), having some extra regular zombies can really come in handy.

These are the same zombies that come in the Zombicide Base Game.  Some of the other zombie sets like Zombicide Box of Zombies Set #4: Walk of the Dead 2 and Zombicide: Toxic Crowd Box of Zombies Set include some exclusive sculpts, but this one does not.  But, I have yet to play a game where I don't run out of one type of zombie or another (in which case all the zombies of that type get an extra activation... an effect that is both cumulative and deadly). So, having some extra zombies can really come in handy. And, as usual, the minis look amazing.

After playing Zombicide and Zombicide Season 2: Prison Outbreak several times, I've decided to give it 3 stars (which on Amazon means "It's ok").I know lots of people love this game and I mean no disrespect to anyone by saying this. I liked the idea enough to play the original multiple times, and also to buy and play Season 2 multiple times in hopes that it improved upon the original. And, as is often the case with many games people feel differently about, I imagine others might value some of the very things I did not like about it. It's definitely got some things going for it (see next paragraph), it just has a few things that took some of the fun out of it for me (and, I've read reviews on other sites like Board Game Geek that suggests at least some other people feel the same way).  So, I thought people might want appreciate an alternative point of view so they could make a more informed decision.  That said...There is no doubt that the minis are awesome, and the fact that it is co-op is a major plus. I also liked this zombie mechanic better than the Last Night on Earth zombie mechanic (i.e., Zombicide zombies are dumb and move/attack using a predetermined algorithm, where as LNoE zombies seemed pretty resourceful and strategic given all the cards they can play to mess with the survivors).Unfortunately, there were many things I also disliked. For example:(1) The targeting priority system does not make any sense to me. It is crazy that you have to attack other survivors first -- especially without a save. And, why would I attack the lowest threat zombie when there is a higher threat zombie standing right next to it? I wouldn't, but the game makes me!(2) It is very easy to run out of zombies, which gives those zombies you run out of an extra activation (an effect that is cumulative, and makes the game harder still). I have yet to play a game where we don't run out of one or more types of zombies on a regular basis.(3) Some of the zombies are very hard or nearly impossible to kill. In fact, just about the only way to kill the abominations is with a Molotov cocktail (of which there are only 2, and they are very hard to make as you have to find a glass bottle and gas card first, and make sure the same person has both of these cards).(4) Survivors die way to easily. Lots of people house rule this, but I would very much have preferred the survivors to have a fighting chance to begin with. And, there are not lots of ways heal in this version (so, once you take a wound it's hard to get rid of it... which is pretty bad since you only need two wounds to die).(5) The game is very random and requires very little skill (in fact, most of the decisions are very obvious). The zombies you draw are random, the equipment cards you draw are random (which is problematic since many of them are also useless), and while the zombies always hit, survivors must roll a D6 to see if they hit. And, as mentioned above, you cannot always chose what zombie you attack and are sometimes forced to attack a survivor before a zombie.On the one hand all this means it really has a chaotic zombie apocalypse feel to it (we all know the odds are against you in a zombie apocalypse). And, given that the game is so popular in general, the above issues are obviously not a big problem to many (and I mean no disrespect to those who love the game by saying any of this). On the other hand they made the game a bit boring since it doesn't involve much strategy and there is not much you can do besides search for better items that increases your chance of successful attack vs. a zombie you may not want to attack anyway. In short, the game just sort of happens to you and there isn't much you can do about it except try (and often fail) to hold out as long as possible.

I played Zombicide Base Game a couple of times and decided to buy this version after hearing it was better than the original in many ways (and finding it on sale for 50% off, which seemed like an especially good deal to me).  After several plays I've decided to give it 3 stars (which on Amazon means "It's ok").I know lots of people love this game and I mean no disrespect to anyone by saying this. I liked the idea enough to play the original multiple times, and also to buy and play Season 2 multiple times in hopes that it improved upon the original. And, as is often the case with many games people feel differently about, I imagine others might value some of the very things I did not like about it. It's definitely got some things going for it (see next paragraph), it just has a few things that took some of the fun out of it for me (and, I've read reviews on other sites like Board Game Geek that suggests at least some other people feel the same way).  So, I thought people might want appreciate an alternative point of view so they could make a more informed decision.  That said...There is no doubt that the minis are awesome, and the fact that it is co-op is a major plus.  I also liked this zombie mechanic better than the Last Night on Earth zombie mechanic (i.e., Zombicide zombies are dumb and move/attack using a predetermined algorithm, where as LNoE zombies seemed pretty resourceful and strategic given all the cards they can play to mess with the survivors).Unfortunately, there were many things I also disliked.  Some were things I also disliked about the original game, and some were new issues (or issues that were made worse by the new game).  For example:(1) The targeting priority system does not make any sense to me.  It is crazy that you have to attack other survivors first -- especially without a save. And, why would I attack the lowest threat zombie when there is a higher threat zombie standing right next to it? I wouldn't, but the game makes me!  And, since there are more types of zombies in this set, the targeting priority system seems even more out of whack.  I think the game should think for the zombies, and let the survivors/players think for themselves.(2) It is very easy to run out of zombies, which gives those zombies you run out of an extra activation (an effect that is cumulative, and makes the game harder still). This problem is bad in this edition because while you get more zombies total (78 in Prison outbreak vs. 65 in the first game), you actually get fewer regular zombies (only 49) and fewer still berserker zombies (only 29).  I have yet to play a game where we don't run out of one or more types of zombies on a regular basis.(3) Some of the zombies are very hard or nearly impossible to kill. In fact, the only way to kill the abominations is with a Molotov cocktail (of which there are only 2, and they are very hard to make) or the concrete saw (of which there is only 1, and thank god for it as it is a new addition to this version of the game).(4) Survivors die way to easily.  And, I'm not a fan of the zombivore system they came up with in this edition to deal with this. I would very much have preferred the survivors to have a fighting chance to begin with.  And, there is no way to heal in this version (so, once you take a wound there is no getting rid of it... which is pretty bad since you only need two wounds to die).(5) The game is very random and requires very little skill (in fact, most of the decisions are very obvious).  The zombies you draw are random, the equipment cards you draw are random (which is problematic since many of them are also useless), and while the zombies always hit, survivors must roll a D6 to see if they hit. And, as mentioned above, you cannot always chose what zombie you attack and are sometimes forced to attack a survivor before a zombie.(6) And, if all that were not enough, the rules are not very well written and include some important omissions. The one that comes to mind right now is that they never explicitly state when you should draw regular zombies and when you draw berserker zombies.  After groping around the components and looking around online I was finally able to figure out that the cards with knives on them mean you draw berserker zombies and the cards without the knives on them mean you draw regular zombies.  But, why did I have to spend any time on this at all (that is, why didn't they just state this in the rules)?  This is just one example.On the one hand all this means it really has a chaotic zombie apocalypse feel to it (we all know the odds are against you in a zombie apocalypse). And, given that the game is so popular in general, the above issues are obviously not a big problem to many.  On the other hand it made the game a bit boring since it doesn't involve much strategy and there is not much you can do besides search for better items that increases your chance of successful attack vs. a zombie you may not want to attack anyway. In short, the game just sort of happens to you and there isn't much you can do about it except try (and often fail) to hold out as long as possible.

Tzolk'in: Tribes and Prophesies is like getting four expansions in one (or five if you count that it lets you include a fifth player).1. There are 13 tribe tiles that give each player a unique special ability.  You are dealt two at random and get to pick which one you want to keep. Examples include (a) getting to star with five rather than just three workers (but you also have to pay more corn to feed each worker, and there is a greater penalty for each worker you do not feed); (b) getting to pay less to place workers (i.e., it used to be 0 corn for 1 worker, 1 corn for 2 workers, up to 15 corn for 6 workers... now you might pay 1 less to place 0-4 workers, and 2 less to place 5 or 6 workers); and (c) letting you take workers form one wheel but using an ability of the same level from a different wheel (i.e., you would treat Tikal and Uxmal the same, or Yaxchilan and Palenque the same).2. There are 13 prophecy tiles that add short term goals for each quarter of the game (i.e., before each food day). Each one has a negative and possibly a positive effect.  For example, you might have to pay a corn or resource to go up a level on a temple, but you get or lose extra victory points for doing so (i.e.,  you might go down a few points if you haven't achieved at least three levels, or go up 13 points if you achieved at least 10 levels). These are a little too punitive for my taste (so we don't use them as much as the others), but they do add a new dimension and short term goals to the game that some might find interesting.3. There are 8 new buildings (4 Age 1 Buildings + 4 Age 2 Buildings).  And many of these buildings add a new dimension to the game like providing a reward (corn, wood, stone, gold) each time you feed your tribe, or allowing you to trade in an existing building to use the resources used to build it to upgrade (or renovate) to a different building or even a monument.4. Finally, it introduces "Quick Actions" that you can select instead of or in addition to the already existing actions. These are randomly placed on the main gear (and there are 7 for Age 1, and 6 for Age 2). A quick action might give you corn, a resource, or allow you to advance a level in technology by paying the usual cost.  You pick up workers from the Quick Action Spaces at the end of your turn (similar to how you would if you selected the first player space), rather than waiting until the next turn.  This makes them available immediately which can come in handy.All that, and it includes everything you need to play with 5 player rather just 4 from the base game (i.e., 1 orange score marker, 6 orange meeples, 7 orange technology/temple markers, plus an extra player board, plenty of extra wood/corn harvest tiles, and 30 wooden resource tiles -- wood, stone, gold).When you consider that you can use each component separately, or add two or more together in many different combinations, this expansion really does add a ton of replayability to an already fun game.  But, it also adds one or more layers of complexity, which might be too much for some people given the base game already has a steep learning curve.  But, if you have figured out and like the base game, you should have no trouble figuring out these additions, too (especially since some -- like tribes -- are pretty easy to incorporate).

I originally wrote this review for and you can get it a little cheaper here: Rivals for Catan. So, please excuse me if you read it twice (but, I thought I'd include it here as well since I didn't know where folks would start).As noted in many of my other game reviews, I'm I am always looking for games I can play with my fiance. She is what some would call a "reluctant gamer" whereas I am an avid gamer, so I have be careful about what games I introduce her to. She prefers games that rely at least a little on luck (i.e., not all strategy) and aren't too complex (i.e., where you can learn/remember the mechanic after a game or two), whereas I love strategy and complexity but don't mind a little luck. We also like games you can finish in a single session (or games you can play multiple times in a single session). And, while there are definitely some luck and strategy components in The Rivals for Catan, after four plays including one with the Era of Gold theme, this game really felt "just ok" to us (and on Amazon three stars = just ok).Luck components come in the form of (1) the production dice -- which tells you which resources you get; (2) the event dice -- which lets you know what benefits or drawbacks might occur in that round; and (3) which cards you draw from the draw stack. Strategy components include (1) what you decide to add to your principality -- and when; (2) when you play various action cards; and (3) how much you complete for Strength Advantage, Trade Advantage, Skill Points, and Progress Points.After our four games, things felt a more luck than strategy based (i.e., a lot is out of you control and depends on both random dice rolls and mostly random card selection). And, we really didn't feel there was need for much interaction or many real / non-obvious decisions to make, both of which took quite a bit out of the game for us. And while we liked the game enough to keep it and give it an occasional spot in our rotation (in the hopes there is more there than we saw after our first four games), I doubt it will see much regular play.As a side note, the instructions say it comes with 2 wooden game pieces -- 1 hero token and 1 trade token. However, ours came with acrylic game tokens. More importantly, the symbol on the new acrylic hero token does not match the hero symbol on the cards or in the rulebook. That is, the hero symbol in the rules and in on all the cards is a battleaxe (this was also the symbol on the old wooden token which is still included as an illustration in the rules). However, the symbol on the acrylic token is a knight on horseback carrying a flag (not sure why it couldn't have at least been a battleaxe). This is a bit confusing/annoying in general, especially since the symbol for trade is a scale on the old token, the new token, and the cards. None of this is a huge deal for a game we didn't love anyway, but a bit of a turn off that they changed the components but not the instructions (and that in the process some of the symbols no longer match).

Ticket to Ride 10th Anniversary Edition is a wonderfully and beautifully redesigned version of the original game.  It includes everything from BOTH the original Ticket To Ride, PLUS the Ticket To Ride 1910 Expansion  (which is the way it really should have been released in the first place in my humble opinion).  Game play is exactly the same, but the components are different.  Here is a list of the key differences:BOX: The box is noticeably bigger and much heavier.  It includes an extremely well-designed insert to keep everything nicely in place.MAP: The map is also bigger (it measures approximately 38 x 26 inches, whereas the original measures approximately 31 x 22 inches) and uses a new/different artwork. The routes on the map are the same as the original.TRAIN CARS: On of the nice parts of this edition is the new plastic train cars. Instead of being the same just in a different color, each train uses a completely different design -- red circus car, blue passenger car, green caboose, yellow stripped barrel car, and black coal car. Each type of car comes with its own clearly marked tin for storage. However, one reason I'm giving this 4 rather than 5 stars is that I must admit that the cars, while nice, feel lower in quality/more fragile than I hoped. I've included a couple of photos in the customer's images page so you can compare the old cars to the new ones, and see how they fit on the old boards.TRAIN CARDS: The front of train cards use new/different artwork, and are marked "10th Anniversary." The back of the train cards looks like the box cover (i.e., black with the "10th Anniversary" logo). Also, these are FULL-SIZE cards (like the ones that came in the 1910 expansion), not the smaller cards that came in the original USA game.DESTINATION TICKETS: The front of destination tickets also use new/different artwork, and are marked "10th Anniversary."  Plus, each cards is still marked "Classic" or "USA 1910" to denote where the card originally came from. Ditto regarding the larger card size.SCORE MARKERS: It includes five larger (about 1 inch) square-shaped wooden score markers -- they come in red, blue, green, yellow, & black.The MSRP of $99.99, but you can get it for between 20% off on Amazon at the time this review was written, and sometimes more if you shop around online (for example, I got my copy for $70). This is the other reason I'm giving it 4 out of 5 stars (still seems a little pricey in general, especially given the quality of some of the components).  But, we are big TTR fans (we own the original with the 1910 expansion, Nordic Countries, Alvin & Dexter, plus Map Collections 1-4), and remain excited to have this addition in our collection.That said, if you just want the experience of playing the game, the original version plus the 1910 expansion will probably do (these two together were going for about $55 on Amazon at the time this review was written -- though you can get them for at least a little less if you shop around online).  But, if you want to celebrate the 10th anniversary of a great game and have something a little out of the ordinary, I think you'll find this to be a worthwhile edition of the game. It's a great set, and the only reasons I'm giving it 4 instead of 5 stars is that I wish the quality of the train cars were a little better, and/or that the price could have been a little lower. Otherwise, I'm very happy with it.EDIT: One quick addition based on a review I read below (in case you don't also read that review). The rules for the 1910 expansion were somehow omitted from this edition.  This is a pretty big and unfortunate omission, and a little embarrassing form Days of Wonder, I'm sure. For those who don't already have the 1910 rules, you can download them for free from the DoW web site (just do a search for "Ticket to Ride 1910 rules."

0:55 MinsThe TIE Defender is one of four "Wave 4" expansion sets for the X-Wing miniatures game. I think there are some good reasons to add one or maybe two TIE Defenders to your Imperial fleet (since the least expensive one cost 30 points, you'll not be able to use more than three in a 100 point game).To begin with it has some pretty good basic stats: 3 attack, 3 defense, 3 hull, and 3 shields. It can perform thee different actions (barrel roll, target lock, and focus), and be upgraded with up to three cards depending on which version you take.  Plus, it is the first ship that can do a WHITE K-Turn (and being able to take an action after a K-Turn -- or doing multiple K-Turns in a row -- will come in pretty handy).Pilots include:(1) Delta Squadron Pilot, a level 1 non-unique pilot that costs 30 points.(2) Onyx Squadron Pilot, a level 3 non- unique pilot that costs 32 points. This is a good example of what I mean when I say they are a little pricy for what you get.  The Firespray -31 Bounty Hunter is also level 3 and can take three actions and even more upgrades, but costs 33 points and has 3 attack, 2 defense, 5 hull, and 5 shield.  It's a little less maneuverable but has both fore and aft firing arcs to make up for this. It's a little harder to fly because of its large base, but it gets easier with practice.  So, I'm not sure why I'd take this over a Bounty Hunter in most instances since neither of them have a special ability.(3) Colonel Vessery, a level 6 unique pilot that costs 35 points, with what seems to me to be only an o.k. situational special ability that reads, "When attacking, immediately after you roll attack dice, you may acquire a target lock on the defender if it already has a red target lock token."(4) Raxler Brath, a level 8 unique pilot that costs 37 points, with another o.k. situational ability (i.e., requires you have a focus token left after you attack) that reads "After you perform an attack that deals at least 1 Damage card to the defender, you may spend a focus token to flip those cards faceup."It also includes one previously released upgrades (Ion Cannon), three upgrade that also comes with other Wave 4 ships (Ion Pulse Missiles -- a 3 point which can assign TWO ion tokens to a ship, Munitions Failsafe -- which lets you keep a secondary weapon if it doesn't hit, and Outmaneuver -- a 3 point elite talent that reduces your targets agility by one if you are not also in their firing arc), plus one that was exclusive to this expansion at the time it was released (Predator -- a 3 point elite talent that lets you reroll 1 attack dice, or 2 if firing vs. a pilot skill 2 or less).As with all expansions, this one includes all tokens, dials, etc. that you need to use this ship in a game (though a copy of the base set is still needed to play).While this is not my favorite ship in Wave 4, it does add a few nice new things in and of itself to the game, plus some new upgrades that can be used on it as well as other ships.  So, I think getting one is definitely worthwhile, and more than that may be worth it depending on your style of play.

I originally wrote this review for Munchkin Gets Promoted. So, please excuse me if you read it twice (but, I thought I'd include it here as well since I didn't know where folks would start).Below is a list of the cards that are included and the sets they go with. If you play one or more of the included versions (especially Fantasy Munchkin) and have always wanted some promo cards, you might want to consider getting it. My biggest disappointment is that it didn't include a single Star Munchkin card (which is too bad, as it is my and many other people's favorite set).Classic/Fantasy door back (8 cards):- Curse! Zombification- Cut In Line- Henchmonster- The Last Laugh- Mug The Shopkeeper- Ranger Hireling- Stacked Deck- Step-And-A-Half- Get Promoted (Go Up A Level) -- new card first released in this setClassic/Fantasy Munchkin treasure back (1 card):- Billiard Ball off Nonexistence -- new card first released in this setZombies Door Back (2 cards):- John of the Dead- Zombie SantaZombies Treasure Back (1 card):- Get A Head (Go Up A Bunch of Levels) -- new card first released in this setApocalypse Treasure Back (1 card):-Love Thy NeighborCthulhu Promo Back -- does not go into the deck and requires a Cthulhu dice to use (1 card):- Whim of the Elder Gods

The item description says this item contains six double sided terrain tiles, but that's not quite true. It does contain six double sided sheets, but four of them break out into multiple (between 5 and 13) smaller double sided tiles. All in all there are 38 double-sided tiles in this set (for a grand total of 76 images). Here is a brief description of what's on each tile:TILE 1 (one 8x10 square tile): Empty grey tile floor/room on one side, and open brown grate tile floor with two computer consoles (low objects/hindering terrain) on the other side.TILE 2 (one 8x10 square tile): Empty grey tile floor/room on one side, and grey tile floor/room with some low objects/hindering terrain on the other side.TILE 3 (five tiles ranging from 2x4 squares tiles to 4x8 squares): Empty grey tiles on one side (to expand the size of rooms or for hallways), and steps and shaft with walkway on the other side (mostly for hallways/walkways).TILE 4 (five tiles ranging from 2x4 squares tiles to 4x8 squares): Empty grey tiles on one side (to expand the size of rooms or for hallways), various hindering terrain (pits, low objects) on the other side.TILE 5 (thirteen tiles ranging from 1x1 square to 2x8 squares): Empty grey or grate tiles on one side (to expand rooms or for hallways/walkways), and various hindering terrain (doors, pits, low objects) on the other side.TILE 6 (thirteen tiles ranging from 1x1 square to 2x8 squares): Empty grey or grate tiles on one side (to expand rooms or for hallways/walkways and some hindering terrain), and grates (to expand rooms or for hallways/walkways) and various other objects (doors, turbo lifts, etc.) on other side.On the plus side, the images are high quality, and they are printed on a very thick, high quality card stock that should hold up for many uses. I also like that there are several smaller tiles rather than just six big tiles. Because of this, the set is fairly versatile and can be used to create numerous maps. Three sample complexes that can be made with these tiles are provided on the inside package, but I see many possibilities - especially if you buy more than one pack. So all in all, you get a fair amount of bang for your buck.On the minus side, the various types of terrain are not marked (walls, low objects, hindering terrain, pits, etc.), so these tiles cannot be used with the Star Wars minis game. I recognize these were designed for the RPG and not the minis game, but it would have been VERY easy for Wizards have given us a (Ploovo) Two-For-One by also making these tiles usable with the minis game (after all, that's what they did with the D&D minis cards -- they put stats/info for both the minis game and the RPG on each and every card). I'm very disappointed they didn't do something like that here.In sum, if you play the Star Wars RPG and want an easy way to create your own maps, I think you'll be happy with this item. But, if you were hoping to use them for the Star Wars minis game (i.e., Rebel Storm, Clone Strike, etc.), I would pass on these tiles.

As noted in many of my other relevant game reviews, I'm I am always looking for games I can play with my fiance. She is what some would call a "reluctant gamer" whereas I am an avid gamer, so I have be careful about what games I introduce her to. She prefers games that rely at least a little on luck (i.e., not all strategy) and aren't too complex (i.e., where you can learn/remember the mechanic after a game or two), whereas I love strategy and complexity but don't mind a little luck. We also like games you can finish in a single session (or games you can play multiple times in a single session).Ra was a real pleasant surprise that we both ended up liking quite a bit. We have played a few games by Reiner Knizia (and I have played several others without her), and this is one of the few we (or I) have really liked. We decided to try it because it was a dice game and we hadn't really done any of those at the time we purchased this one. Since it is a dice game it involves a fair amount of luck. But, it also has some very clever and easy to grasp strategy components that we have both enjoyed. The game-theme fit is ok at best, but the game mechanics more than make up for it in this instance. I believe it is out of print (hopefully they'll consider reprinting it again at some point), so I bought a gently used copy. I'm glad I did as we play it on a regular basis and always enjoy it when we do.

I don't normally write negative reviews. And, if you look at this and similar products on Amazon.com, it seems that 72% of the people who write comments gave it 4 or 5 stars, while 20% of writers gave it 1 or 2 stars.And, mine worked well for the first couple of months. The sound wasn't great, but was fine and better than expected for $30, which is what it was selling for when I bought it. If I rated it right away I would probably have given it 4 stars. Curious to know how many folks who initially gave it 4 or 5 stars do and don't still feel that way a few months later.But, I thought it worth adding my voice to the smaller chorus of folks who had a negative experience with these speakers. Again, they worked well at first, but after a couple of months the battery barely held a charge and the bluetooth and volume control were so flaky that it just wasn't worth the trouble anymore. I knew the risks from the other reviews when I bought it, and it wasn't overly expensive, so I'm not particularly upset by any of this. I just wanted folks to know so they could make an informed choice.At best it is unreliable, and there seems to be at least a 1 in 5 chance you'll have a bad experience with yours. Only you can decide if it is worth the risk to you (turns out, I chose unwisely). I literally through it out after about 3 months.

The 28 Days Later comic/graphic novel series is one of my favorite zombie-themed stories (slightly below the Walking Dead, and well above the rest of the zombie themed graphic novels I've read). The series covers the time period between the two movies 28 Days Later (Widescreen Special Edition) & 28 Weeks Later (Widescreen Edition). The Omnibus contains ALL 6 volumes/24 issues from the series.  The story is top notch, and the artwork is wonderful.  It contains a familiar character (Selena) as well as some solid new ones.  All that, and the Omnibus is a great deal for $32 (the price it was listed on Amazon at the time this review was written). If you liked 28 Days/Weeks Later, I highly recommend this book.

I live in AZ and we drive to the grand canyon a couple of times each year when we want a particularly challenging hike (usually the South Rim). This is by far the best map of the Grand Canyon we have come across, and it is the only map we use at this point.Just to give you a point of reference, we have hiked (1) down and up the Bright Angel -- to Plateau Point; (2) down and up the South Kaibab -- to Skeleton Point; (3) ALL the way down the Bright Angel and up the South Kaibab; and (4) ALL the way down the South Kaibab and up the Bright Angel.  Plus, last summer we did our best hike ever: RIM-TO-RIM-TO-RIM (one day each way, with a one day break in between).  And, a few weeks ago we went down the South Kaibab, across the Tonto Trail -- which is about 3/4 the way down, and up the Bright Angel. So, we've hiked just about every trail in the main area of the South Rim, plus a little of the North Rim.  And, this map accompanied us every step of the way.Our favorite things about the map include (1) it is VERY easy to read -- much easier than any other I have of the area; (2) it includes distance information for each trail segment which you can easily add together to figure out how long your hike is going to be or how far you have left to go, (3) it indicates where there is fresh drinking water along the trail -- though you should keep in mind that some of this water is seasonal; and (4) it is printed on waterproof plastic/paper so even though I've used it for the past several years it is still in very good shape. In sum, I highly recommend this map if you are thinking about hiking any part of the Grand Canyon that this map covers.

I live in AZ and do day hikes in the Superstition mountains many times each year.  We usually hike the Canyon Lake, Peralta, First Water, Lost Dutchman, and others. We prefer loops but also do a few there and back round trips.  We usually hike 8 or so miles at a time, but have done trails in the area ranging from 4-17 miles (and we've done many different loops of various distances from the Peralta and First Water trailheads... which is one of the best parts of hinking in this area -- there are LOTS of options). So, I think it is fair to say that we have used this map, and used it a lot. Unfortunately, I purchased several maps of the area before I happened across this one (all were ok but not great).  But, since I found this one I never use any other.  This one is VERY easy to read (much easier than any other I have).  Everything is very clearly marked and easy to follow. It includes distance information for each trail segment so you can easily add them together to figure out how long your hike is going to be up front. All that and it is printed on waterproof plastic/paper so even though I've used it for the past several years it is still in very good shape.  In short, I highly recommend this map over any other map of the area.

I looked high and low for a circle punch that cut 1.75 inch circles for a project I am working on.  Lots of 1.5, 2.0, 2.5 inch, but few 1.75 inches.  After finding this one on Amazon and reading the great reviews, I decided to give this one a try.  I'm glad I did.  I cut mostly card stock, and this punch has no trouble cutting through even thicker paper.  Plus, there is a view finder on the bottom so you can see what you are cutting (which is very helpful to me since the circles I needed to cut are marked and I need to cut them in precisely the right place).  I also like that it locks when I'm not using it (keeps it a little flatter and makes it easier to store). All things considered I'm very happy with this item, and knowing what I know now I'd buy it again without hesitation.8/12/14 update... Downgraded from 5 to 4 stars because it is already having trouble cutting through thinner paper.  Still works fine on card stock or if I double up a regular sheet of paper, but the cut is not nearly as clean on a single sheet of regular paper (always requires a bit of trimming after).

This is an abridged version of the Star Wars: A New Hope story.  The story itself is about 25 pages (with about 10-30 words per page in an over-sized font, and lots of pictures). They do a wonderful job using Lego minifigures and sets to tell the story (relying mostly on scenes from Tatooine and the Death Star).  And, I'm actually surprised they managed to capture the essence of the story in so few words and images.  Keep in mind that this is their Level 1 reader, which is designed for kids in grades K-2. But, I think it is a nice way to introduce kids to the Star Wars saga.

As far as the mini expansions go, I place Cursed somewhere between Small World Grand Dames Expansion Board Game (2nd Printing) (which I gave 2 stars because we don't use it anymore) and Small World Be Not Afraid Expansion Board Game (which I gave 4 stars because we like most of the races and banners quite a bit).I'm giving this one 3 stars mostly because it only includes 2 new races (Goblins & Kobolds) that we have found to be good but not great.
