It also include 5 new special powers (Cursed, Ransacking, Hordes of, Were-, & Marauding), a couple of which we liked quite a bit.  "Cursed" in particular adds a nice twist to the game if you like that sort of thing (which we sometimes do).  It doesn't actually give you a special power or extra race tokens, but you have to pay 3 gold to skip it instead of 1 (so by the time someone takes it it could be worth quite a few points in and of itself). We also liked "Were-", which works during the day (even number turns) but not during the night (odd number turns). The others fell into the "just ok" category for us (which is what 3 stars means on Amazon).In sum, we do like it enough to use it sometimes, but not enough to use it every time we play.

Another great game from Elephant Games via Big Fish.  Great spooky atmosphere, easy to navigate haunted school.  There is a detailed map that allows teleporting but I didn't need it as much as in some other games.  There were a few times when inventory items had to be hauled back and forth across many screens (which is a good time to use the map!) but not all the time.  I got moderately stuck once or twice, but managed to get out of it without using a hint.  There are not too many hidden object scenes, a major plus.  The mini-games varied from a bit too easy to quite hard, with a good mix in between.  There are a few short clip scenes, but emphasis on short, and the dialogue screens, also not many, can be clicked through if you are a fast reader and impatient (!)Although I experienced no glitches within the game on my HDX 8.9 Fire, I did have a few issues with the Fire after I was about halfway through.  Specifically, if I exited the game and shut off the screen (without actually turning the Fire off) when I turned the screen back on I sometimes had no carousel, just a blank screen.  Or I had the carousel but nothing worked.  Turning off the Fire and turning it back on always resolved the issues and this only happened when I played the game.  Going into "Settings" after you have finished a game session, and doing a Force Stop on the game will also prevent the problem if it happens on your device.  Not a big deal, but I mention it because it scared the heck out of me when my Fire seemed to be acting up!

Boring, cliched, so-so graphics, short.  After I downloaded this, I realized I had played it before, buying it for $1.49 on sale.  Unbelievably, this game is still available on a different page for full price of $2.99!  Why anyone would bite on that now is a mystery.  Why Amazon still has the full-price listing is another mystery, but that seems to be the way of it with these "Actually Free" games.  While it's true you pay no money, and they are the same as the full-price versions, you are required to go into your Fire settings and turn on the setting that allows Amazon to snoop on everything you do.  This may or may not bother you.  It doesn't bother me that much, but being a persnickety person, I make sure to change the setting back when I'm not playing one of these free games.  So far, the games offered for free are only average at best anyway.

This is at least the third time I have downloaded this same game under a different name and developer each time.  As I recall,  it wasn't a bad game the first time.  So why only one star?  First of all I don't like being scammed into a download even if free.  Second I REALLY don't appreciate it if the first thing I see after opening it is a loud, full screen video ad that is unskippable immediately and the next thing is a beg to rate the game.  Well, be careful what you wish for, Mr Developer.  I'm sure this rating isn't what you had in mind.

Lightweight but good for medium weight fabrics too.  It adhered easily and stayed in place.  It's a real advantage to have interfacing wider than the usual 20 inches and made cutting out pattern pieces quicker and easier.

I used to enjoy Playtinium Games.  When this one first came out back in 2013, I couldn't buy it because it was not compatible with either Kindle Fire I owned at the time.  I'm pretty sure it wasn't compatible with the 8.9" HDX Fire I bought last year either -- until now.  I had trouble going left just like everybody else, but then the glitch with going left was fixed.  Admittedly I was surprised it WAS fixed, being that this is an old game released long ago.  Anyway, I was able to get on with the game, but I was not impressed with the touch response and with the graphics in general.  I didn't mind the math problem near the beginning.  Some of the mini-games I thought were a bit tedious with needing to remember complicated symbols set down elsewhere in the game.  A piece of paper and a pencil was a necessity for me and I don't like this in a video game -- give me a journal or a camera or something to remember clues.  It's no fun to have to backtrack several screens for a complex clue and then remember it all when you get to the puzzle.The mini-game that was the last straw for me was the one that involved remembering numbers and symbols that covered a whole page of a "book."  You had to plug the numbers into a puzzle, while also remembering the numbers in a story in another "book."  I really didn't feel like copying all that stuff down just to do a silly mini-game, and I decided to call the whole thing quits.  Life is too short.  Game Over!

Another game that made me glad I waited until it was actually free! If I had paid $2.99 or more for this game I would have been extremely annoyed. The game itself isn't bad and is almost on a par with Big Fish entries, except for the lag time between screens. You spend an awful lot of time looking on a "Loading" screen Every.Single.Time you change screens. Really, even if you have just been there, you must wait. Very, very annoying and led me to give up on the game very early on. Otherwise, I might have played and liked it. I was playing on an 8.9" Fire HDX.

Wonderful point and click adventure!  Good graphics, labeled inventory, good game map, good story - NO hidden objects!  The puzzles were sometimes fairly easy and sometimes devilishly difficult if you weren't paying attention.  So, pay attention!  There is a hint system to get you unstuck.  The game was plenty long enough and well worth the investment.  If you like the Forever Lost games, this is similar except somewhat easier.

I am SO glad I did not bite on actually paying money for this game!  And in fact, if you are not paying attention, you can still spend money for the game if you come across it on another page, which is the way of it with all the "Actually Free" games.  This game has the most irritating narration I have ever encountered.  Not only that, it holds your hand at every step, and seems to be mostly some variation on hidden objects.  Plus every time you change screens, and I do mean EVERY time, you are subject to a "Loading" screen for several long seconds.Just as a heads up, there is one difference between the "Actually Free" and the paid versions and that is the fact that if you are doing the free version (which I highly recommend you do!) Amazon requires you to adjust a setting on the Fire that allows them to snoop on your activity.  This may or may not bother you, and to be fair, they do warn you of this when you try to open the game.

This is one of the better run of the mill, door escape games.  You still don't get labeled inventory but at least the screens are brighter and more interesting.  It's not hard though, and like the others of this type, the hardest thing is figuring out what the inventory objects are because the graphics are pretty sub-par, compared to games from developers like Alawar and Big Fish  -- which often run about the same price or only a little more.  I'm glad I waited to buy this until Amazon was giving it away for free.  It might be worth 99 cents at most.

Wow, I was glad I waited until Amazon offered this game for free!  If I had paid $1.99 or $2.99 I would have been highly annoyed.  It is run of the mill with poor, mostly dark, graphics and unlabeled inventory (par for the course for most of these low-caliber escape games).  Plus there's something really creepy and annoying about the "host" who shows up on every new screen with a stupid comment.  The hardest thing about the game is trying to figure out exactly what you picked up.  It's not always obvious.  Or course if you knew the game would be even shorter and more pointless!

This is a good selection of popular items, including regular and barbecue  Lays chips, Fritos, Doritos (ranch and nacho cheese) and Cheetos.  I paid a good price, around $13, but I see that the price has gone up now, so won't be buying again unless it comes down when I happen to be looking!

I am completely baffled by all the four and five star reviews.  This book is terrible.  As others have noted, Holmes and Watson are NOTHING like Conan Doyle's creations.  They don't talk or behave like Holmes and Watson, and it's not just the anachronistic dialog.  Holmes would NEVER say some of things he says here.  The stories themselves are dull, dull, dull.  It seems like the author got bored with them herself and just ended them abruptly whenever she had something better to do elsewhere.  There are lots and lots of great Holmes and Watson pastiches.  This is not one of them.  I congratulate anyone who got more than halfway through.  I quit at about the one-third mark.

I probably would have given this game five stars if the hidden object scenes hadn't increased so much after roughly the halfway point.  Up until then I was quite pleased that there weren't too many, but later on it seemed like they were around every corner.  Some of the items were hard to find too.  I used hints for the last few objects in many of them, but then I never have much patience with hidden objects.  Once in a while the tap response wasn't the best in those scenes either.  The map wasn't the worst one I've ever seen but it wasn't as detailed as many.  It did allow you to teleport, but not necessarily into the exact scene you wanted.Otherwise, the game was pretty good.  The story was a little different from what's been out there lately; there was no animal helper and the clip scenes were not too long or annoying.  The graphics were quite good.  The puzzles were a mix of the old chestnuts and a few moderately new ones.  There were several of the jigsaw puzzle type and they were no snap to do.The game is on the short side, but not excessively so, and there is an, also short, bonus round.  I had no problems playing it on an HDX 8.9 Fire, not a single glitch aside from the  aforementioned occasional sluggish tap response in the hidden object scenes. All in all, this game was better than what I expected from Artifex Mundi, which is not my favorite game developer.
Hidden objects - boring dialog - hidden objects.  The end.  Worth what I paid, which was nothing.

I was also expecting great things from this game, based on the "Brink of Consciouness" label.  The last Brink of Consciousness game was great, one of the best.  This one is sadly lacking.  First of all, the obnoxious, ever-present long drawn out clip scenes and dialog.  Game Developers:  Here's a hint - I want to play the game!  I do not want the game to play itself!  The adventuring was very by-the-numbers.  The game map was a joke.  Just circles that looked like molecule diagrams - no labels or graphics to tell you where you are or where you are going.  The further you get in the game, the more blank circles.  Even if you could teleport using it (which you can't) it wouldn't help because you would have no way of being sure where you were going.  Oh, and there were no levels of difficulty to choose from either, you take what the game makers give you, which were sparkles and no mistap penalties in the hidden object scenes.  Speaking of the hidden object scenes, at least there weren't an awful lot of them, and they were easy to get through, being the old fashioned no frills kind.This was obviously an older game, maybe spiffed up a little, and re-released.  It just screamed first generation game, with its afterthought map and endless dialog.  One of those games when you're sorry you bought the unlock.  No glitches though, playing on a Fire HDX 8.9.

This game got better as it went along, which was a good thing because at first I regretted buying the unlock.  I didn't think the graphics were that good, although they weren't terrible.  I've just seen better.  There were a lot of clip scenes at the beginning, which I always find kind of boring if they are too long.  I don't like the game playing itself!  There were fewer and shorter ones later on.  The hidden object scenes were fairly easy and not as many as some other games.  I don't mind having to manipulate things in HOS, I even like it if there are a lot of puzzles within the HOS.  I just don't like having too many HOS and objects too hard to find.  In this game the HOS didn't bug me too much.Like its predecessor, Serpent Creek, this game had an oddball thing going on, where you had to find nine objects of interest within a regular (not HO) scene.  Since you generally had no idea in advance what objects would be of interest you just tap on anything that looks like anything.  If it's one of the objects of interest, it sparkles.  Then the "objects" turn into nine tiles that you must arrange in the order of what you think happened before you arrived on the scene.  I found the tiles hard to decipher and so I usually arranged them according to the colors of their frames and the pink "ribbon" running through them.  After you got the tiles right, you were treated to a clip scene in silhouette of what happened before you got there.  I found this as tedious and boring as it was in Serpent Creek, but happily the developers seemed to get tired of it too, and it only was done in probably the first half of the game.During the early mid-part of the game I had some screen change delays that resulted in a black screen for a few seconds.  This went away after a while.  Otherwise there were no glitches on my Fire HDX.  The adventuring was VERY easy, with found objects being almost always used in the same scene, or the one next door.  There is a useful map with enough detail and labels to let you know where you are, and to teleport you if needed.  I found that the asylum was easy enough to navigate that I didn't need to consult the map much.I appreciate that this game was not another fairy tale and there was no animal helper.  The story line was fine, and in the end I was glad I bought the unlock.  I got it for $2.99 though; don't know if I would recommend paying $4.99 for such a short game with no bonus round.  Maybe wait for a sale again.

The stones in these earrings are deep, true London Blue of a good size.  They have sparkle.  I must say that I have never had earrings with this exact type of setting (a wire that clips into a hook at the bottom) and I don't like it.  To me, from the front, the wire assembly is very apparent and detracts from the appearance, especially since the earrings hang oddly and stiffly.  I would not buy earrings made like this again.  However I must say that my husband likes them and says that, from a full side view, the wire assembly is not apparent and the stones are what you notice.

The necklace is a bit clunky perhaps, a bit too sparkly perhaps and does not look at all expensive.  But for the price of $9, it's perfect costume wear.  And as a bonus, the earrings are shiny, pretty, light and do look like they cost more.

I don't usually read this kind of book (I'm more of a short story,  classic cozy or Sherlock Holmes type) and I only took it because it was free.  However, having said that I found it to be a page turner that kept me reading despite some flaws in characterization.  The writing style and dialog were fairly natural and good, or at least not annoying (more than I can say for a modern "cozy" that I just finished.)  I didn't find the plot all that implausible although perhaps it could have been tightened a bit.  I liked the fact that the book was only around 200 pages, rather than the bloated messes that are popular now.  I'm afraid I did guess the villain rather early on, and the ending was a bit rushed, but not bad.  Overall, I think this author has promise and I would probably be inclined to pick up another of her books.

Beautiful ring with lots of sparkle and large dark blue stones, definitely London blue.  Size runs true.  I bought an 8, actually wear a 7 3/4 and it is slightly big, but not to the point it's a problem.

This is a horror version of the supernatural.  A coven of five had convened with other supernatural agents to overthrow this world and allow the seven fallen angels to take over the Earth.  The two noble members turned on the common folk who were given over to the Church authorities for torture and burning.  This book follows the descendants and those who have come across them across the years following.  The book pulls no imagery.  The specifics of witch terror and torture are specified.  Also discussed in harrowing detail are the activities of these agents of evil and the picture is disquieting.  For all of this,  the prose is strangely lyrical and evokes another world beyond our ken.  The characters are in fact multidimensional for all the emphasis on the other side.  It is a book that I recommend to readers of the genre, and those who are strong of will.

Anne Rice is arguably the founder of the plethora of vampire stories now deep on the ground.  Many of these have merits, but Rice continues to be the master of  the genre. Anne Rice fills  her writing with literate and well thought out philosophy of the meaning of immortality.  She does it in an unassuming manner that never intrudes on the sense of suspense and breathlessness that the plot demands.  Her language is lovely and her dialogues effortless.  I think due to her popularity, this skill has been underrated by the critics.When Rice began to the accounts of the modern vampires, I was swept away by the premise of a rock star, Lestat, emerging with his nocturnal ways, fashionable figure and entrancing pallor.  It was a breathless idea to link the two identities.  Over the years, I have wondered how she could maintain the level of invention with this story line, but she has always risen to the occasion.  This book is another penultimate achievement.  I think it is because of the underlying quest of our vampires for meaning that the books retain their vitality.This book enmeshed me from the start.  Some little reasons are the skill she uses to describe the details of his world.  She is a master of "rich porn", describing the opulence of the unimaginable wealth without tipping into the common mistake of allowing it to overtake the story.  Her characters are described physically that one can imagine them easily.  Her settings are lush and chosen with care to resonate with the otherworldly character of the action.  She also does not overdo the vampire "gifts", keeping their souls as the real center of their stories.In this book, LeStat has been in hiding, depressed and tired of the world.  After the full activity of his 200 years, relatively young, he has found his life a burden.  One by one, the central characters of the preceeding years, and books, emerge to becken him from his slumber.  It is as if a great slumber had been interrupted by the peril now in the world.  Two of my favorites, Jesse and David of the esoteric students of the supernatural emerge and more secrets emerge of their founding and they search once more for answers to the nature of the "blood".  This is a book to enjoy on any number of levels. Those steeped in the stories of the Prince Lestat will be pleased with this new chapter, but those people who are new to the series will be able to follow the story and understand the premises. Please read this book, and enter a finely constructed fantasy well rooted in the ponderings of our world.

This is a wonderful book that swallows the reader whole.  Deb, our narrator is witty, and darkly humorous.  By the time she has told us about her wedding, and her slightly antisocial approach to life, we have fallen into her view of the world.  The next chapter, she has gone on a honeymoon with her husband Chip and has seen a mermaid.  And the reader seems to seamlessly go with the assumption that this is true and that the real issue is keeping her safe and secret.Deb is a cranky young woman.  Under the sway of her friend, she is way too obsessed with the obesity epidemic for my taste, but that would be my single problem with her.  The rest of the way she views our race with spirited distrust is endearing to me.  Then having fallen for the whole assumption about having seen the mermaids, it seems logical to be involved in a race to save said mers, which apparently is the politically correct way to refer to them.As far as I am concerned, any book that refers to a politically correct form for mermaids is a keeper.  The quirky point of view enhances the package, and the jaundiced view of society wraps it up.  This is a great book;well a great book to read.

This isn't a pornographic novel, nor is it only for math geeks.  But it does illustrate the rarified existence of those who deal in "pure" reality who try to live in the world.  This novel is written in alternating chapters on the story of Godel's life as seen by his widow, and her life today being interviewed by the a new generation of intellectual elite.  Adele Godel has lived at the side of a neurasthenic genius through the upheavals that have arguably shaped today's world.  They had started in Nazi riddled Austria and fled to the new European intellectual capital, Princeton.  Godel as a friend of Einstien and a peer of Oppenheimer existed in the rarified atmosphere of the intersection of pure science in the world of the atom and relativity and the nuclear age.The discussions cited between the great geniuses are intricately researched and many of the conversations are quoted from life.  Adele is a girl from a merchant home, lacking in education, and convinced of her dislocation in the world of Princeton.  She misses the dirt and the elegance of Vienna, at the end of WWII no longer in existence.  But she is the goddess of small victories and finds her happiness in yeast and sweeping.  She is the eternal nurse of the hypochondriacal and paranoid Godel who rarely turns his attention from his proofs to her.  Yet as his widow, she is repository of extraordinary insight and memories.  Her discussions with the new student seeking archives are are witty and wry.  Her speech is ironic and sincere in cycles.  She has much to say to this generation.I found the book to be engrossing sand thought provoking.  Having gotten the title from Huffington Press, I can in fact agree it is the book of this week.

Dorrigo concluded that "a good book leaves you wanting to reread the book.  A great book compels you to reread your own soul."  This then is a great book.  It is stunning in the true sense of the word, bringing the mind to a bewildered stop over and over.  In telling the story of of Dorrigo's life against the backdrop of a world gone insane, it forces the reader to broken conclusion after broken conclusion.  The gathering focus of the story is the construction of the "Line", an impossible railroad built by slave labor through the jungles of Siam by the Japanese rulers of the Australians POWs.  The life of Dorrigo before, during and after his captivity is interwoven with those of fellow prisoners and jailers both.At many points I was sure I understood the arc of one of these lives and the clear demarcation of good and evil, only to have the next chapter enter from another point of view.  This is not to say that this book deals with relativity or circumstance of morality.  Rather the author successfully addresses the futility of ever knowing all the elements needed for a judgment.  I have always know there is no real return from a war, but this book brings the truth home with a vengeance.The layers of meaning and the subtlety of language make this book that rare novel that challenges my view of the world. In stark contrast to the lightness of touch in many scenes then is the brutality of the life within the slave camp.  Yet neither is this shocking imagery anything but vital to the story being told.  I believe this book is very rightly the winner of the Man Booker Prize.  It belies the despair of its characters in believing their truths would die with the moving of the years.  The haiku in the title summarizes the conundrum proposed, and hints at the depth of the writing on hand.

"The Vines" invokes the haunted land of the Southern estate Spring House.  As a plantation, it was the scene of a bloody past written on the backs of its slaves.  While all the familiar elements are present, Christopher Rice has taken a masterful touch to the ghosts of people used beyond any sense of morality.  Virginie was born to a strange power over the fields but as a slave she suffered the same fate of horror.  Now the estate is the home of an effete family that is nonetheless mired in rage and secrets.  This setting is fleshed out so totally that even the smells of the place come to the reader.Very early we see the vines begin to take their due, starting with the immoral and cheating husband of the present owner, Caitlin.  Her childhood friend becomes embroiled in the mystery, and the past plays the leading role.  The suspense is played beautifully and the writing engages the reader from the start.  Right at the point in which I was sure I knew all the answers, another twist brings the plot forward.  The characters have that southern cache of intertwined fates and characters, and in this sense the book is character driven.To me, the most interesting issue is how the victims are chosen for attack.  Everyone has sins to a greater or lesser degree.  The question of who is spared, and for how long, is left open till the end.  This is the world of morality soaked into the soil.  Can the site of great evil ever clear?  The punishment itself is horrible and beguiling.  The descriptions of the attacks are not gory in the classical sense, although they certainly invoke some nauseating scenes.  Even in the midst of the most supernatural of attacks, the victim's reaction i dominant.  It takes a skilled hand to blend a story of revenge and a tale of horror without stooping to the obvious, and Rice has achieved this task.

These two people are wildly unlikely to find each other in the world.  But this is a small town in Maine in the midst of a blizzard, an atmospheric phenomenon that quickly redraws the lines of daily life.  I have lived in a small town in Maine, and found the unseen setting to be spot on.  But you do not need to understand the tiny cabin that keeps our  two characters barely safe through the storm.  The snow is so impelling as to serve as a third character.Eric s a small town lawyer who has come to save the quirky Danielle.  "sooner of later she would be in trouble, either victim or perpetrator".  Hiking down to see to the safety of his passenger, he has found himself at the mercy of an impersonal storm.  He has been left by his wife who is due to make an unlikely appearance and she is bespoken to her Army Reserve husband.  His wife is distant and rejecting; her husband is possessive and intrusive.  Together they seem to make a dimension of the terrifying world.As the title suggests, they are drawn to each other from their not so separate worlds.  The reader knows, as they do not or will not tell, that the absent spouses are gone and have really never been present.  The description of these two awkward misfits to the world of love is precisely pitched to reveal the people living apart from the world.  The prose encases the reader in the raging storm, exposing us to the elements that strip the superficial.  Its a perfect book for autumn in a cozy chair.

I love the premise for the book.  The idea that a blood plague has left some small group of survivors with special powers is a huge relief from the late flood of zombies.  The story fails for me with the extreme nature of the powers that these young people have developed.  Adelina Amouteru is our first character who has come to her understanding of her new self on the day of her attempted execution.  She has endured a lifetime of abuse from her father.  And here is my second problem, society has reacted exactly as is depicted in XMen with terror an shunning.  Many of the passages are fascinating, but my final problem hit at the end of the book, which is only the starting point for a new trilogy.  I don't know how I missed the fact that this is a series, but I did and it bugs me.There is a lot to enjoy with the world building in this novel, but not enough for me to pursue.

This book starts with a lovely premise.  I like magical realism, but this book disappointed me.  The chapters are interwoven with time changes and with fairy stories.  Set in the chaos before and during World War II, Josef is based on the doctor who inspired and participated in the birth of psychoanalysis.  He has had a new patient brought to him by his servant Benjamin.  Lillie was naked and mute at first.  She was battered.  With the return of speech, she insists she has traveled through time as a machine to destroy the monster.  Krysta in another thread is the spoiled daughter of a Nazi camp doctor.  Set in Austria and Germany, the fairy stories are the scary German based tales of terri invoked upon the children, and the psyche, of the German state.I found the execution to be clumsy.  Often instead of deepening the suspense of the story, the turns of the chapters were very confusing  I have a high tolerance for confusing, but this problem seems to be rooted in poor writing and not in furthering the plot.  In addition, I found the fairy tales to be annoying.  They became repetitive and tedious. They really didn't add anything to the understanding of the Nazi horror.  Despite using the scarier stories, I think they belittle the setting.Of the characters, I like the young apprentice Benjamin the best.  This is probably not a coincidence since he is the single character not given to telling fiction.  I also enjoyed the evolution of the character Lillie.  I did not care for Krysta.  Her brattiness was magnified.  Her language was not convincing.  Her speech seemed exactly as if an adult had written an imaginary child, and this was irritating.  The contrast with the words in her fantasy with the ones she spoke was stark.I did find the mystery compelling despite the stops and starts.  And I did in fact like the ending very much.  I am sad with this book because I waited for it with anticipation.  I still think this writer has promise, but I am not a fan of her editor.

Perhaps I cannot be blamed for returning over and over to thoughts of the Holocaust as this darkly brilliant novel unravels the fabric of a society determined to forget the past by law.  No one is to remember the great brutality of a war gone by as if to examine it would resurrect more hatred in the opposing views of thought and blame.  There are dark references to trains and selections, ruined cities, and toppled economies of greed and affluence.In Kervin's small town, the people congratulate themselves on their distance from the turmoil of the past and of the large cities.  In the Ishmael law, itself a gifted riff on a doomed pseudonym, everyone has taken a new name.  Heirlooms are limited.  Everyone says sorry all the time.  Yet the village is haunted with violence and unions are rarely monogamous.  Fights are common.  No one says J without a gesture across the lips.  No one notes history.  Kervin is a remarkable man, a Cohen unable to drop the significance of this made up name.  He has fallen in love with Ailleen and it is their very temperance that does not allow them to give lip service to the inanities of the new civilization, thus cursing themselves in their small world.The writing is perplexing and often labyrinthine.  The sense of unease and of being followed never abates.  The irony of a society willed to a civility that never holds is ironic in the extreme.  Yet this is a novel that brings to mind every denier, every person who is determined to bury the past, and every book that shades hatreds of history.  It is not so very far to venture from this book to any determinedly pleasant day in the many blood soaked sands of the world.  Yet the main characters remain vibrant in contrast and their determination to be human brings balm to the reader.  I find this to be an inspired piece of fiction and one I will not forget.

This book has been written with Gawande's perpetual insight and care.  It is one gloomy book filled with necessary facts that are particularly depressing for someone like me now full into my sixties.  Surely it can come as no shock that medicine is ill prepared for the ambiguities of elder care.  It is a numbing task to pursue  often opposite goals of safety and self identity.  Much of this book consists of the presentation of the problems of caring for an aging population who as a whole do not wish to be warehoused no matter how comfortably or safely.  The answers are not always palatable and the social motivation in government is not all that available.  Nonetheless, this book presents the realities of life ahead of us, and does it with grace and precision.  It is not the messenger's fault....

This is the second much anticipated novel in as many years that has just failed to arouse much interest in me.  The opening consists of pages and pages of the subjective experiences of young Frank  He has been born into a conservative, salt of the earth family in Iowa and I cannot truly tell you why it never came to engage me.  The progression f the family growing and growing up remains gained to me by the minute details of young Frank from the days of his being the only child.  Now I love Smiley's writing, I am a fan of the slow paced detailed character study, and I dote on stories of the very young.  For some reason these elements failed to work for me this time.  This book is published to critical acclaim so I suspect it is my own shallowness that has left me cold.  You should probably red it for yourself.  Note that even a bad book by Smiley that rates three stars from me.  He writing remains wonderful in its ability to nail human experience in a way that echoes with you are you read.
This is a simple device that fills a simple need with no fuss.  Perfect.

This is a surprisingly lyrical book written by a woman with schizophrenia.  I had picked it up to refer to a patient, but I found myself mesmerized by the prose that the author uses to describe her perceptions, both reality and non-reality based.This is a woman with deepened insight on the human condition after her long struggle to come to terms with her illness.  Schizophrenia is badly misunderstood by most people, and I think this book highlights many of the extraordinary insights that can occur when the usual associations on thought are loosened.  Not to misunderstand, these visions are ones that Kristina would willingly abandon in exchange for a freedom from voices and questionable judgment.  Her discussion of her recovery in AA stands as a solid addition to this book and one that is a testament to the AA movement.  This is well worth reading for those effected, those who are related, and those who wish to understand their fellow human.

Dr. Melinek has spared nothing in her description of the autopsy suite in the Medical Examiner's Office in New Year City.  Her husband prefaces all her work stories with warning I chose for my title, "Remember this can only end badly."  "Autopsy means see for yourself.", and this is as close to seeing for myself that I wish to come.  Still I have a decidedly morbid streak, and knowing details about death is how I keep my own anxieties in check.  This book fills my purposes quite well.  On the way, there is much of idle curiosity that is satisfied.  The writing is bright and concise.  Her inclusion of her own experience and reactions add a human dimension that renders the topic bearable on a cold autumn day.

Lila voices that part of us that is fundamentally alone, and preternaturally outside the the bounds of society. I love this character.  She is not the least cuddly in her wildness, and she knows only how to stand in the world she has learned.  Marilynne Robinson has mastered that archetype of the loner ruled only by the internal truths of her ties to nature.  Robinson has returned to Gilead, a poor town on the verge of collapsing to the surrounding wilderness, resisting only with the basic decency of its citizens.  Robinson has woven a moral fiber which embraces the Bible as it is woven into the rules of empathy and natural order.Lila was born into the  ultimately neglectful family.  She was found by Doll, alone on a porch and half dead at age of four.  She and Doll wander the world in the days preceding the Dust Bowl.  "Doll my have been the loneliest woman in the world, and she was the loneliest child."  They were ruled by  "Whatever happens, just be quiet, and it'll pass, most likely."  We find her years later, aged by the places she has seen, drawn to the world of Gilead.  She has found a savior in the kind, old minister who has fallen in love with her.  The courtship is the loveliest thing I have read in years.  They come to value the comfort of the other standing by her shoulder.  She has come to care for the kind old man and finds him beautiful.  Their marriage is lyrical to me.The ethical code in Robinson's books is a rather lovely one.  The old minister says, "Any judgment of the kind is a great presumption.  And presumption is a very grave sin."  Lila come to believe that the  search for meaning  is like knowing a song. "In a song a note follows the one before because it is that song and not another one.".  This is a book in which to linger.  I would honestly read a recipe written by Marilynne Robinson, but this is because she writes such wonderful language.  She has found a way to put words to thought that surpasses the rule of silence.

This book has an intriguing premise.  Nanobots are minuscule robots that control such processes as disease prevention and sharpening perception.  This is a concept not new to dystopian literature, and it is usually dystopian and not hopeful literature that describes their use.  As in every brave new world, the cost of such luxury is the surrender of freedom.  Certainly as in the of decades of writers, this technology means the essential end of personal privacy.This novel combines this concept with that of the search for complete artificial intelligence, and it does so in the life of our narrator, Ella.  She is surviving daughter of the genius of this science.  She is an appealing voice with an unswerving sense of ethics and an unusual ability to enter other people's minds during her mother's trademark lucid dreaming service.The lucid dream, a controlled visit to one's best world of the past, is the gold standard in psychological services.  It is in this technique that the novel's impetus leaves that of its similar relatives.  I really liked the complexity of Ella's voice.  The world building was done with a masterful touch as well.  The technology of this future is beguiling.  I didn't like the prolonged hunt and seek sequences, but I do not like these in any format.  This may be a personal tic on my part.  For me it weakens the web of the story when the intrigue is drawn too long in the mechanics of flight.  Overall however, this is a book that I recommend.  It held my interest and sparked some new thoughts which is a big part of what I demand from a novel.

"Crimson Dawn" is an entirely satisfying conclusion to the Exilon 5 Trilogy.  Eliza Green has chosen not to include a summary of the trilogy to date, but the book is doable as a stand alone.  It is better having read the first two.In the all too possible future, Earth has been fouled by its human parasites, and the wealthy have gone in search of an appropriate planet to terra form, change to Earth standards, as a new home.  Despite the existence of a colony already there, bombs were set off.  The humans who survived mutated into the indigenes who are one of the most fascinating people of a scifi work that I have read.This book explores what it means to be human.  The indigenes are "other", but they are the superior other.  They may be an answer to mortality.  As a possible future of our race, they provide fascinating commentary on our weaknesses and strengths.  The main characters are caught in the interplay of Exilon a a new Earth and Exilon as a home to the indigenes.  The writing engages the reader from start to finish.  The world building on Exilon is intriguing.  The characters are well developed and multi faceted.  Newbies will be immersed in this enterprise, and readers of the first two books will be gratified.  I was given a copy the author who had noticed my enthusiasm for her prior work in exchange for an honest review.  I thank her for the wonderful book.

"I am no longer fearless."  She is a new mother who finds that the most perilous thing we may do is to bear children.  No longer an entity contained within her skin, she sets off to determine the real risks inherent in inoculations, among other interventions in the modern world.  she notes in a lucid voice, that to act is to start the future in motion, and to do nothing still sets that future in its course.I found this to be an amazing voice who has placed the fears and and anxieties of our modern medicine in the context of our existence as true beings in the whole of our world.  Her various observations of the philosophy of immunizations are truly startling and clear in her well researched discussions of the role of science in our world.She makes a cogent  argument for out inability to rationally assess true risk in the face of fear. In another instance,  her discussion of "herd immunity" point to the obligation that those who have access to care have to those who do not.  The risk of contagion is much higher for one person who is inoculated among many who are not than for a person not inoculated  in a crowd of those who are.  The more people who are protected, the more protection for those who are not protected.  She also explores the continuum of our bodies with the world around us, and notes that toxicity to a scientist is one of degree of exposure.  While she does not address the evils of high fructose syrup, plastics bleeding toxins or other villains in definitive terms; she does point out that each threat must be taken in context.This is a book that challenges the mind without torturing the reader with obscure or overly technical writing.  The education on risk, immunity, ad the role of medicine in our world is succinct and at times lyrical.  I cannot recommend  this book too highly.

The premise of this book is unusual and interesting.  It starts with our narrator who has been sent to a special school for fragile teens after she has lost her boyfriend of 41 days.  The loss has been so traumatic that she has withdrawn from the world only to re-engage with a gifted teacher.  She and four other hand picked students enter the Special Topics English class.This is one YA book which I believe is really much better suited to the target audience than to the adult reader.  The sentiments are the mundane fare of adolescent life, with which I have no quarrel.  But even with the magical realism, it felt like a story told a mile too far away for me.  The main characters are too formulaic to escape to exceptional literature, and the teen boarding school has been thick on the ground as a setting in recent years.  It is a pleasant book with an interesting twist, and there is nothing wrong with that.

In this masterpiece, Amis makes a fresh assault on the ability of a people to launch such concentrated hatred toward the annihilation of the Jews.  My title is taken from the report of an American reporter in Berlin in 1918.  From that point, "hallucinatory anti-Semitism and world historical flair for hatred" is sparked to culminate in the Final Solution.  The world was saying "alas to less and less" (Auden) One of the characters wonders aloud about the conference where the idea was unveiled.  Eight doctorates, and not a flinch or a protest emerged.The "Zone of Interest" unveils the story of "Who somebody really is."  The narrators are a foppish consultant, Thompson; a Jewish worker or Sunder, and the Commandant, Doll,  himself.  The world is the fictionalized Auschwitz where the air has grown foul with the stench of the dead and the staff lives in pleasant surroundings.  We are lulled at the outset by the story of Thompson falling in love with Doll's wife.  The language is prosaic until shortly his best friend has to depart to partake in selection at the railroad siding as a punishment for his lack of discipline.What follows is the forced look each person must endure of their true selves in the mirror of the KZ.  This is a story told many times with numerous views and commentary, yet this book is a fresh and deeply tortured visit to the world of the dark side of the soul.  His prose is darkly, spry and sometimes disturbingly humorous.  As the limits of what is forbidden are pushed further and further, the enterprise has moved in horrifying fashion from the taking of the "Jews off their high horse."  Most poignant to me is Szmul, the Jewish man whose forced slavery work has rendered him vital to the working of the camp.  He argues endlessly with himself over the issue of his own survival and his role as a witness.  To Doll, this renders him  a primary target for the gas chambers.Doll being the sole main character who believes his brief, has descended into madness.  The others teeter perilously on their views of themselves searching for ways to escape the depth of their own involvement.  This brings the current question, is anything less than full rebellion to the Reich a total damnation of the soul?  Many a vignette involves the small resistances that ensue in the camp.  Where does the reader stand in the mirror of the soul?  I am deeply impressed with the scope and depth of this novel within the frame of a novel assessable to the reader and engaging to the mind.

Each of these stories combines Mantel's trademark elegant turns of phrasing and her sly, bleak humor.  Narrators regard the world with a jaundiced eye.  Young or old, they have been jaded by the adults in their world whose incontinent views of right and wrong have skewed their perceptions.Readers of "Wolf Hall" may be startled by the wry wit on display, but Mantel has written in this vein before: notably "Beyond Black".My perverse favorite is "Comma" in which two marginally accepted children on the fringes of society watch a wealthy home for glimpses of a child with severe birth defects who appears to be a "comma".  The physical metaphor is taken in a arc of brilliant writing until one of the girls come "full stop."  All of these stories bear these twists, subtle and otherwise, of the observed judging those at the same margins as themselves.  I would recommend this book not only to lovers of the short story, but any person fond of fine writing.

This is an older basket, and it has a very handy form.  My grandsons love to use it to collect toys to put away.  It actually has a very utilitarian purpose and is handy for a variety of uses as an actual basket.  Also lovely in design.  Really love this one.

My grandson is not exactly clear on the Ninja Turtles.  He isn't allowed to watch much tv and some of the story line is meant for an older child.  doesn't keep him from loving them  By extension, he loves the pajamas and enjoys getting his fantasy kick on two different ways.  Did I mention he is a comfort freak.  Like many little boys, he only want to wear what is comfortable. These are soft and fit ugly without binding.  He is very happy.

this must be one of the most visceral accounts of the meaning of being a soldier of war that I ever read.  It is not long on bloody detail or of gore.  Without hyperbole, this account renders the story of how a human being is turned into a soldier.  While Ash is in fact a woman, the story is not really a story of feminism.  Ash had gone to war instead of her husband because she was strong while he was not.  One of them had to serve the Union, so she dressed as a man and left.  But long before Ash wandered far from Ohio, she had left herself.  In training and drilling for her new role, by the time she said good bye, her husband no longer saw her for herself.Ash remembers the first man she killed in combat.  Then little by little she only remembers a litany of orders, followed by her, and blurred to an inhuman machinery.  The story of any soldier is whether home can exist again after the world has changed to a universe of killing.  The lyrical prose and beautiful writing flows without a touch of flowery hyping.  Each minute that she describes can be felt viscerally, and this makes this novel essential in the understanding of the way people come to declare a war and go off to kill.

Aristotle gave much of his life to biology.  He has broken with Plato to declare that there is value in the understanding of all living things.  He leaves the study of ideal forms in philosophy to explore the reality of nature, "where there is nothing accidental."  Leroi searches for his works in texts extant, in commentary of the age, and in exploration of the locations where certainly Aristotle searched for "truth".Many of the books of Aristotle have been destroyed or are missing, but Leroi has based his work on an extant encyclopedia among Aristotle's work.  While he celebrates all that Aristotle had found, he doesn't veer from discussing those areas in which Aristotle misses the mark.  The prose is is entrancing in its obvious love of the topic at hand.  Leroi has made this search a labor of love.  The "known" animals of this world, reported back from travelers in the field, can be bizarre, but are illuminating nonetheless.  The vignettes that set the scene of his study assure us that much is still the same from antiquity.  The author assists us in our interpretation with his retrieval of modern understanding of the animal in question.I find it exciting and humbling to view the research of a man so long before our time.  He had excited the interest in the natural world simply by his insistence in its value and his courage to deviate from the norms of his age.  This book has much to offer to those of us who find the learning of new things of highest order.

This is a lovely piece of prose.  The premise is a lyrical story of souls that have come to inhabit the place of their deaths  in replacement for a body.  The newly bereaved family of the last owner of the house have come to assess the property, handle the estate and bury him.  They are his divorced ex-wife, her two children, and her daughter's daughter.  Each of them are fragile in their own way.  It seems the younger the living person, the more attuned they are to the whispers of the dead, but each person has some perception of the living house.I think that the reader's reaction to this work will depend highly on personal preference.  Of course that is always the case, but particularly for me in this novel.  The stories of the two reigning ghosts are confusing despite the clearly labeled chapters.  The intertwining of the living and the dead becomes knotted through the story.  One of the main plot devices is fairly artificial.  All in all, the plot is not particularly well articulated.  Yet I enjoyed the book for its prose and its evocative sense of the world of memory and time.  Several passages are startling in their clarity of expressed longing  that survives time and circumstance.  The memories of the living and the dead are told in lovely terms, and this made the book one I really enjoyed reading.  So being a fan of atmosphere and prose, I liked this book a lot.  Those pursuing a strong plot line will probably be disappointed.I think anyone who picks this book to consider already has some predilection to consider the fate of the person after death, and from this point of view, I recommend this book.
This mini version of the toy story dog is a wonderful idea.  Unfortunately it is shoddy and fragile.  They all broke almost immediately.  The spring didn't expand at all.  Very disappointing.

My little two year old has entered construction obsession.  He is enamored of these little machines.  They are tough and really the perfect size for his little hands.  He is able to dig in the sandbox and set races in the living room.  They have stood up to  flying, crushing, and incredible burdens.  Great toy.

This is a huge hit with the toddler fraternity.  Four grandsons get endless amusement with the snare claw that catches the car that loses the race.  Of course, as toddlers, they use it to catch simply everything in sight.  The snare has been up to the task.  The little ones are too young to set up a race, but are expert at having a parent dance attendance on each match.  Its a a good simple toy.  No batteries, no screen, no sound effects: exactly as I like it.

This is a very nice mask fin and snorkel set.  It contains a pair of snorkeling fins, a mask and a dry snorkel with a mesh drawstring bag.Fins:These fins are short-bladed fins meant for more precise control when snorkeling; scuba fins have longer blades while free diving fins have very long flexible blades.  The fins have an open heel meant to be worn with a neoprene bootie/sock (not included) and can be easily adjusted from men's foot size 9-13.  While all straps are standardized, it is not clear whether there are replacement buckles for this brand.  If your feet are inbetween sizes, order down as things tend to loosen up in the water.Mask:This is a scuba-quality medium volume mask, featuring an excellent horizontal view with tempered glass.  It is single-skirted black silicone that help reduces glare and is preferred by photographers.  To fit the mask properly, put the snorkel in your mouth, and place the mask on your face without the strap on while holding your breath. Make sure there are no stray hairs and such under the skirt of the mask. with your hands, attempt to pull the mask away from your face gently while holding your breath.  It should form a good seal. If it does not stick to your face without the strap, then this mask does not fit your face and this is not the set for you.  The reason the snorkel has to be in your mouth during this process is that the shape of your face changes slightly when something is in your mouth and sometimes that is enough to change the fit, and seal, of the mask.Snorkel:This is a dry snorkel.  It has a vertical drain on the bottom of the silicone mouth-piece and a wave protector on the top.  I prefer the vertical design of the drain because the water runs directly down and none of it collects anywhere.  Some other dry snorkels have a U-bend and then a drain, but those tend to collect a bit of water.  Always buy a dry snorkel instead of one without.  It makes snorkeling so much easier in the open water regardless of swimming ability.Mesh Bag:This is just a simple polyester-mesh drawstring bag.  It is unfortunate that there are no handles or straps. However these can be easily sewn on.  Just make sure to sew a backing/re-enforcement piece on both sides of the mesh for longevity.  The size of the bag fits this set and not much more.Conclusion:The fit of the mask is the most important. If it does not fit this is not the set for you.  The sizing of the set is for the fins and not the mask. So ordering a smaller listed size will only get fins for smaller feet and not a smaller mask.

Smith's is known for their knife sharpeners and subsequently a small selection of accompanying blades for their extended consumer kitchen line.  It makes sense that they've introduced a survival tool following the popularity of Survivorman and survivor type TV shows.While most all-in-on survival tools are gimmicky and fail to offer any real use to the outdoorsman during a hobby walk much less during an actual survival situation, this 10-in-one tool does offer a few exceptions:1) Knife bladePocket-knife sized blade comes with a decent edge.  Due to the fact the other components of this system are stored in the handle cavity like a Swiss army knife, the knife blade is not full tang.2) Saw bladeAgain as expected with Smith's, this holds a decent edge.  However the handle cavity is almond shaped and there are no finger guards in this design. Fingers can slip on to the blade and accidentally be cut.  Shaping the handle to have fingerguards on both ends would not decrease its looks and honestly is baffling as to why its not there.3) SharpenerThis is Smith's specialty.  The carbide sharpener gives blades a sharp edge.  These sharpening blades can also be replaced and interchanged easily.  It stores inside the handle cavity.  It is part of the whistle and the firestarter.4) WhistlePealess, but sadly tiny. It is built into the sharpener part with the fire starter. It's also not very loud.5) Fire starter pulls out of the sharpener piece that can be stored in the handle cavity.  It is a simple ferro rod that one strikes the spine of the blade against to create sparks on to flammable materials.  This does produce a respectable amount of sparks although it is much slimmer than the ferro rod by Light My Fire.6) TweezersTiny with ungrounded edge.  Larger fingers or gloved hands, might drop this. Still if you have steady hands this is better than nothing.7) Removable LED light with clip.  It is bright enough and again better than nothing. It removes from the handle easily.8) CompassA very small water-filled compass similar to the type found on zipper pullers.  It's better than nothing but it better suited for figuring out which direction to turn out of a subway exit rather than navigating a densly wooded canyon9) ParacordIt's only 2 feet so it depends on what your situation is.10) Signal mirrorVery small but it should work.Overall this is very cleverly designed to be lightweight and fit into a small space.  All the items are nice to have and better than nothing if there is a situation.  However just like other multi-tools, no piece (with possible exception of the sharpener and the fire starter) can truly stand on its own the way a fully functioning independent piece of kit would.  For a true BOB bag, I would recommend buying each component separately. For EveryDay Carry, this would be ideal as it is lightweight and compact.

I love this small 6" lightning to USB cable. It is the perfect length for laptop and desk use.  It performs just as well as the stock cable my phone came with but is more attractive in the metallic silver colour that matches my phone.If you don't need the length, why carry the weight?  It charges and syncs with no issues.

I have very sensitive combination skin.  Frequent travel for my job often irritates and stresses my skin and I often break out in my T-zone and sometimes oddly in the middle of my check, chest or at a certain spot on my neck or chin.  When this happens, it's usually an angry, ugly zit that is too deep to be drained and requires a visit to a dermatologist to decrease the potential damage.  Without treatment, it often leaves a red angry spot that takes months to calm down and another few months to fade after that.  I found that using ProActive masks help prolong periods between these nasty angry blemishes.This mask is your basic Kaolin mask infused with peeling acids and disinfecting botanticals, texturizing agents and unfortunately fragrance.  It absorbs extra oil, plus works to shed the outer layers of dead cells to prevent and clear clogged pores.  I like to use this as a spot treatment since I mainly get random angry spots, but sometimes I use this as an area mask for my entire T-zone from my chin, nose and forehead to prevent a  breakout just after a very long trans-Pacific/Atlantic flight.It does work to absorb the oil and to decrease pore size.  I use it as needed when traveling which is twice a week (outbound and inbound).  The recommended dosage is not more than three times a week as the face can be overly irritated by over drying and over peeling.  For travel, I put a bit in an contact lens case and keep it in my 3-1-1 baggie.If you haven't tried this, and there is a mall with a ProActive kiosk near you, I would recommend asking for a sample to try out first.  It is a bit stronger than your drugstore/supermarket peel and mask and would be an expensive mistake if it doesn't work out.  If it does work, then it would be worth the splurge.When the package was delivered I was a bit worried as it was packed in a simple padded envelope.  Upon opening the mailing envelope the product box was crushed and I was afraid that the product would have spilled and leaked.  Luckily, ProActive shrink-wraps their products before putting them into the retail box as a tamper-resistant measure that also prevents product spillage during shipment.This is a a sulfur-based acne treatment that luckily does not smell like sulphur (rotten eggs).

This inflatable hot tub was surprisingly nice considering the number of unfavourable reviews on Lay-Z-Spas.  However, this is the newest model that seems to be manufactured of a heavier duty thicker vinyl and a different single piece baffled construction.  I have listed the Pros and Cons of this model (Palm Springs 4-6 person) as well as Logistics and maintenance on what you need and what is nice to have for a better experience.  As a side note, we used to have the co-branded Coleman Lay-z-spa which is equivalent to the Miami 2-4 person spa.  We sold/left it at our old house at the request of our former landlord.Pros:+ This inflatable hot tub is non-permanent and much easier to get it placed and moved where you would like it.+ Low entry price makes it more affordable to have a hot tub.+ 120 air jets help create a soothing massage.  Air jets are not as drying to the skin as water jets.+ Inflatable vinyl-leather cover has easy to use clip-on straps, and is supposed to help prevent heat loss.+ The inflatable hot tub comes with a cushioned floor mat (giant vinyl bubble-wrap) which is supposed to help with protecting the hot tub and also help with insulation. It is also more comfortable when in the hot tub.+ This is a good sized hot tub that can fit 4-6.  The interior diameter is approximately 57" The walls are approximately 9" thick.  Lesser quality inflatable hot tubs have walls 7-8" thick.+ Lay-z-spa also makes a co-branded unit with Coleman based off their Miami (2-4 person) model.  This Palm Springs model is an improvement in both sturdiness and design for the inflatable part.  The motor unit and all accessories are otherwise identical.+ This unit can be directly plugged into an 110v outlet.  There is no need for hardwiring.  There are 220v versions but I think that they are  primarily marketed in Europe.Cons:- The hot tub is inflatable and getting in and out could be tricky for the infirm.- Hot tubs and jacuzzis are noisy.  This one is no exception.- This style of hot tub is more of a sit upright type of hot tub instead of a lounging type of hot tub.  Adding ($) an inflatable pillow for neck support does make it better.- The nature of inflatable hot tubs is that they are not very good insulators so expect the water to loose heat much more quickly than a regular hot tub.- Inflatable hot tubs also generally don't heat the water as warm as traditional hot tubs. The Lay-z-spa is no exception and only heats to 104F (40c)- Inflatables do leak air slowly, so expect to detach the hose and top-off the air every 7-14 days.  This is normal.- The inflatable cover also leaks air and needs to be topped-off. Again, this is normal but nonetheless annoying.- Maintenance cost and effort is similar to that of a traditional tub.- Chlorine tablets are needed for the floating chemical puck are available online but not easy to find in brick and mortar shops.  These tables are also more expensive than regular chlorine.- Emptying the water from the hot tub (to change water) via the garden hose drain attachment is just as slow if not slower than filling it up.  To speed up this process, additional submersible pump is needed.- As the material is vinyl, there is a certain amount of off-gassing.  The scent will be more noticeable when the hot tub is heated.- The safety and auto-shut of thermostat is set for the lowest external operating temperature of 40F (lower than 40F water starts to freeze).  So this Lay-z-spa is not meant for winter time use.  However the season can be extended by warming up the air around the pump with a heater to encourage it to work.  Once the water is heated, the surrounding temperature will rise slightly and help keep the pump going.- It seems that the pump unit can be used for bubbles or for heat but not both at the same time.  The solution is to alternate heating and using the bubbles.Logistics:* The product box is 90-lbs so be prepared to have a hand truck or help moving it to where you would like to open it.* The box includes: an instructional DVD, emergency patch kit, floating chemical puck, monometer, Filter (size IV).* Spa chemicals are not included.* Things that are nice to have on hand to start are Bestway's Chemical Starter Kit, a study step tool to help get in and out of the hot tub, a folding tray table for outside the hot tub or a floating tray for inside the hot tub for beverages and snacks and an inflatable hot tub pillow for neck support.* Some sort of sturdy platform to put the Lay-z-spa on: floating deck, wood patio tiles from Ik*a, foam tiles, kitchen gel mats to help distribute the weight a little more evenly and to provide a little bit more cushion and insulation.* Maintenance requires Bestway Lay-z-spa filters (size IV) that roughly need to be cleaned or replaced every 2 weeks, chemicals (bromine or chlorine), hot tub/pool scent crystals/salts to decrease the chlorine smell if it bothers you.* Round patio table covers also fit the hot tub as temporary covers.* Weber Smoker cover and standard chimnea covers fit the pump unit.* All hot tubs take a while to heat up the water.  The Lay-z-spa takes the same amount of time to heat up the water (overnight) as a traditional spa.  Filling with warm/hot tap water will decrease the time it takes to heat the water.Conclusion:This is a very good inflatable hot tub.  It is built of heavier duty materials than its predecessors and competitors.  It is attractively priced and convenient to set up, take down and move.  However it does require almost as much time, effort and money for its maintenance as a regular hot tub.  There are other additional hidden costs for accessories to personalize your hot tub.  However, I would still recommend this Lay-z-spa for those that need something non-permanent.

I bought a few of these knives for ourselves and as gifts.  These are perfect for what they are: a sharp knife that keeps its edge paired with an effective and easy to use ferro rod.  Everything is where it's needed.Pros:+ Knife is sharp and made of a proprietary stainless formula that helps it keep its edge.+ The design of the blade is perfect for precision slicing at the pointy end and more robust slicing on the elongated end.+ Ferro red is securely twist-locked into the handle but can be easily removed and used when needed.+ Ferro rod still sits securely even after extended use because the attachment relies on the shape of the handle and not on the size of the rod.+ Grippy handle helps prevent accidental slips.+ Variety of subtle and bright colours of the sheath and ferro rod holder to suit almost everyone.+ Gap between knife and sheath prevents an unclean knife from sticking to sheath+ Knife clicks securely into sheath.+ The ferro rod holder has a matching cord to help prevent loss.Cons:- Knife is not full-tang (More on this later)- Knife is secured in sheath via tension. There is a click when it is securely inserted.- There is a gap between the knife and the sheath. While this enables an unclean knife to not stick to the sheath, it also allows grit and dirt between the sheath and knife to abrade the knife.I personally feel that there is no need for a full-tang in a knife of this size.  There is no way I am going to be sawing or prying something with a 3.75" blade in such a way as to require a full tang.  If this were a much larger knife meant for other purposes then the full tang would be important.  For hammering things such as tent stakes I would use a rock rather than risk messing up my knife or accidentally cutting myself.  There are plenty of 10-in-1 "survival tools" on the market and sadly they all fail to preform well in any one of their ten purported functions.  This Fireknife has 2 functions: basic small scale cutting and firestricker.  It excels in both.For those that really do need a big knife, add a hatchet or a machete to your bag.  Small knives, full-tang or not will not do that job.We have used ours for a few years and love the convenience of having everything right where we need it.  We have also put an extra in our hurricane go-bag.

This is the most versatile car cellphone holder I've had to date.  I usually browse through Asian car accessory shops looking for newer and better things to hold my cellphone but this one is still the best.Pros:+ It fits all the rental car vents.  My husband travels weekly for work so this is important.+ It can hold a phone in its case even if it's a thick silicone Hello Kitty or your Mophie Juice pack.+ Fits Iphone 6, Iphone 6 plus, Samsung Galaxy S5 and S6 and LG G4, plus our TomTom+ No fiddly bits to require tools to set up, no sticky pads and no hooks that break off when moved.+ Portable and reusable.  Can be secured to use yet easily removed without marking the car and re-used repeatedly with the same performance.+ Can be easily adjusted safely even whilst driving+ The rubber prong in the back have a wider side and a thinner side so that it fits most car vents+ The entire back prong can be turned so that the phone position can be adjusted.Cons:- Only available in black or white.  So it can be easily missed/forgotten in rental cars. I had to tip the phone grips in neon nail polish so my husband can see it easily. - Sometimes the mount loosens on the vent when pushing the corners of the phone too much (for example when "liking" a song on Pandora) but can easily be pushed back in securely.

Of the many brands of tea I stock my cupboards with, Taylor's of Harrogate Teas are one of my favourites.  Their Yorkshire Tea is a must have staple when friends and family visit over the holidays.  While tea is light and easy to carry as well as tax free to bring into the country, just being able to order it and have it ready here for my guests makes me feel like a much better host.  We drinks lots of tea and this large size is perfect for us.Taste and flavour preferences are very subjective and tend to skew towards what you are brought up with and what you are used to.  Yorkshire tea brings back childhood memories (along with Lipton and PC Tips) and are considered tea blends in the English Breakfast style.  If you like Lipton, you might like Yorkshire Tea as it is a touch stronger and takes milk a little better even when not over brewed.

This is a seamless one-piece tummy and thigh shaper.  It has a 360-stretch that fits most body types.  I'm petite and the waistline hits just a little above my belly button.  However as this entire shaper is like a firm fitting pair of semi-opaque control-top hose, I can adjust it so that there is minimal roll-over at the waist.  The thigh does not have a silicone-latex strip but does not roll up.  The edges are smooth and woven over into itself seamlessly so there are no obvious bumps and lines.  What little roll over there is at the waist (for me) does not encourage the entire shaper to roll all the way down or create weird bumps and lumps like my mother and grandmother's old fashioned shapers.Despite being like thick control-top hose, this feel much more breathable than it looks.  The shaper has a special ribbed weave in the tummy area for extra control.  This ribbed area is also seamless and does not show.  This shaper is matte but smooth.  As it is not shiny it should not show too much through the clothes in photographs the way satiny shapers do.Note that the crotch does not have an added cotton layer nor it is a split crotch for easy "bathrooming".Overall I really do like this shaper even though I hated my mom's.  It does add a lit of confidence when wearing a tighter dress and smooths everything down.Maidenform rates this as 2 out of 3 on their scale of amount of control.

I have been a big fan of Miele vacuums for their performance and reliability.  However this little Shark Hand vac's performance is on par with Miele and Dyson handvacs for a fraction of the price.What I like:+ This is extremely lightweight. I have tendonitis and carpal tunnel in my right arm and hand and find carrying things for a period of time results in numbness and pain for the next few days.  This vacuum is lightweight enough to not aggravate my old injuries.+ The hose itself is flexible and the attachments are perfect for small tasks such as vacuuming stairs, sofas, chairs, headboards and in the car.+ The cord is 15-ft long is is long enough for most tasks in my house.  I have an extension cord if I need to do something such as vacuuming the top of kitchen cabinets or the ceiling fan blades.+ Because this vacuum is corded, there is no heavy battery to carry around or to charge.+ The corded unit provides maximum power and suction for the entire time you need to vacuum. There is no battery/power running low problems.+ The TruePet brush attachment is motorized. Motorized brushes for handheld small units are usually a feature of machines retailing at higher prices.+ Washable cups, bags and filters.+ All this performance is available for a fraction of what Miele and Dyson's cost.What I don't like- This is a bagless vacuum which is both a pro and a con. For allergy sufferers this is bad because emptying the vacuum using means exposing oneself to lots of dust in the process.  There is also the vacuumed-up critter carcases that are icky.- Bagless means that there are no additional costs for bags.Performance:We volunteer at several dog rescues and foster a number of dogs throughout the year.  There are approximately 3 dogs in addition to our own dog at any given time.  This equates to a once a day minimum schedule of vacuuming everything from floor to sofa to drapes.  This little vacuum effectively removes pet hair from our upholstered velour sofa, the fuzzy faux fur papasan, silk drapes and of course all the dog beds.  We also vacuum our car as it is used to transport a number of pets to and from vets, the rescue and other foster events.Recommended for anyone who needs to vacuum small spaces such as cars, sofas, stairs and drapes.

Fantastic phone case that does not obscure the camera at the back.  The clear back panel is also very nice for those that like to wrap their phone or just want a simple clean look without too much bulk.The sides offer decent grip and adequate protection for regular daily use.Recommended for those that like the see-thru look.

OtterBox cases are usually the bulkiest of the all the phone cases so when I received this I was pleasantly surprised.  This case from their "symmetry" collection is about the size of other hard cases on the market and much much slimmer than the traditional OtterBox phone case.I love how this case is smooth and does not catch on the edges of pockets in my bag where the bumps on the traditional OtterBox cases did.  I also love how while being much thinner it does not sacrifice protection.  While it will obviously not be as protective as their traditional clunky case, it seems more than enough for everyday active use.Note the edges at the front of the case wrap in more than your usual case so if you have a screen protector it needs to be of the case-friendly variety.

This is a very nice case that protects your Iphone from bumps, scratches and splashes while being active.It fits my Iphone 6 well, however I had to remove my current screen protector so that the built-in screen protector would make full contact with the screen.  Apple Touch ID works and the screen itself does not seem to have lost any sensitivity being in the case.  Sound from the speakers and the ear-piece are slightly muffled as expected.  Use of the speaker is also slightly muffled when I attempted to make a call on speakerphone.The case is waterproof as claimed.  I tested this with some rolled up tissues in the case and dropped it into the pool and left it there for 15-20mins.  When the case was retrieved and opened, the interior was dry.I am looking forward to be using this case throughout the summer and will report back if my opinion changes.

The smallest and most concise offering by Lonely Planet!This is a new way of organizing travel by Lonely Planet.  The guide is presented in a spiral-bound semi-hard cover with Moleskinesque elastic to keep the book shut.  There is a slip pocket inside the back cover next to a fold-out removable map of Tokyo.  The guide is organized by dividing the day (page) into thirds, morning (orange), afternoon (red) and evening activities (blue) that one can mix and match by flipping through each section and customizing your day.  Once your choices are made there is an attached ribbon to bookmark your choices.In addition to the pull-out map at the back of the guide, which can be used either attached or removed, there is smaller fold-out map in the front that shows one where all the colour-coded attractions are around the city.  This is very convenient for planning your day so as to not ping pong all over the city with a poorly constructed schedule.The LP bits we love such as "3 perfect days in {name your city}", and the logistics section are still there but adapted to the new presentation format.This small guide is perfect for shorter trips and for those that are comfortable with not over planning their days.I just used the Paris version of this guide a few weeks back and love the new format. As a former expatriate resident of Tokyo, this guide seems perfect for a return visit and for newer tourists to the city as well.Note: this guide includes access to online content on the LP app via a smartphone (Iphone or Android)

This is the perfect ice cream chiller and cooler for a pint of ice cream whether it be bought from a store (a Ben & Jerry's pint, in its own container, fits in perfectly) or homemade.  I have a few of these in different colours for homemade ice cream from my Cuisinart ice cream.Notes and tips:+ The ice cream tub is designed to be pre-frozen and kept in the freezer.  It can then be filled with ice cream.+ An entire store bought pint fits in.+ The standardized pint size is convenient for recipes.+ Chilled tub helps ice cream set evenly for a smoother texture with fewer ice crystals+ The matching scoop curls the ice cream into perfect balls.+ Matching tub is perfect for holding and rinsing the scoop between scoops.+ The lid should only be closed finger-tight and the seams wiped clean of any residue otherwise the lid can be difficult to get off once frozen.This is the perfect set for someone who has their own ice cream maker or who enjoys eating ice cream pints directly out of the package on a hot summer day.
