Baby Alive dolls are dolls that come with internal plumbing where it can be "fed" and the liquid trickles down and comes out of its crotch area into its diaper which can then be changed.How it works:The liquid is just water.  There are little packets of  "tea" mix which is just simply a colouring agent you add to the water to make your "food". This then goes into the teapot or directly into the tea cup which as a nipple that you put in the doll's mouth.  after "feeding" the doll the liquid makes its way down and dribbles out the crotch area of the doll into its diaper.  The diaper itself is just a doll panty with what seems to be tissues as an absorbent liner.What I like about this series of dolls:+ It features feeding and diaper changing for kids that want to have a more realistic experience whether you want them to or not.+ It enables safe play.+ There are a variety of accessory "foods" from milk, to tea to juice.+ The dolls are available in both blonde and brunette.+ Mix refills, diapers and diaper liners are easily available.Cons:- The diaper liner is the equivalent of 1 - 2 squares of toilet tissue folded up.  A child that "overfeeds" their doll would cause it to overflow its diaper very easily.  A simple solution is to use actual newborn baby diapers or even cut up pantiliners or pads.- The mix contains colouring that may stain some materials although it is mostly washable.Overall this is a very realistic doll that my nieces love to play with.  She's excited that there is one at my place for her own doll to play with when they visit on weekends.

This is a very lightweight and delicate necklace.Pros:+ Looks classy+ Fashionable "invisible chain" look.+ Inexpensive enough to use as "vacation jewelry" yet classy enough for "first job" jewelryCons:- Very fine chain in the invisible style.- The chain is so fine that it is prone to snagging. If you feel any resistance when pulling a scarf or brushing your hair. You might just accidentally break the chain.- The spring-clasp is very small. you might need help and definitely patience (and fingernails) to put this on.- The ball is hollow as expected but it seems to weigh almost nothing.- The chain-end is large enough to prevent the ball from slipping out so the chain cannot be used with another pendant

Bird feeders fall into 2 categories: 1) practical no nonsense (and often more economical) feeders and 2) Fancy decorative feedersThis bird feeder definitely belongs in the first group.  I filled this up with seed bought at my local Audubon Society store and placed it across the yard from my other finch feeder.  The golf finches in my yard use this as much as they use my more decorative one.  Multiple perches mean that more than one bird can feed at the same time as long as they are not too territorial.  The off-set spacing of each perch and feeding area help prevent this.  The main compartment is clear plastic so it's easy to see the amount of seed decrease.  The yellow plastic top just slides on.As this entire feeder is plastic, I wold recommend using a twist tie or a bit of string to help secure it to where its hung to prevent squirrels or large birds from swinging it off and breaking it on the the ground.  The long narrow shape of this feeder is a bit more tippy.Overall a very inexpensive and functional feeder.

This is a leave-in hair conditioner so a little goes a very very long way.After shampooing, spread a very tiny pea-sized amount in your hands and apply to damp towel-dried hair focusing on the ends working towards the scalp. Avoid actually putting any on your roots or your scalp to avoid weighing your hair down.  If there is not enough product, repeat again in tiny pea-sized increments.  Style as usual.I love this particular leave-in conditioner not only because it plays well with heat and dryers but also because it is equally effective at smoothing frizz without help.  I have combination Eurasian hair: my mother's Asian dead straight and fine hair plus my dad's curls so I end up with a somewhat frizzy messy-looking crop with its own mind.  My hair's personality varies with humidity and since products meant for curly hair weighs it down due to the straight bits and straight hair products just don;t cut it, I'm always in search of something in between that will work. This product seems to be the perfect solution to my combination hair woes. It leave my hair frizz-free and silky to touch without weighing it down.

This is a heavy duty cable for USB 3.0 (interior has a blue stripe). Despite the wire covering being thicker than your average cable, it is not that much stiffer and can easily be rolled and stowed. The ends where the wire connects to the ends is usually where these things start to fray is also reinforced.  Overall this is a very well thought out cable.  Whether it is worth the surcharge depends on how hard you are on your gear and how much you value reliability.  I would recommend this for road warriors despite the added weight over generic 3.0 USB cables from Amazon Basics or other 3rd party no-name suppliers.

This thing is huge! The delivery box is approximately 5-ft tall and close to 4 ft wide.  It is also very heavy and was delivered by a freight company rather than UPS.  Shipping and receiving logistics aside, once this was moved close to where we wanted to install it, the assembly was quite straight forward and simple.The main reasons why I like this Basketball system:+ The height is adjustable.  The range is from 7ft to just over 10ft so all the kids can play.+ The base is compact and sturdy.  There are 4 containers that can be filled with either water or sand that help anchor the base. Each container can hold 50-lbs so the total weight-anchor is 200lbs in addition the the weight-balance of the unit.+ The base has wheels that help with moving and positioning.+ This system is free-standing and not permanently mounted.Cons:- While this is advertised as "portable" it just means that it is not permanently attached to anything and can be stored inside the garage during the winter months.- If you like to dunk and hang more weight is needed on the base to keep this from tipping over the closer you are to 200lbs or more.So far, the kids and cousins are having fun playing in the back driveway.  The age range is 9 to 33 and their weight range is up to 210-lbs.

Fits my new Samsung Galaxy S6 perfectly.  I usually prefer soft cases rather than hard cases.  I also really like this look for my phone.This case adds enough structure to the phone yet does not add too much bulk to it.

Easy to wash and dry.  Almost no ironing is needed if pulled directly out of the washing machine or dryer and hung neatly on the line.  My one caution is to recommend the use of a table pad if your dining table has a special finish.  The heat and steam from the bottom of a hot dish can cause the table cloth to partially adhere to the table and leave marks.  One of my lunch guests somehow did not use the trivet provided.Overall an affordable and attractive tablecloth that is available in traditional colours and the most common measurements and shapes

This is a very different format and NEW format for LP.  While all the same great content is there in the same LP style, the way this guide book is organized and meant to be used is very different.To start, the guidebook is spiral bound with a semi-hard cover that has a moleskine-esque elastic strap to keep it closed.  The back cover also has a slip pocket.  There are 2 maps.  One pull-out map at the back, cleverly folded, that may also be used while attached and one at the front that is printed on thin cardstock at the front.  The map at the front can be partially pulled-out and shows all the colour-coded and numbered attractions.The guts of the guidebook is printed on thin cardstock and colour-coded by morning (orange), afternoon (red) and evening (blue)  activities and attractions.  Each page is divided into thirds (top, middle and bottom) and each attraction is printed on its 3rd.  Physically it resembles a small and thin version of those message log books used in offices.The concept is that one would use this guidebook as a quick reference tool. each attraction is printed on its own "slip" of card and by flipping through the book, one can assemble their own personalized combination of attractions for a particular day.  There is a ribbon bookmark that helps one bookmark their selectionsFor those that like Moleskine and Levenger Circa organizers, this guidebook is right up your alley. My only complaint about this new format is that the individual cards cannot be ripped out and carried because the photo on one side does not match the information on the reverse.  The guide book is not meant to be ripped up into chunks but is to be used as a whole.Overall I like how organized this guidebook is.In addition to this guidebook, there is an App by the same name that you can download for free with the purchase of this book.  This is the most concise and pared-down of all the LP guidebooks. It contains only 39 attractions (more than enough) and none of the hotel or restaurant information contained in the Discover series nor the Classic Series.  It contains even less information than their Pocket series.  This guide does contain the briefest of information for logistics, and a few itinerary suggestions. There are a few lined pages in the back for notes.Perhaps this is where guidebooks are heading? If you own a smartphone or do the bulk of your research online, then this is all you really need to help finalized your day to day activities.

I just introduced this to grandma and the kids and they love it!  A plus is that today grandma brought cupcakes so there is a theme going on in the kitchen.The kids are 2nd and 3rd grade and are just starting to be able to concentrate on board games.  This cupcake-themed checkers game throws in an element of surprise by adding dice (and chance) to the game.  Of course one can play regular checkers with the cupcake pieces but this adaptation is so much fun! The added chance element also levels the playing field between kids of difference ages and abilities.Recommended.

This pendant was a surprise in quite a few ways.Pros:+ The finish and workmanship is very good for the price.+ The stones are precisely and securely bezel-set+ The setting is not overly large.+ Diamond-cut detailing on the bezel setting make the diamonds look bigger than they are.+ The pendant itself is larger than I expected.+ It has a decent gallery that lifts it away from the skin and allows light underneath the pendant.+ Real diamonds are used.Cons;- For this price I was not expecting much, but the diamonds are cloudy and don't sparkle even for I1 and I2 diamonds.Overall not bad for the price, and is a decent gift for someone not expecting something spectacular.

This is a very useful car charger simply because the USB ports are on the side rather than on the top/front.  Depending on the configuration of your car, traditional car chargers with the USB port on top sometimes just don't fit.So far this car charger has quickly and successfully charged my Iphone 4 and 5 as well as my husband's Samsung Galaxy 6.

This is a surprisingly convenient battery pack and jump starter.  We have so far successfully charged smartphones (Iphone 4, 5 and Samsung Galaxy S5) as well as jump start a Ford F150 that had accidentally been left connected to an RV over the week.  I can see this as indispensable for off-roading and RV dry-camping.This useful gadget features a USB port for charging electronics and a polarity protector for jump starting vehicles.

This "Discover" series by Lonely Planet contains full colour glossy photos yet maintains the information integrity of the LP brand.  While this full coloured series does not contain as much information as the tradition LP guides in bluescale, it more than makes up for it by using this colour to its full advantage both in enticing one to get out there and do things (LP-style) and also to help organize information in a logical and easy-to-access way.  For the average tourist this full-colour version contains more than enough information, and there is no need to additionally buy the bluescale classic version.The information contained is as up-to-date as printed guides can be.  The plus here is that there are no specific numbers nor prices, just price-ranges so this guide will remain relevant for quite some time.Overall I love LP guides and they fit my way of active travel.This guide contains a pull-out map of Paris.

I usually inherit my husband's old phones because I need an unlocked phone for work as I travel a lot internationally.  Often these older phones have mediocre battery life.  This battery-case charger barely increases the size of my phone (it is still comfortable and easy to hold in my small hands) while still providing over 1.5x  a charge to my phone.  It is not quite 2x as advertised on the package since the phone cannot have too low a battery life or there would not be enough "push" to start the charging process.Overall I am very pleased that I can charge my phone twice without having to carry a separate battery.  The texture on the case is pleasing and provides a very good grip.

These are what is commonly described as bandage-masks.  The are patches that are pre-infused with the treatment of choice which you them put on your face.  In this packet there are 4 forehead patches, and 4 frown line patches. One just puts these on the appropriate part of their face and lie back and let the treatment work.  Disposable is very convenient.  I love bandage-style masks for travel as they do not count as a liquid.  Do bring a ziplock for resealing in case a TSA does want one of the packets opened so they can make sure that it is not a liquid.In short:Pros:+ Convenient+ Effective with continuous use (especially on long haul flights)Cons:- Convenience can be more expensive that just a jar of your favourite night cream

While I am not usually a fan of slider bags for 100% keeping liquids separate from dry things, they are very convenient for when you use storage bags for storage of things such as cookies, nuts, nails and other bric-a-brac.  These bags are thicker than your average sandwich bag and so far have survived the ultimate test of being squished, stuffed and rolled upon in the bottom of my teenage brother's school bag and gym bag. Unlike flimsier zip-top storage bags, the zip has stayed on the bag after repeated use.

I usually wrap my vegetables with kitchen paper and use pucks of terracotta in the crisper to help control moisture.  This  filter eliminates much of the fussiness in a sleek and easy to use package.  I like how the filter is adjustable.

Unlike fad diets and crash diets, this book focuses on more permanent lifestyle changes that make a lasting impact on our health.Issues addressed are:- Calorie-laden beverages- Treat awareness: smart snacking and controlled snacking- Eating the right amount of fat- Eating the right amount and type of carbohydrates- Eating fruits and veggies- Eating more whole grains.Despite some similarities, this is not another version of "Eat this not that" books.  This book targets habits that can lead to a healthier and leaner lifestyle rather than just focusing on foods.

Heavyweight cotton twill helps keep the heat away plus the silicone stripes help keep a secure grip on baking pans and cookie sheets.  I love how they have updated colours that co-ordinate with what is current now.

We bought this to try out in our RV.  Basically anything that is multi-functional deserves a try in the limited space in our RV.  This is a very good trivet and is a decent bottle carrier.  At first we were a concerned that it would just pull apart at the stress areas but it seems sturdy enough for basic carrying of a bottle of wine with little swinging motion.  It serves well as a stationary trivet.Overall a good, multi-functional and useful design.

We bought a few of these for our RV.  We often like to take the scenic route through the countryside rather than take the highway and the roads are often very bumpy and things get chipped. crack and even broken in the cupboards.  These O glasses in their travel tube have so far survived where other glasses in regular glass storage containers have not.  To be fair, we have added foam paper to the metal caps and the the sides for added padding.While it's usually a no-no to have real glass or crystal in an RV, these are so very nice when opening a bottle of nice wine from a winery.  We have some fancy acrylic glasses in our RV but so far we have only used our Riedel "O" because they are so much nicer.If you give these away as gifts, make sure the recipient knows that the packaging itself serves a purpose.

I have several sets of similar cutlery made by different brands from high-end (Richartz) to low-end no-name brands.The main difference is how these are finished, how easy they are to open and close and to attach and detach.  If there is a chance that you may hurt yourself, it would be during the opening and closing of the blade.For this particular brand "made by Humans", the utensil set is well -made enough for regular use.  My main complaint is that in 1 or the 2 sets I bought, one knife is particularly hard to close. i.e. hazard. On both sets, the can opener-blade is not sharp.  I have not tried opening a can with either of them yet as they seem as sharp as a butter knife.The fork spears well enough, but if you require a fork that is wider for scooping then the Coleman utensil set is a better purchase.Overall, this is a handy tool for an emergency kit or for a backup in a lunch bag.There are printed diagrams and instructions on the back of the package that who one how to safely and efficiently separate this utensil into fork and knife or into fork and spoon (the knife and the spoon are on the same side).

While the elephant is adorable, and the garnets genuine and well set, I did not particularly like the faux-pave pattern cut on the sterling scrolls on either side of the elephant.  The cuts were too coarsely done and made this sterling bracelet look fake.  Unlike some jewelery sold online, the clasp on this bracelet is secure and well made.  The bracelet measures a touch over 7".
These knit containers are the perfect size for pencils, hairbrushes and small tubes of lip gloss.  I love how they co-ordinate with similar (but larger) containers I have from Ikea.

Honest Kitchen makes 2 main categories of food.  There is Complete Food which is basically what is claims and then there is also Food Supplement/Food Base which just needs a protein source of your choice added.  For each of these categories there are Whole Grain and grain-free versions.  Both versions are wheat and corn free.This is a very highly rated dog food.  It is basically freeze dried real food that is then ground down into a coarse powder.  All that needs to be done is to mix a few scoops of this ground up food with warm water to form a paste.  We use this as a supplement to our dog's kibble although it is a Complete Food.  Our dog is a picky eater and we find that this keeps her healthy.  We also like bringing this as a travel friendly food. Warm water is available almost everywhere and this food is easier and much lighter to carry around than kibble or canned food.  Our dog just loves this food and we love that there are no controversial ingredients in this food.

I'm a longtime fan of Tom's of Maine products.  This deodorant performs quite well under gentle conditions but does not really prevent smelly armpits as well as drugstore brands if it is a hot and humid day or if you're exercising. However, for daily use when working in an air conditioned office I prefer Tom's deodorants because they do not contain as much perfume as the regular drugstore brands.  A plus is that it also does not contain aluminum  The texture is smooth and does not stain most clothing.  It does however sometimes leaves marks on dark clothing if not careful.

This is really quite simply plug and play. It connected effortlessly via BT with hoth our phones (Iphone and Samsung Galaxy s5) and our laptops.  The sound quality is good but obviously not as good as a permanently installed professional sound system.  It sounds better on a solid surface than it does partially submerge (for obvious reason per laws of physics).What we love about this is that it is actually water proof and is designed to float in a pool or hot tub and is rated to be submergeable for 3ft .  It is not not merely splashproof so we don't worry that it can be accidentally knocked into the hottub or pool by the dog or the kids.  We tested this in our neighbour's hot tub, our kitchen sink and also in the tub for the kids' bathtime.The BT range is the usual 25-30ft limit so your phone or laptop can be placed safely away from the edge of the water.  The box includes charging cables.

This is the same moisturizing Dove body wash that we all know and love.  The scent is a bit strong, as it usually is, for Dove body products but I love the texture and the way it produces a consistent foam that does not dry the skin.It's so convenient to be able to order it online and have it delivered instead of carrying heavy bottles of body wash from the drugstore or the supermarket.

Although the snow hasn't quite melted here, the kids are already excited about this feeder.  I've taken the opportunity to teach them about the different birds that usually visit our garden feeders and their different diets.  This feeder is just for the kids so they can learn to watch the birds from their window and learn about regular feeding.Overall it seems to hold peanuts and black sunflower seeds quite well. Smaller seed such as nyjer, might fall out.  Currently we have some homemade suet that we have put in and the kids are excited about the birds.

This is a kid's beach towel and is sized like a regular adult bath towel rather than an adult beach towel.  It is also quite thin which I like because the towel can be rolled up compactly, dry quickly when wet and lightweight to carry around.  The smaller size (perfect for a child) and thinness make it easy to wash more towels at a time. This towel is very practical for its intended purpose.However, this towel only contains a few of the Disney Princesses.  I'm assuming that Disney must offer other Princess towels that have the rest of the Princesses on them.  If your child is fixated on a particular princess, I would recommend making sure that whatever princess-themed merchandise you get has that princess on it.

Sterling Silver Swarovski "Peridot" Crystal Pendant and Chain.I was pleasantly surprised at the quality of this sterling silver chain and sterling pendant with crystals.  The size is small: the clover measuring  approximately 1/2"; the stem itself elongates the total height measurement to approximately 3/4". The chain is very fine and thin in the style of the barely-there/"invisible" chains that were popular in the late 90s.Pros:+ This chain and necklace looks very classy+ Swarovski crystals really sparkle and stand out.+ Sterling Silver is clearly marked "925" on both the pendant and the chain.+ Delicate chain included with pendant.Cons- Chain is very delicate- Chain prone to tangling and can break easily.- Lack of information indicating that this pendant contains Swarovski crystals.- "Peridot" is the colour name of this Swarovski crystal as indicated on a Swarovski Crystal Colour Chart. It does not really resemble the colour of an actual peridot (other than being in the green colour family).Overall I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of this sterling silver pendant and chain.  However, the barely-there/invisible-look chain is not for everyone.

This cookbook contains recipes that are authentic yet easy to prepare.  Most of the specialty ingredients can be bought in your local supermarket in the international foods aisle, ordered online and of course in specialty markets if you have one near you.  Overall, there were not that many specialty ingredients other than the usual tamale wraps and chipotle peppers.  The recipes are clear and easy to follow and so far each dish was delicious.  I still have dishes from this cookbook planned out for the next few days and am looking forward to all of them.What really impressed me about this cookbook is that the author tells you how much leftovers you will have when preparing and offers suggestions and alternatives on what to do with some of the leftovers.  It was easy to plan a few meals using the ingredients I bought.If you are looking for chain restaurant-style Mexican food, where burritos are swimming in moats of cheese, this is not the book for you.

This style of corkscrews is one of my favourites. Simply put the corkscrew at the top if the bottle (foil removed) and twist the knob on the top with a slight downward pressure. The worm should go smoothly into the cork and the arms on the side should rise.  Then push downwards in the arms and the cork should pop up.The best versions of this type of corkscrew have pointed worms that penetrate the cork easily and smooth (sometimes non-stick) worms to slide into the cork easily.  This corkscrew is easy and effortless to use.  A big plus is the sturdy hinge that should last many years.A nice addition is the matching bottle stopper.  It is made of the same chromed metal and rubberized accents as the corkscrew and makes a lovely gift set.

I have very sensitive skin and use many products that are originally designed for babies and children.  This particular cream is fragrance free, absorbs easily and does not leave a waxy or oily residue that many baby face creams do.  The tube is also very convenient and stands well on the bathroom counter.Weleda is a well-known and widely available European brand for skin care and bath care products.This face cream does contain coconut oil for those that are allergic to coconut.

If this were twice the price, I'd give it 4 stars. But for the price, it's a great deal.  Yea,the case does have a cheap look and feel - can't really say why, just does. But - the thing looks great, the alarm is loud, and it's very easy to read.I need glasses past two feet - the numbers are so large I can read them from several feet away without glasses. Since I don't wear glasses or contacts to bed, that's a big plus.There's a light sensor, so it automatically dims at night. The clock time, alarm and date are easy to set.  The temp can be displayed in F or C, and time in 12 or 24 hr format. The light sensor can also be turned off. It's powered by three AAA batteries. Wish there was an AC option.A winner all around, perfect for any decor, ideal for kids rooms.  Free sample provided for honest review.

Amazing what $85 gets you. No, it's not the same as a $2000 projector, but for the price it's amazing.  Lightweight, compact and uses very little power. Input from HDMI, VGA or SD card - I supply video to mine via a cheap Android tablet with an HDMI output.  For out Christmas eve family gathering, this will be high up on a cabinet projecting moving snowflakes and so on. The room is always dimly let, so it will look great.In pitch black, this looks darn good.  In a light room - well, unless the projector is three feet from the surface, forget it. Camping, kids sleepovers, tracing images on walls - lots of uses.I actually have mine totally portable, powered by a battery pack.  I use it for light painting patterns (cool in the fog) and projecting on models.  Simple to use and setup. The keystone control is basic, but works (adjusting the distortion caused by the projector pointing in an angle up or down.)  There are even small stereo speakers built in.  Not very powerful, but they'll do in a pinch.Lots of fun, very affordable and great quality. I included some photos. That's projected on the tan vinyl siding on the house, dark out but not pitch black.

Very nice ski/winter pants with a lining that's lightweight yet warm.  They fit small - I wear a men's XL and usually have some room. XL in these is a little tight in the legs - the waist is fine. I'd order one size up, especially if you're borderline M/L, L/XL, or have big legs. If you plan on wearing a base layer under these, go one size up.The pants also have a long zipper in the bottom of each leg, water resistant material, velcro style closures - the usual collection of features for snow boarding pants. There are also flaps over all the pockets and reinforced stitching in stress areas - nice touches.Very comfortable, well designed pants that are suitable for any winter activity, from riding to snow-blowing, hiking to skiing.  Plus they are light weight and can be crushed down pretty small, so they take up about as much room as a pear of sweat pants. Photos showing leg cuff detail and front pocket detail.Free sample provided for honest review.

A lightweight pack with a ton of room, this is ideal for a student carrying books, laptop, water, snacks and more. It's too big for a day pack, unless you carry around a LOT of stuff. You could fit several days of camp clothes in this bag!There are a ton of pockets, including a padded laptop/tablet pocket and  two mesh side pockets (water bottles, etc.). There's actually a couple of places you could stash a laptop or tablet. These mesh pockets have elastic tops - not cinch - and are big. You could stuff a few "grenade" water bottles in each one. The sides and bottom expand to allow you to stuff an unbelievable amount of stuff in here.  You can also use the mesh pockets to hold a small tripod or folding hiking pole - the side adjustment straps can hold these in place.The shoulder straps are padded and adjustable, and typical of a school pack - there's no waist strap.  Quick and easy on and off.  The material beads water and is water resistant, so you're good for a short stint in the rain.

Setup: Easy. Unbox, remove the protective tape, turn on, install the included "initial" cartridge (translation: almost empty, enough for a demo.)  Install via USB or wireless. I used wireless, followed the prompts, used WPS.  From unboxing to up and running - 5 minutes.Now we need to add it to the network. Go to Epson's page and download the driver - I Googled "Epson PictureMate PM-400 and found it in a couple of clicks.  The installer does the rest. From downloading to printing - under three minutes - and that included an automatic firmware update.  You can also set up printing from email and the cloud. I selected both options. One annoyance for me - you can't copy and paste a password.  I prefer to store passwords in a file, this way I can make them as complex as needed. Epson requires an "Epson Connect" account - hence the password.  After creating the account, your printer has it's own email address.  Registration, etc. - another 5 minutes. You'll also receive a verification via email. Actually, I received three emails, one for 10% off on supplies.A verification page is printed. Since I had 4x6 paper in the printer, I have a beautiful 4x6" test page.Everything was 100% painless, no problems at all.  Since the printer is so new (as of 11-5-2015) there were no drivers in Windows or Windows update. But the Google search took care of that.  After the driver is installed you're also prompted if you want the software to automatically check for updates. I always answer "No" to that - I have enough stuff running in the background.Ink, the bane of all printer owners, that can cost more than the printer.  The ink for this printer (Epson calls the ink a "Printpack") comes in two varieties: With 100 sheets of paper 4x6 glossy paper - T320P, or just the ink - T320.  Each cartridge is good for 100 prints.  With the paper the retail is only $6 more.  This is one of those printers you should NEVER use generic ink in.  Most ink cartridges have the print heads built in the cartridge. Not here - the ink is just ink.  I can guarantee that generic ink will cause problems - AKA, clogging your print heads beyond repair.The photo quality is amazing - better than an inkjet printer or laser.  The ink is dye based, so you have very vivid colors on photo paper. Amazingly so. That's also why the resolution is so good - 5760x1440 DPI.Papers supported include glossy, plain, and various photo papers. Also double sided (manual only.)The printer is also a stand-alone print lab, making it ideal for photo booths and on-site photos.  You can print via USB, wireless or SD card.  The printer has some basic editing capabilities built-in: auto photo correction, red-eye removal, crop, rotate and enlarge.  There's a small screen that displays menu choices as well as preview images. Print speed is a snappy 36 seconds on default settings.This is an amazing little printer, very portable and very affordable - prints - at retail supply prices - would be 38 cents each.  No wait, no fuss, no mess.  Perfect for portable studios and events.

Hmmm. No Star Destroyer - that would have really made the set.What you  get (what I received, assuming it's not random):Rebel SnowspeederBoba Fett's Slave 1Millennium FalconX-Wing FighterGhost (from the Rebels cartoons)Tie FighterMisses: Some models are really top heavy and topple over is you stare at them strongly. Especially the Falcon. "Die Cast." Welll, mostly. The Tie Fighter is 90% plastic. Only the body is die cast. Falcon? The top is die-cast, the rest plastic. X-wing? The body is metal. The wings, plastic. The weapons - rubber - and bent at bizarre angles from being packaged poorly.  Slave 1 - 70% plastic, including the wings - and those don't move. Snowspeeder: top half, metal. Bottom - plastic. Weapons - rubber. And again, pointing in strange angles from poor packaging.The gems are the Tie Fighter and the Falcon. Then the X-Wing. The Snowspeeder and Ghost seem like fillers. You get Slave 1 instead of the Star Destroyer. Not a good trade. Slave 1 is a couple of $$ more than the Star Destroyer.The X-Wing and Tie Fighter are the same scale, so you can have mock battles.The "Flight Navigator" is a cute idea, but the opening is sized for kids - hey - adults like these as well. My pinkie finger *just* fits.Overall it's a fun set, with good quality and detail. Calling them "die cast" is a stretch. It's like calling a car "carbon fiber" when only the hood and roof are Carbon Fiber.  The crooked weapons drive me crazy. I attempted to straighten them but only made things worse.

I can't believe this watch is so inexpensive. It has a Japanese movement - not Chinese, is water resistant to 99 feet, and has a sophisticated style that's not *too* dressy.It's also the first watch I have that came with it's own gift bag that's color matched to the watch.It's definitely a man's watch - it's 1.75" inches wide (including the bezel), and only 3/8" thick.  So it's slim enough to slip under a shirt cuff.Unlike many watches, the second hand actually moves in one second ticks - it's not a continuous sweep. This really adds to the classic watch look and feel.  The strap is leather, stamped with an Alligator skin pattern.If you have thick wrists, the band may not size large enough. I have average wrists, 7.5" - there's only two holes remaining on the strap (one if I wear it a little loose) - that's slightly less than 1" remaining.It's also light, like any decent watch. You can wear it and forget it. It is NOT designed to be used in the shower, pool, etc.  That's because the crown does not screw in, meaning it's only a soft seal.It just presses in.  It's fine for the rain, but not prolonged use in the water.For the price you can't go wrong.  Free sample provided for honest review.

My GF told me today that I have something wrong with me - I'm way too into flashlights.  It's a habit I developed in my days as a SCUBA instructor for wreck, cavern and cave diving.  A light was literally a life saver.  This was before LED lights, when a hard tap could kill the light, bulbs burned out, and lights often just failed - bad batteries, flooding - you name it. I developed the practice of carrying several lights.  Even today, if I'm exploring, hiking or out at night, I'll often have several lights.Every company seems to make LED lights today, but there are too few manufacturers that pay attention to quality.  Instead of soldering wires, they're pinched or twisted. Battery connections are flimsy and cases could double as aluminum foil.  When it comes to LED lights, you really do get what you pay for.The R20 is bright. Blindingly so. There's three brightness settings. At the brightest you can actually feel the heat it produces from a foot away.  The max brightness of 900 lumens lasts about three minutes, then drops to 450 lumens - it lasts 2 1/5 hours there.  The light comes with a 2600 mAh (9.6 What hour)  18650 battery. Olight also sells other capacity batteries.  Olight's batteries are top notch and true to their ratings. They even give the Watt hour rating for their batteries.  Their 2600 mAh batteries last longer than many manufacturers "4000" mAh batteries.Other features: There's an internal ring on the lens that's luminescent.  The battery is removable. The lanyard is thick and very comfortable. The lens is glass.  IPX8 rating to two meters.  It's rechargeable and uses a micro-USB cable to charge.The light is durable, reliable and bright.  I've used it working in our pond with the light in and out of the water, Carried it for several days and used it nightly and to inspect in drop ceilings, etc. It's still on the first charge.I've included several photos. One on the deck - you can see it's a wide beam but still has a lot of throw.  It was a foggy night, so there was a lot of backscatter - but the beam looks cool.  I also took it to the park across the street and took a photo on high and low.  Finally, there's a shot of the glowing ring.  This is one fantastic light.Free sample provided for honest review.

I Love this eyelet tool! Very easy to use. We did some wedding cake boxes for a friend - we used this to add eyelets to the boxes for a ribbon to go through.  Anywhere you need an eyelet, this is one handy tool.  There's a setting for the eyelet hole punch position, up to .75" in. Punch the hole, slip in the eyelet, and crimp.A bag of eyelets is included.  One eyelet is used per punch (unlike grommets that need two sections.) The photos I included show both sides of an inserted eyelet and the tool punching it.I've added eyelets to laminated sheets, file folders and more.  Free sample provided for honest review.

Each time I check out an Olight flashlight, I continue to be impressed. Yes, they cost more than the "generic" LED's you see all over Amazon. You know - the same light sold by 20 different places, the only thing that;s different is the name printed on them and the prices. Sure, I've got a few of those - heck, $6 plus batteries/charger? For under $10 you get a decent, bright light. BUT (and that's a big but) there's the question of reliability.  I have a LOT of flashlights.  Some friends joke I have an addiction. I had over 125 at last count. I purchased most, received some as review items.  Many are the cheap $5 and $10 lights.  I do a lot of urban exploring (Urbexing) - delving into long abandoned buildings, usually pitch black, often with basements. Lights are important - and a reliable light is a must.  The problem with those $5 and $10 lights? The reliability sucks.  I have to carry a few of them, and hope I can get 20 or 30 minutes from a light. Drop one? half the time it dies - many don't solder connections - it's just wires pinched between parts.  For example, there's often a lead pinched between the reflector and the housing.  Drop of bang the light, the reflector often pops out and the light dies.  Yea, a quick fix at home, but not in a pitch black warren 10 feet underground.Reliability. *That's* the #1 feature I like about Olight flashlights.  Well, that and you can go blind looking at the LED.  The throw this light has is incredible. It's only 5"x1" and gives of as much light as many headlights. Put the S30R a couple of inches from your hand and turn it on bright - the beam is actually hot. That's one reason it has a glass lens - plastic would eventually melt.Other observations: The reflector is textured - this creates a beautiful, smooth pool of light - no ugly gaps and mottled hot spots.  Every seam is O-ring sealed. The pocket clip is heavy duty and won't scratch the light when you remove or replace it (I usually take mine off.) You need to actually READ the manual, as the soft-touch switch has several functions. The light includes an 18650 2600 mAh / 9.6 Wh battery.  You can use higher capacity batteries as well - but be sure it's a quality battery - Olight sells these as well. There's no lanyard and no place to string one.  No loss there.  The light has a nice feel and weight, with texture and ribbing for heat distribution and grip. The tail is magnetic.I have a lot of 18650 batteries. When a light dies, I swap the battery (I always carry spares), I usually charge them a day before my outings.  This light has an included charging stand and it's really cool.  The magnetic tail clicks onto the base and the light charges via a USB cable attached to the base.  The base is non-slip, but also includes an adhesive pad in case you want to permanently mount it somewhere. With the base glued down, you can drop the lite onto the base and remove it with one hand (the base stays stuck down.)The battery that is included is a 2600 mAh battery (a true 2600 mAh.)  You can use an 18650 up to 3600 mAh and increase the run time by about 30%. Another versatile feature - say you're 18650 battery is dead and you don't have time to charge it. You can just pop in two CR123A batteries!  Most lights would fry if you tried that.The light is waterproof to two meters, so is fine for marine use, in the rain and so on.This is one well thought out and designed light that's also blindingly bright.  From my back porch it lit up my entire deck and a tree 250 feet away!  I've included several photos.  This light is ideal for security, exploring, light painting and more.Free sample provided for honest review.

This is a fun toy for little ones, but personally if they're into the ponies they'll outgrow this fast.  The four year old we babysit already has - seriously - 300 ponies. "Old School". "rainbowified", "glittery", "black", "clear" and more.  At 55, the last thing I thought I'd learn were the cutie marks and names of, er, My Little Ponies.  "Can you bring me Fluttershy?" "Do you know where Applejack is?" "I can't carry the box with the old school ponies..." and so on. OK, yea, it is fun playing with her. My GF jokes that the four year old and I have the same mentality.  Not sure it that's an insult aimed at me, or a compliment for her.Anyway, this is a nice set for toddlers and maybe up to age three. Once they get their hands on "real" ponies, there's no going back.  The ones in this set are simplified - the ponies are colorful single piece of molded plastic. No individual legs, but decent features. You can look at a pony and recognize it - "Yep, that's Pinkie Pie."The structure/toy is well made, has a few parts to assemble (maybe five minutes) and will keep Pony fans engaged for ages.  The recommended age is 18 months and up. I put the upper end at three years, but our little one started playing with "old school" ponies around 2 1/2.

Looking at the reviews, it looks like there's two different products being reviewed - this is for the TinkSky Reflective Cord Nylon Rope, 65 Feet.It's a very handy spool of strong, reflective rope. I included a photo of the spool with a couple of feet hanging off. Night, outside. Man, is it reflective!Lots of uses, from supporting tents and lean-toos,  to securing items to roof racks. Wherever you need a smaller diameter rope (4mm). Tie-outs, tarps, lead ropes, tiedowns, braided bracelets - it's one of the most versatile and handy sizes.  I've used this to secure stuff to my pack and even as an emergency belt.  Great stuff.Free sample provided for honest review.

There's a lot to like about these phones, both in functionality and looks.Looks: Cute, solid pink color with black accent rings. Gray controls on the right earpiece, KidWavz logo on the left. Older kids may not appreciate that.Functionality/comfort: In Bluetooth (not when using the cable) there's a volume limit of 85db (considered safe for 8 continuous hours.) Each earpiece is on a pivot and has a height adjustment for comfort, plus has comfortable padding.  The overall width is sized for kids, not adults, and the top is well padded. In other words, very comfortable.  They *will* fit an adult, but may be a little snug.The Kidwavz headphones are 100% designed with kids in mind, with the volume limiter, smaller size, less bass and clearer vocals (of course any kid can adjust that in the EQ or EQ app), and light weight. Prompts are spoken, not just simple chirps.They also produce great audio and sound very realistic. If you're looking for headphones for a child (these are recommended for ages 3 to 14), this is a great choice.Free sample provided for honest review.

I was not sure what to expect from these knives. I've had ones that cost $200 a piece (or more) and even the old Ginsu cheapo knives. These knives are really amazing. The blades are extremely thin - around 3/32" - yet stiff. The edges are razor sharp, and you can cut amazingly thin slices. Ripe Cherry tomatoes (what I had on hand) - paper thin.I've been using these for a few weeks and have only good things to say about them.  Comfortable grip, sharp carbon steel, great colors. Each knife has a matching sheath to protect the blades.Free sample provided for honest review.

Love the cube, can take or leave the clamp. Details later.I own several laser levels. Single line, multi-line, 360 and cross. Dealt, Bosch and others.  Price ranges from $40 to $450. At $100 this is priced right where it belongs.  The more affordable lasers, like this, use a simple pendulum for the laser - it's a balanced laser head array than hangs from a ring (or similar arrangement.) The expensive ones use electronics to stabilize the laser, the inexpensive ones have no stabilization, and mid priced models often have some type of mechanical stabilization. Why do you want that? If you bump the laser, the whatever it's on, or walk on a floor that's bouncy, the laser swings on the pendulum.  With less the stabilization, the more - and longer - it swings. I've seen cheap lasers take as long as 15 seconds to stop moving. My high-end Bosch is almost instant.  The cube takes about three seconds.In a well lit room measuring 12x12 feet, the laser was clearly visible.Mounting options: The cube base gas a 1/4-20 threaded hole - the same on your camera tripod.  So you can use any camera tripod to mount this. The clamp included is identical to ones sold for holding camera accessories - I have a few of them. It's a decent clamp but has problems - first the rubber on the jaws constantly falls off - I automatically glue them on. Next, the ball head is often mounted incorrectly - mine was. The knob that secures the ball  is over the clamp handle, making it impossible to use the clamp. The ball head has to be removed and re-positioned (with a 3mm Allen key.)  The cube cab also be set on a surface. It has a rubberized base just for that purpose.Other features: The cube warns if it's unable to level with a loud beep (it's at too much of an angle/slope.) The "windows" are glass, not plastic. Uses 3-AAA batteries (generic ones included.) Has a divided padded carry case.Free sample provided for honest review.
I have four of these on our stairs - they work nicely, provide just enough light to walk by, and create an interesting pattern. Easy to install - each light uses two screws (included.)
My favorite coffee for cold brewing! Nice rich flavor.

It's sulfur, it's yellow and it works well for over-wintering our roots, tubers and bulbs. Add some to a lunch bag, drop in the bulb, shake up. Done.  Use it outside if you can - a lot of dust is produced when dusting bulbs and so on.  I wound up getting some powder on my shirt and did not realize it until I rubbed my eyes later on. Ouch.  If you're doing a lot of dusting, I suggest changing when you're done.  My hair still smells like brimstone.

This is an ideal hat for a day in the sun, out on the boat fishing, or any time you need protection from the sun. Add sunglasses and there's nary an exposed inch of shin above your shoulders.  The entire thing is incredibly light weight - maybe two ounces. It's also nylon, with large vents on each side and over the mouth. These provide plenty of ventilation and keep flying bugs away.  Since it is nylon you can dunk it in water for extra cooling - it will dry fast in the heat, and that evaporation will keep you cool.It's also a cool accessory if you're cosplaying anything desert related.Free sample provided for honest review.

If you need to transport or carry a compact  HDD, I can't think of a better way to do it.  Plenty of padding, semi-rigid, with a wrap-around zipper. Enough protection when carrying in your luggage, suit case, or storing in a desk drawer. It's roomy enough for two drives - one in the base and a second in the lid. There's an elastic strap in the base to secure the drive, and a mesh pocket in the lid.Free sample provided for honest review.

This is a lighter weight hoodie, ideal for spring, fall, under a jacket, etc. There's no lining, so it's great for layering. All the seams except for the waist are lay-flat and over-stitched.  The neck and zipper seams are also covered. It's very comfortable. The waist is elastic, as are the cuffs. The cuffs are oversized - there's about an inch of extra room in the cuffs.The XL fits perfectly except for the lose cuffs. I use this as often as not under a lightweight jacket, since there's so little bulk.

I have some SSD's and HDD's that I use for offline storage. I was able to access my SSD's with no problem. I tried this with a couple of different HDD's, but there was not enough power to spin up the HDD's on my laptop or two desktops. If you're using SSD's, this will work fine. If you're using hard disks, you'll need a 12V power supply.  I had a spare one and tried that - then the HDD's worked with no problem.This is a lot more portable than the desktop boxes drives plug into, and is perfect for drives that don't draw a lot of power. It's as simple as plug in and go.Free sample provided for honest review.

I've only been using this for a couple of weeks, so can't honestly report results.  I'm in Illinois, and many portions of our back yard are dry. We had a dog pen between our shed and a large tree. After trimming the tree and removing the pen, we had a 14x14 foot area of dead, bare dirt, dry as a bone, cracked.  I've done a lot of reading on late season planting of seed, and thought I'd give it a try this year.I cleaned up the area removing weeks, rocks, dried rock-like pieces of mud and so on.  Then surface raked a few times to try and loosen something up - just ended up with a lot of dust.  So I spread this over the area as well as some shade grass seed, then tossed on a little dirt - more to keep the seed from washing away in a light rain.From what information I've found, this should give us a nice, green area next spring. I look at this as a long term project. If this works, I'll do the same thing to any bare spots before next winter.The product has no expiration date and is supposed to be used every four weeks. I tried to do some research on the ingredients. You need to be a chemist to understand it. From what I can find, this type of product  is called a "soil wetting agent." If you Google  "soil wetting agent" and "surfactants" you can find some information. They are extremely popular with places that use a lot of water and have a lot of green - golf courses for example. The way they work is interesting and proven science. The stuff bonds with the soil and water, allowing the soil to absorb water (driving it downward.)I'm looking forward to the results and plan on using this in the dry / compacted soil areas of our yard. This is identical to the shaker jug, only in a big bag!

After trimming the tree and removing the pen, we had a 14x14 foot area of dead, bare dirt, dry as a bone, cracked. All I can say is wow.  I have a few laser tapes, including another Bosch. What sold me on this was the Bluetooth feature.  I have an older tablet - Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 and the pairs with no issues.To take advantage of the Bluetooth, you need to use the free "Bosch Floorplan" app. I've tried other apps, but none support the Bosch GLM 50 C. I'm sure that more apps will support it in the future.The tool itself is cool. Bosch took ideas from a smartphone and added them to the GLM 50 C. The display is a screen - not just an LCD or LED. This means there are colors, the display changes depending on the mode, the menu is a real menu, and it rotates in 90 degree increments. So the display is always easy to read. The level readout goes to one decimal place - 6.5, 2.1, 22.5, etc.  The lever starts from 0 when laying flat on it's back, or on either long edge.  There's no audio, so if you're using it to level something, you won't hear a "beep" when you're level.  But it's not primarily a level.Observations: It's a Class 2 laser - same as laser pointers, so you don't want to stare into it. The back has a 1/4-20 thread for tripod and clamp mounting. The included sheath is very snug - the tool won't fall out, even if the flap is up.  Batteries and a lanyard are included.  Auto powers off after inactivity. The rubber protection is a little strange. The edges are protected, but it does not extend to the back or sides - so this will slide around. It extends past the face a *little*, but the soft-touch buttons extend almost as far. About all the rubber is good for is a better grip. The screen is bright and easy to read, even in sunlight. It is glossy, so *reflections* could make it difficult to read. It does not appear to be weather proof - I say this because there is no gasket on the battery door (it actually rattles), so water can get inside.Bosch has several free apps, but from what I can see, only one - the free "Bosch Floorplan" app works with the GLM 50 C.  It's a pretty powerful app with a lot of cool features, but also some annoyances.  You can zoom in and out unless you're in "wall" view. Then all you can do is move at the default zoom level. Since this is the area you add doors, windows, etc., not being able to zoom is really annoying.  It's also where you measure wall height, vaulted ceilings, etc. I hope they fix that soon.The app can create basic blueprints with outlets, windows, doors, openings, etc.  It will also calculate areas, angles and so on.  Of course, the tool can do all that as well, but seeing it on the screen is a big difference, especially if you're using it to measure windows and doors, flooring, paint, etc.  The app is obviously designed with professionals in mind, and there is a learning curve - you'll be accomplishing the basics in under 30 minutes.  There are a couple of ways to input the measurements - manually and via the Bluetooth connection.  You can take a bunch of measurements that are stored in a table in the app, then transfer these to your plan, or tap a measurement on the plan, then use the GLM 50 C to enter it directly.  Bluetooth is only "on" in the tool when transmitting, so this saves batteries. When a measurement is received, the app notifies you.Finally, this is a marvel of compactness.  It's about 4x1x1.75" and weighs just 3.5 oz with the batteries. It's a great tool to add to your arsenal.

We all use power strips. Or power strips attached to power strips and extension chords. One reason for that spaghetti-like mess is the collection of USB cables and adapters. Mini-USB, micro-USB, specialty camera cables, bluetooth earpiece chargers - the list seems endless.  The only common factor is that the majority have a USB connection.  I have a really heavy duty power strip - it has 16 outlets. I have this power strip plugged into that one. Yea, yell at me, but I need the outlets.  Not all are used at the same time and I'm way under the load limits.Several of my devices still require adapters - can't use USB - those are plugged into the other power strip. You know how it goes - some adapters cover two outlets, long narrow ones can cover three.  So those plug into the big strip.  This strip gets the smaller adapters, plus the power hungry devices.  Of the six USB ports, two are 2.4 amp, four are 1 amp.  So you can charge two fast charging devices.  If you have more fast charge devices, you can plug in an adapter and add your own. That's basically what I did.  Between my GF, family members and myself, we will literally have as many as 10 devices charging at one time. Three cell phones, iPad, Droid tablets, headsets, speakers, battery packs.  They all add up fast.This strip alone is perfect for most people - six outlets and six USB ports, all in a sleek package.  There's a power switch on the strip that lights when it's on. My only complaint - it can't be mounted unless you use heavy duty Velcro or VHB tape.Free sample provided for honest review.

One of the cutest bath toys. Ever. The critters light up - bright enough so your child could also play with these in the dark.  Glowing bath critters at night - imaginations can run wild - yea, three or four year olds can have fun with these as well.  There's no openings like squirty toys , so you don't have to worry about mold.  There's also no way to change the batteries when they die - but these are LED and I would expect them to have hundreds of hours or glow timeThere are two contacts on the bottom of each critter - same concept as those chirping plastic chicks that sit on your hand.  The surf board is a cute and fun addition to the set. Fun at bath time, wash time, wading pool or water table.  Even without water - a slightly moist hand will illuminate them.

We've used these medium sized cups for years, both in backing trays and free standing. The only thing we've had stick to them was Angel-food Cake. There's not much you can say about baking cups except they work, are great quality and come is a nice storage container.

I was not really sure what to expect when I ordered this - we had an older wooden step ladder that needed replacing.  Amazingly, they weigh the same - my 30 year old wood ladder and this aluminum ladder. The differences are obvious though - this ladder is tall. A lot taller than I expected.  I had to take it out of the box to fit it across the foot of my back seat.  If I need to change bulbs, reach the ceiling, get on the top shelf - no problem. My GF loves it - the ladder weighs so little that she has no problem using it (she's a skinny 100 lbs.)Unlike most ladders, you CAN use the top step. The handle extends 18 inches above the top step.  The two treads are 3" deep - plenty to comfortable step or stand on.My one complaint is that the ladder does not latch or lock closed. Not a big deal when stored, but when picked up it tends to open.  I wound up putting a Velcro strap around one side near the middle to keep it closed.  The top step/ledge latches in place, so the ladder is locked open when in use.

I'd never heard of one of these bowls until I was offered one free to review. I showed a photo to my GF and she announced that it was hers once it arrived.This is PERFECT for Pistachios and smaller nuts.  Personally I think it's too small for peanuts - you'd be lucky to fit more than a couple of dozen. But Edamame or Pistachios? Enough to keep you snacking for a while.  It's great on our office desk - when we snack on Pistachios it's always two bowls - on a crammed desk, that's a pain.You can also use this as two individual bowls, say one for Fritos and the other for Queso. Lots of uses and a fun set.I don't know it it's made from plastic, melamine or what - but it is synthetic.

This box contains all the HMV/EMI recordings made by four ensembles+ two recordings from Columbia Records (US)1) ADOLF BUSCH violin, with RUDOLF SERKIN piano (except Bach BWV 1004)--- Bach Partita BWV 1004 in D minor for Unaccompanied Violin + 2 alternate takes (1928-29)--- Bach Sonata BWV 1016 in E major - 2nd & 4th movements (1933)--- Bach Sonata BWV 1017 in  C minor - 1st movement (1933)--- Bach Sonata BWV 1021 in G major + 2 alternate takes (1929)--- Beethoven Sonata 3, Op.12,No.3 in E flat major  + alternate take (1931)--- Beethoven Sonata 5, Op.24 in F major "Spring" (1933)--- Beethoven Sonata 7, Op.30,No.2 in C minor (1932-33)--- Brahms Sonata 1, Op.78 in G major (1931)--- Brahms Sonata 2, Op.100 in A major (1932)--- Geminiani Sonatina in C minor (1931)--- Mozart Sonata K.377 in F major (1937)--- Reger Sonata 5, Op.84 in F-sharp major - 2nd movement (1931)--- Schubert Fantasia D.934 in C major (1931)--- Schumann Sonata 1, Op.105 in A minor (1937)--- Vivaldi Sonata Op.2,No.2 in A major (1931)2) BUSCH TRIO (Adolf Busch violin, Hermann Busch cello, Rudolf Serkin piano)--- Brahms Horn Trio, Op.40 in E-flat major - with Aubrey Brain horn (1933)--- Schubert Trio 2, D.929 in E-flat minor (1935)3) BUSCH QUARTET (Adolf Busch & Gösta Andreasson violins, Karl Doktor viola, Hermann Busch cello)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.18,No.1 in F major (1933)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.59,No.3 in C major (1933)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.95 in F minor "Serioso" (1932)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.127 in E-flat major (1936)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.130 in B-flat major (1941 Columbia Records)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.131 in C-sharp minor (1936)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.132 in A minor (1937)--- Beethoven Quartet Op.135 in F major (1933)--- Beethoven Grosse Fuge Op.133 in E-flat major - see Busch Chamber Players--------------------------------------------------------- Brahms Quartet 1, Op.51,No.1 in C minor 1937)--- Brahms Quartet 3, Op.57 in B-flat major (1949)--- Brahms Clarinet Quintet Op.115 in B minor - with Reginald Kell clarinet (1932)--- Brahms Piano Quartet 1, Op.25 in G minor - with Rudolf Serkin piano (1949)--- Brahms Piano Quartet 2, Op.26 - with Rudolf Serkin piano (1932)--- Brahms Piano Quintet Op.34 - with Rudolf Serkin piano (1938)--- Mendelssohn Capriccio Op.81,No.3 in E minor (1949)--- Schubert Quartet D.112 in B-flat major (1938)--- Schubert Quartet D.810 in D minor "Death and the Maiden" (1936)--- Schubert Quartet D.887 in G major (1938)4) BUSCH CHAMBER PLAYERS - a chamber orchestra led by violinist Adolf Busch--- Bach Brandenburg Concerti BWV1046-1051 (1935)--- Bach Suites for Orchestra  BWV 1066-1069 (1936)--- Beethoven Grosse Fuge Op.133 in E-flat major (1941 Columbia Records)--- Mozart Adagio and Fugue K.546 in C minor (1937)--- Mozart Serenade K.239 in D major "Serenata notturna" (1938)--- Mozart Piano Concerto 14, K.449 in E flat major - with Rudolf Serkin piano (1938)If you made it this far, you are probably more than a casual music lover.Chamber music is a small percentage of classical music sales, and historical chamber music recordings are an infinitesimal share of that.The Busch Quartet was the pre-eminent string quartet of the first half of the Twentieth Century (at least in Beethoven, Schubert and Brahms).I am grateful to Warner Classics for making this box available at such a low price (16 CDs for $29).I hope it tempts curious music lovers.PACKAGING AND SOUND:Sixteen CDs in in a cardboard box with a 32 page booklet (thirteen photographs).Excellent article by Tully Potter.Warner does not identify the remastering engineers. These remasterings are copyright 2015:--- Bach Partita BWV 1004 - 2 alternate takes--- Bach Sonata BWV 1016 - 2nd & 4th movements--- Bach Sonata BWV 1017 - 1st movement--- Bach Sonata BWV 1021 + 2 alternate takes--- Beethoven Sonata 3, Op.12,No.3 in E flat major - alternate take--- Brahms Sonata 1, Op.78 in G major--- Geminiani Sonatina in C minor--- Mozart Sonata K.377 in F major--- Reger Sonata 5, Op.84 in F-sharp major - 2nd movement--- Schubert Fantasia D.934 in C major--- Schumann Sonata 1, Op.105 in A minor--- Vivaldi Sonata Op.2,No.2 in A major--- Mozart Adagio and Fugue K.546 in C minor--- Mozart Serenade K.239 in D major "Serenata notturna"--- Mozart Piano Concerto 14, K.449 in E flat major - with Rudolf Serkin pianoThe Late Beethoven Quartets and Schubert Quartets D.810 and D.887 are the EMI "Great Recordings of the Century" remasterings from 2006-2008.Everything else is from the 1990s.The Brahms Horn Trio and Clarinet Quintets are Testament remasterings.Everything sounds good to me, but I am accustomed to the sound of historical recordings.POINTS OF INTEREST-- For a link to the most complete Adolf Busch discography on the internet,  see my Comment dated November 19, 2015.-- With the start of World War II Adolf Busch, the members of the Quartet and Rudolf Serkin were based in America, where they switched labels from EMI to Columbia Records (US).Not the same as Columbia Records (UK) which was a British affiliate of EMI.After the War, the Busch Quartet featured a new second violinist (Bruno Straumann) and violist (Hugo Gotesmann).The revised Quartet made three final recordings in London for EMI: Brahms Op.25 and Op.57, and Mendelssohn Op.89,No.3 (in this box).-- In addition to Beethoven's Op.130 and Op.133 (in this box), other additions to the Busch discography were recorded by Columbia Records  in America between 1941 and 1951:-- Beethoven Sonata 9, Op.47 in A major "Kreuzer" - with Rudolf Serkin (1941)-- Beethoven Trio Op.70,No.1 in D major "Ghost" (1951)-- Beethoven Quartet Op.59,No.1 in F major (1942)-- Brahms Trio Op.87 in C (1951)[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review through to the end, then come back and click on the links.]Previous CD releases of Columbia recordings:-- Beethoven Violin Sonata Op.47 = Ludwig Van Beethoven: "Spring" and "Kreutzer" Violin Sonatas-- Beethoven Quartet Op.59,No.1 = String Quartets 3 Op. 59 No. 1 & Op. 127 - this disc of Op.59,No.1 is part of a four CD traversal of all the Busch Quartet Beethoven recordings on Dutton.-- Beethoven & Brahms Trios =  Beethoven Trio Op. 70 No. 1 Brahms Trio Op. 87 Busch Serkin TrioSony now owns the  Columbia Records archives. A box from them would simplify the situation.

The "Forbidden Hollywood" series from Warner Brothers started in 2006 and is still going strong.Highlight of Volume Nine is young Bette Davis in an atypical role in 'The Cabin in the Cotton' (1932):"I'd like to kiss ya, but I just washed my hair''.Volume Two included an excellent documentary introduction to the topic:"Though Shall Not: Sex, Skin and Censorship in Pre-Code Hollywood" produced by Turner Classic Movies.The Motion Picture Production Code was approved by the studios in 1930, but was not seriously enforced until mid-1934.In 2009, Universal produced a six film collection "Pre-Code Hollywood" *, in the same spirit as Warner's "Forbidden Hollywood" series.I prepared this combined list for my own benefit, but thought I'd share it.Baby Face (1933) Vol.1 - Barbara Stanwyck, George BrentBig City Blues (1932) Vol.9 - Joan Blondell, Eric Linden, Humphrey Bogart (uncredited)Blonde Crazy (1931) Vol.8 - James Cagney, Joan Blondell, Louis CalhernThe Cabin in the Cotton (1932) Vol.9  - Richard Barthelmess, Bette DavisThe Cheat (1931) Universal* - Tallulah Bankhead, Irving Pichel, directed by George AbbottDark Hazard (1934) Vol.8 - Edward G. Robinson, Loretta Young, directed by William WellmanHell's Highway (1932) Vol.9 - Richard Dix, C.Henry GordonHeroes for Sale (1933) Vol.3 - Richard Barthelmess, Loretta Young, directed by William WellmanHi, Nellie (1934) Vol.8 - Paul Muni, Glenda FarrellHot Saturday (1932) Universal* - Nancy Carroll, Cary Grant, Randolph ScottI Sell Anything (1934) Vol.9 - Pat O'Brien, Ann DvorakJewel Robbery (1932) Vol.4 - William Powell, Kay FrancisLadies They Talk About (1933) Vol.5 - Barbara Stanwyck, Preston FosterLawyer Man (1933) Vol.4 - William Powell, Joan BlondellMandalay (1934) Vol.6 - Kay Francis, Ricardo CortezMan Wanted (1932) Vol.4 - Kay Francis, David MannersMassacre (1934) Vol.6 - Richard Barthelmess, Ann DvorakMerrily We Go the Hell (1932) Universal* - Sylvia Sidney, Frederic March, directed by Dorothy ArznerMidnight Mary (1933) Vol.3 - Loretta Young, Ricardo Cortez, directed by William WellmanThe Mind Reader (1933) Vol.5 - Warren William, Constance CummingsMiss Pinkerton (1932) Vol.5 - Joan Blondell, George BrentMurder at the Vanities (1934) Universal* - Kitty Carlisle sings "Sweet Marijuana"Night Nurse (1931) Vol.2 - Barbara Stanwyck, Joan Blondell, Clark GableOther Men's Women (1930) Vol.3 - Mary Astor, Grant Withers, directed by William WellmanThe Purchase Price (1932) Vol.3 - Barbara Stanwyck, George Brent, directed by William WellmanRed-Headed Woman (1932) Vol.1 - Jean Harlow, Chester MorrisSearch for Beauty (1934) Universal* - Dorothy Jordan, Lewis StoneWhen Ladies Meet (1933) Vol.9 - Ann Harding, Myrna Loy, Robert MontgomeryWild Boys of the Road (1933) Vol.3 - Frankie Darro, directed by William Wellman----------------------------------------Volumes 1-3 were deluxe productions on the Turner Classics Movies "TCM Archive" label. Pressed on standard DVDs with SDH subtitles.Volume Two includes the TCM documentary, "Though Shall Not: Sex, Skin and Censorship in Pre-Code Hollywood"plus Commentaries for two films.Volume Three includes two documentaries about director William Wellmanplus Commentaries for three films.Beginning with Volume 4, the series switched to the bare-bones "Warner Archive Collection" DVD-Rs (no subtitles or extra features)People bad-mouth DVD-Rs, but I haven't had any problems (yet).TCM Archives: Forbidden Hollywood Collection - Volume One (Waterloo Bridge (1931) / Baby Face / Red-Headed Woman)TCM Archives - Forbidden Hollywood Collection, Vol. 2 (The Divorcee / A Free Soul / Night Nurse / Three on a Match / Female)Forbidden Hollywood Collection: Volume Three (Other Men's Women / The Purchase Price / Frisco Jenny / Midnight Mary / Heroes for Sale / Wild Boys of the Road)Forbidden Hollywood Collection Volume 4 (Jewel Robbery / Lawyer Man / Man Wanted / They Call It Sin)Forbidden Hollywood Collection Volume 5 (Hard to Handle / Ladies They Talk About / The Mind Reader / Miss Pinkerton)Forbidden Hollywood Collection: Volume 6 (The Wet Parade / Downstairs / Mandalay / Massacre)Forbidden Hollywood Collection: Volume 7 (The Hatchet Man / Skyscraper Souls / Employee's Entrance / Ex-Lady)Forbidden Hollywood Collection Volume 8 (Blonde Crazy / Strangers May Kiss / Hi, Nellie / Dark Hazard)Forbidden Hollywood Collection Volume 9 (Big City Blues / Hell's Highway / The Cabin in the Cotton / When Ladies Meet / I Sell Anything) - reviewed on this page.* Universal Box: Pre-Code Hollywood Collection (The Cheat / Merrily We Go to Hell / Hot Saturday / Torch Singer / Murder at the Vanities / Search for Beauty) (Universal Backlot Series)

Forty years after Eugene Ormandy's death, the conductor is dismissed as a lightweight by many critics.But this was not always the case.The World's Foremost Authority on the Music of Jean Sibelius was an admirer of Eugene Ormandy.Ormandy's reputation as an interpreter of Sibelius (1865-1957) went into decline following the death of the World's Foremost Authority (in 1957)Overdue for re-evaluation.Almost all of Ormandy's stereo Columbia and RCA recordings of Sibelius are in this box (recorded 1957-1980)-- Sony forgot Ormandy's 1959 Columbia stereo recording of the Violin Concerto with David Oistrakh *Two later versions (with Isaac Stern and Dylana Jensen) are included.Also missing are the mono recordings (1935-1954).This is a shame - those are the recordings that Sibelius was so enthusiastic about.COLUMBIA + RCA STEREO RECORDINGS (in this box):Symphony 1 = 1962 Columbia, 1976 RCASymphony 2 = 1957 Columbia, 1972 RCASymphony 4 = 1978 RCASymphony 5 = 1975 RCASymphony 7 = 1960 Columbia, 1975 RCAFinlandia (standard version) = 1968 ColumbiaFinlandia (choral version) = 1959 Columbia, 1972 RCAOceanides = 1976 RCAPohjola's Daughter = 1976 RCAEn Saga = 1963 Columbia, 1975 RCATapiola = 1976 RCAValse triste = 1959 Columbia, 1973 RCAKarelia Suite = 1968 Columbia, 1975 RCAKarelia Overture = 1977 RCALemminkäinen Suite: Swan of Tuonela = 1960 Columbia, 1973 RCAViolin Concerto = 1969 Columbia (Isaac Stern), 1980 RCA (Dylana Jensen) - MISSING 1959 Columbia (David Oistrakh)EMI STEREO RECORDING (not in this box)Lemminkäinen Suite (Four Legends from the Kalevala) = 1978 **COLUMBIA + RCA MONO RECORDINGS (not in this box):Symphony 1 = 1935 Minneapolis, 1941 PhiladelphiaSymphony 2 = 1947Symphony 4 = 1954Symphony 5 = 1954Finlandia = 1940, 1950Oceanides = 1955Pohjola's Daughter = 1955En Saga = 1955Tapiola = 1955Lemminkäinen Suite (Four Legends from the Kalevala) = 1951Lemminkäinen Suite: Swan of Tuonela = 1940, 1950Lemminkäinen Suite: Lemminkäinen's Return = 1940PACKAGING AND SOUND:Eight CDs in cardboard jackets (not original jacket format) in a cardboard box.No booklet - this is one of Sony's super budget boxes.Track listings and recording dates are on the back of each jacket - the identical photo of Ormandy is on the front of all eight jackets.Unimaginative.The box claims "24-bit high resolution audio" - no information on who did the remastering.The RCA recordings are probably the existing 24-bit Japanese XRCD transfers (I can't be certain without the identity of the remastering engineer).Everything sounds fine to me.POINTS OF INTEREST:-- FINLANDIAThis release clears up some confusion about Ormandy's three stereo recordings of Finlandia.Finnish poet V.A. Koskenniemi added lyrics to Finlandia in 1941, turning it into a patriotic anthem.Sibelius gave it his blessing in 1942, so the "choral version" is technically legit.Ormandy recorded the standard orchestral version in 1968 (CD8, track 1)He recorded the choral version twice - Most impressively with the Mormon Tabernacle Choir in 1959 (CD8, track 8)By comparison, the unnamed choir used by RCA in 1972 (CD2, track 7) is pretty bland.All three are in this box.English Text used by Ormandy (deleting reference to Finland):"On great, lone hills, where tempests brood and gather,Primeval Earth, against primeval sky,We, faring forth, possessed by fervent longing,Have found a throne, eternal and high,Have knelt at last in wordless adoration,Till fire and whirlwind have both gone by.With ardent song we greet the golden morning.By faith upborne, remember not the night.The whole wide world, triumphant hails the dawning.God walks abroad in garments of might,The hills, behold, are now a path of splendor,Transfigured all, and all crowned with light."[see the Comment dated November 13, 2015 for the original patriotic text.]Odd - In 1959 Ormandy and the orchestra recorded Finlandia in Philadelphia.Columbia engineers then took the tape 2,000 miles west to record the Mormon Tabernacle Choir in Utah.Surprisingly, this is Not a World Record:In 1976 DG engineers recorded Saint-Saens' Organ Symphony with Daniel Barenboim and the Chicago Symphony.The organist was recorded 4,000 miles away in the Chartres Cathedral.-- One work of  Sibelius was new to Ormandy's repertoire in the 1970s: The Karelia Overture Op.10 (not to be confused with the better known Karelia Suite Op.11)An absolutely gorgeous performance and recording (1975 RCA).Every other recording of this rarity sounds anemic by comparison.--  The sound of the RCA recordings is a lot better than I remembered.The 1970s were a bad decade for RCA: Dynagroove + Dynaflex LP pressings. Yecch.I now find most of the RCA stereo recordings an improvement over their Columbia predecessors (no need to take my word for it - Sony gives you both versions).Where there is duplication, the 1972-1980 RCA recordings (Symphonies 1,2,7) are two to four percent slower than the 1957-1969 Columbia recordings.Barely noticeable.Exception: the 1980 Violin Concerto with Dylana Jenson is a lot slower (in the first two movements) than Ormandy's 1969 recording with Isaac Stern (see next paragraph)-- Dylana Jenson was a child prodigy - a student of Nathan Milstein.Tchaikovsky Competition Silver Medalist at age 17, playing the Sibelius Concerto.She made her adult debut in Carnegie Hall at age 19, playing the same Concerto - Ormandy conducted.Three days later, she and Ormandy recorded it (the only DDD recording in this box).Compared with the Stern/Ormandy recording from 1969, Jenson stresses the lyricism - at least in the first two movements (the first movement is daringly drawn out).The 1959 Oistrakh/Ormandy recording (not in this box) is in the middle.Timings for the Finale are virtually identical.Stern ------ 14:16 -- 7:35 -- 7:21Oistrakh -- 14:53 -- 8:20 -- 7:26Jenson --- 16:22 -- 8:33 -- 7:17-- Three Sibelius specialists:Herbert von Karajan never recorded Symphony 3.Sir Thomas Beecham never recorded Symphonies 3 and 5.Eugene Ormandy never recorded Symphonies 3 and 6.What's wrong with Symphony 3?--  With the exception of the Karelia Overture and two of three Finlandias (1959 choral and 1968), none of these recordings are my absolute first choice, but everything is in the top ten percent.Eight CDs for $15. Hard to resist.Ormandy was not a high profile Sibelius interpreter (unlike Late Bernstein and Late Karajan).These are fairly straightforward performances by a spectacular orchestra.Rachmaninov and even Shostakovich shared Sibelius' enthusiasm for Eugene Ormandy.Two more boxes that Sony could give us.I hope they include booklets this time.------------------------------------------------------CONDUCTORS RECOMMENDED BY SIBELIUS:In addition to Ormandy, eight additional conductors received the blessing of the World's Foremost Authority on the Music of Sibelius:(which ought to count for something)See my comment dated November 13, 2015.------------------------------------------------------* Oistrakh/Ormandy 1959 Columbia stereo recording of the Violin Concerto = Beethoven / Sibelius: Violin Concertos** Ormandy's 1978 EMI stereo recording of the Lemminkäinen Suite  =  Sibelius: Lemminkainen Suite, Tapiola - or - Sibelius: Four Legends from the Kalevala

56 CDs + One DVD for $143 NewRemarkable bargain.Back in 1991, Sony issued the 22 CD "Igor Stravinsky: The Edition" -  Igor Stravinsky: The Recorded Legacyreissued in 2007 as "Works of Igor Stravinsky" -
