Works of Igor StravinskyUnlike that one, this new box is absolutely complete- Every recording that Stravinsky  made for Columbia Records (US) between 1940 and 1967- one quarter of the contents of this new box are the mono recordings that were slighted in 1991.- some performances are conducted by Robert Craft "under the supervision of Igor Stravinsky".- Stravinsky had approval of the solo and chamber recordings:--- Charles Rosen played most of the piano works.--- Gold & Fizdale played the two-piano works (but not the two-piano version of the Rite of Spring, which has only become popular in the years following Stravinsky's death).The new box includes both the mono and stereo recordings of Oedipus Rex and The Rake's Progress, plus the ballets and symphonies.PACKAGING AND SOUND:"Original jacket" format with original cover art and album notes on the back of each cardboard sleeve, plus a 254 page hardcover book.The book is a tribute to Stravinsky the man.For information about the music, you mostly have to read the original jackets (use a magnifying glass).Surprisingly, everything was newly remastered for this new collection (24bit/96kHz)22 CDs remastered by Sony regulars Andreas Meyer and Jeanne Montalvo33 CDs remastered by Martin Kistner1 CD remastered by Richard KingAbsolutely no complaints about the soundPOINTS OF INTEREST:-- Both the 1940 mono and 1960 stereo recordings of the Rite of Spring feature the New York Philharmonic, but in 1960 it was recorded under the pseudonym "Columbia Symphony"Recording session photos show the same musicians who participated in Leonard Bernstein's 1958 Philharmonic recording (also same recording venue - The St. George Hotel in Brooklyn).Columbia actually paid the musicians more to record as the "Columbia Symphony", but saved money on future royalties.There was also a California-based version of the "Columbia Symphony" - mostly Los Angeles Philharmonic musicians-- Several editing errors have been corrected.Movements for Piano and Orchestra (with Charles Rosen) is now correctly edited for the first time on CD (the repeat is included).-- The DVD is not a comprehensive look at Stravinsky's career.It concentrates on his brief flirtation with Hollywood.Interesting.-- The 1953 recording of "The Rake's Progress" was recorded at the Metropolitan Opera shortly after the American premiere, with the original Met cast (Hilde Gueden, Eugene Conley, Mack Harrell and Martha Lipton).The American premiere was prepared and conducted by Fritz Reiner.The actual world premiere was in Venice in 1951, conducted by the composer (with Elizabeth Schwarzkopf, Ottakar Krauss, Robert Rounseville and Jennie Tourel) *-- The 1991 box included a selection of pre-1940 chamber music recordings with Stravinsky and violinist Samuel Dushkin, but they were borrowed from EMI and are not in the new box. **-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------This new collection was an extravagant decision on Sony's part, but I'm glad they did it.I'm not sure how they will ever recoup the cost at the low price asked - they will have to sell a lot of boxes.I have only one complaint - There are no texts or translations for the vocal worksThey were included with the 1991 box (but not the 2007 reissue).Surely Sony could at least have posted them on their website.I will have to keep my booklets from the 1991 boxed set.* The 1951 Venice world premiere of "The Rakes's Progress" is available on Igor Stravinsky: The Rake's Progress** Pre-1940 EMI recordings:  Composers in Person: Igor Stravinsky

There are no new recordings in this box - everything has been issued before (see Buyer's Guide at the end of this review).Riccardo Chailly is the only conductor to have recorded ALL of Brahms' orchestral music.The Four Symphonies, four Concertos, two Overtures and Variations on a Theme of Haydn have been recorded hundreds of times.The two Serenades are also easy to find.To these Chailly has added some RARITIES:-- Liebeslieder Waltzes Op.52, No.1,2,4,5,6,8,9,11 and Op.65, No.9In 1868, Brahms composed 18 waltzes for vocal quartet accompanied by piano four-hands.The following year he orchestrated nine (for orchestra alone - no singers).Also recorded by Gary Bertini/Vienna Symphony and Thomas Dausgaard/Swedish Chamber Orchestra.-- Two Intermezzi for Piano: Op.116, No.4 and Op.117, No.1 - ONLY RECORDINGThis is a ringer - Not orchestrated by Brahms.Orchestrated by Paul Klengel (1854-1935), a German conductor and composer who was a friend of Brahms(the notes don't say when Klengel orchestrated them, or if Brahms approved).-- Symphony 1: Original version of the Second MovementThis version of the second movement Andante premiered in 1876 with the rest of the Symphony, but before publication Brahms dropped five bars and added some transition material.This is the second recording of the original version - Charles Mackerras was first, with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra.-- Symphony 4: Revised opening to the First Movement - ONLY RECORDINGSome time after the premiere, Brahms added four bars to the opening of the First Movement, but quickly changed his mind.The Symphony was never performed this way.These introductory bars are over in a mere eight seconds, but Decca allots it 46 seconds.Brahms based his introduction on the final bars of the same movement, so the first movement now begins and ends with the same music.To illustrate this, the track opens with the final bars of the First Movement (13 seconds),then after a brief pause, you hear the new introduction (8 seconds) leading directly into the familiar First Movement (which fades away after 15 seconds).I don't much care for it, but may feel differently after I've heard it a few hundred times.I think it would have made a better impression if Decca had included two complete performances of the first movement - with and without the introduction - instead of just a fragment for the revised opening.This is the only recording of the revised opening of Symphony 4.I am informed that back in the 1960s, it was featured during the intermission of a Cleveland Orchestra radio broadcast.Apparently George Szell was interviewed and the orchestra performed the music.I'm not sure if Szell or his assistant Louis Lane conducted.It would be nice to have as part of a future "George Szell Edition".-- Hungarian Dances No. 1, 3 and 10Not exactly rarities, but not usually included with the symphonies.Brahms composed 21 Hungarian Dances for piano duet in the 1860s, and orchestrated these three in 1874 (other composers orchestrated the rest)These are fine modern performances - the Symphonies are an improvement over Chailly's first set with the Amsterdam Concertgebouw,but the competition in the major Brahms works is fierce.The primary attraction of this set is it's absolute completeness.All the rarities are included with the Symphonies - this part is an essential purchase.Depending on personal taste, you may or may not need Chailly's CDs of the two Serenades and four Concertos.You can save some money by buying just the 3 CD (or one Blu-Ray * ) collection of the Symphonies.(see Buyer's Guide)------------------------------------------------------BUYER'S GUIDE:[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review through to the end, then come back and click on the links.]This 7 CD box is currently selling for $30 new on Amazon.Versus $43 total for the 7 CDs in previous editions:Symphonies + Orchestral Works + All the  rarities = Brahms: The Symphonies = $19 (3 CD set) *Serenades = Brahms: Serenades = $7Piano Concerti = Brahms: The Piano Concertos = $11 (2 CD set)Violin + Violin & Cello Concerti = Brahms: Violin Concerto; Double Concerto = $6* THERE IS ONE OTHER OPTION:Before spending $19 on the 3 CD box of Symphonies +  Orchestral Works + All the rarities,Consider spending $15 for the BLU-RAY AUDIO edition: Brahms: The Symphonies [Blu-ray Audio]Everything on the 3 CD set is on one Blu-Ray with improved sound at a lower price.(prices correct as of November 2015)You don't need a special Blu-Ray Audio player.Blu-Ray Audio plays on any Blu-Ray Video player.Keep the video output connected to your TV to read the disc menu.Connect the audio to your Hi-Fi system.It's not uncommon to find ordinary CDs remastered at "24-bit/96 kHz", but the CD medium is incapable of accurately reproducing everything on the master.Compromises are made in the conversion to CD.You need SACD or Blu-Ray Audio to realize the full potential of the original master tape.The only real advantage of Blu-Ray Audio over the older SACD technology is a longer playing time.Blu-Ray Audio: Brahms: The Symphonies [Blu-ray Audio]BUT first read my review  "IF IT WON'T PLAY, THE FAULT IS NOT WITH YOUR PLAYER" dated July 9, 2015.(there was a mastering problem with the first batch of discs, but it has been corrected).

This nifty 1947 B-Movie film noir from Monogram (aka Allied Artists) features Barry Sullivan as small-time gangster "Shubunka".No first name.Unless "Shubunka" is his first name.Faithful  to the Uni-Name spirit, Shubunka's girl friend is played by the actress "Belita"."Belita" was actually Maria Belita Gladys Olive Lyne Jepson-Turner, born in Nether-Wallop, Hampshire, UK.She first came to public notice as a thirteen year old figure skater on the 1936 British Olympic Team, before her parents took her to Hollywood.Blond and blue-eyed, she does not fit my image of a "Belita".Nevertheless, not a bad actress.A very talky movie.The dialogue is a bunch of characters reciting their inner monologues out loud to each other.Sort of like a film noir written by Eugene O'Neill.Bizarre and pretentious, but always interesting.Released on a DVD-R from Warner Archive Collection.I watched it on Turner Classic Movies, where it had English subtitles, and a helpful introduction by film noir expert Eddie Mueller.Based on my experience, Warner Archive Collection DVD-Rs do NOT have subtitles.No extras either.Still a fun movie.

This is not Season Four of "Sherlock"It is a single 90 minute adventure titled "The Abominable Bride".This is not Episode One of Season Four.The BBC series "Sherlock" is set in modern-day London.“The Abominable Bride” will be a traditional Sherlock Holmes adventure set in Victorian London (see photos below).Sounds like it should be fun.The first three seasons aired on the BBC at two year intervals -Season One in 2010 -- Season Two on New Year's Day 2012 -- Season Three on New Year's Day 2014Season Four is running late. We will have to wait until New Year’s Day 2017.To tide us over until then, the BBC and PBS are offering us this interesting stand-alone experiment.Presumably the story is based on  "The Case of Ricoletti of the Club-foot and his Abominable Wife" one of Dr. Watson's cases for which the public is not yet prepared - mentioned in "The Musgrave Ritual".Set to air on PBS January 1, 2016, with DVD and Blu-Ray release on January 11, 2016.I can't guarantee that the PBS Masterpiece broadcast will be uncut.I plan to wait for the Blu-Ray anyway.---------------------------------------------------------------------I found the following article on the Entertainment Weekly website dated October 24, 2015See my comment dated November 4, 2015 for a link to their website.(it includes the trailer)"The BBC and PBS Masterpiece just announced premiere dates for the UK and the U.S. debuts of the eagerly awaited Victorian special edition of the acclaimed detective drama. And for the first time ever, those dates are the same day.The Sherlock special – titled Sherlock: The Abominable Bride – will air in both territories on Friday, Jan. 1, 2016.It’s been a very long wait for more Sherlock. The international sensation starring Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman had its third season debut in January 2014. PBS’ agreement has required that the show first air on the BBC, and UK networks tend to announce premiere dates much closer to when the show will actually air compared to U.S. networks (which often announce premiere dates many months in advance as part of a marketing campaign). Sherlock also used to have wide gaps between its UK and U.S. air dates, but fan lobbying and widespread online piracy have considerably shrunk that window in recent years, and for the upcoming special the gap has basically been eliminated entirely.In addition to the one-off episode set during Victorian times, producers are also working on a fourth season of the regular, modern-day Sherlock. Filming of season 4 was originally announced for this year, but is now expected to begin in early 2016.Here’s the Victorian special official description courtesy of PBS:“Benedict Cumberbatch and Martin Freeman return as Sherlock Holmes and Dr. Watson in the acclaimed modern retelling of Arthur Conan Doyle’s classic stories. But now our heroes find themselves in 1890s London. Beloved characters Mary Morstan (played by Amanda Abbington), Inspector Lestrade (Rupert Graves) and Mrs. Hudson (Una Stubbs) also turn up at 221b Baker Street.”

"Pitfall" was released in a totally new DVD / Blu-Ray transfer from Kino/Lorber on November 17, 2015.Unfortunately the cover designs for the old "Treasure Chest" DVD and the new  Kino/Lorber Blu-Ray/DVD are similar in appearance -  a reproduction of the original 1948 movie poster.Amazon has the unfortunate habit of lumping all reviews for a movie together - regardless of format or edition.When I posted this review, Amazon listed it on the same page as 122 earlier reviews of the "Treasure Chest" DVD and even ancient VHS tapes.Brand new reviews (like this one) are posted to the right of the "big four" reviews.As more New Reviews appear, this review will be bumped to a lower slot, and in about three months it will disappear from view entirely - unless it gets thirty "helpful" reviews in that time (not likely).VHS reviews seem to keep the top spot for eternity.Avoid the 2012 DVD release from "Treasure Chest" - fuzzy DVD transfer, no extras. *The new Kino/Lorber DVD/Blu-Ray features a new remastering from a 35mm dupe negative done by the UCLA Film Archive.+ an audio commentary from reliable film noir critic Eddie Muller+ theatrical trailers for "He Ran All the Way" (John Garfield and Shelley Winters) and "A Bullet for Joey" (Edward G. Robinson and George Raft)This deluxe treatment is unusual for a public domain film like "Pitfall".No subtitles is my only complaint.Despite all the care taken by the UCLA Film Archive, the picture is not pristine.A dupe negative is not the original negative, but the picture is still miles ahead of the "Treasure Chest" DVD, which was copied from a print.* BAD DVD = Pitfall (Treasure Chest)GOOD DVD = Pitfall (1948)GOOD BLU-RAY = Pitfall (1948) [Blu-ray]ANOTHER BAD DVD = Best of Film Noir Vol. 2Three DVD set from Treasure Chest with the same inferior transfer of "Pitfall" + two additional public domain films.

Universal, the legendary horror studio of the 1930s and '40s, also produced the Abbott and Costello comedies of the 1940s and '50s.In 1948, they had the genius idea of combining both franchises in the wildly successful "Abbot and Costello Meet Frankenstein".More than Frankenstein - the movie also included Universal's other horror stars Dracula and The Wolf-Man.Dracula was Bela Lugosi .... No problem there.The Wolf-Man was Lon Chaney Jr..... No problem there..Frankenstein should have been Boris Karloff .... but he wasn't.Karloff played the Frankenstein Monster in the first three films (1931-1939).Chaney took over in 1942 ("Ghost of Frankenstein"), followed by Lugosi in 1943 (Frankenstein Meets the Wolf-Man").Glenn Strange finished off the series in 1944 ("House of Frankenstein") and 1945 ("House of Dracula").Universal would have liked to cast Karloff in the Abbott and Costello film, but he was either tired of the role or held out for too much money.Since Lugosi and Chaney were already in the cast, the role of Frankenstein went by default to Glenn Strange."Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein" was an enormous hit in 1948, which caused Karloff to have second thoughts.in 1949, he agreed to co-star in "Abbott & Costello Meet the Killer, Boris Karloff",probably the most awkward movie title ever -- see movie poster below."Abbott & Costello Meet the Killer, Boris Karloff" is not in this collection.A justifiable decision – it’s not really a horror comedy, more of a mystery comedy (and it’s not as funny as “Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein”).But it does have elements of the supernatural, and it does have Boris Karloff.Karloff plays sinister mystic Swami Talpur, but in the end he turns out to be just a crook, not a real Svengali.I do wish Universal had included it in this collection, since it is unavailable outside of big multi-disc collections.*Boris Karloff returned once more for 1953’s “Abbott & Costello Meet Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” (in this collection).[“Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” was not part of the Universal horror franchise - MGM produced the two previous versions, with Frederick March (1931) and Spencer Tracy (1941).]Two additional entries (without famous co-stars) are in this box:- “Abbott & Costello Meet the Invisible Man” (1951)I wish Vincent Price had been cast (he had a cameo as the Invisible Man in “Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein”).Instead they chose the unmemorable Arthur Franz.- “Abbott & Costello Meet the Mummy” (1955) with Michael Ansara as the Mummy – another role originated by Boris Karloff.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review through to the end, then come back and click on the links.]These films (and their special features) are not new to DVD.-- "Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein" has even been given the Blu-Ray treatment: Abbott and Costello Meet Frankenstein [Blu-ray] **-- "Abbott & Costello Meet the Invisible Man" is in The Invisible Man: Complete Legacy Collection-- "Abbott & Costello Meet the Mummy" is in  The Mummy: Complete Legacy CollectionBut the new two-DVD set is the easiest way to acquire "Abbott & Costello Meet Dr. Jekyll and Mr, Hyde"I only wish Universal had coupled this film with "Abbott & Costello Meet the Killer, Boris Karloff",thereby giving us a convenient coupling of the two films that Boris Karloff made with Abbott and Costello.* "Abbott & Costello Meet the Killer, Boris Karloff" is in The Best of Abbott & Costello, Vol. 3 (Abbott & Costello Go to Mars / Abbott & Costello in the Foreign Legion / Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein / Abbott & Costello Meet the Invisible Man / Abbott & Costello Meet the Killer / Comin' Round the Mountain / Lost in Alaska / Mexican Hayride)** "Abbott & Costello Meet Frankenstein" is also available on DVD in three different "Complete Legacy Collection" boxes from Universal::Frankenstein: Complete Legacy CollectionDracula: Complete Legacy CollectionThe Wolf Man: Complete Legacy Collection

Choice Collection is releasing the eight "Whistler" movies on eight DVD-Rs.The price is $10-$15 per film which is a lot for B-Movies that average one hour in length.A better buy would be: THE WHISTLER - THE FILMS COLLECTION - 4 DVD - 8 MOVIESProduced by OnesMedia.Eight movies on four DVD-Rs = $25 new.The picture quality on the OnesMedia prints is OK.I haven't seen the "Choice Collection" DVD-Rs so I am not qualified to comment on them, other than to point out that they are rather pricey.Also, in my experience DVD-Rs do not have subtitlesThis statement is based on experience -  Warner Archive Collection DVD-Rs do not have subtitles, even though many of the same films do when shown on TCM.

D.C.I. George Gently (played by Martin Shaw) debuted on British television in 2007.The first episode was set in 1964 .The final episode of Series Seven takes place during the final week week of 1969.All seven series have English SDH subtitles, and are uncut - Unlike the PBS Masterpiece Mystery broadcast versions.Extras: Season Seven has three brief interviews with cast members.He was Inspector George Gently of Scotland Yard when his wife was killed by a hit-and-run driver.Overcome by depression, he retreats to a small city in Northern England *, where everyone speaks in a bizarre pseudo-Scottish dialect (children = "bairns").Gently is appointed Detective Chief Inspector of the local police.DCI Gently is a big fish in a small pond.The police force he joins is remarkably corrupt (as was the force he left).DCI Gently does not approve of local policing methods, but he is not above looking the other way if it will advance his investigation.His sergeant is D.S. John Bacchus, young and trendy and thoroughly unlikeable (played by Lee Ingleby with a Beatles haircut).Sergeant Bacchus' goal in life (frustrated by DCI Gently) is to drive his sports car to Swinging London and join Scotland Yard.I'm not sure why Gently keeps him on, but they are still together after seven seasons.Sergeant Bacchus did mature a bit following the traumatic events of the Season Five finale ("Gently in the Cathedral") -the best episode in the series.It featured a guest appearance from Kevin Whately (better known as Inspector Lewis) as George Gently's old friend Inspector Don McGhee.Season Six introduced a new character: WPC (Women's Police Constable) Rachel Coles, (played by Lisa McGrillis).Unfortunately she brings out the worst in Sergeant Bacchus, who is jealous of the [professional] attention paid to her by DCI Gently.I'm worried about Sergeant Bacchus.Season Seven struck me as the best writing so far (though episode two - "Breathe in the Air"-  is incredibly manipulative).There is some re-thinking of the series:-- George Gently has health worries and is drinking too much. Ominous.-- On DCI Gently's recommendation, there are two promotions:Detective Inspector John Bacchus and Detective Sergeant Rachael Coles (could a sequel be in the works?).The Season Seven epilogue indicates that another Season is planned, but I am worried.George Gently, a World War II veteran, is in his fifties.The actor Martin Shaw just turned seventy and can't keep this up forever.I will miss him when he goes.* The largest city in the area is Durham (population 50,000), home to Durham Cathedral - featured in the Season 5 finale.Rev. John Bacchus Dykes (1823-1876) was a famous Nineteenth Century clergyman from Durham (thanks Wikipedia).Seasons 3-7 were filmed in several locations in Northeast England including Durham - Seasons 1 and 2 were filmed in Ireland.-------------------------------------------------------BUYER'S GUIDE[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review through to the end, then come back and click on the links.]The first five series occupy a year each, 1964 through 1968.1969 is spread over Seasons Six and Seven.Seasons 1-4 are available singly, but I recommend you purchase the mega-box of the first four Seasons.You get all four seasons for less than half the cost if purchased separately.(also, for once the Blu-Ray version costs less than DVD).Blu-Ray or DVD - GEORGE GENTLY COLLECTION: SERIES 1-4 (BLU-RAY)Each series is individually packaged in its own plastic case (with original artwork), all of which which slides neatly into a cardboard slipcase.Season Five:Blu-Ray or DVD - George Gently, Series 5 [Blu-ray](with the great final episode)Season Six :Blue Ray or DVD - George Gently 6 [Blu-ray]Series Seven: Reviewed on this page..Four years before he played DCI George Gently, Martin Shaw was Inspector Adam Dalgliesh in P.D. James - Death in Holy Orders - and - P.D. James - The Murder RoomInspector Dalgliesh is a published poet as well as a policeman.Dalgliesh and Gentry have a lot in common.I first saw Martin Shaw thirty years ago playing the doomed Scott of the Antarctic on Masterpiece Theater: The Last Place on Earth: The Complete Epic MiniseriesImpressed me then, and now.(its not a spoiler to describe Robert Falcon Scott as doomed - this is history not fiction).-------------------------------------------------------For a list of my all-time Favorite British Police Inspectors, see my Comment dated August 13, 2015.

Bulldog Drummond is not a private eye.He's a retired Army officer who finds peacetime Britain too tame, so devotes his energies to the fight against crime.Very much a modern vigilante.Twenty sound films with eleven different actors were produced between 1929 and 1969.OnesMedia will be presenting the complete collection on DVD for the first time, in two volumes:RONALD COLMAN- 1929 Bulldog Drummond- 1934 Bulldog Drummond Strikes BackPicture and sound quality for the 1929 film are surprisingly good for an early talkie.It's also a pre-code film: When a villain threatens to rape the heroine, Bulldog Drummond immediately strangles him to death.Picture quality for the second film (co-starring Loretta Young) is not as good - it appears to be copied from a VHS tape, and there is a slight glitch every thirty seconds.But this is this film's only listing on Amazon, so one can't be too picky.RALPH RICHARDSON- 1934 The Return of Bulldog DrummondAside from Hitchcock, one does not expect much from pre-war British films, but this curiosity is of exceptional interest.Bulldog Drummond is more than a vigilante - he is the commanding officer of his own private army.Drummond's militia wears black shirts and leather helmets (1934 viewers would not miss the reference to what was happening in Germany - apparently not everyone thought it was a bad idea).Picture quality is pretty good, the sound less so.JACK HULBERT / ATHOLL FLEMING- 1935 Bulldog JackAtholl Fleming as Bulldog Drummond is hospitalized early in the film.British comic Jack Hulbert impersonates him to finish the mission.A successful mix of comedy and thriller.[this is Ralph Richardson's second Bulldog Drummond film - he plays the villain this time.]A British film with an American Damsel in Distress (Fay Wray)Picture and sound are both good.JOHN LODGE- 1937 Bulldog Drummond at BayThough a British film, the lead roles are played by American actors (Victor Jory is the villain).Picture quality is only OK - the competing Alpha Video version is brighter but not more detailed.JOHN HOWARD or RAY MILLANDBetween 1937 and 1939, Paramount filmed eight B-Movies starring John Howard or Ray Milland,with an ensemble supporting cast:- Reginald Denny as Algy, Drummond's best friend- E.E. Clive as Tenny, Drummond's butlerAll eight films have been in the public domain for a long time.Of The five in OnesMedia Volume One, three are a significant improvement over the Alpha Video prints (Bulldog Drummond Escapes, Bulldog Drummond Comes Back, Bulldog Drummond's Peril)Ray Milland:- 1937 Bulldog Drummond EscapesJohn Howard:- 1937 Bulldog Drummond's Revenge- 1937 Bulldog Drummond Comes Back- 1938 Bulldog Drummond's Peril- 1938 Bulldog Drummond in Africa------------------------------------------------ end of Volume 1- 1939 Arrest Bulldog Drummond- 1939 Bulldog Drummond's Secret Police- 1939 Bulldog Drummond's BrideJOHN BARRYMORE never played Bulldog Drummond,even though he was billed as the star of Bulldog Drummond's Revenge, Bulldog Drummond Comes Back, and Bulldog Drummond's Peril.Paramount hired him to play Col. Nielsen of Scotland Yard (a supporting character) in the first three John Howard films.Unfortunately Barrymore's alcoholism forced the studio to cast a different actor as Inspector Nielsen for the remaining films.RON RANDELL- 1947 Bulldog Drummond at Bay- 1947 Bulldog Drummond Strikes BackTOM CONWAY- 1948 The Challenge- 1948 Thirteen Lead SoldiersWALTER PIDGEON- 1951 Calling Bulldog DrummondRICHARD JOHNSON:- 1967 Deadlier than the Male- 1969 Dome Girls DoThe Ronald Colman, Ralph Richardson, Jack Hulbert, Ron Randell, Tom Conway  and Richard Johnson films are extremely hard to find outside of these two inexpensive volumes from OnesMedia.Seven DVDs in a CD-size plastic clamshell case with soft plastic sleeves (the same packaging this company uses for CDs of old radio shows).Picture quality ranges from just OK to pretty good, but OnesMedia did a heroic job of cleaning up the sound.No subtitles, but I wasn't expecting any at this price.These are DVD-Rs, but I had no problems with playback.Finally, THERE IS NO COMPETITION.For the OnesMedia website, see my comment dated July 26, 2015.------------------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as A-Movies, but ended up as B-Movies (Philo Vance began at Paramount and ended up at PRC)PART ONE: REFORMED CRIMINALS TURNED PRIVATE EYE- Boston Blackie, the Lone Wolf and the Saint are reformed jewel thieves. Still viewed with suspicion by the police.- The Falcon has a shady past (never quite explained).- Arsene Lupin is an unreformed jewel thief who sometimes helps the police if it serves his ends.- The Crime Doctor used to be an Organized Crime Boss. He never actually reformed, but was conked over the head and woke up with amnesia.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.If there is ever a problem with a OnesMedia link, go directly to their website - see my comment dated July 26, 2015]BOSTON BLACKIE: BOSTON BLACKIE FILM COLLECTION - 14 MOVIES - 7 DVD-RCRIME DOCTOR: CRIME DOCTOR FILM COLLECTION - 5 DVD-R - 10 MOVIES - 1943-1949 with Warner BaxterTHE FALCON:--- George Sanders: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 1 (3 Discs)--- Tom Conway: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 2THE LONE WOLF: THE LONE WOLF FILM COLLECTION - 15 MOVIES - 8 DVD-RTHE SAINT:--- George Sanders: The George Sanders Saint Movie Collection (2 Disc)--- Hugh Sinclair: The Saint's Vacation / The Saint Meets the Tiger: The Saint Double FeatureARSENE LUPIN:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00KB49ME0----------------------------------------------------PART TWO: PRIVATE EYES WITHOUT A CRIMINAL PASTPerry Mason is a also a lawyer, but we'll overlook that.BULLDOG DRUMMOND: reviewed on this page.NICK CARTER:Copy and paste in the Amazon search bar: *ASIN:B00CDV4OECPERRY MASON: Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Bros. Movies CollectionMICHAEL SHAYNE:Volume One was issued way back in 2007. Still waiting for Volume Two.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B000LC4ZDKPHILO VANCE:--- 7 films, 1929-1947: PHILO VANCE FILM RARITIES COLLECTION - 7 DVD-R - 7 MOVIES (OnesMedia)--- 6 films, 1930-1940: The Philo Vance Murder Case Collection (Warner Archive)You need both for a complete collection - there is no overlap.I LOVE A MYSTERYThree films, 1945-1946 starring Jim Bannon and Barton YarboroughThe last but least of the B-Movie Detective series.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B010J9O0M0PHILIP MARLOWE / SAM SPADEThese two detectives were the most famous Private Eyes of all time, but they don't really belong on this list.They were A-Movie detectives all the way:- 1931 The Maltese Falcon: Ricardo Cortez as Sam Spade- 1936 Satan Met a Lady: Warren William as Sam Spade - adapted from 'The Maltese Falcon' by Dashiell Hammett- 1941 The Maltese Falcon: Humphrey Bogart as Sam Spade- 1944 Murder, My Sweet: Dick Powell as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'Farewell, My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler- 1946 The Big Sleep: Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 Lady in the Lake: Robert Montgomery as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 The Brasher Doubloon: George Montgomery as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'The High Window" by Raymond ChandlerBut two  Philip Marlowe novels were adapted as B-Movies for other detectives:- 1942 Time to Kill (Lloyd Nolan as Michael Shayne) - adaptated from 'The High Window' by Raymond Chandler- 1942 The Falcon Takes Over (George Sanders as The Falcon)) - adapted from 'Farewell My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler--------------------------------------------------------For PART THREE: UNCONVENTIONAL B-MOVIE DETECTIVES from the '30s and '40s, see my Comment dated July 26, 2015.Also directions to the OnesMedia website.* Amazon only permits ten links per review, so I had to use ASIN numbers for the rest (Amazon Stock Index Numbers)

I was surprised to learn that this was the first complete stereo set of Sibelius' Symphonies.Maazel's Vienna Philharmonic box was completed a year later, followed by Barbirolli/Halle Orchestra. *The first two symphonies in this set are among the most extrovert in the catalog, almost a caricature of the young Lenny (even though they were recorded fairly late in his New York tenure).Vigorous and exciting."Hot" performances of a "Cool" composer.Symphonies 3-7 are more conventional performances.Symphony 1 - rec.1967Symphony 2 - rec.1966Symphony 3 - rec.1965Symphony 4 - rec.1966Symphony 5 - rec.1961Symphony 6 - rec.1967Symphony 7 - rec.1960Violin Concerto with Zino Francescatti - rec.1963Finlandia - rec.1965Pohjola's Daughter - rec.1964Swan of Tuonela - rec.1973Valse Triste - rec.1969Luonnotar Op.70 with Phyllis Curtin soprano - rec.1965SOUND QUALITY:All recordings are newly re-mastered (24-bit/96khz) in 2015 by Andreas K. Meyer (Meyer Media Mastering LLC)These recordings now sound infinitely better than they did on LP.The CD remastering is also an improvement over the Royal Edition, or the Bernstein Century Edition, or the Bernstein Symphony Edition.This is the second time that Andreas K. Meyer has had a go at Bernstein's New York Legacy.Five years ago he was responsible for the critically acclaimed fourth CD remastering of Bernstein's Mahler. **Let's hope he keeps at it.Unfortunately, the bulk of these recordings were made in New York's Philharmonic Hall shortly after it opened in 1962.An acoustic disaster and a major scandal at the time.Management refused to admit that there was anything wrong with it. ***Symphonies 5, 7, Pohjola's Daughter, and Finlandia were recorded at the Manhattan Center, a New York ballroom with a much warmer acoustic.If this set had been recorded a few years earlier, Columbia Records could also have used the excellent St. George Hotel ballroom (scene of Bernstein's first and Stravinsky's last recordings of the Rite of Spring)or even Carnegie Hall(but Carnegie management was feuding with the New York Philharmonic over the orchestra's decision to build its own hall).Conundrum: Either the 1960's Symphony Hall master tapes of Mahler and Sibelius contained much better sound than anyone suspected, or Andreas K. Meyer has discovered the secret of alchemy.PACKAGING:Seven CDs in cardboard mini-LP jackets in a cardboard box, but only four CDs get original jacket notes.Symphonies 2,3,4,6 and 7 were first issued as part of a boxed set - Sony foolishly just reproduces the promotional blurb from the back of the LP box on three CD jackets.A 34 page booklet, but only a three-page article, "Bernstein's New York Sibelius"There is an English translation of "Luonnotar" on the back of the mini-LP jacket for CD 1.-- In the 1980s, Leonard Bernstein started a second Sibelius cycle with the Vienna Philharmonic for DG, but never lived to finish it.The 1986-1989 remakes of Symphonies 1, 2, 5 and 7 were significantly slower, but no less passionate than the 1960s cycle.In his later years, Bernstein tended to wallow in the music.This is not a criticism - I love Old Lenny, and you need not fear duplication when you buy his early and late recordings.They are not just remakes, they are re-thinkings.But the earlier performance remains equally valid.BONUS ITEMS:Since the original jacket format is used, some additional works by other composers are included:-- Grieg: Peer Gynt Suites 1 & 2 - rec. 1967 in Philharmonic Hall-- Bruch: Violin Concerto 1 in G Minor with Zino Francescatti - rec. 1962 in Manhattan Center (conducted by Thomas Schippers)-------------------------------------------------* More accurately, Bernstein's was the first Western stereo set.John Berky points out that, contrary to the booklet notes, the first stereo set of the Sibelius Symphonies was Akeo Watanabe/Japan Philharmonic.Before Bernstein, Columbia seemed to be well on the way to a complete set with Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra: but only Symphonies 1,2,4,5 and 7 were completed.Ormandy re-recorded these five symphonies for RCA, but apparently he was allergic to 3 and 6.Too bad: Even though the critics didn't think much of Ormandy, Sibelius was very fond of him.**  Andreas K. Meyer's Mahler remastering: Gustav Mahler: The Complete Symphonies &  Kindertotenlieder - also available in Mahler: The Complete Symphonies*** In 1973, electronics pioneer Avery Fisher donated $10 million to fix the acoustics (it helped a little).Philharmonic Hall was renamed "Avery Fisher Hall".Breaking News:On November 13, 2014, Lincoln Center officials announced their intention to remove Avery Fisher's name from the Hall and sell naming rights to the highest bidder.Pop music mogul David Geffen bid $100 million to rename it "David Geffen Hall".Progress.

First the complaint.DG has given us a 37 CD collection of vocal works, including twelve operas, without texts or translations, or even a synopsis.Aargh.Back in 2012, DG issued a 43 CD box of all thirteen Wagner operas.*The booklet included a detailed synopsis of each opera,plus a link to a website where the complete texts and translations can be found.Not as nice as having them in booklet form, but much better than nothingAnd Fricsay gets nothing.I was tempted to penalize this box one star, but I respect Ferenc Fricsay too much.Maybe four-and-a-half stars.CHORAL  AND VOCAL WORKS:- Bartok: Cantata Profana - 1951 mono (Krebs, Fischer-Dieskau) - sung in German- Brahms: Alto Rhapsody - 1957 mono (Maureen Forrester)- Haydn:------ Die Jahreszeiten (The Seasons) - two performances, 1952 mono (Trotschel, W.Ludwig, Greindl) and 1961 mono/stereo broadcast (Stader, Haefliger, Greindl - Part 4 "Winter" is released in stereo for the first time)------ Te Deum in C major - 1961 stereo- Kodaly: Psalmus Hungaricus - two performances, 1954 mono and 1959 stereo broadcast (both w/Ernst Haefliger) - sung in German- Mahler: Rückert-Lieder - 1958 stereo (M. Forrester)- Mendelssohn: "Midsummer Night's Dream" Overture and Incidental Music - 1950 mono (Streich, Eustrati) - sung in German- Mozart:------ Mass in C minor K.427 "Grosse Messe" - 1959 stereo (Stader, Grummer, Haefliger, Sardi)------ Requiem in D minor K.626 - 1951 mono broadcast (Grummer, Pitzinger, Krebs, Hotter)------ Exsultate, jubilate K.165 - two performances, 1954 mono and 1960 stereo (both w/Maria Stader)------ Vesperae K.339: Laudate Dominum omnes gentes - 1960 stereo (M. Stader)- Orff: Carmina Burana excerpts - 1949 mono (Schlemm, Fischer-Dieskau)- Rossini: Stabat Mater - 1954 mono (Stader, Radev, Haefliger, Borg)- Johann Strauss: Fruhlingsstimmen Waltz - 1952 (Wilma Lipp)- Stravinsky:------ Oedipus Rex - 1960 mono broadcast (E. Haefliger) - with German narrator------ Symphony of Psalms - 1951 mono- Verdi:------ Messa da Requiem - two performances, 1953 mono (Stader, Radev, Krebs, Borg) and 1960 mono broadcast (Stader, Dominguez, Carelli, Sardi)------ Quattro Pezzi Sacri - 1952 monoOPERAS:- Bartok: Bluebeard's Castle - 1958 stereo (Topper, Fischer-Dieskau) - sung in German- Beethoven: Fidelio - 1957 stereo (Rysanek, Haefliger, Fischer-Dieskau)- Bizet: Carmen highlights - 1958 stereo (Dominguez, Simandy, Metternich) - sung in German- Gluck: Orfeo ed Euridice - 1956 mono (Fischer-Dieskau, Stader) - sung in German- Mozart:------ Don Giovanni - 1958 stereo (Fischer-Dieskau, Jurinac, Stader)------ Le nozze di Figaro - 1960 stereo (Capecchi, Stader, Fischer-Dieskau)------ Idomeneo, re di Creta - 1961 mono broadcast (Kmentt, Grummer, Haefliger)------ Die Entführung aus dem Serail - 1954 mono (Stader, Streich, Haefliger)------ Die Zauberflöte - 1955 mono (Streich, Stader, Haefliger, Fischer-Dieskau)- Johann Strauss: Die Fledermaus - 1949 mono (Schlemm, Anders)- Verdi: Falstaff: "Brav, alter Hans" ("Va, vecchio John", Act 2) - 1951 mono (Metternich, Fischer-Dieskau, van Dijk) - sung in German- Wagner: Der fliegende Holländer - 1952 mono (Metternich, Kupper, Greindl)OPERA ARIAS:- Maria Stader (soprano): arias (3) by Mozart - 1957 mono, sung in German- Hertha Töpper (soprano): arias (2) by Verdi - 1957 mono, sung in German- Ernst Kozub (tenor): arias (2) by Puccini - 1957 mono, sung in German- Josef Metternich (baritone): arias (2) by Bizet, Rossini - 1957 mono, sung in German- Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau (baritone): arias (8) by Bizet, Gounod, Rossini, Verdi, Giordano, Leoncavallo - 1961 stereo, sung in French and ItalianDOCUMENTARY: "Erzahltes Leben" (A Life Retold)An hour long radio documentary about the life of Ferenc Fricsay - in German, but an English translation is provided in the booklet.DVD - FERENC FRICSAY IN REHEARSAL AND PERFORMANCE:- Dukas: Sorcerer's Apprentice- Kodály: Háry János SuiteFilmed in 1961, region-free NTSC format, 113 minutes, black and white, English subtitles.Fricsay had an unusual conducting technique.No baton, and he waved both arms about frantically, like a big ungainly bird trying to take off.But once he was in flight, it was beautiful.-- The rehearsals are a little annoying - Fricsay spends a lot of time explaining the stories behind the music.More for the television audience's benefit than the orchestra's,but the concerts are fabulous (the tympanist is really enjoying himself).---------------------------------------------POINTS OF INTEREST:- "Carmina Burana" had premiered in Frankfurt in 1937 - Fricsay's 1949 recording introduced it to the rest of the world.Six excerpts were recorded:11) Estuans interius, 13) Ego sum abbas, 14) In taberna quando sumus, 20) Veni, veni, venias, 21) In trutina, 22) Tempus est iocundum-- Dubious Distinction:Carl Orff's "Carmina Burana" is the most enduring piece of classical music to emerge from Nazi Germany - overshadowing efforts from Pfitzner, Schmidt, Richard Strauss and Anton Webern."Carmina Burana" was privately recorded at the Vienna State Opera in 1942, but that recording was only released in 1995.**- Opera in German:Fricsay was associated with the Berlin State Opera from 1949-1961. It was customary to perform all operas in German.Three operas in this collection are sung in the wrong language:--- Bluebeard's Castle sounds OK - To my ears, German doesn't sound all that different from Hungarian.--- Orfeo ed Euridice doesn't sound half bad either, probably because of Fischer-Dieskau's mellifluous baritone.--- Carmen: French Opera does not travel well. This Carmen just sounds strange - Joseph Metternich is positively villainous as Escamillo - Interesting.--- Verdi: Falstaff: "Brav, alter Hans" ("Va, vecchio John") is a 17 minute scene from Act 2 - Josef Metternich sings Falstaff, Fischer-Dieskau sings Ford.Verdi sounds surprisingly natural in German.The Audite label has an interesting series of Fricsay broadcasts, including an excellent German-language Rigoletto from 1950.***--- You can also find a DVD of Don Giovanni sung in German by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, conducted by Fricsay in 1961 (the CD performance in the DG box is sung in Italian).****- Two operas appear in unusual editions:--- Orfeo ed Euridice: Baritone Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau sings the role of Orfeo.Gluck wrote two versions:An Italian version for castrato (usually sung by a mezzo or countertenor - castrati being hard to find), and a French version for high tenor.But not a German version for baritone.Fischer-Dieskau also recorded Orfeo in Italian and in stereo (Karl Richter conducting).I have no problem with a baritone Orfeo, but I'm not a musicologist.--- Idomeneo: Mozart left two versions, but Fricsay conducts a hybrid version by Bernhard Paumgartner.Recorded live at the Salzburg Festival in 1961.- Four works were recorded twice.Fricsay was diagnosed with cancer in 1958.This had an effect on his late performances (Fricsay conducted his final concert in 1961).Fricsay was a Hungarian patriot and a devout Roman Catholic.The late broadcast performances of Kodaly's "Psalmus Hungaricus" (1959) and Verdi's Requiem (1960) are are both slower, heavier and more emotionally heart-on-sleeve than the earlier recordings from 1954.This also applies to the 1953 and 1959 performances of Tchaikovsky's Pathetique Symphony in Volume One of DG's Fricsay Edition.-- The early and late performances of Haydn's "Seasons" and Mozart's "Exsultate Jubilate" are not that different, but this is basically cheerful music.--------------------------------------------PACKAGING:126 page booklet with an article by the producer, and a reminiscence by Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, plus an  index to the contents.Modified "original jacket" format - the original LP cover is on the front of each jacket,but there are no program notes on the back, just a general list of contents.For tracks and timings, you have to look in the booklet.Wait, multi-disc sets do have track listings on the inside of the jacket fold.Reviewer BP Mills on Amazon UK is correct in noting that "the booklet has an issue in that the binding eats some of the words on the page; the type runs into the binding so much that you cannot pry it open without breaking the spine (see photo with his Amazon UK review dated July 10, 2015) .My booklet was not so bad as Mr. Mills - I can read everything (just), but I see his point.There is no indication in the booklet that anything has been newly re-mastered.The stereo recordings sound fine, as you'd expect.DG's mono recordings have never been sought out by Audiophiles, but these are honest transfers that do not hinder your enjoyment of the music.------------------------------------------- This box is a companion to Volume One: Ferenc Fricsay: Complete Recordings on Deutsche Grammophon, Vol. 1, Orchestral WorksDevoted to orchestral works and concertos.* DG Complete Wagner: Wagner Complete Operas** 1942 Carmina Burana recording: Vienna State Opera Series - Vol 21 )*** 1950 Rigoletto in German: Verdi - Rigoletto (Streich, Klose, Schock, Metternich/Fricsay)**** 1961 Don Giovanni in German DVD: Mozart: Don Giovanni [DVD] [2011] [NTSC]

[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]The CBS Bernstein/NYPO Mahler cycle on CD,Four different remasterings:-- 1) 1980s: Full-price CBS CDs = individual CDs, not in a box.-- 2) 1992: "Royal Edition" = individual CDs, not in a box.I don't know who did the remastering.-- 3) 2001: "Bernstein Century Edition" = individual CDs, also released in a box:  Mahler: The Complete Symphonies ~ Bernstein,remastering engineers: Charles Harbutt, Ellen Fitton, Miguel Kertsman, maybe others.-- 4a) 2009: "Carnegie Hall Presents" - Mahler:  Complete Symphonies (Carnegie Hall Presents),remastered by Andreas K. Meyer-- 4b) 2012: The box under discussion,this is an "original jacket" reissue of the 2009 remastering by Andreas K. Meyer.Critical consensus is that the Andreas K. Meyer remastering (24-bit/96kHz) is an enormous improvement over the first three.It was originally prepared for SACD release, but those Japanese SACDs are very expensive- in the Amazon search bar look up "Bernstein Mahler SACD"Meyer's CD remastering is available in version 4a or 4b.There is a slight difference in contents:-- 4a) The 2009 "Carnegie Hall Presents" version included the audio documentary "Gustav Mahler Remembered" and  Das Lied von der Erde.-- 4b) The 2013 box (reviewed on this page) omitted those two, but added Janet Baker's 1975 Kindertotenlieder.Advantage 4a (2009) = "Gustav Mahler Remembered" (48 minutes) is a very well-done documentary (a 22 minute version can be found in the Kaplan Mahler Edition - see below).Alternatively, the 48 minute version is also on YouTube.See my comment dated July 13, 2015 for the web link.(Meyer's CD remastering of Das Lied von der Erde is available separately at low cost.)Advantage 4b (2013) = Less expensive, and packaged in "original jacket" format for the first time.Attractive and nostalgic for geezers like me.(plus Meyer's remastering of Janet Baker's 1975 Kindertotenlieder is very expensive outside of box 4b.)Disadvantage 4b (2013) = No texts or translations for Symphonies 2, 3 and 8 in the 32 page booklet (the "Carnegie Hall Edition" has them).This may not matter for experienced Mahler collectors.Texts and translations for Symphony 4 and Kindertotenlieder are on the back of the "original jacket" in fine print (Kindertotenlieder is on the jacket for Symphony 5).The additional works are available separately:-- "Gustav Mahler Remembered"Documentary by William Malloch.There is a 22 minute version of this documentary in: The Kaplan Mahler Edition: Symphony No. 2 in C minor- ResurrectionIf you don't already have it, The Kaplan Mahler Edition is an indispensible purchase (cheap too).Not just for the performances, but for all the extra stuff that comes with it.The 48 minute version is on YouTube. See my comment dated July 13, 2015 for the web link.The absolutely unabridged version of "Gustav Mahler Remembered" is 106 minutes, 28 seconds - inNew York Philharmonic: The Mahler Broadcasts 1948-1982 .-- The Andreas K. Meyer remastering of Das Lied von der Erde was reissued in 2010 as an inexpensive single CD:Mahler: Das Lied Von Der Erde-- Meyer's remastering of Janet Baker's 1975 Kindertotenlieder on SACD: Mahler: Symphony No.10-Adagio & Kinde (expensive)P.S. Andreas K. Meyer is not finished working his remastering magic on Bernstein's CBS legacy.He is also responsible for the new Bernstein Sibelius edition:Bernstein Sibelius - Remastered

Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli's recorded legacy is a mess.Warner should at least have assembled the material in chronological order so we could trace Michelangeli's development.As it stands, everything was thrown together haphazardly.Also, the booklet is a disgrace.Just a three-page essay entitled "Il Gattopardo" (The Leopard) + a lot of photographs of the pianist looking molto suave.The "Warner Recordings" come from four main sources:- Italian EMI and German Telefunken recordings made in Italy during World War Two (yes, the bad guys)- EMI recordings 1948-1975.- The March 4, 1957 Royal Festival Hall recital previously issued on Testament.- Italian Radio broadcasts 1959-1963, once issued on the Fonit-Cetra label.Three-and-a-half CDs of early Michelangeli (1939-1943), age 19-23Eight-and-a-half CDs of prime Michelangeli (1948-1963), age 28-43Two CDs of late(ish) Michelangeli (1972-1975), age 52-55Chronologically assembled, this would be: CD 1, 2, 9, 10, 3, 4, 5, 6, 11, 12, 13, 14, 7, 8For detailed contents of each disc, see the photo of the back of the box at the top of Amazon's webpage.Part One - Wartime recordingsCDs 1,2 - Italian EMI 78rpm recordings (1939-1942) on "La Voce del Padrone" - "His Master's Voice"CDs 9,10 - Telefunken 78rpm recordings (1942-1943)Recorded in Fascist Italy under wartime conditions.Mostly encore pieces by Albeniz, Chopin, Granados, Grieg, Marescotti (1902-1995), Mompou, Scarlatti & Tomeoni (1729-1816),but also Bach's Italian Concerto and Beethoven's Piano Sonata Op.2 No.3,plus Piano Concertos by Grieg and Schumann with the La Scala Orchestra conducted by Alceo Galliera (contrary to Warner, Antonio Pedrotti is usually credited as conductor of the Schumann).The sound quality is only fair (the Schumann Concerto is terrible)The wartime recordings have also been issued on three Naxos CDs with scholarly notes and in cleaner sound.See the footnote at the end of this review. *Part Two - CDs 1,2,3 - EMI Mono recordings (1948-1953)In 1948 Michelangeli traveled to London's Abbey Road Studio where he recorded the Bach-Busoni Chaconne (CD 1) and his own version of Brahms Paganini Variations (CD 2).(he omitted a few variations and re-ordered the rest)He also recorded Galuppi (CD 1) and Debussy (CD 2) in London at this time - Warner is mistaken about the dates. *In 1951 and 1953, he recorded three Mozart Piano Concertos for the Italian branch of EMI (K 415 in C, K 450 in B-flat and K 488 in A) conducted by Franco Caracciolo and Ettore Gracis (CD 3)Decent mono sound.Part Three - CDs 4,5 - The Royal Festival Hall recital from March 4, 1957This is Michelangeli at his absolute best.Acceptable mono sound.Includes thirty minutes of rehearsals and "sound checks" - a lot of noodling around at the keyboard (Debussy and Schumann)  plus barely audible conversations with no printed text (or translation for the Italian segments).Previously issued on Testament. **Part Four - EMI Stereo recordings (1957, 1972-1975)The only stereo recordings in this box.CD 6 has the famous 1957 recording of Rachmaninov's 4th and Ravel's Piano Concerto with Ettore Gracis and the Philharmonia Orchestra.CD 7 has the 1975 recording of two Haydn Concertos conducted by Edmond de Stoutz.CD 8 is an all-Schumann LP recorded in 1975: Carnaval (played a lot more slowly than at the Festival Hall in 1957) + three excerpts from Album fur die Jugend.Plus released for the first time is an incomplete 1972 recording of Schumann's Faschingschwank aus Wien (first 3 of 5 movements - he played the complete work in 1957).Part Five - Italian Radio broadcasts in mono soundCDs 11,12 Concertos:- Haydn Piano Concerto 11 conducted by Mario Rossi (1959)- Beethoven Piano Concerto 5 "Emperor" conducted by Massimo Freccia (1960)- Liszt Piano Concerto 1 conducted by Raphael Kubelik (1961)- Schumann Piano Concerto conducted by Gianandrea Gavazzeni (1962)CD 13: Debussy recital (1963)CD 14: Chopin recital (1963)--- Next to Sviatoslav Richter, Michelangeli is the most bootlegged pianist in history.But unlike Richter, who had an enormous repertoire, Michelangeli obsessively concentrated on a few works that he polished to perfection.In the '70s and '80s - according to his critics - it was a sterile perfectionism, but the live recordings in this box, from the '50s and '60s, capture the pianist at his very best(only two CDs were recorded in the '70s).Michelangeli also cancelled more performances than any other pianist of his stature.Despite shyness and stage fright, he responded well to an audience - see the 1957 Royal Festival Hall recital in the Warner box.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]--- By the time Michelangeli made his final recording for EMI in 1975, he had already signed a new contract with Deutsche Grammophon.This produced eight CDs worth of recordings between 1971 and 1990: The Art Of Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli (DG Collectors Edition)For some reason, the DG box also included two Schumann performances recorded in the BBC studios in 1957, concurrent with Michelangeli's appearance at the Royal Festival Hall.The live 1957 performances of Carnaval and Faschingschwank aus Wien in the Warner box are more spontaneous than the BBC studio recordings in the DG box.And both are a great deal more spontaneous than the 1975 EMI studio recordings.The overall sound quality in the DG box is a lot better than the EMI/Warner box, and Michelangeli added some new works to his repertoire.Plus the DG box was assembled with more thought than the Warner mish-mash.Despite this, there is still good reason to buy the Warner box.The young Michelangeli was a force of nature.In his fifties, he tended to become more introspective and metaphysically inclined (OK, slower).Not coincidentally, his favorite concerto accompanists in the Seventies and Eighties were Carlo Maria Giulini (documented in the DG box) and Sergiu Celibidache (MICHELANGELI IN CONCERT - and - チェリビダッケ+ミケランジェリ共演集 ラヴェル、シューマン:ピアノ協... )Aside from the new Schumann excerpts on CD 8, nothing was newly remastered for this box.The ten year-old Great Recordings of the Century remasterings were used for the EMI material.The World War II and Fonit-Cetra transfers date back at least twenty years.Recommended despite its faults.-------------------------------------------------* Naxos squeezed the wartime recordings + the 1948 EMI recordings onto three CDs versus four in the Warner box (CD 1,2,9,10).Contents are identical, but Naxos' scholarship is infinitely better than Warners'.Naxos also benefits from superior transfers by Ward Marston.There is some disagreement about recording dates.Naxos claims that the Galuppi and Debussy on Warner's CD 1 and 2 were recorded in London in 1948.Warner claims Milan in 19?? (the question marks are Warner's).Naxos also provides the British EMI matrix numbers, so I am inclined to believe Naxos.Warner credits Alceo Galliera as the conductor of both the Grieg and Schumann Concertos in 1942.Naxos (and previous Telefunken reissues) credit Antonio Pedrotti in the Schumann.Naxos:-- Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli The Early Recordings 1939 - 1948 volume 1-- Michelangeli: Early Recordings 2 (Including Mozart: Piano Concerto No.15/ Beethoven: Piano Sonata No.3)  -- Grieg/ Schumann: Piano Concertos (Early Recordings Vol. 3) (Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli ) (Naxos Historical: 8111396)** First issue of the 1957 Royal Festival Hall recital on Testament: Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli: Schumann / Chopin / Debussy / MompDoes anyone know if the Testament booklet included a printed transcript of the conversation during the "sound check"?I can only make out about ten percent of the conversation on the CD.

The 1960's saw three important recordings of Mozart's "Magic Flute"- 1964: Karl Bohm, Berlin Philharmonic (DG)- 1964: Otto Klemperer, Philharmonia Orchestra (EMI)- 1969: Georg Solti, Vienna Philharmonic (Decca) - there is no recording date listed in the booklet. The arkivmusic.com website claims October, 1969.The Bohm and Klemperer are classics and have tended to overshadow the Solti (which was even overshadowed by a second Solti recording twenty years later).But I am rather fond of the 1969 Solti - not for the conductor, but for two of the singers (Solti is fine, but not in the same Mozartean league as Klemperer or Bohm).I judge the success of any performance of the "Magic Flute" based solely on two characters.I'm not interested in the plight of Tamino, Pamina or Sarastro- cardboard characters in the Masonic Ritual (though Otto Klemperer - my favorite conductor - excelled at this stuff).The Queen of the Night doesn't have a lot to do in this opera - just two arias and she's gone.Despite this, her two arias are sufficient in themselves to justify the price of a night at the Opera.They are spectacular.The obvious casting choice for the 1969 Decca recording would seem to have been Joan Sutherland.'La Stupenda' was the best-selling Coloratura Soprano in the world, and she and Solti were both under contract to Decca.A recording session would only take one day out of her busy schedule.A guaranteed best-seller for Decca.But it was not to be. *In her place, Decca cast a rising young Dutch soprano, Christina Deutekom.She had a novel approach to coloratura.Eager and uninhibited: it almost sounded like she was yodeling.I am not the first person to point this out.I remember reading it in one of the classical music magazines when this recording was new.That critic had reservations, but as a twenty year old with no preconceptions, I found it tremendously exciting.Still do.Its certainly worth a listen if you haven't heard it (unfortunately her career tapered off in the Seventies).Roberta Peters on the Bohm set is too careful - the opposite of Deutekom.Lucia Popp, the Queen of the Night in Klemperer's recording, was the most acclaimed modern singer of the role in the final third of the Twentieth Century.No complaints here (though I sometimes miss Deutekom's craziness).Papageno is the only character I have an emotional investment in.The three leading German baritones of the 1960s:- Walter Berry: Papageno in the Klemperer recording. Too cold- Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau: Papageno in the Bohm recording. Too hot.- Hermann Prey: Papageno in the Solti recording. Just right.My apologies to Mother Goose.Walter Berry had a great voice, but his interpretation is too generic.Hermann Prey had a great voice and the perfect personality for the role.Prey always struck me as being more naturally boyish than other baritones.This meant he wasn't good at playing villains, but was perfect for Papageno,and he's a good reason to buy the Solti recording.If anything, Fischer-Dieskau had too much personality.His is an "interesting" performance.Klemperer has by far the best supporting cast, down to the smallest role (Elisabeth Schwarzkopf is the First Lady), though Bohm scores by casting Fritz Wunderlich as Tamino (I just wish Tamino wasn't such a stiff).One plus in the Solti set's favor is the decision to cast actual boys as the Three Boys.I think this was the first time anyone thought of it.A successful experiment (Vienna Choir Boys).The chorus is important in the Masonic Ritual.The Wilhelm Pitz-trained Philharmonia Chorus (Klemperer) is the best on record (Pitz spent his summers directing the chorus at Bayreuth).Scorecard:Conductor = 1) Klemperer, 2) Bohm, 3) SoltiQueen of the Night = 1) Deutekom/Solti or Popp/Klemperer (depends on which I heard last), 3) Peters/BohmPapageno = 1) Prey/Solti, 2) Berry/Klemperer or Fischer-Dieskau/Bohm (tie)Supporting cast = 1) Klemperer, 2) Bohm, 3) SoltiThree Boys = 1) Solti, 2) Klemperer, 3) BohmChorus = 1) Klemperer, 2) Bohm or Solti (tie)Wild Card: Klemperer omits the dialog.This was an EMI tradition - the 1950 Karajan also omitted dialog.Bohm and Solti (and everyone since) include a lot of dialog.I may be a Philistine, but I hate dialog in opera.Once you know what the plot is about, Emanuel Shikaneder's prose just slows everything down.Phooey.So which to get? - 1) Klemperer and Solti (tie), 3) Bohm.Better yet buy all three - they're on budget labels.- Klemperer 1964: Mozart: Die Zauberflöte - or - Mozart: Die Zauberflote (Home of Opera) - or - Mozart: Le Nozze Di Figaro/Don Giovanni/...- Bohm 1964: Mozart: The Magic Flute* Joan Sutherland left us only one recording of the Magic Flute, a live Covent Garden performance available on Testament:  Mozart: Die Zauberflote

The private eyes in "I Love a Mystery" are a pretty bland lot compared to Boston Blackie or the Lone Wolf, but I am a sucker for all B-Movie Detective series.And I love a mystery.Back in the 1940s, Columbia Pictures produced overlapping B-Movie Detective series.The studio was competing with itself:-- The Lone Wolf: fifteen films 1935 to 1949 - nine starring Warren William-- Boston Blackie: fourteen films 1941 to 1949 - starring Chester Morris-- Crime Doctor: ten films 1943 to 1949 - starring Warner Baxter-- The Whistler: eight films 1944 to 1948 - seven starring Richard Dix-- I Love a Mystery: three films 1945 to 1946 - starring Jim Bannon and Barton YarboroughWarren William, Chester Morris, Warner Baxter and Richard Dix had been Hollywood stars in the early Thirties.But their careers were clearly on a downward trajectory by the time they signed with Columbia.In contrast, the stars of "I Love a Mystery" - Jim Bannon and Barton Yarborough - were anonymous radio actors whose film careers were virtually non-existent outside of these three films."I Love a Mystery" was a detective serial on radio from 1939 to 1944.Jack, Doc and Reggie were three soldiers of fortune who joined forces to form the A-1 Detective Agency.Their slogan was "No job too tough, No adventure too baffling".Unfortunately, the actor who played Reggie committed suicide in 1942, but Jack and Doc carried on without him.The screenplays are pretty intricate, with a strong element of the gothic and supernatural - In the first two films, the victim is beheaded; the third film is a haunted house mystery.I imagine these scripts would have worked equally well for any of the other detectives on Columbia's roster.Three films, each slightly longer than an hour, on one disc.Picture quality is only fair, but the sound is good.DVD-R, but it played fine.No subtitles.As an unadvertised bonus, OnesMedia enclosed a copy of a 1973 "I Love a Mystery" made-for-TV movie.Horrible.Former ABC newsman Les Crane was cast as Jack.Future ABC newsman David Hartman (first host of Good Morning America) was cast as Doc.Also Ida Lupino and Don Knotts.Grotesque.For the OnesMedia website, see my comment dated July 8, 2015.-------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as A-Movies, but ended up as B-Movies (Philo Vance began at Paramount and ended up at PRC)PART ONE: REFORMED CRIMINALS TURNED PRIVATE EYE- Boston Blackie, the Lone Wolf and the Saint are reformed jewel thieves. Still viewed with suspicion by the police.- The Falcon has a shady past (never quite explained).- Arsene Lupin is an unreformed jewel thief who sometimes helps the police if it serves his ends.- The Crime Doctor used to be an Organized Crime Boss. He never actually reformed, but was conked over the head and woke up with amnesia.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.If there is ever a problem with a OnesMedia link, go directly to their website - see my comment dated July 8, 2015]BOSTON BLACKIE: BOSTON BLACKIE FILM COLLECTION - 14 MOVIES - 7 DVD-RCRIME DOCTOR:Cut and paste in the Amazon search bar: *ASIN:B00T83TLTQTHE FALCON:--- George Sanders: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 1 (3 Discs)--- Tom Conway: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 2THE LONE WOLF: THE LONE WOLF FILM COLLECTION - 15 MOVIES - 8 DVD-RTHE SAINT:--- George Sanders: The George Sanders Saint Movie Collection (2 Disc)--- Hugh Sinclair: The Saint's Vacation / The Saint Meets the Tiger: The Saint Double FeatureARSENE LUPIN:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00KB49ME0-----------------------------------------------------PART TWO: PRIVATE EYES WITHOUT A CRIMINAL PASTPerry Mason is a also a lawyer, but we'll overlook that.BULLDOG DRUMMOND:--- 10 films, 1929-1938: BULLDOG DRUMMOND Volume 1 - 7 DVD-R - 10 FILMS---- 8 films, 1939-1951: Not yet released.NICK CARTER:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00CDV4OECPERRY MASON: Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Bros. Movies Collection[Warren William starred in 4 of the 6 films.]MICHAEL SHAYNE:Volume One was issued way back in 2007. Still waiting for Volume Two.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B000LC4ZDKPHILO VANCE:--- 7 films, 1929-1947: PHILO VANCE FILM RARITIES COLLECTION - 7 DVD-R - 7 MOVIES (OnesMedia)--- 6 films, 1930-1940: The Philo Vance Murder Case Collection (Warner Archive)You need both for a complete collection - there is no overlap.I LOVE A MYSTERYThree films, 1945-1946 starring Jim Bannon and Barton YarboroughThe last but least of the B-Movie Detective series.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B010J9O0M0PHILIP MARLOWE / SAM SPADEThese two detectives were the most famous Private Eyes of all time, but they don't really belong on this list.They were A-Movie detectives all the way:- 1931 The Maltese Falcon: Ricardo Cortez as Sam Spade- 1936 Satan Met a Lady: Warren William as Sam Spade - adapted from 'The Maltese Falcon' by Dashiell Hammett- 1941 The Maltese Falcon: Humphrey Bogart as Sam Spade- 1944 Murder, My Sweet: Dick Powell as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'Farewell, My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler- 1946 The Big Sleep: Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 Lady in the Lake: Robert Montgomery as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 The Brasher Doubloon: George Montgomery as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'The High Window" by Raymond ChandlerBut two Philip Marlowe novels were adapted as B-Movies for other detectives:- 1942 Time to Kill (Lloyd Nolan as Michael Shayne) - adaptated from 'The High Window' by Raymond Chandler- 1942 The Falcon Takes Over (George Sanders as The Falcon)) - adapted from 'Farewell My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler--------------------------------------------------------PART THREE: UNCONVENTIONAL B-MOVIE DETECTIVES from the '30s and '40s - see my Comment dated July 8, 2015.Also directions to the OnesMedia website.* Amazon only permits ten links per review, so I had to use ASIN numbers for the rest (Amazon Stock Index Numbers)

A unique collection of orchestral Brahms unavailable anywhere else.This 3 CD set is also available as a single Blu-Ray Audio Disc with 44 tracks (3 hours, 54 minutes playing time).It's not uncommon to find ordinary CDs remastered at "24-bit/96 kHz", but the CD medium is incapable of accurately reproducing everything on the master.Compromises are made in the conversion to CD.You need SACD or Blu-Ray Audio to realize the full potential of the original master tape.The only real advantage of Blu-Ray Audio over the older SACD technology is a longer playing time.You don't need a special Blu-Ray Audio player.Blu-Ray Audio plays on any Blu-Ray Video player.Keep the video output connected to your TV to read the disc menu.Connect the audio to your Hi-Fi system.Blu-Ray Audio: Brahms: The Symphonies [Blu-ray Audio]BUT first read my review  "IF IT WON'T PLAY, THE FAULT IS NOT WITH YOUR PLAYER" dated July 3, 2015.(there was a mastering problem with the first batch of discs, but it has been corrected).

I can report that if this disc won't play, the fault is NOT with your Blu-Ray player.The first batch of Blu-Rays were faulty,but Decca re-mastered it to correct the problem.Unfortunately some defective discs are still on the market - as I found out.I have been the proud owner of both.From the packaging, there is no way to tell them apart (though the good one had a sticker marked "Made in France" on the cellophane).When you load the disc you will get one of two Menus.Each Menu splits the screen into two halves:-- on the left side of the BAD MENU is the photo of Ricardo Chailly from the cover.Underneath it are the words:"PURE AUDIO FORMAT"-- on the left of the GOOD MENU is the same photo of Ricardo Chailly.Underneath it are the words"PURE AUDIO FORMAT""2.0 pcm 24-bit/96Khz / 2.0 dolby trueHD 24-bit/96Khz"-- on the right side of the BAD MENU are the words "Johannes Brahms 1833-1897".Underneath it is a blank screen.-- on the right of the GOOD MENU are the words "Johannes Brahms 1833-1897".Underneath it are the words:"THE SYMPHONIES - ORCHESTRAL WORKS""Symphony No.1 in C minor, op.62""Symphony No.2 in D major, op.73""Symphony No.3 in F major, op.90""Symphony No.4 in E minor, op.98""Orchestral works"It's not uncommon to find ordinary CDs remastered at "24-bit/96 kHz", but the CD medium is incapable of accurately reproducing everything on the master.Compromises are made in the conversion to CD.You need SACD or Blu-Ray Audio to realize the full potential of the original master tape.The only real advantage Blu-Ray Audio has over the older SACD technology is a longer playing time - The Chailly Brahms Blu-Ray plays for 3 hours, 54 minutes.My only complaint about the Blu-Ray is that it is two channels.An alternate 5.1 Surround mix would have been nice.Perhaps Chailly is a purist.You don't need a special Blu-Ray Audio player.Blu-Ray Audio plays on any Blu-Ray Video player.Keep the video output connected to your TV to read the disc menu.Connect the audio to your Hi-Fi system.------------------------------------------------------Riccardo Chailly is the only conductor to have recorded ALL of Brahms' orchestral music.The Four Symphonies, two Overtures and Variations on a Theme of Haydn have been recorded hundreds of times.To these Chailly has added some RARITIES:-- Liebeslieder Waltzes Op.52, No.1,2,4,5,6,8,9,11 and Op.65, No.9In 1868, Brahms composed 18 waltzes for vocal quartet accompanied by piano four-hands.The following year he orchestrated nine (for orchestra alone - no singers).Also recorded by Gary Bertini/Vienna Symphony and Thomas Dausgaard/Swedish Chamber Orchestra.-- Two Intermezzi for Piano: Op.116, No.4 and Op.117, No.1 - ONLY RECORDINGThis is a ringer - Not orchestrated by Brahms.Orchestrated by Paul Klengel (1854-1935), a German conductor and composer who was a friend of Brahms(the notes don't say when Klengel orchestrated them, or if Brahms approved).-- Symphony 1: Original version of the Second MovementThis version of the second movement Andante premiered in 1876 with the rest of the Symphony, but before publication Brahms dropped five bars and added some transition material.This is the second recording of the original version - Charles Mackerras was first, with the Scottish Chamber Orchestra.-- Symphony 4: Revised opening to the First Movement - ONLY RECORDINGSome time after the premiere, Brahms added four bars to the opening of the First Movement, but quickly changed his mind.The Symphony was never performed this way.These introductory bars are over in a mere eight seconds, but Decca allots it 46 seconds.Brahms based his introduction on the final bars of the same movement, so the first movement now begins and ends with the same music.To illustrate this, the track opens with the final bars of the First Movement (13 seconds),then after a brief pause, you hear the new introduction (8 seconds) leading directly into the familiar First Movement (which fades away after 15 seconds).I don't much care for it, but may feel differently after I've heard it a few hundred times.I think it would have made a better impression if Decca had included two complete performances of the first movement - with and without the introduction - instead of just a fragment for the revised opening.This is the only recording of the revised opening of Symphony 4.I am informed that back in the 1960s, it was featured during the intermission of a Cleveland Orchestra radio broadcast.Apparently George Szell was interviewed and the orchestra performed the music.I'm not sure if Szell or his assistant Louis Lane conducted.It would be nice to have as part of a future "George Szell Edition".-- Hungarian Dances No. 1, 3 and 10Not exactly rarities, but not usually included with the symphonies.Brahms composed 21 Hungarian Dances for piano duet in the 1860s, and orchestrated these three in 1874 (other composers orchestrated the rest)------------------------------------------------------Chailly also provides spirited performances of the Four Symphonies, two Overtures and Haydn Variations, but here the competition is fierce.My all-time stereo favorites are Otto Klemperer/Philharmonia Orchestra (recorded 1954-1957) and Bruno Walter/Columbia Symphony (recorded 1959-1960).I am a sucker for Nineteenth Century conductors conducting Nineteenth Century music.Otto Klemperer (born 1885) was twelve years old when Brahms died.Bruno Walter (born 1876) was 21.Both lived long enough to record Brahms in decent stereo.Klemperer is Grand and Majestic.Walter is Warm and Comforting.Klemperer: Otto Klemperer- Brahms: Symphonies / Overtures / Deutsches RequiemWalter: Bruno Walter conducts Brahms [Box Set]Chailly and the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra recorded Brahms two Serenades a year later.

The Nazis were infamous for banning music by Jewish and politically dissident composers and performers.This 10 CD box, imported from Germany, contains the original recordings that the Nazis found so offensive.176 individual recordings - Ninety percent recorded between 1930 and 1933, the final years of the German republic.Half of it is German popular music of the Twenties and early Thirties.The rest are classical selections, with a lot of Operetta crossover.The transfers from ancient 78rpm records are very well done.There is a 64 page booklet (32 pages in German, 32 in English) with detailed notes about the composers and performers.A bit disorganized, but with so much information this is inevitable.Some musicians (Marlene Dietrich, Comedian Harmonists, Friederich Hollaender) make as many as ten appearances each, but to save space they get only one biographical entry.A lot of cross-referencing and searching back and forth in the booklet.No texts or translations for the vocal works.They are sorely missed - especially in the cabaret songs, but this seems inevitable in a box of this scope and at this price.CD 1: CULTURAL BOLSHEVISM - DEGENERATE MUSIC "And the shark's teeth may be lethal"Political Theater by Kurt Weill, Friederich Hollaender, Hans Eisler, Ernst Krenek, and Mischa Spoliansky.The 1930 excerpts from Weill's "Dreigroschenoper" (Three Penny Opera) document the original cast (Lotte Lenya, Kurt Gerron) of a Twentieth Century masterpiece,plus Otto Klemperer's conducting of Kleine Dreigroschenmusik from 1931.Additional excerpts are available on other labels. *FOUR CDs OF CABARET AND POPULAR SONG:CD 2: CABARET, CHANSON "It's always the fault of the Jews"CD 3: LAX MORALS "The versatility of love"CD 4: TOTAL LICENCE "Falling in love again"CD 5: HIT SONGS AND FILMS "What y'doin with your Knee"-- "It's always the fault of the Jews" ("An allem sind die Juden schuld") - CD 2, track 1.Lyrics by Friederich Hollaender set to the Habanera from Bizet's Carmen (rec. 1932) - Truly Bizarre.The next to last line sounds like "und Herr Einstein ging vorbei" which I think means "and Mr. Einstein goes away".I would dearly love to find a translation of whole song.-- "What y'doin with your Knee" ("Was machst du mit dem knie, lieber Hans?")  - CD 5, track 1.A translation of this could also be interesting.CD 6: OPERETTA "You are my heart's delight"CD 7: OPERETTA "There is a land of fancy"This was the "Silver Age" of Operetta: Benatzky, Fall, Kalman, Lehar, Stolz, and Oscar Straus, plus some "Golden Age" stuff from Johann Strauss.-- Emmerich Kalman and Oscar Straus were Jews who left Germany (Leo Fall was Jewish, but he died in 1925). Their works were blacklisted.-- Johann Strauss had Jewish ancestry, but rather than blacklist him, the Nazis forged documents covering this up.-- Franz Lehar was married to a Jewess (this term is used in the booklet) and his preferred interpreters were Jewish.Lucky for him, he was also Hitler's favorite composer.-- Unexpected delight: All this German schmaltz is interrupted by Otto Klemperer's joyous romp through Offenbach's La Belle Helene Overture (CD 6, track 6), recorded in 1929.If nothing else, Otto Klemperer is the most interesting conductor of the Twentieth Century. **CD 8: OPERA "Ah, I sense that it has vanished"CD 9: OPERA "I know a violent race"New York's Metropolitan Opera was the unintended beneficiary of Hitler's persecution of Jewish singers.Most of these 78rpm records will be familiar to collectors.Jewish composers were also blacklisted: Meyerbeer from the Nineteenth Century, Erich Wolfgang Korngold from the Twentieth (his ultimate destination was Hollywood)Everything is sung in German: "Der Bajazzo" = "Pagliacci"CD 10: CONCERT "On wings of song into exile"Classical music performed by exiles - most of this has already been released on other labels:Mahler conducted by Bruno Walter and Jascha Horenstein, plus Paul Hindemith, Erich Kleiber, Artur Schnabel, Fritz Kreisler, Adolf and Fritz Busch etc.Even Robert Schumann's 1840 setting of Dichterliebe was banned because the poet Heine was Jewish.-- Confession: I normally go to great lengths to avoid listening to German Cabaret Songs,but I'm glad I bought this collection.Depressing at times, but educational.Recommended to students of history and music alike.And its doesn't cost a lot.----------------------------------------------------------* Here is the fullest selection of the 1930 Dreigroschenoper excerpts recorded by Telefunken:Weill: The Threepenny Opera - Berlin 1930 - orDie Dreigroschenoper (The Threepenny Opera);
