Berlin 1930(contents are identical, and both versions include texts and translations).Lotte Lenya re-recorded Die Dreigroschenoper in stereo in the late '50s.But by then her voice had lost it's girlish soprano, and had evolved into a manly contralto (too many cigarettes):  Weill: The Threepenny Opera (Die Dreigroschenoper)[ She also played SMERSH agent Rosa Kleb in the second James Bond film "From Russia with Love" (1962). ]** Otto Klemperer's (born 1885) career lasted until 1971, well into the stereo era.He re-recorded Kurt Weill's Kleine Dreigroschenmusick in stereo in 1961: 20th Century MusicEvery bit as decadent as his 1931 recording.

This box contains most of the recordings that Karl Bohm made for Deutsche Grammophon during the last decade of his life - mostly with the Vienna Philharmonic.Missing are the 1970's sets of Beethoven and Brahms Symphonies.Plus DG forgot their pairing of "Peter and the Wolf" with "Carnival of the Animals". *23 CDs in cardboard jackets, but not original jacket format - DG designed new covers for each cardboard jacket, with a different photo of Bohm on each.Really quite attractive design.The back covers are used for track listings - no mini-program notes.Plus a 60 page booklet (with texts and translations for the Beethoven and Mozart choral works).The 1980 recordings of Beethoven's 9th and Tchaikovsky's 5th were the 86 year-old conductor's final recordings, and are the only DDD recordings in this box.There is absolutely no information about the mastering of these discs.Just a copyright date of 2015.Everything sounds fine to me, but I may not be the best judge. My ears are 66 years old.-----------------------------------------------------One surprise:The booklet states that"When Fritz Reiner stepped down as principal conductor of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, he expressed the desire that Karl Bohm - a kindred spirit thanks to their shared love of Richard Strauss - should succeed, but the orchestra chose Jean Martinon instead."I was 90 percent certain that this was in error.Hard to believe that Fritz Reiner, a Hungarian Jew, was an admirer of Karl Bohm.Bohm was never a Nazi, though like all German musicians of a certain age, he was tainted by the circumstances he found himself in during the Nazi period.(Norman Lebrecht was not so kind in his evaluation of Bohm.)I wondered if the author (Christoph Schluren) hadn't confused Karl Bohm with Hans Rosbaud, a frequent and well-loved guest conductor of the Chicago Symphony.I contacted Don Tait, formerly of radio station WFMT in Chicago, and expert on all things Chicago Symphony.His reply:"Yes ...in 1955 while Reiner was in Vienna to conduct the Vienna State Opera during the opening festivities of the rebuilt Opera House, [he invited Bohm to guest-conduct the Chicago Symphony].Reiner was in Vienna at the invitation of Bohm, who was the Opera's Music Director at the time.Bohm's Chicago Symphony concerts were:January 3-4, 1957: Hindemith, Stravinsky, BeethovenJanuary 10-11, 1957: Mozart, Berg, R. StraussThe concerts were Bohm's North American conducting debut.Regarding Reiner's choice for a CSO successor ... Hans Rosbaud was a regular guest conductor of the CSO during the early 1960s, and I know from conversations with CSO members of the time, including principal trumpeter Adolph "Bud" Herseth, that the orchestra virtually worshipped him and wanted him to be Reiner's successor.When the orchestra's manager, Seymour Raven, told them during a rehearsal break that Reiner had resigned for reasons of health, Raven said that everyone wanted Rosbaud to follow but that Rosbaud too was seriously ill and that his health made such a step impossible ...The author of the program notes is correct that Reiner recommended Bohm as his CSO successor but that Martinon was chosen.I think it says something about Reiner's regard for Bohm as a conductor that he considered him the most qualified to continue his (Reiner's) extremely high conductorial standards."- Don Tait (June 21, 2015)I was about to accuse Christoph Schluren of sloppy research.My thanks to Mr. Tait for saving me from this embarrassment.----------------------------------------------------Karl Bohm always reminded me of Otto Klemperer, but without all the baggage.In addition to extreme physical disabilities, Otto Klemperer had a life-long struggle with mental illness.Bipolar Manic-Depressive at a time when no one had a clue how to treat it.Both conductors had the same pre-World War I training and musical instincts (Klemperer was born in 1885, Bohm in 1894)Klemperer in top form was unsurpassable, but you never knew what to expect on a given night.Bohm produced performances that were steady and reliably excellent.Karl Bohm was a great conductor.Otto Klemperer was a great conductor.But Otto Klemperer was the more interesting conductor.I miss the baggage.Anyway, this review is supposed to be about Karl Bohm.There is still a lot to be said for sanity.After World War II, Bohm shied away from musical politics (except for a brief unhappy stint at the Vienna State Opera), and preferred the life of a guest conductor.He was popular with fellow musicians - on good terms with both Karajan and Bernstein (their only mutual friend?)In 1971 Karl Bohm, age 77, turned most of his attentions to the Vienna Philharmonic,where he shared the podium (and Deutsche Grammophon) with Leonard Bernstein(always remembering that the Vienna Philharmonic has no principal conductor).The Dresden recordings in this set (Beethoven and Richard Strauss) are a nostalgic reunion with the orchestra he had conducted from 1934 til 1942.He also had a late-in-life connection with the London Symphony, which elected him their honorary President (Tchaikovsky Symphonies).-------------------------------------------------------CONTENTS:(Vienna Philharmonic 1971-1980 unless otherwise indicated)- Beethoven: Symphony 9 (Norman, Fassbaender, Domingo, Berry)- Beethoven: Overtures Egmont, Coriolanus, Prometheus (Vienna PO) + Fidelio, Leonore III (Dresden Staatskapelle, 1969)- Beethoven: Missa Solemnis (M.Price, Ludwig, Ochman, Talvela)- Bruckner: Symphonies 7, 8- Dvorak: Symphony 9- Haydn: Symphonies 88, 89, 90, 91, 92, Sinfonia Concertante- Mozart: Symphonies 29, 35, 38, 39, 40, 41- Mozart: Sinfonia Concertante k 297b- Mozart: Masonic Funeral Music k 477- Mozart: Eine kleine Nachtmusik k 525- Mozart: Requiem (Mathis, Hamari, Ochman, Ridderbusch)- Schubert: Symphonies 5, 8 (Vienna PO) + 9 (Dresden Staatskapelle, 1979)- Schumann: Symphony 4- Johann Strauss: Perpetuum Mobile, Polkas (Annen-Polka, Tritsch-Tratsch, Thunder & Lightning), Walzes (Blue Danube, Emperor, Roses from the South)- Richard Strauss: Ein Heldenleben- Tchaikovsky: Symphonies 4-6 (London Symphony, 1977-1980)- Wagner: Overtures and Preludes to Rienzi, Fliegende Hollander, Tannhauser, Lohengrin (Acts 1+3), Meistersinger, Parsifal, Tristan (Prelude & Liebestod)----------------------------------------------------* The missing recordings are available in other boxes:Beethoven: Symphonies (DG Collectors Edition)Brahms: 4 Symphonies; Haydn Variations (DG Collectors Edition)The Beethoven and Brahms Symphonies are also in Karl Bohm: Symphoniesalong with his Berlin Philharmonic sets of Mozart and Schubert.Excellent value for money.-- DG also forgot Bohm's Vienna coupling of "Peter and the Wolf" with "Carnival of the Animals"with German narration: Prokofiev - Peter Und Der Wolf, Saint-Saens - Carnival of the animalswith English narration: Peter & The Wolf-- also there was a series of Mozart Wind Concertos with soloists from the Vienna Philharmonic: Mozart: Wind Concertos and Serenades (DG Collectors Edition)-- Bohm and the Vienna Philharmonic (also Abbado and Jochum) recorded some Piano Concertos with Pollini: Maurizio Pollini - Concertos-- Also recommended: The 3 DVD box of Bohm conducting the Vienna Philharmonic in Mozart.Recorded contemporary with these audio CDs.Mozart: Symphonies 1,25,28,29,31,33,34,35,36,38,39,40,41I recently bought Maestro X's 2 DVD set of Brahms Symphonies on ebay.A frustrating experience - 2 hours of watching musicians pretend to play music to a pre-recorded soundtrack, with lots of close-ups of the Maestro.For relief, I turned to Bohm conducting the Mozart Symphonies: Actual Performances.The finale of the Jupiter Symphony is remarkably exciting coming from an 80 year-old.

[There is an error in Amazon's listing - this is not a 16 CD/DVD Combo - it is a 16 CD + 1 CD-R combo]The virtues of Decca's 1958-1965 recording of Wagner's Ring are well-known.Later stereo recordings have their advocates, but this is the standard against which all are judged.A classic, and pretty much beyond criticism.This is the third time this recording has been remastered for CD - and the second time this particular 2012 remastering has been issued on CD.Contemporary with this, a Blu-Ray remastering was also created.It has also been issued twice.Decca/Universal has issued the Solti Ring in six different packages, though only three CD remasterings are involved:[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]1) 1984 remastering: Wagner: Der Ring Des Nibelungen, Das Rheingold, Die Walkure, Siegfried, Gotterdammerung2) 1997 remastering: Wagner: Der Ring des Nibelungen (Ring Cycle)or 1997 remastering: Wagner: The Operas  (part of a 36 CD box of ten Wagner operas)3a) 2012 remastering on CD + Blu-Ray: Wagner: Der Ring des Nibelungen (Super Deluxe)3b) 2012 remastering on Blu-Ray only : Wagner: Der Ring des Nibelungen [Blu-ray Audio]3c) 2012 remastering on CD only: Wagner: Der Ring Des Nibelungen [16 CD/DVD Combo] reviewed on this pageSOUND QUALITY:The overall consensus view is that Version 3 (2012) is the best-sounding remastering.There are dissenters (read the other reviews).That being said however, there is not a great deal of difference between the three CD remasterings.But Version 3a also included a separate Blu-Ray Audio remastering: the entire Ring on one Blu-Ray (versus 14 CDs).Version 3b is the Blu-Ray, but no CDs.Version 3c is 14 CDs, but no Blu-Ray.It's not uncommon to find ordinary CDs remastered at "24-bit/96 kHz", but the CD medium is incapable of accurately reproducing everything on the master.Compromises are made in the conversion to CD.You need SACD or Blu-Ray Audio to realize the full potential of the original master tape.The only real advantage of Blu-Ray Audio over the older SACD technology is a longer playing time - The single Blu-Ray Audio disc of Solti's Ring plays for fifteen hours.You don't need a special Blu-Ray Audio player..Blu-Ray Audio plays on any Blu-Ray Video player.Keep the video output connected to your TV to read the disc menu.Connect the audio to your Hi-Fi system.The 14 standard CDs sound fine.Blu-Ray Audio is almost certainly an improvement, but it's hard for me to judge.My landlord won't allow concert hall realism in his building.Playing Blu-Ray Audio with the volume turned down is self-defeating.CD RECOMMENDATION:If you want Solti's Ring on CD, you have a choice between Version 1, 2, 3a or 3c.Version 3c (reviewed on this page) is your best buy:Most critics prefer this CD remastering, plus it costs less than the others.+ Libretti and translations in CD-ROM format.+ 2 CDs devoted to Deryck Cooke's "Introduction to Der Ring Des Nibelungen".+ Excerpts from John Culshaw's 1967 book 'Ring Resounding'.If you have a lot of money and want the Deluxe Edition, buy Version 3a.The CD remastering is identical, plus you get a lot of extras (including the Blu-Ray, just in case you are curious).BLU-RAY RECOMMENDATIONIf you want Solti's Ring on Blu-Ray, you have a choice between Version 3a or 3b.Version 3a is the Deluxe CD + Blu-Ray Edition: 14 CDs + 1 Blu-Ray + 3 bonus CDs + 1 DVD+ Libretti and translations in book format.+ John Culshaw's 1967 book 'Ring Resounding'.+ 2 CDs devoted to Deryck Cooke's "Introduction to Der Ring Des Nibelungen".+ 1 DVD of "The Golden Ring", the 1965 behind-the-scenes BBC documentary about Decca's Ring project.+ 1 CD devoted to Solti's Vienna Philharmonic recordings of orchestral Wagner + "Kinderkatechismus"+ a selection of contemporary advertising material (32 pages) from Gramophone Magazine, recording session photos, and Solti's annotated score of The Ride of the Valkyries.Version 3b is the Basic Blu-Ray Edition: 1 Blu-Ray+ Libretti and translations in book format.If you are under age 50, I recommend you look into one of the Blu-Ray versions (3a or 3b).If you are over age 50, your hearing is not as good as it used to be, and 3c is good enough.One exception: I am 66 years old, but obsessive compulsive.I need to know that I am listening the best possible version even if I can't tell the difference.Aargh.Two drawbacks to Deluxe Edition 3a:1) It's expensive2) It's big and bulky - practically the same size and weight as the 1960s LP mega-box. It won't fit on my CD shelf, It barely fits on my bookshelf.EXTRAS:The "extras" included with Deluxe Edition 3a are all very nice, but if you are willing to do without the contemporary advertising material, photos, and Solti's annotated score of The Ride of the Valkyries, you can get the really important "extras" for very little money.Save money by buying Version 3b (blu-ray) or 3c (CD), and add the extras you want:1) John Culshaw's book 'Ring Resounding' is available in hardcover and paperback for under $10. I especially recommend the Time-Life version (available singly and in a slipcase with other books about Wagner). It comes with a lot of extra  photographs.2) Two-CD set of Deryck Cooke's An Introduction To Der Ring Des Nibelungen (2 CD) (already included with Version 3c - reviewed on this page)3) DVD of The Golden Ring - Solti's nickname in the 1960s was "the Screaming Skull" - watch this DVD to find out why.4) Solti's 1962-65 Vienna Philharmonic recordings of Wagner: Overtures / Siegfried Idyll5) Wagner's "Kinderkatechismus" which may or may not be conducted by Solti: Wagner: Overtures & Preludessee my review of this dated May 27, 2015 for more information about "Kinderkatechismus",and who I think the conductor really is.COST:As of May 2015, these are the lowest prices on Amazon:Version 3a = $206  (CD + Blu-Ray Deluxe Edition)Version 3b = $55  (Blu-Ray Basic Edition)Version 3c = $36  (CD Basic Edition)----------------------------------------------------------Decca's English translation of Kinderkhatechismus:SOLO: Tell me, children, what is it blossoms in May?CHILDREN'S CHORUS: The rose, the rose, the rose in May.SOLO: Do you know, too, what blossoms at Christmas?CHILDREN'S CHORUS: The cosy, the cosy, the cosy Mama Cosima!SOLO: If the rose of May has faded, it blossoms anew in the bosom of Christmas.CHILDREN'S CHORUS: Rose in May, cosy in May, dearest loveliest Cosima!Yecch.

Eight actors played Philo Vance in thirteen films between 1929 and 1947.All thirteen are now available in two boxes.The Warner Archive box  has the three films produced by Warner Brothers, plus three by MGM.The  OnesMedia box has four films produced by Paramount, plus three B-Movies from Producers Releasing Corporation (PRC).If you want all thirteen Philo Vance movies, you need to buy both boxes.There is no overlap.The GRACIE ALLEN MURDER CASE  was a Paramount poduction and is in the OnesMedia box.It has seven films for about the price of two DVDs.The OnesMedia box is here: PHILO VANCE FILM RARITIES COLLECTION - 7 DVD-R - 7 MOVIESThe Warner Archive box is here: The Philo Vance Murder Case Collection

Philo Vance was the first private detective of the sound era.He appeared in thirteen films between 1929 and 1947.Four were produced by Paramount, three by Warner Brothers, three by MGM, and three by PRC (Producer's Releasing Corporation).[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.If there is ever a problem with a OnesMedia link, go directly to their website - see my comment dated July 8, 2015]The Paramount and PRC titles are in the OnesMedia box, reviewed on this page.For the OnesMedia website, see my comment dated July 8, 2015.The Warner  and MGM titles are in a box from Warner Archive: The Philo Vance Murder Case CollectionIf you want all thirteen Philo Vance movies, you need to buy both boxes.There is no overlap.Eight actors played Philo Vance:1) WILLIAM POWELL:The great William Powell (five years before he played detective Nick Charles in The Thin Man) was the first actor to play Philo Vance.The OnesMedia collection has his first three appearances in the role - the Warner box has his final effort:- 1929: THE CANARY MURDER CASE - Paramount (OnesMedia box)- 1929: THE GREENE MURDER CASE - Paramount (OnesMedia box)- 1930: THE BENSON MURDER CASE - Paramount (OnesMedia box)- 1933: THE KENNEL MURDER CASE - Warner Bros. (Warner Archive box)The first three are extremely difficult to find.Picture quality is not great, but I could understand 98% of the dialogue, which is rare in early talkies.These are not great films, but they are historically important.The CANARY MURDER CASE started out as a silent film in 1928, but Paramount decided to re-shoot several scenes with sound, and to dub sound onto existing footage.The result is awkward.Early sound technicians were worried that overlapping dialogue would confuse the audience, so actors were instructed to insert lengthy pauses between lines.Very slow going.Silent movie legend Louise Brooks is the murder victim in THE CANARY MURDER CASE.She was in Germany making silent films when Paramount cabled her to return to Hollywood to dub her scenes with sound.She refused.Her voice was dubbed by a different actress and Louise Brooks' Hollywood career was over.- Eugene Palette was comic relief as Sergeant Heath in all four films.- Future star Jean Arthur was a supporting player in the first two films.2) BASIL RATHBONE:- 1930: THE BISHOP MURDER CASE - MGM (in the Warner Archive box)The great Basil Rathbone (nine years before he played Sherlock Holmes) was the second actor to play Philo Vance.His portrayal is closer to the Philo Vance of the novels - not very flattering - basically an upper-class twit, but a very clever one.Technically, this 1930 MGM talkie is a considerable advance over the 1929-30 Paramount films.It has a surprising amount of outdoor filming, including an automobile ride which appears to have been filmed on the back of a flatbed truck in actual traffic.3) WARREN WILLIAM:- 1934: THE DRAGON MURDER CASE - Warner Bros. (Warner Archive box)- 1939: THE GRACIE ALLEN MURDER CASE - Paramount (OnesMedia box)The great - I think he's great - Warren William was the third actor to play Philo Vance.He's one of my all-time favorite actors, but I'll admit that he is an acquired taste.Warren William had a remarkable face -He looked like Satan - which should have stereotyped him as a screen villain, but his personality and sense of humor overcame this obvious handicap.This Philo Vance is not as serious as Powell or Rathbone, but he is devilish fun to watch.THE GRACIE ALLEN MURDER CASE is not a cheesy as it sounds.S.S. Van Dine actually wrote a novel with that title in 1938 (George Burns and Gracie Allen were friends of the author).Gracie Allen is wonderful - Warren William as Philo Vance basically takes over George Burns' role as Gracie's straight man.Warner Brothers also cast Warren William as Perry Mason in four films (starting in 1934).In 1939, he moved to Columbia and made the first of nine appearances as The Lone Wolf - basically playing the same character in all three series.All are available on DVD. See the GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVD at the end of this review.4-8) B-MOVIE ACTORS:Unlike the first three, these five actors never quite made it past supporting parts in A-Movies.But they were leading men in B-Movies:- 1935: Paul Lukas in THE CASINO MURDER CASE - MGM (Warner Archive box)- 1936: Edmund Lowe in THE GARDEN MURDER CASE - MGM (Warner Archive box)- 1940: James Stephenson in CALLING PHILO VANCE - Warner Bros. (Warner Archive box)- 1947: William Wright in PHILO VANCE RETURNS - P.R.C. (OnesMedia box)- 1947: Alan Curtis in PHILO VANCE'S GAMBLE - P.R.C. (OnesMedia box)- 1947: Alan Curtis in PHILO VANCE'S SECRET MISSION - P.R.C. (OnesMedia box)The B-Movie units at MGM and Warners made some quality low-budget films.P.R.C. (Producers Releasing Corporation) had a less exalted reputation (well-deserved), but their films are not without a certain charm.I just like B-Movies.EXTRA: OnesMedia includes an unsold TV pilot - PHILO VANCE, DETECTIVE - which turns out to be a severely edited (18:33) version of PHILO VANCE'S SECRET MISSION.LOST FILMS: There were two additional Philo Vance films from the 1930s that are not in either collection:- 1936: THE SCARAB MURDER CASE with Wilfrid Hyde-White as Philo Vance.No prints of this British production are known to exist. The British Film Institute has placed it on its 75 Most Wanted list of lost films.- 1937: NIGHT OF MYSTERY (Paramount) with Grant Richards as Philo Vance(remake of The Greene Murder Case).Not a lost film, but apparently the only print is in the Library of Congress, which doesn't regard restoration of this B-movie as a high priority.Does anyone have more information?--------------------------------------------------OnesMedia has produced the only available collection of seven rare Philo Vance movies, and is selling them at a very nice price.Seven DVDs in a CD-size plastic clamshell case with soft plastic sleeves (the same packaging this company uses for CDs of old radio shows).Picture quality ranges from pretty bad to pretty good, but OnesMedia did a heroic job of cleaning up the sound.No subtitles, but I wasn't expecting any at this price.These are DVD-Rs, but so is the Warner collection.I had no problems with playback.Finally, THERE IS NO COMPETITION.P.S. There was an early production problem: PHILO VANCE'S GAMBLE was missing the ending - it stopped mid-sentence at 49:35. The corrected version runs 1:01:07.I was an early buyer and found OnesMedia's customer service to be very helpful in supplying the corrected DVD.E-mail OnesMedia if you have any problems(for their web address, see my Comment dated July 8, 2015)------------------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as A-Movies, but ended up as B-Movies (Philo Vance began at Paramount and ended up at PRC)PART ONE: REFORMED CRIMINALS TURNED PRIVATE EYE- Boston Blackie, the Lone Wolf and the Saint are reformed jewel thieves. Still viewed with suspicion by the police.- The Falcon has a shady past (never quite explained).- Arsene Lupin is an unreformed jewel thief who sometimes helps the police if it serves his ends.- The Crime Doctor used to be an Organized Crime Boss. He never actually reformed, but was conked over the head and woke up with amnesia.BOSTON BLACKIE: BOSTON BLACKIE FILM COLLECTION - 14 MOVIES - 7 DVD-RCRIME DOCTOR: CRIME DOCTOR FILM COLLECTION - 5 DVD-R - 10 MOVIES - 1943-1949 with Warner BaxterTHE FALCON:--- George Sanders: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 1 (3 Discs)--- Tom Conway: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 2THE LONE WOLF: THE LONE WOLF FILM COLLECTION - 15 MOVIES - 8 DVD-RTHE SAINT:--- George Sanders: The George Sanders Saint Movie Collection (2 Disc)--- Hugh Sinclair: The Saint's Vacation / The Saint Meets the Tiger: The Saint Double FeatureARSENE LUPIN:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00KB49ME0-----------------------------------------------------PART TWO: PRIVATE EYES WITHOUT A CRIMINAL PASTPerry Mason is a also a lawyer, but we'll overlook that.BULLDOG DRUMMOND:--- 10 films, 1929-1938: BULLDOG DRUMMOND Volume 1 - 7 DVD-R - 10 FILMS---- 8 films, 1939-1951: Not yet released.NICK CARTER:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00CDV4OECPERRY MASON: Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Bros. Movies Collection[Warren William starred in 4 of the 6 films.]MICHAEL SHAYNE:Volume One was issued way back in 2007. Still waiting for Volume Two.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B000LC4ZDKPHILO VANCE: reviewed on this pageI LOVE A MYSTERYThree films, 1945-1946 starring Jim Bannon and Barton YarboroughThe last but least of the B-Movie Detective series.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B010J9O0M0PHILIP MARLOWE / SAM SPADEThese two detectives were the most famous Private Eyes of all time, but they don't really belong on this list.They were A-Movie detectives all the way:- 1931 The Maltese Falcon: Ricardo Cortez as Sam Spade- 1936 Satan Met a Lady: Warren William as Sam Spade - adapted from 'The Maltese Falcon' by Dashiell Hammett- 1941 The Maltese Falcon: Humphrey Bogart as Sam Spade- 1944 Murder, My Sweet: Dick Powell as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'Farewell, My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler- 1946 The Big Sleep: Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 Lady in the Lake: Robert Montgomery as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 The Brasher Doubloon: George Montgomery as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'The High Window" by Raymond ChandlerBut two Philip Marlowe novels were adapted as B-Movies for other detectives:- 1942 Time to Kill (Lloyd Nolan as Michael Shayne) - adapted from 'The High Window' by Raymond Chandler- 1942 The Falcon Takes Over (George Sanders as The Falcon)) - adapted from 'Farewell My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler--------------------------------------------------------PART THREE: UNCONVENTIONAL B-MOVIE DETECTIVES from the '30s and '40s - see my Comment dated July 8, 2015.Also directions to the OnesMedia website.* Amazon only permits ten links per review, so I had to use ASIN numbers for the rest (Amazon Stock Index Numbers)

OnesMedia is selling these films at a very nice price.Eight films on four DVD-Rs for $25.Picture quality ranges from OK to pretty good, but OnesMedia did a heroic job of cleaning up the sound.No subtitles, but I wasn't expecting any at this price.These are DVD-Rs, but I had no problem playing them.The Whistler is not really a B-Movie Detective.He's a mysterious character in a black cape who prowls in the shadows and narrates this series of B-Movies produced between 1944 and 1948.An observer of crime.Richard Dix starred in seven of the eight films, before ill-health forced him to retire.Dix didn't play the actual Whistler - the Whistler is anonymous and mysterious.Based on a popular radio show, samples of which are included on a bonus mp3.Since I wrote this review, "Choice Collection" has issued these films on eight DVD-Rs for $15 each. That works out toEight films on eight DVD-Rs for $120 vs Eight films on four DVD-Rs for $25 on OnesMedia..I haven't seen the "Choice Collection" DVD-Rs so I am not qualified to comment on them, other than to point out that they are rather pricey.Also, in my experience DVD-Rs do not have subtitlesThis statement is based on experience - Warner Archive Collection DVD-Rs do not have subtitles, even though many of the same films do when shown on TCM----------------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as A-Movies, but ended up as B-Movies (Philo Vance began at Paramount and ended up at PRC)PART ONE: REFORMED CRIMINALS TURNED PRIVATE EYE- Boston Blackie, the Lone Wolf and the Saint are reformed jewel thieves. Otto Klemperer's 1964 studio recording of The Magic Flute - with Lucia Popp as a spectacular Queen of the Night - was deservedly included in EMI's Great Recordings of the Century series,but here we have an earlier live performance with  a singer who should have been a spectacular Queen of the Night........................................... 1964 EMI .................. 1962 COVENT GARDENQueen of the Night ........... Lucia Popp ................... Joan SutherlandTamino .......................... Nicolai Gedda ................. Richard LewisPamina ......................... Gundula Janowitz .......... Joan CarlylePapageno ..................... Walter Berry ................... Geraint EvansPapagena .................... Ruth-Margaret Putz .......... Jennifer EddySarastro ........................ Gottlob Frick .................. David KellySpeaker ......................... Franz Crass .................. Hans HotterMonostatos ................... Gerhard Unger ................. Robert BowmanFirst Lady ................. Elisabeth Schwarzkopf ......... Judith PierceSecond Lady ................. Christa Ludwig ................ Josephine VeaseyThird Lady ..................... Marga Hoffgen ................ Monica SinclairFirst Boy ........................ Agnes Giebel ................. Margaret NevilleSecond Boy .................. Anna Reynolds ................ Ann Hood (of the D'Oyly Carte Opera)Third Boy ..................... Josephine Veasey ............ Marion RobertsIn January, 1962 Joan Sutherland sang Mozart's Queen of the Night for the only time in her career - in Covent Garden's new production.She never recorded the opera commercially for Decca.She would have seemed the obvious choice for Solti's 1969 recording, but Decca gave the role to Christina Deutekom(a controversial singer - I admire her Queen of the Night, but admit that what she does with the coloratura sounds awfully close to yodeling).Sung in German as Die Zauberflote.Prior to this production, Covent Garden had always performed the opera in English translation.Thirteen of the fourteen cast members were native English speakers, so this may not have been such a good idea.Contemporary British audiences and critics were not enthusiastic about the change.Otto Klemperer was recruited to conduct (and direct) the performance, but most of the excitement was about Joan Sutherland,a member of Covent Garden since 1952, who had burst onto international fame three years earlier as Lucia di Lammermoor, and was a very hot property indeed.Her only rival on the classical charts was Maria Callas.Of the supporting cast - Joan Carlyle, Monica Sinclair, Josephine Veasey, Geraint Evans and Richard Lewis all had respectable international careers, but their work was in the main confined to Great Britain.Josephine Veasey was the only singer who also took part in the EMI recording (she was demoted from Second Lady to Third Boy).The only singer in the Covent Garden performance who I would rate preferable to his EMI counterpart is Geraint Evans as Papageno (his only recording of the role).Nothing wrong with Walter Berry's singing, but Evans had the stronger personality- my favorite Papagenos are Erich Kunz in mono, and Hermann Prey in stereo.But this was very much Joan Sutherland's show.That being said, she was something of a disappointment.I was expecting to have chills running up and down my spine.But it never happened.Decent performance, but no fireworks.I could never understand this - until I read the booklet and discovered that Joan Sutherland insisted that her two arias be transposed down:- "O zittre nicht, mein lieber Sohn" by a semitone, and- "Der Hoille Rache kocht in meinem Herzen" by a whole tone.This definitely throws a wet blanket on the fireworks."La Stupenda" was famous for her high notes.Why would she duck the challenge in this most famous of all coloratura roles?The booklet offers no explanation.Was she not feeling well?Some psychological barrier?Why did she never record this opera in the controlled conditions of the studio?Decca would have had a best-seller on their hands.Aargh.English critics in 1962 blamed the relative failure of this performance on Klemperer's slow tempos (I don't find them all that slow) and on the decision to sing the opera in German.I think they were just making excuses for their hometown Diva.All that being conceded, this is still an essential purchase for all lovers of singing in the Twentieth Century.This is Joan Sutherland.These Testament CDs are the first authorized release of the BBC's original tape.The sound is mono, but pretty clear.The booklet offers an article and some photos, but no text or translation, not even a synopsis.Otto Klemperer's work is better appreciated on the the 1964 EMI recording with an all-star international cast(even in the smallest parts - Elisabeth Schwarzkopf was the First Lady).Recorded in beautiful Kingsway Hall stereo.That recording omitted the dialog, which some people objected to, but I don't miss it - Emanuel Shikaneder's prose is not great literature.Other recordings mentioned in this review:Klemperer 1964: Mozart: Die Zauberflöte - or - Mozart: Die Zauberflote (Home of Opera) - or - Mozart: Le Nozze Di Figaro/Don Giovanni/...Solti 1969: Mozart: Die Zauberflote (DECCA The Originals)- this has the complete dialogue (bah!)+ my all-time favorite Papageno in Hermann Prey+ Christina Deutekom's always interesting Queen of the Night.Even so, my favorite is still the 1964 EMI Klemperer studio recording(best conducting and overall cast - yielding to Solti only for Papageno + none of that tedious dialog)P.S. The photo on the cover looks like a scene from "Frankenstein Meets the Queen Mum"- except Frankenstein is wearing Dracula's wardrobe.Otto Klemperer basically had one facial expression - an intimidating scowl.When he tried to smile, he just looked weird.Not his fault - he underwent surgery for the removal of a brain tumor in 1939 which left him permanently disfigured and partially paralyzed for the last forty years of his life.This horrific sight had an effect on orchestras - they certainly paid attention.My all-time favorite conductor.

Criminal mastermind Phil Morgan is taken for a ride by his fellow crooks and his body is dumped by the roadside.But they failed to bump him off.Instead he hit his head and woke up with total amnesia.He is taken to the hospital where he is cared for by a brilliant psychiatrist.He resolves to go to medical school himself and become a psychiatrist.Years later, he emerges as Dr. Matthew Ordway, The World's Greatest Psychiatrist, who has devoted his life to the study of the criminal mind.Almost a super-hero, except he has no special powers outside of his intellect(though he is able to hypnotize weak-minded criminals).All  ten  B-Movies were produced by Columbia Pictures between 1943 and 1949, and starred one-time leading man Warner Baxter (42nd Street) as The Crime Doctor.Warner Baxter was a bit older than your average B-Movie private eye, and a lot less physical (his stunt double gets a workout), but I always enjoyed the clever writing of these films.The series has a preposterous premise, but it is very well-done.The seventh entry in the series, "Crime Doctor's Man-Hunt" (1946), has a brilliant surprise ending that took me completely by surprise.Great fun.OnesMedia has produced the only available collection of all ten Crime Doctor movies, and is selling them at a very nice price.Five DVDs in a CD-size plastic clamshell case with soft plastic sleeves (the same packaging this company uses for CDs of old radio shows).Picture quality ranges from OK to pretty good, but OnesMedia did a heroic job of cleaning up the sound.No subtitles, but I wasn't expecting any at this price.These are DVD-Rs, but I had no problem playing them.Finally, THERE IS NO COMPETITION.------------------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as thieves. Still viewed with suspicion by the police.- The Falcon has a shady past (never quite explained).- Arsene Lupin is an unreformed jewel thief who sometimes helps the police if it serves his ends.- The Crime Doctor used to be an Organized Crime Boss. Boston Blackie is a reformed jewel thief turned private detective.Chester Morris played Boston Blackie in fourteen Hollywood films between 1941 and 1949, all produced by Columbia Pictures.Basically a rip-off of The Saint, but great fun nonetheless.And Boston Blackie was not the only rip-off of the Saint in the 1940s - He was not even the only rip-off of the Saint produced by Columbia Pictures.I am a sucker for B-Movies about reformed jewel thieves turned private detectives:- George Sanders as the Saint (RKO Radio Pictures)- Warren William as The Lone Wolf (Columbia pictures)- Chester Morris as Boston Blackie (Columbia Pictures)Class Distinction:The Saint and The Lone Wolf were pretty much indistinguishable: Swanky upper-class reformed jewel thieves turned detectives.Boston Blackie was more of a Common Man reformed jewel thief turned private detective.OnesMedia has produced the only available collection of all fourteen Boston Blackie movies, and is selling them at a very nice price.Seven DVDs in a CD-size plastic clamshell case with soft plastic sleeves (the same packaging this company uses for CDs of old radio shows).Picture quality ranges from OK to pretty good, but OnesMedia did a heroic job of cleaning up the sound.No subtitles, but I wasn't expecting any at this price.These are DVD-Rs, but I had no problem playing them.Finally, THERE IS NO COMPETITION.For the OnesMedia website, see my comment dated July 8, 2015.------------------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as A-Movies, but ended up as B-Movies (Philo Vance began at Paramount and ended up at PRC)PART ONE: REFORMED CRIMINALS TURNED PRIVATE EYE- Boston Blackie, the Lone Wolf and the Saint are reformed jewel thieves. Still viewed with suspicion by the police.- The Falcon has a shady past (never quite explained).- Arsene Lupin is an unreformed jewel thief who sometimes helps the police if it serves his ends.- The Crime Doctor used to be an Organized Crime Boss. He never actually reformed, but was conked over the head and woke up with amnesia.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.If there is ever a problem with a OnesMedia link, go directly to their website - see my comment dated July 8, 2015]BOSTON BLACKIE: reviewed on this pageCRIME DOCTOR: CRIME DOCTOR FILM COLLECTION - 5 DVD-R - 10 MOVIES - 1943-1949 with Warner BaxterTHE FALCON:--- George Sanders: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 1 (3 Discs)--- Tom Conway: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 2THE LONE WOLF: THE LONE WOLF FILM COLLECTION - 15 MOVIES - 8 DVD-RTHE SAINT:--- George Sanders: The George Sanders Saint Movie Collection (2 Disc)--- Hugh Sinclair: The Saint's Vacation / The Saint Meets the Tiger: The Saint Double FeatureARSENE LUPIN:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00KB49ME0-----------------------------------------------------PART TWO: PRIVATE EYES WITHOUT A CRIMINAL PASTPerry Mason is a also a lawyer, but we'll overlook that.BULLDOG DRUMMOND:--- 10 films, 1929-1938: BULLDOG DRUMMOND Volume 1 - 7 DVD-R - 10 FILMS---- 8 films, 1939-1951: Not yet released.NICK CARTER:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00CDV4OECPERRY MASON: Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Bros. Movies Collection[Warren William starred in 4 of the 6 films.]MICHAEL SHAYNE:Volume One was issued way back in 2007. Still waiting for Volume Two.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B000LC4ZDKPHILO VANCE:--- 7 films, 1929-1947: PHILO VANCE FILM RARITIES COLLECTION - 7 DVD-R - 7 MOVIES (OnesMedia)--- 6 films, 1930-1940: The Philo Vance Murder Case Collection (Warner Archive)You need both for a complete collection - there is no overlap.I LOVE A MYSTERYThree films, 1945-1946 starring Jim Bannon and Barton YarboroughThe last but least of the B-Movie Detective series.Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B010J9O0M0PHILIP MARLOWE / SAM SPADEThese two detectives were the most famous Private Eyes of all time, but they don't really belong on this list.They were A-Movie detectives all the way:- 1931 The Maltese Falcon: Ricardo Cortez as Sam Spade- 1936 Satan Met a Lady: Warren William as Sam Spade - adapted from 'The Maltese Falcon' by Dashiell Hammett- 1941 The Maltese Falcon: Humphrey Bogart as Sam Spade- 1944 Murder, My Sweet: Dick Powell as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'Farewell, My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler- 1946 The Big Sleep: Humphrey Bogart as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 Lady in the Lake: Robert Montgomery as Philip Marlowe.- 1947 The Brasher Doubloon: George Montgomery as Philip Marlowe - adapted from 'The High Window" by Raymond ChandlerBut two Philip Marlowe novels were adapted as B-Movies for other detectives:- 1942 Time to Kill (Lloyd Nolan as Michael Shayne) - adaptated from 'The High Window' by Raymond Chandler- 1942 The Falcon Takes Over (George Sanders as The Falcon)) - adapted from 'Farewell My Lovely' by Raymond Chandler--------------------------------------------------------For PART THREE: UNCONVENTIONAL B-MOVIE DETECTIVES from the '30s and '40s, see my Comment dated July 8, 2015.Also directions to the OnesMedia website.* Amazon only permits ten links per review, so I had to use ASIN numbers for the rest (Amazon Stock Index Numbers)

The Lone Wolf is a reformed jewel thief turned private detective.Basically a rip-off of The Saint, but great fun nonetheless.Five actors played the Lone Wolf in fifteen Hollywood films between 1935 and 1947, all produced by Columbia Pictures:1935 Melvyn Douglas = The Lone Wolf Returns1938 Francis Lederer = The Lone Wolf in Paris1939 Warren William = The Lone Wolf Spy Hunt1940 Warren William = The Lone Wolf Strikes1940 Warren William = The Lone Wolf Meets a Lady1941 Warren William = The Lone Wolf Keeps a Date1941 Warren William = The Lone Wolf Takes a Chance1941 Warren William = Secrets of the Lone Wolf1942 Warren William = Counter-Espionage1943 Warren William = One Dangerous Night1943 Warren William = Passport to Suez1946 Gerald Mohr = The Notorious Lone Wolf1947 Gerald Mohr = The Lone Wolf in Mexico1947 Gerald Mohr = The Lone Wolf in London1949 Ron Randell = The Lone Wolf and His LadyNine of the fifteen featured the remarkable Warren William as The Lone Wolf.He's one of my all-time favorite actors, but I'll admit that he is an acquired taste.Warren William had a remarkable face -He looked like Satan - which should have stereotyped him as a screen villain, but his personality and sense of humor overcame this obvious handicap.He is devilish fun to watchWarren William also played private eyes Philo Vance (twice - in the OnesMedia and Warner Archive collections)and Perry Mason (four films in the Warner Archive).See the GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVD at the end of this review.Adorable British actor Eric Blore played Jamison, the Lone Wolf's butler, in eleven of the movies, starting with "The Lone Wolf Strikes" and ending with "The Lone Wolf in London".OnesMedia has produced the only available collection of all fifteen Lone Wolf movies, and is selling them at a very nice price.Eight DVDs in a CD-size plastic clamshell case with soft plastic sleeves (the same packaging this company uses for CDs of old radio shows).Picture quality ranges from OK to pretty good, but OnesMedia did a heroic job of cleaning up the sound.No subtitles, but I wasn't expecting any at this price.These are DVD-Rs, but I had no problem playing them.Finally, THERE IS NO COMPETITION.------------------------------------------------------------------GUIDE TO B-MOVIE DETECTIVES ON DVDA-Movies had bigger budgets and stars, and were top-billed in a double-feature.B-Movies occupied the bottom of the program.Some of the longer-lasting series started out as A-Movies, but ended up as B-Movies (Philo Vance began at Paramount and ended up at PRC)PART ONE: REFORMED CRIMINALS TURNED PRIVATE EYE- Boston Blackie, the Lone Wolf and the Saint are reformed jewel thieves. Still viewed with suspicion by the police.- The Falcon has a shady past (never quite explained).- Arsene Lupin is an unreformed jewel thief who sometimes helps the police if it serves his ends.- The Crime Doctor used to be an Organized Crime Boss. He never actually reformed, but was conked over the head and woke up with amnesia.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.If there is ever a problem with a OnesMedia link, go directly to their website - see my comment dated July 8, 2015]BOSTON BLACKIE: BOSTON BLACKIE FILM COLLECTION - 14 MOVIES - 7 DVD-RCRIME DOCTOR: CRIME DOCTOR FILM COLLECTION - 5 DVD-R - 10 MOVIES - 1943-1949 with Warner BaxterTHE FALCON:--- George Sanders: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 1 (3 Discs)--- Tom Conway: The Falcon Mystery Movie Collection, Volume 2THE LONE WOLF: reviewed on this pageTHE SAINT:--- George Sanders: The George Sanders Saint Movie Collection (2 Disc)--- Hugh Sinclair: The Saint's Vacation / The Saint Meets the Tiger: The Saint Double FeatureARSENE LUPIN:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00KB49ME0-----------------------------------------------------PART TWO: PRIVATE EYES WITHOUT A CRIMINAL PASTPerry Mason is a also a lawyer, but we'll overlook that.BULLDOG DRUMMOND:--- 10 films, 1929-1938: BULLDOG DRUMMOND Volume 1 - 7 DVD-R - 10 FILMS---- 8 films, 1939-1951: Not yet released.NICK CARTER:Copy and paste in the Amazon Search Bar: *ASIN: B00CDV4OECPERRY MASON: Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Bros.
