Richard Bonynge (born 1930) was one of the most underrated, yet most influential conductors of the Twentieth Century.Not everyone took him seriously - Cynics referred to him as Mr. Joan Sutherland.He was married to one of the great sopranos of the Twentieth Century.True, his early career piggy-backed on his wife's success.When Decca signed her, they had to take him.Nevertheless, by the end of the Twentieth Century, he had earned a reputation as on of our most perceptive interpreters of Bel Canto Opera, French Opera, and Ballet.He was instrumental in the 1970's revival of interest in Massenet (the operas he conducted are all first recordings).Bonynge conducts:- Three of the eight operas in this collection (his wife sings in two of them),- Three ballets,- Three-quarters of the orchestral showpieces,- He plays the piano in 25 songs and conducts additional songs and arias.The 144 page booklet includes a detailed plot summary for each opera, cued to the track listing (three ballets get the same treatment).The complete texts for each opera plus English translations are on a CD-ROM that comes with the set.There are also complete texts and translations for the songs, and the arias from additional Massenet operas used as fillers.OPERAS:- "Manon" - Beverly Sills, Nicolai Gedda, Gerard Souzay - cond. Julius Rudel.- "Werther" - Frederica von Stade, Jose Carreras - cond. Colin Davis.- "Thais" - Renee Fleming, Thomas Hampson - cond. Yves Abel.- "Esclarmonde" - Joan Sutherland, Huguette Tourangeau, Giacomo Aragall - cond. Richard Bonynge.- "La Roi de Lahore" - Joan Sutherland, Luis Lima, Sherrill Milnes - cond. Richard Bonynge.- "Therese" - Huguette Tourangeau, Ryland Davies - cond. Richard Bonynge.- "Le Jongleur de Notre Dame" - Roberto Alagna and an all-male cast - cond. Enrique Diemecke.- "Don Quichotte" - Nicolai Ghiaurov (Don Quichotte), Gabriel Bacquier (Sancho Panza), Regine Crespin (Dulcinee) - cond. Kazimierz Kord."Manon" and "Werther" have been recorded many times. For these operas, the recorded competition is intense.The standard was set by each opera's first recording:- 1928 "Manon" - EMI (Naxos) with Germaine Feraldy, Louis Guenot - Opera Comique cond. Elie Cohen. *- 1931 "Werther" - EMI (Naxos) with Ninon Vallin, Georges Thill - Paris Opera cond. Elie Cohen. *None of these singers were members of the original cast (Massenet died in 1912), but they studied with the singers who were.The Paris Opera maintained a distinctively French performing style up through World War II.A lost tradition.In 1955 EMI (Testament or Naxos) recorded "Manon" at the Paris Opera. The singers were of a younger generation, but Pierre Monteux, the 80 year-old conductor, had known and worked with Massenet. *Surprisingly, these popular operas were not in Decca's stereo catalog.A missed opportunity - Suzanne Danco and Regine Crespin, the reigning French divas of the early stereo era, were both under contract to Decca.This box includes the 1970 Westminster/ABC/DG "Manon" (with Sills and Gedda), and the 1980 Philips "Werther" (with von Stade and Carreras).Nothing to complain about here, aside from some discomfort with the language.The uniquely French style of the mono EMI recordings is lost forever (its easier to fake fluency in Italian or German).There was competition from EMI for "Thais" (with Beverly Sills), and for "Don Quichotte" (with Jose Van Dam),but Decca is responsible for the only available recordings of "Esclarmonde", "Le Jongleur de Notre Dame", "La Roi de Lahore", and "Therese" (at least on major labels).ARIAS FROM ADDITIONAL MASSENET OPERAS:"Cendrillon" - Joan Sutherland"Cherubin" - Joan Sutherland, Angela Gheorghiu"Le Cid" - Joan Sutherland"Herodiade" - Huguette Tourangeau, Angela GheorghiuORCHESTRAL MUSIC FROM OPERAS:"Cendrillon" - Marche des princesses - cond. Bonynge"Cherubin" - Entracte - cond. Bonynge"Le Cid" - Ballet Music - cond. Bonynge"La Navarraise" - Nocturne - cond. Bonynge"La Roi de Lahore" - Entracte, Adagio & Waltz - cond. Bonynge"Manon" - Prelude + La Nuit de Noel - cond. Albert Wolff (mono) **"Thais" - Meditation - John Georgiadis/Nigel Kennedy violin, cond. Bonynge (2 performances)SONGS:Huguette Tourangeau: 20 Songs with piano accompanimentJoan Sutherland: 7 Songs, five with piano accompaniment, two with orchestral accompanimentBALLETS:- "Le Carillon" - cond. Bonynge- "Cigale" - cond. Bonynge- "Manon Ballet" (orch. Leighton Lucas) - cond. BonyngeLe Carillon (1892) and Cigale (1904) are essentially one-act ballets (40 minutes each).The "Manon Ballet" is a full-length ballet (1 hour, 48 minutes).It was created in 1974 for the Royal Ballet.The plot is the same as the opera, but arranger Leighton Lewis did not use any music from the opera "Manon".Instead he used music from other Massenet operas and orchestral works. Gimmicky but enjoyable.ORCHESTRAL WORKS:Suite for Orchestra No.3 "Scenes dramatiques" - cond. BonyngeSuite for Orchestra No.4 "Scenes pittoresques" - cond. Albert Wolff **Suite for Orchestra No.7 "Scenes alsaciennes" - cond. Bonynge and Albert Wolff **Concert Overture "Phedre" - cond. Albert Wolff (mono) **Lamento d' Ariane - cond. BonyngeFantasy for Cello and Orchestra - Jascha Silberstein cello, cond. BonyngeInvocation from "Les Erinnyes" - Douglas Cummings cello, cond. BonyngeRECOMMENDATIONS:At the low price asked, and with full texts and translations, the Decca box is an essential purchase for all lovers of French Opera.- "Esclarmonde", "La Roi de Lahore", "Therese" and "Le Jongleur de Notre Dame" - the only available recordings are in this box.- "Manon" and "Werther" - the stereo recordings in this box are as good as any in the catalog, but the three mono EMI Paris Opera recordings  are irreplaceable. *- "Thais" - the Decca recording with Renee Fleming and Thomas Hampson is outstanding, but the EMI recording with Beverly Sills and Sherill Milnes has great sentimental value for me.Also recommended: the DVD featuring Renee Fleming and Thomas Hampson in performance at the Metropolitan Opera: Massenet: Thais- The Metropolitan OperaRenee Fleming is fun to look at.- "Don Quichotte" - Close, but I prefer the Decca recording with Nicolai Ghiaurov to the EMI with Jose van Dam.This is one French opera where being a native French speaker is not necessarily an advantage.Massenet composed the role with Russian bass Feodor Chaliapin in mind.Bulgarian bass Nicolai Ghiaurov is the closest we can come in stereo.P.S. Additional Massenet operas have been recorded on other labels:"Cendrillon" with Frederica von Stade (Sony)"Cherubin" with Frederica von Stade (Sony)"Le Cid" with Grace Bumbry (Sony)"Herodiade" with Cheryl Studer (EMI) - or - Renee Fleming (Sony or Newton Classics)"La Navarraise" with Marilyn Horne (Sony)----------------------------------------------------------------* EMI's Paris Opera recordings:Manon: 1929 EMI: Great Opera Recordings: MassenetManon: 1955 EMI: Massenet: Manon - or - ManonWerther: 1931 EMI: Werther** French conductor Albert Wolff conducts the "historic recordings" on CD 23.Contrary to the booklet, the two Massenet suites are stereo (1955). The Phedre Overture and orchestral excerpts from Manon are mono.The Manon is from an abridged 1951 Decca recording of the opera featuring Jeanine Micheau. Sounds interesting, but I haven't heard it.Albert Wolff (1884-1970) was an historically important conductor who is almost forgotten today.His Paris Conservatoire recordings were a mainstay of Decca's early stereo catalog - Recently documented in three two-disc sets on the Decca/Eloquence label:Fte à la FrançaiseEloq: Invitation to the DanceEloq: Overtures in Hi-Fi

UPDATE: NORTH AMERICAN DVDs FINALLY RELEASED ON OCTOBER 7, 2015.One year before the official North American release, Season 3 of DCI Banks was released in two European DVD versions - from the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.Both European versions have found their way onto Amazon.By the time I posted my review, thirteen reviews of the European versions had already appeared on this page.Some reviewers have complained that the subtitles are in Dutch, not English.Some reviewers complained that it will not play at all.There is a simple explanation:Both the English and Dutch versions are in PAL Region 2 format - If you buy them, you will need a special region-free DVD player.The North American release is identical in content to the UK release (with English subtitles), but it is in the NTSC Region 1 format (the North-American standard).The different versions are easy to tell apart- the cover art for the European releases is radically different. *Make sure the cover of yours has the two women on the left and the man on the right (and no Dutch writing).------------------------------------------------------This excellent and gritty British police series debuted in 2010.Filmed in Yorkshire, primarily in the city of Leeds (population 750,000)Since the series began, Stephen Tompkinson has played Detective Chief Inspector Alan Banks, and Andrea Lowe has played Detective Sergeant Annie Cabbot.There is a surprising amount of sexual tension on this show.D.S. Cabbot took maternity leave at the start of Season Two.Nobody knows who the father is, and there is a great deal of speculation among her fellow officers.[No, DCI Banks is not the father.]D.S. Cabbot is back as a single mother in Season Three.In Season Two, Caroline Catz, as Detective Inspector Helen Morton, was brought in as a temporary replacement, but has caught on and is now part of the team.(I have a major crush on this woman. This was her first series after "Doc Martin").All three are back for Season Three.This show keeps getting better..Season Three has the best writing so far - especially the final episode "Bad Boy".Very Dickensian.Charles Dickens had a knack for introducing unrelated plot lines, which are finally brought together by a remarkable chain of coincidences.In lesser hands this would be a recipe for disaster, but Catherine Tregenna pulled it off successfully.In real life, DCI Banks' evidence against the killer would not be admissible in court,but dramatically the episode was very satisfying.My only concern is that there was entirely too much fraternization between the ranks in Season Three.also Too much "Boinking"also Too much "Rogering"also Too much "Shagging"also Too much "Hiding the Sausage"also Too much "Taking Old One-Eye to the Optometrist"----- Euphemisms from from the Online Slang DictionaryThe implied sexual tension of Seasons One and Two is out in the open.I would have thought the lower ranks were off-limits to Detective Chief Inspectors, but this is apparently not the case in Yorkshire.Season Four will be interesting.Only real complaint is the lack of a Blu-Ray version.Still five stars.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review through to the end, then come back and click on the links.] ___  Pilot (2010): DCI Banks: AftermathSeason 1 (2011): DCI Banks: Season 1Season 2 (2012): DCI Banks: Season 2 - Caroline Catz joins the seriesSeason 3 (2014): reviewed on this pageSeason 4 (2015): DCI Banks: Season FourWatch the Pilot before watching Season 1, Episode 2 ("Friend of the Devil") - a continuing story.While waiting patiently for DCI Banks Season 3, I created a list of my Favorite British Police Inspectors - see my Comment dated May 12, 2015.-------------------------------------------------------* Different versions of Season Three:GOOD: North American version = DCI Banks: Season Three (the man is on the right)BAD: UK version = DCI Banks - Series 3 [DVD] [2015] (the man is standing in the center)BAD: Dutch version = Inspector Banks (Complete Series 3) - 2-DVD Box Set ( DCI Banks ) ( Wednesday's Child / Piece of My Heart / Bad Boy ) [ NON-USA FORMAT, PAL, Reg.0 Import - Netherlands ] (it has "DIE COMPLETE DERDE SERIE" printed on the cover)Don't order the UK or Dutch version unless you have a region-free DVD player and need Dutch subtitles.Region-free DVD players are actually a good idea.Unfortunately you won't find them at Best Buy, Target or Walmart.They are not illegal, but the big retailers are under a lot of pressure not to sell them.On the Amazon search bar, under "Electronics" enter "region free dvd player"Several models under $50.All DVD players are region-free when they come from the factory.The regional encoding software is programmed in later.It can be deprogrammed by someone who knows what they are doing(there is a computer port on the back of your DVD player - along with a warning label that it is for authorized technicians only).I have owned a Toshiba region-free player for two years, and it plays flawlessly.In addition to playing every DVD in the world (PAL or NTSC), it will also play region A and region-free blu-rays, but not European region B blu-rays.Region-free blu-ray players are available, but more pricey - in the $200 range (but the price will almost certainly come down if you are patient).- but read the description carefully: "region-free DVD / Blu-Ray player" is not the same as "region-free DVD / region-free Blu-Ray player".

Jean Martinon (1910-1976) was Music Director of the Chicago Symphony from 1963 to 1968.My family lived near Chicago. I listened to Martinon a lot - at least on radio station WFMT's Thursday night broadcasts.JEAN MARTINON: THE COMPLETE CHICAGO SYMPHONY RECORDINGSTen CDs in an attractive box with a 44 page booklet.'Original jacket' format - Program notes on the back of each jacket except for the bonus disc (CD 10)."Tape transfers from the original analogue sources and mastering using 24-bit/96kHz technology."The Bartok, Hindemith, Nielsen, Varese and five of the eight Ravel pieces have already been issued in 24-bit transfers, most as part of RCA's 'High Performance' series.The rest are newly remastered for this collection.Fritz Reiner retired from the Chicago Symphony in 1963, and died shortly thereafter.Reiner was a Hungarian conductor who made his early reputation in Germany before moving to America.The Chicago orchestra, audiences and critics were looking for a carbon copy of their fallen hero.(only George Szell really fit the bill, but he already had the job in Cleveland and wasn't interested).The closest match the search committee could find was Georg Solti, then in his third year as Music Director of London's Covent Garden Opera.The Chicago board offered him the Symphony, but he was unwilling to leave Covent Garden, and Chicago wasn't looking for a part-time conductor.Jean Martinon was the fallback choice.A victim of circumstanceCertain orchestra members resented him (including the principal oboe, who was the musician's union delegate).Martinon had a terrible local press, though his recordings with the orchestra were universally praised.By 1968 he was gone, back to France.In 1969, Georg Solti took over as Music Director.The orchestra, audiences and critics were happy again.I actually felt sorry for Martinon (I was a teenager).He seemed to have gotten a raw deal.As a farewell gesture, at his final recording sessions, the orchestra agreed to record Martinon's own 4th Symphony.Guilty conscience?(it wasn't RCA's idea).Last year, Sony issued a box of all the Reiner/Chicago Symphony recordings: Fritz Reiner: Complete RCA CollectionI titled my review "Wonderful Performances by a Great Conductor with a Great Orchestra in Remarkable Sound".I thought about calling this new Martinon box -"Wonderful Performances by a Great Conductor with a Great Orchestra, 30% in Remarkable Sound, 70% in Pretty Good Sound".CDs 1-3, the earliest recordings in this collection (Martin, Nielsen, Roussel, Varese + Ravel's Daphnis et Chloe Suite), were the last in a series of audiophile LPs that RCA produced in Chicago's Orchestra Hall between 1954 and 1966.Orchestra Hall was a mediocre concert hall, but a superb recording studio - it actually sounded better empty.In 1966 it underwent a disastrous remodeling, which resulted in a mediocre concert hall and mediocre recording studio.[ Jean Martinon was very unlucky in Chicago.]For the next ten plus years, well into the Solti era, the orchestra recorded across town in the Medinah Temple, a merely good recording studio.Sony's CD masterings of the Medinah Temple recordings (CDs 4-10) actually sound better than the RCA "Dynagroove" LPs of the late Sixties.POINTS OF INTEREST:-- The Varese Arcana, Martin's Concerto for Seven Wind Instruments, and Ravel's Bolero are from the Chicago Symphony's final recording session in the old Orchestra Hall on March 19-21, 1966.Nielsen's 4th Symphony was recorded later that year (on October 10) during a pause in construction - the sound is still recognizable as Orchestra Hall.The first Medinah Temple session was six months later - on April 26, 1967.[the booklet claims that Mendelssohn's Midsummer Night's Dream was recorded in Orchestra Hall on May 18, 1967, but this is probably a typo - two days earlier RCA's engineers were in Medinah Temple for a recording session.]-- The Medinah Temple was not a place of worship.It was a 4200 seat auditorium, built in 1912 by the "Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine", better known as the Shriners.(I saw the circus there as a child)It had surprisingly good acoustics, considering it's enormous size.Still standing, though the interior has been gutted and is now home to Bloomingdale's Department Store.The Shriners are a North American charitable fraternity (related to the Masons) founded in 1870.They run children's hospitals and drive tiny cars while wearing red fezzes.-- Decca used the Medinah Temple for their first Solti recording in 1970 (Mahler's 5th and 6th Symphonies), but never stopped looking for a better hall.Beginning in 1971, they briefly flirted with recording at the University of Illinois (Mahler's 7th Symphony).Results were excellent, but it was 150 miles from Chicago - an extravagant solution.Decca, EMI, and DG reluctantly agreed with RCA's decision to use the Medinah Temple for recording the Chicago Symphony. *-- This is the third CD transfer of Carl Nielsen's Symphony 4 'The Inextinguishable'.This may be the fastest performance on record - extremely exciting.Magnificent playing by the Chicago brass. The critics always made a great deal of Solti's brass section, but the key players were already in place.'The Inextinguishable' is supposed to be performed without breaks between movements ('attacca').It was first issued this way on CD in 1994.Twelve years later Sony issued a new 24-bit remastering in improved sound, but a misinformed editor inserted a five-second gap between movements 3 and 4.For this new box, Sony re-used the 24-bit mastering, but closed the five-second gap.They finally got it right.There is a drum whack at 10:17 of track 3, the sound decays for one second, then the brass lurches in.More of a stagger than a pause.-- Massenet's Meditation from 'Thais' - violin soloist Steven Staryk was concertmaster of the Chicago Symphony during the Martinon years.In 1956, Sir Thomas Beecham appointed the 24 year-old Staryk concertmaster of the Royal Philharmonic (or "leader" in the funny language of the natives).He played the violin solo in Beecham's recording of Scheherezade.Later, Staryk was konzertmeister of the Amsterdam Concertgebouw (1960-1963), and held the Chicago position between 1963 and 1967.After Chicago, Staryk returned home to Canada and devoted himself to a solo career and teaching.Strad Magazine called him "The King of Concertmasters".-- Paganini's "Moto perpetuo", orchestrated by Frederick Stock (not Stokowski) is from a private fund-raising CD issued by the orchestra.Stock was conductor of the Chicago Symphony from 1905 to 1942.-- Ravel's Boléro, Pavane and La Valse on CD 10 were part of a "Ravel's Greatest Hits" LP in the `70sSuite 2 from Ravel's Daphnis et Chloe is performed in the concert version without chorus. Martinon recorded the complete ballet with chorus for EMI in 1974 with the Orchestre de Paris.-- Casadesus' Piano Concerto with the composer as soloist (CD 10) was recorded with the French National Radio Orchestra, not the Chicago Symphony.-- Prior to Chicago, 50 percent of Martinon's recordings were of French (or Swiss) music.In Chicago, 60 percent of his recordings were of French music.Post-Chicago, 90 percent of his recordings were of French music.CONTENTS OF THE SONY BOX:- Bartók: Miraculous Mandarin Suite- Bizet: Symphony in C + L'Arlésienne Suites- Casadesus: Concerto for Piano (composer, piano)- Hindemith: Nobilissima Visione- Lalo: Le roi d'Ys Overture- Martin: Concerto for Seven Wind Instruments, Timpani, Percussion and Strings- Martinon: Symphony 4- Massenet: Meditation from Thais- Mendelssohn: A Midsummer Night's Dream Suite- Mennin: Symphony 7 "Variation-symphony"- Nielsen: Symphony 4 "The Inextinguishable" + Helios Overture- Paganini-Stock: Moto perpetuo- Ravel: Alborada del gracioso / Boléro / Daphnis et Chloé Suite 2 / Introduction and Allegro for Harp, Flute, Clarinet, and Strings / Ma mère l'Oye  / Pavane pour une infante défunte / Rapsodie espagnole / La Valse- Roussel: Bacchus et Ariade Suite 2- Varese: Arcana- Weber: Clarinet Concertos (Benny Goodman)------------------------------------------------------------------DISCOGRAPHY OF CHICAGO SYMPHONY GUEST CONDUCTORS - and - JEAN MARTINON DISCOGRAPHYI have prepared two discographies - See my comment dated March 16, 2015.----------------------------------------------------------------------------* Solti's first Beethoven cycle with the Chicago Symphony was recorded in three different locales:- Symphony 9 in the Krannert Center at the University of Illinois (1972)- Symphonies 1-5 and 8 in Medinah Temple (1973-74)- Symphonies 6 and 7 in the Sofiensaal in Vienna (during the orchestra's 1974 European tour)Solti Beethoven: SymphoniesThere was a second attempt at remodeling Orchestra Hall, which resulted in a slight improvement, but it was enough for Decca to resume recording there.- I think the last recording session in Medinah Temple was Solti's recording of Mahler's 2nd Symphony in 1980.In 1995-97 Orchestra Hall was completely re-designed and enlarged to include the adjacent building - now known as "Symphony Center".I still miss the old Orchestra Hall - even though I only heard one Youth Concert there (I used to be a Youth).

After a delayed start,  Amazon is finally offering Goberman's Haydn on CD.The 14 CD box  costs less than the digital downloads.BACKGROUND:In the early years of LP ('50s and '60s), there were four abortive attempts to record the Complete Symphonies of Haydn:-- Jonathan Sternberg with the Vienna State Opera Orchestra (mono recordings) on the Haydn Society label (augmented by Anton Heiller, Mogens Wöldike, Franz Litschauer, Hans Swarowsky, and Erwin Baltzer)-- Hermann Scherchen with the Vienna State Opera Orchestra (mostly mono, some stereo) for Ultraphon and Westminster (augmented by Henry Swoboda, Lazslo Somogyi and Robert Rudolf)-- Leslie Jones with the Little Orchestra of London (stereo) for Pye and Nonesuch.-- Max Goberman with the Vienna State Opera Orchestra (stereo) for "The Library of Recorded Masterpieces".The first three were commercial ventures, but Max Goberman's was a labor of love - He funded the Haydn Symphony project out of his own pocket."Library of Recorded Masterpieces" LPs were sold by subscription, which brought in some money, but Goberman made up the difference.His income came from being one of the most sought-after conductors on Broadway (see "West Side Story" original cast CD).After three years of work, Goberman had made it to almost the half-way mark, when he died of a massive heart attack in 1962.He was 52 years old, and had recorded 45 Symphonies and three overtures:Symphonies 1-6, 7-9 (Morning, Noon & Night), 10-17, 19, 20, 21, 22 (Philosopher), 23, 24, 26 (Lamentation), 27, 32, 34, 35, 37, 40, 41, 48 (Maria Theresa), 49 (La Passione), 51, 52, 55 (Schoolmaster), 56, 57, 60 (Il Distratto), 65, 92 (Oxford), 96 (Miracle) and 98+ Symphonies A and B (Hob 107 + 108)+ Overtures to "L'infedelta delusa", "Lo Speziale" and "Acide et Galalea"In the late '60s, Columbia Records (USA) acquired the rights to "The Library of Recorded Masterpieces", and announced their intention to finish the Haydn Symphony project on the budget label Odyssey.Charles Mackerras and the London Symphony were recruited for the remaining works, but only Symphony 18 was completed before the project foundered (unfortunately Symphony 18 was left out of the new collection).To date, there have been four complete sets of the Haydn Symphonies:[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]1) Antal Dorati with the Philharmonica Hungarica: recorded 1969-1972 by Decca: Haydn: The SymphoniesIt's very well done, with scholarly notes, but I'm not sure how it would have measured up to a hypothetical Goberman/Mackerras set.Dorati has one advantage over other complete sets - an appendix with two versions of Symphonies 22 and 63, four finales to 53, and two finales to 103 (unavailable outside the Dorati box).2) Ernst Maerzendorfer with the Vienna Chamber Orchestra: recorded concurrent with the Dorati project (never released on CD).3) Adam Fischer with "The Austro-Hungarian Haydn Orchestra" on Brilliant Classics: Haydn: The Complete Symphonies4) Dennis Russell Davies with The Stuttgart Chamber orchestra on Sony: Haydn: The Complete SymphoniesThe booklets included with the Fischer and Davies boxes are not as detailed as that in the Dorati box.Both conductors are spirited, but there are some questions about their scholarship (see my comments on Symphony 48 "Maria Theresa", third version).If you want a boxed set of all 106 Symphonies played on period instruments, you are out of luck.- The late Christopher Hogwood with The Academy of Ancient Music came closest with 81 Symphonies: Haydn: Symphonies- Roy Goodman with the Hanover Band recorded 62 Symphonies - Individual CDs on the Helios label, not yet in a box.- Derek Solomons with L'Estro armonico recorded at least 30 Symphonies for CBS (only a few made it to CD).- Trevor Pinnock with the English Concert recorded 22 Early Symphonies: Haydn - Pinnock: Complete Recordings (DG Collectors Edition)- Thomas Fey with with the Nuremberg Symphony has an ongoing series for Hanssler (55 symphonies in 15 years) using modern instruments, but played in period style. I'd sooner invest in a 100% period instrument recording.- Dorati, Fischer, Hogwood, Pinnock and Solomons are available on you-tube.- There are thirty-second samples of Goberman on Amazon's MP3 downloads page.- See my Comment dated May 30, 2015 for links to websites with brief samples of the Davies set and a perceptive review.(Amazon won't allow me to print website links in a review, but its OK in the Comments section).---------------------------------------------SOUND QUALITY AND PACKAGING14 CDs in mini-LP cardboard jackets, but not "original jacket" format (no notes on the back).36 page booklet with a brief article about Max Goberman, but no notes about the Symphonies.If I remember correctly the original LPs came with program notes by H.C. Robbins-Landon.[the much-maligned Wikipedia is a good source - their "Haydn Symphonies" page has links to an article about each Symphony.]Contrary to Sony's claim, "these historic recordings [are not] restored to pristine condition".Some are, but several of the original 3-track master tapes were lost before Sony acquired the Columbia archives.The transfer to CD was supervised by Sony's Andreas K. Meyer, who has done quality work in the past."Given the musical importance of Goberman's recordings, we decided to continue with the Haydn Symphonies project and managed to cobble together sources, comprising original 3-track masters, 2-track masters used in the Odyssey re-releases, and, as a last resort, pristine copies of the original LPs issued by the Library of Recorded Masterpieces."The booklet does not specify the source(s) used for each Symphony.This is not a deal-breaker for me - it's unfortunate, but even at it's worst, the sound is still pretty good.Sony did a valiant job in making the Goberman recordings presentable.A lot of time and effort.Early '60s stereo means wide separation and clear placing of each instrument.The sound is close-up, not "concert hall realism".If you are at all concerned, check out the thirty-second samples of Goberman's Haydn on Amazon's MP3 downloads page.--------------------------------------SYMPHONY 48 in C MAJOR: "MARIA THERESA"I don't have time to compare recordings of everything in this box, so I decided to start with my favorite middle period Haydn Symphony.Haydn scholar H.C. Robbins Landon shared my enthusiasm:"From the tense excitement of the opening (with those reeling horn parts that must be heard to be believed) ... to the breathless pace of the Finale, this Symphony seems to have been composed in one great inspirational sweep."Originally scored for two oboes, bassoon, two horns (first, third and last movement for high horns in C), and strings.There are three versions of Symphony 48:- Without Timpani (as per the original score)- With Timpani- With Trumpets (replacing high horns)H.C. Robbins Landon started the war against trumpets and drums:"It is not certain that the crude timpani part in the Esterhazy archives is really Haydn's ...The modern trumpet and timpani parts as published by Breitkopf & Hartel, and in the Eulenburg score, are patent forgeries."--- `The Symphonies of Joseph Haydn' - New York, 1955If you want to hear what Symphony 48 sounds like without drums, try the period instrument performances by Goodman or Hogwood (Hogwood is on you-tube).I miss the timpani.Later on Robbins Landon changed his mind - at least about drums:"No authentic timpani part for this work has survived, but it is unlikely that Haydn performed the Symphony without one (all the other similar C major works of this period include a genuine kettledrum part) and none of the other existing versions can be considered satisfactory.The editor (Robbins Landon) has therefore reconstructed one especially for this recording."--- HCRL, notes written for the Solomons CD, 1983To the best of my knowledge, everyone but Goodman and Hogwood include timpani.The third version, adding trumpets to the orchestra, was created after Haydn's death.Trumpets sound in the same range, but are less prone to accident than high horns.Substituting trumpets for high horns takes away a lot of the danger in live performance (no clams), but also much of the excitement - high horns have a uniquely thrilling sound (they whoop).Though he eventually accepted timpani in Symphony 48, Robbins-Landon remained adamant that the the trumpet part was a forgery.Dennis Russell Davies recorded the trumpet version in Stuttgart.I'm also pretty sure I hear trumpets in Fischer's recording (no mention in the booklet).OK in concert. Not for a recording.I love the sound of high horns in this symphony.First impression: Goberman whoops quite nicely, thank you.His "Maria Theresa" is very nearly perfect.Unapologetic high horns.[Dorati also uses high horns, but they are less boisterous than Goberman's.]Prominent timpani.The chamber orchestra sounds larger than is fashionable nowadays, and the strings play with full tone - historically incorrect, but I like it.First and Second violins are seated on opposite sides of the orchestra, as they should be.Haydn wrote with antiphonal strings in mind (try listening over headphones).By the 1960s, divided violins were going out-of-fashion after 200 years.The most influential Maestros - Bernstein, Karajan and Solti - scrunched all violins together on the left.Basically reducing the orchestra to two string groups (highs on the left, lows on the right).Nineteenth Century relics Otto Klemperer and Bruno Walter clung to the old ways in their stereo recordings.Max Goberman followed their lead.Dorati and Fischer use the modern seating plan with all violins on the left.Period Instruments: If you must have drums in "Maria Theresa" (I must), your best historically correct bet is Derek Solomons.I am not normally a big fan of period instruments, but was greatly impressed by his CBS CD - Tiny orchestra, thrilling natural horns: Symphonies 45 " Farewell " & 48I'd love to hear the rest of his Haydn, most of which never made it to CD.Trevor Pinnock used a larger period instrument orchestra, but his performance is on the sedate side compared to Solomons, who is almost manic (both are on you-tube).OTHER SYMPHONIES:Goberman's performances of the early symphonies display the same qualities as "Maria Theresa".The orchestra is not quite as large as that used for the middle period Symphonies, but is still scandalously large by historically-correct 21st Century standards.I like the sound of Goberman's orchestra, but I'm old and set in my ways.I'm also a crank - my all-time favorite conductor of late Haydn is Otto Klemperer (his Symphony 102 is the greatest Haydn recording ever).Followed closely by Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic (not his Vienna remakes).Goberman only recorded three late Symphonies (92, 96 and 98).His 98 is outstanding, the others very good.--------------------------------------There are 108 "Symphonies" in the catalog published in 1956 by Anthony van Hoboken.Hob I: 1-104 are Symphonies 1-104 in the traditional canon devised in 1906 by Eusebius Mandyczewski - imperfect chronological order.Hob I: 105 is the Sinfonia Concertante in B flat Major for violin, cello, oboe and bassoon (1792). A popular work, recorded many times. Not really a symphony.Hob I: 106 (Symphony C) is an incomplete single movement fragment in D Major from 1769.Hob I: 107 and 108 (Symphonies A and B) are early works (1757-1760), which were discovered after Mandyczewski's publication.Goberman, Dorati, Fischer and Hogwood include Hob 107 + 108.Hoboken thought Hob 1:106 was a fragment from a lost D Major symphony of 1769.Haydn scholar H.C. Robbins-Landon originally agreed and called it Symphony C, but later speculated that it might be the missing overture to the opera "Le Pescatrici" - a work which only survives in fragmentary form.Even more confusing, there is a Hungarian recording of Robbins-Landon's reconstruction of "Le Pescatrici" but it has no overture.A reconstruction of the Symphony Hob I: 106 (3 minutes, 11 seconds) is available in a 2 CD set of Haydn's Overtures: Haydn: Complete Overtures, where it is identified as the overture to the opera 'Le Pescatrici'.There was also a performance by Derek Solomons (3 minutes, 33 seconds).Not on CD, but someone posted it on you-tubeEnter the following on the you-tube search bar:J. Haydn - Hob I:106 - Symphony in D major (fragment)-------------------------------------In addition to the Haydn Symphony project in Vienna, Goberman also planned to record the complete Concertos of Vivaldi: 75 were recorded with the "New York Sinfonietta", plus a very nice set of Bach Brandenburg Concertos.All in the three year period 1960-1962.---------------------------------------My favorite "Maria Theresa" of all time was the old Nonesuch LP by Karl Ristenpart and the Chamber Orchestra of the Saar, but I am relying on memory.I haven't heard it in twenty years, not since I donated my turntable and LP collection to charity.Perhaps this is just nostalgia.Was it as good as I remember?I wish whoever owns the rights would issue it on CD - Perhaps in a big box of Karl Ristenpart recordings.Back then I naively assumed that every LP would eventually be available on CD or the internet.99 percent are, but there are a few treasured recordings still in limbo.Max Goberman spent a long time there.Back among the living, thanks to Sony.P.S. See my Comment dated August 2, 2015 for a discussion of repeats in Goberman's Haydn.

If you are looking for a CD collection of Haydn's Complete Overtures, you don't have a choice.To date, this is the only time it's been done.Fortunately the performances are spirited and well-recorded.Played by a chamber orchestra of approximately 35 players on modern instruments.22 Overtures.- Eleven overtures to Italian operas (one overture is speculative)- Three overtures to German operas (one overture is speculative)- Two concert overtures Hob Ia: 4 and 7- Symphony fragment Hob I:106 (identified as overture to the Italian opera "Le Pescatrici")- Five orchestral introductions to the oratorios.When Anthony van Hoboken published his Haydn Vercheiznis in 1956, he assigned Hoboken numbers by category.Hob I was "Symphonies".There was also a category of Hob Ia, "Overtures": fourteen of which were excerpted from complete operas, which also had their own Hoboken numbers.The booklet uses the Hob Ia numbers for these fourteen overtures - this is confusing as nearly every other recording uses the number assigned to the complete opera (Hob XXVIII = Italian Operas, Hob XXIX = German Operas).The Hob Ia number really only makes sense for the two independent Concert Overtures, Hob Ia: 4 and 7.In the list that follows, I have used the more commonly accepted Hoboken number, not the Hob Ia number.[I found the complete Hoboken Catalog in the appendix of 'The Oxford Companion to Haydn', ed. David Wyn Jones, 2002]OVERTURES TO ITALIAN OPERAS:Hob XXVIII:1 AcideHob XXVIII:2 La Canterina - HAS NO OVERTUREHob XXVIII:3 Lo SpezialeHob XXVIII:4 Le Pescatrici - SEE BELOW UNDER "INDEPENDENT ORCHESTRAL WORKS"Hob XXVIII:5 L'Infedelta delusaHob XXVIII:6 L'Incontro improvvisoHob XXVIII:7 Il Mondo della LunaHob XXVIII:8 La Vera costanzaHob XXVIII:9 L'Isola disabitataHob XXVIII:10 La Fedelta primiataHob XXVIII:11 Orlando PaladinoHob XXVIII:12 ArmidaHob XXVIII:13 Orfeo ed Euridice (L'Anima del filosofo)OVERTURES TO GERMAN OPERAS:Hob XXIXa:1 Philemon und BaucisHob XXIXa:1a Der Gotterrath - THIS IS THE FIRST MOVEMENT OF SYMPHONY 50Hob XXIXa:4 FeuersbrunstHaydn constructed Symphony 50 in C Major with music recycled from his marionette opera "Der Gotterath" (now lost), which was performed as a Prologue to the German opera "Philemon and Baucis" during a 1773 visit by the Empress Maria Theresa.Manfred Huss has assumed that the overture to "Der Gotterath" was re-used in it's entirety as the first movement to  Symphony 50.Not unreasonable, but not absolutely certain.(the booklet notes should have explained this).ORATORIOS:Hob XX "Seven Last Words of Christ" - orchestral introductionHob XXI:1 "Il Ritorno di Tobia" - orchestral introductionHob XXI:2 "Creation" - orchestral introductionHob XXI:3 "The Seasons" - orchestral introductions to Part 3 (Autumn) and Part 4 (Winter). Huss includes passages that were cut from the original manuscript before publication.INDEPENDENT CONCERT WORKS:Hob Ia:4 -- Overture in D Major (1784)Hob Ia:7 -- Overture in D Major (1777)Hob I:106 - Symphony in D (1769) fragment, IDENTIFIED AS THE OVERTURE TO "LE PESCATRICI" Hob XXVIII:4There are 108 "Symphonies" in the catalog published in 1956 by Anthony van Hoboken.Hob I: 1-104 are Symphonies 1-104 in the traditional canon.Hob I:105 is the Sinfonia Concertante in B flat Major (1792). Not really a symphony.Hob I:106 is an incomplete single movement fragment in D from 1769 ("Symphony C").Hob I:107 and 108 (Symphonies A and B) are early symphonies, 1757-1760 (recorded by Goberman, Dorati, Fischer and Hogwood in their more-or-less complete sets).Manfred Huss in this recording identifies Hob I:106 as the long-lost overture to "Le Pescatrici" Hob XXVIII:4.Well, it might be.Hoboken thought Hob 1:106 was a fragment from a lost D Major symphony of 1769.Haydn scholar H.C. Robbins-Landon originally agreed and called it "Symphony C", but later speculated that it might be the missing overture to "Le Pescatrici" - a work which survives only in fragmentary form.Even more confusing, there is a Hungarian recording of Robbins-Landon's reconstruction of the opera "Le Pescatrici" but it has no overture.Hob 1:106 in this set of "Complete Overtures" is the only recording on CD (3 minutes, 11 seconds).There was also a performance by Derek Solomons (3 minutes, 33 seconds).Not on CD, but someone posted it on you-tubeEnter the following on the you-tube search bar:J. Haydn - Hob I:106 - Symphony in D major (fragment)--------------------------------------------------------------------My only complaint is that the booklet notes are unnecessarily confusing.As already mentioned, Manfred Huss is the only conductor on record to use the misleading Hob Ia numbers.The booklet does not acknowledge the better-known Hob numbers assigned to the complete operas.Also, the booklet should have credited H.C. Robbins Landon for coming up with the idea that the Symphony Hob I:106 was actually the overture to "Le Pescatrici".And the identification of the three German opera overtures is pretty sketchy.Unfortunately the Hoboken Catalog  is also a bit of a mess, and 'The Oxford Composer Companion to Haydn' doesn't help.Hob XXIX lists six works as "Marionette and other German operas" (Esterhazy actually had an elaborate puppet theater)."Philemon und Baucis" and "Feuersbrunst" are listed,but not "Der Gotterrath" which, as explained above uses the first movement of Symphony 50 in C Major for an overture.The booklet notes make no mention of this.Messy. But still nice.

This box is the second time the series has been released on DVD.Contents are identical to the 2006 release on the A&E label. *Order whichever version is cheapest (usually this one).The box under review was actually manufactured in Australia, but don't worry - it is region-free NTSC, which means it is compatible with all North American DVD players and televisions.Eight DVDs in four standard-size double-DVD plastic cases; all in a cardboard slipcase.CONTENTS:- The 2000 pilot "Golden Spiders" (90 minutes)+ Season One (2001) complete = Eight episodes (four are double-length)+ Season Two (2002) complete = Twelve episodes (four are double-length)+ Bonus: "The Making of Nero Wolfe", a 22 minute introduction to the series (2001)(see end of this review for the titles of each episode)HOW TO VIEW THIS SERIES:-- Step One: Insert DVD number 8 (Volume 4, Disc 2) into your player.Watch the pilot: "Golden Spiders".-- Step Two: Watch the 22 minute bonus "The Making of Nero Wolfe" (also on DVD 8), an excellent introduction to the remaining episodes in the series (no spoilers).-- Step Three: Watch DVDs 1 through 7 in that order. When you come to DVD 7, you have a choice of aspect ratio for watching "The Silent Speaker" -The series is presented in the 4:3 aspect ration which was standard for televisions in 2001.Apparently it was also filmed in the wide-screen aspect ratio of 16:9, common to modern televisions.But only one episode is presented in wide-screen, "The Silent Speaker" on DVD 8."The Silent Speaker" can also viewed in the old 4:3 format on DVD 7.If you have a modern TV set, by all means view it in wide-screen on DVD 8.The pilot, "Golden Spiders", is rated M for Mature audiences, because of violence (Archie Goodwin actually tortures one of the bad guys to make him talk).It is the best film in the series, and darker than the rest.The remaining episodes (rated PG for Parental Guidance) are a bit flippant in tone, almost campy at times, but still rewarding for mystery buffs.[a surprising number of Wolfe's clients are murdered after hiring him - seems like this would be bad for business.]With Maury Chaykin as Nero Wolfe, and Timothy Hutton as Archie Goodwin,this TV series was originally produced by the cable network A&E.Hard to believe,A&E has gone down-market considerably since then.Back in 2000 they spent a lot of money and produced a quality product.Set in 1950's New York, it was filmed in Toronto.No problem. 2001 Toronto looked a lot like 1955 New York. Beautiful cinematography, sets, automobiles and costumes.SUBTITLES?Not actual subtitles, but the DVDs are closed-captioned in English.Closed-Captioning is activated while the disc is playing by pressing a button on your TV's remote."Subtitling" is activated by pressing a button on your DVD player's remote."Closed-Captioning" is obsolete, but it's better than nothing.Unfortunately closed captioning will not work if your DVD player is connected to the TV using the preferred modern method of HDMI cable.You have to use the three-cable (red-white-yellow) method to connect your player to the TV.[a lot of the less expensive DVD players do not even give you the option of a three-cable output - one tip: DVD/VCR combo players always include a three-cable output.](old-fashioned coaxial cable also will work with closed captioning)The remastering on these DVDs is pretty old, but looks gorgeous.I think they would look even better on blu-ray, with everything in 16:9 widescreen.Whenever it is released on blu-ray, I hope we will have subtitles instead of closed captioning.* Earlier A&E DVD release: Nero Wolfe: The Complete Classic Whodunit Series (this is usually more expensive, though the contents are identical - including the bonus feature)The A&E version is also available in separate volumes for Seasons 1 and 2, but that is really expensive.------------------------------------------------------------CONTENTS:Pilot (2000)- The Golden Spiders *Season 1 (2001):- The Doorbell Rang *- Champagne for One *- Prisoner's Base *- Eeny Meeny Murder Moe- Disguise for Murder- Door to Death- Christmas Party- Over My Dead Body *Season 2 (2002):- Death of a Doxy *- The Next Witness- Die Like a Dog- Murder Is Corny- Motherhunt *- Poison Ã  la Carte- Too Many Clients *- Before I Die- Help Wanted, Male- The Silent Speaker *- Cop Killer- Immune to Murder* 90 minute episodes, the rest are 45 minutes long (give or take a minute)-----------------------------------------------------------------------P.S. An earlier "Nero Wolfe" series (14 episodes) aired on NBC in 1981 starring William Conrad  as Nero Wolfe.It was preceded by a 1977 pilot starring Thayer David who passed away before filming on the series started.Neither is commercially available at the present time,nor are the two movies that Columbia Pictures made in the 1930s:- "Meet Nero Wolfe" (1936) starring Edward Arnold- "The League of Frightened Men" (1937) starring Walter Connolly(but see my comment dated March 19)

I was a teenager living near Chicago in the 1960s.I listened to Jean Martinon a lot - at least on radio station WFMT's Thursday night boadcasts.He was Music Director of the Chicago Symphony for five mostly unhappy years.For details, see my review of Jean Martinon - The Complete Cso RecordingsJean Martinon (1910-1976) was in charge of four of the world's great orchestras, and left recordings with each of them:- Lamoureux Orchestra of Paris, 1951-1957 (Philips, DG)- Israel Philharmonic, 1957-1959 (Decca)- Chicago Symphony, 1964-1968 (RCA)- O.R.T.F (French National Radio & Television Orchestra), 1969-1973 (DG, EMI, Erato, Vox)JEAN MARTINON: THE DEUTSCHE GRAMMOPHON LEGACYFour CDs in a standard plastic case with 12 page booklet.Everything but the Ginastera Harp Concerto has previously been issued on CD.The pre-Chicago period is represented by a 1960 recording of Cello Concertos played by Pierre Fournier (Lalo, Saint-Saens, Bruch).This was Martinon's last recording with the Lamoureux Orchestra of Paris.Post-Chicago, Martinon's primary orchestra was the "Orchestre national de l'Office de radiodiffusion-télévision française"  (whew).Better known as  the O.R.T.F., the orchestra of France's National Broadcasting Corporation.The Bizet and Lalo orchestral works were recorded with the O.R.T.F, plus a collection of Twentieth Century Harp Concertos played by Nicanor Zabaleta (Ginastera, Saint-Saens, Tailleferre).Martinon made many more recordings with this orchestra, for EMI, Erato and Vox, in particular an invaluable series of Twentieth Century French music.[the 1969 DG recording of Martinon's Violin Concerto is conducted by Rafael Kubelik, and has already been issued in a box of that conductor's recordings.]These are Martinon's only recordings of:Bizet: La jolie fille de Perth Suite // Lalo: Rapsodie norvegienne // Cello Concertos by Lalo, Saint-Saens and Bruch // Harp Concertos by Ginastera, Saint-Saens and Tailleferreand his only stereo recording of:Lalo: Namouona Suites 1 & 2-----------------------------------------------------------------I haven't been able to locate a discography of Jean Martinon on the internet, so I thought I'd create one.Limited to CD reissues.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]DECCA: Complete Decca Recordings 1951 - 1960 issued in 2006 (deleted and insanely expensive), or reissued as individual CDs on Eloquence - five different orchestras, mono and stereoPHILIPS/ELOQUENCE: The Philips Legacy , 1953-1956 Lamoureux Orchestra - monoDG/ELOQUENCE: "The Deutsche Grammophon Legacy" (the box under review) , 1960 and 1969-1971 Lamoureux Orchestra and O.R.T.F. - stereoSONY (RCA): Jean Martinon - The Complete Cso Recordings , 1964-1968 Chicago Symphony - stereoWARNER (EMI/HMV and ERATO): ICON - The late years (14CD)(the EMI Debussy, Ravel and Saint-Saens are not in this box, but are available separately)VOX: Prokofiev Symphonies and Overtures, 1971 O.R.T.F. - stereo----------------------------------------------------------Adam:- Giselle: highlights - 1959 Paris Conservatoire (DECCA)- Si j'Etais Roi Overture - 1951 London Philharmonic, mono (DECCA)Bartok:- Miraculous Mandarin Suite - 1967 Chicago (SONY) +1971  O.R.T.F. (WARNER BOX)Beethoven:- Piano Concerto 5 "Emperor" with Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli - 1970 O.R.T.F. I have not included the series of private-label CDs that the Chicago Symphony issued in the 1980s and '90s.They included some interesting Martinon broadcasts (Mahler's 3rd Symphony and 10th Symphony in the Deryck Cooke edition), but have been out-of-print for twenty years and are insanely expensive.If they are ever reissued, I will certainly list them.Additions / Corrections to this discography are welcome.

I was a teenager living near Chicago in the 1960s.I listened to Jean Martinon a lot - at least on radio station WFMT's Thursday night boadcasts.He was Music Director of the Chicago Symphony for five mostly unhappy years.For details, see my review of Jean Martinon - The Complete Cso RecordingsJean Martinon (1910-1976) was in charge of four of the world's great orchestras, and left recordings with each of them:- Lamoureux Orchestra of Paris, 1951-1957 (Philips, DG)- Israel Philharmonic, 1957-1959 (Decca)- Chicago Symphony, 1964-1968 (RCA)- O.R.T.F (French National Radio & Television Orchestra), 1969-1973 (DG, EMI, Erato, Vox)JEAN MARTINON: THE PHILIPS LEGACYThese are mono recordings, 1953-56 with the Lamoureux Orchetra of Paris.Three CDs in a standard plastic case with 16 page booklet.Martinon was Music Director of L' Orchestre des Concerts Lamoureux from 1951-1957, his first important appointment (the orchestra was founded in 1881 in by Charles Lamoureux).These are Martinon's only recordings of:Dukas: Sorcerer's Apprentice // Falla: El Amor Brujo + Noches en los jardines de Espana // Faure: Pavane // Mozart: Symphonies 31,32,33 // Prokofiev: Love for Three Oranges Suite.Martinon re-made the remaining half of the contents of this box in 1970s stereo with the O.R.T.F. (French Radio & Television Orchestra), a better orchestra than Lamoureux, though less distinctively "French" sounding.French orchestras used to have a distinctive sound: Woodwinds were "nasal" (according to critics) and horns sounded like saxophones.The Lamoureux Orchestra of the 1950s was basically a virtuoso ensemble with slightly odd-sounding winds.Russian orchestras were influenced by the French, but England and America adopted the German sound, which has come to be the international standard.French composers of the Nineteenth and early Twentieth Centuries expected an orchestra to sound like this (Lamoureux gave the premiere of Debussy's La Mer in 1905).Martinon's successor, Igor Markevitch. maintained the Lamoureux's high standards in a series of stereo recordings for DG.In the mid-sixties, there was a reorganization of Paris orchestras, recruiting the best players from French and international orchestras to create the "Orchestre de Paris" (music directors Charles Munch and Herbert von Karajan).This depleted the Lamoureux Orchestra (the Paris Conservatoire Orchestra went away completely).Only the Orchestre de Paris and the O.R.T.F. (now called "Orchestre national de France") remain in the big leagues.Nowadays all orchestras sound the same.Progress.-----------------------------------------------------------------I haven't been able to locate a discography of Jean Martinon on the internet, so I thought I'd create one.Limited to CD reissues.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]DECCA: Complete Decca Recordings 1951 - 1960 issued in 2006 (deleted and insanely expensive), or reissued as individual CDs on Eloquence - five different orchestras, mono and stereoPHILIPS/ELOQUENCE: "The Philips Legacy" (the box under review), 1953-1956 Lamoureux Orchestra - monoDG/ELOQUENCE: Jean Martinon: The Complete Deutsche Grammophon Recordings 1 , 1960 and 1969-1971 Lamoureux Orchestra and O.R.T.F. - stereoSONY (RCA): Jean Martinon - The Complete Cso Recordings , 1964-1968 Chicago Symphony - stereoWARNER (EMI/HMV and ERATO): ICON - The late years (14CD)(the EMI Debussy, Ravel and Saint-Saens are not in this box, but are available separately)VOX: Prokofiev Symphonies and Overtures, 1971 O.R.T.F. - stereo----------------------------------------------------------Adam:- Giselle: highlights - 1959 Paris Conservatoire (DECCA)- Si j'Etais Roi Overture - 1951 London Philharmonic, mono (DECCA)Bartok:- Miraculous Mandarin Suite - 1967 Chicago (SONY) +1971  O.R.T.F. This was re-issued by Warner after they bought out EMI.The only difference is that now it has the blue Warner logo instead of the red EMI logo.Everything else is identical, so check both listings for the lower price.See Sviatoslav Richter: The Master Pianist

All of Sviatoslav Richter's recordings for Deutsche Grammophon, RCA, Columbia, EMI, Philips, Decca and Teldec have been released in four inexpensive mega-boxes.I thought it would be useful to prepare a combined index to the material.After a false start due to World War II, Richter's public career lasted fifty years - until his final concert in 1995.The first fifteen were spent behind the Iron Curtain - It wasn't until 1960 that he was allowed to visit the West.Once the dam had broken, Western companies rushed in to record Richter.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]-- Deutsche Grammophon was first: They actually jumped the gun by sending DG engineers to Prague in 1956 and Warsaw in 1958.-- In 1960, RCA and Columbia documented Richter's first North American tour:Thirteen CDs recorded over a ten week period. The most thorough documentation we have of Sviatoslav Richter in his absolute prime (seven recitals were recorded in their entirety).For the bizarre story of that tour, see my review of Complete Album Collection-- In 1961, Richter visited London - Philips recorded him in the Liszt Concertos, and EMI recorded him at their Abbey Road Studios.-- Decca waited until 1970, though later on they issued some 1960's recordings from Benjamin Britten's Aldeburgh Festival.-- Teldec made a few very late recordings with Richter in 1993-1994 (he retired in 1995).  Bach, Mozart and Schumann - all new to his recorded repertoire.Decca, Philips and Deutsche Grammophon are now owned by Universal = this review, 51 CDs (DECCA BOX)RCA and Columbia are owned by SONY = 18 CDs Complete Album CollectionEMI is owned by WARNER = 14 CDs Icon: Sviatoslav Richter (first edition was on the EMI label)TELDEC is owned by Warner, but their box is still on the TELDEC label = The Remarkable.WEBER:Sonata 3 = 1966 Locarno (DECCA BOX cd 6)WEBERN:Variations Op.27 = 1989 Vienna (DECCA BOX cd 32)WOLF:"Morike-Lieder" with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, baritone - 1973 Innsbruck (DECCA BOX cd 49)* The 1958 Sofia concert (Mussorgsky etc.) is not really a Western recording.Unlike DG, who sent their own engineers (and equipment) to Prague and Warsaw,Philips simply bought the tape from Bulgarian radio and issued it on LP in 1960.Terrible sound, fabulous performances.COMPLAINTS ABOUT THE DECCA, PHILIPS AND DG BOX (minor):-- The jackets for CDs 1-34 (solo piano) feature white print against a yellow background. Unreadable.-- CDs 1-25 and 29-32 are arranged in roughly chronological order (Bach through Shostakovich).CD 33 is a jumble of composers, in recordings made between 1966 and 1989.CD 34 is the famous 1958 Sofia, Bulgaria recital.CDs 26,27 and 28 are miscellanies that reproduce the contents of three DG LPs from the 1960s.Why not a straight chronological arrangement on CDs 1-33, and the Sofia concert on CD 34?-- For some reason, six solo piano works (Beethoven Sonatas 10, 19, 20, Liszt's Funerailles, Ave Maria, and Harmonies poetiques et religieuses) are distributed among "Chamber Music" (CD 40) and "Concertos" (CDs 43 and 44).-- Typographical Errors in the "Decca, Philips and DG" booklet:- page 9: Prokofiev Visions fugitives (CD 30) should be recorded 1979 not 1993- pages 9 and 69: The Rachmaninov Prelude (CDs 26 and 34) should be Op.32 No.12, not Op.32 No.13- page 10: Schubert Sonatas D575, D840 and D894 (CDs 15 and 16) are numbered as 11, 17 and 20. Traditionally numbered as 9, 15 and 18- pages 33-34: Beethoven Diabelli Variations (CD 14) - tracks 24-28 are Variations XXIV-XXVIII, not XIV-XVIII- page 61: Shostakovich Prelude and Fugue Op.87 No.14 (CD 30) should be E-flat minor not E-flat major- page 101: Schubert Grand Duo (CD 51) - track 14 is 13:05 not 3:13If you notice any other errors, please let me know in the Comments section (thanks to Ben B.)P.S. This "Decca, Philips and DG" box includes everything from these two earlier boxes:Solo RecordingsSviatoslav Richter - Complete DG Solo / Concerto Recordings

In the 1950s, Russian pianist Sviatoslav Richter was an almost mythical figure to music lovers in the West.He was was forbidden to travel beyond the Iron Curtain.Beginning in 1956, Deutsche Grammophon sent engineers to Prague and Warsaw to record Richter in improved sound,but the pianist's big breakthrough didn't really come until 1960, when Soviet authorities finally allowed him to visit the West.Between October 15 and December 28, Sviatoslav Richter embarked on an extended concert tour of the United States and Canada.Thirty concerts in 75 days. Fifteen cities.The two dominant American record companies, RCA and Columbia, each expressed an interest in recording Richter during his American tour.First stop was Chicago where he performed Brahms 2nd Piano Concerto with Erich Leinsdorf and the Chicago Symphony on October 15, 1960.Two days later it was recorded by RCA, which signed the pianist to a three LP contract.Next stop was New York City and Carnegie Hall, where he embarked on a marathon of five recitals in twelve days,October 19-30 (interrupted for a concert with the Philadelphia Orchestra on the 21st).Six concerts in twelve days is actually something of a stunt, but it certainly caught the attention of the New York press.[would any living pianist dare something like this?]The recitals were not broadcast, but back then Carnegie Hall routinely recorded performances for the personal use of the artist, using their in-house microphone system, which unfortunately dated back to the 1940s (medium-fi mono, obsolete by 1960).Columbia Records saw their opportunity, and negotiated a deal with Carnegie Hall and someone in the Soviet Ministry of Culture, allowing them to issue these taped recitals on LP.Consequently all five recitals were released on ten mono LPs by Columbia Records.RCA threatened legal action, claiming that Richter had signed an exclusive contract with them - at least for the American tour.RCA convinced the pianist to sign a letter demanding that the Columbia LPs be taken off the market.Columbia agreed to the recall and destroyed their inventory.[the account in the booklet paints Columbia Records as the innocent victim of Russian perfidy.]For 55 years, the few surviving LPs have commanded astronomical prices on the used record market.The continued non-availability of the Carnegie Hall recitals has created a mystique around them that may or may not be justified.Judge for yourself.This is the most thorough documentation we have of Sviatoslav Richter in his absolute prime.Twelve days of concentrated piano playing.Unedited.In response to popular demand, Richter returned to Carnegie Hall at the end of the tour for three additional concerts:-- On December 18, he appeared with Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic (Concertos by Liszt and Tchaikovsky).Unfortunately no recording session (Bernstein was a Columbia artist).-- The December 23 recital, all-Beethoven, was not recorded.-- The December 26 recital was recorded, this time by RCA using their own stereo microphones, plus a repeat program on December 28 across the river in Newark, New Jersey.Highlights from both were issued on a single RCA LP in 1965.The entire December 26 Carnegie Hall recital, plus the encores from December 28, were issued in a 2 CD set in 2005, "Richter Rediscovered".The rest of the December 28 recital appears for the first time in this new box.Luckily for us, RCA and Columbia are both now owned by Sony.The Cold War is over.After 55 years, we finally have a complete edition of Richter's 1960 American recordings:Seven public recitals on 13 CDs + 3 CDs worth of studio recordings (2 concertos, 3 sonatas).-- October 17: RCA STUDIO RECORDING (Chicago) = CD 1Brahms Piano Concerto 2 w/ Erich Leinsdorf, Chicago Symphony-- October 19: Carnegie Hall recital = CD 2+3Beethoven: Piano Sonatas No. 3, 9, 12, 22, 23 // Schubert: Impromptu Op.90, No.4 // Schumann: Fantasiestücke Op.12, No.2: Aufschwung // Chopin: Etudes Op.10, No.1 and 12-- October 21: [Concert with Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra (Concertos by Dvorak and Brahms). Not recorded.]-- October 23: Carnegie Hall recital = CD 4+5Prokofiev: Piano Sonatas No. 6, 8 + finale of Sonata 8 encored / Sonatine Pastorale, Op.59, No.3 / Paysage, Op.59, No.2 / Pensées - Andante Op.62, No.3-- October 25: Carnegie Hall recital = CD 6+7Haydn: Piano Sonata No.60, Hob.XVI No.50 // Schumann: Novellettes, Op.21, No.1,2,8 // Debussy: Suite bergamasque / Images, Book I / L'Isle joyeuse / Images, Book II, No.1 - Cloches a travers les feuilles / Préludes Book I, No.3 - Le vent dans la plaine / Préludes Book I, No.5 - Les collines d'Anacapri-- October 28: Carnegie Hall recital = CD 8+9Beethoven: Piano Sonata No. 7  // Schumann: Novellettes, Op.21, No.1,2,8 // Rachmaninoff: Preludes, Op.23, No.1,2,4,5,7,8 Op.32, No.1,2,6,7,9,10,12 // Chopin: Etude Op.10, No.3 / Mazurka Op.24, No.2 // Debussy: Images, Book II, No.1: Cloches a travers les feuilles // Prokofiev: Cinderella Op.95, No.2 - Gavotte-- October 30: Carnegie Hall recital = CD 10 * Schumann: Fantasie Op.17 // Chopin: Scherzo No.4 // Ravel: Pavane pour une infante défunte / Jeux d'eau / Miroirs No.2 - Oiseaux Tristes // Scriabin: Piano Sonata No.5 // Rachmaninoff: Prelude Op.32, No.12-- November 2,3: RCA STUDIO RECORDING (Boston) = CD 11Beethoven Piano Concerto 1 w/ Charles Munch, Boston Symphony-- November 29,30: RCA STUDIO RECORDING (New York) = CD 11+12Beethoven Piano Sonatas 12, 22 and 23-- December 26: Carnegie Hall recital = CD 13+14-- December 28: Newark recital - same program = CD 15+16Haydn: Piano Sonata No. 60, H.XVI No.50 // Chopin: Scherzo No. 4 / Ballade No. 3 // Rachmaninoff: Preludes Op. 23 No.1, Op. 32 No.9,10,12 // Ravel: Jeux d'eau / La Vallée des cloches  // Prokofiev: Piano Sonata No. 6-- Dec 26 encores: Prokofiev: Visions fugitives, Op.22 - Selections-- Dec 28 encores: Prokofiev: Cinderella Op.95, No.2 - Gavotte / Visions fugitives, Op.22, No.4 - Animato // Debussy: Préludes, Book I, No.5 - Les collines d'Anacapri // Chopin: Études Op.10, No.10,12 / Mazurka Op.24, No.2 in C----------------------------------------------------------------------------------* The October 30 recital on CD 10 is the only recital on one CD (73 minutes).The four earlier recitals are on two CDs and average 95 minutes each.[for a while I thought there might be some missing music, but this is the October 30 recital in its entirety.]The original printed program featured Liszt's Piano Sonata in B Minor as the first selection.At the last minute and after programs had been printed, Richter made the decision to substitute the Schumann Fantasie for the Liszt Sonata.This still wouldn't account for the short program: The Liszt and Schumann are approximately the same duration.There was only one encore [two nights earlier there had been seven encores]. Perhaps Richter was in a bad mood on the 30th.You'd never guess from the evidence on this CD.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SOUND QUALITY and PACKAGING:11 of the 13 CDs devoted to the 1960 recitals have been newly mastered at 24bit/96kHz by Sony's chief engineer Andreas K. Meyer.- The five October Carnegie Hall recitals, though mono, still sound pretty good. Better than I had expected.There is not a lot of high frequency information on these tapes, but low and mid-range reproduce well.I don't know how much high frequency information there was on the original tapes.They have always had a bad reputation.It was still a pleasant listening experience, once you get used to it.- Meyer also mastered the December 28 Newark recital.- The December 26 Carnegie Hall recital is the same Marion Conaty remastering used for "Richter Re-Discovered" (24bit/96kHz)No complaints.-- If you're concerned about the sound of the October Carnegie Hall recordings, try Disc 9, Track 12 in the free audio samples on Amazon's digital music page (or Disc 7, track 3 for some quiet playing):Sviatoslav Richter - The Complete Album Collection.Studio recordings: Brahms 2nd Piano Concerto is a new 24bit/96kHz remastering by Andreas K. Meyer (at least the third time it has been remastered for CD).Beethoven's 1st Piano Concerto and Piano Sonatas 12, 22 and 23 are XRCD remasterings by Kazuie Sugimoto of Sony Japan (they previously sold for $30/disc in North America).Everything sounds wonderful to me. The piano in the Sonatas is a bit clangy, but that's an accurate reproduction of Richter's Steinway.I may not be the best judge of sound - my ears are 65 years old (as is the rest of me)."Original jacket" mini-LP format. Original cover art with program notes on the back.Everything comes packaged in an attractive rigid cardboard box.56 page booklet with essay by Jed Distler.My only complaint is the lack of an index to the music on these CDs.Sony used to get a lot of complaints about the difficulty of removing CDs from their two-CD cardboard jackets.They must have listened, because this time two-LP sets are packaged as two single CDs with identical covers.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------After the 1960 North American tour, Richter's next Western appearance was another five-concert marathon, this time in London, July 8-18, 1961.Some, but not all of this has been released on BBC Classics.Unfortunately not in a systematic fashion.Nearly all of Sviatoslav Richter's public recitals were recorded- Authorized or not.He is the most pirated pianist in recorded history.There is an enormous data base of recordings:From 1960 alone, there are five recordings of Chopin's Etude Op.10, No.1 in C to choose from:Prague, Bucharest, Kiev, Moscow and New York.I will not attempt a comparative analysis of Richter's recordings.Way beyond my capabilities, and life is too short.I do think this box is one of the best ideas that Sony has ever come up with.And it doesn't even cost a lot.-------------------------------------------------------------------POINTS OF INTEREST:-- As someone will no doubt point out, the 75 day U.S tour was not actually Richter's first appearance outside the Communist Bloc:Between May 10 and 15, 1960, he gave three recitals in Finland.I don't think they were recorded.-- If the five October Carnegie Hall recitals seem to have had noisier audiences than the December 26 recital, blame the microphones.On December 26, RCA used directional microphones, more sophisticated than Carnegie's in-house microphone system that picked up everything indiscriminately.-- The account of the LP release of the Carnegie Hall recitals in the the Sony booklet goes into some detail.It looks bad for Schuyler Chapin of Columbia Records:Chapin asked the representative of MK (the Soviet Cultural Bureau) if this agreement had Richter's approval.Soon after he received a telegram from Richter confirming his OK.But the telegram was sent from Washington D.C at a time when Richter was in New York.Apparently Chapin never made an attempt to contact Richter personally, relying on intermediaries.-- re the October 30 Carnegie Hall recital: the fine print on page 44 of the booklet reads: "Original LPs: ML6065/6 in set M2L312 (release cancelled)"If the release had not been cancelled, I hope they would have corrected the glaring typographical error on the album cover: Schumann's Fantasia in C, Op.17 is credited to Schubert.The actual first LP release was in Japan in 1979.-- The December 28 recital was given in the "Mosque Theater" in Newark, New Jersey.No - It's not a real mosque. No connection to Islam.The Mosque Theater (original name "Salaam Temple") was a 3500 seat auditorium built in 1925 by the "Ancient Arabic Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine", better known as the Shriners.Still in use as an auditorium - renamed as "Newark Symphony Hall" so as not to offend.The Shriners are a North American charitable fraternity (related to the Masons) founded in 1870.They run children's hospitals and drive tiny cars while wearing red fezzes.In the early years of the Twentieth Century, they built a lot of auditoriums.In addition to the Mosque Theater in Newark, they built the 3700 seat "Syria Mosque" in Pittsburgh (1911-1991 R.I.P.) and the 4200 seat Medinah Temple in Chicago (famous as a recording venue for the Chicago Symphony), built in 1912 and still standing, though the interior has been gutted and is now home to Bloomingdale's Department Store.-- The October Carnegie Hall recitals were previously released on CD by the small Canadian label Doremi, but they were copied from commercial Columbia LP pressings, not the master tapes to which Sony has access.-- Sony's booklet claims that five selections are previously unreleased.In fact, four were omitted from the Columbia LPs (and Doremi CDs), and are appearing here for the first time:- Chopin: Etude Op.10, No. 12 in C Minor "Revolutionary" -- October 19- Debussy: Images Book II, No.1 - Cloches a travers les feuilles -- October 28- Prokofiev: Sonata 8, Op.84, finale encored -- October 23- Schumann: Novelettes Op.21, No.1, 2, 8 -- October 28See my comment dated January 24 for details.------------------------------------------------------------------------------LATE RECORDINGS:The 1960 Sviatoslav Richter was a far more fiery and risk-taking pianist than the mature Richter many of us have grown accustomed to.Tremendously exciting.As a bonus, the Sony box has two CDs of the mature Richter in concert at the 1988 Schleswig-Holstein Festival (previously released), plus some Schubert pieces recorded in concert at the Aldeburgh Festival.CD 17 = Aldeburgh, 1977 (first CD release)Schubert: Scherzo in D-flat D.593 / Andante in A D.604 / Four Landler D.366CD 17+18 = Schleswig-Holstein, 1988Beethoven: Piano Concerto 1 w/ Christoph Eschenbach, Schleswig-Holstein Festival Orchestra // Brahms: Sonata 1 // Chopin: Etudes Op.10, No. 1-4,6,11,12 // Liszt: Etudes d'exécution - Harmonies du Soir / Hungarian Rghapsody 17 / Scherzo & MarchThe 1977 Aldeburgh Festival recordings on CD 17 were last seen on a CBS Masterworks 3 LP set sponsored by cigarette manufacturer Benson & Hedges (no engineer is credited).The 1988 Schleswig-Holstein Festival recordings on CDs 17 and 18 appear to be straight reissues of the 1993 CD remasterings (no engineer is credited).-- Missing from the Sony box is the early '70s studio recording of Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier that RCA issued on 4 CDs in 1992: Well-Tempered Clavier, The (Richter)It was not an original RCA production, but was licensed from Melodiya.----------------------------------------------------------------------ALPHABETICAL INDEX TO THE SONY BOX:BEETHOVEN:Sonata 3 -- 1960 Carnegie Hall (SONY cd 2)Sonata 7 -- 1960 Carnegie Hall (SONY cd 8)Sonata 9 -- 1960 Carnegie Hall (SONY cd 2)Sonata 12 -
