No. 4 "Le poème de l'extase" (1952) -- monoStravinsky: Petrushka (1959) -- stereoStravinsky: `Sacre du printemps' (1951) -- monoTchaikovsky: Symphonies 4, 5 and 6 (1955-1959) -- stereo--- CHICAGO SYMPHONY:Franck: Symphony in D Minor (1961) -- stereo--- RCA VICTOR SYMPHONY, New York:Chausson: Poème de l'amour et de la mer with Gladys Swarthout (1952) -- mono--- BONUS CD: 80th Birthday Interview (1955)- All but one of Monteux's American recordings are in this box.His final American recording, Hummel's Trumpet Concerto with Armando Ghitalla and members of the Boston Symphony (1963 stereo) is available on Armando Ghitalla -Trumpet [IMPORT]--------------- PART THREE: EUROPEAN RECORDINGS, 1956 - 1964LONDON SYMPHONY:Brahms: Violin Concerto in D, Op. 77 with Henryk Szeryng (1959) -- stereoBetween 1956 and 1964, Monteux made a large number of stereo recordings with the London Symphony, Vienna Philharmonic, Amsterdam Concertgebouw and Paris Conservatoire Orchestras.Recorded by Decca, Philips and Westminster.Some Decca titles were released in North America by RCA, but the rights to all but the Brahms Violin Concerto are now owned by Universal, which owes the public a big box of Monteux's European recordings (it would be approximately 20 CDs).The 1961 'Daphnis et Chloe' with the London Symphony is especially recommended.Some Decca titles have recently been issued on Australian Eloquence.--------------- PART FOUR: OPERA, 1955 - 1957Gluck: `Orfeo et Eurydice' with Stevens, Della Casa and Rome Opera (1957 stereo)Verdi: `La Traviata' with Carteri, Valletti, Warren and Rome Opera (1956 mono)But Monteux's best-known opera recording was a joint EMI/RCA project:Massenet's `Manon' with Victoria de los Angeles, recorded in Paris (1955 mono).All rights have reverted to EMI.Currently available on: ManonAfter World War II, Monteux regularly appeared at New York's Metropolitan Opera, where he was typecast as a French specialist (Rudolf Bing wouldn't let him conduct Verdi or Wagner).A 1955 Met broadcast of Offenbach's `Tales of Hoffmann' is in Sony's  Metropolitan Opera Live series: Offenbach: Les Contes d'Hoffmann (Metropolitan Opera) (mono)SOUND QUALITY and PACKAGING:Back in 1994, RCA/BMG issued a 15 CD Pierre Monteux Edition boxed set.That accounts for about two-thirds of the material in this new box (the old box was not an original jacket production so individual CD timings were longer), and about half the remasterings.Sonically, the earliest of the wartime San Francisco recordings are nothing special, but the situation had improved by 1945 (the 1945 Rite of Spring on CD 5 is astonishing).RCA concentrated most of their engineering talent in Boston and New York.This is reflected in the superior sound of Monteux's 1951-1954 mono recordings, made in those two cities.Monteux's 1955-1961 Boston and Chicago stereo recordings (Debussy, Franck, Khachaturian, Saint-Saens, Stravinsky and Tchaikovsky) were among the highlights of RCA's "Living Stereo" LP catalog, and are still of demonstration quality.The London Symphony recording of the Brahms Concerto with Szeryng was actually produced by Decca Records in 1959.Excellent "ffrr" stereo sound.Attention Audiophiles: the 1950 Berlioz Symphonie fantastique, 1950 Franck D Minor Symphony, 1951 Brahms Symphony 2, 1952 Schumann Symphony 4, 1953 Mozart Piano Concerti, 1958 Brahms Violin Concerto and 1959 Tchaikovsky Symphony 4 are XRCD remasterings by Hiromichi Takiguchi of Sony Japan (they previously sold for $30/disc in North America).Hard to believe that the finale of the Symphonie fantastique was recorded 65 years ago.Spectacular."Original Jacket" mini-LP format beginning with CD 11 (the 1950 LP reissue of the 1942 Scheherezade).Original cover art with program notes on the back.CDSs 1-10 are 78rpm recordings that were never issued on LP: Plainish jackets with contents printed on the back.Everything comes packaged in an attractive rigid cardboard box.110 page booklet with full discographic information, an index to the recordings, and essay by Monteux biographer John Canarina.Unfortunately no texts or translations for the operas.Inevitable with these bargain boxes, but still sad.Also, for some reason, the 2-CD opera sets get no program notes, just 3 blank pages.Plot summaries for the Brahms, Chausson and Mahler vocal works are reproduced with the original program notes.POINTS OF INTEREST- Delibes: Prelude et Mazurka from Coppelia (CD 26) is RCA's earliest surviving stereo recording - December 2, 1953.- Debussy: La Mer was recorded in stereo on July 19, 1954 but CD 27 presents the entire work in mono as it was issued on LP, aside from a 4:23 fragment in stereo.Explanation in the booklet: "The entire recording was made in stereo and was edited for release, but the edited tape got lost, with the result that, even though the stereo master of Nocturnes did survive, the coupling was originally issued in mono. The surviving stereo take from La Mer shows the extreme clarity that the two-microphone pickup techniques provided at that time."The edited tape "got lost".Good grief.- Brahms: Alto Rhapsody with Marian Anderson (CD 18), recorded 1950, is conducted by Fritz Reiner.Monteux conducted the singer's first recording of the work (CD 5), recorded in 1945.- Chausson: 'Poème de l'amour et de la mer' with Gladys Swarthout (CD 24), recorded 1952, is conducted by Monteux, but the coupled French song recital is accompanied by pianist George Troville.- Stravinsky: 'Sacre du printemps' Two RCA recordings of 'The Rite of Spring' are included:The 1951 Boston Symphony version (CD 15) is usually regarded as the best of Monteux's four commercial recordings.The 1945 San Francisco version (CD 5) clearly is played by a lesser orchestra, but the sense of strain has its own rewards -In the opening solo the Boston bassoonist, playing in his highest register, makes a beautiful sound;the San Francisco player sounds like he is about to have a stroke (not inappropriate).This is the first CD release of the March 10, 1945 recording of The Rite of Spring(it was only in RCA's catalog for six years before being replaced by the Boston version).It's the most brutal of Monteux's four recordings.I wonder if the date of the recording had anything to do with it?Impressive achievement.Now my preferred 'Sacre du printemps'.- Richard Strauss: Death and Transfiguration (CD 38), recorded 1960.During World War I, shortly after his arrival in neutral America,Pierre Monteux created a mini-scandal in the New York press when he refused to conduct the music of Richard Strauss on the grounds that he was an enemy composer (Monteux had no objection to conducting the work of dead Germans).In December, 1944 Monteux received word that his favorite brother Henri had perished in a Nazi concentration camp.In Henri's memory, he programmed the still-living Richard Strauss' Death and Transfiguration at the next concert."It shall be my message and my prayer for my brother".

These are not tasteful performances.Big orchestra Mozart with a vengeance.NEW TO CD:- Piano Concerto 20 in D Minor k466 with Maria Isabella De Carli and the International Youth Festival Orchestra of St. Moritz, Switzerland.This is one of Stokowski's rarest studio recordings (1969 stereo).It was not intended for public sale.Only issued on a souvenir LP given to the young musicians who took part in the 1969 Festival.Apparently the idea was to give as many students as possible the opportunity to play under the 87 year-old legend.It sounds like a hundred piece orchestra with doubled winds (tripled? quadrupled?).Tremendously exciting performanceNot much subtlety.Thanks to skilled engineering, the excellent pianist is not drowned out by all this noise.There is no other recording of a Mozart Concerto remotely like it.- Piano Concerto 24 in C Minor k491 with Ezra Rachlin and the Houston Symphony is from a radio broadcast (1960 mono?).Another exciting performance.Another big orchestra, But not quite so insanely large as in the D Minor concerto.The label says "mono", but I hear some limited channel separation over headphones.- Overture to "The Marriage of Figaro" with the Philadelphia Orchestra is from a radio broadcast (1960 stereo) made during Stokowski's historic return to the orchestra he had led from 1912 to 1940.Decent broadcast stereo.I wonder what music lovers under the age of forty who grew up listening to Mozart conducted by Hogwood, Norrington and Gardiner will make of all this.I loved it.ALREADY RELEASED ON CD:- German Dance k605,No.3 "Sleigh Ride" - N.Y. pickup orchestra (1949 mono)- Rondo alla Turca in Stokowski's orchestration  - NBC Symphony (1955 mono)These are the same RCA recordings that have already been issued on CD by Cala - Less conveniently coupled there as fillers for other composer's work.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------These are the only surviving recordings of these works conducted by Stokowski.In addition, Stokowski recorded five additional Mozart compositions:- Sinfonia Concertante k297b with the Philadelphia Orchestra (1940 mono) Stokowski -- Beethoven: Symphony No. 6; Mozart: Sinfonia Concertante for Winds- Symphony 35 with the New York Philharmonic (1949 mono broadcast) Vaughan Williams: Symphony No. 6 / Tchiakovsky: Romeo and Juliet / Mozart: Symphony No. 35 / Scott: From the Sacred Harp / Weinberger: Polka and Fugue from Schwanda the Bagpiper- Piano Concerto 21 in C k 467 with Dame Myra Hess and the New York Philharmonic (1949 mono broadcast) Myra Hess: Public Performances, 1949 - 1960- Serenade k361 with the American Symphony (1966 stereo) Vivaldi / J. S. Bach / Corelli / Mozart- Overture to "Don Giovanni" with the National Philharmonic (1976 stereo) Stokowski Showcase / Stokowski, National Phil Orch

My 30 pound beagle ran after a rabbit she saw and the line snapped off.And I bought the large heavy duty version just so something like this wouldn't happen.Also the 30 day return window had expired - This happened 45 days after I bought it.My beagle returned after thirty minutes.She was OK, I don't know about the rabbit.

My 30 pound beagle ran after a rabbit she saw and the line snapped off.And I bought the large heavy duty version just so something like this wouldn't happen.Also the 30 day return window had expired - This happened 45 days after I bought it.My beagle returned after thirty minutes.She was OK, I don't know about the rabbit.

Three One-Act Operettas by Jacques Offenbach:"Le Mariage aux Lanternes" = "The Betrothal by Lantern Light" (1857)"Le Fifre enchante" or "Le Soldat magician" = "The Enchanted Fife Player" or "The Soldier Magician" (1864)"L'ile de Tulipatan" = "The Isle of Tulipatan" (1868)Before anyone reports me to Amazon, let me point out that "Grosser Querschnitt" is German for "Highlights" (literally "Greater Cross-Section").Performed in German translation:"Die Verlobung bei der Latern", "Die kleine Zauberflote", und "Die Insel Tuilipatan".Each opera is slightly under a half-hour in length.Pretty sure they are "Grosser Querschnitt".Hanssler Classics is a label with a reputation for quality production values, but they dropped the ball this time.There is a 16 page booklet, but no plot summaries.Not a paragraph.Nice bouncy music, annoying German dialogue, but I wonder what's going on.[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]"L'ile de Tulipatan" has been recorded once before, complete and in French: Offenbach: L'ile de Tulipatan (The Island of Tulipatan)This 1984 recording times in at 60:33 versus 29:38 for the Kleiber/Hanssler which confirms my suspicion that the latter is "Grosser Querschnitt".I'm pretty sure that "Le Mariage aux Lanternes" and "Le Fifre enchante" have never been recorded before.Recorded from German television in 1962 (limited mono sound).The video no longer exists.Carlos Kleiber is a conductor who I normally award five stars as a matter of course, but I am withholding one due to the inadequate presentation by Hanssler.This is the earliest documentation we have of Carlos Kleiber conducting.He didn't really hit the big time until eleven years later when he signed with Deutsche Grammophon: Carlos Kleiber: Complete Orchestral Recordings on Deutsche GrammophonePLOT SUMMARIES (You're welcome)----------- "Le Mariage aux Lanternes" (1857)Pierre is secretly in love with his orphan cousin Denise, who was entrusted to his care by their wealthy uncle.Pierre hides his feelings by treating her roughly, driving the young girl to despair.Both write to their uncle: Pierre for money, Denise for advice.Pierre receives a letter from his uncle telling him that a treasure may be found under the great tree in the village when the evening church bells peal.Denise enters, reading a letter from her uncle telling her that she will find a good husband underneath the great tree in the village when the evening church bells peal.She falls asleep under the tree.Pierre arrives with his spade and lantern.He hears Denise speak his name in her sleep, and understands that she is his uncle's promised treasure.By the light of the lanterns of villagers, who have come to the church for Evening Vespers, they agree to wed.General celebration.---------- "L'ile de Tulipatan" (1868)Rombodal is Prime Minister to Cacatois XXII, King of Tulipatan.He blames his wife Théodorine for their daughter Hermosa's tomboyish behaviour.Hermosa is in love with Prince Alexis, the charming and gracious heir to King Cacatois.Hermosa and Prince Alexis burst into a love duet, but are surprised by the return of her parents.Alarmed, her mother confesses a dark secret to her daughter.She is really a boy - an interminable war eighteen years earlier made her mother fearful that her son would be drafted into the army.Therefore she passed Hermosa off as a girl.Romboïdal returns and reveals to his daughter that King Cacatois was so determined to have a male heir after three daughters that the Queen conspired to pass off their most recent daughter as a son - and for 18 years Prince Alexis has believed she is a boy.Prince Alexis overhears this conversation.Hermosa now re-enters dressed as a dashing guards officer, accompanied by Prince Alexis in a dress.After a barcarolle, King Cacatois enters to demand that Romboïdal and Théodorine consent to the marriage of their daughter to his son Prince Alexis.The couple eventually reveal the deception to their ruler.Cacatois agrees to the marriage, then declares that he will remarry and try again for a son.---------- "Le Fifre enchante" (1864)I haven't been able to find a plot summary for "Le Fifre enchante" (1864)I did find the complete French libretto with piano accompaniment in pdf form:[...]If you can read French, all music lovers and the ghost of Offenbach would be grateful if you would post an English summary in the Comments section at the end of this review.

Don't forget the video at the top of Amazon's web page.Wow."Phase 4 Stereo" was the brainchild of Decca Records (London Records in America).Starting in 1961, the label produced over 300 LPs of "Easy Listening" music.Lots of percussion and gimmicky stereo imaging, designed to show off your new home entertainment center.There was also a "Concert Series" of 190 LPs devoted to light classical music - Once again, Lots of percussion and gimmicky stereo imaging.At first, Camarata and Stanley Black were borrowed from the "Easy Listening" Division.But in 1964, classical music heavyweight Leopold Stokowski was recruited to record Rimsky-Korsakov's "Scheherezade" in Phase 4 Stereo with the London Symphony.Not as gimmicky as the early Phase 4 recordings, but more gimmicky than what the classical record buyer was accustomed to.Stokowski went on to record a total of 22 LPs (+ 6 greatest hits anthologies) for Phase 4.Precisely half of them are in this new box, which is cause for complaint.Stokowski deserves an entire box to himself, gathering together all his Decca and Philips recordings from the '60s and '70s.For this Phase 4 box, a token Stokowski CD would have been sufficient- thereby freeing up space for some Phase 4 recordings not yet on CD (see the next five paragraphs).Other heavyweight conductors who recorded for Phase 4:- Antal Dorati: 6 LPs, 5 are in this box  (missing Johann Strauss Waltzes),- Charles Munch: 3 LPs, all are here- Arthur Fiedler : 4 LPs, all are here- Anatole Fistoulari: 2 LPs + a 3 LP set (Tchaikovsky's Swan Lake is here - missing Tchaikovsky Symphony 4 + Brahms Piano Concerto 2 with Ilana Vered)- Erich Leinsdorf: 4 LPs (Mahler and Wagner are here - missing R.Strauss Rosenkavalier Suite + Stravinsky Petrushka & Rite of Spring)- Lorin Maazel: 3 LPs (R.Strauss, Tchaikovsky and Prokofiev are here - missing Mussorgsky-Ravel Pictures + Chopin Piano Concerto 1 with Israela Margalit)Lesser-known house conductors Stanley Black, Henry Lewis, Eric Rogers and Robert Sharples are represented, but Phase 4 stalwarts Camarata (14 LPs) and Carlos Paita (6 LPs) were snubbed completely.Stanley Black is represented by 5 CDs, one third of his classical total.House pianists were Ivan Davis and Ilana Vered.Inexplicably absent is the great pianist Rudolph Firkusny who recorded two Beethoven LPs for Phase 4.MOVIE MUSIC:There was a series devoted to film scores.Conducted by Stanley Black ("Film Spectaculars" Vol. 1-5 - not in this box)and composer Miklos Rozsa ("Ben Hur" - in this box, but "Quo Vadis" is missing).But the most important film recordings were conducted by composer Bernard Herrmann.His own scores and those of others, plus a concert series (Holst's "Planets" was a best-seller).Fourteen LPs, but only two are in this box.This is the biggest disappointment.Included: "Music for Alfred Hitchcock Thrillers", plus Science Fiction Film Scores.BLOATED SPECTACLEThere were a number of Phase 4 audio documentaries on LP.Not high-brow BBC documentaries."Battle Stereo", conducted by Robert Sharples was typical: Actors accompanied by military music and EXPLOSIONS!Modified original jacket format: 4 Fiedler LPs = 3 CDs, 3 Munch LPs = 2 CDs, etc.See the detailed list of performers at the end of this review.CONFESSION:I haven't bought this box. Yet.I have all the Dorati, Fiedler, Munch and Stokowski recordings in their previous CD incarnations.More than half the contents of this rather expensive new box.The Fistoulari complete `Swan Lake" is tempting - this is its first CD release,But everything else is of marginal appeal.The Leinsdorf and Maazel look interesting, but I'm not sure if I want all those Stanley Black recordings.Who knows? Maybe I do.If the price comes down I will certainly buy it.The five star rating is for people new to "Phase 4" and for rich people who don't mind the duplications.I am extremely annoyed by all the missing stuff - Especially the twelve LPs of Bernard Herrmann and the two Rudolph Firkusny LPs.Eleven LPs of Leopold Stokowski are missing, but I already have them on earlier CDs.It seems like this could have been better planned.SOUNDI can't comment on the sound.Normal standards for "Concert Hall Realism" do not apply anyway.The Phase 4 Concert Series was not marketed to serious classical music lovers with audiophile equipment.Their intended target was the popular music listener with a healthy curiosity, and a modest home stereo.I was the intended target.I was a fifteen year old Beatles fan in 1964, with no background in classical music.Stokowski's "Scheherazade" was one of my first classical LP purchases."Phase 4" should not be confused with the four channel recording fad of the 1970s.These are two channel recordings.The original recording sessions involved 20 microphones, which were recorded directly to a four channel master tape (one channel reserved for percussion), which was then mixed down to a two channel master tape.I wonder if the four channel master tapes still even exist?Universal seems to have given up on surround sound SACD in favor of Blu-Ray Audio - with new boxed sets of Beethoven and Strauss conducted by Karajan, Wagner's Ring by Solti, and a tribute to Carlos Kleiber.The first three are two-channel audio, but the Carlos Kleiber box features 2 hours, 38 minutes of hi-def surround sound: Carlos Kleiber: Complete Orchestral Recordings on Deutsche GramophoneWHAT IF?IF THE FOUR CHANNEL MASTER TAPE STILL EXISTS,We might some day be treated to a very interesting Blu-Ray Audio collection of "Phase 4 in Surround Sound".Gimmicky, but true to the spirit of Phase 4.But the box at hand is composed of standard two channel CDs.Oh, Well.P.S. For a complete Phase 4 discography, check outhttp://www.endlessgroove.com/lphase4/lp4discog.htm--------------------------------- ALPHABETICAL LIST OF CONDUCTORS IN THIS BOX:Rodney Bashford: Sousa Marches (Band of the Grenadier Guards)Stanley Black:- Gershwin Rhapsody in Blue, An American in Paris / Variations on "I got rhythm" (David Parkhouse/Bernard Herrmann)- Khachaturian Gayaneh, Masquerade, Spartacus Ballet Suites- Ravel Boléro / Borodin Polovtsian Dances / Rimsky-Korsakov Capriccio Espagnol / Tchaikovsky Capriccio Italien- "Spectacular Dances"- "Americana" (Robert Merrill baritone)Antal Dorati:- Dvorák Symphony No.9 "From the New World" / Kodály Háry János Suite- Orff Carmina Burana- Prokofiev Peter and the Wolf, Lieutenant Kijé / Britten Young  Person's Guide to the Orchestra (Sean Connery narrator)- Rossini-Respighi La Boutique fantasque, RossinianaArthur Fiedler:- Gershwin Overtures etc.- J. Strauss Waltzes / Tchaikovsky Nutcracker Suite- "Fiedler Encores" / Grieg Peer Gynt SuiteAnatole Fistoulari: Tchaikovsky Swan Lake (complete on 2 CDs)Bernard Herrmann:- "Music from the Great Hitchcock Movie Thrillers"- "Journey to the Centre of the Earth"Erich Leinsdorf:- Mahler Symphony No.1 "Titan" / Wagner Tannhäuser Overture and Venusberg MusicHenry Lewis:- Beethoven: Symphony No.6 "Pastoral" / R. Strauss Till Eulenspiegel- Bizet "Carmen" excerpts (Marilyn Horne) / Tchaikovsky Symphony No.6 "Pathétique"Lorin Maazel:- R.Strauss Tod und Verklärung / Tchaikovsky Francesca da Rimini / Prokofiev Piano Concerto No.3 (Israela Margalit)Charles Munch:- Bizet Carmen and L'Arlésienne Suites- Offenbach Gaîté parisienne  / Respighi Pines and Fountains of RomeEric Rogers:- "Immortal Works of Albert Ketèlbey" / Violin Encores (Josef Safonov)Miklos Rózsa: Music from "Ben Hur"Robert Sharples: "Battle Stereo" (Bloated Spectacle) / "Magnificent Voice of Eileen Farrell"Leopold Stokowski:- Beethoven Symphony No.9, Egmont Overture- Berlioz Symphonie fantastique, Damnation de Faust Ballet des Sylphes / Ravel Daphnis et Chloé Suite No. 2, Fanfare pour "L'Eventail de Jeanne"- Mussorgsky Pictures at an Exhibition, Boris Godunov Symphonic Synthesis, Night on Bare Mountain (all orch. Stokowski) / Tchaikovsky 1812 Overture- Rimsky-Korsakov Scheherazade, Capriccio espagnol / Borodin Polovtsian Dances from Prince Igor- Tchaikovsky Symphony No.5 / Glazunov Violin Concerto in A minor (Sylvia Marcovici)- Tchaikovsky Swan Lake, Sleeping Beauty selections, Romeo and Juliet, Marche slave- Vivaldi The Four Seasons, Op.8 (Hugh Bean violin)- Wagner Orchestral Masterpieces from the Ring of the Nibelung- Orchestral Transcriptions: JS Bach / Byrd / Clarke / Schubert / Chopin / Tchaikovsky / Duparc / Rachmaninov-------------------------------------------- INSTRUMENTALISTS, VOCALISTS:Ivan Davis, piano:- Liszt Piano Concerti (Edward Downes conductor) / Rachmaninov Piano Concerto No.2 (Henry Lewis)Eileen Farrell, soprano: "The Magnificent Voice of Eileen Farrell" (Robert Sharples)Marilyn Horne, mezzo:  Bizet "Carmen" highlights (Henry Lewis)Robert Merrill, baritone: "Americana" (Stanley Black)Paco Peña, guitar: "Flamenco Live" with lots of castanets and dancing feet. Arriba!Ruggerio Ricci, violin:- Mendelssohn / Tchaikovsky Violin Concerti (Jean Fournet)Ilana Vered, piano:- Yellow River Concerto / Mozart Piano Concerto No.21 (Lawrence Foster)- Beethoven Piano Sonata No.21 "Waldstein" / Schubert Fantasy in C major "Wanderer" / Stravinsky Three Movements from Petrouchka

There is no such thing as Janos Starker's "Warner Legacy".This box contains seven CDs of his "EMI Legacy" (1956-1959)plus three CDs of his "Erato Legacy" (Beethoven & Brahms Sonatas from 1959).EMI first released CDs 1-6 as "L'Introuvables du Janos Starker" in 1994, a boxed set that had some problems.The Dohnanyi, Milhaud and Prokofiev Concerti in that box were mono, but are now quite decent stereo.- CD 10 consists of previously unreleased EMI stereo recordings (53 minutes of encores).CHAMBER MUSIC:- Bach: Suites (6) for Unaccompanied Cello, BVV 1007-1012 (1957-1959, 1,2,3,5 mono, 4,6 stereo)- Beethoven: Sonatas (5) for Cello and Piano - Gyorgy Sebok, piano (1959 stereo)- Brahms: Sonatas (2) for Cello and Piano - Gyorgy Sebok, piano (1959 stereo)- Kodaly: Sonata for Unaccompanied Cello, Op. 8 (1957 stereo)-  "Encores & Showpieces - Part 1" by Bach, Chopin, Debussy, Kreisler, Mussorgsky, Paganini, Saint-Saens, Schubert, Schumann, Tcherepnin - with Gerald Moore, piano (1958 mono)-  "Encores & Showpieces - Part 2" by Bach, Chopin, Davidoff, Delej, Dinicu, Handel, Hindemith, Liadov, Pergolesi, Popper, Ravel, Rubinstein, Saint-Saens, Valensin - with Gerald Moore, piano (1959 stereo, first publication)CELLO & ORCHESTRA with the Philharmonia:- Boccherini: Cello Concerto in B flat, G.482  - Carlo Maria Giulini (1958 stereo)- Dohnanyi: Konzertstuck, Op. 12  - Walter Susskind (1956 stereo)- Dvorak: Cello Concerto, Op. 104 - Susskind (1956 stereo)- Faure: Elegie in C Minor, Op. 24 - Susskind (1956 stereo)- Haydn: Cello Concerto 2 in D Major - Giulini (1958 stereo)- Milhaud: Cello Concerto No. 1, Op. 101 - Susskind (1956 stereo)- Prokofiev: Cello Concerto in E Minor, Op. 58 - Susskind (1956 stereo)- Saint-Saens: Cello Concerto No. 1, Op. 33 - Giulini (1957 stereo)- Schumann: Cello Concerto in A Minor, Op. 129 - Giulini (1957 stereo)Mstislav Rostropovich, with his larger-than-life personality, tended to overshadow every other cellist in the second half of the Twentieth Century (at least in the public mind).The great Hungarian-American cellist Janos Starker (1924-2013) was perhaps too modest for his own good.Between 1945 and 1958, Starker was one of the world's most-sought after orchestral cellists;In 1953, at age 29, Fritz Reiner appointed him principal cello of the Chicago Symphony (that's him in the third movement of Emil Gilel's 1958 RCA recording of Brahms Second Piano Concerto).In 1958, at age 34, Starker unexpectedly left Chicago and retired to Bloomington, Indiana, where he spent the remaining 55 years of his life teaching young cellists at the University of Indiana.Surprisingly, his other career as a concert cellist, which lasted into the 21st Century, was a part-time occupation.According to the booklet, all EMI recordings were newly remastered in 2014, correcting the problems from "L'Introuvables du Janos Starker".The three CDs of Erato remasterings date from 1994 (everything sounds fine to me).[hint: for ease of navigation, read the review though to the end, then come back and click on the links.]In the 1960's Starker launched a new series of recordings for the American label Mercury.Most of these have been reissued in a 10 CD box: János Starker - The Mercury Recordings (Decca box set), which is the main rival to the Warner box.Unfortunately, there is a lot of duplication between the two: The Bach Suites, the Brahms Sonatas, and three Cello Concertos.Starker's interpretations hadn't really changed that much.In the the Concertos of Dvorak, Saint-Saens and Schumann, it is the Philharmonia Orchestra under Giulini and Susskind (Warner) versus the London Symphony under Dorati and Skrowaczewski (Mercury).As interpretations, I prefer Dorati/Mercury in Dvorak and Giulini/Warner in Saint-Saens and Schumann, so its a toss-up.Mercury adds the Lalo Concerto, Bruch's Kol Nidrei, and Tchaikovsky's Rococo Variations.Warner is much more generous, adding Concertos by Boccherini, Haydn, Milhaud and Prokofiev, plus Dohnanyi's Konzertstuck and Faure's Elegie.The Warner box is also a lot more adventurous: The Dohnanyi and Milhaud are rarities, andthe Prokofiev Concerto, Op.56, is the seldom-heard original version of the Sinfonia Concertante, Op.125.Both boxes have the Brahms Sonatas with Gyorgy Sebok, piano: 1959 versus 1964 - I can't tell the difference.Warner adds the Beethoven Sonatas.Mercury adds Sonatas by Bach, Chopin, Mendelssohn and Debussy, plus some baroque cello sonatas (available as single CDs).Warner has two CDs worth of "Encores and Showpieces": lighter music, most of which he never recorded again.At present, the Warner box costs significantly less than the Mercury box.Kodaly's Sonata for Unaccompanied Cello, Op.8, is a Twentieth Century classic.It has been recorded over forty times.Starker, who studied with Kodaly in Budapest in the 1930s, is the work's definitive interpreter- He made the first recording in 1948, he would return to it again in 1950, 1957 (in the Warner box) and 1970 (Janos Starker plays Kodály)[misprint: the Warner booklet claims that the 1957 recording of the Kodaly is stereo, but it is mono.]----- Later in life, Starker re-recorded much of this repertoire for other labels.The Bach Suites in 1994 for RCA: Bach: 6 Cello Suites Bwv 1007-1012 - Sony Classical MastersThis pretty much supersedes the Mercury version as an example of the mature Starker's Bach playing.In 1978, he re-recorded the Beethoven Sonatas for Teldec with Rudolf Buchbinder: Beethoven: Complete Works for Cello & PianoTeldec is now owned by Warner.This should have been in the "Warner Legacy" box.Too bad they forgot it.Every serious cello student should invest in the new Warner box.

This bra provides some stretch, but it was not enough stretch to accommodate my body during the later stages of pregnancy.  I had to order some bra extenders, and now that I have them, the product is pretty comfortable.  The bra lacks underwire but does have a thin layer of padding for modesty.  Unclipping a side is easy enough, but I'm not always able to unclip with one hand.  I like that the segments connecting portions of the bra are made with metal.  I've had bras that have plastic connectors and they just don't hold up.  If you are ordering toward the end of pregnancy, I would size up or order an extender.I received a complimentary product for review.

This assortment of bamboo towels is a great way to test an alternative to cotton towels.  While thin, the towels are very soft and silky.  They absorb liquids well and I've found that they wash and dry nicely  (they've gone through two washes thus far).  With each stint in the dryer, they have become a bit more fluffy.  The most obvious purpose for these is for body cleansing, however,  due to the softness, I may try these as liners for cloth diapers for an additional layer of soft absorbency.  I have several cloth diapers that are the same composition of 70% bamboo and 30% cotton and this combination is absorbent, soft, and gentle on baby's skin.  As a simple holiday gift, these would pair well with a nice body wash or hand soap.I received a discounted or complimentary sample for review.

Most of the dog beds I have purchased in recent years have come from stores like K Mart, Big Lots, or Target.  They were all nice beds, but after a year of use, the sides were floppy or the stuffing had disintegrated.  That could very well happen with this bed; I've only had it for a month.  However, compared to the other beds that I purchased, this one is substantially more heavy from the get go.For my two dogs, I selected the large bed.  One is a 30 pound puggle and the other is a 35 pound husky shepherd mix.  Only one dog can fit in the bed at a time, but I expected that.  While both of my dogs are medium sized, the puggle is a much better fit for this bed than the husky shepherd and that is solely based on the overall length of the puggle's body compared to the husky shepherd's.  The puggle is shorter and stockier and the husky shepherd is leaner and longer.  I am very glad that I did not go with the smaller bed for my dogs because it would have become a cat bed.The color on the bed I received - particularly the blue component - is much more low-key than what is shown in the stock image.  I find that to be great.  I don't want my pet's furniture to be the center of attention.The fabric on this is different than other beds I have had. Many of the other beds I have owned utilized a surface that was easier to wipe clean.  This cover can be removed and washed in the event your furry one excessively sheds or deposits something in the bed that is not easily cleaned.  The product has zippers to remove the exterior component from the interior ones for washing purposes.  Placing the cover back onto the interior pillows requires some manipulation and tucking.Overall, I like this bed and my puggle likes this bed. It is easy for her to get in and out of and she likes to drag her toys into it.  For a dog bed, the cost is more substantial than others.  I think it will take multiple washes and at least a few months to determine if this product will match the initial appearance of durability and quality that it initially presents.  Update to come.Disclaimer:  I received a discounted or complimentary product for review purposes.

I wear a ladies size 10 shoe and I found these socks to fit well even during pregnancy when my feet were exceptionally swollen.  The socks have a good bit of stretch to them, which makes them comfortable for daylong wear.The thickness was better than anticipated.  I would not classify these as winter socks (at least for an Ohio winter), but they would definitely work for the other three seasons of the year.The color assortment is nice - white, black, and grey - which makes it easy to match socks to outfits.  A small but nice detail is that each sock has a different color used on the toe and heel.  In my house, there is a major problem when it comes to matching socks.  While we are finally using sock clips, we still have quite a few  wandering, unmatched socks in black and white.  It can be a difficult task to search through a pile of similarly colored white and black socks to find sock partners.  So, I love the different toe colors on these socks.  It makes it easier to pinpoint where the match is in a pile of socks.The height of the sock is good for me.  When I work out, I prefer socks to peek outside of the top of the shoe to prevent rubbing and these do accomplish that.The set of six socks came in a box that can be quickly wrapped for gift giving.  While the box is easy to wrap, it does have some strange phrasing.  Inside the lid is the sentence, "Thank you for your patience."  On the side of the box are little snippets like "healthy and comfortable" and "buy with confidence" next to a recycling symbol.  No where on the box is the product of origin specified, however, the customer service line uses a country code of 86, which is China.Ultimately, I wouldn't hesitate to give these as gifts to someone I was close to, so long as I knew that the person had a shoe size that would work well with these.I received a discounted or free product for review purposes.

This is a really nice assortment of socks with distinct patterns to assist in the matching process post-washing.  I love the little grippers on the socks to help young ones with their traction.  Also, the patterns would work for boys and girls.  I'm not above giving socks as holiday gifts and kids always tend to lose them, so these would make a good stocking stuffer.Currently, the product description indicates that the socks "Fit for 0-3 years baby" but this is not correct and if you are wondering what part of the age spectrum these are truly for, it is for toddlers (2-3 years) and definitely not those under a year unless you have a monster size baby.  I washed the socks and they did not shrink, so they will be going into storage until my little one grows a bit.All in all, I like this product, but I do wish the socks were smaller.I received a complimentary or discounted item for review purposes.

I have two dogs - one that eats like a 99 year old and another that could consume all her food in 15 seconds if I didn't add water to it and crunchy stuff like apples and carrots.  The slow-eating pup often needs encouragement in the way of wet dog food or pieces of treats to start eating.  Unfortunately, I don't have hours to wait for her to eat, so I oblige her affection for treats.  This product is an easy way to make a dry kibble more appealing.  The bags are full of soft dog food that apparently have a delightful smell and taste.  I just open up the bag and poor half on her kibble and swirl it around.  I know there are foods out that there that already have a mix of soft and hard kibble, but I'm able to adjust the amount of soft treats in my slow-eating dog's food with these single-serve bags.

It appears that this product is not intended to have a very long lifespan. The fabric is very thin and snags much too easily on the velcro.  Because the closure is velcro, lint and strings attach to the velcro which weakens the effectiveness of the closure.  A couple of buttons along the top in place of velcro would have made the closure better.  There is some stretch to the fabric, but I don't see how this one size fits most towel will work for a lot of people - kids sure but any fit adult male at 200 lbs  will likely find this towel to be inadequate in terms of width. The length of the towel works decently for someone who is 5'6'', but if you are much over that, you'll be showing quite a bit of leg.  I use the towel at the pool and it is looking pretty shabby already with strings hanging.  The towel has fallen off a couple of times even when the velcro fastener has been pretty clear of lint and string.  This will become a dog towel in the near future.

The premise behind this product is a good one - the ability to open a gate in a hands-free way.  If you are carrying kids or boxes or other items, this is a great idea.  The gate does have some pros, including:1) Easy install with adjustable tension knobs,2) A gate that is of moderate height (32" high, which is too high for my dogs to jump over), and3) Two options for opening the gate - through the foot release or push down/pull up level (requires a free hand).However, the first and second pro tend to accompany most pet gates and the third pro isn't really that wonderful if both of the opening options are executed poorly.In terms of cons:1) The gate's foot release requires a great deal of pressure, which can make the user's body unstable and prone to falling.2) The gate does not automatically snap shut.3) Finding the appropriate tension so that the foot release works (albeit poorly) takes time and patience.4) The push down/pull up level combo is sometimes sticky (even after playing with the tension knobs).I have lots of gates around my house. Most of the gates require multiple maneuvers in order to be opened.  Unfortunately, I will not be replacing the gates I have with extras of the Four Paws Metal Foot Release Gate. The biggest con from the list about is that the option of using one's foot to open the gate takes a great deal of work.  I played around with the tension, and it has never opened smoothly.  Because I have to use more force than ideal to open the gate via the foot release, it makes me fearful that I will lose my balance when my hands are full of something.  I cannot be losing my balance when carrying a baby or a load of laundry - that is dangerous.If you won't be opening the gate frequently because it will be placed in hallway/doorway that has limited use, then it functions as a barrier to keep pets from passing.  If you will be going into a room multiple times a day, this isn't the product that I would recommend selecting.

When I have an assortment of appetizers or cookies, I've used the labels to differentiate different food items/flavors.  For that purpose though, I almost prefer to use slate slabs since I don't have to peel stickers - I can just write on the slate directly.  For the most part, I have  been using these labels for one of the other alternatives suggested in the picture gallery which is as gift tags.  The black background looks great when paired with the ink of metallic markers.  The labels are a nice size for labeling gifts. I could see this being a fun tool for teaching kids how to practice letters and creation of words.  Kids like to write on different mediums and with different writing utensils.  I would have child write words and then assemble sentences with the words that are written.I received a complimentary product for review.

For shoes, I am going to stick to spray and powder.  These units do absorb odor, but the results are temporary.  If you have sweaty feet, your shoes are going to stink again at the end of the day.  What's more, if you are wearing multiple pairs of shoes over the course of a week, you can only treat one pair of shoes at a time.  For stinky areas - like baby diaper pails, gym bags, and dirty clothes piles - this product may have better utility.  You can just hang the units but for shoes, these are a bit cost prohibitive and only address odor issues for a couple of hours for shoes.I received a complimentary product for evaluation.

These pens require quite a bit of shaking before use but they write so nicely once they are prepped.  I wanted to send thank you notes on dark paper and was struggling with the widths of my other sharpie markers.  These fit the bill beautifully and allowed for crisp, clear writing.  In addition to the considerable shaking required, I found the pens dried out fast.  If you have a project that you plan to use them for, plan on using them in one or two settings because once opened, the lifespan seems limited.

These bowls come in a set of four and could work for small pets or kids.  If you wanted to separate ingredients during baking, the product could also work well for that use. The bowls clean out easily and also collapse quickly.  I washed them on the top rack of the dishwasher without problems.  I found the bowls to be pretty tiny and not ideal for my dogs who themselves are only medium-sized (30-35 lbs).  If they were a bit larger, I would take them with me on walks with the pups but I found my dogs actually tip them over when they try to drink.  For little dogs or cats, this product would probably work much better.I received a complimentary sample for review purposes

I'm expecting a little one in a few weeks and I wanted to get an assortment of little props for newborn photos.  This product is well made.  It took a while to reach me, so I'm glad I ordered when I did.  I definitely don't subscribe to the belief that girls and boys have to wear particular colors, but to me the overall outfit has more a baby boy feel. The outfit has little overall straps that are not seen in the stock image very clearly.  The bottom portion of the outfit reminds me of a little kid playing in the creek out in the country.  The hat is cute and matches the bottoms but each piece would work alone.  The product is very soft.

The spandex and nylon mix makes this a stretchy little number, but not necessarily for good.  It does ride up quite a bit and is actually pretty thin.  It is easy to see any undergarments that are worn - both the color and the underlying lines of the chosen bra.  I was hoping to use this as a longer tank for yoga and other classes where I prefer my shirts to be long given constant movement and bending.  This particular top simply isn't what I had in mind. I want something that is stretchy but also that stays down and doesn't ride up.  Whether you are wearing this for dancing, walking about, or gym use, I don't think this is a great product.  I will not be ordering again.

I received this product in green, and the shade is a very happy green that is pretty true to the product image.  If you are wearing a mostly dark outfit, this purse can add a bit of a punch to it.Despite the great color, there are a couple of disappointments with this pursue.1) First, the clasp on this purse is not the same as some of the other colors that are offered by the seller.  The closure is a magnetic closure and it never closes tight enough to make me feel comfortable to carry expensive items in it.  Some of the other pursues offer a turnlock clasp where the clasp must actually be turned to open the bag.  This provides some measure of security so that the flap doesn't open randomly.2) A second security element that would have likely made up for the bad clasp would have been zippered pockets on the inside.  There are no zippers, so if you are carrying a smart phone, credit cards, or cash, there is no zippered compartment to keep them securely stowed away in the event the flap opens or your purse falls upside down.3) The strap is pitiful.  The hardware is cheap, and it can take a bit of time to adjust the strap to the appropriate length.All in all, I love the color a great deal.  The security related elements have much to be desired, however.  Other than chapstick and a couple of dollars, I rarely carry anything of value in this purse.I received a complimentary purse for review purposes.

I have had many different vacuums, including the much-applauded Dyson Ball vacuum.  I would have to say that the Dyson was actually one of the worst vacuums I have ever owned.  The sweeping head on the Dyson literally broke to pieces over three years and it never picked up pet hair.  In 2011, my husband and I made the switch to Hoover vacuums and we took it one step more and decided on a vacuum with bags even though bagless vacs were all the rage. We went with the Hoover Platinum Collection Lightweight Bagged Upright with Canister, UH30010COM.  It was an amazing unit when we bought it and after years of abuse, it is still pretty good but considerably more tired and a touch louder.  The Hoover Commercial Hush Tone is very similar to the Hoover Platinum in many, many ways.  The bags last, the product picks up substantial amounts of pet hair and dirt (from humans and animals alike), and is of a very sturdy, yet lightweight, construction.The first thing you notice when you take the Hush Tone Lite is that it is well constructed.  It does have a good bit of plastic components, but these appear to be made of a very high quality plastic. The vacuum bag compartment is a dense fabric with a metal zipper. The power cord and prong are also thick and sturdy.  I always see these fancy ads for Dyson, but after having owned one and heard similar Dyson horror stories from others, I can say that the Hush Tone, seems like it has over $200 worth of build quality and engineering in the design and not into hype and advertisement like Dyson products.When it comes time to use it, it's exceedingly simple. There are limited settings and buttons.  You pick whether you want a high or low brush setting and then turn the unit on and you are on your way.  There are no attachments stuck in random places all over the vacuum to worry about. Some people will probably hate that this product lacks attachments, but I love it.  When I need attachments, I pull out a detail vacuum that is portable and light.  The lack of extra pieces make this unit lighter; it weighs in at just over 11 pounds.  A huge plus for me is the cord length. With a cord length of 35 feet, you can cover multiple rooms.  Probably one of the coolest features of this product is the ability to easily switch out the cord.  There are effectively two cords to operate the product.  One is very short (a pigtail) and affixed to the top of the unit.  The user than affixes the 35 foot cord to this shorter cord.  I have had many vacuums that have needed to have tape wrapped around the cords because someone in my family mutilated the cord, which is not safe.  It is so easy to replace the cord on the Hush Tone should it be run over or otherwise damaged.  If a 35 foot cord is not long enough for you, you could easily plug in a 50 foot cord into the pigtail cord instead of using the 35 foot cord that comes with the product.When we first bought the Hoover Platinum, we immediately noticed the difference in air quality and carpet quality.  As noted, the Platinum that we have had for years probably should have died after two years; we are not kind on our vacs.  So, when I used the Hush Tone Lite, it was amazing the difference in air quality that was experienced again.  As a commercial vacuum, this thing has some suction.  It works well on low-pile carpets, but I would not use it on berber and some carpet runners would also be bad to pair with this vacuum because the Hush Tone pulls every little particle up.The bags last a long time.  We vacuum twice a week on average but with leaves dropping off the trees of late, we've had to increase that to three times for some areas of the house.  The first bag we used lasted three weeks, and I think that was largely because our old Hoover was leaving stuff on the carpets.  The second bag we used with the Hush Tone Lite lasted over a month.  Our house has multiple floors, over 2,000 square feet, and a mix of carpet, vinyl, and hardwood flooring.  Really, I love bagless vacuums.  I find them so much cleaner to handle.  When trying to open canister vacuums, I find that dust and hair inevitably escapes or gets stuck in the canister.  It is disgusting.  With a bagged vac, I don't have to have debris flying about.  When the bag needs changed, I just toss the old one in the trash.  The bags on the Hush Tone keep the gunk and junk inside them very well.Overall, I think this is a great vacuum for a home with mixed floor types and especially a home with pets and/or children.  If you have particularly high carpet, I would urge caution before purchasing.  Likewise, if you have lots of runners that are not low pile, I would ask yourself whether you have alternative ways to clean those rugs since they could get pulled up into the unit.  This unit is great for enhancing air quality.

I have a Graco Snugride Click Connect 35 Infant Car Seat, Pierce  for my little one.  This seat cover fastens easily to that seat to provide some light blockage of sunlight. The Click Connect Seat comes with a short canopy that can be extended, but this seat cover encompasses the entire opening of the car seat.It is a very light product that makes it ideal for spring or summer months because it isn't heavy enough to severely restrict air flow.  Because it is light, the edges can blow around easily in the wind, but the two snaps that affix the cover to the seat will keep the cover from blowing away,  I likely wouldn't use this in winter for fear that snow and rain would penetrate the cover and cause it to droop on baby's face.  This is not a waterproof cover.In a pinch, the cover can be removed and used as a small blanket for a little one to be placed on.  I would avoid placing the cover on grass because it isn't an industrial fabric and the background of the fabric is white, which does not make it a great match for grass stains.  If you do use it on grass, place the underside of the cover on the grass and use that side consistently.This certainly isn't a critical piece for those initial weeks of parenting, but it is something that is nice to have.  If all of the mom-to-be's items are gone from her registry, you are looking for some type of gift to finish off a basket for a baby shower, or you want to avoid getting mom-to-be her umpteenth newborn onesie, this is a nice extra to consider.I received a complimentary product for evaluation and review purposes.

This is a pretty good product for creating some nice sea salt inspired waves.  I had to fool around with the product quite a bit to get it to work well for me though.  While I have naturally curly hair, I couldn't just spray the product on to wet hair and scrunch it.  The result when I did that was a bit limp.  So, I pinned my hair up when it was wet with some bobby pins and then applied the product liberally.  The next day, I removed the pins and the result was exactly what I wanted - loose, non-greasy waves that held the whole day.  The smell of this product is pleasant.  I do find that the sprayer component can get clogged, but I can usually get the product moving again by cleaning the nozzle with warm water.  In terms of a product that I can spray directly on wet hair and have loose waves without pinning, I would recommend Tresemme Salt Spray Sea, 6.76 Ounce.

I am expecting a baby in late October and despite the books and the hospital classes, I still feel like there will be that moment when I will leave the hospital and feel completely unprepared for ensuring that a little human thrives.  The Baby Manual is a nice break from the books and the classes and a great way to synthesize a lot of material in a documentary style film.  Does it have all the information you need?  No.  However, if it were any longer, it would be just as overwhelming and information-dense as the classes and books I've used.The DVD set is composed of two CDs that each have chapters.  Some chapters are short, especially the initial chapters.  Other chapters are much longer, including the breastfeeding section.  I found the breastfeeding section to be great; it covered all the material that I encountered in a two-hour in-person, hospital-sponsored breastfeeding class.  I actually liked the lactation consultant (Taryn) in The Baby Manual a heck of a lot more than the hospital instructor.  She was funny and had some great demonstrations for appropriate latching.The demonstration videos by folks like Taryn, the lactation consultant, and Selena, the safety technician, who helped show how to install a car seat are what makes this set especially nice.  You could search YouTube for similar videos (and you probably still will at some point), but it is great to have the information in one complete set with professionals that are straightforward but likable. Similarly, the parents who are showcased are real about their struggles with parenthood; they were all people I wouldn't mind having a tea or coffee with to learn more about parenting.  Most of the videos with the the parents and professionals are of good quality sound wise.  One that did seem to have a bit of an echo was with Maria the pediatrician.  For the most part, however, these videos seemed modern and did not feel hokey or home-produced.There are helpful lists at the end of each chapter, but it can take a while to get through some of the lists as the video imitates a person writing each thing to buy or remember.  This can make the checklist portion a bit tedious. Some things on the lists were not discussed in the chapter but seemed like potentially obvious and necessary items depending on personal preference (e.g., pacifiers).While The Baby Manual is geared toward new parents, I did share the set with my future little one's aunts and uncles and grandparents since there were some requests.  The most pertinent chapters for them dealt with diapering, reducing crying, health routines, and sleep routines.  If the grandparents, aunts, uncles, haven't been around babies for a while, this set could be a welcome refresher.  My child's grandparent for instance reared children when putting babies on their tummies was the recommended practice.  Times change and recommendations change so the video offered helpful protocols and reminders.  With that in mind, if any of these folks you may share the The Baby Manual with have a sensitivity to seeing unclothed chests, realize that this video does talk about breastfeeding and show it in progress.Some random likes:  I liked that the creators gave some references to cloth diapering and acknowledged working moms.  The idea of having a friend cull through a registry and the addition of an exercise ball to the nursery were great suggestions as well that I will be incorporating.All in all, I liked this DVD set quite a bit.  It doesn't provide all the information you are going to need, but I think that it is worth a watch near the start of pregnancy and a couple of times later on.  Between the start of pregnancy and the end of pregnancy,  you can read, read, read and take classes and consult with others and then take a mini refresher course via The Baby Manual to resurrect some of the lessons that were pushed to the corner of your brain because of anxiety or the forgetfulness that often accompanies pregnancy.This DVD set is 240 minutes long and in English.  It has no subtitles.I received a complimentary product for evaluation purposes.

I would size up on this product.  The wings on the support allow for adjustments, but if you are borderline on the measurements, do yourself a favor and size up to more easily allow for those circumference modifications.  The velcro is strong and will keep you supported for long periods of time.  Sizing up also allows for greater flexibility of product adjustments during the day.  The color of the fabric works well under lighter colored fabrics although it is obvious that a support is being worn if you opt for thinner fabrics.  A camisole or tank top over the support can help hide the support under clothing although this can lead to additional perspiration.  The back of the product has holes to encourage breathability and air flow, but the front is a fairly solid panel so it can get pretty sweaty where the solid panel is positioned.  The support cleans fairly easily  in the wash although there have been some problems with the support's velcro picking up lint and fuzz, which over time, could impair the product's usability.  To remove the lint, I often use another piece of velcro, a toothbrush, or tweezers.I received a complimentary product for review purposes.

I have quite a few tops with awkward neck lines that just don't accommodate traditional bras.  To boot, I'm pregnant so comfortable bras can be like finding a unicorn.  I went with the XL since I am a 36C right now and that is what the description recommended.  If is completely feasible to size down if you are around that measurement.  While this product did not slip down on me, there was certainly a lot of added stretch that could make it feel large on some women.I picked the nude color and it worked really well with light colored fabrics.  The inserts are somewhat annoying.  I have to use inserts/pads, but these ones don't seem to sit in a centered position and for lighter fabrics, it is often clear that the user is wearing a bra with pads.  Further, the inserts/padding always agitate out of the bra when washed or the inserts bunch together, so I would encourage use of  a lingerie bag to keep the pieces at least somewhat together.  It isn't hard to put the inserts back in the bra, but I would prefer they just be affixed in a semi-permanent way.The height of the bra has caused some annoyances.  Even with tops that I wouldn't deem low-cut, the top of the bra can creep over some necklines, which isn't attractive.I found the bra comfortable and I have worn it for long periods of time (14 hours+), but I do think picking a good size is important and somewhat tricky given the parameters provided in the description.  Post- baby I don't believe the XL will work in the way I need it too.  A large would have provided longer term use since the product is, again, quite stretchy.  The fabric is breathable, which has been wonderful for recent hot summer days.I received a complimentary product for review.

I love shampoo with tea tree oil.  The hair products, particularly shampoos, that I have tried with the ingredient always make my hair feel clean and fresh.  The Luseta tea tree and argan oil shampoo and conditioner duo is a good option for individuals who have never tried a tea-tree infused hair product.  Some tea tree products have strong tea tree scents and can lead to a very concentrated feeling feeling when applied to the scalp. In addition to this set, I currently have  Generic Value Products Tea Tree Oil Shampoo compare to Paul Mitchell Tea Tree Special Shampoo 33.8 oz and Tea Tree Oil Shampoo 16 fl oz (473 ml) Liquid in my shower. The Luseta products, especially the conditioner, are much less intense than the other tea tree hair products I have noted.  I like strong tea tree products, but for newbies just trying tea tree oil shampoos, the Luseta set is great.I began using tea tree oil to treat an itchy scalp.  I had used dandruff shampoos that sometimes worked and often had a horrible odor.  Tea tree oil smells fresh and clean and happens to work wonderfully on scalps prone to dryness.  Even though tea tree oil is further down the ingredient list, the shampoo appears to have a higher tea tree oil concentration than the conditioner; the shampoo feels stronger on the scalp.  The scent associated with both products is mild and dissipates quickly.This duo both led to clean-feeling scalp but also soft hair.  Argan oil is an ingredient that I like a great deal, but when I have used it in the past for conditioning, it has caused a greasy look.  I haven't had that problem with the Luseta duo.  Both the conditioner and shampoo have cetearyl alcohol, which is a good alcohol for hair conditioning.I really like the pump bottles and the bottles themselves are a thick plastic, so I may save the bottles for refilling purposes in the future for body wash or some other bath product.  The 16.9 ounce options will last me a while because a little goes a long way.  Not that it matters much to me, but the coloring of the bottles and overall appearance are pretty attractive for shampoo and conditioner.The product bears the leaping bunny symbol, which means it is not tested on animals.  It comes in a #1 bottle; plastic #1s (next to #2) are the most readily recycled in communities across the US.Ingredients:Shampoo -Shampoo: Water (Aqua, Eau), Sodium Cocoyllsethionate, Cocamidopropyl Betaine, Cocamide MEA, Dimethicone, Sodium Chloride, Glycol Distearate, Parfum, Propylene Glycol, Cetearyl Alcohol, Diazolidinyl Urea, Carbomer, Polyquaternium-10, Tetrasodium EDTA, Argania Spinosa Kernel (Argan)  Oil, Melaeuca Alternifolia (Tea Tree) Leaf Oil, Lavandula Angustifolia (Lavender) Oil, Mentha Piperita (Peppermint) Oil, Iodopropynyl Butylcarbamate, CI 19140, CI 42090Conditioner: Conditioner: Water (Aqua, Eau), Cetearyl Alcohol, Dimethicone, Steartrimonium Chloride, Paraffinum Liquidum, Hydroxyethyl Cellulose, Glyceryl Stearate, Cetrimonium Chloride, Parfum, Amodimethicone, Tetrasodium EDTA, Melaleuca Alternifolia (Tea Tree) Leaf Oil,  Argania Spinosa Kernel (Argan) Oil, Astrocaryum Murumuru Seed Butter, Lavandula Angustifolia (Lavender) Oil, Mentha Piperita (Peppermint) Oil, Citric Acid, Iodopropynyl Butylcarbamate, CI 19140, CI 42090I received a complimentary shampoo and conditioner to review.

The diffuser, other than button operation, is easy to use and set up.  There are three main pieces - cover, water tank, and plug-in adapter.  The cover does not screw on; it just sits on top of the water tank/base.  The adapter, plugs in on the bottom of the unit.To use this device, the user needs to lift off the cover, fill the water tank with up to 1/4 cup of water/120 ml of water (there is a maximum fill line) .  Then, place several drops (or maybe only one drop depending on the intensity of the oil), into the water.  Place the cap back on the water tank.  Then, the user has one button to push to turn the unit on.I found the last step of pushing the button to be the most annoying because pressing the button can have different effects.  The first push turns the unit on (sometimes), once the unit is on, the second push will allow you to select a single color rather than the flashing colors, the third push allows all light changing features to be completely turned off so that the dome is unlit. This is nice for sleeping but it may make you think the unit is off when it is very much on.  The final button push (sometimes) turns the unit off.  My fear would be that I (or someone else) would push the button in to turn the unit off and then walk away and it would not have shut down, so make it a practice to always unplug the device even if you think it is off.My unit did turn off when flipped on its side.In terms of how it moves scents about a room, the product is impressive.  My room smelled like eucalyptus and lavender within five minutes of operation.  The unit is  fairly quiet and the changing colors can be pleasant, but I like being able to select a single color as well.I received a complimentary product for evaluation and review.

I enjoyed this oil blend, but it only took one use for me to realize that a little goes a very long way.  I used it in Essential Oil Diffuser, Vtin 120ml Aroma Essential Oil Cool Mist Ultrasonic Humidifier with Adjustable Mist Mode,Waterless Auto Shut-off and 7 Color LED Lights Changing,against Dry Air for Bedroom,Office,Home with 3 drops of oil in 120 ml of water and the scent, while lovely, was quite intense.  I didn't smell a lot of peppermint, but the lavender and eucalyptus were very noticeable.The blend is noted as one that helps with breathing function; I have sniffles even in the summer and after using this blend in the diffuser, my sinuses felt less obstructed.While this seems to be a quality product, the concentration and scent intensity must be approached with caution if the user is prone to headaches, which I am.  I actually only left the diffuser on for 10 minutes with this product before turning it off.  The scent lingered in the room for a couple of hours; it is strong stuff.I received a complimentary oil blend for evaluation purposes.

In terms of sharpness, I didn't find these to be very sharp.  The tips don't have a great point, so it is harder to grasp short hairs and stubborn hairs.  I have never been able to use just one set of tweezers.  For ingrown hairs, I need a set that has very thin ends.  The Petunia Skincare tweezers do not work well on ingrown hairs for me.  For longer hairs and sculpting, I usually reach for tweezers that are slanted.  The Petunia Skincare tweezers do have a slanted end and I was able to sculpt my brows a bit.  I did find that some of the hairs I tried to pluck broke off close to the skin because I just couldn't get the hold that I typically strive for.  The length of these tweezers are probably average;I tend to prefer shorter handles to provide more exact control; the Petunia Skincare tweezers don't provide this.Just as people have preferences for hairbrushes, shampoos, and shoes, I have very strong preferences for my tweezers.  I have two favorites that are both made by Tweezerman and include:  http://www.amazon.com/Tweezerman-Mini-Slant-Tweezer-Colors/dp/B00AAJOZN4/ref=sr_1_1?s=beauty&ie=UTF8&qid=1441367030&sr=1-1&keywords=tweezers and http://www.amazon.com/Tweezerman-1300-r-Ingrown-Hair-Splintertweeze/dp/B000FFYMYU/ref=sr_1_31?s=beauty&ie=UTF8&qid=1441367030&sr=1-31&keywords=tweezers.  (I haven't always experienced consistent tweezer quality with the Tweezerman tweezers, but when I get a good set, the results are great.)The Petunia Skincare tweezers have found a place in my gym bag so that I can pluck on the go.  They won't be my go-to tweezers, but they will serve as an alternative if I have no other option on hand.I received a complimentary set of tweezers for evaluation and review.

Pros:Eye contact: This cover has a semi-rigid neckline that can be manipulated to allow mom to maintain contact with baby.  The adjustable neckline also allows downward air movement to the baby.Adjustable: Metal d-rings allow mom to adjust the neckline of the cover similar to some aprons.Color is gender neutral:  The color of the cover is light grey and white with images that resemble flowers.  The images are printed in white but are very lightly printed so from far away, the cover would appear to be mostly grey.  The interior of the cover is not lined; it is just the backside of the fabric, so it too looks grey.Storage pockets:  There are two storage pockets that are about 7 inches long and 6.5 inches wide.  These are on the inside of the cover and could temporarily hold small items (set of keys, pacifier, burp cloth).  See commentary below.Light fabric:  The fabric is very light which would make it good for summer late spring and summer use if you have warmer/hot temperatures in your area.Folds up small:  The cover folds up small and doesn’t take up much room in a bag that is already probably full of miscellaneous diapers, outfits, and equipment.Provides moderate coverage:  Not including the neck strap, the rectangular portion of the fabric that covers the chest area and baby is 37 inches wide by 26.5.  The loose strap for the neck is about  27 inches long and can be affixed to another shorter strip of fabric (2.75 inches) via a d-ring.Product can be used for other purposes:  The cover can be draped over a car seat to provide additional shade to a little one.Cons:Storage pockets:  The storage pockets are at the bottom of the cover and sewn on the inside.  They are open at the top.  I would have preferred pockets on the outside of the cover that had zippers on the top so that items could actually be stored within them without the small items potentially falling out.Cover constructed with lightweight fabric:  The fabric is good for use in warmer temperatures because it is not double-lined.  However, due to the thinness, it can shift a bit in wind.  I wish there were little weights in the lower corners.  Putting items into the storage pockets can help a bit on the bottom.  The top upper left and upper right corner also flap downward, regardless of the presence of wind , and an extra flexible strap at the back would be helpful to maintain modesty although it would make the unit harder to put on.  A better alternative I think would be the presence of semi-flexible and rigid plastic (similar to the neckline construction) running down along the left and right of the cover  to keep the cover from flapping about.Moderate coverage could be more ample: I’m 5’6”  with an average torso and the fabric dimensions noted above would be the bare minimum amount of fabric I would want to work with if I were out and about. Ideally, there would be more fabric on the sides to wrap around the back a bit this is especially case since the upper left and right flap do not stay upright but flip out.Wrinkly:  If you are highly sensitive to wrinkles, this product tends to wrinkle regardless of whether the user decides to fold the cover or roll the cover up for storage.All in all, it is a nice product that gets the job done.I received a complimentary product for evaluation purposes.

I like it as a really long tank top for the gym and casual outfits. The length covers my bottom when I am wearing spandex gym/yoga pants, which depending on the manufacturer, can be a bit thin.  The fabric is lightweight so for my local climate, it would work from late spring to mid-fall.  The color was as expected and it arrived in good shape without loose threads.  The product has some stretch to it so it does nicely accentuate curves.  I'm pregnant and therefore ordered a larger size than I normally would wear, and I felt quite comfortable in it.  I let me sister who is a pretty petite gal try it on and while it was more dress like on her, she indicated she wouldn't use it as a dress because she felt too much of the leg area was exposed.  For purposes of being used as a really long tank top, this product meets expectations and I would consider ordering a second color.I received a complimentary sample in grey  for evaluation purposes.Update October 2015:  I liked the length of this so much that I ordered a second in black.  The black was as equally comfortable as the grey, but if you have pets, it is a hair magnet.  I cannot keep the black tank hair and lint free.  It is not one I would wear out often in public.  I do wish the company offered this tank in additional colors.  I would probably start to replace all my shorter tanks with this option if there were more color options.

If you are looking for a knee brace that you can wear out and about, this isn't one that I would recommend.  I found that the brace moved considerably.  The product is tightened and through the use of velcro.  Unfortunately, the velcro does not stay affixed which leads to a fit that loosens over the course of mere minutes.  The pressure provided is weak and does not stabilize the knee.  The advantages of this type of product, if you can keep it on, is that it is easier to apply than a neoprene knee sleeve and is adjustable.  If the user is going to remain in confined to a bed or chair, then this product may be worth considering, but any minimal movement will cause shifting.I received a complimentary sample for purposes of evaluation.

I liked the idea of these yoga pants because they had a dip in the front to accommodate a large (and still growing) pregnant belly and a stretchy fabric that is not at all constricting.  The fabric is thicker than other exercise pants that I have but still stretchy and breathable.  I've worn these in many exercise classes and they don't shift around.  The pants also hit at a nice point on my leg - right around the mid-calf.  I need to wash these a few more times to assess longevity, but thus far the fabric seems to be holding up to consistent (3-4x a week) use.  If you have pets, they do attract hair but most black colored fabrics do.  I would like to see these stretch pants in different solid colors.I received a complimentary pair of pants for evaluation purposes.

This product comes in various pieces that do not  connect easily.  While pushing this along hardwood floors covered with cat hair, the handle separated, and the broom didn't collect much hair on hard surfaces.  On carpeted floors, the broom did not move easily and the handle, again, disassembled itself. On couches, I had better success but only after I decided to just use the broom head.  The broom head when moved across fabric-laden furniture allowed a ton of hair to be clumped together.  The hair did not stick to the broom, but it did form a bit of a ball that could be swept or picked up. If you really want a broom, this is not the tool unless you are committed to replacing the handle.  If you don't mind using this as a handheld device, it can help with the gathering of fur.

I used these for party favors that were somewhat tall.  The plastic was pretty thick and can be bunched together nicely even if the item(s) to be wrapped do not fill out the bag completely.  I've also used these bags with small baskets and the bags have worked pretty well.  I think these bags would be pretty big for treats unless the treats were pies or cookies.

When I want makeup to truly last all day long and especially in the heat, I've found that a primer is 100% critical.  I use Revlon primer before applying foundation, but this Victoria's Secret primer is spectacular in providing the final stabilizing layer.  I can use this final product and the makeup will stay on easily for 12+ hours.  I haven't found it necessary to use a really expensive foundation for this product to work well.

I'm expecting and have tried a variety of products throughout pregnancy to keep skin moisturized.  I've tried and liked many Burt's products, but this one just came across as average.  It absorbs quickly, but it does have a smell.  To keep the skin from drying out, it seemed like I had to apply this moisturizer more frequently than other products I've tried. The container size is not huge so if you are using this each day, you will burn through quite a bit of this. This latter point seems like that is the problem with most of the pregnancy-oriented moisturizers like Palmer's and Bio-Oil.  After 28 weeks, my ultimate preference is either Cetaphil Moisturizing Lotion or  Eucerin Original Moisturizing Creme.  I buy huge vats of the Cetaphil from Costco.

My husband and I are in the kitchen all the time. At least once a month, one of us will drop a plate in the sink or on the floor. So, we need pieces that will work for us (they have to be durable and functional) and they have to be able to grow with us (that means the pattern cannot be retired in 6 months). I started buying Corelle shortly after my wedding six years ago with two of Corelle's Corelle Livingware 16 piece Dinnerware Set, Service for 4, Winter Frost White.  I still have most of those original pieces.  As I've begun to host gatherings, my kitchen collection has expanded significantly.  I've purchased Corelle Livingware 12-1/4-Inch Serving Platter, Winter Frost White and Corelle Livingware 9-1/2-Inch Oval Platter, Winter Frost White and Corelle Livingware 10-1/4-Inch Divided Dish, Winter Frost White, which are especially useful for little ones.In 2014, I needed more dinner plates in Winter Frost.  All the plates I ordered perfectly matched the set I bought six years ago after my wedding.  Nearly all of Corelle's pieces are products I would buy for others.  When I meet individuals registering for their weddings, I always suggest Corelle over the pretty-pattered ceramic dishes that so easily crack. These Corelle dishes would be perfect for a couple's new home; they are well-made and a good size. In addition to being a well-made product, this particular color has two advantages:1) Expandable set:  The first advantage is that Corelle has a lot of other pieces that come in this color. As noted, I had reached the point in my life when it was time to expand the set.  Even though six years had passed, the plates matched my old dinnerware set perfectly. As you need serving bowls and platters, they are easily available.  This is the perfect product and color for a family that is rough with plates and/or is potentially expanding. You will be able to find a matching piece and those pieces will endure through the years.2) White is adaptable: The second advantage is the actual white color. You can make any piece look as dressy or casual as you want by pairing fancier or more casual tablecloths and placements with the dishes. Many people seem apprehensive to purchase white dinnerware for fear of staining. You don't need to worry about that with Corelle. I frequently use Corelle dishes to reheat pasta with marinara sauce and foods that incorporate dark sauces like soy or teriyaki. My dishes are still perfectly white.I really love Corelle's products. You can expand this set to fit the needs of your family and the white color is perfect for casual dinners, larger family affairs, or fancy parties. You have to be very, very brutal to your plates to get one to chip. I highly recommend this product.

For a new parent, this assortment provides some essentials all in one kit.  Taken as a whole, the set is nice but not overly praiseworthy.  All of the contents are made in China.  While soft, the blankets and sheets are pretty thin.Blankets - A 30" by 40" blanket is not that big. It can be hard to picture, so I'd get out the tape measure. These are good for swaddling and soft enough. The color of the blankets that I received does not really match the product picture. When you google Ecru, the color can range from an off-white to tan to a light buttercup yellow. These blankets are a pale yellow. I like them, but they were not the color I anticipated. The packaging says the thermal blankets are 100% cotton, but that is not what the sewn in tag says.  The tag identifies them as 100% polyester.  Made in China.Crib sheet - The fitted sheets are very soft but also very thin.  If you hold them up, they are fairly see through.  Again, similar to the blankets, the color is more of a pale yellow.
