I have had seven broken bones and fractures in my life, and I can’t even tell you how many sprains and similar injuries I’ve sustained. Needless to say, I have some experience with braces. In fact, I keep a bag of various braces on hand for times when I have an injury.The Ipow Support Brace is a great option for pain in the knee area. It is easy to put on, comfortable to wear, and allows some freedom of movement for walking while still mobilizing the area for optimal healing and relief.This brace is useful even when you aren’t injured but want to help support a trick knee while doing something strenuous, like physical work or exercise.I would highly recommend this brace to anyone who needs to stabilize their knee either just for support or for a minor injury.I received a complementary sample unit for review.

The Sterling Silver Pink Crystal Bow Pendant Necklace with Swarovski Elements is not a necklace I would have chosen for myself simply because the bow design isn’t really my style. Looking at the photos of this necklace on the Amazon product page, I thought it looked OK, but didn’t expect to like it as much as I did when I saw it in ‘person’, so to speak.The close up photos made me think the bow pendant was larger than it is and the crystal stones look like they have a lot of gaps between them. In real life, the bow is smaller, so it looks cute and pretty and not tacky. The stones are set very close together so that I can’t see any obvious space between them.The silver chain is very nice and I will get a lot of use out of it for more than just this pendant. The construction on both it and the pendant is very good – the setting and the clasp seem very secure.The pendant falls at the perfect spot about mid-chest.This is a wonderful necklace for a girl or woman who wants something flirty, feminine, and fun. I think this will be a piece I hand down to my niece in a few years when she is a bit older, perhaps when she reaches her teens.I received a complementary sample unit for review.

I love rubies and have always thought they looked beautiful paired with silver. Having seen the photos on the product page for the Created Ruby and Diamond Pendant-Necklace in Sterling Silver (1 34ct tgw), I thought this was a really pretty necklace that I could pair with numerous outfits. Rubies really do work well with so many colors.Now that I have the necklace in my possession, I am even more enamored of it. It may be a created ruby, but my untrained eye would never be able to tell the difference in this and a natural one. The design of the pendant is attractive, but simple, allowing the ruby to take center stage in this setting.The pendant comes with a delicate silver chain that falls at just the right length for me – not hanging too far in the cleavage, but not so short it chokes me.This is the kind of necklace I find myself choosing outfits that will look nice with it. Not only that, but the workmanship of the setting and the chain feel very secure. I am very happy with it and would highly recommend it.I received a complementary sample unit for review.

I love jewelry and go back and forth between gold and silver. I really don’t have a preference outside of which suits that particular piece of jewelry best as well as which metal works better for my outfit. Having seen the Sterling Silver Blue Crystal Dangle Earrings with Swarovski Elements in photos online, I thought these earrings looked pretty, but now that I have seen them up close, I think the photos don’t really do them justice.The product page for these earrings gives the dimensions, but I am really not good at envisioning a thing’s sized based on measurements. From the photos, I worried these earrings would be a bit larger than they are. Instead, they are large enough to catch attention, yet small enough to avoid being tacky.Also, the close up photos of this jewelry makes it appear as if there is a lot of space between each stone, but that is misleading. The stones are nestled next to each other both on the outer edge and in the middle of the design with no gaps obvious to the naked eye.The gradient shades of blue will allow these earrings to blend with several hues of that color and I have a semi-formal dress that these will be perfect with.I am thrilled with these earrings and would highly recommend them.I received a complementary sample unit for review.

When it comes to graphics creation and editing, I am still very much a novice. I have advanced computer skills, but that isn’t enough when you are working with graphics – you also have to understand the artistry of the task. I don’t know if I will ever be more than an amateur when it comes to this kind of technical work, but luckily Corel helps me be better than I am at it.I’ve used several Corel products in the past, and one thing has stood out for me above all other features with this brand – they really make an effort to hand-hold their users through the software. The software has all the power to satisfy advanced users (I am taking the word of a friend who is proficient with graphics editing) but they don’t turn their nose up at people like me. I’ve honestly found Adobe Photoshop a bit intimidating – I haven’t used the current versions, so I am speaking of older editions of Adobe Photoshop. I have never felt this way about Corel, at least not for long.Corel includes built-in help to guide users through the plethora of tools built into Corel Painter 2015, and they also have a great series of video tutorials published at YouTube. I am still working my way through these tutorials, but have learned a bit already.I also appreciate that this software doesn’t utilize a lot of system resources. I can run Corel Painter 2015 alongside other applications with no degradation in system performance. Of course, Corel provides options where you can set how much memory and other system resources are being devoted to Corel, which is a huge plus.Like I said before, I am an amateur when it comes to graphic editing, but with Corel Painter 2015, I don’t have to look like it. Sure, it may take me longer to perform some of the tasks than it would a graphic artist, but I can definitely get the job done with this software.

I do not recommend Standing Stone Farm. I enjoyed the beginner's cheese making class I took there, but have not had a good experience with them since. In April 2013, I signed up for an Intermediate class to be held in August 2013. They charged me the $150 as soon as I registered in April 2013. When the date of the class drew near, the owner, Paula Butler, cancelled the class, for seemingly good reasons. She said she would reschedule it in Oct or Nov 2013, but she did not. She also did not provide refunds, promising the class would be rescheduled in Spring 2014 'when the goats would be active.' I waited patiently, still interested in the class. It is now Summer of 2014, 14 months after she charged me for the class, and I still don't have my money, nor has she rescheduled the class. I've emailed asking her for a refund, but she will not reply.I should have demanded my money back the moment she cancelled the class. I'm of the firm belief companies like this should not charge the customer until the class/service date is near or until the goods are ready to be shipped. I probably shouldn't have trusted her when she said she was going to reschedule it, but the beginner's class I took went so well and I really didn't want to lose my spot in the Intermediate class, which only allowed 8 students and she said she hasn't offered this class in several years.After the last year of stressing over this, the idea of this class is no longer fun at all. She could come to my house to teach me and I don't think I would want to do it now. I'm too upset. The lack of response is really the icing on the cake.After I began posting online reviews and warnings, I got a reply from a relative of the owner. She said the payment is nonrefundable - even though the owner cancelled the class and has refused to schedule another in 14 months. At this point, I will start filing complaints with the BBB and any other regulatory agency that might cover this situation.If you are interested in cheese-making supplies or cheese-making classes, find a more reputable company unless you have money to throw away should they randomly decide to take your money and not provide the service or goods you paid for. Standing Stone Farms is not reputable.

I love to cook, and I prefer to make things from scratch whenever possible. Fresh ingredients always produce better flavors and are usually healthier. I had never thought about having a puree maker, but when I saw the Paderno World Cuisine Puree Maker, I was curious – especially after I saw other people use it to make homemade marinara sauce.I haven’t yet used it for marinara sauce as I am looking for a good recipe that calls for it to be pureed, but I did recently make a strawberry puree using this gadget. Honestly, I think I will use this more for fruit purees than for marinara sauce anyway. I found a simple recipe for strawberry puree that called for frozen strawberries and sugar. After thawing the strawberries, I drained them and ran tham through the Paderno device. Cranking the handle was not at all difficult with this ingredient and I pureed a 48-ounce bag of strawberries very quickly. The puree is deposited to a puree cup and the juice ran off into a different cup.I can’t say this is a device I will use often, but I will use it more. I can see this being a very useful gadget for anyone who wants to make homemade baby food.The device was not well packed inside the Paderno World Cusine packaging and the puree cup was broken when it arrived on my doorstep. I contacted their customer service, and they shipped a replacement part to me in about a week. I was very pleased with their customer service – problems occur with any product, and all I ask for is good customer service policies and personnel ready to make the problems right.One other thing of note: I was disappointed in the manual. They include a one page sheet of instructions that could be improved. It really doesn’t make it clear how to remove some of the parts that come pre-assembled. Also, for an item like a puree maker that many people would have few immediate uses for, it would be a good idea for the manufacturer to include some recipes in the manual that utilize their device.If you have ingredients you need to puree, I would recommend this device.

I don’t drink coffee every day, but I do keep an automatic coffeemaker set up in the kitchen for those days when I am in the mood for it or when I have company that would like a cup. I’ve had several automatic coffeemakers over the years and you would think that they would all be pretty much the same. For the most part that is correct, but I have owned one Mr. Coffee unit that was terrible – it frequently leaked water all over the counter when you tried to make coffee.The Black and Decker CM3005S 12-Cup Tea and Coffeemaker definitely has no issues with leaks. This appliance has all of the most popular features that most people have come to expect in an automatic coffeemaker: Sneak-a-cup feature, auto brew and auto shutoff, permanent filters, and an automatic cleaning system.On top of those common features, this maker also has something I’ve never seen in a coffeemaker before: you can brew tea in it using a special tea filter included in the package. Being allergic to tea, I cannot test that feature myself. What I can say about the tea brewing feature is that it has its own filter that works in the same carafe that you use for coffee, and special brew settings on the control panel that you select for tea. I will keep this feature in mind when I have guests that drink tea, though.When I first get a new coffeemaker, I like to run it through a cleaning cycle before I use it – just like I wash new dishes or pots and pans before use. The manual instructs to use a vinegar and water solution with the cleaning cycle option, and then run a rinse cycle afterwards to remove any vinegar residue that might be left behind. This worked very well, and I will perform this task regularly to keep the maker clean and the coffee fresh tasting. The removable parts (carafe, permanent filters and filter basket) all can be run through a dishwasher cycle to clean them or can be washed by hand if you prefer.As with most automatic coffeemakers, this one has a clock and a timer to automatically start brewing at a specified time. I did test this once and it worked well, but I was raised to unplug coffeemakers when they aren’t being used, so I don’t use this feature on a regular basis. For me, it is just as easy to set up the coffee the night before, and then just plug it in and press the power button when I wake up. With the Sneak-a-Cup feature that lets you pour a cup of coffee before the brewing cycle is complete, the timer function is even less important to me, although it is nice to have it in case I need it.One feature I do really like is the ‘Strong’ button. Choosing this setting allows the unit to brew a stronger pot of coffee, which I prefer. I can’t stand a weak, watery tasting cup of coffee.There is also a switch that tells the maker whether you are brewing a full pot of coffee or only 1-4 cups.When the coffee completes the brewing cycle, a short series of beeps sounds to alert you that it is done. The coffeemaker emits a similar series of beeps when the automatic shutoff feature activates a couple of hours later.I mentioned before that the unit comes with a permanent filter for brewing tea, and it also includes a gold-tone filter for the coffee grounds. Brewing with a reusable filter like this saves money on coffee filters over time, and I much prefer this.I am very pleased with this coffeemaker, and would recommend it to anyone who needs a good automatic coffeemaker – especially if someone in your household drinks tea also.

The first books I ever read by Lori Foster were the stories in her ‘Love Undercover’ series. Something about those stories grabbed me and wouldn’t let go – I devoured each title in that saga. I first ‘met’ the main characters of ‘No Limits’ in that series when Cannon and Yvette appeared as supporting characters. They were very young in those books, and so I really didn’t think about them possibly having their own book.When I saw this pair starring in ‘No Limits’, I had high expectations based on the ‘Love Undercover’ books. After I began reading this book, I realized their world felt very different from the one I had been so intrigued by in the ‘Love Undercover’ series and it just didn’t click for me. I was about halfway through this book when I realized that while ‘No Limits’ is connected to the ‘Love Undercover’ books, it is actually in a different series with a different theme.In the other series, one of the main characters was always in law enforcement and the case they were engaged in was the back plot for the story, often throwing the main characters together very often. In this new series, titled ‘Hard Knocks’, the theme changes from law enforcement to the fighting arena, where the heroes are all MMA fighters. Not only that, but the lead characters are considerably younger than those in the other series. Neither the fight world nor the age group of the lead characters really intrigued me much.Worse, something about Yvette just left me feeling flat. While I could understand why a woman would fall for Cannon, I could never really see why he fell for her. Granted, love doesn’t often make sense, but I felt like their connection was somewhat forced, despite the shared trauma they experienced together in the past. I also felt like her reactions to certain situations just didn’t ring true.If this had been the first time I had read a book by Lori Foster, I doubt I would read another. Thankfully, I have enjoyed some of her other books, so I know this is unusual. I can’t say it is a bad book, it is just not a great book. Perhaps someone who is into MMA fighting or enjoys romances with young adults would appreciate this story more than I did. While I will certainly read other books by this author, I won’t continue reading the ‘Hard Knocks’ series.

As soon as I finished reading the first book in Alessandra Torre’s “Innocence” series, I had to buy the sequel, “Masked Innocence.” Our hero and heroine went through quite an evolution in the first part of their story, but in the second book, we learn they both have a long way to go before they even think of the possibility of a happy ending. This pair is so different in nearly every way that one wonders how they will make it, but one thing never in doubt is their love and commitment to one another.This story puts both characters through the wringer in so many ways, testing the depths of their love for one another again and again. There are times when lesser people would throw in the towel and call it quits, but circumstances make that an impossible choice – especially for Brad. He truly has grown in leaps and bounds from the confirmed bachelor we met in “Blindfolded Innocence” to the man who would do anything for those he loves.The author certainly throws these two for a loop in her story, but still manages to ramp up the kink to a delicious level that is bound to inspire fantasies in all but the most conservative readers. I should say, if your tastes in romance lean toward the conservative, this is probably not the book for you. If you like to fantasize about things you would likely never do but find it fun to read about, then you should enjoy “Masked Innocence” as much as I did.Just as when I finished the first book in this series, I bought and read the last book in the series as soon as I finished this one. “Masked Innocence” is the kind of book that makes me appreciate the instant gratification ebooks afford me even more than ever.

‘Blindfolded Innocence’ is the first book I’ve ever ready by author Alessandra Torre, and it definitely will not be the last. When I finished reading this book, I immediately ordered the second in the ‘Innocence’ series from the review list. Within an hour I decided there was no possible way I could wait for that print copy to be shipped to me and bought the Kindle version so I could continue this addictive story without further delay.With Brad and Julia, this author has created two characters that felt so real to me that I often forgot it was a fictional book and not actually Julia’s diary I was reading. This book is written in first person, using Julia’s perspective, so the reader really gets the chance to emulate all of the mixed emotions Julia deals with during and after each interaction with the utterly confounding and irresistible Brad.So help me, as much as he did frustrate her, I found myself wishing for a man like him to barrel into my life and sweep me off of my feet. Of course, this isn’t a sweet romance with flowers and candy. No, this is one scorching hot affair that sweeps Julia up like a tidal wave with no idea of where she will end up.Both of the lead characters are complicated people and while they have plenty of differences, once they do get together it is easy to see what each of them like about the other.‘Blindfolded Innocence’ is the first part of a three (and a half) book story. There is definitely a cliffhanger at the end, so be prepared to buy the other books in the series if you want the complete story. I knew this when I got the first one, so it didn’t bother me, but I can imagine how disappointed another reader might be if they didn’t realize this book wasn’t the complete story.

Currently, I have five cats in my home. Two of them are about eighteen months old, one is about three years old, and the other two are about sixteen years old. The older cats pretty much stick to a routine of nap and eat, but the younger cats need stimulation – especially if I want them to sleep through the night and not wake me. I have several toys I use with them, but I like to have a couple of hands-off toys so that I can tire them out a bit even when I don’t have time to sit and play myself.The SmartyKat FeatherWhirl Electronic Motion Ball is definitely interesting to my youngest two cats. Since I turned it on, they’ve been stalking it in the bathroom. Of course, it has been mostly that slow-motion stalking that cats are known for, but as they got more used to it, that did progress into full on batting it with the paws, picking it up and carrying it off, and the like.The toy needs two AA batteries, which are not included. You will need a small Philips head screwdriver to open the battery compartment and to close it again. Once that is done, slide the stick with the feather on the peg atop the ball, and press the power button on the side to activate it. I’ve had some cat toys that had no power button, requiring removing the batteries every time I need to turn it off, so I have come to appreciate a power button more than you know.Set the toy on the floor, and it begins a series of random twists and turns, flicking the feather on the end of the stick around in a way that will surely entice most cats as much as it did mine. As with most of these motion toys, this will work best on a hard floor, so if you don’t have much space without carpet, this may not be a good toy for you. That said, even though it doesn’t move around much on carpet, it still wiggles in a way that they like.Most of my home is carpeted, with the exception of the bathrooms, kitchen, and the dining room. I usually put this kind of toy in the larger bathroom, which works well until it ends up trapped against the cabinet. I also put it in the bathtub, which works well and allows it to move a lot, but of course the tub isn’t very big.As I’ve written this, the kittens’ stalking of the SmartyKat toy has definitely picked up its pace and progressed to full on capture and growling. These kittens are from the same litter, and are having a great time playing with this gadget.

A few years ago, I realized the difference in cheap cookware and good cookware when I invested in some KitchenAid pots and pans. Those pans have definitely made a difference both in my cooking and in cleanup and still work as well as they did when I first got them.Consequently, I was very excited about getting the Cooks Standard NC-00347 10-Piece Hard Anodize Premium Grade Nonstick Cookware Set, Black. The Amazon product page gave me high hopes for this set. As I unboxed and washed them, I was even more excited. The pots and pans have a good, solid feel to them – heavy duty without being too heavy. Not only that, but they have a very attractive look.Made from aluminum, they have a hard anodized surface that works better than any Teflon coating does. The metal distributes heat very well and the coating keeps food from sticking to them. The manufacturer says you can hand wash them with a towel and forgo the detergent, but I can’t do that. I do wash them in hot water with some Dawn detergent and cleanup is easy.While the pots and pans are metal, the lids are clear glass, so you can see how your dish is doing without removing the lid. Having used metal lids for most of my life, this made a big difference to me when I first got pans with see-through lids, and I won’t go back willingly. Unlike my KitchenAid set, the Cooks Standard set includes a small hole in the top of each lid, which would let steam escape and also allows the insertion of a cooking thermometer without removing the lid.Cooks Standard strongly recommends against putting these pans in the dishwasher, and this seems to be pretty standard amongst the more expensive brands of cookware. Since they clean so easily, this hasn’t been a problem for me.There are a few things that prevent me from giving this cookware set five stars. First, the lids cannot be set half open on the pans. There are times when I want to tilt the lid up to let more steam escape, but not remove the lid completely. These lids won’t stay like that – as soon as you let them go, they slide back into place. I’ve never had a lid that did that before. This may be a plus for some people, but it isn’t for me.Second, the handles are just too big. They feel good when you are holding them, but they are bulkier than they need to be. Again, this may not be a problem for others, but my kitchen has very narrow cabinets, and it makes it harder to fit these pots and pans in them.Last, the handles get hot while you are cooking. The manufacturer acknowledges this in the manual, warning that you should use potholders when handling these pans. However, I don’t always find it convenient to have to use a potholder while cooking. None of my other cookware needs a potholder except for the items that go in the oven. Just cooking pasta made the handle warm enough that I felt safer with a potholder to protect my hand. Also, because the handles are smooth and rounded, it is easy for them to slide against the fabric of a pot holder, which isn’t really safe when you are pouring off hot fluids, etc.This set cooks very well, but given the issues with the handles and the lids, I think they are overpriced when you compare them to competitors’ models.

Many of us these days use Post-it notes. They are convenient way to leave short notes for others and even ourselves. Over the years, I have also found Post-it flags to be very useful. I use them when I want to mark a section of a document that I need to find easily again or to mark spaces where someone needs sign. Most frequently, however I use Post-it flags to mark interesting recipes in cookbooks.The Post-it 12 Inch Notebook Kit, Includes 25 Full Adhesive Notes, Yellow, 2 x 2 Inches and 100 Arrow Flags, Bright Colors (ED-FLIPOUTM) intrigued me. Being able to attach the pad of notes and flags to the book or notepad that I am using them with seemed like a great idea.Unfortunately, the implementation of this product left something to be desired. While the notes and flags work perfectly fine. The sticky back on the kit doesn't hold very well when you place it on a notebook or book. Not only that, but the sticky notes fell off the kit while still in the package and have not stayed affixed to it. Since I received it.While the notes and flags work well, I can't really recommend this kit since its main purpose is to attach it to a notebook to keep its contents handy.

I almost never have problems with ants inside my home, but I do see them on a couple of windows where I have hung suction cup hummingbird feeders, since the ants are drawn to the nectar. I’ve sprayed the perimeter of the windows with Safer Brand 14-Ounce Aerosol Ant and Roach Killer 5720 to prevent them coming inside and also to minimize the ants at these feeders, and this formula has proven effective outside so far. Because it is a contact killer and not a repellent, I do spray the ants on the windows again every few days.The last time I brought the feeders into the house to wash them, I didn’t get all the ants rinsed off before making it to my kitchen, but luckily caught the few that came in quickly and sprayed the area with this ant killer, which took care of them immediately.Unlike most insect sprays, this one has a fresh citrus spray that is actually pleasant.If you need a good ant killer, I’d recommend this spray. If you need something to keep them away, this is not the product for you.

I never thought I'd say this about a power bank, but the Cell Phone Battery Charger by Haidue - 10000mah Dual-port Ultra Compact Battery Charger is the prettiest power bank I've ever used. Of course, being pretty really isn't a criteria for choosing such a device, but since this one is just as functional as it is attractive, the look is just a bonus. The gold finish is subtle, not gaudy, and the lines of the device are smooth.This power bank has two USB ports which can be used to charge most devices that charge via USB - not just cell phones. I've used it with my Plantronics 975 Bluetooth headset, my Samsung Galaxy S4 smartphone, and my Kindle Fire HD tablet. All of these devices kept their charge while plugged into this device.With 10000 mAH, this battery backup can fully charge my Samsung Galaxy S4 smartphone three times, with some juice leftover.To charge the power bank itself, simply plug the micro USB cable into the matching port, and plug the USB end of that cable into either the port on your computer or into a USB power adapter.There is a flashlight built into this device, so if you have a power outage, you can use it to charge your phone and to see in the dark. The flashlight isn't very strong, but it is definitely enough for an emergency like a power outage, at least to help you find your standard flashlight.If you have a device that charges via USB and you don't want to be caught with a dead battery, I would recommend this power bank.I received a complementary sample unit for review.

I love to grill, and use my gas grill on the patio when I can, but sometimes the weather just doesn’t allow for outdoor grilling. Luckily, indoor grills can work very well for most meals.I’ve used several indoor grills before, but have wanted a George Foreman grill for a while, having heard good things about it from friends who own one. I got the George Foreman GRP360R 360 Grill this week and used it the night it arrived to grill a nice rib eye steak.Until I used one, I really didn’t understand what the difference was between a George Foreman grill and the other indoor grills. The George Foreman model is the only one I’ve used that slopes forward, with the drip tray in the front to catch all the juices and fat. This provides two great advantages: there is less chance of the juices and liquids overflowing over the rim of the grill plates and it makes it easier to clean after you’ve finished cooking.Cleaning this grill really is easy. The grill plates are removable – I won’t own a device that doesn’t have removable plates anymore. After removing the plates, you can completely submerge them in water to wash them either by hand or in the dishwasher. I washed them by hand when it arrived so I could use it immediately, and then ran them through the dishwasher after dinner. The drip pan is also simple to wash. I put it in the top rack of the dishwasher last night and it worked fine there.The specifications state that this is a four-serving grill, and that really just depends on what you are cooking. The rib eye I grilled last night is pretty big, and I think I could only fit three of those on this grill.I should also mention that since this device has grill plates both on the top and bottom you can cut your grill time a lot and shouldn’t need to flip most items you grill on it. I didn’t flip the steak that I grilled last night.The hinge on the back of the grill is pretty wide, and this (combined with the top and bottom grill plates) makes it ideal for grilling Panini sandwiches as well.The manufacturer’s website has additional plates you can buy for this grill if you want to make waffles with it as well.I am very pleased with this grill and expect to use it on rainy summer days and throughout the winter when I can’t grill outside.

I was surprised to find that this is a very light, airy cream that is used twice a day as a moisturizer, and lightens the dark spots over time. Very nice. I love the feel of the cream and it goes on easily. It's not an instant cure, but then it's not designed to be.
I like the route options which are embossed directly onto the ball and the size that makes it easier for young players to handle. Very nice! It seems to be well made and a very good size.

Strangely enough, the best part of this 'soft activity book' appears to be the crinkly feel and sound of the 'pages' when you touch them. The sound 'bag' is a little hard to punch and a baby would not, of course, be able to match up all the items, but that doesn't really matter. There's enough activity just handling the pages and the sound bag.

I'm really enjoying the La Roche-Posay Thermal Spring Water. I have it in two sizes, the small 'purse size'  being more portable. The idea of spraying water in my face was a little strange at first, but it's good for my face after cleansing, instead of a toner, and feels wonderful! I've started using it when I've overworked as a de-stresser and also just to cool off when I've been running around too much in the hot weather.

The La Roche-Posay Thermal Spring Water feels great on my skin. I wasn't sure I was going to like spraying mineral water on my face, but it feels great! It's a wonderful pick-me-up when I'm needing to relax or just want to cool off a bit, not to mention that it's healthy for my skin. I'm enjoying using it and have it in two sizes. The smaller size is purse-sized and easily portable.

These are industrial rubber (Nitrile) gloves which are powder free, non-sterile, latex free, and textured. The materials comply with FDA regulations for food contact. They cannot be used for medical or healthcare purposes.

These blue powder-free textured non-sterile heavy duty rubber (Nitrile) exam gloves are extra thick and extra long. You can tell the difference. They are 'not intended for applications involving prolonged, direct exposure to harsh chemicals, where heavy duty or industrial gloves are required, so they are thick, but not heavy duty, even though the description does say heavy duty.  Made in Thailand.

Little bear that sings and says things in English and Spanish, like "Sing along with me"  and "I love this song" followed by a cute little song about sunshine, rain, and being happy. Then it's followed by the same song in Spanish.  It's a huggable toy with nice colors and design.

Adorable little pony that looks more like a deer to me, but it works.  It's made with solid plastic with several little nondescript noises. The horse has a fairly long mane and tail to brush and groom and the body of the horse is smooth plastic.  It has really big eyes.

Note that this is the 20 lb. bag, not the 40 lb.  It's a handy way to get your grass seed delivered to your front door. Basically you just spread it and keep it moist until the grass is big enough to survive.

These are exceptionally sharp. The grip is small but 'extra wide' to make it easy to grasp.  They work really well.  Keep away from children and don't use them if you are in a klutzy frame of mind. These are serious tweezers that live up to their name, 'Slice' if you aren't careful.  I like them very much.

These latex-free industrial gloves go  on easily. They seem thinner than some and work well. Because they are black, they are easy to identify among my others. These are designed to work with solvents, antifreeze, lacquers, gasoline, grease, silicoates, brake cleaner, hand cleaner, ethylene glycol, glass cleaner, paint thinners, hydraulic oil, carburator cleaner, transmission fluid, and adhesive remover. At least they have 'Chemical Resistance' to them.
Comprehensive resource on how community college finance works. It's well written, carefully referenced, and easy to understand.

Interesting.  Te epilator function worked well. I have other epilators and they are always fairly painless for me and this one was painless as well. My favorite part was the foot care head. I was skeptical because my feet are pretty much hopeless, but I can see that this really does help.

Excellent resource.  There is so much bad information out there about resumes and cover letters. They promote silly, ridiculous statements that lack common sense.  This book has some very good suggestions. Better than most.

The PUR 11 cup ultimate pitcher with LED replacement filter light was very easy to put together and start using, and I am a klutz with anything even remotely mechanical.  Eleven cups doesn't seem like a lot, but I  have used a PUR system before and it is a very good system. I'm very pleased with it.

These are excellent. They are sturdy, the right size, and they close well. I very much like the fact that they are recycled. I even like the funky grey color. That's a nice change from the usual choice of either white or black.

I wanted to use this without using the app, as it says that you can do according to the instructions. I haven't been able to get it to do anything other than light up the SET button. Nothing else happens no matter what I do.  It's attractive.  I just wish it worked for me.

We're already agreeing with and using many of the main concepts in the book, but I have concerns. I'd like to look ahead 10 or 15 years and see how this all pans out. My gut feeling is that we will have given away our means of employment to those who will do it faster and cheaper, but not better.  I agree that actual employment isn't necessary to get the work done. The author's conclusion of "This will lead to a host of dislocations for us as individuals and citizens. It's natural and appropriate to worry about how this will affect our children."  I agree that "there will be some good and some bad, but no guarantee of anything close to an optimal outcome."  Can we, as he suggests, "If we're smart individually and collectively" ensure that the good outweighs the bad?  I'm not sure we're that smart. I think history has proven otherwise.  I do agree though that being proactive is better than trying to hang on to the past. Interesting.

While my own opinion of this is that it was a product failure and practically worthless, babies sometimes like things that adults don't expect them to like. This may be one of those things. I can't imagine it, but it's possible.  There is a distorted-view mirror something like the ones in a fun house or house of mirrors. I can't see how that can be helpful. One page 'crinkles' and if you press the right way you get sound from the little packet with musical notes on it that is connected to the soft 'book' with a ribbon.  It wasn't very impressive.  I would recommend that they try again. Nice idea, poorly executed.

This is the story of a dividing line, originally a shepherd's path, sometimes a street, between Jerusalem and Bethlehem. It's the story of people on both sides, living right on the border, sometimes peacefully, other times embroiled in fighting and brutality.  So very many people have lived on or near this dividing line between Israeli-controlled West Jerusalem and Jordanian-controlled East Jerusalem, and this is their story.

Love it. I love all the Battle Bugs books. They are easy to read and enticing. I think they are a great encouragement for reading once you get far enough into it to care about the characters.  That initial getting into it may not be easy, but it would be worth it.

Adorable little brown bear who is actually bigger than I thought he would be from the picture. You press the 'heart' button on his little green diaper cover and he laughs (or giggles) and says: 'I'm a curious bear ready for adventure."  Then he sings, " I'm a little brown bear. I like to crawl  1, 2, 3, 4, away I go.  Come on, follow me!"  Then his lets start moving and he crawls, encouraging the 6-36 month old to follow him. He also says other things like, "How fast can you crawl?"He's got a great face. There are flashing lights, but not obnoxious ones. The sound is probably enough for parents to want to pull the plug on it at times.  It isn't necessary to remove a battery and tell the child it's broken as sometimes happens in our family. The bear has a volume control on it and an automatic shut off.  Thank Goodness!  There are 5 songs and 10 little blips of music.It requires 3 AA batteries.

DYMO has had a good idea to package the printer with the labels so you can buy all at once with no worries that you might get the wrong kind or size labels. Very nice idea.  I found out the hard way that my computer system on my Macintosh isn't compatible with the Label Writer 450, so I had to pass it along to a staff member who uses a PC. I ended up with a very nice Smart Label printer that does work with the Mac.  *Compatible with Windows 7 or later and Mac OS X v10.8 or later.  Be sure to check to make sure yours is compatible. If you don't, you may end up frustrated like I did. Other than that, I've always liked the way the DYMO works and the quality of the machine and labels.

There isn't much 'fluff' in this book. That's good because most of us have had enough bumper-sticker mentality in our lives and want information based on facts. What you do fine is helpful information that you can put to use immediately. It's heavy on the food part rather than exercise, which was fine for me. That's where I need the most help.  It also isn't only for men.There are sections for fast fuel, slow fuel. There's even a section for those of us who are vegetarians, helpful sample shopping lists that are actually usable. Again, I stick with the basics and don't prefer books with lots of foods I can't pronounce, wouldn't recognize if I saw, and wouldn't be able to find.  This was well done..

Using examples that we're all familiar with, the author has told the story of great brands and what made them great. There is a great deal to read and absorb, pretty much all of it interesting. Anyone reading it will most likely develop or reignite a passion for their business, whether they are the CEO or not. It's an energetic book full of new information. I recommend it.

These are the best I've tried so far, and I've tried almost all of the different Hefty Odor Block Tall Kitchen Bags.  The first thing I noticed when I was opening the box is I was already prepared for a strong scent, but it wasn't. It was just a very subtle fresh scent that was very pleasant. I loved it! This is my all-time favorite because it doesn't hit you over the head with odor-block fragrance.  Very nice!  The size is great because there is ample room in it, extra room, not skimpy as some are, and it ties efficiently.  All-in-all, this is a winner.

I bought the small size in these Nitrile Industrial Gloves, and they fit fine. They go on (and off) easily and it's easy to work using them. They are for non-medical use and are latex free and powder free. There is a caution that there are some components which may cause allergic reactions in some people. I suppose that's true in almost anything.
I like the Tone on tone side panels. They look good. I like the material and design. It's made in Egypt. It's a very comfortable material and is made to last.

The doll, sled, and Sven are all impressive looking and definitely attention-getting. However, the box delivery and presentation was a huge disappointment.  I've never seen toys displayed that way and now I know why.  It didn't make the toys themselves any less fun, but the plain old brown box didn't make anyone smile either.  The toys themselves though are lots of fun and represent the whole Frozen concept well.

I'm enjoying the AHAVA Purifying Mud Mask very much. It's easy to apply and feels refreshing. I got to experience floating in the Dead Sea with all of those minerals when I was in Israel. It's fun to be able to experience at home as well. It appears to work as advertised and will most likely be an effective way to clarify skin over time.

I think I heard my feet say 'thank you' for the Dermud  Intensive Foot Cream. I had heard about it for years. It feels wonderful. It has a great smell. After a few minutes I felt a really pleasant tingling sensation. I have to admit that I put some on my elbows and arms that felt dry.  Very nice!

This is a cute but small toy drone with an auto stunt button that makes it do flips. It also has "Auto take-off, auto hover, and auto land" as well. It's fairly sturdy, but I think it needs adult supervision until your children know the rules, limitations, and what 'not' to do with it and where 'not' to fly it. Keeping that in mind, it's a fun toy for anyone who likes to 'fly' things.

Works great!  This box-cutter is the size of a writing pen and feels a little like one when you are using it.  I just had a couple of large boxes that I was avoiding cutting to throw away and tried it out.  It makes a very sharp, clean cut.  I tried it on a smaller piece of cardboard and the cut on it was razor-thin.  I'll be using it often.

This is a beautiful set for any child that is interested in horses. The set is well designed and the pieces are well made. This isn't a use-once-and-discard kind of toy. It's one that will be used for hours and possibly years.

This is a beautiful suitcase. Very light weight. It reminds me of a shiny black fancy fast sports car. I love all of the wonderful features including the pull-down but securely set-in handle for when you don't want to use it, the regular handle, the well-built wheels, and the security lock.  I LOVE the fact that it has a handle so you can carry it from either the long end or the short one.  Even though I rarely pick it up because it's so great to be able to roll it everywhere,  that's a brilliant idea, at least when you're loading and unloading it. This case is such a great size!  It's right in between my small carry-on, under-the-seat one and the one I take for 3 weeks overseas. This is a very handy size for small trips, but trips where I need a little more than a simple carry-on.  It's so easy to move around on those 4 wheels.  I know I sound like a Tumi commercial, but I don't think you can get better suitcases anywhere. They are simply and beautifully put together to last, and I have tested them in every conceivable way. Tumi always passes my tests.It comes with a little white cover to keep the suitcase from picking up dirt or lint while stored, which it would in this case because of its shiny black surface, which collects lint.At first I couldn't figure out how to open it. You align the 3 numbers on '0' and then you take your thumb and move the tab over and it works beautifully. Now I really do feel silly for struggling to figure it out, but I am so happy because the inside is just as gorgeous as the outside.I have another large Tumi suitcase that I've taken all over the world. It has been on planes, buses, ships, cars, and who knows what else.  It is still just as beautiful as ever.  Now my son has it and I'm afraid he may have forgotten that he has it on loan, not as a gift, but he has taken it from sea-to-shining-sea more than a few times and he's not careful with things. It was one of the best purchases I've ever made.  Now I have two beautiful Tumi cases and I'm very pleased with both of them.

I love this hand cream. It has a really refreshing but very light scent and goes on in a thick, luxurious cream that my skin just drinks in. The thing I like about it most is that I never take time to do anything about my awful nails and cuticles. This cream is designed to help condition them, and I appreciate that.  This is large tube that will last quite a long time.  My skin feels smooth and healthier.

Intelligent, well-written book about the potential demise of just about everything as we know it. Obviously my short review can't cover all that was included, but one part was particularly interesting to me as an investor who is interested in our American economy. If you think back to the 2008 financial crisis, "Student loan debt is now greater than total US credit card debt, with the average student loan balance being $29,000." "One oout of five Americans over the age of twenty owes money on student loans, and half of them are worried about it." Currently the average payment on student loans is $279 per month, which is not easy to pay on an entry-level salary after rent and car payments. There was a quote from investor Mark Cuban with "dire predictions that ballooning student loans are poised to trigger the next major deb crisis in the US, rivaling the home mortgage debt crisis for its potential to upend the economy."  Most people don't realize that students owing that student loan deb can't get rid of it by declaring bankruptcy.  That causes students to 'settle' for less risky jobs with a lot less future potential that may be 'converting higher education into a bloated luxury product."  Okay, that is just one part of the book that SCREAMED out to me, but there are parts that will probably call out to you as well.  Robotics have the potential to take over many jobs but, according to the book, have not done well with healthcare technology. Interesting, thought-provoking, and more than a little unsettling, so if you are a person who has trouble sleeping, probably better pass this one up.

The Call: The Life and Message of the Apostle Paul is an easy-to-read story of Paul's travels. It almost felt a bit like a travel guide, with maps and charts, and wonderful pictures. I've had the opportunity to visit some of the places mentioned: Athens, Corinth, Ephesus and others, and the pictures were those I would have chosen to include as 'companions' to the stories. This is not the book Biblical scholars are waiting for about Paul. It's not intended to be. It is informative though, and I enjoyed reading it.

Really cute doll that actually could be of any race or nationality. She has a cute little pink dress, a few 'jewels' everywhere, adorable little high-heel shoes, a cute little colorful purse, and very nice hair. She's pretty and very lovable, spotlighting her 'inner' beauty.

Steve Martini has pulled out all stops to make this legal thriller #13 in the Paul Madriani series into a comprehensive legal thriller with a background of  political and financial conspiracies, woven around an up-to-the-moment environment of electronic manipulation.Alex Ives goes to a party and wakes up in his car 50 miles away after a fatal high speed crash. He has no recollection of leaving the party and his blood alcohol level is minor. The driver of the other car who was incinerated after the crash is Olinda Serna a Washington lawyer with powerful friends and financial connections.When Alex is accused of homicide he asks Madriani for help in defending him in court. It is soon clear to Madriani that the crash may been staged and that Alex is in danger because he should have also been killed in the crash. He sets out to uncover everything he can about Serna and her clients - a search that leads to a path of political and financial corruption, both in Washington and overseas, and shadowy people with worldwide connections who will murder to maintain their power.This is not your run-of-the-mill legal thriller - it has a bit of everything to keep you on the edge of your seat. A lot of what you read is beyond the bounds of believability but is very entertaining and if you like this kind of escapism you will enjoy this book. This is another case where a best-selling author has gone to great lengths with a new plot to keep a long running series alive. I see seeds of international espionage and powerplay in the plot that suggest that this is only the beginning of a longer story and despite his successes Paul Madriani and his small legal firm will continue to be accidentally involved in things beyond their control.My thanks to The Reading Room and the publisher for an advance copy of this book for review.

Once again Stuart MacBride has produced a top "Scottish Noir" crime thriller featuring DS Logan McRae and his whacky police colleagues in Aberdeen. While Aberdeen is the star location for most of the action it shines as a place that I would like to avoid, both in climate and lifestyle.McRae is caught up in the investigation of a myriad of difficult and violent cases, mostly with a violent sexual background. A bloody body is found with terrible wounds and investigations suggest that a local BDSM bondage group may know something about it. A serial rapist is menacing and torturing girls in both Aberdeen and Dundee. An attack on Logan's girl-friend PC Jackie `Ball Breaker' Watson who was out along late acting as bait suggests that it may be Aberdeen Football Club's star player - but he has an alibi for each time the rapist strikes. Jackie is not convinced and she is hell-bent on proving that he is the rapist. On top of all of this an 8 year old boy runs away after he stabs and kills an old man and puts a policewoman into intensive care with knife wounds.This all means lots of overtime for McRae, but lots of problems in dealing with his superiors, overweight and angry DI Inch and foul mouthed crazy lesbian DI Steel. All of this is light and very amusing relief from trying to find murderers and a rapist. A warning - there are some parts of the book with very vivid descriptions of violence and sex that are not for the faint hearted.There is one amusing dig at MacBride's biggest competitor in the field of "Scottish Noir", Ian Rankin. When the local BDSM group plan their activities they meet in an upstairs room of a local pub under the pretext of  discussing books by Ian Rankin.You probably need to read earlier books in the series to really appreciate the characters and the setting. McRae is a bit of an enigmatic character to me, a good diligent policeman who deserves better from his job and from his bosses. All in all another very realistic but amusing police procedural which is well recommended. I plan to keep on reading more books in this addictive series.

I have read and enjoyed several books in the Jake Grafton series by Stephen Coonts but unfortunately IMHO this one is a "Lemon". It falls between the early adventures when Jake Grafton is a Naval pilot and the latter stories when Grafton is associated with covert operations. This time Grafton is working in the Pentagon directly for the Joint Chief of Staff on drug related issues and seems to be a bit out of his depth in a pretty unrealistic story.What would happen if a Colombian drug lord is apprehended and brought to trial in DC? What would happen if that drug lord (with a wealth of billions of dollars) wants to spend part of his wealth hiring terrorists and assassins to bring Washington to its knees? Coonts paints a violent picture of a missile attack on the President's helicopter, the assassination of several key politicians, Judges and power brokers plus an invasion of suicide gangs intent on killing as many people as possible.What is the outcome - martial law and Grafton and his cronies trying to find the main assassin and destroy the suicide gangs. This is done against a background of war between drug dealers. IMHO things like this are a bit over the top.All in all this book really didn't work for me especially because Coonts involved real people in the drama, with George Bush Snr and Dan Quayle taking leading parts in the fiction. He also manufactured a fictitious overthrow of Fidel Castro.The only part of this story that really interested me was that Coonts told me how Washington Post journalist Jack Yocke became an unusual associate of Grafton - something that had puzzled me in some future books where Hockey plays an important supporting role.All in all I still love the Jake Grafton series, despite this "Lemon".

The late Walter Tevis was a fantastic storyteller, especially when the story involves someone who has an inbuilt need to win. This time the tale is about 'Fast Eddie' Felsen, a young pool hustler, who had an ambition to beat the best pool players in the country.After making his seed money in small Pool Halls around the US, Eddie arrives in Chicago to find Minnesota Fats - the best there is. Travis describes Eddie's first pool battle with Fats almost on a stroke by stroke basis, building up the tension, the exhaustion and the emotional strengths of the two players.This is also a coming of age story for Eddie as he meets shy Sarah, slowly falls in love but doesn't have the emotional strength to understand what is happening. Travis also shows that Eddie can't make it to the top without support from others and how Eddie doesn't realise that he needs that support to  achieve his dreams.You don't need to be a pool player to understand what is happening as Travis is a master in describing complex things in simple and understandable language. While his prose is straightforward he is able to put you into the middle of an action-filled and evocative arena. His games become battle scenes as bloody and compelling as scenes on a real battlefield.I first encountered Tevis's work in The Queen's Gambit where the battle scenes were on the chess board (and you didn't need to know how to play chess to appreciate the action). Tevis followed up THE HUSTLER  with The Color of Money where we meet Eddie later in life still wanting to follow the ambitions of his youth. I look forward to reading that book soon.

Over the years David Baldacci has created a range of interesting characters and this one is probably one of the most unusual. Amos Decker was involved in a serious violent football tackle where he died twice and woke up with hyperthymesia (an exceptional memory of everything that happens).Amos - the "Memory Man"- went on to become an excellent detective (helped by his great recall of details). One evening he returns home and finds his wife, young daughter, and brother-in-law have been brutally murdered. Amos's world collapses as he is not able to forget anything about that night - his mind replays things like a DVD. He just avoids suicide, quits his job, and becomes homeless. Eventually he pulls himself together sufficiently to set up as a PI and earn enough to live in a low-cost Motel.Amos is a pretty forbidding character, six-five, and has let himself go - fifty pounds overweight, shaggy and initially bearded. Because of his "gifts" his social skills are lacking (he's a bit of  a UK TV's Doc Martin).Horrific murders happen at the local high school and Amos is asked by the local police chief to help because they a don't have a clue how the killer got into or out of the school. At the same time a strange man confesses to the police that he murdered Amos's family, but was in police custody at the time of the murders. Amos has to take better control of himself as the two tragedies slowly converge and he is the only person who can unravel what has happened.Baldacci has written a complex, frequently confused story about a huge man with a huge memory who is struggling to understand and survive huge emotional traumas. The plot meanders and loses direction and sometimes passes the believability level. 3.5 stars.The book it is listed as a standalone but the ending suggests that Baldacci plans to bring Amos back and it seems to me that he has edited parts at the last moment to allow this to happen. This is very confusing - I am not sure if this is a good idea as Baldacci has several other good characters around (for example, Will Robie, the hitman with a conscience, is coming back in November - The Guilty).

One day a "Stranger" approaches Adam Price at a school sports meeting and tells him that his wife faked a recent pregnancy and miscarriage to keep him from leaving. He also speculates that Adam might want to check the DNA of his sons to prove that he is really the father.Adam's world is turned upside down when he finds that his wife has purchased something from a website called Fake-A-Pregnancy.com. He confronts his wife who asks for time to think about a response - then she disappears.  The Stranger then tells someone else unpleasant things about how a family member is financing her college fees that has a serious impact on that person's life.The story develops as the impacts of the Stranger's activity unravel and have more serious and complex consequences than anyone could envisage.While the plot is fascinating the writing and the setting didn't grip me. I put the book down several times and moved over to other books that took my attention before eventually getting to the half-way point when the implications of the various revelations started to unravel and become more interesting. I think part of the reason for my lack of connection is that the US setting in a society absorbed in living the dream, especially in the competitive field of college sports is foreign to me as an Aussie.I have read and enjoyed most of the the last few of Coben's annual mysteries, but this one didn't rank as highly as the others. 3.5 stars rounded down.

Bernard Cornwell has written another page-turning historical adventure featuring Lieutenant Richard Sharpe, a foot soldier in the Napoleonic Wars between France and Britain, this time during the campaign in northern Portugal in the spring of 1809.Sharpe is leading a very small company of riflemen cut off in Portugal from the main English army when French Marshall Soult takes the key city of Oporto, a key stepping stone to taking the capital Lisbon. While it is an almost impossible task to fight his way back to British lines, Sharpe is ordered to follow Lieutenant Colonel James Christopher (a Foreign Office agent) and find Kate Savage, a 19 year old English girl who has run away from her mother to a town under attack by the French. On the way Sharpe joins up with a group of 37 Portuguese soldiers who have also been cut off during the attack on Oporto.At last Sharpe is beginning to make his mark as an officer, despite the distrust of his peers of someone who was born into poverty and his troops towards someone who started out as a humble private.  Sharpe achieved his promotion to an officer through bravery in the field and gets the respect of his troops through tough and skilful leadership under almost impossible conditions.Sharpe, his men and the Portuguese group fight their way out of danger against far superior French forces and track down the renegade Colonel Christopher who has suddenly become an ally of the French. Their only hope is that General Arthur Wellesley (the future Duke of Wellington) will arrive with relief forces in time to drive the French out of Portugal.This is another great adrenaline-filled page-turning authentic historical re-enactment with Richard Sharpe taking a front-seat role in the battles for the control of Portugal. 4.5 stars.I have resolved to read all of this brilliant series - so far I have read 9 with only 13 to go. I read this book as part of 3 book Sharpe Kindle bundle available in the Australian region.

E-novellas are normally written as promos for a forthcoming full length book - this one is no exception. The main difference is that Steve Martini wrote this novella to highlight the issue of the impact of Post Traumatic Stress Disorder on returning US military personnel. US Navy SEAL's are highly trained killers who are sworn to secrecy about their sometimes very deadly missions. Adjusting to the peaceful environment of civilian life after being a SEAL is even more difficult and stressful than for most other military personnel.Paul Madriani is asked for legal help by an ex Navy SEAL who says he is being sought by the authorities for disclosures he may have made about the most famous SEAL raid ever. While Madriani is not prepared to help the SEAL he gets dragged into a deadly game of intrigue when his girl friend joins the SEAL to find out more about a top-secret drone program.This is a short, somewhat disjointed story about a dangerous man with a dangerous medical condition. 3.5 stars.

This is #1 in the long-running John Rebus series by Ian Rankin. While it has some of the signs of a debut novel it also shows Rankin's great ability in plotting a thriller and developing a character as complex as John Rebus.After an eventful and stressful experience with the SAS Rebus is adjusting to life as a Detective Sergeant in the Edinburgh homicide squad. He is still suffering from post traumatic stress but he can't remember what was the real trigger. He drinks too much, smokes too much and still suffers nightmares. His marriage has collapsed, he only sees his teenage daughter occasionally and his love life is occasional.Rebus is thrown into a major investigation of a serial killer of young girls where there are no real clues except that the killer will strike again. The only thing that can be done is to try and find a clue through diligent police work. Rebus is part of the team but doesn't realise that the case has a personal element - until almost too late.There is a bit of a strange sub-plot featuring Rebus's brother John who has taken over his father's profession as a stage hypnotist, and a local crime journalist who thinks he knows more than he really does.Ian Rankin has written 19 bestselling crime novels in the John Rebus series with another one (Even Dogs in the Wild) due to be published in November 2015. This series has come a long way since this book was first published nearly 30 years ago. At the time Rankin contemplated making it a standalone book - thank goodness he allowed the series to develop. It now has a such a cult following that the real settings used in later books in the series are now part of tourist "John Rebus" tours.There is still some time before #20 in the series is published and I will try to find the time to read more of this great series before then. Unfortunately there are other talented writers of "Tartan Crime Noir", especially Stuart MacBride, who will compete for my attention.

This is a wonderful book about a remarkable character. "With some people chess is a pastime, with others it is a compulsion, even an addiction... every now and then a person comes along for whom it is a birthright." This person is Beth Harmon - "she is quiet and well-mannered. And (when she plays chess) she is out for blood..." She hates to lose.Beth Harmon was orphaned at the age of eight when her parents were killed in an automobile accident. She is placed in an orphanage in Kentucky that is almost a modern equivalent of a Dickensian orphanage, with children given tranquilisers twice a day to keep them calm and controllable - opening the gates to long-term addictions..One day when cleaning the board erasers in the basement for a teacher, Beth comes across an old janitor playing chess alone. After several attempts the janitor agrees to show her how to play chess, and she goes over the moves in her head during the lonely hours when she can't sleep. It takes three games for Beth to win her first game and in three months the janitor can no longer beat her. Then he gives her a book - "Modern Chess Openings" - and Beth is addicted to chess for life, playing chess movements and strategy in her mind in class and in bed at night.At thirteen she wins a local chess Tournament. With the help of her foster-mother by the age of sixteen she is competing in the US Open Championship. Her ultimate challenge is to go to Russia to face and beat the Russian world champions.While it helps to know something about chess is not important because the late Walter Tevis wrote in a way that even if you don't understand what is really happening you are part of the action and this keeps you on the edge of your seat, barracking for Beth. If you are a chess "expert" you might find errors in the game and strategic descriptions, but you need to remember that chess is the vehicle Tevis uses to tell us a wonderful tale that could also apply to almost any competitive game.The Queen's Gambit is a more than a story about chess - it is fundamentally a thriller with the same kind of adrenaline filled action that takes you into the heat of battle in a similar way that Bernard Cornwell takes you with Richard Sharpe into the heart of battles between the British and the French in the Napoleonic wars. All along I had to remind myself that chess is fundamentally a battlefield game between sides with a King and Queen, who live in castles protected by knights, supported by their Bishops, with an army of Pawns (soldiers). Let battle commence!This is an exciting and beautifully crafted book which had a profound effect on me emotionally. It has gone straight to my best list of best reads of 2015 and will stay in my memory for a long time. Highly recommended.

While Nora Roberts' books are not my normal genre I try to read her annual romantic suspense releases (recently The Witness, The Collector, Whiskey Beach, Chasing Fire) to see how a bestselling author who has written so many books manages to turn out something different. While I have been impressed with her recent romantic suspense releases I was disappointed with this one.Shelby Foxworth lost her husband, Richard, in a boating accident. Then when she is settling his estate she lost her illusions of the man who provided  a life of luxury for herself and their daughter when she finds herself left with a crippling debt. Her luxury life was a complete fabrication, and Shelby soon finds that he was an adulterer, a liar and a con man.Staggering from the impact Shelby moves back home to her loving family who she deserted for the high life with Richard. Despite initial problems they welcome her back and she meets Griff Lott, a local building contractor who is totally the opposite of Richard. Of course following the typical Roberts formula, Shelby and Griff are immediately attracted to one another.In recent books Nora Roberts was able to mix her romantic formula's with interesting suspense and a courageous but flawed young woman. This time IMHO this formula was somewhat  disappointing. The romantic stuff would hardly make a successful Harlequin/Mills and Boon book, the suspense was weak and unbelievable and Shelby was not a very memorable or powerful heroine. I had worked out most of what was going to happen, both romantically and with the suspense plot when I had read about one fifth of the book.It seems to me that Nora Roberts has written so many books that she may be getting to her use-by date. Her romantic formulas are tired and repetitive and her suspense plots are becoming unbelievable. I did give it 3 stars but this is because it is not my normal genre and I am sure that there will be many readers who will love anything that Roberts writes.My thanks to Net Galley and the Australian publisher for a copy of this book for review.

This is a fascinating Cold War espionage thriller by the late Helen MacInnes set in Paris, Athens and Mykonos. MacInnes was well known for the many best-selling espionage thrillers that she wrote from 1941 to 1984 covering WWII and the Cold War.John Craig, a historian, is on a working holiday in Paris when he encounters Professor Sussman, one of his old teachers. Sussman tells Craig that he has just been a witness at war trials and tells him about his experiences in Auschwitz, especially with one of the worst of the Nazis, Heinrich Berg. While Berg is known to be buried in Berlin, when a stranger approaches Grossman he is sure that it is Berg. The next day Grossman is found dead in an apparent suicide from his hotel balcony.Through his sister, who has been working at the US Embassy in Moscow, Craig meets a strange mixture of people from various nations, many of whom eventually turn out to be in the espionage business and are seeking Berg who may be Russian Colonel Insarov. As Craig is the only person who has seen Berg he is persuaded to go to Mykanos where a major Russian espionage group is planning an exchange or a coup. Craig gets drawn into the web of intrigue and proves to be as good if not better than many of the professionals.This is a complex and compelling espionage tale with all the hallmarks of knowledge of fieldcraft of the day. Microfilm is the preferred data form for transfer of information as data storage and cell phones were still in the future. While I was absorbed and involved by the plot I had some difficulty in keeping up with who's who, from what country and who were working together. In the end a fair proportion of the tourists on the small island of Mykonos seemed to be spooks trying to outdo one another in their secret trades.This was a thoroughly enjoyable and well crafted espionage thriller that took me back to the days of the Cold War - 4.5 stars. I certainly plan to read some more of MacInnes's books which are now being re-released in e-book format. Next time I plan to visit one of her WWII thrillers.

I like financial thrillers and this one by Andrew Gross is one of the best I have read based on the events of the recent Global Financial Crisis. Gross uses his knowledge of the background to the GFC to craft a conspiracy thriller suggesting that it may have been partly manipulated by outside forces.Ty Hauck is a former NYPD detective who is now a private security consultant to a big financial institution, but despite the greater income benefits he is not comfortable with his new role. In the midst of the GFC a key market operator, Marc Glasman, his wife April and most of his family are killed during in a midnight home invasion. Hauck gets drawn into the case because during a traumatic time in his past he had become very close to April and he makes a promise to himself that he will discover the truth behind the tragedy.The killings become financially important when it is discovered that Glasman has billions of dollars in outstanding trades that could bring down one of the biggest Wall Street businesses. Then another Wall Street trader who appears to have committed suicide is also found to have billions of bad outstanding trades.Hauck's soon realises that he is looking at murders arranged by powerful forces. He joins forces with Naomi Blum, a beautiful and ambitious US Treasury investigator as they track down the people behind this major financial conspiracy.Andrew Grosss is a top-notch thriller writer who has written a page-turning and mostly plausible financial thriller that goes behind the scenes of the worst financial disaster in recent times. I will certainly look out for other books in his Ty Hauck series.

It has been several years since I read a Sean Dillon thriller by Jack Higgins, and it was great to read one again. This time Dillon, ex-IRA enforcer, who is surprisingly now part of a covert group supporting the UK Government, takes a bit of a back seat with the introduction of Major Harry Miller MP who has as similar background of violence to Dillon, but from the other side.Miller is on a mission for the UK Prime Minister (as his personal Rottweiler) to find out more about Russian influence in Kosovo when he meets Blake Johnston, the US President's head of dark forces. The meeting becomes explosive when Miller shoots the leader of a squad of Russian soldiers who are about to commit an atrocity to the inhabitants of a small village in Kosovo near the Russian border. The incident has international repercussions in London, Washington and Moscow and brings Miller, Dillon and Major Ferguson together to defeat the plans of the secretive "Broker" with connections to Bin Laden, and Putin's Rottweiler General Volkov.The plot is made more entertaining and different with the introduction of Miller's sister Monica, Lady Starling, a lovely widowed University Don who is immediately attracted to and excited by the dangerous Dillon.While some of the plot was a bit over the top it did show that Jack Higgins continues to be a master craftsman of page-turning political thrillers full of exciting international suspense, intrigue and action. I hope to catch up with a few more in the series from time to time as I have always enjoyed Jack Higgins writing and am sure that they will keep me well entertained.

For some time I have been meaning to sample one of Laura Lippman's books about Tess Monaghan, first an investigative reporter and now a "fearless" private investigator. I was disappointed.Tess is a strange PI who really doesn't know what she is doing and stumbles around (trailing her pet Greyhound with her) doing silly things that accidentally lead her to solving a case. I really didn't connect with the character, the writing or the plot and only finished this book by flipping the pages and thinking that things would improve - which they didn't.

John J Davis has chosen a complex plot for his debut (spy?) novel about the Granger family. Ron and Valerie Granger are living a quiet rural life with their brilliant 16 year old daughter Leecy when their peace is abruptly disturbed one night by a home invasion that attempts to kidnap Leecy.Ron and Valerie are no normal rural couple working in a small family business - both of them have a history, Ron with the CIA and Valerie with Mossad. They have been waiting for the right opportunity to tell Leecy something about their history when everything unravels. Ron overcomes one of the invaders single-handed and Valerie shoots the other invader in the head with professional accuracy.The family leaves home on the run, after stopping off to get pre-packed "Go" bags for both parents containing weapons, money and false identities.  Their aim it to to find the mastermind before he finds them.Leecy is soon asking for answers about what her parents did before she was born which she surprisingly finds exciting. When Ron asks for assistance from his former CIA minder things get very complex and dangerous.I don't know why Davis called this a spy novel as neither parent was a spy - they were assassins. It is a brave plot for an action-packed debut novel but it didn't absorb my attention as much as it should. There will be more books in the series released soon but my jury is still out on whether I will want to find out more about how this family business develops and prospers.

This is a fantastic historical fictional novel about the early troubled years of the State of Israel. Herman Wouk takes us from the 1948 Arab-Israeli War after the UN vote that recommended the partitioning of Israel, through Israeli cooperation with France and Britain and invasion of Egypt during the Suez crisis, to the bloody but overwhelming victory of the Six Day War.Wouk has a magic touch in being able to seamlessly integrate fictional and real historical characters with both insight and compassion in action-packed environments. David Ben Gurion, Moshe Dyan, Golda Meir and West Point trained US Army colonel "Mickey" Marcus (who was Israel's first military chief of staff during the 1948 Arab-Israeli War), are larger than life.Fictional characters include Austrian born Zev Barak, an Army officer, later military attaché in Washington; Sam Pasternak, born in Czechoslovakia - a combat officer, later in military intelligence and a renowned womaniser; Benny Luria, born in Moshe Dayan's moshav who becomes an Air force pilot and leads a squadron that destroyed the Egyptian air force within minutes of the start of the Six Day War; and Benny's beautiful sister Yael (who has also been an Army officer), caught between a love of Israel, her family and the magnetic attractions of living the high-life in the US.The most fascinating fictional character is Polish born Yossi Nitzan, fresh out of the refugee camps of Europe who turns up at the front in the 1948 War as "a lanky bespectacled dust-covered boy of sixteen or so, wearing a rusty British tin hat and mounted bareback on a muddy white mule.". He is immediately nicknamed "Don Kishote" (Quixote in Hebrew) and volunteers for the war - "I'm eighteen. Give me a gun." Kishote eventually becomes a paratroop leader in the Suez war and a Tank Commander in the Six Day War.This is edge-of-seat adrenaline-packed authentic historical action written by one of the World's best storytellers. Of course Wouk writes from a Jewish perspective backed up by vital knowledge about the various ways the Jewish religion is practiced. It is this comprehensive perspective of Jewish life that helps to explain the painful birth of modern Israel. I was captivated when I read this book when it was first published in 1993 and was even more captivated when I read it again recently.I plan to revisit the sequel The Glory very soon. Both books would have been given six stars if that was permitted.

This is an enjoyable and intriguing story by talented author Australian author Fiona McIntosh set in 1930's England.
