Stella, an impoverished but well educated young woman takes a job as a French/Piano governess/tutor to support her much younger brother and sister.It all starts with a chance meeting with an unusual man at a Piccadilly ballroom who orchestrates a job with the wealthy but strange Ainsworth family at their huge home in Sussex. While Douglas Ainsworth welcomes her, his wife and teenage daughter don't want her help. Slowly Stella learns something about the family secrets and more about the world of the mysterious Douglas.Things come to a head when Douglas decides to take his whole family and Stella on a cruise calling at North Africa, Egypt and the Holy Land leading to two unexpected endings.Both Suncoast and Mrs Suncoast read and enjoyed this book. Mrs Suncoast read and enjoyed Fiona McIntosh's previous book Nightingaleand considered that this one is as good if not better. Mrs Suncoast gave this book 5 stars, Suncoast gave it 4.5 stars as it is not his normal genre.Our thanks to Penguin Australia for an advanced copy of this book for review.

Bernard Cornwell's long running series about Richard Sharpe, a foot-soldier in India and in the Napoleonic Wars is one of the best historical series around. Sharpe's Rifles is set at the time of the brutal French Invasion of Galicia in Spain in January 1809.While Richard Sharpe joined the Army to avoid prison he quickly found that he loved a life of a soldier, especially the adrenaline pumping excitement of battle. He has proved himself in battle and gained a stunning battlefield promotion to become an officer. This is not a comfortable situation as other officers look down on him because he is not their class and his troops who won't look up to him because he is not seen to be a proper officer.Sharpe has moved on to join the  95th Rifles who are posted to Spain. His Company Commander is killed in a skirmish with the French and Sharpe is left in command to get his Company to safety through French lines. This would be hard enough with the respect of his riflemen which is not forthcoming, especially from the dominating and difficult Irishman Harper who the troops look up to instead of Sharpe. The battle of wills between two strong personalities is enthralling and compelling.Sharpe's Company meet up with Spanish cavalry commanded by aristocrat Major Vivar who means to raise the flag of Spain's patron saint over Santiago de Compostela, now in French hands. Sharpe is faced with a dilemma, to help Viva or to go it alone in dangerous country.Once again this is a history lesson about the art of war in the early 19th Century which is bloody and brutal. It is also the story of a brave and clever man of common background who has to face up to his gremlins to get the respect of his men.I found some of the background, especially Sharpe's relationship with women from a genteel background, is a little confusing because the book was written before SHARPE'S TRAFALGAR (which comes before Rifles in the timeline) where Sharpe has a torrid and very emotional relationship with Lady Grace Hale.Once again this is a great page-turning story which puts you in a front row seat on the battleground and builds up Sharpe's character as he faces up to his gremlins and shows that he is one of the smartest soldiers of his generation. I still have lots of Sharpe's adventures to share and I look forward to reading them from time to time as exciting relief from more contemporary novels. 4.5 stars.

This is the final volume of Herman Wouk's two masterly historical novels about the early days of Israel. Wouk is a compelling storyteller of Israel's dangerous and exciting days from the end of the Six Day War through the battles of the Yom Kippur War, the Entebbe Rescue and the first Camp David agreements.Wouk tells the story through a few compelling fictional characters who interact seamlessly with real characters such as Golda Meir, Moshe Dayan and Menachem Begin and Egypt's Anwar Sadat.This is edge-of-seat adrenaline-packed authentic and exhaustively researched historical action written by one of the World's best storytellers. Of course Wouk writes from a Jewish perspective backed up by vital knowledge about Jewish life and values and the various ways the Jewish religion is practiced. Despite this he pulls no punches with detailed descriptions of the chaotic practice of politics in Israel, the arguments, the disasters and the triumphs.The surprise attack at the start of the Yom Kippur War by several Arab countries caught Israel by surprise during one of it most revered religious holidays and shows how close Israel came to absolute defeat. In the end audacity and sheer military skill left Israeli tanks within striking distance of Damascus and 100,000 Egyptian troops surrounded and starving in the Sinai. These amazing achievements have so easily been forgotten.This a front-row seat of history as Israel becomes the centre of the Cold War and the World gets nearly as close to a nuclear war as the Cuban missile crisis. It also forms the foundation of the US support for Israel.The story ends in the early 1980's - so much has happened since then as Israel continues to live a fortress existence, now facing different kinds of terrorist enemies and looming nuclear capabilities in Iran. The saga continues.....

This is a playful story, written for an older child, about how to keep your body healthy. Nolan is out exploring the woods--searching for a good spot to build a fort--when he accidentally falls and cuts his knee. He knows his body is doing all it can to repair the cut and fight off any germs that have entered into his body. So he works doubly hard to eat right and rest, so his body has all the nutrients and energy it needs to heal.There are some more advanced concepts in here (like T-cells, B-cells, lymph nodes, etc.), but the cute, fun illustrations go a long way in helping the reader understand the content. As a parent, I also like that Nolan is active and engaged in imaginative play, and that, in the story, his parents encourage his independence.Moreover, I applaud author Wu for not overly-vilifying junk food. We all know that sweets and treats aren't good for us if we eat them all the time. But being too negative about unhealthy foods has a tendency to backfire and give kids food hang ups. Thankfully, Wu doesn't put too much judgment on food choices. Nolan has a dessert of yogurt and fruit, and even though he wants to have that Ultimate Chocolate Sandwich cookie, he tells himself, well, I'm working on healing my body tonight, so I'm going to eat healthier foods; I can still have that special treat tomorrow. What a perfect way to handle that situation.Overall, this is a really cute story that will definitely help kids understand their immune systems better. The story is easily accessible, and the battle theme will appeal to young imaginations.

This book is a helpful resource for kids who want to learn more about what it is (or will be) like to have a newborn baby in the house. Emily is very excited to meet her baby sister, Sarah. But she isn't sure what to expect either. This book follows Emily as she meets her new sister and then learns how to help her parents take care of their very young baby.The book covers a lot of important and relevant info that will genuinely help a child understand what babies are like. Wu talks about nursing, bathing, umbilical cords, why Mommy is so tired, baby milestones, changing diapers, etc., etc. And I like that Emily interacts with and asks questions of, not just her mother, but her aunt and father, too. Having multiple family members involved seems much more realistic to me.I am not completely sure who the intended audience for this book is, though. In my opinion, the book is probably going to be best for a slightly older child, since there are definitely not enough pictures to keep the interest of any kid under the age of five or six. But I'm also confused by the "helpful tips" section located in the front of the book. I think it is intended to be read by parents (?), since this section talks about topics like how to position a baby during breastfeeding. But if it IS meant to be read by parents only, I would suggest to the author that it be put in the back of the book, after the story. Otherwise, it's confusing to the (young) reader.Overall, I like the idea of this book. I believe it is very important to keep kids connected and in the loop when it comes to major family transitions. Any resource that can help a child be more comfortable with something so life-changing as a new baby is wonderful. My only wish is that there would be more clarity about the age of the intended reader.

I was looking forward to reading this book. I love The Husband's Secret, so I had high hopes for All of Us and Everything. Plus, I really like stories that focus on relationships between sisters, and relationships between mothers and daughters, so I really thought this one was going to be a good fit for me.Yikes, what a disappointment. While I think there was some potential here for an interesting story with weird, eccentric, engaging characters, author Bridget Asher just couldn't pull it off. The story is sprawling and unfocused. It has engaging moments, but it also has a lot of superfluous, boring sections that could have been eliminated all together. In fact, I'd say the whole book could have been edited down, probably by at least 40 percent. It would have moved along much more quickly.I took issue with the dialogue, in particular; it just wasn't believable to me. And some of the conversations between characters went on and on and on. I found myself zoning out at these points, and I'd have to catch myself and reread what I just read (never a good sign).Ultimately, this book did basically nothing for me. While I still think the plot had potential, I never fell in love with the characters.If you are looking for a better book about relationships between sisters or between moms and daughters, I'd suggest The Roots of the Olive Tree: A Novel. I really liked that one. Oh, and if you've never read anything by Liane Moriarty, don't judge her based on a (totally misleading) comparison to All of Us and Everything. Her books are nothing like this one.

The Mare is a beautifully written coming of age novel. Velvet is a tweenager living in Brooklyn and struggling to find her place. Her home life is rocky; her mother dotes on her little brother while constantly criticizing Velvet. Velvet endures a lot of verbal and physical abuse and is generally unhappy. So when she is offered the opportunity to visit an older couple living in the country as part of an inner-city youth reach out program, Velvet eagerly accepts. During her first two-week visit, Velvet's hosts, Ginger and Paul, let her ride a horse, and Velvet's world is basically changed forever. Despite her mother's protests, Velvet repeatedly visits the farm to ride the horse. And while she begins to develop her riding skills and ends up feeling proud of herself (for the first time in her life), she also has to deal with the problems that arise when she attempts to exist in two very different worlds.I agree with other reviewers that Gaitskill's writing is phenomenal. The story she has created is very engaging. I loved watching events unfold from the point of views of each main character. This multi-POV approach isn't really unique anymore, but in Gaitskill's hands, it still adds a lot of depth and feeling to the book. I ended up empathizing with just about every character here--though I was never able to dredge up much sympathy for Velvet's mom. (I know she's been through some things, but, yikes, what a piece of work...)My only complaint is that the book is predictable at points. In fact, I would say that even within the first few pages, I had this feeling like I knew exactly where the story was going, almost like I had read it before. Gaitskill managed to surprise me a couple of times, but, for the most part, I knew what was coming next. I'm still not exactly sure why the story feels so familiar to me (maybe it's as simple as I've read too many "a girl and her horse" stories?), but other readers may not feel the same.Regardless, the book is written so well that I was willing to overlook a little bit of predictability. There is enough depth--to the story and to the characters--that I found The Mare to be a satisfying and engrossing read. I think this one is going to be a popular pick for book clubs.

2:31 Mins This is one of the best toys we've ever played with.I was worried that the bear was going to be bulky and hard (especially his head), but he is super soft and cuddly. The voice is adorable:  very kid-like without being annoying, and always clear and understandable.Operating the bear is easy. Ours was charged out of the box, but recharging him is as simple as plugging him into the wall with a basic USB cable. To turn him on, you just press his left foot. (It's marked with a power symbol.) You can interact with the bear by pressing the button on his belly (easy to push but still nicely disguised) in response to his questions. You can also talk to the bear, answering his questions that way, and he will respond back. He doesn't always understand what my kids are saying the first time around, but he usually gets it after a second or sometimes third repetition.The activities, stories, breathing exercises, music selections, etc. are perfect. I've been listening to this bear for the past few weeks, and even I haven't grown bored of him. Except for bedtime stuff, I rarely hear repeating activities. I am genuinely shocked by how much information this little guy holds. It's crazy. And though I haven't seen a place to buy separate activity cards yet, apparently Fisher Price has come out with separate card packs that will let the bear do even more stuff. I will definitely be getting those.Hands down, one of the best features of this toy is that it can also be operated through an app on a parent's smart phone. This sounds creepy, but it really isn't. Parents have the ability to prompt the bear to move on to a different activity (brushing teeth, bed time story/song/breathing, clean up time, adventures, music, drawing, games, stories, dance/party time or even break time). This is an AMAZING feature, in my opinion. I don't interfere with my kids' play often, but I love being able to have the bear wind down an activity (break time) and, especially, to have the bear prompt my kids to start their bedtime routines--all without me being in the room or having to touch the bear in any way. It's genius.Parents also have the ability to control the bear's volume through the app, which is wonderful. And you can tell the bear your kid's name (again, through the app), and the bear will greet your child personally. I have a four-year old and an almost six-year old, and both of them have been playing with the bear. The app actually lets me program both of their names in, and then I can choose the name of the kid who is playing with the bear in that moment, so the bear can say the right name. It takes very little time to set up, but it sure adds a personal touch.Ultimately, I am blown away by how cute, fun, and full of info this toy is. It keeps both of my kids busy for a long time. They don't whine while they play it. They don't get bored. They stay engaged with the activities and stories, and cheerfully interact with the bear for at least a couple of hours each day. Granted, this is a pricey toy--but, oh man, I'm willing to bet you will get your money's worth out of it.

Accidental Brownie is a memoir written by Paul Froiland about his experiences as a child. Many of the stories focus on relationships--especially relationships with and between neighborhood kids, as well as his own relationships with family members. Froiland is playfully self-depracating and minimally critical of his naive child self. Thankfully, he never ventures into "self-loathing" territory (which can easily become tedious and tiresome, in my opinion). His recollections stay light, and he remains full of forgiveness. Based on this memoir alone, I would venture to say that Froiland, in reality, is probably a very likable fellow.I have one observation and one minor criticism. First, I would argue that the title Accidental Brownie brings to mind an image that the author didn't intend. It could be that I have been cleaning up after three young children for too long, but all that title makes me think of is a kid pooping in his pants. When I read the essay "Accidental Brownie," which is really about Froiland unintentionally acting like a member of his sister's Girl Scout troop, I was legitimately surprised that the story did not, in fact, involve fecal matter. Clearly, I need to get out of the house more...As for my minor criticism, I think Froiland's writing style can be sprawling at points. Though I was entertained by the memoir and felt engaged with the stories, there were definitely moments when Froiland could have come to the point sooner by editing out superfluous details.Regardless, Accidental Brownie is an enjoyable read. The light subject matter makes the book go quickly, and, ultimately, I felt this was a sweet and fun walk down memory lane.

There is no denying that my daughter went ape-sh*t for this My Little Pony Castle. She about peed herself when she saw the box. Luckily I was able to put it together in about five minutes, so she didn't have to experience anticipatory anxiety for long.She can interact with this toy in several ways. There is a flap on the second level which can be pulled down. (It plays music when in the down position). Also, the pony figures (which are surprisingly well-made, btw) can take the elevator, slide, swing, stand on the upper level, or twirl in a circle on the maniacal merry-go-round. In order to make the ponies twirl, you will need to press the big pink button on the upper level. Pressing the button also initiates the music, so buckle up, y'all.Woo-ee! This toy is loud. You better really love the My Little Pony theme song, because you are going to be hearing it. A lot. Like, through your ENTIRE living space. And there is no volume button either, so it's going to get intense. You will probably sweat.I agree with other reviewers that this toy does require a higher degree of imaginative play. Your kid has to do most of the heavy lifting, so to speak, not the other way around. My daughter really likes the castle--and especially the ponies--but she can talk to herself for hours without getting bored, so she's probably the ideal customer. Based on her satisfaction with the toy, I would have given the castle five stars. But I just can't forgive the soul-crushing, mercilessly loud music.

I'm not a huge fan of these soft fold out books from Baby Genius. In addition to 1-2-3 Count, we also have Baby Genius What Do You Hear Soft Activity Book with Sound for Infants by Manhattan Toy and Baby Genius Colors and Shapes Soft Activity Book with Sound for Infants by Manhattan Toy.This book folds out to show pages with different numbers of food items on them:  carrots, strawberries, bananas, etc. If you press the circle shape sound box (the one attached to the book by a ribbon), the sound box will say the number and food on each page in a musical way. The sound from the sound box is surprisingly clear and very responsive to touch.The book itself is very bright and engaging. My one-year old was immediately drawn to it, and he enjoys flipping the "pages" around. However, from my point of view, this book could have been designed better. I don't like that the "music" from the sound box isn't incorporated into each page somehow. In other words, there is nothing connecting the music to the content. There is a sound box...and then there is the rest of the book. Also, once the book is unfolded, it just kind of flops around, and feels messy and disorganized to me.Ultimately, this book looks nice, but I wish it had been designed better--especially for the price. You are better off with Jellycat Soft Books, Jungly Tails (or any Jellycat book, really) or Kids Preferred Amazing Baby Feel and Learn - Soft Book.

I'm not a huge fan of these soft fold out books from Baby Genius. In addition to Colors and Shapes, we also have Baby Genius What Do You Hear Soft Activity Book with Sound for Infants by Manhattan Toy and Baby Genius 1-2-3 Count Soft Activity Book with Sound for Infants by Manhattan Toy.This book folds out to show pages with different colored shapes on them: a purple rectangle, brown square, white oval, pink heart, yellow star, orange triangle (my personal favorite), and green circle. If you press the circle shape sound box (the one attached to the book by a ribbon), the sound box will say the color and shape on each page in a musical way. (And I actually kind of love how the colors and shapes are sung in this book.) The sound from the sound box is surprisingly clear and very responsive to touch.The book itself is very bright and engaging. My one-year old was immediately drawn to it, and he enjoys flipping the "pages" around. However, from my point of view, this book could have been designed better. I don't like that the "music" from the sound box isn't incorporated into each page somehow. In other words, there is nothing connecting the music to the content. There is a sound box...and then there is the rest of the book. Also, once the book is unfolded, it just kind of flops around. It feels messy and disorganized to me.Ultimately, this book looks nice, but I wish there was more to it--especially for the price. You are better off with Jellycat Soft Books, Jungly Tails (or any Jellycat book, really) or Kids Preferred Amazing Baby Feel and Learn - Soft Book.

I am not impressed with this puzzle at all.The pieces are thin, and the art isn't engaging. The puzzle doesn't come with batteries, so you will need to supply those. And even when you do, the puzzle still may not work. For us, four of the puzzle cut out slots were missing the metal part that communicates with the puzzle piece in order to know when to play music. In other words, straight out of the box, four of our pieces were broken and no music played with them. The other pieces that did actually work, weren't that great. The sound quality and musical composition is garbage--even my kids agreed (and, let's face it, their standards aren't that high).Ultimately, I was shocked by the bad quality of this puzzle. It's like something you would discover on the dollar aisle in Target. Definitely skip this one.

I was surprised how easy it was to put this spinner together. It comes in three pieces, all hardware included. You fit the rod pieces together, tighten one screw, and you are done. And putting it in the ground is also easy. You just step on the horizontal bar, push it down, and that's it.It took me way too long to figure out how to bend the pieces so that they would spin correctly. The directions are actually confusing on this. But all you really have to do is turn EACH red flower 30 degrees in one direction on one wheel and then 30 degrees in the other direction on the other wheel. I've attached pictures, and I hope they make the process more clear.Once assembled and properly bent, the windmill is beautiful. The red color next to the green plants is very complimentary.My one complaint--and I considered taking off an extra star for this--is that the paint is already peeling off in certain areas. Not a ton, but enough that I notice it close up. And I can tell that more is going to peel, so I'm not sure how long this windmill is going to last outside. For $100, I expect more than that.Still, from far away it looks so beautiful, so I'm happy with it, overall.

Caroline is a hot mess. Recently acquitted of murdering her husband and released from prison, she is trying to figure out how to make a life for herself with help from her two grown twin daughters.While I like the unique premise of this book, that is about all I liked. Unfortunately, the characters are incredibly underdeveloped and uncomplicated. Caroline, especially, never felt real or complete to me. She comes across as someone who thinks she is sassy and smart, but really is petty and insecure. I disliked her through the whole story.Unfortunately, the other characters aren't any better. They all felt one-dimensional to me, too--all so narrowly defined (the scummy husband, the underestimated but brilliant public defender, the wise inmate) and not allowed to move beyond their assigned roles. I found nothing interesting or engaging about any of them. And watching them interact with each other was awkward and, worse, boring.Overall, I like the idea of this book, but I wish Sherman had done more with less. In other words, I wish this book could have been just about Caroline's trial or just about her experience after being released from jail, for example, but with more build up, explanation, and depth. I wanted more of an intro into the story. I wanted more insight into Caroline's experiences and perspectives. And I wanted a deeper understanding of her personal relationships. Ultimately, there wasn't enough substance here for me to really engage with.

My husband bought Poo-Pourri Before-You-Go Toilet Spray 2-Ounce Bottle, Lavender Vanilla for me last Christmas as a silly stocking-stuffer. I thought it was hilarious at first, but after actually using it, I have to say that Poo-Pourri is really a great product. We haven't used up the first scent, but I decided to try this original citrus scent, too. I actually like it better than Lavender Vanilla.I am very sensitive to scent. I smell EVERYTHING, and what other people can barely smell, I can smell no problem. In fact, usually I'm overwhelmed by the smell of perfume, smoke, lotion, soap, cleaners, etc. So the fact that this stuff doesn't irritate my nose is amazing.I think it helps that this isn't like chemical-ridden Febreeze or something else synthetic that tries to mask odors. The only ingredients in here are natural oils. And all you have to do is spray a few spritzes of oil in the toilet before you poop (the directions say three to five sprays, but I only use one), and, amazingly, once the poop gets coated in the oils, it won't smell. It's an honest-to-God miracle. Seriously.Now that I've used this product for a while, I'm in love with it. It's quirky and weird, for sure, but genuinely effective. Such a great concept.

In Uninvested, Bobby Monks argues that the financial system is seriously dysfunctional. Especially when it comes to investing for retirement, most people are operating in the dark. They don't understand where their money is going, they don't know how much they are paying in fees, and they aren't sure if they are invested in respectable companies. And, to top it off, their money managers--who are supposed to be giving them wise and unbiased advice--may not necessarily have their best interests in mind.Monks paints a fairly bleak picture, giving plenty of evidence showing how uninformed investors are getting taken advantaged of by greedy bankers. I thought his perspective on mutual funds--specifically, how investors see mutual funds as a solution to the complex mess of saving for retirement, despite the fact that many don't really understand what they are investing in--was interesting and unique. Most people praise mutual funds (and index funds, too) like they are the gold standard, so it was nice to see another perspective.Honestly, I was completely on board with Monks until the very end. Unfortunately, when it came time to DO something about the problem, Monks couldn't deliver. His solutions are way too basic and nebulous to be useful, and, worse, they don't make sense. In addition to knowing and understanding the contents of your portfolio and what you pay in fees, etc., Monks encourages investors to buy stocks directly from individual companies that they believe in and are familiar with--and no more than ten at a time. While I, of course, agree that investors should be familiar with their investments, I don't see how investing in a handful of companies that "share my values" is going to get me through retirement. I may like baseball cards and organic skin products, but that doesn't necessarily mean that Topps and Honest Company are going to be the aggressive growth companies that will sufficiently grow my nest egg. And God forbid one of them goes under...Moreover, one of the great benefits of mutual funds is that people like me--people who have a little bit of money, but not a lot--actually have the option to access and invest in solidly growing, well-founded blue chip companies that otherwise would be out of my price range and unavailable to me. No, I don't want to be fleeced by money managers and their fees, but I still see investing in index funds as an okay way to build my retirement accounts.Ultimately, I enjoyed this book up until the end. Monks laid out such a great case for how messed up the system is, but then went nowhere with it--not a tangible solution in sight. As a result, I finished the book feeling dissatisfied and slightly depressed. I will continue to work to understand my portfolio and prospectuses, yes, but, for right now, I'm sticking with my index funds.I received a complimentary copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

This is a surprisingly well-written memoir written by a man who pushed himself hard to become a scholarship athlete at the University of Mississippi. Richie Contartesi doesn't look like a typical football player, and throughout his sports career, he was told repeatedly that he was too small and too slow to play. Much like Rudy Ruettiger, though, Contartesi never quit on his dream. In the face of obstacles, he simply pushed himself more and worked twice as hard. As a result, he was eventually able to accomplish his goal of playing on a D1 team.I liked Contartesi's story, overall. He shows a lot of heart, and I respect anyone who is willing to persevere even when things get tough. I certainly admire his spirit. I was also very impressed with his writing skills, and I thought the book had a nice rhythm and flow to it.My only complaint is that the book could be a bit too "play-by-play" for me at parts (no pun intended). I didn't need to know so many specific details about each game. To me, that extra detail became tedious. However, I also felt that way when I read Rudy: My Story, so I can acknowledge that younger and more enthusiastic football fans may not agree with me.Ultimately, this was a satisfying and heartfelt read. I enjoyed learning Contartesi's story, and I'd recommend In Spite of the Odds to anyone who liked the book written by or the movie based on Rudy Ruettiger.I received a complimentary copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.

I love the brown craft paper vibe of these labels. I've been using them as gift tags, and they are adorable. Avery has templates available to print online, but, honestly, I think the designs look too busy with the brown labels. I prefer keeping the tags totally plain.There are six labels per each 4 x 6 page, 60 labels total. The labels adhere permanently onto paper, glass, wood, and plastic. They are easy to write on. (I use fine permanent Sharpies.)The final product looks great. It was exactly what I was looking for.

I used these labels on treat bags for my daughter's 4th birthday. They are really cute, and add an extra something to an otherwise simple, and somewhat boring, bag. The adhesive on the label is permanent, so it doesn't peel off nicely, just FYI. But the label is really adorable. I love how it has a somewhat shiny and textured appearance, too.I ended up not using the Avery template for my daughter's birthday, but I did print out a couple of labels just to test things out. I've used Avery's online templates a bunch, so I am very familiar with their website. But even for someone who is unfamiliar, it's easy to enter the product code and see the templates available for your specific label. There is a nice selection for the scalloped label. And the designs print out nicely. In fact, I've never had a problem with Avery's website. The design and print process always goes smoothly.The only weird thing about these labels is that they come on a 4 x 6" sheet of paper. Usually Avery puts their labels on an 8.5 x 11" sheet, so this is different. It's not a deal breaker, but I can't help but notice that a lot of paper seems to get wasted with this specific scalloped label. (You only get three labels per sheet.)Overall, though, I'm happy with the finished product. The labels looks very nice, very polished. The site is easy to use, and I like the template designs.

Anne-Marie Slaughter was Director of Policy Planning under Secretary of State Hillary Clinton--but she's most familiar to me as the author of her controversial Atlantic article, "Why Women Still Can't Have It All." The woman has some seriously impressive credentials, and I was excited to hear what she had to say about the oft talked-about subject of work/family balance, and I was curious to see how her thoughts stacked up against other books on the subject, such as Overwhelmed: How to Work, Love, and Play When No One Has the Time, Thrive: The Third Metric to Redefining Success and Creating a Life of Well-Being, Wisdom, and Wonder, All Joy and No Fun: The Paradox of Modern Parenthood, and Lean In: Women, Work, and the Will to Lead.Amazingly, Unfinished Business adds something new to the discussion. Slaughter's ideas are refreshing and insightful, and I also happen to think she is spot on. Slaughter's strongest point is that there is powerful and ubiquitous discrimination against caregiving in the United States. Fifty years ago, women wanted out of the home. They wanted to have freedom to pursue their own goals, while also having the opportunity to support themselves. And over the past half-century, they've more or less accomplished this goal. Obviously there is still progress to be made, but there is no denying that women are better off than they were several years ago. They are better educated, more independent, and largely more self-supporting. But, as Slaughter says, "In the long quest for gender equality, women first had to gain power and independence by emulating men." They may have proven that they can do "men's work," but, unfortunately, what was once considered "women's work," (i.e., caring for children and the home) is still not valued in our society.Traditionally, we talk about kids and work/life balance as if these are "woman problems." But Slaughter argues that having the time and flexibility to provide care--whether to our kids, parents, or friends--is a freedom that everyone, man or woman, should have. Moreover, people should be respected and rewarded for engaging with and taking care of their families--for, say, taking paternity leave or adjusting their schedules in order to attend a child's play.In fact, I love how Slaughter sees the next phase of the women's movement being a men's movement, where men fight for and ultimately achieve the same range of choices that women have when it comes to care-giving vs. breadwinning. Imagine if men could be accepted, truly accepted, as the lead parents at home, without judgment or condescension. How freeing that would be for both women and men alike!Slaughter ends the book with several in-depth and creative ideas for creating workplace environments that are legitimately family-friendly. There is little here that is concrete or immediately implementable, but I thought she gave some good jumping off points.Overall, I loved Unfinished Business. I'm so happy to see more high-powered women writing books like this, books that honestly examine the barriers people face when they try to do their jobs well AND still be present with their families. Talking about these issues is the first step to genuinely addressing the problems.

Sol Nazerman runs a pawn shop in a low-income neighborhood. His business is mostly legitimate--sure, he pays money for the random trinkets brought in by his destitute neighbors--but the business isn't profitable. And he's only able to stay afloat through the patronage of a local criminal who is using Sol's business as a vessel to launder his money.Sol lives an isolated and sad existence. As the story advances, we see why. Sol is a Holocaust survivor--the only one of his nuclear family to make it. His wife and two children were all not only killed, but also suffered horribly beforehand. (His flashbacks about his wife were awful, nearly unbearable to read.) While many see the numbers etched into Sol's forearm, few seem to make the connection that he is a survivor. Or maybe they just don't care.This book reads about as drearily as the plot sounds. At first, I didn't know if I was going to make it through. I've heard a bunch of people say this book reminds them of Dostoevsky's works, but I have to disagree. At least Dostoevsky injected some mania in with his depression; The Pawnbroker, on the other hand, is straight melancholy, through and through.However, when I made it past the first 50+ pages, when I started knowing more about Sol's backstory and started seeing his more significant relationships unfold, I found myself hooked. I was absolutely enthralled and invested. And though I really don't want to sound cliche here, the flashbacks to his experiences as a prisoner broke my heart. I'm not going to lie:  I cried...a lot. I have to give Wallant credit for creating a deep, thoughtful, multidimensional story and cast of characters. I don't think that I ever really liked anyone in this book, but I definitely felt for all of them.Ultimately, The Pawnbroker is not a book to read if you want to feel warm fuzzies. It's deeply--just OPPRESSIVELY--sad. But it is also thought-provoking and honest. (And I would add that it ended on a surprisingly optimistic note; I actually wasn't expecting that.) Before reading this book, I had no idea that Edward Lewis Wallant was a Jewish-American author lumped in with the likes of Saul Bellow, Norman Mailer, or Bernard Malamud. But after reading this book, I can definitely see that his talent more than qualifies him for the company of those talented authors. This was a heavy read, but also a very, very good one.

I like the look of this animal zoo. It's bright and colorful. My 15-month old was immediately drawn to it. The monkey and animal figures are the perfect size for his hands; even when my son isn't playing with the whole tree house, he seems to have at least one of the figures from this set with him.The elephant is probably the most fun part of the set. He is weighty, substantial. His feet move, and his trunk bends. When you touch the button on his back, he plays music. And the music sounds surprisingly good, too! My son always smiles and dances to it--and inevitably presses the button again to keep the fun going.My only complaint is that the actual tree house is somewhat boring. My son (and his older siblings) like teetering the figures back and forth on the tree tops. But it's hard for little hands to position the figures so that they actually stay on the tree. Same with the swing. It's fun in theory, buy my baby can't get the figure to stay on the swing (even I sometimes have trouble with it). As for the part to the right of the tree, well, it's not much better. The yellow piece slides up and down the vertical bar, the red flat piece opens up to reveal a very shallow compartment (too shallow to put anything in), and there is a blue piece that can be flipped up and down. There just isn't much to engage on that side (and my baby agrees with me on that point; he only plays with the tree part).So, overall, I really like the brightness and durability of the set. And the elephant, monkey, and people figures are a lot of fun for my son. I just wish there was more to interact with on the actual tree house part.

"A Dark Inheritance (UFiles, Volume One)"Written by Chris D'Lacey. . . . .Chris D'Lacey's dragon-oriented "Fire" series was one of the first series that my kid delved into on her own, leaving dear old dad in the dust - she was really into it, but by the time she put down the last one, she was done and sold them all back to a local book shop. I figured I'd give this book, the first in a new series, a try and see what the fuss was about. We read it aloud together, and I gotta say I was pretty shocked by how badly written this was. D'Lacey's authorial voice is stiff and self-consciously mechanistic -- you can hear the gears grinding as he tries to make his writing sound clever, with several real clunkers in the metaphor department and character descriptions that frequently bring the narrative to a screeching halt. The dialogue is often terrible, and many of the characters are thinly conceived and have unclear motivations and unrealistic interactions. All in all, I was somewhat appalled that this guy is such a popular writer, given the high level of kids' lit these days.The main character Michael is tweenage boy who apparently has reality-altering superpowers that he was unaware of... A cool concept that quickly gets swallowed up into a fairly stiff narrative. Michael is the book's first person narrator and often lapses into inexplicable descriptions of what the female characters were wearing -- D'Lacey seems more concerned with describing fashion than character traits -- and his interactions with these female characters often ring false, particularly a long sequence where the mother of a girl the hero has never met practically adopts Michael on the spot, welcoming him into her house and trading bon mots with him in an almost sub-Mrs. Robinson-ish way. Although almost all the supporting characters are female, D'Lacey doesn't always fill these characters in that well -- the most convincing is Michael's sarcastic little sister, the least is the French super-spy Chantelle, who wobbles between roles as an object of undefined desire and vague maternal authority -- and male characters mainly exist as potential bad guys.The narrative flow is pretty uneven, with patches of natural-sounding dialogue punctuated by forced scenes that are meant to drive the plot forward, but which stand out like boulders in the road. D'Lacey adds a lot of elements that draw attention to themselves and pull readers out of the story -- overly elaborate and clunky metaphors, monologues, iffy plot devices and abrupt shifts in narrative that seem too contrived. The most compelling element of the book, Michael's ability to warp reality, is neglected in the second half of the book, in favor of resolving the book's not-too-compelling mystery. I suppose if you're not looking for top-notch writing and just want a quick book to gobble down, this is okay "junk food" reading, but it also seems that there are a lot of writers working in similar veins who do a better job. I guess I'd give this a 2.5, if I could. (DJ Joe Sixpack, ReadThatAgain childrens' book reviews)

...even when she was struggling.This five-CD "brick" includes five albums from her 1970s heyday on Warner Brothers:"Streetlights" (1974)"Home Plate" (1975)"Sweet Forgiveness" (1977)"The Glow" (1979)"Green Light" (1982)This collection omits her first three albums, which are the stuff of legend and probably sell quite well on their own, in favor of the next five records which have their ups and downs, but are still vital parts of the Bonnie Raitt canon. The first album, "Streetlights," is of a piece with the first three, with a soulful mix of blues, country/folk and soul, but it also shows Bonnie starting to get swallowed up by the LA studio system, and maybe losing her way a bit aesthetically speaking. Still, it includes her version of John Prine's "Angel From Montgomery," which is a stone cold classic. The next album, "Home Plate," was just awful and probably reflects various other bad choices she was making at the time. Two years later she bounded back with "Sweet Forgiveness," which was a little gooey but great, and included some classics such as the title track and her versions of Paul Siebel's "Louise" and Karla Bonoff's "Home."Personally, I love 1979's "The Glow," which is a slick set of torchy soul songs worthy of Percy Mayfield or Etta James, and 1982's "Green Light" is also a guilty pleasure.  This one was sort of her new wave album, a glib, bouncy rock set recorded with Terry Adams of NRBQ. There are some dumb songs on here, as well as some soulful gems, all of it framed by bright, melodic, round-toned production and tons of shameless pop hooks... It doesn't really stick to my ribs the way her best stuff does, but I like it. Used to sing along to it as a kid.All in all, this is a great collection of music by one of America's great roots musicians. Skip "Home Plate" and cherish the rest. Ya gotta love Bonnie Raitt! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue Guide To Country Music)

"Fury: My War Gone By"Written by Garth EnnisIllustrated by Goran Parlov(Marvel Comics, 2014). . . . .NOTE: spoilers below. . . . .How did Nick Fury get to be such a bad-ass? What was he doing in the days before SHIELD? Dystopian writer Garth Ennis tackles this question in this grim, grisly, uber-cynical story-cycle about Fury's career as a black ops super-commando during the Cold War, with chapters set in 1950's French Indochina, Cuba, Vietnam again, and Contra-era Nicaragua. Fury and his compatriots run clandestine hit jobs for the CIA, while history noisily unfolds in the background -- he's there at the Bay Of Pigs and the invasion of Laos -- just nobody knows it.Actually, this series doesn't really tie into the whole SHIELD mythos -- it never comes out and this books seems to be non-canonical, as Fury's groovy 'Sixties swingin' spy days are replaced by a much grittier career as a war-addict, ex-war hero, a half-thug soul-dead hitman working for the CIA. SHIELD, the Howlers, Hydra and AIM are nowhere to be seen, just a lot of blood guts, boobs and really coarse language. Some scenes are particularly harrowing -- this is a "war is hell" comic writ large. It isn't your grandpa's Nick Fury comic, for sure, but it is a good read -- grim, gripping and substantive.Particularly nice are the nods to action tales and artists of yesteryear, hints of Canniff, Kubert, Oliver Stone, and others. This book ain't pretty, but it sure is well-made. Recommended, though not for squeamish readers. (DJ Joe Sixpack, ReadThatAgain book reviews)

OXO Good Grips Zester. . . . .This is billed as a zester, but they also suggested it could be used as a cheese grater... My current cheese plane is getting a little bit dull, so, yeah, it was time to get a backup. The OXO Good Grips Zester does not shave parm as finely as does our old microshaver, but it's fine nonetheless. I gotta say, though, that the angled grip is a nice feature -- they sell it as a plus for storage and countertop stability... I dunno about that, but the angled tilt between hand and grater feels nice in a subtly ergonomic way... With my old straight cheese plane, I have to point the tool away from my hand, and invariably tension builds up as I'm grating on a straight line, and I'll lose the line and cheese flecks go flying across the kitchen... So far this hasn't happened with the OXO model... Maybe it's also because the cheese is being grated more coarsely and there's less tension required to get a good "bite" out of the parm... Anyway, this is a pretty effective kitchen tool... Nothing super-fancy - it just does the job and does it well.  I would recommend this item.

Various Artists"FEEDBACK MADAGASCAR"(ARC Music, 2014). . . . .A lively set of modernized, contemporary pop from the isaland nation of Madagascar... For those of us familiar with the more acoustic-oriented Madagascarian music that leaked out in the '80s and '90s, a lot of these more high-tech recordings may come as a revelation -- slick pop sounds have come into this corner of Africa as well, although with that unique Malagasy spin. A few artists, such as Rossy and Jaojoby, may ring a bell, but most are unfamiliar -- to me at least, and to my way of thinking, that's a very good thing. Some of the production is a little too slick for me, but the music is all new, and thus I am hooked.  Definitely worth a spin... Plus, the album sales are a benefit for TREEMAD, an environmental fund that aims at reversing the deforestation that's endangering the Malagasy ecology, so it's good works as well as good music. (DJ Joe Sixpack, SLipcue Guide To World Music)

"The Walking Dead Volume 22: A New Beginning"Written by Robert KirkmanIllustrated by Charlie Adlard(Image Books, 2014). . . . .Mild spoilers festering below. . . . .I refrained from posting a review of the last Walking Dead TPB... Like a lot of people, I felt let down by the arty but perhaps predictable expectation-defying anticlimax, though I didn't feel as strongly about it as some of the more strident readers who posted denunciations of Robert Kirkman for betraying all that is zombilicious and good... I figured, he's got a plan, it's ambitious, let's see where he goes.So, finally, Volume 22 came out and like all the others, and whizz-bang!! I burned through it in an hour and was still hooked. Kirkman does a little deus ex machina number and skips ahead a year or two (oops! did I mention the spoilers?) and we get to see his vision of a recovering human civilization coming to fruition. Everybody's older, wiser -- happier even! -- and things are looking pretty hopeful, even though there are still too many zombies out there to eliminate altogether, so there's that. A cranky batch of new characters are introduced, to balance out the casualties of the last few years, and the surviving characters from issues past are generally going through some interesting changes, with the keenest focus being placed on Rick's son, Carl.Despite the rotting corpses on the cover, the real dangers still come from other humans: this book is a prelude to another conflict with a criminal human faction (oh, right - oops! spoiler alert!) and in some ways I wish Kirkman & Co. had spent a little more time fleshing out the mechanics and daily rhythms of their post-apocalypse utopia. (Doubtless, a Volume 21-1/2 will come out someday...) I kind of hope the battle between the new batch of sociopaths isn't too drawn out - the Negan storyline got really old, and I'd like us to see more of the world than just one patch of forest in Georgia...) But as I said above, I'm still hooked.  This was a good volume that packed in a lot of information, and I'm hanging onto it for a while, as I'm sure that it will be fun (and informative) to re-read as the plot thickens later on. (DJ Joe Sixpack, ReadThatAgain book reviews)

"Last Shop Standing: The Rise, Fall AndRebirth Of The Independent Record Shop". . . . .This brief documentary is an ardent love letter to locally owned record stores, once a dying breed and now back off the endangered list as the novelty of the digital era gives way to a more mature view of the music world. The setting is Great Britain, as musically-obsessed a nation as ever there was, and the cast of characters includes dozens of delightfully idiosyncratic record store owners and employees, and many of their numerous fans, including music journalists and fabled British artists such as Billy Bragg, Johnny Marr and Paul Weller of The Jam, who sing the praises of their favorite local shops, while also offering clear-eyed analyses of what went wrong.The opening chapters paint a dire picture, of a heartless music industry that threw the indie shops to the wolves when their corporate profit models changed, and a fickle fan base who plundered the Internet's bounty when Napster & Co. arose, and quit spending money in the analog world... Many shops went under, but the sellers that survived became lean and adaptable, as well as philosophical about the various twists of fate. The film examines a global phenomenon through a "small" local filter, and while the specifics may have been different in other countries, the overall story sound much the same. (And I'm sure I'm not the only viewer who spent a lot of the movie quickly absorbing the flavors and rhythms of various shops across the UK, looking yearningly at the overstuffed record bins in the background shots, and making mental lists of all the stores I'd love to check out on my next vacation...)Numerous interviewees offer clear and cogent explanations of how indie stores fit into the wider music business, and how the changes of the '80s, '90s and '00s made them vulnerable to decline. The funereal tone of the film gives way, surprisingly, to a strong note of hope, as a new generation of music lovers got the "shop local" vibe, and events like the annual Record Store Day brought new life into the surviving shops. The end of the film feels a little rushed (probably trying to keep it short enough for TV slots, perhaps?) but the optimistic tone is a pleasant note to end on.This documentary is simultaneously clear-eyed and misty-eyed -- a neat trick -- and is an informative and delightful excursion into the world of independent music and independent retail. Plus, what a great cast of characters - one charming local music nerd after another... what's not to love? Highly recommended! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Music Maven Emeritus)

Various Artists"MALE VOICES OF FADO"(ARC Music, 2014). . . . .An excellent collection of contemporary fado ballads, featuring some of Portugual's finest male singers, including some old-timers and some younger artists.  This particular selection is easy on the ears, in the sense that it doesn't showcase much of the severity that sometimes characterizes the genre... Which isn't to say that it's a goopy world-fusion crossover set, not by any means.  These performances are uniformly soulful and compelling, wonderful examples of the aching, reflective nostalgia and romanticism that characterizes the genre.  Female fado singers often get the most attention with global audiences, but this album is a great way to introduce yourself to the masculine side of the style... Features singers such as Joao Braga, Fernando Farinha, Carlos Ramos, Ricardo Ribeiro and others.  Recommended! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue Guide To World Music)

Korrontzi"Tradition 2.1"(ARC Music, 2014). . . . .Freewheeling world-beat instrumentals and vocal songs from a lively Basque band.  The melodic, accordion-led music reveals strong Celtic, African and Arabic influences (as well as Iberian/Latin ones) with vocals in a variety of languages, including Italian, Euskara (Basque) and African dialects such as Shona... The wide array of influences reflects both the unique cultural geography of Catalonia and the band's wide travel and embrace of many styles of music.Guest performers include Celtic virtuosi such as Scottish accordionist Phil Cunningham (on "Arkupeko Dantza") and Michael McGoldrickm playing uileann pipes on "Diatonic Bilbon," as well as Portuguese fado guitarist Custodio Castelo. Most songs center around the giddy, high-energy performances by bandleader Agus Barandiaran on the trikitixa, which is a Basque version of the accordion. This album is very cheerful and easy on the ears... After a while it may seem a little too "poppy," but mostly it's quite pleasant.  The new version also includes a two-sided video disc, presented in both PAL and NTSC formats, with two long-ish clips of live performances that give a sense of this band's high-energy approach. (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue Guide To World Music)

Dan Brock & Louise Brock"Kentucky Songbag"(Donerail Records, 1968). . . . .Bluegrass fans will want to give this a listen - it's JD Crowe and his first band, The Kentucky Mountain Boys, backing folksingers Dan and Louise Brock on a perky set of songs about Kentucky and its traditions. The musical approaches are quite different -- the Brocks were very much in a Chad Mitchell-esque coffeehouse folk mode, but the low-key bluegrass backing works well. The musicians include J. D. Crowe on banjo and guitar, fiddler/bassist Bobby Sloane and Doyle Lawson on several instruments as well.The Kentucky Mountain Boys -- soon to change their name to The New South -- also recorded their first album, Bluegrass Holiday, at the same time as this one, though the Brocks got the first release date, and the band's picking is kind of in the background on most of this album. Cool to hear some of their earliest work! (DJ Joe Sixpack, Slipcue Guide To Country Music)

I never have purchased organic or healthy cereal in the past.  I actually rarely eat cereal, but if I did, it was usually one of the big brand sugary type of cereals.  This Cascadian Farm Oats & Honey is simply delicious!  I will never buy 'junk' cereal again.  It tastes great, just the right sweetness, and it is very healthy!  I like to add in some blueberries or strawberries, and if you do want some extra healthy sweetness, try adding a touch of blue agave, it's a great and healthy sweetener!

I have had these since I was a child in my grad school lunches!  They are fairly healthy, and a great snack anytime!  I give them 5 stars because a price of just 3.75 for 18 bars is just great (that is just 21 cents per bar)!  Of course prices change, but no matter the price, they are a good deal, and a great snack for kids and adults!

I have used this a few times now.  And I can say, it does make your hair much easier to brush.  I have hair past my shoulders, and I haven't had it cut in over a year, not even a trim.  It brushes fine but sometimes a snag.  This conditioner made my hair very silky soft, but, not weighted down; and, my brush went through like it was just going through air.  Great conditioner, highly recommend!  It smells great too!

I absolutely love these plates!  Thick, strong, microwaveable, don't soak up liquid.  Amazing!  Plus, they are made from quick growing, easily renewable plants!  They are 100% biodegradable and good for our environment, plus, they are great plates to eat off of!  The price isn't too bad, considering how nice and thick/sturdy they are!I don't like doing dishes, nobody does, but I also don't want to be throwing away tons of plastic or foam.  These are the perfect solution!  I also have their smaller plates and bowls, also great!

YUM.  Very tasty and healthy!  Few ingredients and only around 100 calories.  Great snack!  I took away one star due to price!  Although the product is great, the price seems a bit high for the amount of food you actually get.

I have a lot of merino wool clothing... probably 90% of my clothing.  Most has been minus33 brand, but I have now been trying a couple other brands for some more options and styles.  This long sleeve shirt is great quality, fits me perfect (I am 5'11" 160lbs and ordered a medium), and feels great; no itch at all (I have no itch with my minus33 either).  I use this shirt, due to it's light weight, from spring to fall.  It makes a great base layer under a tshirt on cool days or nights.  And of course, because it's merino wool, it has tons of great properties which I'm sure if you are looking at merino wool clothing you probably already know!  I wash my merino wool just in a sink!  Just cold water, a little wool shampoo, swish around a bit, rinse, then lay out on towels to dry.  So easy, and saves tons of electricity and water by not using my washing/drying machine!

I wear a 31 to 32 waist for my jeans.  I ordered a small and these fit perfect.  A medium would probably be fine as well, but I prefer my underwear to fit well, so it doesn't have extra material to bunch up.  They are soft, breathable, easy to wash, and really just some of the best boxers I have ever owned.  Pricey, but when you start using merino wool you will understand that you don't need 50 shirts, 50 underwear, 50 socks, etc.  You just need a few of each.  So you have less, they are easier to care for due to having less, and they are much better material and quality!
I really like these socks!  These are my first short socks, but I have had other aplacor socks.  They feel amazing, very comphy, and fit great!  Wonderful for summer!  Highly recommend!

Love these socks!  I always order socks one size small, they seem to fit me better.  So even though I wear a 9.5, I ordered a medium.  Fit is perfect, and they feel great!  Keep my feet dry in warmer weather, and warm in cold weather!  They don't smell, and they wash easy!  Some of the best cool/cold weather socks I have!

I have an older roomba 530 (had it for like 7+ years now)!  It was in storage for a couple years, but I just got it out, put in new battery, new brush assembly, and this new bin.  This bin is much better than the old 500 series bins!  More space, more powerful, and seems to pickup more!  Highly recommend this if you want to revive an older 500 series!
Amazing hat.  Very soft and warm, and fits me great!  Love the material and style!
Works great.  I use robotic vaccums for my main house cleaning, and this Black & Decker portable is great for quick clean ups of small messes.  Also great for the car!

Roomba works great!  Every one in a while I get a 'charge error 7' (I think that's what it says).  Only happened a couple times, and I just redock my roomba and it is fine again.  Never happened with nimh batteries, but so far hasn't been a problem.  Roomba runs great, lasts longer, and seems more powerful.

Best hoody ever!  Wow, this thing is warm, yet not bulky.  I use it as a winter coat!  I wear minus 33 heavy weight long sleeve shirt, minus 33 tshirt on top of that, then this hoody, and that is all I need.  No more huge winter coats!  Love the thumb holes too.  I also have minus33 fingerless gloves and they work great with this hoody to keep my hands warm but still able to use my fingers!For size, I purchased a medium.  I am 5'11" and about 155lbs.To wash, I put on gentle cycle with wool shampoo, then I usually just lay it out on my bed to dry, or sometimes will tumble dry (you can tumble dry on low).
I keep a few drawers of only wool.  I spray this in there, just a spray like once a week, and it just keeps everything smelling nice.

Great Shampoo for my merino wool and cashmere.  Works great!  The shampoo itself is the best I have tried. If you are using something like woolite, time to switch!I have one CON, which is why only 4 stars instead of 5.  My 2nd bottle came in only 3/4ths full because it had leaked during shipping!  Luckily nothing else in the box was damaged, and I simply rinsed with water to clean the bottle off, but I didn't get my full moneys worth due to the leaking during shipping (the internal seal under the cap wasn't sealed and it was leaking - the cap also wasn't on tight, so the leak spewed through).

Probably the best shoes I have ever warn.  They fit perfect, they are waterproof yet still breathe.  I probably wouldn't wear them in the hot summer unless I was going on a hike where I knew things would be getting wet or muddy, just because I think they may get a little warm if it was say 80F or higher out.  But I really can't say yet, I have only warn them during winter so far, and they have been amazing.  They keep my feet warm due to the waterproof and windproof.  Being windproof really makes a difference!  It lets my socks do their job of insultaing my feet without new cold air always coming in.  My toes haven't been cold once while wearing these in wet freezing conditions!  I wear a 9.5, and I ordered a 9.5, they fit perfect.

Amazing.  I love these shirts so much, I litterally got rid of almost all my other shirts.  I wanted a smaller, easier to manage wardrobe.  I now have about 90% merino wool clothing.  I have about 7 of these short sleeve shirts, and they are simply amazing.  If you haven't tried merino wool give it a try!  Do some research though.  You do wash them differently.  Now these can be washed in a normal washer/dryer; however, you should get some good wool shampoo, not normal detergent, and wash with only cold water, and I usually just dry with no heat, it takes a bit longer, but uses less energy because it isn't making heat.

These are what I use for every cleaning with my Braava.  I simply get them wet with hot water from the sink, and if the room is large, also spray down a little extra water around the room, then let the Braava go.  Sometimes I will do 2 cycles, one to wash around, then a 2nd to dry and buff (without changing the pad, it will dry out naturally as it is doing).  Then, I just rince it quick and toss in the laundry machine.  My Braava only came with one of these, so I purchased this 3 pack.  They work great and really pick up and lot and scrub better than I could have ever expected!

I purchased one of these for my older Roomba 535.  I didn't need to upgrade, my roomba still worked.  But I had taken it out of storage, got it a new lipo battery, new bin, and this new brush assembly.  My 7+ year old roomba works as good as any Roomba 700series now!

This Laugh and Learn Puppy's Remote is a fun little toy for babies that combines numbers and color learning with  music and  an appealing little light show.  This toy packs a lot of entertainment in a small space, and is an excellent choice for infants and toddlers who are fascinated with remotes and cell phones.The small size means this remote is easy to hold. The buttons are easy to push, rewarding baby with a variety of responses.  Numbers, colors and short little tunes make this toy tons of fun and it's small size means it's easy to transport.  This toy has an on/off button and isn't all that loud.  A great little toy that is well worth the price.

Eternity Now comes in a very appealing bottle that only adds to its sophisticated appeal.  When I initially sprayed this perfume, I was a bit turned off by a sharpness of scent that my husband described as "tangy".  After the scent settles in a bit, it develops a complex, light, and clean quality that I enjoy quite a bit.  This perfume is not as strong as many I have tried recently, and it has a nice staying power, lasting all day.I find this scent to be both calming and refreshing.  Eternity Now is an enthusiastic recommend for those looking for a mature, sophisticated scent that will leave you feeling refreshed and not encumbered by heavy florals.

Where It Hurts is a very well told mystery and a piercing examination of grief.  Coleman's latest offering is beautifully written, masterfully plotted and keenly heart felt.  Gus Murphy is a complex character struggling to come to terms with the death of his son, who finds himself drawn into a tale of murder and corruption that will shake his town to the core, and just might bring him back to life.I started reading this story and was quickly overcome by the dark, depressive atmosphere and Gus' air of hopelessness.  Just as I was starting to wonder if I could continue with this dark tale, I found myself thoroughly engaged by a mystery that just kept delivering new twists and turns, and by a lead character that managed to win my heart from the depths of his depression.Where It Hurts is the work of a master storyteller.  I found this book hard to put down and was sad to say goodbye to Gus Murphy.  I hope this is the first installment of a new series, as I can't wait to see what the future holds for Gus,and I can't wait to read more of this author's fine writing.  His authentic dialogue, his dark imagery, and his perceptive observations on grief and family all make this a stellar work and an enthusiastic recommend for any fan of dark, gritty mysteries.

Game of Flames is an adequate installment of the exciting Voyagers sci-fi series that will be eagerly read by the series' many young fans.  This is a fast paced, action packed read and an excellent choice for reluctant readers.  Although the author does a fine job of bringing new readers up to speed on the events of the previous book, readers will find it much easier to start with book 1.  This book continues to follow the formula of a new planet and a new element as we continue to follow the efforts of the Alpha Team as they struggle to find each of the elements required to make the energy that will save the Earth.This installment of the series answers some of the questions that were left at the end of book 1, and poses quite a few new ones.  Kids will be thoroughly engaged by the characters, but might find that this installment lacks some of the suspense and drama that was present in the first book.  There's plenty of action, but it's all predictable, and I doubt that even the youngest reader will feel much tension or have any doubt about the eventual outcome.The science involved in this work of science fiction is a bit sketchy at times, but the strong characters carry the story along at a good clip.  Some of the character motivations remain unclear, and there are enough unanswered questions to ensure that young readers will be clamoring for the next installment.  This one was just okay for me, and I hope that the next installment brings back some of the drama.

I'm not sure how I've missed this series, but I'm glad I finally found it!  I'm kind of sad though, as I think I've started at the end!  Bryant & May works just fine as a stand alone, but it is filled with characters that are so intriguing I found myself wishing to know more about the histories that are only hinted at in this volume.The Burning Man is a smart, well written mystery that is full of twists and turns that  will certainly test your detective skills as you try to figure things out along with the Peculiar Crimes Unit.  I will admit that I became lost in trying to track a rather large cast of characters, and struggled to make sense of London police organizational structure and financial district geography.  This became easier as the novel progressed as I became more accustomed to the author's writing.I was able to hang with a somewhat confusing, complicated beginning thanks to the author's fine writing. It is a true pleasure to read, turning this mystery into an exercise in witticism and solid plotting.  Dialogue snaps along so fast, and developments occur at such unexpected intervals that it's important to pay close attention.  This is not a novel to be read with only half of your attention.  Instead, this is a mystery to be thoroughly enjoyed and devoured.  I look forward to searching out more Bryant & May cases!  The Burning Man is a must read for any fan of British mysteries.

The Peddler's Road marks the first installment of an exciting new series steeped in folklore and filled with adventure.  I thoroughly enjoyed this story, and admired the author's imaginative take on the classic story of the Pied Piper.  I wasn't expecting Baba Yaga to show up, and enjoyed the homage to classic fairy tales.This is a well told story, with two main characters who are well developed and easy to cheer for as they find themselves on a good old fashioned quest, facing evil in an effort to find their way home and ultimately save the world.  They are joined by creatures both magical and tragic.  Dialogues are well written and filled with energy, helping to move this story along at a fast clip.Parents of very young readers should be cautioned that this story is rather dark.  The thought of children being stolen from their parents might be a bit too scary for some, while others will relish both mood and atmosphere.  Yaga's forest of bone is a triumph, and the Pied Piper himself is sure to send shivers to young readers.  The Peddler's Cove is a well written action adventure that is sure to please young Percy Jackson fans looking for some new magic, and is an enthusiastic recommend.

This fragrance is beautifully presented!  The bottle is heavy and stylish, and while it might take a minute or two to figure out how to open it, it''s not hard and delivers an even spray.  The deep red color and melting heart shape make this an excellent choice for a romantic gift.  The fragrance itself is very strong, so just a little bit will do the trick!  It's very floral, with an earthy undertone that my husband found very appealing.  Love is On is an excellent perfume that is sure to please fans of floral scents and stylish design.

I was searching for a spider puppet to use in story time that wasn't too scary, too large, or too realistic.  More of an Itsy Bitsy spider than a horror movie spider.  This Mini Spider Finger Puppet is just what I needed.  It's soft and furry, small, and with its big soulful eyes, actually kind of cute.  This little guy will do a great job of acting out all my favorite spidery nursery rhymes, and since it is a Folkmanis product, I know he'll be around for a good long while.  Easy to operate and full of personality, this Itsy Bitsy spider is an enthusiastic recommend.

Bear and Squirrel Are Friends is a delightfully funny read aloud and a must have for any story time collection.  The author uses a rather muted color palette, smart design choices and cartoon-like characters to tell a story that is filled with moments of sly humor.  I've been reading this story to various groups of preschoolers all week with great success.  The author builds suspense as she leads us through a description of this rather unorthodox friendship, bear's hibernation, and bear's great hunger when he wakes.  Will he eat his friend?  That's the question that will engage any story time audience, as they can see where this is going from early on.  I heard whispered questions as they eagerly waited for me to turn the page.  That's great story time stuff!This picture book is wonderfully paced, very well written and filled with enough small details to guarantee lots of requests for repeat reads.  No worries, all ends well and the power of friendship is once again reinforced.  A surprisingly light and whimsical take on the typical hibernation theme and an enthusiastic recommend.

This is the second Build and Imagine playset I have examined, and although I feel that it does have some design flaws, I do think this one provides plenty of play opportunities for young children ages 5 -8 with an interest in story telling.  The increased number of panels offers more building opportunities than some of the other available sets, and the addition of sturdy animal characters add to the value of this offering.The stand alone characters are sturdy, and the building panels fit together securely and are stable when used to construct the building shown.  Note that the panels are only magnetic on one side, and that these magnet pieces are very small.  They will be hard to manipulate for younger children, and easily lost.  This playset is a recommend for kids at the upper end of the recommended age range and will provide even more play opportunities when combines with some of the more basic Build & Imagine sets.

It's. Nice. Outside. is a wonderful novel, filled with characters who will leap off the page and break your heart.  There were quite a few of them I never learned to like, but it seems that I came to understand most of them, and came to care for all of them.  Sort of like family, right?  That's what is at the heart of this incredibly well written novel.  It's a celebration of family, even the members that drive you crazy, and that wonderful thing that allows us to love them anyway.This was a hard read.  I wanted to stop a few times, just because it became so intense that I was having trouble dealing with some emotions that this story brought forth.  As a parent of a 19 year old special needs son, there were so many things in this story, so many feelings, so much dialogue, and even moments of humor that struck so close to home, it was uncomfortable.  This story rings with authenticity and it's cast of flawed characters are a treat to read.  This is not the soft and fuzzy story that you sometimes find that depicts parents of special needs kids as martyrs or saints.  This is a searing examination of love and bitterness, and guilt and doubt.  It's incredibly human, and achieves that balance between the dramatic and the realistic with an uncommon grace.The author has created a powerful story that sheds light on the plight of America's disabled adults.  As importantly, it sheds light on the issues families face when the special needs of one member effect everyone in the family.  This is a distinctly American family story.  A road trip like no other and  a well observed and heart felt roller coaster ride along life's journey.  It's. Nice. Outside, is a truly memorable story and an enthusiastic recommend for any fan of literary fiction.

I thoroughly enjoyed Under the Udala Trees and found it to be a well written, deeply personal coming of age story that moved me with it's keen observations on love, war, faith and tradition.  The writing is stellar, conveying both the beautiful and the terrible  with a level of care that brought me fully into the story.  This book is filled with characters that are vibrant and fully developed, all prepared to infuriate you and break your heart.There are many references to Nigerian culture, tradition and folklore that sometimes left me feeling a bit adrift, but I never lost the essence of this powerful story, and as we reached the end and Ijeoma states that she and her daughter were "...both choking under the weight of something larger than us, something heavy and weighty, the weight of tradition and superstition and of all our legends", I felt that I knew exactly what she meant.This book was very eye opening for me, as it brought to bitter focus the plight of the LGBTcommunity in Nigeria.  In reading this story that is so far removed from my own personal experience, I was able to gain perspective and knowledge.  I was also entertained by a finely written tale that proves once again that love is universal, struggles with faith are ongoing no matter what corner of the globe you call home, and that we all sometimes suffer from the weight of the very things we hold dear.  Under the Udala Trees is an important story and an enthusiastic recommend for any fan of literary fiction.

Little Penguin Gets the Hiccups is a gift to any story time leader looking for fun, interactive books for preschoolers.  With a text that flows along in a wonderfully conversational tone, we get to meet a young penguin with impeccable comedic timing.  Let's face it, hiccups are always funny, and when you throw in a little guy that loves chili and taco's, well you just can't go wrong.  A spirited reading will result in plenty of laughs and a fully engaged audience!The artist's illustrations are totally charming, with this big eyed little penguin carrying the story with ease.  He is full of personality, and with some truly inspired design choices, the artist manages to convey just the right amount of energy for this wonderfully funny tale.  Little Penguin Gets the Hiccups is a MUST have for story time and an enthusiastic recommend for any preschooler.

I love Mother Goose and use her rhymes every week in story time.  I was overjoyed to see this new title as it represents yet another opportunity for young readers to learn the classics.  The author pays homage to 15 classics, all wrapped up in a brand new story that will appeal to every toddler or preschooler.  The rhyming is fast paced and well written, creating a smooth read aloud flow that makes this an excellent choice for a sleepy themed story time or a bedtime read.Mother Goose has called all of her favorite characters to her house for story time, and we get to follow the cow, dish and the spoon, along with Jack be Nimble and Jack-a-Dandy as they gather together their things to head to her house.  Wee Willie Winkie is coming, along with Bo Peep, and that Contrary Mary,  Miss Muffet's spider is also there, and they all get to listen to MG's tales of faraway lands.
