When it's time to say goodnight, Mother Goose puts them all to bed as the stars spell out Good Night.  The text is clever and the rhyming is perfect as befits a Mother Goose story.But Wait!  This book isn't done yet!  After the story is done, you get a full text of each of the fifteen rhymes featured in the story.  The illustrations have a classic, timeless feel and with the addition of the original rhymes, this turns this book into the complete package.  I love everything about this one, and if you are looking for one toddler book to give this Christmas, you can't go wrong with Mother Goose's Pajama Party.  This is a whimsical treat that will keep on giving and is an enthusiastic recommend.

Loren Long has created a truly beautiful look at the seasons with this gem.  An excellent choice for story time or the classroom, the author uses a spare, sometimes lyrical text to tell a story of one little tree that is afraid to let go.  All young story listeners will be able to identify with the fear of change, and will easily understand this little tree's reluctance to let go of his leaves when the seasons change and all of his fellow trees seem to be moving on without him.  The book exudes an atmosphere of caring and concern as the animals wonder if the tree is feeling sick, and try to encourage him to let go. It's only when the little tree realizes that he can no longer see the sky because his fellow trees have grown so large, that he decides to let go.  The final spread provides a nice pay off as we see the little tree finally as big as his fellows and embracing the seasonal changes.Long's illustrations are quite stunning.  His charming depictions of both trees and animals really pop against an abundance of white space.  He perfectly conveys the changing seasons with forest scenes that make you feel the chilling cold of winter and the lushness of summer.  Little Tree has a ton of personality, which is surprising as he has no features.  This story will serve as an intro to seasonal change or just a fun fable about nature and letting go.  Little Tree is a new classic and an enthusiastic recommend for story time, classroom use, or any young child's personal collection.

Race Car Count is a wonderful counting book that will hold great appeal for young racing fans.  Michael Slack takes that whimsical  touch that gave Monkey Truck such charm and uses it to  create a group of 10 race cars that are loaded with personality.  His illustrations are filled with so much energy that this book just races by. In a book filled with wrecks, oil slicks, engine trouble, and loops, it's hard to take your eyes off the pictures long enough to worry about counting the cars.The text is spare, making this a perfect choice for toddlers as well as preschoolers.  The rhyme rolls along without a hitch as its energy perfectly complements the illustrations.  Each number is highlighted and over sized to aid in number recognition, and with the exception of the spread featuring car number 10,  all cars are available for counting on each two page spread.  The final two pages highlight all 10 cars lined up in a row and ready to race again, creating an excellent number line for some of the best counting practice to be found this side of the race track.It's not often you find such an effective counting book that is also a fun read aloud.  Since this one does not feature the number word, and only counts up to 10 and not back down, this is best recommended for early counters and race fans of all ages.

I have read and enjoyed Katherine Howe's previous novels, so I was excited to dive into this one.  I soon discovered that although Ms. Howe's writing continues to be top notch, in this case she has decided to tell a story that is so ponderously slow that it was a struggle to finish.  As a ghost story, The Appearance of Annie van Sinderen  is a success, but as a thriller, the total absence of suspense and the slow pacing leave this novel floundering about in its own creepiness.Howe succeeds once again in creating a story that is supremely creepy.  This story is deeply atmospheric, and Howe sets the scene beautifully. Her transitions are seamless, and the story itself is intriguing.  With all this great stuff going on, it's a shame that the pacing was so off.  This might have been overcome if the character of Annie had been stronger, but I never felt any sort of connection with her.  The Appearance of Annie van Sinderen is an intriguing story, but only a cautious recommend for older teen and adult fans of literary ghost stories.*This book provided courtesy of the publisher

The Searcher is a very enjoyable fast paced read that features fine writing, suspense, and memorable characters.  I had a hard time putting this one down, as the author had me hooked pretty much from page one.  This work is extremely well plotted, offering up intrigue, mystery, and action in just the right amounts to keep the pages turning at a fast clip.  Solomon Creed is indeed a man of mystery, and the hints of the supernatural only add to his allure.I think it's the author's extensive descriptive talent and his ability to balance that with finely choreographed action that makes this book seem so cinematic.  The Searcher is a fine thriller.  It's grisly and violent, and also well observed and very unique.  A twisty, gritty thrill ride that is an enthusiastic recommend.

Killing Trail marks the debut of what will surely be an interesting series featuring an engaging heroine and a truly memorable dog.  I think I was a bit surprised by this book, as I was expecting something a bit more gritty.  This is in fact a cozy mystery, with no language or graphic violence.  I love a good dog story, so I did enjoy this one and actually found myself wishing for more stuff about the dog and less about the rather flat, one dimensional characters.  The relationship between Mattie and Robo was the high point of the book and the only reason this sneaks into a three star rating.The mystery here is very predictable, and the ending offered up few surprises.  I found the dialogue to be very clunky, hampering the character development and leaving me adrift in plot developments that didn't seem very realistic.  The author has some very interesting subject matter to work with here, and an engaging lead character, unfortunately she just fails to tell a very exciting story.  Even though this book is a very fast, easy read, the story lacks substance and is only a cautious recommend for those readers who like their mysteries on the simple, cozy side.

Mudpuppy makes wonderful puzzles, and this construction themed cutie is no exception.  At 25 pieces, this is a perfect choice for three year olds, who will likely find it just challenging enough to make it fun.  The artwork is whimsical and filled with energy, featuring cute dog characters guiding favorite construction machines along a windy road.  The color palette is kind of muted, but fits well with the theme.The pieces of this puzzle are thick and well cut, fitting together easily.  I love the fact that the box is so sturdy, and young toddlers and preschoolers will love the carry handle.  This is an enthusiastic recommend for any young construction fan.

I went into this novel not knowing what to expect.  I chose it based on the author, so I was a bit taken aback at first, not sure what to make of this format, and the author's rather light hearted tone.  It wasn't long though until I had fallen in love with the characters and caught on to the author's satirical send up of all things YA.  It's a strange combination of events that bring fantasy and reality together in this story, but the final message is a good one, and the ride was fun.  Patrick Ness always produces literature that stretches convention. and The Rest of Us Just Live Here does a great job of pushing that envelope and reminding us that the most important things in life are happening every day.  It turns out that we don't have to save the world after all.  We are still pretty special.  What a relief.

Jack Gantos is a brilliant writer, and I firmly believe that any teenager struggling to find his way and learn how to be true to himself will find it easy to relate to this story. I also firmly believe that it's a miracle that Mr.Gantos survived his adolescence.  I know that this is a fictionalized account, but even if only a portion of this is true, then it had to be a miracle.This is a short, fast read filled with perceptive observations on growing up, hilarious accounts of bad behavior, and heart breaking moments of such poignancy that they took my breath away.  All of these can occur on a single page, as this is the gift of Jack Gantos.  This book takes place over a very short period of time.  It ended up feeling a bit truncated.  The ending seemed abrupt, just as the beginning felt like being thrown in the deep end of the pool after all the party guests had already been there for a couple of hours.  Still, there is great stuff in these pages.  The Trouble in Me is a must read for any troublemaker or anyone trying desperately not to become one.

The Scribe was a treat to read, combining elements of historical fiction, horror, and mystery (my favorite genres) into a a riveting story that was hard to put down.  The author seamlessly spins out an excellent mystery, all the while firmly setting this gory story in time and place through excellent use of period detail.  The characters are well drawn and fascinating.  I was immediately invested in Thomas Canby, intrigued by his past, and engaged by his intelligent, straight forward manner.  His pairing with Cyrus Underwood added an even further dimension to what was already a multi-faceted story.This story won't be for everyone.  It's quite gruesome, although none of the authors details seem gratuitous.  His distinctive writing style depicts a serial killer's gruesome activities with a keen analytical eye and a gothic sensibility.  Cyrus Underwood adds a local Atlanta feel that brings in the supernatural in a voice that is haunting and true.  The Scribe is a creepy, compelling read and a recommend for any fan of literary horror fiction.

The Girl Who Could Not Dream is the perfect fantasy adventure for the 9-12 year old set.  Heck, I'm way past that age group and I totally loved it.  This book has it all!  Well drawn characters, humor, action, a unique and interesting premise, monsters, glitter ponies and pink rabbits.  What more could you want?Durst has fashioned a true children's adventure novel that is so refreshing and well written that I can't wait to tell all of our young  library patrons all about it.  In a time when so many fantasies are being written that lean toward the dark side, Durst has went the opposite direction, infusing her story with a heavy dose of whimsy and humor without sacrificing the action and suspense.  Kids will find it easy to relate to young Sophie and her middle school struggles, even as they envy her own personal monster.  She is a character of unexpected depth, and the author manages to address a number of important issues without ever becoming didactic.I had a hard time putting this book down once I started it, a testament to the spot on pacing, fine writing and originality.  Sophie finds herself in genuine peril throughout most of the book, dealing with some nightmarish monsters on her way to save her parents.  Creepy, funny, and totally engaging, The Girl Who Could Not Dream is an enthusiastic recommend.

This is a high quality, attractive candle that burns evenly and has a distinctive scent that packs quite a wallop.  I lit the candle in my dining area, and within the hour I let it burn, the scent had permeated most of my relatively small house.  Unfortunately, I found this scent to be far too strong and cloying.  I blew the candle out and don't foresee using it again.I was very impressed with the powerful scent, but not a fan of the scent itself.  I would like to try one of these candles in a different scent, as I have never run across one quite this strong.  This scent though is just not to my liking, so this quality candle is not a recommend.

After 21 days of use per package instructions, this product has proven to be very effective at reducing the appearance of dark spots.  My husband has been using this consistently and has reported that although the darkened age spots on his face have not disappeared, they have significantly lightened.  He is quite pleased with the results and advised that he will continue to use the product.This is a small container and quite pricey, but not much is needed to achieve maximum effect.  This product has turned out to be a good value, and is an enthusiastic recommend.

This book provided courtesy of  the publisher.Who Done It? offers a unique twist on the usual seek and find format.  This long, skinny book opens up horizontally to offer two rows of characters along with a question.  Whether it's "Who didn't get enough sleep?" or "Who's in love?", each two page spread provides lots of opportunities for parents and children of all ages to interact as they try and determine which character is the right answer.  Some answers are kind of obvious.  All you have to do is look for the puddle to determine the answer to "Who couldn't hold it?"  Some require more attention to expression.  For those who might not be sure, the author/illustrator provides a handy answer key on the final page.This picture book take on the classic line up is full of charm and whimsy.  Each character offers up subtle differences in attitude and expression that are perfect for discussion and play.  The abundant humor will guarantee requests for repeat reads, and the sturdy construction ensures that this book will remain a first choice in any child's collection.  A must have for group activities as well, Who Done It? is an enthusiastic recommend.

This product certainly sounds great! The price is great, and the fancy applicator promises easy use with no mess.  Unfortunately, this didn't work at all for my long haired terrier mix.  The applicator is pretty ineffectual and broke during use.  The bottom line is that this did not do its job, and is not a recommend.

Although I'm not a total fan of the CEB translation, I do feel that this is at heart an excellent bible for kids ages 9-12.  It's beautifully bound, with a very engaging cover that is sure to appeal to young readers.  I liked this Bible's use of colorful, engaging characters, and enjoyed the many devotionals that are sprinkled throughout.  The beginning of each book features a very readable summary of events that will take place, and highlights the people, places and "words you'll remember".I especially appreciated the "Bet you can!" challenges that challenge young readers to read certain passages.  I also liked that memorization suggestions were included throughout the text.  Also included is an impressive selection of maps, a dictionary, and a topic index for the articles.  I liked the index entitled "I wonder when I'm...."  The index cites verses that apply to topics such as anger, fear sick and thankful.  I actually feel that this area could have been expanded.While I do feel that this is a solid Bible for pre-teens, there is a significant drawback that keeps it from a five star rating.  I feel that the print is far too small for a kids Bible.  In the same vein, I wish the publisher could have used more graphics to further break up the text and make it less intimidating for younger readers.  A few more interesting fonts, text boxes and a bit more color in the heart of the text would have made all the difference in the world for what is otherwise a very fine and worthwhile offering.

This is my first exposure to a CEB translation, and I will admit that I kind of miss the language from my usual New King James version.  Still, I was interested in what insights this Bible might be able to offer so I selected a chapter to do a direct comparison.  It stays pretty true to meaning and offers up some new and valuable perspectives that I feel will be invaluable to young readers.  There are articles that appear right in the text, The book of Romans features short articles entitled "On Being A Nonconformist", and "Nothing Can Separate You From God's Love", just to name a couple.  They are quick and insightful reads that pulls the Bible text into present day in an engaging manner.One of my favorite elements are the "Pray" boxes which feature prayers and insights from teens.  Each book ends up with a section of discussion topics, which are perfect for any teen interested in leading a Bible study.  One of the most innovative features is the Reading Differently section which ends each book and encourages teens to experience the Bible in a new way.  The suggestions range from simple to advanced and offer new opportunities for anyone interested in gaining a deeper understanding of the word.Personally, I don't think I'll ever give up my New King James translation, but I will be passing this along to my 16 year old son who will no doubt find it valuable.  This Bible also includes a surprisingly complete selection of maps, an index to well known Bible passages and stories, and an article index.  This is a nice tool for any student of the Bible, but is targeted for teens and young adults.  An excellent resource and an enthusiastic recommend.

I am a big John Sandford fan, and when I heard he was writing a sci-fi thriller, I was very excited.  See, I enjoy sci-fi as well as mysteries and although I'm not a huge fan of hard sci-fi, I felt sure that this book would be one I would enjoy.  Unfortunately, after 195 pages, I have decided to quit.  I can't force myself to go any further because I have absolutely no interest in finding out what happens next.  I feel that in this instance, Mr. Sandford's writing can best be described as flat, and I find the characters to be totally uninteresting.  I'm tired of slogging through repetitive information dumps that rob the story of any momentum, while dissecting the science to a level of minutiae that was mind numbing for this lay reader.I felt that the cast of characters represented a lot of missed opportunities to give real dimension to this story.  With the exception of one or two, they never seemed like real people - and I really wanted to get to know them. Unfortunately, I got to know the ship a lot better than the people, which for me is never a good thing.  Where's the suspense?  I kept looking for some sort of tension, but since there was so little emotion and so little feeling to be had in this dispassionate narrative, I couldn't find anything to keep me going.Saturn Run is not a recommend from this reader, who evidently prefers her space stories a little more on the space opera side of things.  I've read reviews comparing Saturn Run to the works of Heinlein.  I have to admit that I just don't get it.

I am beginning to love this entire Dead Sea Essentials product line!  This three pack of bubble bath/shower gel is a real treat and is sure to please any fan of a relaxing bathing experience.  Of the three scents that are included in this pack, my favorite is the lavender.  It's a true delight and produces a lovely scent when used in a nice steamy bath.  The Hibiscus is way too floral for me and really struck me the wrong way, although I'm sure there are others who will love it.  The Milk & Honey is kind of a middle of the road scent, although I will say that this was my husband's favorite of the three.I was a little disappointed that this trio didn't produce more bubbles!  I did think that this additive made the water feel silky, and I loved how the scent stayed around.  I felt that the product lathered up fine as a shower gel, and once again appreciated how the scent lingered.  I would purchase this item in the future, but probably in individual bottles.  These bottles are kind of small, but I didn't have to use much in the shower, and as long as your prepared to not have quite as many bubbles, you don't need to use that much in the bath to get that delightful scent.This is a quality collection of gels, and an enthusiastic recommend.

I love this little animal matching book!  I've been looking at a lot of these cloth books for babies lately, and I must say that this one is my favorite by far.  It offers a combination of cloth and plastic textures, and while I wish the entire book was plastic for easy cleaning, this one offers up plenty of other exciting features to make this a five star product.  This book features three animals that you can mix and match with ease, since each page is split in the middle.  A hedgehog, a bee, and an owl can interchange their upper and lower halves for a extremely colorful effect.Each page is crinkly and features a variety of fabrics.  The spine is plastic, and the handle is a rattle.  Attached to the bottom on a stretchy string is a bumpy plastic cloud that is perfect for teething.  This is a well designed book/toy that will be easy to transport and is sure to entertain your baby for many months.  A great choice for baby

This Baby Genius Toy is soft and squishy, makes some cool sounds, and offers a mirror.  Those are about the only great things I can say about this one, other than it's very portable and will be easy to pack.  This is my second Baby Genius Activity Book and I'm just not impressed with the overall design of this toy.I wish this toy was plastic, for easy cleaning.  If you are going to have a sound gadget attached, you should probably be able to change the batteries.  Not so in this case.  With the sound box attached to the book by a string, there is no connection between the sounds and the book.  It's not like baby pushes the button on the flute picture and then gets the flute sound.  The sound quality isn't all that great and the illustrations aren't that impressive, especially not when you consider the high price.Don't be dazzled by a little sound gadget and a crinkly page.  Books for babies are always a good idea, there are just lots of better options out there.

I'm not a big fan of this Manhattan Toy product.  It's soft and squishy, offering a crinkly texture and a mirror.  Babies always love mirrors, so it's for this reason that I almost let this toy barely squeak into the three star rating. The pictures are bright and colorful, but overly busy, with characters that are pretty unremarkable.  There's a loop to attach this to a carrier, and it's easy to pack, as this little book/toy will squish down to almost nothing.I just didn't care for the design of this toy.  I wish it had been made of plastic for easy cleaning, and I don't like the little dangling sound box.  The sound quality isn't all that great, and I think it's strange that little ones would push the box for the sound and then somehow relate it to the correct picture.  Better to just have the parent point to each picture and read it instead of relying on this random little gadgetBooks for babies are always an excellent idea, I just don't think this one is the best choice, Baby Genius or not.

I Will Chomp You!  is a must have for any preschool story time thanks to it's interactive nature, colorful illustrations, and hilarious read aloud flow.Spot on comedic timing guarantees lots of laughs, and with Bob Shea's adorable, frenetic illustrations, it's a guarantee that you will have all your story time listeners merrily chomping away.I had the pleasure of featuring this book in a recent story time, with wonderful results.  I invited each participant to come to the front and collect one of the construction paper "chomp monsters" that I had pre-made.  We then read the book, with all the audience chomping away every time our little blue monster went chomp.  For a craft, each child then created their very own cake out of construction paper and sequins for their chomp monster.  When story time resumed two weeks later, the kids were still talking about the chomp monster!This entire book flows very fast as the monster tries to talk the reader out of reading the book in order to protect his stash of beautiful cakes and pastries.  The illustrations provide tons of energy, with some of the monster's chomps taking up an entire two page spread. Shea's color palette is almost blinding in it's neon brightness, only adding to the fun of an exceptionally well written and delightfully illustrated book.  I Will Chomp You! is a must have.

I had doubts about this book, as I didn't think it would have much to offer for a parent who's kind of waited until the last minute to start worrying about paying for college.  I'm happy to say that although there was a lot of information here that didn't apply to me, there is also quite a bit that I found immediately useful.  Don't grab this expecting a detailed explanation of things.  This is more of a road map of "where do I go from here".  This book helped me start asking the right questions.  It's pointed me in the right directions, so I can then pursue more detailed information.The layout is very user friendly, so no matter what stage you are at in your college preparations, you can easily turn to the relevant chapters.  Much like CliffsNotes literary efforts, this gives a down and dirty look at a complicated topic.  Sometimes that's just what you need.

An Inheritance of Ashes is a dark,gloomy, beautifully written fantasy that combines a surprisingly wide variety of different plot elements to create a story that is incredibly compelling and totally unique.  It's the writing itself that almost steals the show here,as the author exhibits amazing gifts with imagery, creating a world that is as ambiguous as the mist and as startling as some of the bleakest dystopian creations.  I think that the author's decision to leave so many questions unanswered and to leave her world with so many unfinished "edges" will prove frustrating to some, however I found it to be all the more intriguing and the perfect backdrop for the powerful story of family and coming of age that unfolds.Hallie is a vibrant, compelling narrator who is easy to like and cheer for.  Young readers will be able to relate to her desire to please her older sister, to be the hero, and to her feelings of inadequacy.  I have met so many teens who are trying so hard to be perfect at everything, that it was easy to hear their voices in Hallie's dialogues, which gave her character that much needed authenticity and enabled her to carry a story filled with so many fantastical and vague aspects.An Inheritance of Ashes is part epic dystopian, part coming of age, and part fantasy, but at it's heart it's about family.  It's about home, and about love, and about the danger of secrets.  It's about dealing with the past and moving on to the future, all without losing who you are.  It's a wonderful story that defies description.  It's slow moving and thoughtful, but those willing to stay with it and lose themselves in this dark world will be well rewarded.

The Rig is an adventurous, action packed novel that will hold great appeal for young readers, especially boys.  I found it less than engaging and couldn't help but compare this work to Lockdown by Alexander Gordon Smith, a work I thoroughly enjoyed.  This novel lacked the suspense I was expecting and I actually found myself bored for the first 150 pages or so.  There's really no character development and I initially found it difficult to care much for Will Drake.This story redeemed itself for me in an ending that was actually pretty incredible.  The author delivered on some unexpected story elements that elevated this from a derivative teen novel to a distinctive work of science fiction.  Will even managed to finally become a character with a bit of depth.  After a rough start, The Rig finally found it's way and will definitely find it's share of fans.

This is an excellent foot cream!  After a week of use, I can already see a significant difference in the condition of my feet.  After years of going barefoot whenever possible, I now have big problems with calloused and cracked heels.  This cream is very effective and easy to use.  I've been using it every evening before bed.This is a pretty large tube, and the cream is pretty thick, so a little goes a long way.  The scent is light and pleasant.  The cream does feel a bit greasy, but since I applied before bed, this has not caused me any problems.  I will be purchasing this product after this tube runs out!  An enthusiastic recommend.

Burning Bush 2.0 is a well written examination of popular media and how it relates to Christian faith.  This is a fast read, as the author zips through many of the most popular titles in movies, television shows, books, music and video games, giving proof that God is to be found in all of them, no matter the story.  Whether it be the hope to be found in a zombie movie, the moral choices to be made in video games, or the sheer joy to be heard in music, the author effectively brings God into everything.  It turns into a refreshing look at a society that sometimes seems awash in darkness, reminding us that God's light is always there.My only problem with this work is the sheer volume of examples the author utilizes.  I found myself craving more of his conclusions and insights and less of his specific analysis.  I worry that the number of contemporary cultural references will date this work and perhaps dilute the author's valuable message.  Perhaps the most important moment in this book comes when the author encourages the reader to enter any type of interaction with media as an intellectually aware, discerning participant.  I agree wholeheartedly with the author's assertion that it is important for Christians to not shut themselves away from popular culture, but to instead be an active member.  I also think that it is important to not let media wash over you, but to interact and actively search for God's word.  This will be an important read for any parent feeling the pressure of helping their teen make solid media choices.  I plan on passing this book on to my 16 year old son, who is currently walking his own path toward discernment.

The Afterlife Academy is a well written, adventurous tale that arrives just in time for Halloween  to deliver a solid helping of monsters and the paranormal. It's not easy to write a story about death, demons, possession and the Underworld for the 9-12 year old set, but this author has certainly done an excellent job.  He combines just the right levels of wit, humor and action to offset the darker aspects of this story, and keeps things moving at a fast rate.When Walter Prairie meets his end, he wakes up in the "categorizing office" trying to figure out what's next for him.  After a mysterious mix-up sends him back to earth as a guardian agent tasked with protecting young Charlie Dewdlle, Walter quickly finds himself in over his angelic head and facing a whole new world of wraiths, shades, and demons.  Charlie and Walter make a wonderful pair in this witty take on the classic buddy saga.The plot is interesting, the characters well developed and easy to care for, and the dialogue is fast and funny.  I loved the author's concepts of the Underworld and his demon mythology, and admired how he is able to give the reader a couple of genuine scares right alongside more than a few genuinely funny moments.A special nod as well goes to a fine portrayal of a supportive family.  Charlie's parents play only a small role in this story, but I loved how they had his back even when he presented them with an unbelievable story.  They were pretty ineffectual, but they were there giving it their best, and it's always nice to see that in a kids book.  The Afterlife Academy is an enthusiastic recommend for young readers grades 4-7 who like their adventure stories a bit on the dark side.

After reading about the many benefits of Maca Powder, I decided to give this a try.  Unfortunately, I was unable to tolerate this supplement.  The odor and taste are terrible, and after two days of mixing with yogurt, trying it in a smoothie, and juice, I am giving up,  This stuff is terrible and it makes my stomach hurt.  I should have researched this powder more thoroughly, then I might have discovered that this stuff really isn't meant to be eaten raw.  The packaging should have included more information, and provided more direction for use.  Even the small amounts that I was trying to use were unpalatable.  Not for me.

This Hershey product is a surprisingly large, well made tin filled with yummy caramels. There are three different kinds; vanilla, butterscotch, and plain caramel.  There seems to be an equal distribution of the three, although I did not count them all out and measure them.  The candies are soft and rich, much smoother than most caramels I have tried.  Each caramel is individually wrapped.  I do wish it was easier to differentiate between the flavors.  The wrappers could have been different colors instead of the subtle differences in striping.  Each flavor is written on the side, but the print is very small!This tin will be a perfect Christmas gift!  I brought them to work to share with my colleagues, and they have all admired the full flavors and rich, smooth, texture.  These Lancaster Soft Cremes are an enthusiastic recommend as a gift idea, or a for anyone looking for a high quality, gourmet caramel.  The vanilla is easily my favorite, although caramel purists will love the others as well.  Yum!

I had a difficult time getting into this story, but by the end I really fell in love with Charlie Han and his family.  This is a great story about coping with family dynamics, and being true to who you are.  I didn't like Charlie very much at first.  He comes across as bitter and a bit mean spirited.  The story has an edge that was a bit unexpected for a book aimed at the ten year old set, with lots of talk of girlfriends, and  getting "felt up".  This one seems perfect for 12-14 year olds, but a tad mature for those younger readers.It took a bit for the story to take off, and after we get past some repetitive, bitter ramblings from Charlie, the narrative flew at a rapid pace.  Charlie grows quite a bit during this story, and I loved the author's portrayal of his family.  Their interactions were very well done, and the book reinforces the idea that even when parents aren't quite perfect, a family held together by love is a strong family indeed.  Despite some early flaws, this is a great story that will appeal to young readers, especially those searching to overcome their own barriers and find their own unique ways to succeed.

The Dead Boy offers up a gruesome read for young horror fans, but it unfortunately failed to capture this adult reader.  I'm a fan of things dark and creepy, but feel that it's seldom done well for this age group. This book promises humor, but I was unable to find anything humorous or even witty in this writing.  It was hard to feel much for Crow other than pity, and felt that his character was really quite pathetic.There's an over-indulgence in all things maggoty in this story, and the author relies far too heavily on the quick gross out gags that will likely appeal to young readers, but don't do much for the story or characters.  I loved Melody, his friend who is willing to overlook his dead status.  She's a wonderful, well-developed character and she provides a nice story line about the importance and power of friendship.Despite a truly pathetic main character, this story still squeaks into a three star rating thanks to a plot that is interesting and action packed.  It's the final half of the book that kids will find fascinating and it's here that the story rises above it's cheap, gross out maggot moments and finally achieves a bit of depth.  I had a hard time getting through this one, as I felt that it was missing a bit of the heart that is necessary to make this premise work.  Not a first choice, Dead Boy is only a cautious recommend.

Naked is a very compelling read that takes an unflinching, gritty look at some truly disturbing issues.  Young Anna runs away from home at the age of 13 and becomes a teen prostitute.  This story begins when she returns home to her parents after three years and attempts to become a "normal" teen.  Despite it's occasional heavy handed treatment of characters, this novel effectively deals with subjects like domestic violence, freedom of choice, bullying, and of course self worth and redemption.A fast read, this book is best saved for older teens merely because of it's brutal look at prostitution.  There are no graphic sequences, and  limited language, however emotions are intense and the portrait of Anna and how she has been damaged is particularly disturbing.  I found myself becoming very invested in Anna's character at a very early stage in the story, and stayed with her even when her motivations occasionally became muddled and her inner dialogues repetitive.  I don't think the author did a perfect job of writing an authentic teen voice, but I still found myself rooting for her.The story was intense, emotional and hard to put down.  Unfortunately, it also became a bit predictable.  The best part of the story for me was in the author's exploration of the mother/daughter relationship.  Seeing that change and grow lent a new level of depth and power to the story and saved it from becoming a typical, issue driven teen novel.  Naked is a powerful debut from this author, and while it didn't blow me away, it was a good read, and a recommend for older teens and adults.

This little doll is a cutie that will be sure to inspire young super hero fans to imagine their own adventures.  She's quite a bit smaller than I imagined, and just doesn't feel all that substantial for her price.  Her costume is dazzling though, so kids won't mind a bit.  Her face is stitched on, and everything is geared toward the youngest superheroes.I loved the pigtails, but wish you could take the mask off.  That would have really added to this doll's play value.  Everything seems very well made, so despite her small size, I'm sure she will be starring in many adventures.  This Hero Girl doll is an enthusiastic recommend for it's play value and as a welcome alternative to the usual doll choices.

This is an excellent choice for any new parent, and a great baby shower gift.  This picture gallery is very easy to install in your car, and the cards can be taken out and changed, providing images that grow with your baby.  The pictures are vibrant and made to be appealing to even the youngest babies.  I plan on adapting this for play group, and converting this picture gallery to a play mat.Years ago, I learned the importance of visual stimulation for babies, when the pediatric nurse working with my son in the NICU drew many of these same designs and placed them around his crib.  I was amazed by how quickly he latched on to the images, becoming excited by the high contrast designs. I could envision those little neurons firing, even in his dire condition.  This is a simple gift you can give your child, but ultimately one that is very worthwhile.  High quality materials only add to the many reasons that this activity board is an enthusiastic recommend.

This Whoozit cube is a delightful, well made toy that will be great for babies to explore as they develop their fine motor skills.  All the elements are attached, and combine to form a cube that is pretty compact.  There's a mirror, an interesting crinkly texture, an abacus, a clock that makes a clicking noise when you turn the hand and a musical block that plays a tune and lights up.  There's also a dial to spin, and beads to rattle.  I was very impressed by how many things were included in this block!  Everything then fits together neatly into a cube that doesn't latch, but does fit together neatly.One of my only problems with this toy, is that it doesn't latch together.  It would have been a nice opportunity to add another skill, and added to its portability.  Also, I think the musical element is kind of a fail.  It's a little too loud and sounds very tinny and mechanical.  I was expecting something a bit better from such an expensive item.  Still, these are small things in what is otherwise a very good choice for baby-one that will be interesting to your child for many months as they continue to learn new skills.

Rules for Stealing Stars is a well written novel that combines magic and realism to look at four sisters as they try to cope with an alcoholic parent.  This novel is well written, very readable, and painfully authentic.  I didn't like it a bit.  I think that whenever an adult reader attempts to review a kid's novel, they must in some way come to terms with the baggage they are bringing to a book, their own agenda, and try to eliminate an adult perspective when they judge the novel's merits.  I admit that I am finding that very hard to do in this case.I found this novel to be dark, depressing and disconcerting in it's unique examination of alcoholism and magic.  I felt that the characters were never fully developed, and had a hard time engaging with them.  The author did a fantastic job portraying the damage that can occur to an entire family when a parent is battling alcoholism.  That's one of the things I do admire about this novel.  I didn't like the combination of the magical closets with a very real life problem.  I found myself wondering just what story the author was trying to tell, and getting quite angry as the story progressed.  The magic in this story is really not very magical, but dark and creepy, even when the girls think it's something positive.This book professes to provide a hopeful look at this family's struggles, but I for one couldn't find a sign of anything positive or hopeful for these girls  until the last 20 pages or so.  Up until then it's a dark, emotionally intense, and sad story. The publisher recommends this book for ages 8-12, however I don't think this book is in any way appropriate for those readers on the young end of that scale.  This is not the magic of Narnia and it's unlikely that these sisters will inspire any young readers coping with their own family struggles.  The story elements are not all that unique, however the attempt to aim this particular combination at this age group is misguided.  Rules for Stealing Stars is not a recommend.

My plain jane bathroom is now feeling a bit overdressed after I added this rather ornate shower curtain.  This a very nice shower curtain that was easy to install.  It hangs well for our standard size tub and rod, with a pleasing fullness.  This is obviously a high quality product, with an ornate almost middle eastern design.  If you are trying to coordinate bathroom decor, please note that the color seems to be a bit closer to yellow than ,most shades of cream.  The fabric is a bit shiny for me, and it's this along with the slight color discrepancy that makes this a four star product instead of a five.  Personal taste aside, this is a solid, high quality product and a recommend.

I have been using an older version of this Folkmanis snowy owl in library story time for many years.  I was eager to receive this new one as he seemed to be a bit different and my older one was starting to fade a bit.  I love this puppet.  This one is a bit smaller than I anticipated, but that just makes him easier to operate.  The wings can flap and the head can rotate fully around thanks to a rod centered in his head that you can then turn with your hand.  I have a pretty small hand for an adult so I can't move his head and operate his wings at the same time.  An adult with slightly larger span should have no problem, but a small child might have problems reaching to flap both wings.This owl is very soft and cuddly, and features small velcro spots on his wings so that they attach to each other in a front, perching position.  He has claws, a tail, and spots that are surprisingly vibrant.  You can't manipulate his beak, however his expression is filled with wide-eyed, owlish curiosity.  This owl looks to exhibit the same high quality construction that I've come to expect from Folkmanis, along with their usual charming attention to detail.  This snowy owl is a brilliant addition to any puppet collection and I can speak from personal experience when I say that these puppets last for years and years.  A must have for owl lovers, preschool teachers and story time leaders.

I had a hard time getting started with this story, as I think I was expecting the usual ugly duckling turning into a swan tale, and when this novel began going in a different direction, I felt a bit lost.  I wasn't expecting a story of such emotional depth, and I certainly wasn't expecting a character like Georgia.  She is beautifully flawed and astoundingly authentic.  There were times when I didn't like her very much and other times when she broke my heart as she learned so many painful lessons on her journey through grief and during her attempts to then embrace a new quality of life.This is a smartly written tale that offers up plenty of insights into grief and coming of age that will thoroughly engage young readers exploring their own limits and learning how to embrace their own possibilities.  Please note that this novel does include sexual references, language, drug and alcohol use. It is also an incredibly poignant and intelligent story that is not to be missed.

This little bunny is a true charmer that promises tons of fun for little ones by offering interesting motion, sound and textural elements.  The weighted bottom guarantees that this little guy will wobble, the soft springy middle offers up a nice textural contrast, and the rattly beads will make a great sound whenever baby makes a grab for bunny's ears.  Those ears fold over, adding one further point of interest.This toy is made to travel, and is built to collapse in the middle for portability.  I found it difficult to collapse and lock, although I was eventually successful.  It stayed locked in the collapsed position after lots of jostling and was easy to open back up.  I do wish the toy would have been a bit skinnier, or maybe would have included a handle for baby to grasp.  Still, as a tabletop toy, this one is pretty top notch and sure to distract an infant just beginning to bat at things.

Vivian Apple Needs a Miracle is an excellent second installment of a series that continues along a path of smart writing, innovative ideas and comprehensive character development.  Vivian continues to be a strong lead character that carries a story that requires a significant suspension of disbelief as it zips along at a fast pace.  The author does a magnificent job of creating suspense, and if the events seem unlikely, it's still easy to get caught up in things thanks to the excellent writing and Vivian's strong voice.While this might appear to be an irreverent look at religion and American culture, it's actually the American media machine that gets skewered more than anything. The world building sometimes goes way over the top, almost becoming a parody in places. The author is not subtle.  Still, I continue to be a fan of the series,and will follow Vivian and Harp as they face a future on a dying planet.  I hope there's a next installment as I am eager to see how things progress.  Don't worry, the author does tell a complete story here, but leaves plenty of things open to further exploration.  Vivian Apple is my kind of heroine and readers will love to see how she grows and changes throughout this story - never letting go of her sledge hammer or her big heart.

Jennifer McMahon has once again proven herself to be the queen of the dark, atmospheric thriller.  I loved The Night Sister and lost quite a bit of sleep so I could stay up late and finish it.  The author does a wonderful job with pacing and characters, offering up an intricate plot that leaves you guessing to the end.  The times shifts are handled with ease, and the resolution is unexpected and gratifying.  The Night Sister is an enthusiastic recommend for anyone with an appreciation for the darker side of literary fiction.

Fortune Smiles is an astounding collection of short stories.  They are dark and brilliant, well written and profound.  Adam Johnson is a master of his craft and there is really nothing more to add than to agree with what every other reviewer has already stated - this is an important book and a must read for any fan of literary fiction.  I am not a fan of short stories, but these are a different experience in that they possess all the complexity of a full length novel.  String them all together and you get a valuable reading experience that you won't soon forget.

Challenger Deep is an emotionally powerful novel that will engage young readers with it's unflinching portrayal of mental illness.  Shusterman never shies away from important issues, and Challenger Deep plunges right into the schizophrenic mind without hesitation.  Interestingly enough, the very thing that makes this book ring so true also makes this book not quite as readable as his other offerings.  There are many confusing, surreal moments that left me wondering where we were until I could get a handle on this story.Challenger Deep is an important story and a challenging read that will captivate those teens interested in the subject matter.  A cautious recommend for the right audience.

The Admissions is a smartly written novel filled with characters that are compelling, real, and truly memorable.  I was riveted by this cautionary tale of modern life and felt that I was getting a ring-side seat to witness the implosion of the modern family.  I found this book very hard to put down as I became entwined into the lives of this family.  I was mesmerized by their secrets, and charmed by their devotion to each other.  This book explores the family dynamic in a truly modern unique way, and offers up more than a few insightful moments and keen observations on family, guilt, love, and obsession.Living inside Nora's head was exhausting, but I came to really love her.  She is the backbone of this story and of this family, and the author has absolutely nailed every aspect of her character.  Moments of humor and heartache abound in this novel, and the author writes all these events with intelligence, authenticity and heart.  The Admissions is a must read for any fan of literary or women's fiction looking for a book high on drama, low on melodrama and filled with the sort of revelations that make you consider your own life and priorities. I was sorry to see it end, as I will miss the Hawthorne family.

First posted on Amazon.co.uk on 8 November 2015This is a quite good follow-up of Vulkan Lives (the author’s previous volume in the Horus Heresy) and of the Unremembered Empire (from Dan Abnett). A couple of little warnings before starting this review: it is not absolutely necessary to have read both mentioned volumes before this one, but it certainly helps. In fact, it also helps to have read the whole series, to some extent, and in particular the five first volumes. Also, and although I try to both avoid them and limit them, the following review may contain a few “spoilers”.This rather long volume (slightly less than 500 pages) focused upon the Odyssey of a handful of Salamanders, survivors of the Isstvan V’ “Odyssey as they bring back the corpse of Vulkan, their Primarch, back to Nocturne (hence the book’s title), their home planet, across the war-torn space of the Imperium and across the storm-ridden warp in particular (hence the book’s subtitle). They are driven by their belief, or rather by their need to believe that “Vulkan lives”, despite all evidence pointing to the contrary. Taking point in this belief is Artellus Numeon, once captain of the Pyre Guard and Vulkan’s Equerry, who is freed from captivity and torture by the Ultramarines, rallies the survivors of his Legion and leads the Odyssey with the grudging acceptance of Guilliman and the two other Primarchs who have joined forces with him to found – a bit prematurely - the “Second Empire”.The plot and events that take place during the Odyssey are somewhat unoriginal. They are however some nice touches, such as a murderous warp version of Ulysses’ sirens (I will say no more about them). Another nice touch is that, at one point in the voyage, the huge but largely empty battle-barge of the Salamanders is forced to drop out of the warp near the Segmentum Solar, gets to hear the call by Rogal Dorn for all Legions to rally to the defence of Terra and therefore learns that Terra has not yet fallen. The Salamanders are therefore forced to make a rather hard choice between obeying the summons and continuing on their journey. This, at least, is how the author portrays it.There is also the usual number of “desperate” void battles, boarding actions and even a battle on the ground, all of which are quite griping and well told, but not terribly original. You also get “treated” to the usual reminiscences about the treason, trauma, defeat and massacre of Isstvan V (here we go again!).Perhaps the main theme of the whole book is the Salamanders’ own agonies, and how they are torn and divided between hope/belief against all odds that “Vulkan lives”, quite literally, of course, and that bringing him back to Nocturne will revive him, and mourning and despair, which leads the Legionaries to bring him back to be buried at home. Here again, the theme and idea is rather good, but the execution is borderline stereotype, at times. It did not elicit much empathy – allegedly one of the main characteristics of the Salamanders - as far as I was concerned and, at times, I could not help getting a bit impatient with all the moaning and whining (that is how it felt like, to me) coming from the fearsome Space Marines.A related point is the author’s tendency to exaggerate and “overdo it”, at times, to make his history more dramatic, although this might also be editorial glitches. So, at one point during a particularly tense boarding action, Artellus’ ammunition is low, with the author telling us he has only half a clip left in his bolter. A few lines further, and without a single additional shot having been fired, you learn that in fact he only has three rounds left and, of course, hardly any other weapon.More importantly, when describing and exploring the moral crisis of the Salamanders, the author comes up with the dubious claim that their Legion was the one which suffered the highest casualties on Isstvan V. I would rather have put my money on the Iron Hands, although the Black Guard was also decimated! Even more controversially, the Salamanders are presented as worse off than the two others because they do not know what happened to their Primarch, whereas Corax of the Black Guard escaped, although badly wounded, and Manus Ferrus of the Iron Hands was decapitated. What the author may have wanted to convey is the uncertainty as to whether their Primarch is still alive or not was, for the Salamanders, perhaps even worse to bear than the certainty that he had been killed. Unfortunately, this is not exactly how his point comes across.Another interesting feature which could have been better used is that of a somewhat schizophrenic sharpshooter “Knight Errant” who, by and large, gets to help the Salamanders quite a lot. The problem here is that the author never entirely tells how this character made it onto the battle barge, yet alone how he acquired his somewhat mixed personality. IT would also have let readers know what the Sigillite was up to...Finally, while quite entertaining despite all my gripes and rants, this book is yet another “side-show”, even if one that is interesting at times. The point here is that, once again, the reader is no closer to the invasion of Terra and the assault of the Imperial Palace. Also, it would be nice if, in some not too distant future and before the invasion of Terra begins, a Black Library author would be kind enough to write a book on Book 17 of the series (the Outcast Dead) and focus on the preparations for the defence of System Solar. This is book 32 and, for the last fifteen instalments, authors have been spinning out the outcomes of Isstvan V but almost exclusively from the perspective of the Loyalist or the Rebel Legions.Three stars.

The hero is the illegitimate son of “the Half-Hanged Man”, one of the nicknames of an English mercenary who had his hour of fame during the first part of the Hundred Years War before being killed by a rival mercenary captain. His son follows in his footsteps, flees to France and joins the army of Henry V of Lancaster after Agincourt, as the English King conquers Normandy.The story begins with Sir John Page, an old mercenary knight, being captured by the Turks, and by Sultan Mehmet II in particular, at the fall of Constantinople, together with the Byzantine historian Phrantzes. The latter is a historical character that really existed. The former, the hero of this book (and the next ones) is fictional, but could perhaps have been among the mercenaries that defended Constantinople. In a male version of the Thousand and One Nights, the old mercenary is made to dictate the story of his life to the historian for the Sultan’s entertainment. As long as this lasts, they will survive.The author has clearly well researched his topic, as shown by his little historical notice, but also by his attention to detail, such as the armour of Sir John Page. Also interesting, and in the same vein as “The Half-Hanged Man”, is the depiction of the main character as a human being, with all his flaws and limitations, who happens to be somewhere at the right time and moment and becomes portrayed as a hero, without really being one, and becomes a knight and a – very minor – baron. Also of interest are John Page’s motivations, and those of his fellow soldiers, to join the war in France. Patriotism may have been one of them, but it may not have been the main factor. Escaping justice, poverty and, more generally, the absence of any future and the off-chance to get rich quick in France, seem to have been at least as important.Also well reconstituted are the hard campaigns and sieges that Henry V had to sustain to conquer Normandy. As shown, many towns just gave in because they were insufficiently garrisoned and had little hope of being relieved by a French army. Some (Honfleur, Caen and Rouen) did, and in all cases, the sieges were terribly costly for the besiegers, with diseases killing probably more men than the enemy. Readers might be interested to learn about the battle of Baugé, the only clear-cut French victory during this period, and disaster for the English which was entirely the making of Henry V’s envious brother – the Duke of Clarence – who paid for it with his life, but also with those of hundreds of his men and a number of other senior and highly experienced lords and commanders.A last feature I would like to emphasise is the care taken by David Pilling’s in drawing what seems to be a realistic portrait of Henry V. The King’s superb soldiering and leadership is well displayed through the few glimpses that Page has of him, but his ruthless efficiency and his somewhat self-righteous piety are also well shown. Henry’s need to conquer and be victorious in order to cement the legitimacy of his reign, he was after all the son of a usurper who murdered his legitimate King, are also hinted at.There are however some minor glitches here and there or features and interpretations introduced by the author for dramatic effect and which may not always work or which are not entirely historical. Regarding the fall of Constantinople, the injury suffered by Guistiniani, the Genoese mercenary captain who was defending one of the most vulnerable sections of Constantinople’s Walls, did lead to his evacuation by his men, and therefore a weakening of the defence that the Ottomans took advantage off. It is however doubtful that the walls were totally abandoned as a result. Also, the Ottoman artillery simply did not pound to rubble the palaces of the Byzantine Emperors during the siege. Finally, John Page’s age, he is supposed to be sixty, is just about plausible but it is rather unlikely that he would have been able to hold his own against five Janissaries and kill three of them. Another little glitch is to have John Page addressing the Sultan as “Khans of Khans” – a title used the unfriendly Mongols – or as “Shahs of Shahs” – a title used by the Persians who not exactly on friendly terms with the Ottomans either.Four strong stars for a good and exciting read. I am also very much looking forward to the sequel of this book in which John Page, after leaving the English army following the disaster of Baugé, goes off to fight in Central Europe during the cruel and little known Hussite Wars.

This is rather fascinating of Gaston III, Count of Foix and self-proclaimed sovereign Lord of Béarn (he is termed “Prince of Bearn in French) and feudal lord of many other places scattered across Languedoc, Aragon and English Guyenne. Although much shorter, it does resemble Barbara Tuchman’s “A Distant Mirror” in some respects since it is also the portrait of a great feudal lord, but one in Southern France, as opposed to Enguerrand, the powerful baron of Coucy, North of Paris. Both men were also the last of their line and both were roughly contemporaries which lived through the first half century of the so-called “Hundred Years War”. Both men also died within the last decade of the fourteenth century and both books are therefore very much about the period from the 1330S to the 1390s, and all the disasters that occurred throughout France, then the most powerful and richest Christian kingdom in Europe.This, however, is about where the parallels end and the differences begin. “Lord of the Pyrenees” is more of a biographer and it focuses on Gaston, the man himself, his achievements, his struggle to both assert his independence and remain independent. It is about a fascinating character who managed, during a long reign of some forty five years to maintain his independence against all of the much more powerful neighbouring kingdoms and play them off one against the other while never really siding with any of them for very long. It is also about a prince who, through his pragmatic, self-interested and highly efficient diplomacy, managed to preserve most of his domains from the atrocities of the Hundred Years War and make them prosper, in stark contrast with most of the rest of the Kingdom of France.The author presents in a clear style how Gaston, self-consciously self-styled Fébus, managed this, describing his considerable diplomatic talents. He also presents rather well the basis of his power, the complex relationships with his subjects in his scattered possessions and his strategic vision to link them together. Just as well presented are the tools he used to build up his power, the centralisation of his administration, the small group of faithful kin - his bastard half-brothers and sons and some of his faithful followers, and the taxing of his domains whose economic development he promoted. Above all, however, one of his main sources of power was money, and in particular the large treasure which originated with his crushing victory against his hated rivals – the Counts of Armagnac, their clan and their followers and vassals.It is the huge ransoms he extracted from the captive enemy leadership which were the root cause of his fortune and overflowing treasure, a treasure that he managed to at least maintain if not increase for a period of more than thirty years through the careful administration of his lands. It is also this treasury that allowed him to bride, impress through lavish spending and, perhaps more importantly, to raise professional mercenaries, launch them against his enemies and more generally use them as part of his diplomatic arsenal. It is also this treasury which, more generally, gave him the military means to defend the County of Foix and the Lordship of Bearn while also expanding his influence through the County of Bigorre and towards Toulouse.Another fascinating dimension of this book is to show the complexity of Gaston’s character and personality. Through certain aspects, for instance his old family feud and rivalry against the Armagnacs which he ruthlessly prosecuted, he was very much the medieval and feudal lord. Through his multiple family connections, he was related to the most powerful families of the region, including the King of Navarre, who was his brother-in-law, and the Gascon Lord Jean de Grailly, one of the Black Prince’s foremost captains, who was his first cousin. Through other aspects, as a patron of arts (music and poetry in particular) and as a highly skilled huntsman who composed a highly praised and much used treaty on the subject, he was both a great medieval lord and the forebear of the Princes of the Renaissance.A related dimension was the complexity and ambivalence of a rather passionate character, the dramas of his personal life and some rather autocratic streaks. He could be ruthless and violent. He had his sole legitimate son and heir killed, and may even have killed him with his own hands. He repudiated his wife, the sister of the King of Navarre, who survived him, and send her back to her brother with just about only the clothes she was wearing, although the exact reasons for this were never disclosed. Despite having numerous mistress and illegitimate sons from them, he never had his marriage dissolved and therefore never remarried, for reasons that are, here again, not explicit. He also ruled his domains and subjects with what seems to have been autocratic methods and a ruthlessly efficient exercise of censorship to the extent to the extent that much of the rationales underpinning the personal dramas above remain essentially unknown.The final point here is that I cannot quite agree with the statement made in the summary of this book about his reign standing “out as one of the rare success stories of the `calamitous' fourteenth century.” His reign – he would have liked the use of such a word – saw many achievements, mostly mentioned throughout his review. However, to view it as a “success story” is somewhat simplistic, because he ultimately failed to organise his succession and preserve the integrity of his lands (Foix and Bearn were split up). In other words, assessing his achievements turns out to be just as complex as the man himself. Five stars.

This is a very interesting and fascinating little with slightly more than 160 pages of text that is easy to read and therefore accessible, although scholarly. Essentially - and perhaps for a change – the book’s presentation summarises rather well its contents.The book does indeed challenge a number of views and myths that are at least partly derived from Ancient Greek sources and from Athenian ones in particular. One of these is that the rule of Kings disappeared from Greece, was superseded by oligarchies and democracies, and that the rule of one (or monarchy) made a comeback during the fourth century BC in the form of tyranny.As the author shows rather well, the reality seems to happen more complex. Kingship (Basilea) was defined, or rather caricatured by reference to the Persian King of Kings. However, it had existed before in areas that were part of Greece and continued to exist throughout the classical period (Macedonia, but also Sparta). Also, and although presented as “arch-villains” in such ways that the term “tyrant” can only have very negative connotations nowadays, there was a link between tyrants, heroes and saviours of the city in a number of cases during both the 7th and 6th century BC and the 4th century. In the latter case, the typical examples are those of Denys I and Agathocles who both became tyrants of Syracuse and remained in power for decades at least partly because of their “heroic” status as protectors and victors against Carthage.Another strongpoint is the author’s ability to clearly show how monarchy was underpinned by a common heroic ideology among rulers based on arte (loosely translated as excellence), and to what extent, even in monarchies and tyrannies, “rule of one” was never exclusive and always somehow shared, or at least supported by the family or even the clan.A further component of the rule of one was its instability, or, perhaps to be more precise, the absence of any clear succession rules within the ruling clan or family, or even within the kingdom or city. Two examples that the author uses extensively are those of the Kings of Macedonian and the Kings of Sparta. In both of these cases, and in all other cases of “one-man rule”, there was no hereditary primogeniture and there was no guarantee that a son would succeed a father since, by definition, the successor had to be “the best”. In practice, this could mean the strongest, as Alexander’s last words on his deathbed are supposed to have been when asked for the name of his successor, or, perhaps more cynically and in a more sinister way, the one who survived all of the other potential claimants.An additional key point is the author’s effort in identifying the various components that sole rulers used to legitimise their rules rule. For instance, they were themselves heroes or belonged to a kin group descendant of a hero. They could also be law-givers, the ones who gave their respective cities their constitution and therefore, at least symbolically, were its founders. Interestingly, the author also shows how the relationship between ruling/power of one and law interacted and evolved, with the later ultimately becoming the main limitation and constraint of the power of one in an interesting reversal of causality.Clear, well-presented and well-written, even if not always fully convincing and sometimes “cutting a few corners” because of its limited size, this little book is certainly a valuable contribution and an excellent starting point for anyone interesting in monarchy or tyranny during the classical, but also during the Hellenistic period. It is also, more generally, a valuable piece for anyone wanting to learn what monarchy, whether exercised by a King or by a Tyrant, meant for the Ancient Greeks, how the two differed and evolved, and how they compare to the modern notions that lurk behind the very same terms nowadays. Four strong stars.

I understand another reviewer on the US site has questioned and heavily criticised the author’s narrative of the battle of Agincourt, and especially the numbers of each side. There is, indeed, a bit of a controversy regarding respective numbers and depending upon which historian you happen to read: about 6000 or rather 9000 for the English and 12000 or double that number on the French side. To a large extent, the discrepancies arise because the numbers may mean different things and may also have been calculated differently. For instance, whether only men-at-arms, archers and crossbowmen and other armed infantry are included or whether servants and pages are also added can lead to significantly different totals, perhaps especially on the French side. Also, whether the numbers correspond to the forces on each side that sent out on the campaign or whether they actually correspond to the numbers on the battlefield can also explain the significant discrepancies that authors have come up with. To a large extent, and while interesting, this kind of debate is somewhat sterile because none of the numbers can be definitely proved. In addition, it is a rather minor point and there are much more important ones, which the author does make, and makes in a rather brilliantly way.One of these is that the victory of Agincourt, the whole campaign that led to it, and the follow-up campaigns a few years latter through which Henry V conquered Normandy and managed to stave of French counter-attacks following the defeat and death of his brother, were certainly not “walks in the park”, to use the title of another review. Henry V’s armies suffered huge casualties during sieges, particularly those of Harfleur (in 1415 before Agincourt) and Meaux (in 1421-22), with the author estimating (and it is no more than an estimate) that these could have represented up to a third of the forces engaged. These casualties seem to have been caused at least as much by insufficient food supplies, poor quality food and disease resulting from poor hygiene – as they were due to the enemy, even including wound infections. Various authors estimates that between a quarter and third among the injured would die of their wounds although, here again, these are estimates and a further qualification would be that the chances of a lowly archer might often be worse than those of a high ranking noble. Regarding diseases, the author rightly insists on dysentery as one of the main killers during medieval sieges and it was in fact dysentery, probably contracted during the siege of Meaux, lack of proper healthcare, and Henry’s own determination and drive to carry on that killed him at the “ripe old age” of thirty-six.In addition to showing – once again - the horrors and squalid conditions of medieval warfare in general and of the conditions during the early decades of the 15th century in particular, Jonathan Sumption’s book shows how difficult and costly it was for both England and France to wage war. This is perhaps the second main merit of this volume. It shows the extreme difficulties that both sides had in recruiting, paying and feeding the armies they raised.The author’s emphasises at length, with an almost overwhelming luxury of details, how inadequate the finances of both Kingdoms were. In both cases, the King’s own revenues were woefully insufficient and tax revenues were neither regular nor could they entirely be relied upon. The King of England, which was smaller, less populated and poorer than France, has to obtain subsidies (taxes) from Parliament whereas the revenues that the King of France could raise were largely subject to graft from the civil service and, perhaps even more so, by his numerous Valois relatives. The consequences are very well shown. Both Kingdoms had to borrow heavily to make up the shortcomings and were endemically courting bankruptcy as a result. Their armies’ pay was frequently or even typically in arrears with troops sometimes payed by those who had raised them on behalf of their respective Kings. More generally, this inadequacy in financial resources essentially meant that they could only stray in the field for a few months before disintegrating or needing to be disbandedOne of the main consequences of this state of affairs, which is also very well illustrated and described by the author, is that actual fighting was often desultory and a huge amount of time was spent in parleys and diplomatic negotiations, with just about everyone talking to everyone else. Here again, the author “treats” the reader with extremely details accounts of the various political and diplomatic negotiations between the French factions, before and during their civil war, and between them and the English.Another strongpoint of this book is to show how remarkable Henry V’s successes were, but also how expensive and fragile they turned out to be.Put simply, and without demeaning the achievement in any way, the author does convey the clear impression that the English King overreached and that the English Kingdom of France that he established and that his brother (John Duke of Bedford) would strive to defend was somewhat doomed from the beginning. To some extent, this might seem to be hindsight, although Jonathan Sumption makes a strong case, showing that even before Henry’s death, it was increasingly difficult to find sufficient money and volunteers in England to go fight in France. He also shows that despite the attempts to organise the defence of the conquered lands, and of Normandy in particular, these did not yield sufficient money or soldiers and were therefore neither self-sufficient.A final strongpoint is to show to what extent the English triumph and conquest of most of northern France was against the odds and was only made possible by taking advantage of the political chaos and divisions in France, with the root cause of these being the madness of Charles VI, the French King. Here again, there is no attempt to demean or question the achievement. Rather, if anything, it shows that Henry V was much more than a gifted soldier. He seems to have been also a first class diplomat and leader, and a very determined leader who sought legitimacy (he was, after all, the son of a usurper who had murdered the legitimate King of England) through victory against France and conquests and achievement that were equal to or even surpassed those of Edward III and of the Black Prince.Five stars for a superb piece of scholarship, even if this thick and very detailed book is not always exactly easy to read.

Posted a couple of minutes before on Amazon.co.ukThis book from Professor Mary Beard is in many respects a masterpiece, but it is also a somewhat original one because it covers the history of Rome, but only its first millennium. The period starts with its foundation, traditionally set at 753 BC, and it stops around to 212 AD, when the Emperor most well-known as Caracalla made all free inhabitants of the Roman Empire into Roman citizens, therefore changing what it meant to be “Roman” and making “more than 30 million provincials into Romans overnight”, to quote the author. The event was indeed momentous, as rightly emphasised by the author, but this was largely because of its far-reaching consequences, and these may only have appeared overtime.It can seem odd to publish a book on the history of Rome or on the Roman Empire and stop in AD 212, knowing, as we do, that the Roman Empire continued for over two and a half centuries for its Western part, and at least a further century and a half in the East. This is where the book’s title, its meaning, and the author’s intentions are important to understand.SPQR is the acronym of the Senate and the People of Rome. The meaning refers to a period where the Senate and the People exercised supreme power in the city of Rome, which was a city-state to begin with, then the capital city of Italy, and the capital of an Empire. It also refers to a period where they appeared to exercise such power, as was the case after the so-called “Roman Revolution” from Augustus onwards, during what used to be called the period of the Principate. This is the period where the Emperor styled himself as the “First among equal” or the Princeps - the First in the Senate, and was careful, at least initially, to preserve the appearances of the Republic and of its institutions.However, this book is really about Roman identity and, more precisely, what it meant to be a Roman citizen, from the foundation of the little city on the Tiber to the million large city that ruled over an Empire centred on the Mediterranean that the Romans arrogantly – but aptly - called “Mare Nostrum” (“Our Sea). It is not about what it meant to be a subject of the Roman Empire, or of the Christian Roman Empire, with multiple imperial capitals and Rome being, at best, only one of them.Here we get to the (relatively recent) divide between “Classics” and the Greco-Roman city-state model, as opposed to “Late Antiquity” which covers the Late Roman Empire up to the Arab conquests and no longer up to AD 476 only, and which is underpinned by the Greco-Asian concept of imperial power and Emperors.
