The reader is also “treated”, somewhat amusingly, to the “politically correct” and faintly ridiculous and hypocritical BCE and CE (Before Common Era and Common Era) that have become fashionable and which refer to exactly the same dates as BC (before Christ) and AD (Anno Domini – Year of the Lord), except that they attempt to hide the Christian origin of the supposedly “global” and “universal” dating system.Since this book is about the formation and the expansion of Roman identity and Roman citizenship, Mary Bard stars by examining, explaining and debunking Rome’s founding myths, most of which seem to have been elaborated between the first century BC and the first century AD. She also analyses more recent Roman founding myths, such as the so-called decisive battle of Actium, and the propaganda of Augustus. Also included is an analysis of what the Roman regimes and societies really were like – the so-called Republic started as an oligarchy and if Roman Senators cum politicians chose, at times, to become “populares”, as Caesar did for instance, it was more about power and self-interest than about genuine interest for the poor. To help with this, the author makes use of recent archaeological findings and excavations in Rome itself, and all of what used to be called (somewhat disparagingly) the other “auxiliary disciplines” such as numismatics (studying old coins) and epigraphy (studying inscriptions).To conclude, this is a remarkable book written in a very accessible style but nevertheless with few anachronisms and not attempt to “dumb down”, as books targeted towards the so-called “general reader” and written by academic specialists sometimes tend to do. It is also a book that contains numerous and carefully chosen illustrations which are intended to elicit the reader’s curiosity and interest, such as the fake representation of Cicero’s famous appearance in front of the Senate during which he confounded Catiline. Also included are five excellent maps of Rome and its surroundings, including its Empire. Finally, there are no notes but a rather copious section for “further reading” with just about all of the key references included and commented upon for each of the book’s chapters.There would in fact be much more to mention about this very rich book. By this point, however, I believe that anyone reading this review will have understood how valuable I found it to be and how much I recommend it. Easily worth five stars, and I would have given it more had this been possible.

Published a couple of minutes ago on Amazon.co.ukThis book is the last of the Cicero trilogy. It covers the last fifteen years or so of his life, from 58 BC to 43 BC and it is largely dominated by the rise and fall of Caius Julius Caesar (hence the book’s title). It ends with the beginning of a new struggle from which the new Caesar - and future Augustus - would emerge victorious and – almost literally - the “last man standing.” I can also confirm that this book can reads perfectly well on its own. It is not necessary to have read the two previous episodes (Lustrum and Imperium), respectively on the rise of Cicero as Rome’s prominent lawyer, with the case against Verres in particular, and his consulship and the Catiline conspiracy. This is exactly what I have done. It may help, however, to know a bit of the last years of the Roman Republic, although even this is not absolutely indispensable.This is because – to put things bluntly –Robert Harris had done a wonderful job and come up with a rather superb novel which is extremely well-researched and contains excellent characterisation. The result is a superbly entertaining novel told in the first person by Cicero’s secretary (Tiro) who really existed, who really was Cicero’s slave (and then his freedman), confident and friend and who really wrote a biography (now lost but mentioned in various primary sources) of his master and published Cicero’s letters after his death. Also, he did invent a kind of shorthand and we do owe him a number of abbreviations such as e.g. or etc…Interestingly, Tiro is perhaps the most sympathetic character of the whole book. All other characters, including Cicero himself, are presented “warts and all”, with their qualities but also their shortcomings. Cicero himself is a complex mixture of selfishness, lucidity and puffed up self-importance, with a level pf arrogance that is at times borderline stupidity, but also capable of streaks of remarkable generosity, although the latest feature may have been somewhat “enhanced” by the novelist in order to make Cicero more sympathetic. He cannot resist a “bon mot” that may make others laugh at someone else’s expense and therefore mortally offend some powerful Roman who will never forgive him and treat him as a potential threat for ever after. He is also both aware of his extraordinary oratory talent, and rather vain about it. He is also aware of his major shortcomings compared to the other Senators, his competitors. Essentially, he is a “parvenu”, and upstart in the eyes of the “old money”. He was not an aristocrat from one of the old families, such as Caesar, Crassus, Cato or Brutus. He did not have the fortune to make up for this, such as Pompey, neither did he acquire such a fortune during his career, as Caesar (and Pompey) managed to do thanks to their conquests. Finally, he had no military skills whatsoever, contrary to both Caesar and Pompey (and even Crassus, to a lesser extent) and seems to have been somewhat of a physical coward, even if perhaps not always a moral coward.The portraits of the other characters are also quite remarkable. This is particularly the case of the skilful and utterly ruthless Caesar, with his winning charm hiding his cold mind. Also good are the portraits of the young Octavius/Caesar whom Cicero did both mortally offend and grossly underestimate, and that of the ageing Pompey whose military talent was largely in his qualities as a first class organiser and expert in logistics. Even Mark Antony is rather good, with the author having shown him as no mean orator himself and quite capable of hitting back and hurting Cicero through a public speech of his own.The presentation and description of the historical events through the eyes of Cicero’s secretary are also excellent although, at times, the author may have provided Cicero – his hero – with a bit too much clairvoyance that only hindsight could have provided. It is for instance a bit doubtful that Cicero would have been in a position to identify Caesar as the most dangerous threat to the Republic of the three (the other two being Pompey and Crassus) in 59 BC. However, apart from this and perhaps one or two similar exceptions, the rest is excellent, including the details, such as Caesar’s Commentaries on the Gallic Wars which were publicly read in the Senate but also in the street. They were very skilfully and very much used as a media for self-promotion. Another interesting feature is the change in Caesar’s attitude after his final victory at Munda in Spain, against Pompey’s sons. His “mercifulness” towards his ex-foes allowed him to assert his primacy and superiority, as Cato very well understood. The impression here is that his autocratic tendencies came to the fore. He was less and less careful in hiding them and he increasingly appeared as a tyrant, as opposed to the somewhat anachronistic use by the author of the term Dictator, with its modern sense.Another handful of superb features are the description of life in Rome and the life of a Senator, with their peregrinations from their houses on the Palatin hill (a few had also suburban palaces) and of the increasingly deleterious atmosphere in Rome during the 50s BC. Also excellent are the depictions of everyday life at the time, more generally, including the huge mortality rates that affected women during childbirth across all social classes and the marriage/divorce behaviours within the members of the Senate in particular.To achieve this, the author has not only done his research thoroughly, he has also used extensively Cicero’s correspondence with quotations and extracts of letters abundantly used throughout the book. The end result is one of the best novels I have read this year, and also one that is so well done that just about everything “feels and look” authentic. Five stars, easily.PS: those who may want to check the historical record, and see to what extent Robert Harris has stayed extremely close to what we happen to know, may also want to read Mary Beard’s also superb and very accessible SPQR, for instance.

This is indeed book 5 in the Hereward series and it follows closely the previous episode which both take place within the Byzantine Empire (or Eastern Roman Empire) in the 1070s. This one, like the previous one, have a good deal of fiction and even fantasy at times, built upon a more or less historical context.The historical context is that of the Eastern Roman Empire in the year 1073 AD and, more precisely, the (historical) rebellion of Roussel de Bailleuil, a mercenary commander of a Tagma (regiment) of Norman mercenaries. The historical outline is more or less accurate. The rebellion did take place. Roussel did try to carve a principality for himself in Asia Minor and did defeat a Byzantine army commanded by the Caesar John Doukas, the Emperor’s uncle, whom he captured. He did have the Caesar crowned, but it is quite unlikely that the Caesar had much of a choice. Finally, the rebellion was crushed when the Byzantines essentially called in a large Turkish war band to do the work for them.It is in the details that the author has taken a number of limitations. The Athanatoi or Immortals was a crack Byzantine heavy cavalry regiment made up of nobles, but it was highly trained and not the ill-disciplined and totally inexperienced – if brave - bunch that appears in the novel. There is also some uncertainty as to whether this regiment, which existed in 1078, had already been formed five years before. It was formed when Nikephoritzes (a historical character, although perhaps not as sinister as described in the book) was in power, but seems to have been raised and put together after 1073-74.Some of the Byzantine families and the Nepotes in particular, are completely fictional. The main rivalry was between the Doukai and the Comnenes, as mentioned by the author is his foreword, although, contrary to his assertion, neither had “a strong claim to the throne”. The members of the Doukai had and were sitting on it and that the uncle of Alexis Comnene had been Emperor for a couple of years after having come to power through a military coup in the 1050s. As for the Court at Constantinople having “become a nest of vipers”, this was not exactly new, to put it very mildly. It had been such a nest for at least half a century by the time this story begins, that is at least since the death in AD 1025 of the Emperor Basil II and, three years later of his brother Constantine, both without male heirs.Also, statements according to which the Byzantine army had deteriorated and was heavily relying upon foreign mercenaries need to be somewhat qualified. The byzantine army had, just like the Roman one from which it had evolved, always been open to professional soldiers originating from beyond the Empire’s borders, at least as long as the Empire could pay for them. Regarding the Imperial Varenguard in particular, they were indeed extremely well paid and highly regarded for their prowess, but also for their loyalty to their pay master.  Seriously doubt, however, that “they were adored by the people” of Constantinople, especially since Emperors could use them, at times, as enforcers of the Emperor’s will. So, feared probably, higly-regarded, certainly, but it is very unlikely that they were adored, especially since they wer "Barbarians" in the eyes of the Byzantines.Regarding the quality of the Byzantine army, there is some truths that the territorial units - known as themata – had deteriorated and were no more than local militias. However, this was not entirely the case for the professional army – the tagmata (or “regiments”) – within which the foreign mercenaries were found. With regards to troop quality, and when compared to the 10th century for instance, it also seems that the infantry deteriorated perhaps more than the cavalry. What might be more accurate is that the Byzantines had few indigenous troops of horse archers, which put them at a disadvantage against the Turks, and did not use the same shock tactics as the Franks in general, and the Normans in particular. Unsurprisingly, Turks and Franks, for cavalry, and Russ, Viking and Anglo-Danes, for heavy infantry, were the most sought “foreign mercenaries” because they provided troop-types that were better adapted to the fighting tactics of Byzantium’s enemies.Then there is the characterisation. I will not mention much here, in order to avoid so-called spoilers. Some of the characters are somewhat hard to believe. This includes Hereward himself, who rather curiously, appears “more emotional”, at times, as another reviewer puts it, while being also a fierce and, at times, a berserker killer. Frankly, Hereward presented as some kind of “compassionate killer” did not seem terribly plausible to me. Also, having one of the female Byzantine characters believe she is the reincarnation of a deceased female war lady from North Africa was not very convincing, nor did the sadistic Byzantine child (a boy this time!).Then there is the action. The battle scenes are mostly good, although, here again, there are glitches. One of these are head and limbs flying left, right and centre. The author is far being from the only one to go for this kind of “gory” ploy. However, both he and his colleagues need to understand how difficult and therefore how improbable such features are in reality, especially when the warriors happen to be covered in chain mail. Although I confess that I have no personal experience in the matter, chopping off arms and heads in battle is unlikely to have been as easy as James Wilde makes it look. Also, it is quite impossible for a warrior on horseback to wield the two-handed Danish long axe for which the Varenguard became famous.All in all, this was not an unpleasant, although perhaps not quite among the best. Readers wanting to compare with another novel with the same historical background can read the much older “the Lady for Ransom” from Alfred Duggan, which is also on Roussel de Bailleuil, and which I found much easier to believe. After hesitating between three and four stars, I will finally settle on the latter, although I feel I am being somewhat generous.

The first – and perhaps the main – merit of this book is to present Constantine in context. First and foremost, he was - and wanted to be – an Emperor. He was a power-hungry autocrat even if, to prevail over his rivals, he chose to become a Christian. It is in fact because he became a Christian and because this transformed the Empire and was the first step towards ensuring that Christianity would survive, prevail and then become the Empire’s religion, that Constantine has received so much attention over the centuries, and still does. This started with the Christian bishops of the fourth century, some of which were quick in recasting some of the most momentous events of Constantine’s character in a Christian light and eager to put a positive (that is a Christian) spin on them. They have been so successful in doing this that most people associate closely Constantine with Christianity, and some, including among historians, define him exclusively as the “Christian Emperor”.This is where David Potter’s book is truly excellent, even if, as other reviewers have also mentioned, it is perhaps not the best starting point for “beginners” (this would rather be Stephenson’s “Constantine: Roman Emperor. Christian Victor” published). In particular, and this second revised edition, David Potter shows to what extent Constantine conformed to traditional imperial patterns, that of a power hungry Emperor who could have no rivals and for whom religion, and State religion in particular, was a way to enhance and establish his legitimacy so as to make it unassailable and uncontested. Interestingly, Constantine did not start out as a Christian ad did not become one overnight, contrary to what the Christian sources may want us to believe and as the author shows very well. Interestingly also, he was very careful not to alienate other religions. Although it did become clear over time that becoming Christian was an asset for ambitious men who wanted a career in the palatial administration, this was never imposed, and even less so in the army where most still worshipped a range of other divinities (Mithras, among others, being particularly popular). Also quite fascinating are the author’s analyses showing how various events, such as Constantine’s “escape from the clutches” of the Court of Galerius or the Milvian Bridge miraculous apparitions, were remodelled over time in the most traditional fashion, as imperial propaganda had been doing for centuries.Another strongpoint of this book is the author’s intellectual honesty. This is most apparent when describing the fate of Maximian, whose supposed attempt to murder Constantine after having been put under house arrest is rather implausible and rightfully dismissed by the author as a piece of propaganda. It also appears with the fates of Crispus and of Fausta. We do know that Constantine had his eldest son executed in AD 326, but we simply do not know the real reason for this. We also know that Fausta disappears from all official records and nothing more is officially heard of her. It does seem that Constantine had her removed and perhaps even executed, although the later accounts about her demise are somewhat implausible. An interesting point mentioned that the author is that Constantin never remarried after her death, although his interpretation, that this was because Constantine still deeply loved Fausta, is somewhat speculative. It may just as well have been because she have left him with plenty of heirs so that he had no need to contract yet another political marriage which could have created issues.All in all, the narrative of Constantine’s life, his involvement in Church affairs and is role as a legislator are perhaps the best pieces of the book, together with the foundation of Constantinople as a new imperial capital. The latter, and the rationales or it, is particularly good. In addition to the advantages afforded by the location of Constantinople, the author elaborates on a particularly interesting reason for the Emperor to move to the eastern part of the Empire, one that is rarely mentioned and that I will leave the reader to discover. Constantin’s role as a legislator, with detailed examination of his rescripts, is perhaps the section of the book which is the hardest to read for a so-called “general reader”. It does however show rather well to what extent Constantine’s conceptions of family, marriage and slaves, in particular, was conservative, rooted in “Roman” traditions, and therefore far from novel. Also very interesting are the sections about his involvement in Church affairs, whether the Donatist controversy or the Council of Nicea and the Arian controversy. All in all, the picture shown throughout the book is that of an autocratic Emperor deeply concerned about his duty and the need to ensure “law and order”, rather than that of a reformer or even a revolutionary, even when his decisions had far reaching consequences for his successors and future generations.There is however one significant weakness of this book: there is little on military events and on the army in general. It is as if the author was simply not interested in the topic. This is rather surprising given that Constantine was – and is claimed to be by David Potter – an excellent general. There is, for instance, not very much about Constantine’s invasion of Italy and war against Maxentius, although what little there is exceeds the bare minimum on the two civil wars against Licinius and the next to nothing about Constantine’s multiple campaigns on and beyond the Rhine and Danube frontiers. This is a bit of a pity for it leads the author to make a number of statements about the superiority of Constantine’s general ship and the better quality of his troops that are essentially unsubstantiated. Also missing is Constantine’s policies about recruiting non-Romans into the army or settling them within the Empire in exchange of military obligations, both of which are continuations of previous practices. Finally, there is simply no discussion at all on military reforms – the separation between comitatenses and limitanei and the fortification of the frontiers and the reasons underpinning them. I was rather surprised (and a bit disappointed) by what must have been the author’s deliberate (but unexplained) choice.Four stars because of this.

This is a good and, at times, a very good presentation of Emperor Aurelian, the Roman Empire and the so-called “Third century crisis”. It is written in an easy to read way. The author’s use of numismatic evidence is extremely interesting, largely convincing, and particularly useful for analysing the kind of economic problems that the Empire was facing and how the Emperor tried to solve them. Also largely - but not entirely – convincing are Alaric Watson’s efforts to portray his hero, for which he has obvious sympathies, in a positive light and to identify the attempts of some of the sources to denigrate this emperor and his tremendous efforts. The book is divided into two somewhat uneven parts.The first and longest is entitled “Restorer of the World”. It focuses on the tremendous upheavals that saw the fragmentation of the Empire and its reunification thanks to Aurelian’s achievements, hence the title of this review and this first part. This, title, however, was also a key piece of Aurelian’s propaganda. The point here is that I would have expected Alaric Watson to demonstrate to what extent the sweeping and boasting claim to have “restored the world” was justified, as opposed to somewhat excessive, and I did not really find such a discussion in the book. What I had instead was the impression that the author’s apparent sympathy from his subject translated into a willingness to take Aurelian’s claim at face value.There is no doubt that the Empire fragmented in AD 260, under the reign of Emperor Gallienus and following the defeat, capture and death of his father Emperor Valerian at the hands of the Sassanids. There is no doubt either that it was Aurelian’s military skills and sheer determination that reunified the Empire. There is no doubt either that Aurelian’s achievements were herculean, especially when keeping in mind that they took place during a short reign of five and had a half years. However, what is somewhat missing in a thorough assessment of the Empire’s fragmentation and its causes, and a thorough assessment as to whether Aurelian, by forcefully reconquering the splinter regimes, really put an end to the Empire’s divisions.The reunification, while real, was also short-term and perhaps also superficial and this is what Alaric Watson does not really discuss. Attempts at break-away regimes in Gaul continued, for much the same reasons as those mentioned in the book. There was one during the reign of Probus, which he forcefully put down, and there was the usurpation of Carausius during the reign of Diocletian, at a minimum. In the East, Aurelian did destroy the “separatist” regime of Palmyra, although one could also discuss whether and to what extent it really was “separatist” since Palmyra’s survival depended upon trade with the Empire. However, this did not solve unrest in the East, including insurrections in Egypt which Diocletian had to put down.The second part of the book is about Aurelian’s internal policies. His economic reforms are mainly about his attempts to reform the currency. The chapter on public works and administration include his fortification of Rome while the chapter on his relations with the Senate and the army are largely about explaining the somewhat mixed reputation and ambivalent treatment that this Emperor receives in the sources. The final chapter – “the Emperor and the Divine” – explores and describes Aurelian’s religious policy and, in particular, the cult to the “Unvanquished Sun” (Sol Invictus) which he put in place and which would inspire both Constantine and Julian during the next century.Here again, the contents are mostly good, but only as far as they go. Here again, the author largely avoids discussions that would show Aurelian’s achievements to be less than stellar. First, Aurelian’s “economic reforms”, mainly his attempts to reform the currency, were essentially aimed at the army, and at increasing the Emperor’s financial resources. In modern terms, this could be seen as an attempt to restore faith and confidence in the currency, except that the aim was to restore the soldiers’ trust and to bolster resources to pay them. This was achieved by cracking down on fraud and peculation and restructuring the mints, but also by modifying and slightly improving the silver title in some of the issues. The consequence, especially during the next two reigns, was galloping inflation. Aurelian is also shown to have reformed the urban dole. Here again, the Emperor’s objectives and intentions could have been worth a discussion. Although Aurelian may have sought to improve the well-being of his subjects, it is as least as likely that he wanted to ensure that they would be no unrest when he was away fighting on the borders of the Empire. A similar concern can be identified when discussing Aurelian’s walls around Rome. In fact, just about all of his “reforms” were designed to protect, to put the Empire’s in a state of defence and to give the army the means to be victorious. This, and the extent to which Diocletian developed and pursued similar policies because of similar needs, would have been worth showing.Another surprise is that the author has managed to write it while having comparatively little to say on the Roman army itself, on its performances in the field, and on those of its general and Emperor. Aurelian is mentioned as being an excellent tactician and general but, apart from the fact that he was victorious, there is little discussion to make the case with the campaigns only described in general terms and not very much about the battles themselves. Also somewhat missing is a discussion on the changes that may have started to affect the army, and its equipment and tactics in particular. Even the cavalry force that Gallienus formed and in which Aurelian served and then commanded could have merited a more thorough discussion.However, there are reasons for rating this book four stars instead of the three stars that the previous comments would suggest. This is because some of the limitations listed above, in particular those related to the army, have, to some extent, to do with unsatisfactory sources. Not very much is known for certain, for instance, about most of Aurelian’s victories against the Germanic invasions and incursions across the Rhine and the Danube, although his victories against the Palmyrean armies, and his campaign more generally, could perhaps have been described in more detail.Perhaps one of the most significant merits of this book is to put pay to Aurelian’s reputation for cruelty, and the blackening of his reputation, more generally. It is also to show where this reputation comes from, and why and how it was established, and how misleading such a reputation happens to be. He did execute some Senators, because they plotted against him, but so did the so-called “good Emperors”, such as Trajan or Hadrian. Unlike them, however, he had little time to spare on establishing good relations with them and was much more interested in the army and the Empire’s defences. Simply put, this was because he was, that is he was a pragmatic soldier first and foremost and probably also a disciplinarian.He believed in Roma Aeterna and the traditional Roman ideology of eternal victory. He would do whatever it took to turn the tide and make sure that, ultimately, the Empire would prevail and survive, and this is exactly what he did.

For someone looking for a comprehensive, affordable and up to date reference on the Roman Army over some twelve centuries, this is probably your best bet. However, it is not perfect.First of all, the book’s coverage seemed (to me at least) to be pretty comprehensive and covers all aspects including logistics, sieges, organisation command and so on, all within slightly over 500 pages of text. To this is added a bunch of maps, a chronology of main events, a glossary and a basic bibliography including most if not all of the main references on each period and theme, all of which are very conveniently listed by chapter and theme.A second advantage is its affordability. To my knowledge at least, there is no other book offering such coverage of the Roman Army throughout its history within a similar price range. A third advantage is that many of the sections are good summaries of the main points and issues, with the author carefully presenting what is really known as opposed to the various assumptions that are taken for granted because they have been repeated time and again over decades.There are however also limitations. The book could have done with some better editing and presenting. The paragraphs are dense. There are multiple repetitions and this is simply not a book that you are going to spend an afternoon reading on the couch! There also seem to be a few mistakes that could have been avoided. If I remember correctly, it is at the battle of Illipa that Scipio (soon to be Africanus) used the unorthodox strategy to post his Roman legions on the wings and his allied troops in the centre, and NOT at Zama. There are a few other similar “glitches.” Regarding substance, the contents read at times like a compilation, with bits and pieces summarised from the main references on each subject, including some of the author’s books.More seriously perhaps, these contents are uneven. The sections on early Rome and on the Republic are acceptable, although they often largely paraphrase and summarise other titles (such as Keppie’s “Making of the Roman Army”). The bits on the Principate are good. Those on the third century, and on Roman fortifications throughout the period are probably the best sections, but others are average or even poor. There is, for instance, very little on the Roman Navy. The pieces on the Dominate from Diocletian to Constantine included are rather average, although all the main points are made. However, the next sections, and those on the second half of the Fourth century, the Fifth century and the demise of the Roman Army in particular, are rather disappointing.Here again, a number of excellent points are made, such as the choice to increasingly recruit Barbarians, the lack of time to train and integrate them and the decline in discipline. However, other points are not as clearly made. It would, for instance, have been worthwhile discussing and explaining more why recruitment became such a problem during this period although it had not been before. Another missing point is a discussion of the Roman Army’s performances after the death of Theodosius.A third problem is a tendency to oversimplify. Stilicho, for instance, was not only “a Vandal”. He was half-Roman and had been thoroughly Romanised, like dozens of senior officers and thousands of soldiers. Moreover, “Barbarians” - a term whose meaning became increasingly blurred overtime – did not monopolise the highest military positions neither in the West not in the East. I seem to remember that, according to statistics brought together by Mc Mullen, they occupied between a quarter and a third of the senior commands. Contrary to what the author suggests, the armies of Stilicho, Constantius, Aetius, and some of their successors (Majorian or Anthemius in particular) were not entirely or even perhaps mostly made up of barbarians.Overall, and despite the limitations listed above, this is probably just about worth four stars (three stars would be too harsh in my view). It is not perfect, but it is the most up to date title. It also covers the whole period, and it is the most affordable in doing so.

I came across this book a bit by accident and, after reading some of the reviews on both of Amazon’s site (the UK and the US one), I decided to give it try and read a historical novel set in what he rapidly becoming a fashionable period: seventh century Britain. Others have already noted that the story told by Matthew Harfyy has been inspired by Bernard Cornwell’s hugely successful “Warrior Chronicles”. It is, however, also original in its own right and not set during the same period with the action taking place some 250 years before. The inspiration, in my view, mostly comes from Matthew Harffy’s methods and efforts in bringing together the main ingredients of a successful historical novel, those that I have mentioned in this review’s title.First, the author has meticulously researched his topic. His historical note, although only five pages, is to the point regarding both the military retinues of major Saxon warlords and their equipment. Also accurate are the small numbers involved in what were the major “battles” of the time: a few hundred or, at most, a couple of thousand on each side. There were several reasons for this. One was that most of this battles occurred during raids and counter-raids, when one “King” attacked the lands of another to gather the loot and plunder that was necessary for him to reward his military followers as the “ring-giver” that he was supposed to be. Another, perhaps even more important, was about logistics and transport. With roads in a poor state and logistics very limited, keeping a large army in the field for more than a few weeks was an impossible task. Limited transportation capability was also the reason why early Anglo-Saxon Kings tended to move with their respective courts and following from one domain to another.Another well designed feature is the interactions and relationships between the Anglo-Saxon warlord lord and the members of his trusted warband of retainers. These are described in a way that “looks and feel” realistic, with different levels of status and equipment. An interesting feature around which much of the novel is built is the relative rarity of hugely expensive good quality swords, with these, in addition to torques, rings of silver or gold but also armour and helmets, being among the main gifts and rewards that a King to bestow onto his followers.Second, the characters are well-designed and their behaviours reflect what may have been those of the times. At the very least, they are plausible. The hero himself, one Beobrand from Kent who follows his brother to Northumbria and wants to become a warrior like him, is believable. He is subject to fear and unsure of himself, but he is also driven by vengeance and blood feud and experiences to battle rage. He survives his first battle and fights at least as much through luck than because of skill. He also gets “bashed about” and wounded and is far from being constantly successful and heroic. In, other words, he comes across as a gifted and brave warrior, but also as a believable human as opposed to some unbelievable “super hero”. Other characters and their human emotions are also well drawn, including the murderous and sadistic Hengist who has lost his way because of jealousy and envy or Strang, the huge, bitter, dour and brave smith, who is so afraid of losing his daughter after having lost his wife.Third, there is the historical context. Here again, the author mostly scores high marks, even if he does “confess” to having distorted some events. For instance, it does not seem that Oswald was already in Bernicia and he was not holding Bebbanburg. It seems rather than he came from the west with a large following of Dal Riata warriors in addition to his and his brother’s own retinues of exiles. Together, they defeated Cadwallon, probably catching him by surprise, somewhere near to (or at) Hadrian’s Wall, but this will no doubt be for the next book. Another relative weakness is that the book essentially focuses on the last months of Edwin’s reign and does not show how he became the Bretwalda of Britain.I can only highly recommend this rather superb read and will rate it five stars, despite my little grip above. Finally, and for those wanting to read more about this period, but something non-fictional, I can also warmly recommend “King of the North” by Max Adams, which is very readable, much more than only about Oswald and covers the whole period.

This, which is instalment three of the series, is an exciting book to read, but only if you have read the two previous titles. Otherwise, you will be rather lost, will miss a lot of the background, and will find that many of the characters that appear in this volume are poorly described, partly because the reader will have meet them before. The bottom line here is that this is NOT a standalone book.My second problem with this title is not so much the first person writing in itself. Although some reviewers make no bones in disliking this, I do not really mind, when it works well. The issue here is that he does not always work out well, although I will refrain from giving specific examples in order to avoid spoilers. A related “stylistic” point is the overuse of dialogues where the characters speak in acronyms, most of which are even explained in this volume. I counted up to six per page and could not help finding this rather annoying at times. This could have been mitigated if the author had replicated the little annex he came up for one of the previous titles. Unfortunately, he did not bother to do so.Then there is the story itself. Our hero, his mates and friends, and the task force to which he belongs and which has been fighting another bloc (Sino-Russians, of course) are stranded far away from Earth and the Solar System which is being threatened by ruthless aliens bent on destroying the human race. The North American Commonwealth’s elites are, of course, corrupt, incompetent and interested in saving their own skins rather than fighting the Aliens that have already destroyed the human colonies and bases on Mars and killed millions. I don’t need and do not want to tell the rest: it is painfully obvious. The last feature, with our hero, his girlfriend – well, more than that in fact – and his favourite squadron leader will, of course, join the forces of “good” to defend Earth (and Detroit in particular!) and its downtrodden populations against the terrible aliens just like that…Three stars for what was an exciting but also a shallow read.

The commercial blurb that accompanies this book describes it as “a soundly researched and elegantly written history of Rome's decline and one of its most important empresses.” It also presents Galla Placidia as a “forgotten” Empress, which is, at best, an exaggeration. Once again, the blurb does not do justice to a rather good book, which may be questionable at times, but is also quite original in its approach.First of all, there has been more than half a dozen books on this remarkable daughter of Theodosius over the last half century or so, including so recent ones in English, French and Italian. So, Galla Placidia is hardly a “forgotten” topic and not a very original one either.What is more original, however, is the way that Joyce Salisbury has dealt with her topic. As indicated by the book’s title (Rome’s Christian Empress), she has chosen to show and emphasise her use of the Christian faith to sacralise her power, combined with her genuine piety and her tendency to bargain with God. This slant is certainly the most valuable aspect of the whole book which does indeed give the impression of being soundly researched.Also valuable is the skill with which the author shows Galla Placidia somewhat walking in the footsteps of her father the Emperor Theodosius, and being for Rome what the Empress Pulcheria was for Constantinople. The problem here is that although Theodosius did “credit his victories to God’s blessings”, these were in fact due to his military skills and were hard won. His sons did not have such skills, to put mildly, and neither did Galla Placidia or Pulcheria meaning that all had to rely on strong loyal and successful generals, with the later term tending to become self-contradictory, or to “divide and rule” by playing the generals against each other, which meant ensuring that none of them became strong enough to become threatening.Such a construction was not realistically viable over the long-term, especially at a time when the two halves of the Empire were at bay and under pressure and when military skills would therefore be at a premium. Accordingly, I could not help feeling that while the description of the sources of Galla Placidia were fascinating, the somewhat limited attention given to political and military events, and to the successful campaigns of Aetius in Gaul in particular, were perhaps a weakness of this book.Another well-made point is the Galla Placidia’s “Gothic marriage” and what would then become her “gothic connection”, and her personal guard of Gothic retainers. In this, however, she was not unique. Count Bonifatius also had Gothic Buccellari, while Aetius had Hunnish cavalry through most of the 430s and it is with these that some of his major victories were won.I was however much less convinced by the author’s efforts to show how important and far-reaching her legacy was. Some points, such as her role - and the role of Pulcheria in the Eastern half of the Empire - in promoting the cult of the Virgin Mary are well described. I was however, and unlike the author, not quite convinced to what extent “the blending of cultures” between Roman and Germanic “places Placidia once more into the centre of this story”. While she may have made the most of it, she was, at least initially, a captive of the Goth and how much influence she really wielded over Athaulf during his relatively short reign is subject to interpretation.Some points remain largely uncovered or undicussed. For instance, Placidia is presented as ambitious and very self-conscious of her "right to rule" because she belonged to the House of Theodosius. While this is true to a large extent, the author does not really discuss whether and to what extent  she was able to dominate, and whether she was really trying to exercise power on her own, as the author at times seems to imply, or on behalf of her son Valentinian as an Empress-mother and regent.Anyway, this was a fascinating and rather original perspective on “the Twilight of the (Western) Empire” which is well worth reading even if you remain not totally convinced by the time you have reached the last page. Four strong stars.

I cannot state that I disliked this book. It was easy to read and I rather enjoyed it so I will rate it three stars, despite everything else.“Everything else” essentially means that the book gave me the impression of being written to a formula. For me, the story was totally unoriginal to the extent that I had already read quite a few similar stories about “nasty” aliens with vastly more advanced technology destroying Earth (or simply threatening it, in milder versions), and the survivors becoming some kind of shock troops or mercenary force doing other aliens’ “dirty work” for them.Character description is rather limited, to put it nicely. Our hero is, of course, a relentless though guy and a real “badass”, and some would say. He will, of course, kill the opposition and always be among the survivors, however impossible the odds may be and, of course, they are.The problem with all this is that the story becomes unbelievable, at least at times, and some would say quite frequently! The various aliens are initially shown as terrifying, but the human assault troopers, despite horrific losses, always seem able to cut them to pieces and leave just about no survivors behind them.The last point I will make is about style. This is one of these military science fiction pieces which are written in the first person in order to convey a sense of immediacy and urgency. Again, while unoriginal, it is the kind of ploy that works quite well here. Needless to say perhaps, do not expect any long and beautiful pieces of literature describing sceneries in choice terms! You simply will not find this in what is a rather typical “action-packed” military sci-fi novel.No surprises at all here, as far as I was concerned, meaning neither “bad” nor “good” surprises.

This is the second instalment of the White Hawk, the emblem of the noble Bolton family of Staffordshire, and of their fights on the Lancastrian side during the Wars of the Roses. The pattern is similar to that chosen in the first book, and it works almost as well. All of the “action” (of which there is plenty) is concentrated in a period of no more than a year, from April 1470, and the beginning of the conflict between Edward IV and the Earl of Warwick, to April 1471 and the final victory of the former against the last of the Lancastrians at Tewkesbury.You will very much find the same kind of features as those included in the first volume of the White Hawk, with battles described in a brutally realistic way with all their horror and savagery, and the warriors on both sides subject to fear, rage and terror. You will also see, if you bother to check, that the author has been rather careful when reconstructing both the battles and the general (and rather traitorous) atmosphere within the nobility.Again, there are no “shinning heroes”, with Geoffrey of Malvern, the despicable coward on the side of the Yorkists, and Martin and James, the two surviving Bolton brothers, still fighting their own personal feud against the former, but quite capable .The historical characters are rather well drawn, especially that of King Edward and his brothers the untrustworthy Clarence and the fanatical and ruthless Gloucester (the future Richard III). Those of Margaret of Anjou and of the young Lancastrian Prince of Wales are also very plausible, as is the last Duke of Somerset.There are however a few things for which I had some regrets. Because of the author’s choice, the action here begins some nine years after the first book and at the time when the hero of the first book (Richard Bolton) who the reader left escaping the crushing Lancastrian defeat of Towton, is dead after having been killed in a further battle. The point here is that you will hear little about him and only in passing in this book. The interesting piece, however, is that you see his two brothers struggling to live up to his example and pick up the fight for the Lancastrian cause and their own family and lands that have fallen under the control of their arch-enemy Geoffrey of Malvern.Another little glitch which I do not remember finding in the previous instalment is that author having heads and limbs flying during at least one of the battles. Such “clean-cuts” were rarely achieved on battlefields, regardless of what authors’ may want their readers to believe and how eager they may be to “overdo” the gory bits. This was especially the case during the 15th century, given the tendency to wear more armour. However, injuries caused by poleaxes, maces and various other pole weapons could be just as horrific and lethal but with less bits and pieces flying about.Four strong stars.

I very much had mixed feelings, despite having liked some of the author’s previous books (his Empire series). I cannot claim that I did not like this book. I clearly did, but it was a bit of a “mixed bag” to me, with some strongpoints and great ideas but also a number of problems.Starting with the positive elements, the author has clearly done his homework thoroughly. This shows throughout the novel and particularly in his descriptions of Rome towards the end of the second century AD, but also, even if it less visible perhaps, in the end of the Danubian campaigns and the death of Marcus Aurelius.Another great set of features are the ways in which Simon Turney creates a piece of fiction, inserts it into the known facts, and manages to make his take of the historical events just about plausible. Marcus Aurelius did die towards the end of the campaign, after the last battle, but was not assassinated, regardless of what you find in Gladiator (the film). Another wink from the author is his description of the battlefield (but not the battle): it is – more or less – the same as in the film (the opening scenes of Gladiator, again), with the Marcommani being cornered and making their last stand. The (simply great!) original piece is the aftermath of the battle, with Roman legionaries hunting down the fugitives through the snow.A related feature here is the shift in the cast of characters, with Commodus portrayed as more or less sympathetic, at the beginning of his reign at least, and his sister Lucilla presented the over-arrogant and ambitious villain. Commodus happens to be one of the most maligned Roman Emperors, along with quite a few others, some of whom are mentioned in the (excellent) author’s historical note. He may, however, have started out relatively well and is likely to have become (as many others) increasingly paranoid over time, after a few foiled plots and attempts against his life. Also, the fact that the sources for his reign are generally hostile is unsurprising since they largely originated from the senatorial class who opposed him and which he purged repeatedly, as other Emperors had done before him and would do after him.I nevertheless quickly started to have problems with the way the plot was delivered. As another reviewer has mentioned, Rufinus, our hero, gets repeatedly beaten up, wounded, and saved at the eleventh hour (three or four times across the book) in ways that are barely credible. It is for instance simply beyond belief to have someone who has just been bashed up and tortured jumping on his horse, galloping away to Rome and, of course, saving it all (almost) single handed, regardless of how good his doctor happens to be and how powerful the painkillers that he is administered.I also had quite a bit of a problem with the pace of this book. It starts of well with the bits on the Danube frontier. It then slows down to a crawl with a long section where the hero becomes a private guard but during which not much happens. The rest of the plot, during which the pace picks up again, is very, very predictable.I also had a bit of a problem with the cast of fictional characters, which are not terribly original. Our hero is the son of a disgraced senator who becomes a (Roman) boxing champion after joining the legion. Some might be reminded of Anthony Riches’ Aquila, with the “Two knives” replaced by two fists… Also, this Rufinus develops a soft spot for a slave girl belonging to someone else, which is another not so original feature, except that here the slave girl happens to be a Briton. One interesting character was that of a Sarmatian guard with two huge hunting dogs. However, another shady character – a giant with filed pointed teeth which is portrayed as a cannibal – was simply incredible. Finally, the book also includes a collection of modern expressions inserted into the various dialogues between the characters, and these anachronisms tend to grate...At the end of this book which I nevertheless did enjoy reading, I could not stop myself from having mixed feelings and being a bit disappointed. There were some great ideas underpinning the book and some interesting features, but I was somewhat disappointed by the delivery, hence the rating.

his book’s subtitle better reflects its content (“the rise and fall of English supremacy at arms”) more faithfully than its “Medieval Warfare” title. Even the subtitle, however, does not exactly match the contents. As another reviewer has mentioned, this book is essentially about England’s wars against Scotland and France (the so-called Hundred Years’ War) and her civil wars commonly known as the War of the Roses.As well-shown in the book, the Kings of England learnt some hard lessons during the early wars against Scotland during the first decades of the 14th century. Once these were learnt and once new tactics combining longbow archers and men-at-arms were developed, with the later fighting either on foot or on horse, they were able to overpower the Scottish schiltrons. These tactics were then applied so very successfully against the French and led to Crecy, Poitiers and Azincourt, and a few other less well known victories such as Cravant and Verneuil which were won over combined Franco-Scottish armies.Another major advantage of this book is that it is written in an engaging way, although there are at times some repetitions. The author’s background - a retired Major General – helps in making this read even more interesting in several ways.One is the author’s focus on logistics, and their frequent inadequacy at the time, with the need for most armies of the time, and for English armies campaigning in France in particular, being often obliged to live off the country. Hence, when the smaller English armies just before Crecy, Poitiers or Azincourt, after being hunted and cornered, were finally forced to turn and fight, the troops were not only tired but also hungry and very low on food. A related strongpoint is to show the importance of these logistics on both sides during the siege of Orleans. He also presents a careful analysis of the reasons explaining the failure of the siege. One of the these was certainly the morale boost that the French received from Joan of Arc’s presence, but there were quite a few other factors, most of which, including mistakes made by Lord Talbot, being mentioned.A second focus is the author’s careful descriptions and analyses of the campaigns, tactical deployments and battles of the period. According to him, the English triumphed against the French during the Hundred Years’ War against the odds not because they had better soldiers but because of what he terms “better discipline”, an expression which includes better control of the troops by their commanders and a better use of them. The author does show that the French commanders strived to solve the problem that the use of massive archery combined with hobilars and dismounted men at arms created for them and came up with innovative ways to do so. However, these were often not successful because of poor implementation.A third interesting point is the author’s reasons for the final French victory of the Hundred Years’ War. These, as well as his whole analysis and description of the war during the fifteenth century, have heavily inspired Juliet Barker’s more detailed “Conquest: the English Kingdom of France in the Hundred Years’ War” where many of the same points are also made. Perhaps the most salient point is the increasing difficulties to prosecute the war after the death of Henry V and, even more so, after the death of his brother John Duke of Bedford, both in financing the expeditions to France and in recruiting volunteers. He also shows how and to what extent the French after 1431 reorganised their forces and developed what was the first permanent and professional army of the late Middle Ages and a first class artillery train.Another interesting and well-told section is the author’s take on the War of the Roses. Here, however, I had a bit of a problem. The narrative is well told. However, the author did not really show to what extent these civil wars exhibited English supremacy at war or even its fall, given their very nature. If anything, the slow fall of English medieval supremacy seems to have taken place during the last twenty years of the Wars in France, and the Wars of the Roses seem to have little to do with it.However, while the author tries hard, and largely succeeds, to remain even-handed, at times, biases tend to surface. This is a bit of a pity and it could have been perhaps avoided with more thorough editing. I will mention just four examples (there are a few others).One is a mention of the Black Prince confidently preparing for battle at Poitiers while a few sentences further the author mentions that he attempted to steal a march on the French when trying to get the baggage (and the loot) across a river. He clearly was not at all confident about the outcome of a possible battle which he did his utmost to avoid, and neither was his father ten years earlier at Crecy or Henry V at Azincourt. Given the odds, with the English forces tired, hungry and so heavily outnumbered in all three instances, it is easy to understand why.The second example concerns Talbot who had been made into the “English Achilles” and for which the author clearly has a soft spot. His track record is more mixed than what the author is prepared to concede, and not only because of the disastrous English defeat at Castillon which put an end to the Hundred Years War. His rashness had also cost the English another defeat almost a quarter of a century before at Patay during which their lost most of their very hard to replace field army.A third example is the ruthless decision taken by Henry V to massacre his prisoners at Azincourt. However the author may want to paint this decision as “understandable”, this, even at the time, was somewhat beyond the pale. It was a stain on his reputation and was, of course, exploited and used against him by his enemies.A fourth example is the English defeat at Baugé in 1421. This was entirely due to the recklessness of Henry V’s younger brother, Thomas, Duke of Clarence, who lost his life alongside almost 1500 of his men. While clearly not on the same scale as Azincourt, this was clearly not “only a skirmish”, contrary to the author’s assertion and (obvious) attempt to minimise the disaster.Finally, some of the battle descriptions may be a bit questionable. One the main examples is the battle of Verneuil in 1424 where the Lombard heavy cavalry seems to have done more damage to the English archers that the author mentions, as shown in a recent book on this little-known battle.Four stars for what remains a fascinating read.

This is a good “Men-at-Arms” title, even if it is not the appropriate format for the author’s lofty ambitions. John M.D. Pohl is quite correct in stating that, when studying Late Medieval History, attention shifts to Spain only with the fall of Granada (1492) and the first conquests of the Americas, or in connection with the Hundred Years War during the 1360s. However, such a title simply cannot suffice to explain how “the Catholic Monarchs” (Fernando and Isabella) were able to lay “the foundation for the first world empire”, nor does it have the space to describe the dynastic struggles that took place from 1370 onwards and for a century and a half.It nevertheless tries to do so and some sections, however limited and perhaps even superficial, had, at least for me, the merit of making me want to learn more on the period or events that they were describing. This was particularly the case for the multi-year conquest of Granada, which proved to be a rather tougher nut to crack than what the general reader may assume and which was largely conquered while taking advantage of “Muslim disunity”, as the author puts it so nicely (read “civil war”).Another particularly interesting bit was the growing involvement of Aragon in Southern Italy, its conquest of the Kingdom of Naples, and the role of Gonzalo de Cordoba, sometimes presented as the founder of Spanish Tercio regiments, in Italy. Each of these topics would have deserved a (our several) book of several hundred pages to do it justice.A third little known aspect which this booklet touches on is the development of Spanish sea-power and of that of Castile in particular, during the Late Middle Ages. Unfortunately, it does mention its Aragonese equivalent in the Mediterranean, and how this allowed the Kings of Aragon to maintain their rule over Sicily during the fourteenth century in Sicily and allowed them to expand to Southern Italy during the next century.Also interesting is the very brief summary of the reigns of “the Catholic Monarchs” and their very complementary roles, with Fernando the soldier and Isabella the organiser. There are perhaps several missing elements here. One is how they governed their two kingdoms. Another is their religious policies. To be fair, however, both these aspects go beyond the scope of a Men-at-Arms title but this might show you how much I, at least, was left wanting for more once I had finished.Also to be fair, there are relatively short but good descriptions of weaponry, tactics and campaigns during the late 14th, the 15th and the first decade of the 16th century. These are rather well supported by the plates, which I found good, even if they may not be the “best” that I have ever come across. There is also a useful chronology and a family tree if only because, since the names and events are somewhat compressed into a limited format, you might tend to get confused with kings bearing the same name when reading about a period and royal families that you may not know much about beforehand.Finally, there is a short bibliography. Here, for those wanting to learn more about Spain and who may be willing to read books in English that are not targeted at the so-called “general reader” (i.e. they are more scholarly and much more detailed), I can recommend the two following titles in the History of Spain collection (although there are certainly other good ones!) which cover the same period as this title, but include all aspects:- Spain’s centuries of crisis: 1300-1474, by Teofilo F. Ruiz and- The Spain of the Catholic Monarchs (1474-1520), by John Edwards

As others have mentioned, this is the author’s debut novel and it is a rather remarkable one. The topic – the Wars of the Roses – is hardly original. In fact, it is becoming a rather fashionable one among writers of historical fiction who seem intent on copying each other and coming up with their own take on this period of cruel civil war, full of bloody battles and treachery, and therefore “ideal” for anyone wanting to write an “exciting page-turner”.At first, and after looking at the title of this new series (“Kingmaker”), I thought I knew what to expect: yet another story about a knightly family feud, or perhaps a couple of them, with each family siding either with the Lancastrians or the Yorkists and, of course, taking the opposite side from that chosen by the other family. Do not get me wrong: this would have been perfectly fine for me, although it would hardly have been original. In fact, you get quite a bit of this in this book, with the infamous Lord Riven taking advantage of the civil war to appropriate his neighbours’ lands after killing them. You do get the impression that there might have been quite a few “nobles” during the War of the Roses at all levels who took advantage of the break down in law and order to either settle scores or grab the land of others, especially if the men had been killed in battle.However well-shown, this is however not the book’s best feature. In fact there are at least three other features which are perhaps more remarkable.One is the minute attention to historical details that the author displays. This comes across in his reconstitution of the historical events, with his description of the battle of Towton, often presented as the bloodiest to have taken place in England, being one example, among many others. You can check the various phases of the battle in your favourite reference book on the War of the Roses and you will see to what extent the author has researched his topic. The same goes for a number of other clashes that took place between 149 and 1461, such as the battle of Northampton, where the glamorous Earl of Warwick was at least partly responsible for losing the battle for failing to come to the rescue of his brother’s division sufficiently quickly.Another feature, related to the previous one, is the author’s careful description of some of the historical characters. One is the charismatic and brave giant (Edward Earl of March and future Edward IV), at least at this stage of his life (he 18-19 at the time). Another is his arrogant, gifted but devious and ruthless friend Richard, Earl of Warwick, of the powerful Neville clan (the future “Kingmaker” who has yet to earn his nickname). A third is William Neville, Lord Fauconberg, the old and experienced warrior and the uncle of the Kingmaker. A fourth and a fifth were Lord Montagu, the Kingmaker’s younger brother, and Hastings, another of the prominent Yorkist captains. One limit, perhaps, is that the story is clearly told from the Yorkist side, and in particular from the side of two Thomas and Katherine, respectively escaped monk and nun, so you do get hardly any glimpse at all of the Lancastrian leadership.The second excellent feature of the book is the author’s effort to paint the “everyday life” of his characters as realistically as possible. The battles are brutal and terrible, but depicted without feeling the need to be over-gory (no heads or limbs flying all over the place, as in some other novels!). Nevertheless, the story clearly shows how lethal a poleaxe could be when wielded by someone who knew how to use it. The desperate lack of food, the cold, the sea-storms when the heroes get caught out at sea, are also quite vividly shown. So is the gruesome training while part of the Calais garrison, with endless practising, day after day after day. Deserted villages and countryside, with all the population taking refuge within the nearest castle, are also a feature of the time, especially since both sides tended to “live on the country” and since it was very difficult for any commander to prevent pillaging and foraging, even in “friendly” lands. At times, I even felt that the grim pictures being described where perhaps a bit too much. For instance, would our heroes and three other soldiers really set off to cross the whole country from Lincoln to Wales in the middle of the freezing winter and under the snow? This feature felt a bit overdone and not entirely credible.The third feature which I particularly appreciated was the author’s ability to “tell the story” through dialogues between the characters without this becoming phoney or too obvious. So Thomas the monk, who has spent the largest part of his life in a priory cut off from the rest of the world is, at various points, “briefed” by Walter, the gruff but brave veteran soldier, who essentially tells him what he is fighting for and what has been happening in the world. A feature that I did not like so much was to have just about the whole story told in the present tense. I understand that this is supposed to give a sense of rhythm, perhaps even of urgency, to the story but somehow this grated a bit, although it was not a major issue.All in all, this was a rather superb read and quite a performance for a first novel, even if there were perhaps a few little minor glitches here and there. I would have rated this book 4.75 stars, but since this is not possible, I will go for five stars…

I was a bit surprised by some of the lukewarm reviews of this Osprey Campaign by Christopher Gravett. It is not quite perfect, of course, given its limited size, and perhaps also the fact that it is now a dozen years old. I will however give it the highest ratings because, within the limits of the series, this is a title that is just about “as good as it gets”, with all the main components present, presented, and discussed.To begin with, the introduction includes some necessarily limited but nevertheless interesting considerations on the sources. For once, as the author mentions, they are abundant and varied. Several are from eyewitnesses. There are four chronicles representing the viewpoints of several sides. Finally, there is archaeology, and in particular the skeletons and skulls discovered in one of the mass graves dug after the battle, and which offer grim testimony of its ferocity, and much more besides.All along, the author follows the usual Campaign series format and walks you through, step by step, starting with the origins of the campaign and brief summary of the early phases of the War of the Roses before presenting the opposing commanders and armies.Although succinct by necessity, the author manages to present the main characteristics of both, with, in particular, very interesting portraits of Edward IV, the young, brave and dashing giant war lord, and his glamourous but “more nervous” (to use the author’s apt expression, because his military leadership was not always equal to his political skills or his huge wealth) Richard Neville, Earl of Warwick, the future “Kingmaker”. The presentation of the respective forces also includes a comprehensive discussion of the respective forces, with the numbers favoured by the author – 20000 for the Yorkists and 25000 for the Lancastrians – being the most plausible. Also included in a brief description of troop types and how they were recruited and equipped.The author then moves on to the march to Towton, with a comprehensive description of the first clash – the battle at Ferrybridge. This is where John, Lord Clifford, a dashing, talented and ruthless (as most were) Lancastrian commander, succeeded in holding up for a while the whole Yorkist army and gave it a hard time when it attempted to storm the crossing. Although well described, this episode is where I had my only reservation regarding this title. This is because Clifford’s force is mentioned as totalling 500 but the total casualties come up to some 3000 according to the author. Since Clifford and his force were pursued as they retreated and caught and destroyed before managing to reach the main Lancastrian army, something does not seem to add up. Either the Yorkists suffered massive and disproportionate losses when trying to force the crossing or perhaps the 3000 include both fatalities and wounded. Alternatively, the 500 mentioned for Clifford’s force may only represent his mounted vanguard, with additional men reaching him after he had occupied the bridge and thrown back the Yorkist reconnaissance party.The next stage is a careful and thorough description of the positioning of the two armies. In particular, Christopher Gravett meticulously presents the alternative options which have been argued between historians before explaining the reasons for his own personal preference. He also presents the rather terrible weather conditions under which the battle was fought - cold, with wind and a snowstorm blowing in the face of the Lancastrians – and how the Yorkists, and Lord Falconberg (the Kingmaker’s uncle) in particular, took advantage of it to poor arrows into them and trick them into attacking.Although the battle turned out to be a massive triumph for the Yorkists, these are well shown to have had a hard time. They almost lost as superior Lancastrian numbers began to tell before being essentially saved by the very timely arrival of the fresh troops of the Duke of Suffolk. As in all late medieval battles, once the Lancastrian broke and were pursued by the Yorkists, the slaughter started. Also interesting is the discussion on the respective losses, at least 8000 for the Lancastrians or a third of their force, and some 5000 for the Yorkists, a number which I found high, not entirely convincing and somewhat inconsistent with the previous point made about most fatalities taking place once one side broke and the rout began.The most fascinating (however morbid this may sound!) part for me, however, was the five pages (a bit less) on the grave pits, the detailed analysis of the grievous wounds inflicted to some 28 skulls that have been found in one of these pits, and the types of weapons that could inflict such wounds.Four very strong stars.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film, despite the fact that it concentrates of what seems to be a limited period of the life of Pablo Escobar, a few years before the time where he constituted himself prisoner in 1991 and put an end to his assassination campaign in exchange for a lenient treatment and sentence, and a promise that he would not be extradited to the United States.The story is that of a young Canadian surfer (Josh Hutcherson) established on a beach in Columbia who falls in love with the niece of Pablo Escobar (Benicio Del Toro) without knowing so. He gets increasingly dragged into Escobar’s hyper violent and ruthless universe and is increasingly reluctant to become part of it, hence the film’s title: Paradise Lost.I will, of course, not mention the plot or how it ends but will just mention that this is a dark, rather despairing and hyper violent thriller. More than the violence itself, it is the tension and the almost suffocating atmosphere that comes across which makes this film so worthwhile. Most of this is due to the fantastic performance of Benicio Del Toro who manages to make to make his character into someone that is simply terrifying and utterly ruthless, as the real drug lord probably was.Also well presented in the scenario are a number of features associated with the “reign” of the drug baron.One of these was the carefully cultivated image of a “Latin American Robin Hood” that he created for himself and behind which he tended to hide. It may even have been sincere, given his own modest origins, but it was also very convenient and very useful for him to play the protector and the defender of the poor and destitute. It seems to have largely worked since, at least in his own region, he seems to have been very popular, had tens of thousands of supporters and was even elected in the early 80s as a member of the Columbian House of Representatives.Another feature, linked to some extent to the previous one, was the collusion that existed between him, the local police and even some of the armed forces whose services he had bought after eliminating those (allegedly hundreds) that disagreed.However, because the whole film revolves around the personality of Pablo Escobar and the fantastic performance of Benicio, the main events of his “career”, while mentioned, tend to take a backseat. For instance, the film never shows explicitly to what extent he managed to control the cocaine traffic towards the United States. At one point, it is estimated that 80% of what reached the US was sent by him or his associates.Another limit is that the film contains virtually nothing about his relations with other Colombian drug lords at the beginning of his “career”, and nothing at all about his constant and merciless war of assassinations against his rivals of the Cali cartel. A third weakness is that the effort deployed the Reagan and Clinton administrations to combat drugs, the huge financial and military support provided to the Columbian government and the just as important constant pressure put on it to combat both the left-wing guerrillas and the drug lords are either barely mentioned and entirely omitted.Essentially, the whole film is about the personality of Pablo and Benicio’s very powerful incarnation of the drug lord, with the benevolent mask and pretence slipping at times and then disappearing completely to be replaced by the merciless monster lurking beneath it. This is both the main strength of this superb film, but also perhaps also its main limitation. Four stars, with at least two for Benicio’s performance…

First posted on Amazon.co.uk on 22 February 2015As another reviewer has mentioned a couple of weeks before (on the UK site), this is indeed an excellent book. This is both because of its form - it is easy to read - and because of its contents - it is nevertheless scholarly, provides masses of context and also clearly explains the most interesting point surrounding the battle itself and both its prequels and its sequels. This is why, just like this previous reviewer, I will rate it five stars.Although I will come back shortly to the many reasons underpinning such a high rating, it is also worth mentioning that the book is nevertheless not quite perfect. The main contention of this book, to quote its summary, is that "despite its importance, the battle of Verneuil is largely overlooked in accounts of the Hundred Years War, and this book is the first proper account of the battle and its significance."These statements are not quite accurate. They may have something to do with commercial hype and they need to be qualified. The fact that the battle itself was presented - with some exaggeration - as "the second Agincourt" years before this book' publication is already revealing. Moreover, a look at other books covering the same period, for instance Juliet Barker's "Conquest", to mention just one of them, shows that not all authors have "largely overlooked" this battle.A related point is that this book does not entirely explain why the battle may have been overlooked, assuming, of course, that the battle and its importance have been underestimated. Richard Wadge does provide some elements in response to this, but only some. His contention is that this was because no king was present on the battlefield, unlike Crécy (where both Edward III and Philip VI were present), Poitiers (where John II, his sons and the Black Prince were present) and Agincourt (where Henry V was present and faced a number of Royal Dukes on the French side). At Verneuil, the only "Royal" among the commanders on both sides was John, Duke of Bedford, brother to the recently deceased Henry V, Regent of the English Kingdom of Franc on bahalf of his Young nephew Henry VI, and who was struggling to keep the dream of a united Anglo-French kingdom alive.Another key difference on which, this time, the author does not really elaborate, is that while Verneuil was a crushing English victory after having almost been a disaster, it was hardly as decisive as the other three major battles. Crécy, Poitiers and Agincourt saw trapped, retreating, exhausted and badly outnumbered English armies winning crushing victories against all odds and therefore themselves avoiding utter destruction. Verneuil was somewhat different, although the English forces were certainly outnumbered and had been skilfully manoeuvred onto a battlefield of the Frenchs' choosing. This is something that the author shows rather well when discussing the battle itself.A third difference lies in the aftermath of the respective battles. The consequence of Crécy was to allow the English to settle for a long siege (about a year) of Calais, capture it, and retain it for over two centuries as a permanent base for trading and a permanent threat of invasion against France. The consequences of Poitiers were even more far-reaching largely because of the capture of King John II. The French side, bereft of its King and beset by insurrections, was forced to negotiate the Treaty of Brétigny (signed in 1360) and pay a huge ransom for its King. The consequences of Agincourt is that it essentially allowed Henry V to conquer Normandy through multiple sieges over several years until the Treaty of Troyes which, in 1420, saw him become the heir to the mad King of France.Next to this, the victory of Verneuil in 1424, two years after the death of Henry V, ensured that the "English Kingdom of France" still had a fighting chance to survive the death of its founder, but this is about all it really brought.
