It stopped the French counter-strike into Normandy and it allowed Bedford's captains to continue their efforts into expanding towards the South towards the Loire and the South West into Anjou, in an attempt to make Normandy and Maine secure. Ironically, and with some hindsight perhaps, it allowed the smallish English forces which were becoming ever more difficult to sustain and replace to overstretch themselves even more. Five years later, the dual disasters of the failed siege of Orléans and the destruction of the English field army at Patay happened and put a stop forever to English conquest.Apart from not emphasising this, Richard Wadge does an excellent job in presenting the battle of Verneuil in its context to the extent that this is a book that you can read even if you know next to nothing about the Hundred Years War. You are also treated to a brief history of the conflict, the military aspects of medieval warfare in the early fifteenth century (arms, armour, troop types, organisations, respective tactics and battle plans). As the other reviewer has also noted, one of the key qualities of this book has been the author's ability to provide just enough context and detail to make the story fully understandable but not too much, therefore avoiding the duel risks of either overwhelming or of boring the non-specialist reader. This is certainly one of the main reasons for finding this book so successful. There are many others.One of these is the attention and importance given to the "Auld Alliance" between France and Scotland, and how the French Kings used it (rather skilfully) against the English by providing help to Scotland, but also to raise large forces of though Scottish lance and bow infantry to continue the war in France. Interestingly, the author shows the importance of these Scottich troops at both the battle of Baugé in 1421, which the French won, and at Verneuil, which they lost and where the Scots were cut down almost to a man because they were encircled. He also shows the rather ambivalent attitude of the French King towards them (Charles VII), an attitude which stems at least in part from the jealousy and small mindedness of some of the French nobility.Another fascinating theme which is well dealt with is the organisation of the English forces, their growing professionalism, their cost, the soldiers' motivations - a mixture of serving the King and personal enrichment - but also their relatively small numbers and the growing reluctance of the English in England to contribute to the endless war, either in money or in men, and especially after the death of the charismatic Henry V. A related theme is the contrast between the two sides, with the French Kingdom side still more populated and still richer than the English one, despite its conquests. An implicit conclusion, that the author does not make in his book and which may owe something to hindsight, is that the French could - just about - afford the crushing defeats that they suffered, and they could certainly afford them more than the English could.A further theme is to try to explain how and why the English won these crushing victories against the odds. This is also an extremely valuable piece of the book because it shows that the reasons for the English triumphs against the odds cannot be solely explained by the presence and effective use of the Anglo-Welsh long bowmen, even if this was one of the factors, and one that was already acknowledged at the time. However, English archers were far from invulnerable and far from always efficient. They could be cut to pieces if ambushed, as they were at Baugé, or if caught by cavalry before they could organise an effective defence and deploy, as at Patay. They could also be incapable of stopping fully armoured cavalry, as they were at Verneuil. This leads the author to develop a couple of complementary ideas.In all of the four main battles, and perhaps through the largest part of the Hundred Years' War, the English were often more disciplined and better lead than the French. Each of these differences on its own - discipline and leadership - had at least as much to do with the English victories than the long bow, and probably more. Superior discipline and professionalism certainly did play a role and was important in explaining how the outmatched English forces held, fought ferociously and won against all odds. This is especially true when compared to the heterogeneous and quarrelsome contingents of most French armies in general, and of the arrogant French nobles in particular.The issue of leadership - and military leadership in particular - is perhaps one of the most interesting and most crucial ones. It is dealt with across the whole book, and it is one of the ones that is best dealt with. The English were fortunate enough to have two Kings (Edward III and Henry V) and at least one Royal Prince, if not two (Edward the Black Prince and John, Duke of Bedford) who were either remarkable commanders or were wise enough to act on the advice of their better commanders. The French had none of the former, and only two of the latter (Charles V and Charles VII). At a lower level, that of command of field armies, English command was generally less divided and, with the possible exception of the last two to three decades of the war, leaders either did not tend to quarrel as much as on the French side, or, at least, they made sure that their diverging views did not negatively affect their troops morale and performances in the field.Finally, there is a related point about leadership which is made in a way that I could not help finding simply excellent: there were good and bad commanders on both sides. Accordingly, the French leaders were neither all incompetents and arrogant individuals, nor were they powerless and inefficient. In fact, as this book shows with Verneuil, and others have shown with both Agincourt and Poitiers, the French tried hard to learn from their mistakes, as their battle plans show and, at Verneuil more than in any of the other major battles, they almost got it right. However, "almost" was not enough, and, at Verneuil in particular, all of the main leaders on the French paid the price for this by getting themelves killed.This book is simply a "must read" for anyone interested in the last phase of the Hundred Years' War, in this conflict, and in military history more generally.

This is a relatively old book, or, more accurately, it is two books initially published separately in 1967 and 1970, which can currently be bought together as a single volume. These two volumes tell the rather extraordinary story of “The Normans in the South” (the title of the first book) up to the crowning of Roger II as their first King in 1130, and of “The Kingdom in the Sun” which he founded but which only lasted some 64 years down to 1194 when the last Norman King died and the Kingdom was overrun by the German Emperor.Together, the two books add up to a bit more than 750 pages of text, plus the bibliography and a few other things that bring the grand total close to 800. They can, of course, be read separately, although I think it preferable to read them together and one after the other in order to get the full and continuous story. Both volumes include maps of Southern Italy and Sicily which allow the reader to closely “follow the action.”At first sight, the overall size could seem daunting and could put off a general reader for which these books were written. This, however, would be a pity, because such a first impression would be quite misleading. This is because the two books read almost like historical novels, as opposed to pieces of first-class scholarship. In fact, they are neither one nor the other, but something in between and this is largely what makes them so valuable up to this day.Despite the author’s modesty and claim to be no scholar, they are meticulously researched and backed by a rather impressive bibliography, even if it is no longer up to date. They are not, however, the “usual” pieces of academic scholarship that you might expect because the author strived, and, in my view, fully succeeded, in making them lively. They do not contain the king of rigorous, comprehensive but cold analysis that you might expect to find in pieces of scholarship. Instead, the authors prose and views are, at times, somewhat biased, with the author clearly showing to what extent he found his subject fascinating and presenting the Hautevilles as open-minded and tolerant founders of an outstanding and cosmopolitan Kingdom. They seem to have been that, but they also had darker sides which the author gives, at times, the impression of minimising.The way the story is told and the book is written will however allow you to fully empathise with many of the characters that it contains, whether the willy and ruthless Robert Guiscard, his dashing and just as skilful younger brother Roger or the various Kings, starting with Roger II, the first and the greatest of them. Empathising with his characters is certainly what the author does, to the extent that his prose becomes lyrical or even poetic at times. There is even what seems to be a touch of nostalgia as if the author regretted what he presents as almost a “Golden Age” where Christians, both Catholics and Orthodox, cohabited peacefully with Muslims within the same religiously tolerant and multicultural Kingdom. While the portrait may be somewhat idealised, it is certainly true that no other Kingdom around the Mediterranean exhibited such a level of tolerance. This was the result of a deliberate Hauteville policy which begun with the very founders (Robert and Roger) and which reflected their pragmatism. Norman warriors were few and tolerance was a tool allowing them to gain acceptance and adherence from their subjects.Another characteristic of these books is the author’s deliberate attempt to reflect the intentions, feelings and emotions of his principal characters. This, of course, is rather risky for an academic and a professional historian, which John Julius Norwich claims not to be. However, he offers plausible, if unverifiable, insights about their possible state of mind, and it certainly makes the story telling both more entertaining and much livelier.Then there are the stories of the main characters, starting with the founding brothers. They are so fantastic that they could be seen as implausible pieces of fiction, if they were not historically true. One reviewer mentioned these as being the “real Game of Thrones”. Apart from being incorrect - Game of Thrones is rather inspired from the Hundred Years War and the Wars of the Roses according to its author – R.R. Martin’s fiction does not come even close, in my view, and despite being remarkable in its own way. This, the story of the “other Norman Conquest”, of the foundation of a Kingdom that became very prosper, powerful and dominated the Central Mediterranean, and of its decline and demise, is a true story which is told in a rather breath taking way.I can only recommend you to read it, as its author would have wanted you to. Five stars.

This is the sequel of Swords of Good Men, where the action (and lots of fighting) was mainly concentrated in and around Stanvik, which is besieged and assaulted by one pagan army, and then “liberated” by a second army, that of the “Christian” Battle King Olaf Tryggvasson who forcefully united most of Norway under his iron rule in the last years of the tenth century. You get a couple more glimpses of what it meant to be “Christian” according to Olaf. The conversion and christening of vanquished pagans was more like an exercise in “waterboarding” rather than anything else. You are also treated to Olaf’s very personal and utterly ruthless interpretation on doing unto others what they have done to you and of rendering summary justice, of sorts. This is part of his campaign to “win hearts and minds”. The Norse King made his point in a “crystal clear” way, that is a rather crude, extremely brutal, but very effective way than everyone and anyone can relate to immediately.This volume therefore paints in a little more of the historical context, as King Olaf continues to subdue the various jarls of Norway, and the lone in Tronheim in particular. Meanwhile, the Danish King (Swein Forkbeard, the future conqueror of Anglo-Saxon England), is busy subduing the southern part of Sweden with his own army, and acting just as ruthlessly and brutally by letting his war bands loose on the countryside. Here, instead of overwhelming the reader with grim and gory details, the author suggests the endless pillaging, burning, raping and killing than one of the heroes takes more or less part in, day after day, after having joined one of these bands.Interestingly, however, this volume is much less focused on fights and battles. In fact, there is none of the later. The book could even have been a bit of filler between the previous instalment and the last volume of the trilogy when the climax will supposedly be reached. That it was much more than that, and quite different from the previous book, while being just as griping is to the credit of the author. This had been achieved by focusing more on the main characters of the story, as another reviewer mentioned, but also, and perhaps even more importantly, by showing to what extent the two main heroes - and one of the arch-villains - are being increasingly manipulated by forces far beyond them, justifying the title of the whole series (The Valhalla Saga).The difference with this book is the shift in focus, with the Old Gods coming very much into play, walking the earth among human beings, taking human forms and competing against each other. I will not mention them by name but you will certainly recognise at least three of them, if not more. A related difference with this book is an increase in fantastic features and in suspense, with a number of new characters that the reader comes across not being who they seem to be.So while the first volume was more about the clash of battles, with armies fighting for the New God or the Old Gods, the second one borders more on the fantastic and on the mysterious and not exactly friendly intentions that they seem to have in store for the main human characters. I cannot help wondering what the author will come up with in the next volume. Meanwhile, and despite a rather abrupt ending, this one was just as much a griping read as its predecessor and is therefore also worth a strong four stars.

This is the first instalment of the White Hawk, the emblem of the noble Bolton family of Staffordshire, and of their fights on the Lancastrian side and their survival during what is now called the Wars of the Roses. It only covers some eighteen months of the conflict but includes half a dozen battles, four of which are described vividly, in a brutally realistic way and with a remarkable care in getting all of the historical features, events and details, including armour and weapons, “right”. For instance, the sheer savagery involved in fighting at close quarters and the fearful damage inflicted by medieval weaponry in general, and the poleaxe in particular, is rendered in a rather amazing way.The battle of Towton, which saw the two largest Lancastrian and Yorkist armies of the whole war clash, is particularly well told - which does not imply in any way that the others are not - including the preliminary events that lead to it, and the demise of “Butcher Clifford”, as the Yorkist got to call him, in particular. It was the largest, and perhaps the bloodiest, of the Wars, with plenty of archaeological evidence – the terrible wounds sustained on the skeletons that have been found buried after the battle – to attest to its savagery. Well aware of this, David Pilling has made full and efficient use of it, including the slaughter of the defeated as these turned their backs on their victors, dropped their weapons, sometimes even got rid of their helmets to run away faster and got stabbed and speared while trying to do so.Another very realistic feature is to depict the warriors on both sides as men subject to fear, rage and terror. There are no “shinning heroes” in this book, with even Richard Bolton, the main character of the book, seeking to save his skin by hiding among the dead once the battle is lost and capable of horrific behaviours when seeking revenge. On the other side, the Geoffrey, the younger Malvern, is a rather despicable coward, the exact contrary to his father.The historical characters are also well-developed and accurate including the mad King Henry VI and his headstrong and ambitious Queen, the over-arrogant Duke of York and his giant young son Edward Earl of March (Edward IV) or the Dukes of Somerset (both father and son). The Neville clan are also presented in a historically accurate way, in particular the fifth Earl of Salisbury (Thomas Neville), his brother Lord Falconberg (William Neville) and his son Lord Montagu (John Neville). The only character for which there is a bit of a doubt is that of Richard Neville, Montagu’s brother and the 16th Earl of Warwick (better known as the “Kingmaker”). This is because the author has chosen to show him as brave warrior but an indecisive general, at best, and an incompetent one, at worst, given his defeat at the Second Battle of Saint Albans. Whether he was responsible for turning a setback into a debacle as shown in the book is doubtful (meaning maybe he was). What is certain, however, is that Montagu was the better soldier of the two but Warwick was the better diplomat.The grimness and horror of civil war in general, and this one in particular, is remarkably well shown, with the Bolton and the Malverne families choosing different sides and therefore at each other’s throats (literally and graphically!). In fact, whether longstanding or recent, rivalries between noble family burst out into blood feuds with each murder inciting retaliation and drawing in generations (fathers and sons), relatives, allies and retainers.The blood feud between the Malvernes (and the Huntleys) and the Boltons (father and son and Henry of Sedgley), and their respective allies reflect the reality of the war where neighbours and men who had trained and practised at arms together since childhood turned against each other. These feuds only mirror those opposing the greater lords, for instance the Percy versus Neville feud or the Clifford versus York one, but there were numerous others as well. The feuds involved plain and cold-blooded murders, such as executing prisoners that had surrendered or seeking out specific targets on the battlefield, ganging up against a single man, and “taken him out” without any possibility of honourable surrender and no quarter either asked or given. The deaths of the hero’s father at Blore Heath and of Richard Duke of York at Sandal Castle with the latter falling into what seems to have been a cunning trap are the two main examples of such behaviours.Another well-illustrated feature is to show to what extent these feuds spilled over to the families at large and did not necessarily spare either women or children, to say nothing about family castles and manors. The assault against one of the Huntleys and against the Malvern estate, the kidnapping (and worse) of one of the Boltons and the assault of their own manor are all illustrations of what may have been happening as order broke down and noble families took law into their own hands to settle scores directly.This was a superb read worth four stars and three-quarters (rounded up to five) with my only regret being that the story begins in 1459 only, leaving out the prequels to the War of the Roses and the initial events, including the First Battle of Saint Albans in 1455.

This is a particularly interesting and well-presented book on the Roman navy during the Empire and, more specifically, its role in Roman Britain. I would want to emphasise the latter point. While this is no way a criticism, the topic covered by this book is essentially the Roman navy in Britain, a narrower topic than a history of the Roman navy during the Empire.Having mentioned this at the outset to ensure that confusions are avoided and potential buyers not disappointed, this is a rather excellent book in several respects. It also does include, in the introduction and the next three chapters, an overview of Rome’s naval history up to Actium (31 BC), the end of the Republic, and how the imperial navy was set up and organised by Augustus and how it evolved during the Empire. The chapter on shipbuilding, ship types and naval bases, while succinct, is particularly interesting.The next chapters focus almost entirely on the Roman navy in Britain. The presentation is chronological and easy to follow and to read with each chapter centred on a major event or a major period.Chapter five is therefore about Caesar’s two “invasions” of Britain, with the first attempt being a reconnaissance in force and both attempts resulting in having the Romans “learn the hard way” that sailing across the Channel could be quite risky, especially for those who ignored the tides.Chapter six is about the invasion and conquest. It shows that the navy’s role and importance went well beyond just ferrying the original expeditionary force across and that its ability to supply the invasion force for at least the first months was just as essential to the success of the whole enterprise. Also included in this chapter is the navy’s role in seaborne and combined operations for conquering the rest of the island, up to and including Agricola’s conquest of (most of) Scotland.The next four chapters are about the navy’s missions in Britain once the island was conquered and how these evolved over time, which a shift from offensive to increasingly defensive operations. These are perhaps the most interesting sections of the book, although they are also the most speculative given the limitations of our sources. The author reviews thoroughly the various bases, forts and naval infrastructures (lighthouses, ports, shipyards) built by the Romans along the island’s coasts. He shows rather superbly how these evolved, with his reviews backed up by a considerable amount of research and illustrations including numerous maps, schematics, photos and descriptions of the sites. He also makes full use of the various excavations that have taken place.As another reviewer had also noticed, the last sections, and the bits on the Saxon Shore defences in particular, are a bit weaker than the rest. I was, for instance, expecting the author to review each and every of the forts associated with the so-called “Saxon Shore” in as much detail as he had provided for the previous periods. To be fair however, the book does contain enough references to satisfy those wanting more. Besides, those wanting more, and more “visuals” on the Saxon Shore forts of the late third and (mostly) the fourth century AD can read the excellent Osprey title that is now devoted to them.Finally, the book also contains some very interesting references about the mixed garrisons of at least some of these forts and naval stations which seem to have sheltered a naval squadron of light ships, which were ideal for patrolling the coast and spotting the sea raiders, and a force of cavalry which would, of course, be the best suited for “rapid interventions” as a strike force once the raiders had landed.This book is a great read, even if I would have wished for the very last section on the end of Roman Britain and the demise of its navy to be a bit more developed instead of being limited to an (nevertheless interesting) outline of the main events. This, given the dearth in sources, may however have been asking for too much. Four strong stars.

There are dozens of books on the First Crusade. There are dozens more of various aspects of it, in particular in “the Idea of Crusading” and on who were “the First Crusaders”, just to mention two titles from Jonathan Riley-Smith, or on the military aspects of it (see “Victory in the East” by John France). There are also quite a few biographies on various prominent characters that took part in it (for instance biographies of Raymond Count of Toulouse, Bohemond of Tarento, Robert “Courtheuse”, pope Urbain II, to mention just these). I should probably also mention R. J. Lilie (Byzantium and the Crusader States), Jonathan Philips, Steven Runciman and Peter Frankopan on the Byzantine connection and could go on, and on listing pages and pages of titles……And then, there is this one, which is an excellent overview and introduction to the subject, regardless of whether you happen to agree with the author’s conclusions or not, because it brings most of the elements and titles mentioned above together. It also presents a clear, well-laid out and comprehensive narrative of what happened, and why. This book’s subtitle - ”A New History” - might sound a bit overblown, if only because so much of its contents is NOT new but is made up of bits and pieces drawn and summarised from most of the authors mentioned above (and a number of others, as well).However, this book is not simply a compilation and a skilful and easy to read summary about the First Crusade and the current historical consensus among (western) historians. It also includes elements drawn from the author’s own works and in particular from his own (excellent) thesis on the creation of the Principality of Antioch. The most interesting contribution here is the author’s presentation and his interpretation about what happened during the period following the Crusaders’ victory at Antioch and why it took so long for them to reach Jerusalem. In a nutshell, the leaders were divided and their personal ambitions compromised almost fatally the Crusade.A related feature upon which the author dwells quite a bit, as a few other authors have also done, is the complexity and paradoxes of what it meant to be one of the Crusaders at the time. One of the most interesting features of this book is the attempt to present the medieval mind set, and that of the Frankish warrior class in particular, and show to what extent it differed from ours and was dominated by violence, by the fear of committing unforgivable and by greed and ambition. As the author shows well, this does not at all imply that the Crusaders were not religiously motivated. They very much were, but these motivations and beliefs were quite different and should not be confounded with modern views.Another worthy feature of this book is to show how the “idea of crusading” developed and, in particular, how popes, and Gregory VII and Urbain II in particular, shifted and distorted Christian thought to further elaborate on the Augustinian concept of “Just War”. Also well shown are the ways in which this doctrine was made compatible with the warrior ethos of what would become the ideals of “chivalry” a century or two later.A further excellent point is to show the Byzantine perspective, and how, after hordes of armed pilgrims crossed into his Empire and threatened to go on a rampage, the byzantine Emperor Alexis I deployed his considerable diplomatic skills to harness them and use them as tools to further his own objectives. An additional point shows how and why the relations largely soured between the Crusaders and the Emperor after Antioch was captured by the former against all expectations.There is one weak element, however. The author does not really show that the deteriorating relations between the Emperor and the Crusaders were encouraged by Bohemond”s ambitions. His military genius, upon which Thomas Asbridge insists so much and quite correctly, was matched by his devious and quite unscrupulous diplomatic skills, which the author barely mentions. In all fairness, however, the break with the Emperor took place after August 1099 and the victory at Ascalon, which is where the book stops. Nevertheless, since this is the choice made by the author, his claim that the Crusaders’ conquest had been made secure by this victory is somewhat shaky. Over the next six years, the Fatimids would attempt several times to reconquer Palestine and Baldwin I, starved of soldiers as he initially was, would have fight some more desperate battles to ensure the survival of the Kingdom of Jerusalem.This relative weakness is largely made up by the multiple strongpoints which I have already mentioned and also by the presentation of the somewhat shifty behaviours of Count Raymond of Toulouse. By showing that the latter’s actions were just as much driven by ambition and self-interest as those of Bohemond (and some of the younger leaders, in particular Tancred and Baldwin himself), Thomas Asbridge’s narrative does somewhat help to set the record straight. Bohemond, sometimes presented as “one of the villains” in this story, was certainly driven by personnel ambition. He was not an isolated case, although some of the leaders were clearly not driven by ambition at all. In military terms, however, his contribution to the success of the First Crusade up to and including the capture of Antioch was simply considerable and exceeded that of any of the other leaders by far. This included that of Raymond of Toulouse, whose leadership and political skills are shown by the author as being less than impressive.Five stars for a very good overview and introduction which is well supported by excellent maps and schematics of the main sieges and a comprehensive bibliography for anyone wanting to go further.

This is episode 4 of the Legionary series and the build up towards the disastrous battle of Adrianople which will probably be the topic of the author’s next volume. To me at least (and, it seems, for a number of other reviewers), this one is the best title of the series so far, even if it still has a few “glitches”. Whether, and to what extent a potential reader considers these glitches are important is largely a matter of opinion.As far as I am concerned, they can be important in two respects. One is when certain features are hard to believe and make the story implausible. Another is when an author written a so-called “historical fiction” has distorted what little is known of certain events to fit her/his own purposes. While this may be acceptable to some and it often is a question of degree about how much you are ready to put up with, altering known “historical facts” (as they are sometimes called) also exacerbates the tension between the two terms “historical” and “fiction”. In other words, the more an author will distort the “historical record” to fit his plot and the dramatic effects he wants to introduce, the more he will be producing a piece of fiction rather than a “historical novel”.To me at least, this title is “the best of the lot” largely because the author has “stuck with” the historical context, and has done so more than in some of his other titles (in particular more than in episodes 1 and 3). The sections about the ultimately failed blockade of the Haemus Mountain Passes by the talented Magister Equitum Sebastianus and about the successful defense of the Succi Pass (or Trajan’s Gate) and defeat of a large Gothic warband lead by Farnobius are rather good, even if they do contain bits of fiction and even if some of these might be a bit questionable.Perhaps the main positive feature about both events is the clear way in which the author explains the huge strategic value of both sets of places in the book itself and in his historical note. The Roman strategy of containing the Goths until the Emperors could arrive with their mobile and elite forces and of denying them access to the Southern Thrace plains and their food supplies is also well described. Implementing this strategy seems to have been Sebastianus’ task and it is to this effect that he had been allowed to select up to 300 men from each of the units of the Roman forces in Thrace. These, although they had sustained (and inflicted) heavy losses, were not “in tatters” after the drawn battle of Ad Salices, contrary to what the over-dramatic commercial blurb for the book, and the book itself tend to show. The fighting qualities of the legions themselves (oddly, there is very little mention of auxiliary units) do not seem to have been as uneven as shown in the book, judging by their performances in the field. Rather, and probably more than anything else, the Romans were outnumbered and remained so even why the (limited in both numbers and time) help they received with the troops of Count Richomere.What the historical sources do not really explain is the reason why the blockade of the Passes and the harassing of the Gothic forces beyond it, both of which were initially successful, were lifted and stopped after some 6 to 9 months. There are several possible explanations. Gordon Doherty has chosen the most dramatic one, but perhaps the most plausible one as well – that the fortifications at one of the passes were finally stormed after numerous unsuccessful attempts. Two alternatives could be that Sebastianus withdraw deliberately either when he realized that the positions could no longer be held or when he decided that the time had come to attract the Goths onto the Thracian plain where they could be defeated once and for all, since the Emperor and the Praesental army were approaching. The author’s choice, which is here perfectly compatible with the historical record, is also the most exciting and allows for a Roman version of a “mini-Thermopylae” to take place.A related feature is the storming of the Roman camp and the defeat of the main Roman army because of sheer incompetence. This piece is entirely invented by the author. However, the level of incompetence displayed on the Roman side, and its disastrous consequences, are not implausible. What is harder to believe is the (usual, by the time you have reached episode 4!) “heroic last stand” of our little bunch of heroes who see their partly reconstituted XI Claudia legion cut to pieces but one again manage to get through with barely a few scratches. This, of course, was a bit less plausible.The third interesting feature is the very successful defense of the strategic Trajan Gates with, again, their strategic importance being well presented. Here I had perhaps more of a problem with some of the features because the author has presented them in such an exaggerated way that they become implausible. It is, for instance, highly unlikely that the military road and the fort defending the pass were in the state of decay and disrepair that is shown in the book. Both had been used as recently as the early 360s when Emperor Julian moved the bulk of his army to the East in preparation of his campaign against the Sassanid King of Kings, at a time when the Empire certainly had the financial means to maintain fortifications and strategic roads. It is also quite unlikely that the fort – given its importance - would be defended by a mere century of archers. Finally, it is also quite unlikely that these archers, along with a scratch force of three other centuries – less than 500 all told – could inflict such massive casualties and successfully resist against a force of ten times their size. Also unlikely is their “eleventh hour” relief, with our heroes (still among the survivors, of course) being saved by the cavalry (quite literally).Other features are also worth emphasizing, whether good or not very plausible. Even when exaggerated - with the author seeming to have a propensity for heads flying all other the place and guts spilled just about everywhere – the battle scenes are rather exciting. I also liked the opposing characters of Farnobius the Gothic leader and the old war horse, Count Geridus (who seems to have been invented), however stereotyped they may appear to some. Also interesting are the descriptions and attitudes of the civilian Governors at Tremontium and Sardica. These are also fictitious but nevertheless plausible. A feature that is not at all fictitious is the freeing of the mine slaves by Gothic war bands, with these (and other) slaves joining them and providing valuable intelligence to them. Also well shown is the mixed nature of the so-called “Gothic horde”. The multiple leaders of the Gothic forces, with their associated tensions and rivalries, are also well depicted and seem very plausible, even if the sources (exclusively Roman) do not mention such tensions explicitly. The composition of Farnobius’ force with its associated leaders seems to have been fairly typical, even if the size of his break-away force may not have been large and well beyond that of most other war bands rampaging through Moesia and Northern Thrace.Finally, there are the main characters: Numerius Vitellius Pavo, his beloved Felicia, his lost half-brother, Dexion, Tribune Gallus, and a few others. There are quite a few interesting twists and turns which I will mostly, of course, refrain from mentioning to avoid spoilers. Some, however, are not plausible, in particular the two following.The book starts with our little band of five (the survivors of the very implausible Persian episode) walking on their own from Constantinople to Adrianople (over 150 kilometers) on their own through a part of Thrace ravaged by Gothic raiders and their allies. It is very hard to believe that out five heroes would even set out on their own on foot and would be allowed to do so, to put it mildly.The second implausible feature is the expedition from Trajan’s Gates to Emperor Gratian undertaken by Tribune Gallus and Dexion. First, it is rather hard to believe that both the commanding officer and his second in command would leave together on such an errand. Second, some of the events seem excessive, with perhaps too much crammed into too short of a timeframe. Third, the rather cynical description of young Emperor Gratian was a bit hard to believe when you know that his main concerns were to defend his own threatened frontiers but also to limit the influence of Merobaudes, his chief general who would play a major role in his overthrow a few years later. The point here is that he had much more pressing concerns much closer to home so that the limited and somewhat reluctant help that he provided to his uncle could really have been just about as much as he could afford to provide.Four stars.

“The Macedonian War Machine” is a unique reference on the Macedonian army under Philip II, Alexander III and the Successors down to 281 BC and the battle of Couropedion which saw the victory of Seleukos over Lysimachos, and was shortly followed by the murder of the former. It is not, however, fully comprehensive because the author has chosen to focus on just about everything except campaigns, battles and sieges, which tend to be better known and covered more frequently in other books. What this book tends to be therefore is a review and study of the daily life ofMacedonian armies, their soldiers and their officers over the reference period.In doing this, the author and his book are largely successful. Besides, this is, to my (arguably limited) knowledge, the only book to achieve this in English. In fact, the main merit of this book is to achieve what has been done numerous times for the Roman Army: coming up with a single volume that brings together most, if not all, of the aspects related to the Macedonian soldier and Macedonian armies and therefore providing a very valuable reference and a starting point for anyone wanting to go further and investigate any given specific aspect. A related feature is the sheer amount of work that underpins this compilation. This is reflected by the bibliography with the list of modern works used for the purpose of this book exceeding thirty pages (in relatively small characters!).Having mentioned these features which make this book well worth four stars (and probably a “must have” for Macedonian “fans”), it is however not quite perfect and contains some rather questionable aspects and behaviours.One general comment is that much of the contents and interpretations are speculative. To some extent, this is unavoidable. However, the author’s methods when presenting certain aspects, especially the dress and panoplies, are quite questionable. They include sweeping statements and generalisations based on flimsy and very limited evidence. For instance, a few traces of paint on a couple of shields found in a tomb and described with a level of detail that be almost overwhelming will be used as a basis to state that shields were of a certain colour. A related feature which sometimes borders on the inelegant, immodest and the unpleasant is the author’s tendency to criticise previous authors while very heavily relying upon their work for his own, and presenting his own assumptions (or layers of assumptions) as “solving the problem.Despite these few limitations, this book achieved what seems to have been one of its main objectives: once you have finished it, and although this is often no “easy read”, you will have learnt how much the Romans seem to have borrowed from their Macedonian predecessors. You will also see to what extent “the Macedonian war machine” was a very sophisticated one on multiple levels, on par with the earlier Assyrian and the latter Roman ones. Four strong stars.

Well, my two-cents worth, short and simple:After throwing T-H-I-S 3D movie into yourblu-ray-player and firing-up your surroundsound system, you just HAVE to feel sorryfor people that don't have the means to buya home theater.After a LONG wait since the last "Jurassic"...when all I had was a 200-pound, 35", glasspicture tube TV... it was indescribable HOWentertaining it is to have the dinosaurs rightTHERE in your viewing area.Life doesn't GET any better.** EXCELLENT FAMILY ENTERTAINMENT! **Thank God I retired and haven't beem impactedby this crappy economy... yet! As one wouldguess, they start falling in love. Ah ha! Her---notorious outlaw---HUSBAND shows up looking revenge.THAT is where complications, courage,and the humor comes in.Features Charlize Theron, Liam Neeson, Amanda Seyfried, Giovanni Ribisi, Sarah Silverman and Neil Patrick Harris.

Another [1963] Vincent Price anthology! This one with Hawthorne short stories.The first story, which also stars Sebastian Cabot is the scarier of the three: abody that comes back to life. The two guys go into a tomb, noticing, after thecasket slides aside, that, inside, is still moist and not decayed at all, after thepass of a decade.The second story has a horror-able garden, with plants that kill people.The last one is an abbreviated classic story which---in 1940---also, stared Price...about a legendary house and a cursed family..."HOUSE OF THE SEVEN GABLES"Vincent Price is in all three, with co-stars such as Richard Denning... Mari Blanchard...and Brett Halsey.I remember seeing this when it was new... and I was too. In 1963---52 years ago---I was14, and probably more interested in MONSTERS than girls... three marriages later, Idiscovered that sometimes girls A=R=E monsters!I deducted ONE star only because it's NOT in stereo... but, then again, I didn't originallySEE it in stereo [either].

SOUNDS INTERESTING, to quote---okay, it's cut'n'paste: >>>>>>>Picture this: a full-grown moose comes crashing through the roof of your garage! And not only does it fly - if a bit carelessly - it talks! It seems that Mr Moose was on a test drive with Santa Claus when he lost control of his sleigh. Max appreciates the uninvited visit, even if he stopped believing in Santa ages ago. With his parents recently separated, a new friend is always welcome. In Mr Moose he finds a partner with whom to watch movies, an unusual ally against bullies and, most important of all, someone who understands how much he misses his father. But Max soon finds out that being friends with a moose isn't all that simple. Especially since the grumpy neighbour Mr Panneman is keen on adding moose antlers to his hunting trophies.Actors: Dennis Reinsma, Dana Goldberg, Jelka Van Houten, Arjan Ederveen, Derek de LintStudio: BBC Home Entertainment ; DVD Release Date: December 1, 2015 ; 85 minutes <<<<<<<This ISN'T a review, per-se. NOT being per-fect, I buy, plenty, of per-ky holiday movies----per-mited by my wife----per-haps, I watch MANY per-formances because, per-ogatives, alone, will per-mit me to watch many per-fect movies as possible.Yes! It's true. I have 8 pre-orders on their way. Pre-posperous? I think not!BECAUSE of actor's names,this MIGHT be a bit CHOPPYif it's dubbed, but it IS an English,British Broadcasting Companyproduct. Well, the price was right. The product description describes ONE of the movies illustrated; not the other; and two OTHER movies>>>>>THE COLONY.. (2012, NR, 94 Mins) Laurence Fishburne (The Matrix), Bill Paxton (Aliens).... INCLUDES SPECIAL FEATURES>>>>>SCAVENGERS (2013, 94 Mins) Sean Patrick Flanery (The Boondock Saints), Roark Critchlow (V) and Jeremy London (Party of Five)...>>>>>GATTACA.......... (1997, 112 Mins)... I hope what I get is "COLONY" & "STRANDED"... I'll get back with ya when it arrives in my mailbox!\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\\-------------------------------- UPDATE -------------------------------////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////It is, indeed, the two-----illustrated-----double-disc, double feature.To complete the product description:READ The Product Description about THE COLONY, ignore the other ones, and read this:"STRANDED: When the isolated American military moonbase is bombarded by a rogue meteor storm, Colonel Gerard-Brauchman (CHRISTIAN SLATER), and his small crew, are cut off from Earth with their life-support failing.Before long, the crew discovers the meteors harbor alien spores... and, they're replicating. Now, a vicious, shape-shift-ing predatory life-form is loose inside the crippled facility, picking off victims one-by-one.Locked in a desperate flight for survival, Brauchman and the terrified remaining astronauts have one final mission... keepthe creature from escaping the moon, and finding a new food supply on Earth.(2013, NR, 88 Mins) Christian Slater; Amy Matysio; Michael Therrault; Brendan Fehr INCLUDES SPECIAL FEATURES"I have an older model of a BOSE Lifestyle 5.1 Surround System that has worked GREAT for many, many, many years, andcontinues to this day. One exception: While BOTH of these movies---and their [many] special features---play without flaw,the PREVIEW TRAILERS actual turn MY sound off! Ain't THAT a hoot? I thought my sound system was failing... every OTHERmovie I've seen does NOT demonstrate THAT, particular, peculiarity! My audio system rocks the house, but... Just sayin'...

Virginia “Red” Sullivan (Felicia Day [The Guild; Dollhouse; Supernatural]) leads a werewolf huntering group, safeguarding a pact between humans and werewolves.When a new, rogue, breed of werewolves---led by Gabriel---break that truce between hunters and wolves, "Red" sets out to kill Gabriel (Stephen McHattie [Watchmen])to save mankind. It's up to "Red: [The] Werewolf Hunter" to prevent a full-fledged werewolf takeover... you may NOT recognize the actor's names in this modest-budget production, but, Felicia Day---a fan favorite from SUPERNATUAL---that greets Sam 'n' Dean with her trademark line "What's upba-itches?!"

Rarely does a TV series last ten seasons... unless it's THE SIMPSONS. I certainly do NOT own any Simpson's episodes---other than some of the HALLOWEEN COLLECTIONS. “Supernatural” stays interesting, and new, by adding new, interesting,Dean and Sam foes. Ackles' and Padalecki's charcters keep the show afloat. These handsome guys please the ladies, whilethe monsters and good-looking women demon-chasers keep we male fans awake.Bonus features on the [4-disc] Blu-ray release include commentaries on three episodes;“Supernatural at 2014 Comic-Con”;unaired scenes;gag reel;a look at the staging of the show’s 200th episode; and,background on the mythological influences in Season 10.A digital HD copy is included with this OR the 6 DVDs version...Go with the Blu-rays... just in case we ever buy a 4K, or 8K TV!

Tell ya what. I'll be 67 on my next birthday... I saw this movie when I was ten. It was pretty creepy to a kid---and the BLU-RAY quality---and all those bonus features were pretty interesting... even if Roger Corman forgets what a few female character's roles were.Three stories based on Poe's tales: Morella, The Black Cat and The Case of M. Valdemar are turned into a movie anthology.The segment with Peter Lorre's performance as the drunk is comical...till the macabre climax of course. Vincent Price is in ALL THREEof the tales.* "Morella" - A woman who dies after giving birth to her daughter. She blames her death on her daughter. The, now, dying daughterreturns to reconsile with her father.* "The Black Cat" - A drunken man that no longer cares for his wife nor her cat; his only love is booze. His wife falls for her husband's drinkin' buddy. In the end, the black cat and the ghost of the lovers get their revenge on the boozer.* "The Case of M. Valdemar" - A mesmerizer [Basil Rathbone] has intentions of marrying a dead patient's wife, while he holds the dead man's spirit captive.

The teenagedaughter was replaced with another, younger, thinner, actress in the final film.OBVIOUSLY, these are highly recommended for HALLOWEEN!You'll be bewitched!

Always BEEN hecklers and show-offs interrupting performers' acts. The best comedians have insults prepared for such events. Rickles will be ninety on his next birthday... HE, and his Las Vegas insult-comedy never gets "old".One night Frank Sinatra caught Don's act in Miami, instead of being insulted, Frank helped Rickles become THE Las Vegas headliner he is today.This 1968 Compact Disc was at the The Sahara in Las Vegas, NV. "Billboard Hot 100" chart position: #54.Don hurls bricks---and hockeypucks--- at every color ethnic group, religion, and sexualpersuation. At each show's end, Rickles always thanks the audience for being good sports...once seeing Frank Sinatra---at an earlier performance---Don quiped "Feel at home Frank:punch someone in the mouth!"At 36-minutes,this was too short... but it WAS from a double-sided record album... so, justorder the OTHER Don Rickles CD as well!

This movie is about a business-woman, Julie (Jessalyn Gilsig), who is encouraged---by her boss (Patricia Richardson)---to volunteer asa Girl Scout troop leader [for 90 days]. Julie has a chance to get on the next level of her job to be named “Real Estate Agent of the Year," if she does this. At first she's not interested, but, Julie agrees to meet the troop [The Fireflies].I enjoy Hallmark movies; especially Christmas ones with Bailee Madison.The Fireflies names are----wouldn't you know it!----Daisy (Bailee Madison);Francine 'Frank' Mabel (Claire Corlett);Emma (Maddy Yanko);Mattie (Michelle Creber);and, Paris (Melody B. Choi).I listed the major female stars in this, but cannot remember that actor playing Daisy's dad, but my wife said he was "a hunk".At first Julie only wants those 90 days to be over with. Julie grows to love the girls, and helps them get their merit-badges. When Julie meets the rival Monarchs' leader, (Samantha Ferris) the cookie sale competition... and the fun begins.

I live SOUTH of the Isle of Man [TT Mountain course].  I experience the extreme thrill of riding at speeds approaching 200mph around the legend- ary course.>>>"Using jaw-dropping on-bike footage from state-of-the-art High Definition cameras, you join a series of white-knuckle laps with the best in thebusiness, including John McGuinness, Guy Martin, Bruce Anstey and Sidecar World Champion Tim Reeves."<<<A variety of camera angles let you see the scenery pass by, bikes come within inches of walls, and then there's the crystal-clear sound of the engine... while I ride my DUMB stationary exercise bike.

*******************************************************************************************************************************************************************- - Reminder: Amazon lumps Beta-Max/VHS/LVD/CD/DVD/BD reviews [of the same title] together... and for as long as 20+years! - -*******************************************************************************************************************************************************************The RECENT---(September 2015)--- Blu-Ray disc, is wonderful! It is so clear in the "old dark house" I was actually wondering WHY you couldsee all t-h-a-t detail without any candles and flashlights.Excellent transfer a-n-d Vincent Price, Christoper Lee, Peter Cushing, David Carradine's dad, and Lucille Ball's son, Desi, Junior.How can you go wrong?Kino Lorber bought the rights and had promised to re-master their Blu Ray release.

One-thouasand-four-hundred, and, sixty-five people took the time to say why they loved---or hated---this sixth sequel in the FAST AND FURIOUSFranchise.FURIOUS7, appropriately, has seven people on the discs' cover. As the blurb on the cover mentions this is the final installment... never say "never!",I'm pretty sure that these films will continue as long as the stars have muscles and teeth.I'm happy with my purchase, but remind you that this is NOT reality television: the stunts; logic; and action sequences are waaaaay over the top.The slightly under 2.4-hour movie is sO0o fast-paced it seemed to be a typical 88-minute flick, to me... at the conclusion of the film, I had to usea clothes brush to get the fingernails off my shirt.HIGHLY recommended!

F=O=U=R hours of OUTSTANDING footage!!! (Originally 10-hours, on 5 discs, this, newer, edition [minus the booklet] is on two{thin case}DVDs).This  2 [or 5] DVD disc collection covers the age of Steam trains. Rare C=O=L=O=R footage of Iron Horses before they gave-up-the-ghost toDiesel in the early '50s. Luckilly, we still have the TOURIST RAILROADS throughout The United States!- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -Your choices: FIVE [ten-hours] or TWO [four-hours] editions.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -The TWO[2]- D V D version chapters are:DVD #1:STEAMS OF THE '50s============> 1. Prehistoric Monsters ; 2. Chicago & Northwestern ; 3. Grand Trunk Railroad ; 4. Rock Island Line ;5. Norfolk & Western ; 6. Canadian Nat'l ; 7. Canadian Pacific ; 8. Illinois Central ; 9. Pennsylvania Railroad ; 10. Baltimore & Ohio.STEAM SHORTLINE OF THE SOUTH=> 1. Tourist Steam Railroads ; 2. Installing a New Switch ; 3. Murphy Branch ; 4. Brimstone Railroad ; 5. Dieselisation. . . . . . .DVD #2:COLORADO STEAM=============> 1. The 346; 2. Georgetown Loop; 3. Steam Locomotive Maintenance; 4. 489 Westbound; 5. Durango & Silverton.COLORADO NARROW-GAGE======> 1. Train Chasing ; 2. "S"-Curves ; 3. Pulling In At The Yard.SANTE FE ODYSSEY [part 1]======> 1. hicago to Kansas City ; 2. Going Eastward ; 3. Ormonde ; 4. Conrail Run-through at Gibbs ; 5. La Plata-Great View.BONUS EPISODES:*Wabash RR*Going For Servicing*Romulus Tower*Wabash In Canada*CN Trains*Merger of Railroads-----------------------------2.0 Dolby Digital StereoCOLORRated "G"Covers: Cass and Mower Lines and Canadian Steam. Bonus included, The Best of Steam the 1950's. Disc 2 covers Classic Steam the 1920's - 1960's. Bonus included, The California Zephyr. Disc 3 covers Steam of the 50's (throughout North America) and Steam Shortlines of the South. Bonus included, Wabash R.R. Disc 4. covers Colorado Steam and Colorado Narrow Gage.Bonus included, Santa Fe Odyssey Part 1 d Steam Giants Across America. Bonus included Santa Fe Odyssey Part 2. Plus, a 20 page booklet covering the entire history of the steam engine a great supplement document to have.This is a very enjoyable Collection seeing and hearing these mammoth steam engines powerfully cruising the rails with their wailing whistles sounding their approaches and departures. Buy it!! A great addition to your DVD library!! Enjoy.

This improv-comedy is the only show on television that routinely is wet-yer-pants-funny.Live audiences [better than DEAD ones] occasionally are involved in the skits.I'm glad I can purchase these DVDs by comic-performers that CAN deliver...without a script.I laughed as hard and frequently as I did when the series was "new" --- THIS never gets "old".

This will be SHORT:.I enjoyed the abridged version of this story that I read in----the disc's cover art LOOKS like one----READERS DIGEST. Not so much the theatrical version.It's the story of a preacher that is provided with a free house, but has a second... and third... and fourth job; financial problems; a recent still-birth; personalmedical problems; self-doubt; and a 4-year-old child that survives a burst appendix, and sees Jesus.The deleted scenes, rightfully, cut the scene where all the neighbors pay of the preacher's bills... before making MORE money from a book/film-rights.

Season Three picks up where season two left off: many fingernail slivers on MY chest... and Chetos crumbs!Brilliant writing, throughout EVERY season. Amazing which plot-lines end and begin in just 43-minutes.One of my favorite FIVE programs, still on-the-air.It showcases MANY actors' capabilities. David Giuntoli has become more than a man that, once, just remindedme of [a recent movie] Superman. He's developed into a capable leading man, of mega-movie merit.I could Google it, but he's been in a few other shows as a guest-star. He IS star material! Nick's characterhas as much TEETH as Monroe... BOTH men show their characters' CHARACTER. In fact, there are NO small roles.It is an ensemble cast-of-characters that has charcters you either love or hate. Season two had an unbelebablealliance that actually worked well. Who KNOWS where season five and six will go.Grimm is a giant step FORWARD from the other shows that I like:THE WALKING DEADSUPERNATURALHOMELANDTHE GOOD WITCHAfter you've seen the first episode, season one, you'll be scooped up in the magic, and forget the world's B.S.for 43-minute mini-movies... every single week on the tube, or like I do---here in Germany---BINGE WATCHone of the five discs, a day, Monday through Friday.Help keep the show on the air as long as SOME dumb shows that have been on TV for over twenty years. Buy everyseason available:Grimm: Season 1 [Blu-ray]Grimm: Season 2 [Blu-ray]Grimm: Season 3 [Blu-ray]Grimm: Season 4 [Blu-ray]Grimm: Season FIVE -- Blu-rayA Review From NEAR Grimm's Black Forest,SFC Michael John Groesch-McCluskeyU. S. Navy and U. S. Army, Retired*..*=denotes a 67-year-old man that dresses up like... well, the profile photo IS me; I live near Frankenstein castle,on the Bavarian-Hessen border. When you are the same size as "Frankie", flaunt it!Happy Howl-o-we'en!

Bought this in the deep blue and wore it to a casual wedding with a cute white crochet bolero and white hat. Yes, the foam "cups" (they're actually thin foam pads, attached to the dress at the bottom of the pad only) do shift a bit and weren't my "shape" at all. One even had a "nipple" look to it that wasn't very attractive. Before wearing, I also cut mine out (thanks to the other reviewers who said they had done this successfully!)I was a bit nervous, but it worked perfectly! For anyone else interested, here's how I did it: on the inside fabric layer of the bust (the one that lays against your skin), I carefully cut a 1" or so horizontal (parallel to the waistband) slit right in the middle (between where the breasts sit). That way, if it pulled there wouldn't be a weird gap shape showing through. Plus, I could access both "pads" from the center. (Surely, there are other good places to cut this hole, too). Then, I simply dug around a little until I had the left pad in hand, gently pulled it toward the slit, and then rolled/folded it a bit until it fit through the hole. Then, I took a sharp pair of scissors and cut the little fabric tab that held the pad in place. I cut it in the middle of the pad and the dress, in case I needed to reattach it, or something else, to the dress. Then, I did the same thing with the right side pad. If I was more industrious, I'd sew up the hole (and maybe I will someday), but even without that, it worked perfectly.I was really nervous about messing up the dress, but I'd tried on dozens, even after after buying this one, and this one really did look the best (besides the pad issue). I wore a bra with clear straps (a little tacky and not super comfy, but supportive and not too visible), and a pair of high-waisted Hanes support short things underneath just to smooth everything out for photos and stuff. Got lots of compliments and, despite being "dressed up" (ugh!) and it being almost 90-degrees F and humid, I was EXTREMELY comfortable from start to finish (even went to a lively birthday party after the day-long wedding!). Seriously, wearing this dress is like wearing pajamas! It's just stretchy enough, and it's super soft. I'm considering buying the other colors, too! If you're courageous, you could even wear this dress with a good strapless bra, as the empire waist helps a little with support. I was dancing and moving around a lot, so I'm glad I had the extra security of the clear straps.Also, I'm 5'2" and thankfully, didn't have to hem it (of note, I did buy both my usual size, and one size up, just in case, and the size up was a tad longer). I don't wear heels, but I did wear a pair of white fitflops, which do have a 1" or so platform on the bottom. I danced barefoot and it didn't drag too much, but not sure if I would have been ok walking around in true flats in this dress. If you're my height, just something to consider. I'm very short-waisted, narrow-waisted, wide hips and bust, with longer legs, and it's not easy for me to find dresses that fit right and fall in just the right places. This one was pretty much perfect. Didn't even come up too high under the arms (a common problem I find).The main downside to this dress is that it almost seems like a "disposable" dress (or, at least only wear it once to a nicer function), as the fabric around the bust/under the arms was very "pilled" by the end of the night (albeit a very long night!). I would expect this from knits after extensive wearings/washings, but just one wearing!?!? I'm even a little hesitant to wash it now, as I'm concerned about the construction and the "jewels" around the waist. Fortunately, it wasn't very expensive, and it hit the mark in all the other areas that I am focused on.Overall, I'm very glad I bought it. So far, I've gotten one great day out of it, and plan to wear it to other casual/comfy functions.I rely on reviews to help me make informed buying decisions. I hope this review helped you! :)

I used 4 packs of these for my wedding invitations. I printed directly on them using a large office laser printer, then cut them, and shaped the corners. All handling (printing/cutting/shaping) response was appropriate for the method & the medium.Individual sheets varied in thickness from one to the next - not enough to affect printing, but enough to notice the difference. I liked that aspect, but that's my personal preference. These papers are a bit thicker than typical papers so you cut fewer at once.There are "pieces" of things in the paper (bits of straw and other "elephant treats"), some sheets had very small holes, and the color varied a bit (I believe the packs I got had been stored in the sun, as there was some obvious shelf fading). This was in early 2014 and they were out of stock for a while, so this fading may no longer be an issue. It only bothered me a little.Ink disbursement on them can be somewhat inconsistent, due to the uneven surface and "natural effects" listed above. I was able to use all prints, and I preferred the natural/organic look for my wedding. If you're considering using these papers, I'm guessing you like that look, too.I loved the eco-friendliness, and the unique-ness of the paper. In some places, it has somewhat of a soft "hand feel", kind of like a natural felt.Oh, and people really dug the dung aspect!I rely on reviews to help me make informed product decisions. I hope this review was helpful to you :)

I happened upon this option while looking for more natural "bandages". I was intrigued by the claims to heal eczema and so I bought a bottle. I had an awfully stubborn patch on my palm that wasn't responding well to the other natural remedies I'd tried (that do work well for other things). I began to see improvement within the first two days. Four days later, the patch was almost history. I couldn't believe how well this worked, but I'm thankful!Yes, it smells funky, kind of like bad plastic, and it looks like watery milk, and it's a bit runny when you first spray it, and you have to rinse the nozzle after you use it to keep it clear, but all that is so worth it to me, as none of those are as bothersome as the eczema that I dealt with for months, and was healed in a few days with the Natural Seal.Many thanks to the woman who invented it and put in the market. Thank you for your ingenuity and gusto!I rely on reviews to help me make informed decisions. I hope you also found this review helpful.

The filters are pretty good. They are like silky tea bags of charcoal "sand" that you can put in any bottle of water (especially great for "flexible bottles" like the vapur bottles or possibly hydration packs). They're prolly not going to freshen really funky water (and are certainly not true filters, and definitely not purifiers), but they do help to freshen water that isn't quite totally tasteless. I used them for my trip to India to help the water in my bottle stay extra fresh (I filled it with bottled water, but couldn't wash it as much as I'd like). Could have just been my awesome Vapur bottle, but I went the whole month with the same bottle and didn't have any funky water whatsoever. Good stuff.Bonus, they are individually-wrapped (like tea bags) so you can toss one in your day pack and leave the others back at "base". The packaging claims up to 50 uses. The challenge is finding a spot to hold a wet, in-use one when you are cleaning the bottle in the field. I held mine between my teeth.I rely on reviews to help me make informed buying decisions. I hope this review helped you :)

This may be the most painful review I've ever written...My hubby and I found these bars a year or more ago and have been buying them (this flavor, and others) consistently ever since. They are (have been) much better than all other "better" chocolate bars we've tried (and we've tried most of them - I even toured the only single-origin organic chocolate factory in Italy).I favor this flavor, and my hubby favors their coffee flavored bar. We are very happy they are organic, dark, RA certified, and help support a charity. We like the cool, outdoorsy photos on the bars, as well.Shortly after we started buying them, it seemed like Salazon reduced the amount of caramel inside the bar. All else was the same, so we didn't mind too much. After all, their chocolate, itself, was the smoothest and tastiest we'd found. And, that's before the salt and caramel (YUM.) are added to the mix.Then, with our last purchase, we found that they made the bars SMALLER (from 3 oz to 2.75 oz), but the cost was the same. At first, we were irritated (and sad), but we figured hey, as long as the inside is still the same, then maybe it's a good thing they're "limiting" our intake. Unfortunately, this is not the case. They have also messed up the ratio of caramel to chocolate in the wrong direction. They increased the thickness of the chocolate on the edge and in certain places on the imprint ("continents") and now it seems as if there's less caramel-to-chocolate in the mix. (see photo of NEW bar) This reduced surface area also makes it seem like there's less salt sprinkled on the bar, too. The salt is reportedly "hand sprinkled", so maybe I just got a scant one, but the Sodium reported in the Nutrition Facts has gone from 201mg to 110mg, so maybe they have in fact also reduced the amount of salt by almost half. (I have uploaded the NEW Nutrition Facts label, as the one currently on Amazon is old) This increase in edge thickness also makes the bar much less "melt in your mouth", causing you to have to chew it a bit to achieve the same mouth feel as before. In addition, they have changed the shape (again?) of the mold, and have effectively eliminated the sectioning that used to break into nice, fairly even "pieces". Albeit, the map relief is cool, but honestly, it comes "face down" in the wrapper and I never flip it over to look at the full bar, anyway. Who cares what it looks like - I enjoy this bar for the other senses it appeals to. The molded "pieces" used to be a good size to fit singly in your mouth (possibly even better in their earlier days), but now the "breaks" are bigger, so the smaller bar gives you even less "mouth mileage". And, along with the increased chocolate thickness, makes for a much less pleasant sensation when savoring the flavor/texture.Salazon, in your description, you report that the bar is less calories than others. Well, now it's 17 less calories than it was before, it's SMALLER (by 7 grams / almost 9% smaller) and has half the sodium. Also, there's 1 gram less each of Fat, Sugar, & Fiber. Oh, and the new shape makes it a much less enjoyable indulgence. Humph.I used to have to exert immense self-control to only eat 2 or 3 pieces in a sitting. Now, it seems as if I have to force myself to eat one piece, period.So, thank you Salazon. You have effectively ruined for me an almost perfect chocolate bar. A bar that was in my grocery cart every time the store had it in stock. A bar that we would buy multiples of to ensure we always had at least one on hand. A bar that served as my only chocolate ration in the house. A bar that, even though it was expensive, we'd always make room for in the budget. My tongue may be broken-hearted, but my hips and wallet can rejoice. oh, yay.

This may be the most painful review I've ever written...My hubby and I found these bars a year or more ago and have been buying them (this flavor, and others) consistently ever since. They are (have been) much better than all other "better" chocolate bars we've tried (and we've tried most of them - I even toured the only single-origin organic chocolate factory in Italy).I favor this flavor, and my hubby favors their coffee flavored bar. We are very happy they are organic, dark, RA certified, and help support a charity. We like the cool, outdoorsy photos on the bars, as well.Shortly after we started buying them, it seemed like Salazon reduced the amount of caramel inside the bar. All else was the same, so we didn't mind too much. After all, their chocolate, itself, was the smoothest and tastiest we'd found. And, that's before the salt and caramel (YUM.) are added to the mix.Then, with our last purchase, we found that they made the bars SMALLER (from 3 oz to 2.75 oz), but the cost was the same. At first, we were irritated (and sad), but we figured hey, as long as the inside is still the same, then maybe it's a good thing they're "limiting" our intake. Unfortunately, this is not the case. They have also messed up the ratio of caramel to chocolate in the wrong direction. They increased the thickness of the chocolate on the edge and in certain places on the imprint ("continents") and now it seems as if there's less caramel-to-chocolate in the mix. (see photo of NEW bar) This reduced surface area also makes it seem like there's less salt sprinkled on the bar, too. The salt is reportedly "hand sprinkled", so maybe I just got a scant one, but the Sodium reported in the Nutrition Facts has gone from 201mg to 110mg, so maybe they have in fact also reduced the amount of salt by almost half. (I have uploaded the NEW Nutrition Facts label, as the one currently on Amazon is old) This increase in edge thickness also makes the bar much less "melt in your mouth", causing you to have to chew it a bit to achieve the same mouth feel as before. In addition, they have changed the shape (again?) of the mold, and have effectively eliminated the sectioning that used to break into nice, fairly even "pieces". Albeit, the map relief is cool, but honestly, it comes "face down" in the wrapper and I never flip it over to look at the full bar, anyway. Who cares what it looks like - I enjoy this bar for the other senses it appeals to. The molded "pieces" used to be a good size to fit singly in your mouth (possibly even better in their earlier days), but now the "breaks" are bigger, so the smaller bar gives you even less "mouth mileage". And, along with the increased chocolate thickness, makes for a much less pleasant sensation when savoring the flavor/texture.Salazon, in your description, you report that the bar is less calories than others. Well, now it's 17 less calories than it was before, it's SMALLER (by 7 grams / almost 9% smaller) and has half the sodium. Also, there's 1 gram less each of Fat, Sugar, & Fiber. Oh, and the new shape makes it a much less enjoyable indulgence. Humph.I used to have to exert immense self-control to only eat 2 or 3 pieces in a sitting. Now, it seems as if I have to force myself to eat one piece, period.So, thank you Salazon. You have effectively ruined for me an almost perfect chocolate bar. A bar that was in my grocery cart every time the store had it in stock. A bar that we would buy multiples of to ensure we always had at least one on hand. A bar that served as my only chocolate ration in the house. A bar that, even though it was expensive, we'd always make room for in the budget. My tongue may be broken-hearted, but my hips and wallet can rejoice. oh, yay.

I found this very interesting and well-done. While I already had a background in some of the topics highlighted, I still learned quite a bit, and would benefit from a second-watching. It was an in-depth introduction of Ayurveda and focused on several specific treatments, as well as the history and potential future of this "long life" form of well-being. If you're at all interested in alternative (non-western/pharmaceutical) or complimentary "medicine", I recommend watching this video.

Fits either one of two of my HP Laptops perfectly, plus, I can stash a mouse or Ethernet cable, etc in the pocket. I mostly use it inside another bag, but purposely bought one with a handle, as I do occasionally carry it on its own (sometimes, as a laptop case, sometimes, as a notebook case.)I love the short-side loading, as my computer bag is "vertical" and my laptop slides right into this sleeve, already inside the bag. The zipper works great - no snags and is still in great condition.The inner surface of this sleeve is soft and fleecy and has done a great job (since 2011) of helping to keep my laptops looking new.The stream pattern is nice, in that it gives a little bit of style, without sacrificing "professionalism".Highly recommended!!I rely on reviews to help me make informed buying decisions, I hope this review was helpful to you! :)

I've tried several different styles/shapes/sizes/forms/raw materials of alternative disposable plates and these are my absolute favorite. We've used them in hotel rooms, and we even used them for our 150-person wedding reception. They were probably a bit more sturdy than we needed, as we just had small bites but I liked their style. Some guests even took theirs home!When considering size, if they are truly 9 inches, they might compare more to a 7 or 8" plate, as the shape kind of "bowls" (which is really great for saucy things, or for food that tends to roll around). They have been the perfect size for any meal I've used them for (not too big, not too small, just the right balance of curve and flat center). They are very sturdy, and hold up to water/moisture/sauce quite well (we even rinse them off and re-use them a few times, when travelling). They are so sturdy, in fact, that I often feel bad throwing them away after just one fairly dry use. They are compostable, however, so that's a bonus (we composted all of the ones used at our wedding - along with the cups, napkins, and utensils). If you microwave them, they won't get super hot, they won't deteriorate right away, and they probably won't leach nasty chemicals into your food.Note that the color/pattern is VERY "organic" in that EACH one is different, and sometimes, VERY different (many have dark brown veins/splotches/patches). Like a snowflake, no two are the same. The photo they're showing now is one of the more plain ones I've seen. So, if you're looking for an even-colored or pale-colored plate, you'd have to pick-and-choose from a batch to get what you want. I like the various colors (I dig the "natural" look AND it makes it easier to recognize "your" plate!)The "feel" of these plates is also "organic". Some have very noticeable, thin ridges (further security for free-wheelin' food), some are a little rougher on the back (where your hand or table goes), but never any splinters or anything like that. Some bamboo plates we've gotten had those. From what I can tell, these plates are made from one piece of palm-thing, so you don't have to worry about adhesives or the plate falling apart/leaking. Also, I have a friend with an aversion to cardboard, even paper plates, and she was fine with these.They stack securely, but not tightly, so they will take up much more space than a stack of another, more uniformly-shaped plate. This does make them easier to grab, as a single. They do not stick together. They are also fairly thick in material, maybe 1-2mm - but again, this varies, as the raw material is "organic" (in the "natural shape" sense; but I doubt there's pesticides, either). They're not as eco-friendly to transport - as mine came in a huge box (seriously, be prepared for like a 2-3 foot cube for 400 plates), and the plates were wrapped in plastic, inside the box. Maybe 25 plates per wrap? There wasn't much space left over at all in the box, as the plates took up most of it. They fared well in transport, no broken plates or anything like that.The company claims these are harvested from fallen palm leaves and my hubby and I questioned if this is really true. Well, soon after, we happened to visit a Palm Grove Rainforest and yes, thousands of these palm-leaf things had naturally fallen to the ground and covered it in a thick carpet. Of course, we also questioned the harm that picking them up in large quantities would do (aren't they needed, in order to decompose, and help nourish the new plants...etc. but, surely, they're much more environmentally-friendly than anything that has to be "made" - these are simply cut and "formed").The company also makes smaller ones and ones in different shapes - we used a few smaller ones for some decorations, and we used the heart ones for dessert - they were perfect for a few mini-cupcakes and some cookies. YUM!Yes, these are considerably more expensive than your typical paper plate, but they are also considerably much cooler and considerably better for the environment. After our wedding, people were talking about the cool plates as much as they raved about the food!HIGHLY Recommended!I rely on reviews to help me make informed buying decisions. I hope this review was helpful to you :)

...and inspired me to write a corny headline for my review!
