The biggest advantage of using projectors is not only are they uniquely portable, sort of like carrying an additional laptop along in size, but they are capable of displaying whatever size picture, within limitations that you want. It not only provides a huge viewing experience, but it also provides a very real looking image; one that you relax at looking at. If I had to describe it in a word it would be warm. It also is so large it is like having the person sitting in the room.I really got excited about the idea of having a projector on the ceiling, or on a table, and have a drop down screen, one that is controlled by a remote control. The 110” screen which is one of the top sellers goes for not very much money, and you can remotely have it drop down. It would eliminate the need for having either a big huge black screen in the room, or a large piece of furniture to conceal it. However I think these projectors make a very nice add-on to the regular TV’s rather than an absolute replacement for them. There are times you don’t want to sit in the large theater room, but rather want to snuggle up to a smaller screen.  Even the Epson VS value series, or their EX models make for a rewarding show time experience. This 2040 is a league above the VGA’s.With twin HDMI ports I was able to connect my computers HDMI port as well as insert an Amazon Fire TV stick. By clicking on the source button you can toggle between those sources. The connections on the back include both a VGA PC connection, the two HDMI ports I mentioned, as well as a USB. Finally there is also the three part composite connections of yellow video, and two audio in red and white that accepts the old RCA connectors. So you essentially have the bases covered. It does not have an old S-Video input.I just got this and the brightness level is very pleasing. It is as fully bright as you would like to have it. Setup is a breeze. I just took it out of the box, plugged in the power cord, attached the HDMI cable from my PC, inserted the Fire TV stick and turned it on. Everything was intuitive and easy to do. You can go into the menu and customize the settings to fine tune it to your preferences.I am new to 3D and this projector is a 3D and all you need to enjoy that are a set of 3D glasses, and a 3D movie. I just ordered the Samsung SSG-5150GB 3D Active Glasses which are RF (radio frequency) glasses that have two batteries sent with them; each battery provides 70 hours of viewing experience. Epson sells their own version of 3D glasses and they are excellent quality from the reviews. I wanted to get my feet wet with the Samsung’s reported by other posters to work well also. 3D has come a long way, and I can't wait to experience that bird flying toward you so realistically that someone’s wife ducked on the couch as it flew by. This whole movie theater, 3D huge viewing experience is very exciting; something I have been dreaming of for a long time. The picture is so alive that you can discern subtle qualities of the making of the film. For example we all know what depth of field is like which of the actors in a given scene is the one that the focus is concentrated on, and which is at a different depth, and may be a tiny bit out of depth creating a softer haze. After watching the projection screen when I go back to a regular LCD/LED TV I now am aware of these things so I look for them, but they are not as apparent.At full brightness you can hear the fan running but even the built in speaker drowns that out. It is a small sacrifice next to having the people sitting in the movie theater behind you sneezing and talking. Now you get to see the full movie experience in the convenience of your own home. So far I have been shining this on a wall that is not even white, but rather a medium pale blue and due to the high brightness you wouldn't even know it. I plan on buying the current most popular selling Homegear 120" HD Motorized 16:9 Projector Screen W/ Remote Control which is the second most popular seller currently going for $120, and the number one seller is a manual pull down type for half the price. So this whole projection fever can be purchased for a nominal amount of money these days, and the quality of the picture is outstanding for this kind of money. So having a home theater experience is no longer the domain of the super wealthy. Exciting, very, very exciting. Invite your friends over for the ball game, or have a quiet date night with just the two of you, or enjoy a screen big enough the whole family can get into. .

I have two areas that could really use these; a woodworking shop, and a garage. The box this case came in measures 24 x 16 x 17 inches. The rolls themselves measure 8 x 8 inches. Measurements are all inches rounded. In comparison I just purchased a 12 pack of standard paper towels and that package measures 24 x 11 x 17". So the 12 pack is the same measurement with one exception of the difference of 5". So storage difference is nominal comparing a case of these to a regular store bought pack of 12 towels.These towels have a tough enough consistency to them to do the job without falling apart, yet are more easily tear-able in order to accommodate the widest range of holders. However they are tough enough to hold up to someone pulling one from the dispenser without it falling apart.There is a challenge finding the right dispenser. What is super important is that most of them are proprietary. So be sure and double check in inside diameter of the hole. If the paper and the dispenser are different, for example if the paper has an opening a 1.5" like this Scott Hard Roll 01040 and the dispenser is set for 1.75" like some of the popular ones that means this roll won't fit. I finally settled on the Sanitouch Hard Roll Paper Towel Dispenser (09990), Hands-Free Pull Dispensing, Smoke / Black by Kimberly-Clark Professional. I'm big on prevention of spreading germs during the cold and flu season and that model has the pull the towel feature and automatically cuts off at 12". It does not however have an adjustable setting for how much towel dispenses. Also it does not require batteries.Studies were conducted and the result was that when you dispense less than 12 inches worth of towel, people commonly took more than one towel. So the preset model such as the 09990 is very desirable, and no D batteries to replace. You will notice that it is a challenge matching up dispensers and towels since the inner core size is often not posted. Maybe you will do better with that then I have.With a cost of $6.29 per roll which is the current cost of the 800 foot roll that means it only costs .0078 cents per foot, or rounded 8 tenths of one cent. When you are buying in bulk like this it comes in handy, however I don't expect people to place an industrial/commercial dispenser in their kitchen. As I mentioned this is great for the garage or workshop, and of course its most common use that of a public, or business rest room. Just be sure to have a large toilet paper dispenser in the stalls at the same time so people don't resort to flushing hand towels possibly causing a sewer back up problem.For me after purchasing the dispenser I am looking at it that I have a decade long supply of towels not taking up more space than a standard 12 pack or regular towels and at a good sized cost savings. The main advantage is always have a towel at the ready without having to constantly purchase a new supply. Great for commercial use, and an interesting alternative for use right at home.

What a sweetheart deal this is. Get one for your home too. You can use a 12 volt converter. Use it in your shop, or garage, shed or anyplace you want sound. I have an inexpensive solar charger that can connect to a 12 volt battery in my shed if I want to use it in there. This one is going in the garage and will draw current from my winter storage of a 12 volt battery for the boat. The amp tucks neatly away and the control panel is connected with a wire that has a 3 prong 3.5mm plug on it. At first I was concerned by looking at the picture just how I was going to manage mounting the included control panel. I was pleasantly surprised that the control panel only measures 1  inches by 3 ¾”. The amp itself only measures 7” by 3 ¾” by 1 ¾”. The fact that it is powered by 12 volts means you can use it in any type of vehicle including cars, campers, boats, RV’s etc. etc. etc.Included is a handlebar mount also. In order to install it to the handlebar mount you need to remove the control panel from the pre-installed bezel, making it even smaller, and then attach the handlebar mount with attaching screws. The handlebar mount is really a standard automotive pipe clamp secured to a stainless looking bracket specially designed to mount to the back of the control unit.The control unit has changed from the one you see in the pictures with the blue letters. If they update it to the new one they are using the letters are white. They both have a black background. The new one with white letters is better. The configuration makes sense. For one the lower left corner has the combo of a right arrow for play plus the pause button symbol on the same one. So push to play, push to pause. There is no such button on the blue one. I guess they originally felt like that control can be handled at the source of what you are using to play with. Then the center two positions are different as well. The upper one is a single arrow pointing straight up meaning increase the volume, and the one below it is an arrow pointing down, and that decreases the volume. The third button/panels on the right are the upper double right arrows with an upright line following are for next track / fast forward, and the one below it with the arrows in the opposite direction are previous track / fast rewind. Now it makes sense.There isn’t anything that seems flimsy in the way that it is built. I mean it is not cast iron of course, but the finish will last a long time and the buttons on the control panel feel substantial when you press them. The large paddles are a never miss configuration, and the click sound is not sloppy at all.This is a 4 channel amp with a MAX continuous output of 500 W when all channels are driven. The PEAK power rating is 125W per channel. The rating is based on 4 ohms. It is a class A/B amp with an astounding frequency response of 20-25 kHz. The RMS power output is 38 x 4. If you are looking for more power the Rockford Fosgate TM400X4AD has 400 Watts PEAK power output x 4 and is bridgeable to 200 x 2, the Boss MC900B is not bridgeable at all. Many comments have indicated that if you bridge this amp you will turn it into a paper weight. The Rockford Fosgate provides 4 times the power at 5 times the price. So this is a very nice unit for automotive, or boat applications. Myself personally I like to bring along a portable player in my boat so I don’t run the risk of wearing the battery down. Larger cruisers have dual batteries with an option to keep them connected, or not. That way you are sure to have one good one when it comes time to start up the motors.I know from my Dynaco amp days I learned that any time you short the positive and ground leads coming out of an amp you fry components inside. Fortunately this Boss amp has 3-way protection including thermal, overload, and speaker short protection. A friend of mine had an expensive Krell audiophile grade amp and all it took was one glance between the output wires and it needed repair.There are no published THD as in distortion ratings anywhere including in the owner’s manual, but this amp puts out an excellent quality signal: especially at this price point. I haven’t heard any bad remarks about Boss amp quality, and that is verified because the MC900B comes with a 3 year parts warranty, and a 3 year labor warranty. So Boss stands behind their product. I wish I could find something that I don’t like about it but I can’t. For its intended purpose it is a very nice unit. The real kicker is the Bluetooth function. You can walk in the room with your cell phone, hit the power on button and be automatically connected up to 30 feet away. All your favorite tunes, or your Pandora with your custom selections playing. Way cool stuff.

I have the 5 and this 3 Tier. I must say that for only less than a 20% difference in price at the current pricing you are getting with the 5 tier a larger stand with heavy duty thick rope twine wrapping the upright posts which are an ideal scratching post. Both of these are assembled using 3/8" threaded rods and bolt inserts. You could easily consider that overkill.This 3 Tier and why I wanted both is covered completely with a very soft furry material. It is so soft and comfortable that it's as much a cat nap machine as anything else. My cats have been tearing up my natural black walnut coffee table with bark sides. They love that bark. So that is why I wanted the 5 tier the most. You could get both of these and put one on different floors. I see that there is the rare review stating that this is not built strongly enough. I researched this and found the most common word to describe this stand is the word sturdy. This 3 tier tree stand is garnering 5 star reviews from over 70% of those reviewing it.I think part of the problem experienced by the few pertaining to assembly is that the directions are a simply illustration type. So detailed explanations about how to assemble are few. If you are not handy or mechanically inclined you may want to have someone assist you. Hey sometimes it can be rough enough assembling something with intricate thorough instructions let alone something with such scant directions.The fabric is made from a very soft and plush material that is waterproof and vacuums very easily. So the cat hair challenge doesn't present much of a problem. This company, Iris makes a lot of cat stands so this is not someone new to the industry cutting their eye teeth. These are seasoned designers and builders. Highly recommended.

The suggested use from the manufacturer is a once a week treatment for a total of 7 treatments over a period of six weeks. There are also 3 settings you can use in order to try it out. You have a low, medium, and high setting. This is called a permanent hair “reduction” system because although it is proven to remove 95% of hair using it as directed, it is not an all-out annihilation of hair follicles.Consider the alternatives. You may have some hair that starts out very fine at the tip. If you shave it, the ensuing hair growth looks like a thick stubble which is unsightly to say the least. You can pull it out with a tweezer but for the most part it will come back. And then there is hot waxing which can be messy and painful. Then there are depilatory creams which if used improperly such as leaving it on the skin too long can burn your skin. Another option is an epilator which is an electrical device used to remove hair by mechanically grasping multiple hairs simultaneously and pulling them out. Some people wax first and then use an epilator to remove regrowth. All of these options are hardly ideal, and most of them are painful. Laser removal if conducted at a doctor’s office is ideal because they can oversee the treatment in order to minimize risk, make adjustments, and manage side effects. Unfortunately it costs between $100 to 500 dollars per treatment and you will need 4 to 6 treatments or more. Even with laser removal the FDA approves of the procedure for permanent hair reduction not removal, so regrowth or stragglers are common. Electrolysis uses a tiny needle to deliver a shortwave radio frequency. The FDA considers that a permanent hair removal method but requires 4 to 6 or more treatments at approximately 100 dollars per session. Yes it is painful so a topical anesthesia is suggested. There is a risk of infection and scarring.So comparing this to the Precise touch which glides over your skin, adding just a touch of warmth, but due to its combination of light and radio waves can really fry the hair follicle at its source. With a 95% success rate that means only 1 hair out of 20 will survive. The ones that do grow back are very fine making them nearly invisible.  If you need to do supplemental treatments the device is there. It truly is painless. All you feel is a little warmth. If you are using the device for a while of course heat accumulates to it is best to pause after a certain amount of use, and then resume again.Some different hair removal systems work better with certain hair and skin types but the Precise touch works with a wide range of types in both hair color and skin. A word of caution. As is stated on the Amazon page under the directions photo it is not for men to use on their jaw, face, chin or neck etc. Using the Precise touch in areas like that can cause skin injury. It should also not be used by anyone under the age of 18. Please read the contraindications for other exceptions to its use which is available here on the Amazon page in the photo. You can click on it and use the zoom tool to hone in on the different sections. The advantage being that with three different settings, one low, medium, and high you can try it out at the low setting, and slowly work up to the high. Illuminage beauty is a joint venture between Unilever and Syneron Medical.It is suggested that you shave the area first before using the Precise touch. No need to burn hairs above the skin. I am not a hair removal expert, nor am I a physician or medical professional. Consult your physician for expert advice. I just thought that I would do a lot of leg work in order to conveniently provide helpful information. It is a woman’s product, especially not recommended for a man’s face. Hope this helps.

I am quickly becoming a fan of Amazon Basics. This wall mount LCD monitor stand comes in a no-frills box at about a 30 or 40% savings over a comparable product with retail boxing. This is a well-built commercial grade appliance. I am in the planning stages, and have already bought plans for building a CNC machine which is an industrial grade machine with a 48” bed and requires a computer with a monitor in order to run it. So this will be a nice solution to suspending a monitor at different angles in order to optimize the viewing.These days a lot of complaints are found at sparse and iffy instruction manual for installation. That is exactly the opposite of what you will find here. Included is an instruction manual that is built every bit as well as the stand. At first you will be put off at how thick it is until you discover that it is an all in one in 7 different languages which include English, Francais, Deutsch, Italiano, Espanol, and two different Chinese dialects. These instructions are some of the best hand holding, complete and thorough including diagrams and complete worded instructions every step of the way.The beauty of having this LCD monitor arm is twofold. One is the fact that it extends out from the wall up to 25.7 inches, and then also will collapse to only 3.9 inches from the wall. So you can super extend your monitors reach, and neatly tuck it against the wall when you are not using it. You can mount this to a wall stud or a concrete wall. Notice I didn’t say cinderblock wall or even the motor in between cinderblocks. It must be into solid concrete, or directly into a wood stud.The mounting plate is 3/8” thick metal, and the arm is way thicker than that in different areas. It has some cast aluminum parts to it weighs only 7.71 lbs. GW. This is specifically the wall mount model. If you need one to attach to your desk top those are a different unit and are available as well. With this wall mount unit your monitor can swivel horizontally, or vertically for a complete 360 degree view. It also has a locking nut so you can fix it in a specific view and keep it that way. You can adjust the monitor viewing angle, height, tilt, and orientation such as portrait, or landscape.The matte black what appears to be a powder coated finish is very professional looking. To me the number one advantage to having this is how much it frees up your desk space. I have a dual monitor setup on my desk, and with its large base it occupies way more real estate than I would like it to. Usually desk top space winds up at a premium. This is something I would recommend if you are planning to stay in a certain location for an extended period of time because you need to drill holes in your wall in order to mount it. If by any chance your desk is going to move to another location, a desktop model would be more suitable. All in all, highly recommended.

This thing is sturdily built. I was a licensed state inspection mechanic. I know what quality construction is. This 5-tier cat tree is assembled not using 1/4" bolts which would be more than enough, it is assembled using 3/8" bolts which to some degree is overkill. I must admit that I was taken aback and hesitated to order it after reading a single review to the contrary. So then I read all of the other reviews, and went out on the web and researched even more reviews and the number one word that is used is sturdy.When the box first arrived I was surprised at how heavy it is. The shipping weight is on the label, and when it says 50 pounds they mean it. This 5 tier model is the one to get. The 3 tier is nice and if you are looking for an add-on that one is good also, but for the difference in price the 5 =tier gives you scratching poles with heavy duty rope that the cats love to get into. My cats for years had a hay day clawing at the natural bark on my highly finished coffee table. This really tightly wrapped, heavy duty rope will provide long term use. They naturally will be clawing at it because the whole nature of the unit is for climbing.The box measures 21.5 x 22 x 14 inches. The directions are abbreviated in terms of the way most directions are provided these days; there is a simply illustration showing you which piece goes where with a step by step, 1, 2, 3, diagram to follow. If you are not mechanically inclined in the least, as in mechanically challenged then have someone who is breeze right through the construction. Complete assembly can be accomplished in as little as 15 minutes. The cats are loving it, and I am amused because they can keep themselves busy, at least part of the time instead of walking on my keyboard. Nice unit. Well built. Highly recommended.

Seat of the pants were sewn in a little more than expected. Everything else fit great. I tried an X Large but they were way too loose, and not much relief in the rear. Got the large, and they fit fine other than that.

When the box first arrived I was surprised at just how compact the unit was and it only weighs 11.6 pounds. Even though this is a professional grade commercial canister vac, the Hushtone HCC-08 is compact enough that you wouldn’t think twice about tossing it in your back seat. With the 9 Liter capacity it has plenty of storage for doing multiple floors of a good sized office building without even having to change a bag. So this is ideal for someone who is running a small part time cleaning business, or a cleaning professional alike. It also would be a good choice for a proprietor who wants to take care of their own cleaning needs. It doesn’t take up a lot of closet space and it light enough to park on a shelf. It is 9 Liters though, so its adequate storage space goes up instead of out.Due to its larger capacity, it is configured a lot like a shop vac, except the wheels are more sophisticated in that they are designed like a shopping cart with single direction fixed wheels in the back, and conveniently uni-directional swivel wheels in the front; so it will follow you anywhere. I like that the wheels are made from a softer grade of plastic, almost a rubbery type of plastic than the body is made out of. This eliminates having any streaks being created on hard floors.Next to a shop vac this this is super, super quiet. It has two speeds which enables the volume to be even quieter. I have heard other home style vacuums that are as quiet as this but this is way quieter than the typical shop vac. So if you were cleaning an office, or a store, there wouldn’t be a loud offensive vacuum going off during normal business hours. If you are cleaning after hours it is all the more reason to keep the volume down.It comes with stainless steel tubes and also includes a crevice tool, and a dusting brush for table tops, books, lighting fixtures and blinds. The 50 foot cord is bright orange matching the accents on the vac.Multi-purpose floor nozzle/sweeper. Flip the top side switch backwards and it does carpeted floors, flip it forward and it does hard floors. There are two foot operated switches the control on/off and which mode it is in. Turn it on with one switch, and then toggle between hush mode, and boost mode for heavily soiled areas.  There isn’t a huge difference in volume levels between the two modes, however both of them are rather quiet.The pre-motor foam filter is washable and reusable. The large cloth pre-motor filter is cleanable by simply using the dust brush. The dirt collection bag is replaceable and not washable. It is for dry use only. There is a large cord hook on the back of the unit. You simply wind up the cord typically by using your elbow and hand, or you could simply wrap it over your hand and then tie it off, or use a wire tie, and drape it over the cord hook. The large cord hook also acts like a convenient way to store the vac wand. This is not one of those double hook cord storage models. If it was you would have to bend over in order to wrap it. This way you wrap the cord standing up, and simply place it over the hook. If you do use this for home you could plug it into one outlet and probably do your whole house or apartment. No having to plug into various outlets as you go along.I have grown accustomed to my higher priced vacuum having a foot activated automatic cord return feature. They have short range thinner cords. But with a thick commercial grade cord that is designed to carry some voltage for 50 feet that type of system is impractical.With the Hoover logo emblazoned on the side with the word commercial under it, and then the words Hush Tone on the base leaves a professional impression. I wish I could find something wrong with it, but the nature of the job at hand requires manual cord wrapping. Other than that it is highly recommended.

I feel sorry for bands these days. What typically happens is that someone, or some few pop out their cell phones and record the band with a cheesy mic built into their cell, and even poorer lighting in the room. Then they take a video of the band and post it on You Tube with the name of the band in the title. So if someone wants to get a peek at someone’s band they are getting a view in the worst light possible. Oddly enough it is not the video that suffers due to the cell phone lens, because many cell phones take a 1080p movie, it is rather the sound, and lack of proper lighting that is the culprit.If you really wanted to do the band a favor, and be of good service, get this MXL MM-130 and carry it in your pocketbook, or a guy could even stick it in his pocket, and bring it along to the gig. It takes nothing to plug it into the headphone/mic input combo jack on your cell; the difference in sound is amazing. If you visit You Tube and do a search “MXL MM-130 Mobile Mic for iPhone” you will see a video that displays the incredible difference between an iPhone built in mic and this MXL mic.Trying to capture a voice back at the camera, a shotgun mic is typically used. This is not a shotgun mic so it needs to be used in closer proximity. It is however a condenser mic even though it looks like a stage dynamic mic. Dynamic mics are great at cutting out background noise, and are so insensitive that at times even standing in front of a PA speaker will not cause feedback. A singer usually sings directly into a condenser mic, sometimes with their lips touching it.A condenser mic on the other hand is so sensitive it not only will cause feedback if you are broadcasting what is being heard through a PA. In a studio setting it is so sensitive that even the air rushing out of a heating vent will be picked up. Studio mics that are condensers are typically phantom powered. This is not a phantom powered mic which is a good thing for this application since you don’t have a phantom power supply with you. Not only does it eliminate the need for a mixer that provides 48 volt power, it also tames it down some. MXL went a step farther and included a hi-lo gain switch, so you can custom tailor sensitivity to your needs. In addition to that it also is switchable between Omni-directional, and cardioid patterns. Omni directional is all around the mic/room, and cardioid is just what is being received in the top of the microphone. It is not being shot through a tunnel like a shotgun mic, but rather isolating the input somewhat as to what is directed at the top of the mic. So if you are aiming it at someone to speak you would hear more of their voice, and less of the room background noise. Sometimes background noise is a good thing. You may want to capture some of the excitement of where you are. Or in the case of capturing a band having some ambience is a good thing. Professionally capturing both sounds up close and a separate mic for out in the audience provides an interesting mix. With this MM-130 both options are there with the flick of a switch right on the mic.So this is really a condenser mic complete with a 3 pin jack. In the directions there is a warning. It says;Important note: This microphone will NOT work with standard audio mixers by using a standard XLR cable. There is a potential for damage to the MM-130 microphone and the mixer in this configuration.So this microphone as listed is for use with your cell phone or tablet. I have seen some pretty amazing videos made with an iPhone, and with Android based phones as well. Some phones such as my BLU even though the screen is not 1080P it still shoots 1080p video. So then it can be exported, or shared online. The listed applications for this mic are interviews, podcasts, videos, speeches, presentations, and performances.A few years ago I purchased the Tascam DR-60 which is a great entry level add-on for a DSLR with movie making capability. It has twin XLR inputs including phantom power. The newer one is out now which is the Tascam DR-60Dmkll. That exceeds the model that I have. That costs twice what this microphone does and does not include a mic. That one just opens up a lot of options for things like boom mics or a wider range of mics.This MM-130 fits a very interesting niche because it puts you way ahead of the pack that are still recording with the tiny little mic in their phone. If you wanted to get started doing podcasts you can even get a small pedestal stand to do interviews Jay Leno style. It comes with a microphone clip with the standard mic stand mount. So for stand up, or with a short desktop stand you are ready to go. Hey you have your cell phone with you everywhere. Having this mic with you is a very nice option to have. As I mentioned, nothing ticks me off more than to see a band on You Tube that someone recorded with their cell, with the crummy mic, and then they post it on You Tube with the name of the band in the title. So when the band members tell someone the name of their band, they go look it up, see the crummy video and don’t come back. Audio quality is first and foremost in video taking. Bad audio and they change the channel. Good audio they hang out and watch it. So for the niche this fits, it is highly recommended.

This Cobra JumPack is such an incredible device it is hard to believe it works. How can anything that is slightly thinner than a pack of cigarettes although longer have the capacity to jump start a vehicle. Oddly enough in order to recharge it you use a 1 amp USB connection; not even a 2.4. The directions say 1 amp. That is what you need to hook it up to in order to charge up the JumPack. On the other hand the Jumpack itself charges outboard devices such as phones or tablets at the 2.4 amp rate. That is what the owner’s manual says. On the other hand the writing on each of the outlets on the device says… round input “14 volt 1 amp” mini-usb input 9 volt 1.8 amp, and full sized USB out 9 volt 2.4 amp.If you stash this in your glove box and forget about it another incredible thing is that it retains 85 to 90 percent of its charge up to 8 months. So this truly is a charge it up and forget about it device. However for maximum performance the JumPack should be recharged at least once every 3 months.Additionally you can charge the Jumpack with the supplied 13.8v DC car charger with the cigarette lighter plug which is included, as well as the USB micro to standard USB cable.The directions warn us about using the JumPack in extreme temperatures. However the extreme limits measured in the Fahrenheit scale is 113+ degrees or under -14 degrees below zero which is -10 degrees Centigrade.  I think in a glove box you would be hard pressed to dip below -14 degrees below zero, at least in most all locations, but the upper limits of 113+ are attainable in a closed car especially if it a dark car with black interior for example on a hundred degree day during the summer. So with that information you can best judge how to store it.One of my pet peeves is running out of battery life on my tablets or cell phone. There are a lot of quick charge backup devices out there, but not many that has the capacity of the JumPack. I would feel comfortable going away for a weekend expecting to do a recharge several times.There are some caveats to jump starting a vehicle. First let me share with you and experience I had. I had an automotive shop for 20 years. One time I was hooking up a set of battery cables to a battery and a spark jumped out and the gases that were inside of the battery as is typical are explosive so it blew the top of the battery and fortunately even though some battery acid got on my face none of it went in my eyes. So the directions on the JumPack tell you to hook the cables up to the battery first, and after that is all done plug the other end of the cable they provide into the JumPack. No sparks get near the battery that way.The one caveat pertaining to usage is that the directions tell you to not crank to start a vehicle for more than 3 seconds at a time otherwise the fuse may blow in the JumPack. The fuse is in the jumper cables. There is a clear window box on the ground side in-line so you can clearly see if it is good or not. Another reason for the fuse to blow is if you short the jumper cables. If the fuse blows you cannot replace it but rather need to buy another set of the jumper cables that comes with the JumPack. These cables are short, not like typical automotive cables. There is no listing on Amazon that I can find for these cables, and I was unable to find a listing on the cobra web site either. I won’t guess what they cost but it shouldn’t be much.There is also a warning about trying to start a car with a dead, dead battery. I know from experience you can use regular jumper cables from a freight train battery and the car usually won’t start. You have to sometimes, when jumping between cars let the other car run for a while thereby charging the dead vehicle up to a certain point so a jump start will make the difference in starting it. This is not a limitation of the JumPack but rather an inherent situation in car batteries no matter what the situation.The advantage of this JumPack is its size. That makes it truly portable. I was in the shopping mall parking lot the other day and this woman took a much larger device out of her trunk, lifted the hood, hooked it up and was able to start the car. It was twenty times the size of this JumPack. So if you have a weak battery and some additional juice will make all of the difference, then this JumPack is for you. I want to say that when I had my first car and the battery got weak, I spent countless frustrating hours getting jump starts, trying to roll down hills to get it up to 20mph so the auto-trans would engage to pop start it. The lesson I learned from that is if your battery is getting weak, or even starts to show signs of weakness, get a new one. Don’t mess with frustrating battery scenarios. It’s not worth it. Did you know that a newer battery if it is weak will at least partially regenerate itself?Anyhow my take on this is that it is overkill in a good way as a device to charge your portable devices. Going out and finding that your cell phone or tablet, or laptop battery is running low if frustrating and this device is just what the doctor ordered. If your car battery is weak this will even jump start it as long as it isn’t totally dead. Think how cool it would be if someone is stranded with a dead battery and they ask you for a jump start, and you whip out the JumPack and off they go. It beats the heck out of chewing up your battery terminals, and running any risks on your vehicles sensitive electronics. It’s great for what it does, and even has a light that you can turn on with it. Portable is the key here. Super, super portable. You could slide it into your pants pocket. It would even sit in a shirt pocket but stick out the top a little.Great for what it is.

It comes pre-installed with a standard AA Alkaline battery. That’s encouraging considering the battery lasts for ten months. So there is no super expensive battery to buy. Standard fare with a superb long life extraordinaire. The incredible thing is the universal ability to connect to most all of the big operating systems and devices out there. It even paired with my Amazon Fire 8.9 HDX. Pairing has never been simpler. I opened up the wireless settings button, turned on the mouse with the on switch and pressed the button on the bottom. When I went into the Fire HDX it instantly recognized it, so I tapped on it in the list and bingo; instantly recognized. I have grown so accustomed to touch screening the tablet this new tool is going to get some getting used to.I have been using a compact Microsoft mouse for use with my HP X2 2-1 10.1 inch portable. It is the same size as this Logitech. I love all things Logitech. I use their keyboards exclusively. This Logitech M535 is the perfect size to simply put in your pouch/cover/case that you rest your small portable in. The profile is much lower than a standard mouse, and it also is super light-weight, but that doesn’t transfer into any less critical in its accuracy. This works on just about any surface you can throw at it. It is comfortable enough to even be your primary desktop mouse. So if you have a sole laptop as your primary weapon of choice this M535 enables you to comfortably use it on the road or at your desk. The unusual thing using it in the Fire HDX is that the scroll wheel works fine but when you roll it up the page scrolls down, and vice-versa. It takes little effort to just use it the opposite way. I purposely tried it on my HDX because the operating system is based on Android but custom applied for Amazon. I figured if it worked there, it works everywhere. So I tapped on Help in the Fire and up came the Mayday option so I used a chat session and it all resolved. I was able to adjust the pointer speed, but oddly enough it also corrected the scroll wheel movement so it works properly in the right direction now.Logitech has a downloadable advanced gestures and customizations software for Windows and MAC. So you get a full suite of options that way, but the way it is working automatically with the adjusted settings in my Fire HDX I don’t need any more options.Believe it or not this greatly expands my uses of my Fire HDX. I have been using it exclusively as a carry around tablet and that’s it. Now it seems logical to keep it open on my desk and have it as an 8.9” super high def. entertainment screen set off to one side as I surf the web and conduct business in my PC. I have a small, very, very, small portable fold up keyboard that I also paired with the HDX since it has dual Blue Tooth connectivity. Now this Logitech mouse and the keyboard both work great at the same time. Now I can really park my HDX off to one side and have complete autonomy. However it is worth noting that touch screen devices are best used of course as a mix of mouse/keyboard/and touch commands. So I access Amazon Prime videos and Amazon Music conveniently without having to turn on a large TV and speakers while I am working. One click of the mouse and I am back to undisturbed work for the phone etc.Did I say that I love all things Logitech? This is a great example. It is going into the portable pouch/cover along with the slim fold out keyboard. Highly recommended.

I bought the Eureka Mighty Mite on August 4th 2014 so I have had quite some time to use it. I just acquired the Bissell Hard Floor Expert Multi-Cyclonic Bagless Canister Vacuum, 1547 and wanted to share this with you. I love it. It’s my little fuelie dragster. That is what the shape reminds me of. What better design to instill a feeling of power and performance. I also love the color combination. Click on the bottom picture in the listing which is the close up shot and see it full screen. It looks every bit as good, and even better in person.How does this compare to the Eureka 370G Mighty Mite Canister Vacuum, the one I had purchased earlier and is the number one seller here at Amazon? No comparison. This Bissel Hard Floor Expert Multi-Cyclonic Bagless Canister Vacuum, 1547 hereinafter referred to as the “BMC” has just that, a cyclonic dirt collector whereas the Eureka has on the other hand an ongoing bag replacement requirement. You can easily see when the BMC is filling up with its transparent removable canister, but the Eureka you have to guess; as in when it stops picking up dirt you have to disassemble the filter portion and give it a poke in order to see if it is full.The fact that you don’t need to replace filters although they are available, you can simply hand wash them and use them again, and again, and again. With the Eureka Mighty Mite you have to buy new bags, and with the cost of them being a dollar a bag, how many 9 packs do you have to buy before you wind up spending the same amount of money as purchasing the BMC in the first place, and there are sooooo many advantages to the BMC.Next item up for bid, the wand. On the Eureka you have this long, fixed plastic tube that does allow you to pull the sections apart and store them on the couch for those times when you need a longer reach. The BMC has this beautiful stainless steel telescoping wand/tube that has no such problems. It retracts and extends anywhere along its reach with the locking dots all along the shaft. So there is no having to take anything apart, and place sections around the room that you have to go and find when you want to extend the Eureka. This also is a huge advantage for storage. My one complaint about the Eureka is that it takes up a lot of closet space with the long fixed plastic tube plus the long flexible tube. This BMC with the push of the collar collapses the stainless steel tube into a length that is about half of the space of the Eureka.I also like the substantially larger diameter hose on the BMC and the way it is configured makes for a much more easily maneuverable device that is not always banging into walls and marring up your trim when going from room to room. The Eureka has a smaller diameter hose that is stiff and comes straight out the front so it has more of a mind of its own when tagging along.Now let’s talk about a really big feature with me and that is the filtration system. The Eureka has a joke of a small plastic post-filter that is designed to let everything through except maybe large chunks. My main complaint with that one is when my brother is vacuuming and the exhaust is blowing out the back it enters my room and has quite an odor to it. I go and close my door and turn on the air filtration unit to clean the air. The BMC has a very fine filter on it that is thick and looks like something someone would use with a hazmat suit to filter out serious allergens. It is white and instantly looks like something you would trust your lungs to. It is good to note that the ultra-fine stuff is what causes the problems because your lungs don’t have such an easy time getting it out.The wheels are configured the same but that is about where that ends. The BMC have softer wheels either made out of rubber, or more likely a rubbery plastics grade material that is guaranteed not to scratch itself across your nicely finished hardwood floors and tile. The Eureka wheels are hard black plastic.Unlike the breakdown of the different BMC models the check sheet on this listing page only has the one foot tool that comes with this BMC 1547 but in reality it has both right in the box. You have one that is made for rugs that is vacuum only, and a second one that is made for hard floors such as tile and hardwoods and that one contains a beater brush to pick up the stuff that may be minimally attached to the floor. The bristles are very fine, almost silk like so as to not scratch your polished/shiny floor surfaces. They interchange very simply. The Eureka has two heads as well; one they call the bare floor nozzle and the other that they call the deluxe floor brush is really an open rectangle at the bottom with a brush material around the circumference that does not act like a beater spinning head like the BMC has.As far as convenience the crevice tool and brush tool for blinds etc. stores right underneath the handle area for easy access. The Eureka has a storage area for the crevice tool that is a hollow insertion area on top of the motor itself requiring that you bend over to the floor every time you want to access it.Power and performance. The Eureka is listed as a 12 amp motor and there isn’t any listing I can find that states the size/amperage of the Bissell. Another line that Bissell has especially designed for pet hair lists them between 9 and 12 amps depending on model. The noise level of both units has the Eureka putting out about twice the noise level of the BMC. The BMC is so quiet that if someone was sleeping in the next room it would not awaken them. I have to relate the sound to a pleasing purr instead of noise. When you shut it off as it slows down it sounds like an extremely quiet 747 with its whistling sound as it de-accelerates.Now here is a super biggie for me; the auto rewind cord. This is where the two really are on a separate planet. The BMC has a cord that is spring wound to wind up IN the housing instead of wrapped around it. So at any time you can extend the cord to as much as you need, and when you are done, and this is huge you simply step on the large silver auto-retract knob and the BMC automatically sucks the cord up into its body. I have found from experience with the Eureka that has one of those two paddles on the bottom that you have to manually wind the cord up with it. Most often I find it with the cord wrapped around the body, or not wrapped at all strewn all over the closet. Did I mention that the BMC not only has a retractable wand but the cord storage is a lot better?Look do I hate the Eureka Mighty Mite? Not really, but it is a good example of you get what you pay for. There is no way they can make something as integrally well built with the features of the BMC for less than half of the price. So for the money it is a bargain, but like I mentioned in the long run you are going to eat up the difference having to replace the filters all of the time on the Eureka as well as having to replace the bags. So in the long run you are going to spend the same amount of money and have an inferior unit in the Eureka. All of the filters in the BMC can be hand washed in cold water with a mild detergent, and then thoroughly dried before returning them to the vacuum. I am sure after a while it would be a good idea to replace them, but that is a supposition on my part. I have the Hoover Wind Tunnel Bagless Upright and emptying out the dirt has to be the easiest job going. It is the same as this Bissell. All you do it push one button and the completely enclosed canister lifts right out. I go outside to my plastic trash can, release the lid on the bottom, give it a few light taps on the side of the can, snap the lid back on and I am ready to go. Comparing that to replacing bags at a cost and having to get them of the closet, install them after expanding them, and making sure the collar is properly inserted etc, not to mention the risk of breaking or even getting a little tear in the bag and then the entire inside of the vac is a mess; there is no comparison. I have both and I will take the bagless every time.Swiveling head on the BMC is also a mind blower in comparison to the Eureka. The BMC is created much like a gyroscope in that it swivels on two different axes. You are able to stand it up perfectly upright while still having the vacuum head square on the floor. The Eureka has no such flexibility only allowing a single knee operation. So how does this compute into its actual use? The BMC made it effortless to get into the tiny area alongside my bathroom sink where I park the trash can and almost always needs cleaning because of the near misses. The distance between the wall and vanity is only 9 inches, and with the installed towel rack taking up that space it is only 5 inches. I was able to drop it in and do one side of that area, and then simply drop it in again to do the other side. It got everything in there. I tried to access the same way with the Eureka but from straight down from the top it is not flexible enough to have the shoe sit squarely on the floor rendering it useless for such task. Overall the gyroscope like flexibility of the BMC both with its coplanar flexible dual plane intuitive ability makes it a breeze to use even when vacuuming the regular wide open floor. I am sure you have seen a commercial with a vacuum head swiveling and going in any direction you may want it. Well this one does exactly that. The Eureka does have a single flexible knee that has a limited range of movement. So for moving the head side by side you are more or less scraping it across the floor instead of gliding it in the direction of movement. You can see the spinning brush through the clear plastic upper area of the foot brush giving you convenient feedback if anything is stuck or jammed in the brush area. The brush does not spin until you make complete contact with the floor.The Mighty Mite may have the same size, or even a little more powerful motor than the BMC, I have no way of knowing since the BMC does not publicize the amp rating at this time, but I do know that when I am cleaning my hardwood floors or tile something that is an inch away from the floor tool is sucked into the unit before it even gets to it. I am sure some heavier, more solid items would need to have the floor tool run directly over it such as is the standard case with many vacuums.I think I may move the Eureka out to the garage for using it to clean the car so the smell from the poorly filtered air has a chance to escape instead of being blown into the inside air of my bedroom etc. Have I tried every vacuum out there? Of course not, but I do have the Miele Compact C2 Quartz Canister Vacuum in Lotus white that is over 2.6 times the price of this Bessell with all of the same exact features except it is not a bagless. That is why I jumped at the opportunity to have a go with this one.Understand this Bissell is a “hard” floor expert so if someone tries to bash it because it does not have a beater brush for carpeting understand why. This brush head depends on the vacuuming air pressure to make the brush head spin. On a non-resistant slick shiny floor it works great, but it would get snagged on plush carpet. So a separate vacuum cleaner designed for that purpose is advisable if you want to beat/brush the deep dirt out of carpeting. The carpet head on the BMC is a passive vacuum head only.It is common that people prefer to have an upright with such capabilities as well as a canister that can get into places and upright can’t even dream of accessing; like tight spaces, doing your blinds, getting the cobwebs up on the ceiling, although some uprights do have the add on tube vacuum option.Did I tell you that I am in love with this Bissel? You betcha. The Eureka Mighty Mite served its purpose, but my new pet is the Bissell Multi-cyclonic. Highly recommended.

I ran Verizon online speed test with the WiFi connection and the results I got were as follows:5.53 download.35 uploadran it again and got10.89 download1.53 uploadI have been having trouble with the wifi adapter in this unit and is part of the reason I wanted this TP Link USB to Ethernet adapter. So I plugged it in and ran the test again.50.43 download56.50 uploadThen I ran it again56.75 download54.87 uploadI'm running this on my Verizon FIOS 50/50 and get these kind of results on my HP i7 Laptop 17 inch. So this adapter really works without any glitches. I plugged it in my USB port, Windows 8.1 instantly recognized the device and automatically loaded the drivers.I am using this USB to Ethernet adapter on my HP X2 10.1 inch 2 in 1 laptop running an Atom 1.3 processor with only 2 gig of ram. These small compact portables are known for not having RJ45 Ethernet ports due to the extra large size. In the ongoing battle for ever slimmer screens there is no room for that, but a slimmer USB port is often included. So this adapter opens up the world and advantage of hard wired Ethernet opens up.I couldn't recommend this more. Great device. Works great.

I’m a Pro Tools user and when I took the introductory courses for Pro Tools from a Guitar Center instructor who had a bachelor’s degree in studio engineering, and actively masters other people’s work all of the time he said, “I use Ableton Live when I am doing my creative tasks such as song writing and then I import that into Pro Tools to do all of my final polishing and tweaks.” Ever since then I have always wanted to get a copy of Ableton and am glad it is included as part of the package of this Novation Launchkey. It is the Lite version which limits you to only 8 tracks but that is way more than enough in order to get down your creative input Live 9 Lite is not time limited and you can save and mix down your work. It is designed to be a powerful performance tool for the stage. Hopefully I will get so familiar with it, and realize beyond a shadow of a doubt what my instructor said and get the full version. This is definitely a great way to get your feet wet. The big bonus is that with this Live Lite you also can upgrade to Live 9 Standard and Suite saving a hundred dollars. So that savings alone is half the price of the Novation Launch Key 49. You don’t have to using Ableton Live to run the Novation it is also compatible with other major DAW’s, and also control the music making apps in the iPad. I have an iPad Air but draining the battery with a USB powered keyboard can be challenging so I picked up a USB Hub that is compatible and has an A/C plug in adapter. The instructions from Novation state the same thing about laptops stating that since it is a USB powered keyboard it is suggested that you use either a laptop that is connected to an A/C outlet, or use an adapter to directly connect the NL49 directly to an outlet instead. So this is not really a totally portable keyboard but rather a powerful MIDI controller for in studio work, or on the road as a live performance machine using Ableton 9 Live Lite with a plugged in computer/laptop etc.I purchased a few years ago the M-Audio Oxygen 49 49-Key USB MIDI Keyboard Controller The Oxygen 49 MIDI controller offers out-of-the-box integration with Pro Tools software just like this Novation Launchkey offer integration with Ableton. So this perfectly complements what my needs are. The huge advantage of these kind of MIDI controllers is that you can get more easily into the creative mode when you are not scurrying across the room in order to use the mouse to stop, record, and play back tracks. There is a lot more in the way of controls than that, a lot, lot more.This new Novation comes with the keypads right on the top of the keyboard which double as a trigger for drum sounds for example or for use as a controller device.A quick word about MIDI. I was lost in the world of buying whole units containing keys or other MIDI triggers that had built into them sound engines, AD/DA converters, sound samples, computers, etc. etc. etc. and those things were at best only marginal in quality next to the three thousand dollar plus counterparts. Then I discovered something that was right in front of me all along, and that is buy MIDI controllers and use your high quality interface as your pre and AD/DA converter and then buy whole suites of super high quality samples. For example I purchased the Alesis DMX7 electronic drum set for a very reasonable amount of money, and then picked up Superior Drummer for the samples which include a 1960’s Roger’s and Slingerlands drum set recorded with Neumann U87 microphones and more. So with my single purchase of the drum set for around $500 I acquired something that sounds as good, as or better than the 5 thousand dollar Roland set; so I decided to do the same thing with my keyboards from now on. Yes this does require that you bring a computer with you, but that is a lot more convenient than lugging around a super heavy keyboard. However having an all in one keyboard workstation as your main keys has its advantages. These MIDI controllers are so light they almost scare you and make a great add on for an instant access symphony of sounds.Now specifically about this Novation. These keys have a semi-weighted feel about them. There is an even amount of resistance to them throughout the whole keys range of motion. Feeling the action of a keyboard is a very personal thing and certain preferences do abide. With Amazons no holes barred 30 day return policy all you are risking is the cost of return postage if you don't like it, and you get the armchair convenience of trying it out. That being said the overall action in my opinion is very good.I never measured the size of my keys before but someone mentioned that these are smaller than usual. That is not the case. The length of the keys are 5 ” long, the width of the keys are a tad under 7/8” actually 27/32” to be exact. The space between the black keys ranges from 5/8” to ¾”. I never really measured the distance between keys before but I got the same measurements on my Yamaha MM6, as well as my Oxygen 49 as well as my M-Audio 88 keystation. The length of the keys on my Yamaha MM6 are also 5 ½” long, but my M-Audio 88 keystation key length, at least what is accessible and does not tuck under the housing is 5 3/8” long and my M Audio Oxygen 49 is the same 5 3/8”. So unless someone has an extra-large keyboard that goes beyond these measurements any comments that the keys are too small is unfounded. I think the illusion is created that smaller keyboards have smaller keys even though they don’t. When I stand behind my full sized 88 key monster I get the feeling that the keys are huge when in actuality they are an eighth of an inch smaller in length, and the same size in width.The M-Audio Oxygen 49 newest generation IV has 8 velocity sensitive trigger pads and this Novation Launchkey 49 has 16 that are also assignable and usable for different purposes.Ableton Live 9 Lite in as little as 3 months ago which would be 7/15 actually two weeks before Windows 10 launch date, so those using the beta version of Windows 10 were having problems successfully opening the software. Glad to see that on the Ableton web site that Live 9 Lite is now fully compatible as of the date of this review. 10/15. They do however warn you that any plug ins you may be using, may or may not be compatible so they suggest that you do not upgrade to Win 10 faster than you need to for that reason. I know with for example Pro Tools each version is very Windows version specific. So my Pro Tools 9 works with my desktop tower running Windows 7 only.You download Ableton right from their site so you are sure to get the latest version. Included are 600 MB of loops and samples. The overall download is 707 MB’s. Mine loaded with Windows 10 without a glitch. I authorized it through the Ableton site and it loaded some samples onto some tracks so all I had to do was hit the play button to see it working, and playing in action. I hate it when a program arrives blank asking you to load some samples, etc. By maneuvering around in an already built session is the quickest way to learn something, and add on tracks etc.This package comes bundled with a lot of extra content that is nice to have. You do have to register to both the Novation site, as well as the Ableton site. Registering provides support and access to insider information so to speak. I have never met a DAW or other music related software that didn’t require some time to register and activate the software, and then configure. It’s not a 2 second job no matter which one you choose. I personally want all the included stuff that they provide. You may not wish to download the 1.4GB of Loopmasters_Excite content especially if you are running a DSL line, but with a Verizon FIOS 50/50 it only takes 3 minutes.This review is rather lengthy, and I appreciate you reading all of this. I hope it was helpful. I have to spend some time in Ableton using it in conjunction with this keyboard to provide that end of it, but everything seems to work well in my Windows 10 machine. I am excited about the expanded capabilities Ableton provides and it is just the right size in the 49 if you want to use it in your studio on top of your desk as a controller. It is also a nice add on to your rack in a live situation using it with a computer. It looks impressive as heck with the 8 sliders, and a 9th as a master in conjunction with the 16 velocity keypads. A great addition to your arsenal. Highly recommended.

I purchased Adobe Premiere Elements 12 a ways back, and also have Corel Video Studio Pro X8. I acquired Cyberlink Power Director 14 Ultimate because of its compatibility with Windows 10. As the description states, “World's Fastest Rendering -TrueVelocity 5 leverages hardware and software technologies to speed up video processing and outperform all others. TrueVelocity is optimized for modern CPU and GPGPU hardware platforms from Intel, AMD and NVIDIA to maximize memory allocation and usage.” So it is compatible with all three manufacturers Intel, AMD, and NVIDIA of display adapters.My Adobe Premiere Elements 12 is not compatible with Windows 10, at least not in every function, but fortunately Corel Video Studio Pro X8 has released a free update to 8.5 which is. This Cyberlink Power Director 14 is being released as a designed for Windows 10 piece of software from the get go.When I first got Corel X8 I was pleased that it had an easy-peasy video editor option that made it a candy walk to create a video right out of the box. This Cyberlink Director 14 has an equivalent easy editor. That probably has a lot to do with the instant results, and wall to wall 5 star reviews of those stating how easy it is to use out of the box. Others who delve into the more complex functions of video editing, and are frustrated that they cannot master it right away are those who are slamming the software with low star ratings. If you want a fully featured program that does incredible things, and enables you to do things that you simply can’t do with for example Windows Movie Maker then there is going to be a learning curve.The thing I love the most about CPD 14 is that you can edit this with 4 different camera angles. I have multiple high def. cameras, some more expensive than others, and I know how great it is to have different angles to capture the excitement of a scene. When a scene is captured using just one angle it creates boredom for the viewing audience. Having a multiple method option for synchronizing all 4 whether it be automatically through the audio track, or by markers that you can set and tweak using right and left arrows controlling individual frames etc. is an option that is worth the price of admission.Much is said about the lack of an owner’s manual and not without merit. But with the price of the manual to print, and then the large increase in shipping such a product compared to a simple disc in a light box it makes the lack thereof a smart move. Having a digital manual is just as convenient except for those who stubbornly hold onto having to have a book on the desk. To be honest I wish all of my books were scanned so my entire library would take up zero shelf space in the FireHDX. With the split screen in Windows 8 + you can divide a good sized monitor into the right half, and left half, and operate both programs at once without even having to bring them back up; they just stay there. Anyhow you shouldn’t have to change your computer in order to use some software but on the other hand all software these days doesn’t come with a written manual so get over it.A really cool tool is all of the videos you can find on You Tube where they take you through certain functions right on the screen. There is no better learning tool than to see it being done. A picture really does say a thousand words. Also Cyberlink has online help both in the way of information, as well as providing a forum that is filled with information from those who have been using the program, and are willing to help. So you can look something up quickly, or even make your own post about how to do something, and watch the CL community come to the rescue.Right now this is #9 in video editing software in the ASR’s - Amazon Sales Ranks. That’s a lofty spot because every other contributor in video editing software above it are all cheapy versions. So this is the number 1 video editor over $100; that is saying something. It even beats out Adobe Photoshop & Premiere Elements in the over one hundred dollar category. Right now it is actually priced the same.It comes with 2 discs containing more extra add-ons then you could ever use. They are offered to you individually when you load the program, or should I say after loading the program, they want you to do that first. So if you don’t want the wedding videographer suite of tools you don’t have to load them.No wonder it earned PC Magazine’s Editor’s Choice award beating out all others. In the words of PC magazine, “BOTTOM LINE- Power Director continues to outflank the competition, with top rendering speed, a massive set of video editing tools, the latest file-standard support, and a wealth of new features in its latest update."Buy it.

I have been eyeballing the Nest thermostat for quite some time. This Lux Geo-WH Wi-Fi Thermostat provides all the automation plus the remote access whether in the house or from another location. There is a downloadable app for an Android or iOS phone or tablet. You can also control it intuitively right from the dial.Here comes the good part; installation is a breeze. You can visit the Lux-Geo website and they have multiple installation videos. After seeing one of those short videos depending if you have a heat pump with or without aux, or a conventional furnace with gas/oil/electric & air conditioning you will instantly be confident in just how easy this is to install. You want to be sure to shut off the main breaker servicing your heater so you don't short out a live line connect while disassembling the connections on your thermostat. That would take an easy install, and possibly turn it into a headache requiring you to purchase a new control panel for your furnace. Just be sure to shut off the breaker to your furnace. If you have a line tester just to verify you disconnected the proper breaker that would be good.Then it becomes as easy as drilling two holes in your wall, installing the screw/wall plugs and installing the thermostat. It comes with a really nice backing plate so if your thermostat was from days of old like mine is it covers up a world of sins without you have to spackle and paint your wall.By watching the online video for your type of furnace it is as easy as connect the dots. With a clear up close video they tell you to put for example the blue wire in terminal X, and the yellow wire in Terminal X etc. etc. etc. I purposely did not provide any of the real options because someone may read my review and look at it like the actual instructions. The online video provides exactly which wire goes where.If at any time during the installation you require any additional support you can call Lux-Geo at their 856 phone number. The easiest thing to do is visit the site, but it is good to know someone is standing by ready to help. You do not need to use the Wi-Fi app in order to control the thermostat, you can actually skip Wi-Fi altogether and simply use the scroll wheel on the unit.You set your comfort at home settings, and your away settings so when used in concert with the Geo-fencing via GPS through your phone or device it knows when you are away from home, or at home, and can set the thermostat to the appropriate settings. It is kind of like you are on your way home and it kicks on to the warm at home setting before you get there. You can also set up guests who can achieve the same thing.So for all intents and purposes it does what the Nest does and at a much better price. It looks good on the wall. The LCD screen is easy to read. Highly recommended.

The AmpProbe AMP-210 measures AC and the model 220 measures both AC and DC. The current number one seller in Oscilloscope Accessories is the Fluke 323 True-RMS Clamp Meter. Both AmpProbe and Fluke are owned by the same parent company Danaher Corporation. The price difference between two is only about a 10% difference. However the accuracy measurements on the 210 exceed the comparably priced Fluke.The Amp-210 comes with standard contact test leads. The alligator clip set comes with the 310, and 320 models. The AAA batteries are included and pre-installed. Enclosed in the box is also the user manual, and a carrying case. I have to say the LCD panel is easy to read when in standard mode at every angle. By pressing and holding the select button the panel is back lit. In the back lit mode it is well lit but the angle of use is limited to being below the unit or right on top of it which are the common positions of use. If you tilt the unit up and try reading the LCD from above the unit it is unreadable.Accuracy: the amp tip provides a measurement down to a tenth of an amp. The true RMS AC voltage range is 0 to 600 volts. The AC current accuracy ±1.0% + 5LSD (50 to 60 Hz) The AC current range is 0 to 600.0 A with an accuracy of ±1.8% + 5LSD (50 to 60 Hz) ±2.0% + 5LSD (100 to 400 Hz)The jaw opening is 1.18 inches. The 210 does have an auto-power off feature. It does not include a work light. It does provide the max/min/ and average feature. It is lightweight and well-built and should give you many years of good service.

The IOGEAR KVMP switch has been an excellent switch for me.  I previously purchased a KVM switch for a few dollars more that was smaller and not as feature rich.  I wasn't able to get it functioning properly, so I returned it and then purchased the IOGEAR KVMP switch from Amazon.When I first connected it, it wouldn't recognize my keyboard or mouse.  I called technical support and was quickly connected to a man who was a bit brusque at first, but became more friendly as we spoke.  Tip: Don't use a speakerphone when calling technical support.  When he heard my equipment and setup, he expressed confidence that we would get everything working fine.  He was right!One of the key things about this switch (and perhaps any switch) is that you need to have the drivers loaded on each computer for every device connected directly to the KVMP switch.  So, for example, in my case, I needed to connect the keyboard and mouse directly to each computer's USB port first, let the drivers load, THEN connect the keyboard and mouse to the IOGEAR KVMP.  At that point, the switch recognized the keyboard and mouse and everything worked well.While on the phone, the technical support representative gave me a quick tutorial on setting up hot keys to bounce between computers.  He set things up so I just press Ctrl-Ctrl-Enter and it flips me from one computer to the other.  I also use another hot key combination.  While on my work laptop, I can't stream music.  I can only do this from my home PC.  So he impressed me to study the user's manual, which I did.  I leaned very simple function keys combinations that enable me to tell the switch to port audio from my home PC to the speakers while I'm using my work laptop in the docking station.  It works great!  This a feature I absolutely love!I highly recommend this switch to others.  It may take a little work to get everything configured for your setup, but once it's setup properly, it works well.  IOGEAR's customer support is also a nice bonus!  The switch is feature rich with hot key possibilities.  Unlike other switches, the IOGEAR KVMP switch is very solidly built.  I found other switches at this price tend to be very plasticy and light, causing the switch to flop around under the weight of the connected cables.  Not this switch.  It is very solid and sits flat on my desk, even with a mountain of cables connected.  If you want to stack multiple IOGEAR switches, no problem.  The feet on one fit into recesses on the top of another.  Very nice feature.Highly recommended from one customer who is very happy with this device!

UPDATE 10/19/15: This product has failed and has been thrown in the trash.  For the last month, my reception has slowly deteriorated.  Thinking it was the indoor HDTV antenna I was using, I decided to purchased and install an outside antenna with a preamp.  I wired this to my house cable wiring and it works great!  Except for the TV where the Mediasonic HW180STB is installed.  That TV receives signals terribly pixelated.  I then direct wired the line to the TV, bypassing the Mediasonic, then tuned the Samsung flat screen.  All my channels are back!  It's the Mediasonic tuner that's the problem.So I've reduced this review to four stars.  It's a good box, as long as it's running properly.------------------------------------ORIGINAL REVIEWHaving been locked in the cable and satellite television market for years, I've been accustom to using a rented box to receive my television stations.  We recently "cut the cord" and ditched our cable TV, which freed up about $800 a year in television bills.  In the process, we purchased this box as a way to receive local over-the-air (OTA) content.  It's been since I was a child, in the 1970s, that I last pulled stations in using an antenna.  Boy, has this process changed, and for the better!  No more staticy, ghosty signals that constantly require adjusting the "rabbit ears" to pull the signal in well.After much research, I chose the Mediasonic HW180STB HomeWorx digital converter.  This little box grabs signals from your antenna, converts the analog signal to its digital constituent, then passes this processed signal to your television or home theater receiver for viewing.  The advantage of using this converter, for us, is it unlocks Dolby Digital 5.1 over an HDMI line to our home theater receiver.  Our television doesn't have an HDMI return channel feature to pass the audio from the television back to the receiver, so if we didn't have this box, we'd forever have to use the television's internal tuner and speaker, leaving our surround sound unused.After receiving the converter, I set up this little box in a matter of minutes.  It was really simple!  All I did was plug in the HDMI cable from our old cable box into the HDMI out on the back of the converter.  This cable runs to our home theater receiver, but it could also go directly to our television.  I then plugged the antenna in and plugged the convert into an AC outlet--done!  When this was complete, I powered it up.  After the box booted, I pressed the Menu button.  From there, it's very easy to locate the Antenna Tune function from the onscreen GUI.  A total OTA tune took only a few minutes, and this tuner found 28 channels in our modest, local market.The first thing I noticed was how rich and sharp the 1080i stations are.  Cable and satellite stations utilize a compression algorithm to reduce bandwidth.  The compression used is lossy and produces a "softer" image than OTA images.  Using this box, you get uncompressed OTA digital stations.  I found the OTA 1080i images to be really stunning!  They contain sharper detail than their cable/satellite counterparts.After you've completed a tune, you can press the extended programing guide button to see what's on each channel.  Unlike cable and satellite tuners, you don't get an overall guide showing everything on every channel.  Rather, you get the schedule for what's on the station you're currently watching.  This information is encoded into the digital OTA signal.  Using the tuner in my Samsung television, I wasn't able to view the channel programming guide.  That's a nice feature that the Mediasonic digital converter provides that is really handy.If you want to view cable stations, the Mediasonic HW180STB also supports tuning to your cable provider's cable line.  This tuning process takes quite a bit longer. I left the room and came back in five or ten minutes.  It also isn't as feature rich as your cable provider's cable box.  You won't have a fancy program guide, for example.  We cancelled our cable service, but I connected the cable line and performed a cable tune to see if I could grab anything off our cancelled service.  Sure enough, I was able to tune all our local stations and a few cable stations.  Unfortunately, the tuner also grabbed 167 scrambled stations, and the watchable channels it grabbed were mixed into these, making it very difficult to easily locate the channels I could watch.  There was also no programming guide for each local channel.  In addition to this, the local channel 1080i quality was inferior to the OTA content, so I wouldn't recommend viewing your local content this way.  Using an OTA antenna is really the way to go, if you can do it.The Mediasonic converter can act as a DVR.  Mediasonic refers to their DVR function as PVR.  The PVR feature records programs either by pressing record while viewing a program or scheduling a program to be recorded at a later time.  Unlike many DVRs, you cannot watch one channel while recording another.  Programs can be recorded to either a USB thumb drive (up to 64GB) or an external USB hard drive (up to 2TB).Experimenting with the PVR feature, I found using a USB thumb drive to be inconsistent.  I have several thumb drives of varying size.  Some worked smoothly while others caused pixilation and screen freezing.  I found two Verbatim thumb drives, each of the same size, were inconsistent.  One worked well while the other failed.  This failure could have been due to problems with read/write times to/from the drive chip, or it could be due to a problem that Mediasonic may correct in a later firmware update.  There's no way for me to tell.  I didn't test further to determine what was causing the inconsistency between each thumb drive.In place of the thumb drive, I purchased a Western Digital Passport 1TB external hard drive.  This worked perfectly.  Recordings were captured smoothly and effectively.
