I know there will be gasps of disbelief from some but it reminds me in many ways of Hugh Howey's Silo series.South African author Boffard has created believable characters - some very likeable and some dastardly. And some that you change your opinion of partway through the story.Boffard has also done a fine job in world building. I was able to visualize the Outer Earth easily although I'm claustrophobic and don't think I'd do well stuck in space.This is the first book in a series. ZERO-G is the second book and is due out in January 2016 and the third book, IMPACT, is due out in July 2016.If you like space thrillers, post-apocalyptic science fiction or even just straight-up action tales, try TRACER. I sure wasn't disappointed.NOTE:  I received this book from Redhook Books through Net Galley in exchange for my honest review.

Bella Bradley, famous TV cooking star, and Amy Lane, Maths teacher, used to be best friends back in school days. They were each envious of the other's life but both loved cooking with Amy's mother. They had a falling out and many years have passed.Then Amy's husband of 20 years leaves her for a younger woman, their twins aren't going to be home for Christmas, and Amy sees something on Bella's cooking show that gets her seeing red. And Amy finally gets in touch with Bella again - with results that neither expected.This was a fun but oftentimes serious look at marriage, friendship, television production, the haves and the have nots. It takes place in England but the messages imparted are universal.I especially enjoyed Amy's character just because I felt closer to her. Bella grew up in a wealthy family and is still very rich as a TV star and was harder for me to identify with.The side characters were a fun bunch and it was interesting to see details about a cooking show being produced.NOTE:  I received this book from Bookouture through Net Galley in exchange for my honest review.

I love Christmas, from Jesus being born in a lowly stable in Bethlehem to all the glitz and glitter of Christmas trees and lights, presents given from the heart and special times we spend with our family and friends.CHRISTMAS WISHES AND MISTLETOE KISSES was a fun, perfect story to start getting me geared up for the holidays.Abbey Fuller is a single mom to 6 year-old Max, a full-time nurse that dreams of being an interior designer. She is the caretaker of an elderly woman who refers her to her grandson - for a design job.She meets Nick Sinclair at his residence - a mansion which he needs fully decorated before Christmas. And he offers Abbey an exorbitant amount to get it done.This felt like a Cinderella story, rags to riches, too good to be true. But even so, it was a wowser of a story.I loved the characters and I'd love to stay in Nick Sinclair's mansion. Some parts of the story were a tad unbelievable but it's fiction and it's a feel-good tale so that's okay by me.This is a story about the importance of family and friends, keeping promises, and following your dreams. It is a new favorite Christmas story of mine.And it's a clean read, suitable for all ages.NOTE:  I received this book from Bookouture through Net Galley in exchange for my honest review.

My fiance could not get over that you could actually hear the bass in these headphones.*I received these at a discounted price for my honest opinion.

I really wanted to like this game because Alawar develops some fantastic point and click adventures, however, this one is a let down. The story is good, you meet a "prince" on the internet and travel to his castle where you find out he has imprisoned women in paintings. It could have been a very interesting game, but it quickly became boring and I lost interest early on.The adventuring is bare minimum, with only a few things to do in each area. There is a lot of back and forth, mostly to drag out the game length. The graphics are very average. There are hidden object searches, which are the basic old school type, and mini games, which are very easy. There are no voice-overs, only written text on the screen. The game includes a diary and fast travel map, accessible from the diary by pressing the compass at the top of the page. There are 2 difficulty settings, but the game is easily played on either one.There are 7 chapters, but they go by quickly and I finished the game in one afternoon. There is no bonus content. For $1.99, the game is fairly priced, but it just didn't appeal to me.

This is an enjoyable point and click murder mystery, although it is not as good as the second "Final Cut". This time you are sent an ominous package by a serial killer who calls himself "The Director", and you must follow his instructions before more people die. Once again, you play in the "real world" and the "projected world". Some of the story is a little slow, but overall it kept my interest.The game has all the usual bells and whistles. There is a journal, fast travel map, hint button, and footsteps which show you all available directions of travel from the current location. The journal and map are on a separate screen and accessible only from the MENU button. I wish they were on the same screen as the game, and didn't like having to exit the game to access these features. There are hidden object searches and mini games, both well done. In this collector's edition, you must find 49 slates, which are hidden throughout the game, and 16 morphing objects, which are only found in the hidden object searches. The music is great, the graphics are detailed and clear, and the voiceovers are very well done.I had no problems picking up or using the inventory items, and all scene transitions are smooth without any loading screens. You can adjust the difficulty level - casual, expert, or insane. I had no technical issues playing on Kindle HDX 8.9. There are seven chapters and a bonus chapter, so the game is long and involved. There is also some bonus content which was interesting. I got the game on sale for $2.99 (will go up to $4.99), and do feel I got my money's worth. I recommend this game, as it is worthwhile, especially if you're a fan of the "Final Cut" series (Death on the Silver Screen & Encore).

This is a decent point and click adventure, although it is not as good as the first one (Off The Record: Linden Shades). You play again as a detective, this time you are sent to Italy to investigate the thief "La Volpe", but things may not be as seem. The story is good, but not one that you will remember once you finish the game.The adventuring is standard, and you don't hold on to inventory items very long, as many are used in the same scene where you found them.There are a variety of hidden object searches, mini games, and you must collect 52 foxes, 15 travel guides, 12 letters, and 17 morphing objects, all scattered throughout the game. It seems they threw in a lot of collectibles to make up for a short and so-so game. There is a journal with your objectives, but it isn't on the main screen - you access it from the MENU button. There is a full written strategy guide if you need help beyond the hint button, but overall, the game is on the easy side. You can adjust the difficulty settings (casual, expert or insane). The graphics and music are good, and the voice-overs are believable (except no one has an Italian accent?).I had no technical issues playing on kindle HDX 8.9. There are 4 chapters, a bonus chapter, and some bonus content, but the game is on the short side. For $2.99, I feel I got my money's worth, but I would get this before the sale ends and it goes up to $4.99, as it might not be worth it.

This is a well-made game with a great story by a new developer (Orchid Games). You play as an archeologist who must stop an ancient curse and the evil that it might bring on the town of Avalon. It is equal parts mystery, Celtic/Druid folklore and evil happenings. The story kept my interest throughout.The game includes all the usual elements we have come to expect: hidden object searches, mini games, a fast travel map, hint button and journal. You also collect 70 mistletoe twigs, which are scattered throughout the game. The adventuring is fairly intuitive, but simple, as there aren't as many close up scenes to explore as I'd like. I had no technical issues playing on kindle HDX 8.9. Each scene transitioned smoothly without any loading screens. I was able to pick up and use all inventory items as intended. The graphics are spectacular, with a high level of detail, and the music is perfect.This is a fairly long game with 7 chapters, but no bonus content or chapter. You can play part for free, but it is $4.99 to unlock the full game. I missed the sale, but still paid for the unlock, and think the game is worth it. I recommend trying the free part and seeing if this is your kind of adventure.

This is a fairly good game, although the story is overly complicated and convoluted. You must return to 1677 in order to prevent a terrible betrayal which happened in the Order of the Griffins in their top tier, the Secret Five. There is a lot of information and back story, and some of the adventuring is just mindless chores, so the story ends up losing steam as you run around looking for a piece of rope or a crank handle. However, I did enjoy playing, and overall the story is quite good and held my interest throughout. This is the second game in "The Secret Order" series, but the only one available for android (the others are distributed by Big Fish and available for Ipad).There are standard hidden object searches (or you can play mahjong instead), and mini games, which are fairly easy. The game includes a very detailed journal, which has a lot of text and tells the complete story. There is also an interactive map, but it doesn't work that well, and only shows one major location at a time and the available areas within that location only. Because of this flaw in the map, there is a lot of back and forth if you don't know exactly where to go; and even if you do know where to go, you can't use the map as a short cut to fast travel to a different level. The graphics, voice-overs, and music are all good, but nothing outstanding.I had no technical issues playing on kindle HDX 8.9. I do appreciate that this game does not have a lot of invasive permissions, which most point and click adventures seem to be loaded with. You can play the first chapter and part of the second chapter for free, then it is $3.49 to unlock the full game, which is on sale right now and will go up to $4.99. This is not a very long game and only has 6 chapters with no bonus content. I did like this one, but recommend you try the free part and see if it is your kind of adventure.

This is a fantastic game! The first "League of Light" is one of my favorite games, so I had high hopes for this one, and it did not disappoint. The story is interesting and very well done. You play as a detective who travels to Blake's Mountain to investigate missing children.  The adventuring is fun for a change, and doesn't feel like mindless chores. Each scene has much to do, and there may be 3 or 4 close up areas to explore. At times, you will have to find parts of items and put them together in your inventory before you can use them.The game has all the bells and whistles. There are hidden object searches (some which require interaction, and the standard type), clever mini games, a fast travel map, a journal for clues, a full strategy guide, and you get a small scarecrow as a helper. The scarecrow helper is the only part of the game I didn't like, as it really seems out of place for this type of game and detracts from the story. You must also collect 25 owls and 7 figurines, which are scattered throughout the game. The game settings are fully customizable, so you can get as much or as little help as you want. The graphics are spectacular, with a high level of detail. The voice-overs, music, sound FX and cut scenes are all very well done.There are 5 chapters in the game, which go by quickly, but there is a bonus game and an extra bonus game. This game is made by MariaGlorum, and if you've had problems or tap response issues with their other apps (Mystery of the Ancients series & League of Light Dark Omens) you will most likely have issues with this one, as I don't think their games run as well on older devices.  I had no tap response issues, glitches, or technical problems playing on kindle HDX 8.9. I really enjoyed this from start to finish, and I highly recommend.

I play a lot of point and click games and usually know within a few minutes if I'm going to like a game. Within a few minutes of playing this one I knew it was not my cup of tea. Something about the game did not click, but I had high hopes since the other "Myths" game (Chinese healer) was very well done. The theme is super natural/Native American meets mystical healer/ghost spirits. Although it is a different type of story, I just didn't connect, and didn't find it interesting.The game has all the usual components we have come to expect: a journal, fast travel map, hint button, hidden object searches (or you can play a bubble shoot game instead), and mini games. There are a couple of other features which require you to find parts of an amulet and you also use special binoculars to see far away items. In this "collector's edition", you find 35 sun runes which are scattered throughout the game. The graphics are average, the voice-overs are well done, and the background music was okay to start, but became irritating noise, and I had to mute it.This is a long game with 8 chapters, a bonus chapter, and bonus content. Right now the game is on sale for $2.99. I didn't have any technical problems playing on Kindle HDX 8.9, but there are some questionable permissions that could cause issues on your device. As I have said before, a lot of work goes into making these games, so I am hesitant to give less than 4 stars, and not every game will appeal to every player.  I would recommend trying the free part and seeing if it is your kind of adventure.

This is a murder mystery point and click adventure, which is on the easy side. You travel to the Holy Mountain Hotel looking for your detective friend James, and discover somebody has been carrying out their own vigilante justice. It's a good story and kept my interest. The game progresses at a decent pace and each scene is well executed, but the adventuring becomes repetitive. I had no problems picking up or using inventory items and everything made sense.There are the usual hidden object searches (not too often), and mini games. The game also includes a detailed journal, fast travel map, a full strategy guide, and you can adjust the difficulty settings. You also collect 22 antiques throughout the game, and 11 collectible figurines. These are accessible in a separate screen. The graphics, music, cut scenes and voice-overs are well done. I had no glitches playing on Kindle HDX 8.9. The game is six chapters, with a bonus chapter, and some additional bonus content, but it is not a long game and I finished in a few hours. I got it on sale for $2.99 and think it was worth the money, but when the price increases to $4.99, it may not be worth it due to length.

This is a fantastic point and click adventure, and the sequel to "Enigmatis: The Ghosts of Maple Creek". You don't have to play the first one to enjoy this game, as it does stand on its own, and the sequel does not disappoint. The gameplay is similar to the first Enigmatis in that you collect evidence to solve a mystery, and are given "objectives" throughout the game to guide your investigation. There is a journal with notes and all your objectives, a map, a hint button, and sparkles overs areas of interest.The game flows intuitively and moves at a good pace. The graphics are detailed and crisp, the voice-overs and cut scenes are well acted, and the music and ambient sounds are perfect. I had absolutely no trouble or glitches playing on kindle fire HDX 8.9. Be aware that this is a large game and took up 1.07 GB, but it downloaded without incident and installed fine. I had no problems collecting or using inventory items, no delay with the tap response, and no loading screens between scenes.The hidden object searches are a bit different - you find items by silhouette or part and then follow steps to ultimately find one object, which goes in your inventory. This is a very long game, including a bonus chapter and an extra 10 page section in which you can read about redwood trees (actually pretty interesting). You also collect "illusive" objects (which are the same as morphing objects) and "ethereal" butterflies throughout the game. There's a lot to do in this game, it's an intriguing mystery which should hold your interest, but is definitely an adult story as there are murders and dead bodies.

I am very impressed with this game, as it is a thoughtful, well-made point and click adventure. The story revolves around a supposed suicide of a famous actress and you play a detective who goes to investigate. Each scene is well executed, the story moves at a good pace and kept my interest throughout. There are some interesting features in the game, such as an evidence board, which you add to as you find new pieces of evidence and meet new characters/suspects. This is separate than your inventory items, which might need an extra step in order for you to use them, such as finding a flare gun but then needing the flares, or finding a locked box and needing a key.There are the typical hidden object searches (or you can play a bubble shoot game instead), and mini games, both are nicely done and not too frequent. The game also includes an interactive map that will fast travel you, a full strategy guide, and hint button. There are also little magnifying glasses over areas of interest, as well as travel arrows (to access these, push the blue button to the left of the inventory banner). There are no loading screens, and each scene transitions smoothly without delay. The graphics are spectacularly detailed, and the voiceovers are very well done. You also find 44 stars, which are hidden throughout the game, and 12 morphing objects, which are only found in the hidden object searches. I had no technical issues playing on Kindle HDX 8.9, although EIPIX games are notoriously glitchy, so beware you may have some issues as you go along - best thing to do is clear the cache in the running application of the game, force close it and start again. I unlocked the full version right away and it is definitely worth the $2.99 (on sale now). This is a long game which includes seven chapters, a bonus chapter and bonus content. It will give you many, many hours of play, and I highly recommend this one.

This is a wonderful fairytale type adventure game with all the bells and whistles. If you liked the first "Grim Legends", you will like this one too. In this game, you play as a healer sent to help the queen of the Eagle Kingdom and her infant son. The story is original and kept my interest. The game is very entertaining, with many cut scenes, dialogue and character interaction. I really enjoyed going to this other world each time I played.The graphics are spectacularly detailed and colorful. The sound, FX, music and voice-overs are all very authentic. The game includes a map which indicates your current location, tells you where actions are available, and will fast travel to any location. There is a quick charging hint button and a notebook which lists all your objectives. There are mini games and hidden object searches, but not overly done. You find the hidden objects by list and also by "parts" - the screen zooms in the HO searches. You also find 31 "healer's signs" which are hidden throughout the game. I had no glitches or technical issues playing on kindle HDX 8.9 (FYI - this game is not compatible with kindle first generation).The game is a decent length with 8 chapters and a bonus adventure. However, the free trial is VERY short, about 10 minutes of play time. I wanted to continue with the unlock and was able to purchase the full game on sale for $3.49. The price will go back up to $4.99 soon, so I suggest buying asap. This game is definitely worth the money, and will not disappoint.

If you're a fan of escape games, you will enjoy this one. The gameplay is straight forward with no obscure or unconventional solutions needed, although some of the puzzles were tricky. There are 15 levels and you must play them in order. Each level is a different, unrelated room. To clear a level, you must escape the room by finding a way to open the door.  You search each room and pick up important items which go into the banner on the right side of the screen. At times you will have to combine items before you can use them in the scene. There are also the usual number codes and various puzzles to solve, so pay attention to any numbers or patterns you see.Other reviews have made mention of random tapping. EVERY escape/point & click game has random tapping to some degree. That is how you "search" the scenes and discover active areas. If you knew exactly where to click, they'd be no point in playing the game.The graphics are simple and easy to see. There is generic "elevator" type music in the background, which you can mute. If you get stuck, there is a YouTube walkthrough available for each level by pushing the settings button on the top right side of the screen.  The game is not terribly difficult, but still presents a challenge and is suitable for all ages and skill levels.

This is an impressive, well made, "true" (meaning no hidden objects) point and click game. It is by the same developers who created "The Lost Ship", which is also a worthwhile game. In this story you travel to Blackthorn castle in search of an artifact. The gameplay is standard point and click - you search each location and pick up useful items which go into your inventory (a satchel on the bottom left of the screen). If you come across an important puzzle clue or code, a camera opens from the satchel and takes a picture of the clue. This is a great feature, and saves you from having to remember or write things down.There is a map which consists of small screenshots of every location. However, locations appear on the map only after you have visited them. Each location is numbered and there are quite a few, but many of them dead end. The map is not interactive, and will not transport you. Be warned - there is a lot of back and forth in this game, and you never get to use an item in the same scene where you picked it up. If you don't have the patience to keep going back and forth, or you have difficulty remembering locations, this game will be frustrating. There are hints available by clicking the notebook in your satchel - this will bring up a written clue with the location number. I liked this hint system because it doesn't give you the answer, just points you in the right direction. If you are still stuck, there is a full walkthrough available online.The graphics are very clear, the music and sound FX are just right, and I had no issues or glitches playing on kindle HDX 8.9. The game is a challenge, but relaxing to play and you can go at your own pace.

This game is a different sort of mystery game than I am used to playing. I will say that I found some parts difficult to follow and maneuver as there are no hints. The story is interesting and involves a string of murders which you are investigating. Each murder takes you to a different location and as you search the room you find inventory items which you pick up. These are used later when needed. This part of the game is standard point and click, however, there is another part of the game which is unique, although frustrating (for me anyway). This involves playing a fictional PC game called "The Source and the Darkness" in each murder location.There is no way to skip playing the "game within the game" (GWIG) part. I appreciate something different, but had problems with the controls, as playing on a tablet is different than playing with a joystick or mouse. There is also a lot of dialogue in the GWIG, and some of the tasks were difficult to figure out. The rest of the game is basically solving puzzles or entering clues, many of which you find in the GWIG. There is a map, and it is the only way to travel from one location to another, as none of the locations connect. The graphics, music and sound FX are all very well done. I had no technical issues or glitches playing on kindle HDX 8.9.Once you get the hang of it, this is a worthwhile game. But be prepared, it is challenging, and you must pay attention to the clues. Thankfully, there is a full walkthrough available online, which I made good use of. If you like having clues readily available, or you don't have much patience, this may not be the game for you. But, if you are looking for something different and don't want a game that plays itself, I highly recommend this one.

This developer, EIPIX, seems to be the only one making point and click games for android. I was very happy with their last few games (Final Cut: Encore, and Myths of the World: Chinese Healer), and this one is decent, but not as good.Firstly, I had no problems, glitches, or technical issues playing on kindle HDX 8.9. and was able to download and install the game in about 10 minutes. I unlocked the full game after the free part ended and the purchase went through just fine. Now on to the story: You are on an airbus (zeppelin) which is downed by red spirit wisp-type demons (yes demons again!) and you crash on a strange and ancient jungle island. Then a blue spirit wisp, who is supposedly good, promises to help you if you find her human form. However, you discover things are not as they seem. It sounds better in type than it actually is, there is not much character interaction, and the adventuring was a bit tedious. Also, the story moves very slowly.The game includes a map (it does NOT fast travel you), a hint button, and a notebook with your "journal" and "objectives". There are mini games and hidden object searches, some have the final object found by answering a riddle, which was different, but not difficult. The graphics are good, but not as detailed as other games, and the music is very good. You also find 40 golden blimps, 14 butterflies and 12 owls, which are hidden throughout the game. One note: when you use inventory items DO NOT drag them, instead, tap the item, then tap where you want it to go. If you are in a hidden object search or some of the mini games, then you DO drag the object to combine with another object when needed. Also, when you travel from scene to scene, you must double-tap the arrow to move.The free part ends quickly, and it is $1.99 (probably $2.99 by now) to continue. The game is not as long as others, with 6 chapters and a bonus part. You also get the strategy guide and other bonus content with the unlock. I lost interest in the game fairly quickly, it just didn't keep my attention, but that could be me. I know a lot of effort goes into creating these games, so in all fairness, I recommend trying the free part and seeing if it's your kind of game.

This is a fairly easy escape game, and enjoyable to play. The goal is to escape each room by finding an access card, which will open the door to the next room. You find the access card by searching the room for important objects, hints, and clues. You pick up the objects by tapping on them, which places them into the inventory banner on the right side of the screen. As you explore, you will use these inventory objects to help escape. (For example, use a corkscrew to open a bottle).  Sometimes you will have to combine inventory items before you can use them in the scene. Pay attention to codes, patterns and numbers - you may want to write some down, or just remember them. Escaping each room took anywhere from a minute to a few minutes, but there is no timer so you can go at your own pace.There are 15 levels and you must play them in order. Some levels have more than one room that you must search. There is very pleasant, meditative background music and good sound FX, both of which you can mute. The graphics are minimalistic, but sharp and easy to see. I have played all the escape games by this developer, and this one is probably their easiest. However, if you need help, there is a walkthrough available for each level that you can easily access at any time. I would recommend this one to all, especially first time escape players, it's simple, but there is some degree of thought and logic required. More experienced players may not find this enough of a challenge. You will know after the first few levels if this is your kind of game.

This is a fantastic "true" (meaning no hidden objects) point and click game. It is by the same developers who made "Alice Trapped In Wonderland", which is also a wonderful game, and the gameplay is similar. In this story, you travel to an island in search of the Fountain of Youth. The game is loosely separated into 5 parts, which correspond to 5 different areas of the island. Be warned that there are many locations, and you search and return to each one several times over as you explore the island. There is a degree of concentration needed to remember all the locations/scenes and what actions can be taken in each one. As you go along, you pick up items, solve puzzles, and read journal entries.There is a full written hint system which you can access at any time, and a notebook which keeps track of all the important symbols and clues. There is also a map with small screenshots of every scene, but they only appear after you have visited that particular area. The map is not interactive, and will not transport you. The graphics are very detailed, and the music is perfect. All inventory items are labeled, and stored in a chest on the bottom left of the screen, which you tap to open. I had no trouble accessing or placing the inventory items, and no glitches playing on kindle fire HDX 8.9. However, at times my inventory banner would not scroll to the left. To fix, I just closed the chest and reopened.Although there are some challenging parts, which require logic and thought, the game is relaxing to play and you can go at your own pace. Unlike some that you can complete in an hour or two, this game is quite long and will give you many, many hours of play. I highly recommend this for all point and click fans.

I really enjoyed this game, this is one you will not be disappointed with. I liked the first Web of Deceit, but the game had so many technical problems and glitches, I was never able to finish it. Thankfully, I had no glitches or problems with this game playing on kindle fire HDX 8.9. I was not kicked out of the game, nor did it crash, stall, freeze or act up. (If playing on a different device, you may have some problems). I did get a message when opening the game about local and global progress not matching, I have no idea what it meant, but I pushed the "use global" button and never had any trouble.The story is a continuation of the first installment, with lots of intrigue and a mysterious woman who is more than likely very evil. The game has a nice pace to it and really held my interest, I played until the wee hours of the morning..The graphics are spectacularly crisp and detailed, some of the best I've seen. There seem to be a lot of cut scenes, but they are short and not too distracting. There are hidden object searches (I know some of you really dislike them), but not too many and they are done with a slight level of difficulty. You have to complete another step or two to find some objects. I did not find the game very difficult, but there are hints if you get stuck, an interactive map, a journal, arrows to show available directions of travel, magnifying glasses over areas of interest and hands over items that can be picked up (in casual mode). I was able to pick up and use all inventory items with no lag time or tap response issues. Also, none of my inventory items went missing. I did not care for most of the mini games; I found them more confusing than fun.The game has a lengthy bonus chapter which continues the story. I recommend this one for all, so far it's one of my favorites for the year.

Firstly, I had a few minor glitches playing on kindle fire HDX 8.9. I purchased the full game from the free version. The game downloaded just fine (took about 10 minutes with wifi), and I was able to play without incident - at first. Then, the third time I opened the game I got a black screen. I shut off the kindle, restarted, and the game was fine after that. Also while playing I noticed some actions and tap responses were a bit slower than I liked - especially when investigating a close up scene or placing an inventory item. At times, the game almost stalled (more like a sputter), but never did completely, and I was able to play OK without any other severe problems. Having said that - WOW - this is a good game! It reminds me of the older Alawar games. The story has many twists and turns (missing people, giant octopus, curses, mystery to be solved) and the game execution is very well done - it held my interest throughout. The graphics are spectacular, and each scene has a high level of detail. The music and ambient sound was just right.The gameplay is basic point and click where you find and pick up useful items, put them in your inventory and use them accordingly when needed. Nothing was too difficult to figure out, but if you need help there is a hint button, a journal, and a strategy guide. You can choose from 3 difficulty levels. There is a map, and another map, and yet another map in the journal. There are hidden object searches and mini puzzles, which were interesting and I took the time to figure them out. You also find 39 hidden turtles throughout the game.This game is really fun to play with a lot to do, and it is a good length with 6 chapters and a bonus chapter. However, the download is very large at 1.1 GB, so be aware and make sure you have the space. I also think it runs better on newer devices and/or ones with plenty of free space. I definitely recommend this one, and hopefully you can work around the glitches, it is a very worthwhile game.

This is a gem of a game! I play many point and click games, but this one is both unique and thoughtful, and really in a category all its own (although it did remind me of "Shapik the Quest"). In this story, you guide Josef the robot to save his girlfriend from the Blackcap Brotherhood. The gameplay is standard point and click: you pick up useful objects as you explore each scene and use them at the appropriate time. Unlike other games, the objects do not go into an inventory banner, instead, the robot eats them. There is a sense of humor throughout the game.The graphics are stunning with hand drawn artwork, and really set the mood for this steampunk adventure. The music is great. I found the game to be a challenge, and really had to think in order to move forward and solve the puzzles. There are no easy actions here (like find a key and open a chest), you must consider the whole scene and what the robot can do - for example, his body can extend up or squish down. At times, I could clearly see what needed to happen, but simply couldn't figure out how to get it done. The game offers help, but even that was difficult to figure out, and I overlooked the whole help guide the first hour I played.  Alternatively, there are many walkthroughs available online.I recommend this adventure for those who have the patience to figure things out and want to take their time. I was actually very frustrated when I first played it, and sent it to the cloud. However, on my second (or third) attempt, the game clicked, and I found it captivating. This is not a game to rush through, or one you play when you're looking to waste a few minutes. It requires attention and some degree of concentration. I recommend this one, as it is very worthwhile.

I have several colors of these lights now in my front yard and I must admit that this color is my favorite.I placed the solar panel in direct sun for a day to let it charge up.  Then I strung it around my rosemary shrub and turned it on.  The thin double-wire copper is hardly noticeable during the day, but at dusk these lights come on and light up the shrub.  The lights are small and do not emit heat.The first six feet of this wire is coated in clear silicone and contains no lights.  This allows the string to be placed up off the ground.  Each light is two inches apart from the other lights.  There is an on/off button and a mode button, allowing the lights to flash, blink, fade, strobe or just stay on.  They shine all night long.  The entire light set is small and packs away easily.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

I bought these because they are not cotton.  Cotton socks get sweaty and don't dry out very quickly. I don't want to be on a long hike and have to change my socks because they are damp.  Polyester does dry faster.  These are comfy socks and fit well.  The only complaint is that they do make my feet smellier.  Guess that's the trade-off for not wanting to wear cotton.

Have a household with diverse tastes in chocolate? This is a nice variety. My husband immediately grabbed the milk and dark chocolate and left me the rest.  I like the Fruit and Nuts and also the almonds one.  The Caramello one is our least favorite because the caramel oozes out too much.  There are two bars per variety and all bars come packed tightly in another box to keep heat out.  Each bar is 3.5 ounces.The chocolate is not too sweet and has a soft melt.

This is basic parchment paper made into sheets that fit most standard baking pans.  Just place one down on a pan and place the cookie dough or whatever is getting baked, on these sheets.  They stay flat.  After the baking is done, the baked goods do not stick to the paper, making removal of cookies or whatnot easier than using no parchment paper at all.  This may be a pricey way to bake cookies, but clean-up is easy and fast.The paper leaves no aftertaste on the cookies.

We use our dish washer for most dishes, but some things just need extra help coming off, like baked scalloped potatoes lingering on a Purex baking dish.  I soaked my pan in warm water for an hour, then took this scrubber cloth on it and easily got most of the baked-on residue off with little effort.On our cookware, this leaves no marks and on regular dishes, this cloth takes things off better than a sponge.  Another plus is that this scrubber doesn't fall apart as easily as a sponge does.  Soap stays in the cloth but water and debris go through itI'm using one scrubber for dishes and another scrubber for our windows.  Sun-dried debris came right off with this thing.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

OXA makes quality canvas bags and this one is no exception.  There is plenty of room here in a small space, and pockets are well-organized to give even small objects their own area.  A small 7" or 8" tablet fits well in any of the pocketsAll six generic zippers glide well, which is the first thing I test.  There is no hesitance or stoppage anywhere.  All external zippers have gliders attached to them, making these easier to grab when in a hurry.  There are three pockets in this bag, with the center pocket the biggest. Here is where bulkier objects no more than three inches thick would fit nicely. Inside the center pocket is also a mesh pocket, ideal for loose change or other small objects.  Across from the mesh pocket is a smaller, zippered pocket.The front pocket has eight credit card-sized slots and one slot for a thick pen.  All these slots are ideal for business travelers who have a habit of picking up business cards.  A checkbook can also fit inside the upper slot.  This pocket is covered by a thick canvas flap that is held in place by velcro with another 7" pocket available for quick access.The pocket in the rear closest to the body is the smallest pocket.  It measures 8" diagonally.There are two slots on the sides of this bag, one on each side.  The slots are deep enough for a small smart phone, keys or other small electronic device.This is a well-made bag.  All the seams are tight.  A lot of important things can be carried in this thing.  The enclosed shoulder strap is long enough to be worn across the shoulders for added security, but the bag can also be carried by the hand strap on top.  Overall, this is a very useful and diverse bag that will fit all kinds of needs, and best for someone who does not want to carry a bulky bag, but wants a bag that organizes the smaller things into easily-accessible smaller pockets.  My sample is a handsome charcoal grey, and the dye is even across the material.  The inside pockets are lined with brown polyester.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This is the story of a school that a Hazara man founded to educate his village's children, located outside the city limits of Kabul.  Teacher Aziz taught his students that they must think independently and critically, and question authority.  He is a well-respected man by both students and adults.  His students have been accepted to universities across Europe. What author Jeffrey Stern does here is portray him, several of his students, and describes how his school fared when the Taliban took over his country, and then as the school had to prepare to make it again on its own once the Americans leave.Stern's narrative is very personal and it gets the reader feeling compassionate about all the players in this story.  Even the Americans are depicted as wanting to help, but are held back by military bureaucracy.  Even the Russians under their occupation allow for education for all Afghans, including girls, and several students portrayed tell Stern that their literacy began when the Soviets were in charge, but once they left the suffering under a leaderless government began.The chapters are chronological, from the school's beginning to the end of American occupation.  Will the school survive?  Will Teacher Aziz survive?  Will the girls and women who learn under Teacher Aziz survive? Stern always writes with the student's point of view in mind, so memory may be incorrect or the trauma more embellished than it really was.  There is joy and sadness in this story, but in the end what remains is human determination.  An educated mind does not easily give up, or forget, once the window of opportunity is opened.
My grandson won't touch this (he does not like this brand at all) but I find this soothing for mild throat irritations.  It has a citrusy taste.

The material is very soft, but thin.  This is a pretty sweater for indoors, but for extreme cold this would not keep very warm.  It's a lovely autumn top, though, that hangs loosely in the middle.  The giraffes are definitely a conversation piece since these animals aren't depicted much.

This has quite a tasty sweetness to it.  The spray delivery works well, and as long as the nozzle isn't touched by human lips, it's safer to take the vitamins this way than via a spoon.  I don't taste anything artificially sweet about this.  It's tart, but quite good.

This is a fast and practical 3-port hub. It's also attractive.  I can quickly download images from my SD card while also having three other USB plugs attached.  There's also a macroSD slot as well.  The center blue light comes on when this is in use.  This will stay in my laptop bag for when I need to download images while on the road.No other software is needed for this use.  Just plug and play.  My PC took to this right away.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

This little night light is a soothing addition to any room.  I plugged it in last night and got to fall asleep to the faint colors it cast as it changed from blue to purple to red to green and yellow and white and cycled through the colors until daybreak.  The stems of the mushrooms are only three inches tall and are flexible.  The llight isn't bright so it won't keep people awake, but it does cast enough light to allow people to see where they are walking.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

This is a very nice commuter bag for anyone who doesn't like carrying the kitchen sink to outings, or anyone who doesn't want or need bulky bags.  It has one main compartment and two smaller ones.  It's big enough to carry all essentials.  It can carry a 10" tablet, but a 11" Chromebook is already too big.  The largest compartment has room for a tablet, a book, a water bottle and perhaps some snacks.  There is a smaller department for a cell phone and other small gadgets. Another zippered 5x7 internal compartment also has room for more sensitive documents.There are two smaller compartments on the front, both which have zippered closings.  The lower compartment has room for a packed sandwich or other edibles.  The top compartment has room for perhaps sunglasses.The one lightly-padded adjustable shoulder strap can be snapped over the left or right shoulder.  The material overall is a faded grey canvas that is very sturdy.  The one flaw in my sample is the zipper on the lower outside pocket.  It's not as smooth as the other zippers, even after oiling it. Overall, the design is very pleasing to both women and men of all ages.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This is the first Chuckit Toy I just don't like.  I'm no archer but I can't get this dart to launch farther than 20 feet!  I'm better off throwing it, and Chuckit makes plenty of great balls for that.  The dogs don't mind the dart and can easily grab on to it, as its diameter is ideal for their mouths, but my older GSD prefers to chew on this rather than fetch it.  The trouble lies in the launching.  The elastic isn't very strong.  The launcher and dart both float (see my photos).  My sample is a bright green which is easily found in grass.

These jeans fit me perfectly!  The material is definitely stretchy, but my butt crack is spared public exposure because these jeans' "no gap" texture really do keep that gap in the crack area to a minimum.  The jeans are high enough up the waist to be comfortable without being too mommily, avoiding any blubbery muffin top from hanging over.  I ordered a L for my 5'7" height and my jeans come down to the middle of my shoes.  The dye is a dark, even blue.There is a different material break-down listed on the pants' label, though.  It says 60% cotton, 22% Rayon, 17% polyester and 1% Spandex.  The product write-up says this is 71% cotton, 21% Rayon, 7% Polyester and 1% Spandex.  Jeans made in Egypt.

These headphones are nice.  Very nice.  The ear pad is soft fake PU leather, the microphone is folded back into the headset when not in use, the cable is reinforced and coated with a clear silicone cover, the USB plug is gold-plated for better reception.  There is another soft head pad to keep the phones from falling.  The controls are on the left ear phone. My sample is black.The audio is also very clear, with a nice range from bass to soprano.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

This bra fits as expected.  It's itchy at first, brand new, but softens up after the first wash.  It's actually a bit on the thin side with little padding, but this is a nice look under a thin top.  I always wear camisoles underneath my shirts at work.  The straps are snug against the shoulders and don't fall off.  The back side is a thin mesh which can get ripped in a normal washing cycle.

This is a sturdy colander.  My older one was aluminum and had gotten dented over the years.  It also didn't have a base. This one is larger than my old one AND it has a base to keep this colander upright when in the sink without having the food actually touch the sink. This is a nice feature to have.  My sink is too large for the handles to cradle the rim, so this way of draining water from food works best for me. From big portions of pasta, potatoes or other boiled vegetables, this is a nice sample to have in the kitchen.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

This is a fascinating story but it's not presented very well.  There is mention early on that there's already a movie in the works starring Will Smith and the first chapter is a courtroom scene with Dr Bennet Omalu having to tesitfy against his former mentor and supervisor Dr Wecht.  So what went wrong?  Movies tend to start out with an opening climax and then show the audience how it came to be.That style may work in movies, but it's harder in literature.  Jeanne Marie Laskas uses first person and third-person narrative to interchangeably tell the story.  The italics are the doctor's words, the rest is her back story.  It can get confusing.  She goes back to Bennet's traumatizing childhood in Nigeria during its Civil War.  Omalu is an Igbo, a Christian tribe from the southern part of the country that was the target of the Muslim Hausa tribe from the north.  He was a smart but lazy boy, but with luck and family ties was able to attend medical school and then study further in the United States, where he was subjected to racism from the start.  Knowing what the end story is, it's hard to focus on this part that seems to ramble on too much.The build-up to the courtroom drama is steady but predictable once the reader learns about Omalu's task to conduct an autopsy on the brain of a former Pittsburgh Steeler.  He had always worked under Dr Wecht, himself a poor kid from eastern Europe,seldom signed his name to his studies, and now he was in the forefront. Laskas is very fair at showing strengths and weaknesses by all the main characters.  The NFL's legal team doesn't even get involved until almost half-way into the story and the pace picks up, and this is where the beginning backdrop of Omalu becomes important.  All the good that Omalu had done as a forensics expert under Dr Wecht now becomes scrutinized, including Omalu's bouts of depression and other character flaws.  In the end this story is about a Nigerian doctor and his work fighting against the NFL.  I can see why this was quickly chosen as a movie; the Good Boy done Wrong mantra is popular here.3+This is not a long book, but even then the first part is all background.

I like how this applicator works.  Dab the liquid in three separate areas along the back, rub it in using gloves, and fleas or ticks will die off.  We have a tick issue this year but this stuff kept the ticks away off of the dog I tried this on.  I'd comb the dog with my groomer and never found one tick in the comb. The stuff smells strong, but it's no worse than other tick and flea repellent.

This case is for the 2015 Kindle Fire 7" only.  The case fits this tablet well.  Pop the tablet into the upper and lower sleeve and this will not budge.  The front stays connected to the back via two magnets, one on either upper and lower right side.  There is also an elastic stylus holder.This case does not cover the headphone outlet, volume buttons,mic, USB mini port or the on/off button.  The elastic strap in the upper right partially covers the macroSD slot, but that is easily pushed to the side.The material is a polyurathane with little to no smell.  This cover also has a flip-out stand for using horizontally, such as for streaming videos.  The stand does not work in the vertical position.This is a fine case and does what it's meant to do:  protect the tablet's screen and provide for some grip while holding the thing.  The purple is a nice lavender and nothing too flashy.

This light has several very good selling points:  it's lightweight, at only 3.2 ounces (once three AAA batteries are installed, which do not come with this purchase) , it has a very comfortable head strap that adjusts to most head sizes and the price makes this very affordable for those who only need headlamps occasionally.The light is quite bright when tested outdoors, and the beam does spread out more than it does indoors.  Pull the scope out for a more narrow beam (better for close-up jobs).  One can adjust the angle easily from the headset and it will "click" when it's in position.  There's a straight beam, a 30' beam, and a 5' beam.  As for the light, there's a dim, bright and blinking mode that is adjustable from the one top button.  You cycle through all lights by pressing on that button.  The scope is about two inches long and about 2.25 inches when extended.Getting to the battery compartment is a bit tricky, though.  You need to press down on both side buttons to open it.  The three AAA batteries, which are not included in this price, fit snugly inside.This is a very nice light for indoor and outdoor use.  It's not waterproof, though, but it's fine for hiking, walking, running and cycling, as long as you don't overshoot the light.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

I have now tried three different Eukanuba recipes this week and this one's the best.  This one actually has healthy ingredients in it and no corn, which gives many dogs the squirts.  I have learned after sampling the Eukanuba Large Breed Puppy and Weight Maintenance recipes, that the quality of Eukanuba's kibble is as diverse as there are dog breeds on this planet.  I've learned to pay attention to ingredients.  The ingredients for this recipe are listed here on Amazon.  Interestingly, the recipes for the Large Breed Puppy and Weight Maintenance, both which contain corn meal as #1 and #2 ingredients respectively, are NOT listed on the company's Amazon pages.  I wonder why that is?The kibble here is smaller than a US Dime and of a medium shade of brown.  My dogs are liking this formula.  This formula is definitely one of the company's better formulas.

This oil certainly has an interesting scent.  It's like a combination Patchouli-Tamanu scent, both which are a bit too much for me, too pungent-musky.  Olive oil is listed as the #5 inactive ingredient, and perhaps that is where the smell is coming from.  Luckily the oil absorbs very fast on dry skin and the scent quickly dissipates. It also moisturizes very well, something I've noticed after using this for a few days. One big drop from the dropper covered my face, but this needs to be reapplied every two hours if in the sun.Active Ingredients are Avobenzone 2.96%, Homosalate 8.78%, Octosalate 4.88%, Otocrylene 5.92%

This stuffed beagle may not be life size for a beagle, but it sure does come close as a beagle puppy in size and coloring.  This stuffed dog is slightly larger than my six-year-old adult cat Pache Boy (whose current nick name is much less flattering for reasons I won't divulge here), but much less lighter than a real beagle pup.  The innards are soft, so there's no loud rustling from the inside when hugging this dog.  The eyes are the only part that are "off" as my sample's left eye has black liner that doesn't outline the eye.  The dog also has no whiskers.  The floppy ears are sewn to remain downward.The dog is made to remain in a sitting position, so this will go well on a bed cover, a desk, or even in a car (but be careful of sun fading).I received a free sample in exchange for a review
The tablets seem to be preferable for my grandson.  He doesn't sit still for us to apply this to his gums., and most oozes out with his drool.  He doesn't mind the taste, though.

What lovely lights!  I have an older set of these kinds of thin, double-wire copper lights but they do not come with a remote.  For first-time users, be gentle when unraveling these, as the copper wire can easily become entangled in itself.  The remote and the white adapter (which connects the two black ends to allow the remote to work) are inside the plastic coil.  A CR2025 battery is already included for the remote.  Just remove the plastic safety tape and the set is ready to go. These lights are very lightweight, which is a big plus when putting up lights anywhere.The remote has a range of about 30 feet, which is what most bluetooth ranges are.  The red button in the upper left is the on/off switch, and the blue button in the lower left is the mode switch.  The lights have six different settings. You can change the settings of the light from solid, to  flash, blink, wave, fade and strobe.  I prefer my lights to not blink or flash.The lights themselves are a little bigger than tear drop and are four inches apart from one another.  They emit a soft yellow light. The copper wire is very bendable and these lights can be wrapped around most anything for a festive effect.  These lights are designed for indoor use, due to the electric plug on one end, although the lights themselves are waterproof.The only instructions that come with these lights are found  on the cardboard that comes inside the plastic.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This nylon rope or "paracord" is what one needs at a campsite for a variety of reasons.  The orange is bright enough during the day to warn passers-by of tent pegs and other hazards on or near the ground.  It's great for tying bags up to trees, and it's useful for other small chores.There is some reflective material in this nylon, but it's not a super-bright quality.  Throw a roll in your camp box and you'll be set for many emergencies.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

What a soft, warm jacket this is.  It's fake leather but it feels like the real deal. There are lots of pockets in this thing:  two breast pockets, two hand pockets and two inside pockets.  The hoodie can be removed but I prefer this with it on for when that wind blows.  If you are broad-shouldered but normally wear a size medium, size up one for a looser, more comfortable fit.

This is a very attractive aerator/chiller.  I had the rod in the freezer for over a day. I personally do not like cold wine, but wine that's slightly chilled is OK.The first thing I noticed is that the rod takes up volume in the bottle.  I had to pour some wine out (don't worry, it didn't get wasted!) before the rod would fit nicely in the bottle, with it screwed on to the pourer.  Both pourer and rod stay in place; there is no wobbling.  But perhaps because I used this on a 1.5 liter bottle of wine, I must say there was no big difference between the wine's temperature before and after the rod was inserted.  For having been in the freezer overnight, I was surprised at how not-so-chilled this wine was after 30 minutes.Some people may be annoyed that some of the wine has to be poured out before this rod is inserted, however, for large parties this is a nice thing to have for perhaps a .75-liter bottle that doesn't need as much time to get chilled.  The combination rod and pourer look really nice together.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

The one thing about this formula that I like is the faint cucumber aroma.  Applying this is a bit different than some of the other XEN-TANs I have tried.  With this one, it's best to use it BEFORE taking a shower and let the lotion absorb for 45 minutes to a few hours before washing it off.  Also it's best to use a mitt or wear vinyl gloves before applying.  The tan that comes from this format is a natural-looking tan.  The longer you let it absorb, the darker the results.  There is a slight olive hue to this, so ghosts should not use this.

Wow.  These are very attractive and comfortable headphones.  My sample sits right over my ears and provides for some noise blockage. They come with their own hard vinyl zippered carrying case that will come in handy during air flights, road trips and carrying from home to school or the office.  The head strap is adjustable.  The soft pads are fake leather and comfortable.  There is no unnecessary writing or gizmos on these headphones so even adults can use them.The headphones are indicated with L and R for the proper ear.  The cord is a 3.5mm cable that is covered in nylon, making this more durable.  The inline control and mic are adjusted from a button halfway down this cable.All around, the audio is quite good, but I'm no audiophile.  The range from bass to treble sounds good to me.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This is a well-made wine bottle opener made of stainless steel and dark wood that packs small.  The design is the standard corkscrew in the middle design, which folds into itself twice for easy transport.  It comes in a nice black cardboard box with molded styrofoam, to prevent the opener from rattling around.  Directions on how to use this are on a small card that's inside the box.I like the foil cutter on one end.The only thing that's a little imperfect is the sealant on the wood.  It looks uneven to me, and creates a partial shine on both sides, as if the sealant was applied unevenly and settled thicker in the wood's pores.  This doesn't take from the opener's performance, but for an observant eye, is not very attractive and may be enough to look elsewhere.I was given a free sample in exchange for a review.

This is the iRulu X7 with QuadCore-A33 Processor, 4.4.2 Android version with v2.0 Firmware and 3.4.39 Kernel version.  My sample is in a purplish-blue cover.For basic internet surfing, email, Facebook and other social media, this isn't a bad little tablet for the price.It comes with a keyboard, connecting cable and carrying case.  The case adds bulk and weight, but it protects the tablet's screen and makes the device easier to carry.  The case closes with a magnetic strip.  This tablet can be placed upright with the stand in the back of the case, for easier viewing and typing. The case holds the tablet inside securely with elastic corner grips.One must first sign in using one's preferred email address before setting up the date, time, year and connect to one's Google account.But there are other things that make this tablet cumbersome.  The touchscreen isn't very responsive.  The tablet tends to freeze. Not all apps work with this tablet.  Everything is slow to download, if it downloads at all. Netflix doesn't work with this tablet and many other cites like CNN don't work.  My German telenovella comes in garbled.  The few short videos I have watched tend to freeze. All the games that are featured in the iRulu folder warn you that they are not safe and can steal private information from your SD card and accounts.  (The games appear to be bootlegged versions of the copyright versions.)Video and audio quality are decent for a tablet in this price range.  There is a headphone port. The camera takes decent photos. One can disconnect the keyboard and remove the tablet from the case and  a touch-keyboard will pop up on the tablet.  However, other than the USB cord that comes with this, there is no AC adaptor for this device.(I thought I was missing one, contacted the company, and was told there is no AC adaptor with this tablet.)  This means that the included USB cord that comes with this tablet is the only means to charge this tablet, and there is only one macroUSB port, and that's the one for the keyboard.  This tablet does work while charging.  It also has a front and rear camera (3MP, 2MP) but the rear camera is covered by the case and obviously only works when one takes the tablet out of its cover.The Google apps seem to work well.  I can ask Google questions, I can use the GPS and view movies via Google.  .This isn't a bad tablet, but one must be aware of its limitations.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

Eukanuba is marketing this as a high-end diet food for dogs by giving it some exotic name, but its first ingredient is corn meal?  And yet in the product write-up the company claims  "EUKANUBA Adult Weight Control Dog Food is designed to give adult dogs the key nutrition they need without the extra calories. Our weight management formula, with real chicken as the first ingredient..."  This statement is deceptive and needs to be removed!Chicken by-product meal is the second ingredient, "a natural source of chondroitin-sulfate and glucosamine" for joints, but this food is not healthy. Corn is not easily digested by dogs or by humans and is often the #1 source of stomach sensitivities and allergies.  The sugars in corn also are blamed for dental disease in cats and dogs who are fed mostly corn-based food.  I might as well feed my dogs Cheetos.Sadly, my dogs seem to like it.  Even dogs like eating junk food.  But had I known that the first ingredient is corn meal, no way Jose would I have chosen to try this out on my own dogs.The kibble is the size of a US nickel.

Oh my.  My dogs really went after these.  All the meat jerky treats by True Chews are a big hit with my pack.  My dogs are all at least 50 pounds, from 52 to 94 pounds, and can eat up to four a day.  That means this bag won't last long at all.  In fact, I forgot to place this bag high enough on the shelf and my lanky GSD was able to pull the bag down.  All five dogs feasted on all the treats and I woke up to a torn-up bag in the hallway.These only have a faint smell of duck to human noses and aren't sticky or leave an icky feeling on your hands.  They can be torn apart by bending them in half.  I will definitely buy more of these treats, but next time I'm leaving the bag in my truck so that I can use the treats as snacks when I go out hiking with my pack. I don't think hanging this bag in a bearproof canister (like the one required when backpacking California wilderness) and hanging it from our 10-foot ceiling is enough to keep my dogs away from these.

I always appreciate having extra USB cables around because so many things today are using USB cables:  LED desk lamps and flashlights being the newest members.  I tried all the cables on my Samsung and all but one didn't seem to work properly.  I had each one plugged into a 2.4A outlet.These are simple, unmarked black cables of three lengths, and all come in handy for different reasons.  The foot-long cables work best when the PC is horizontal on the desk and the USB outlet is near the desk surface; the six-footer cable is best for when the outlet is under a table.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

If this guide had more photographs, I'd probably give this five stars.  This guide is written by native Brooklynites and illustrated by one.  It has a personal taste, and is very thorough in its many landmarks, be they parks, hotels, restaurants, bars.  Brooklyn has 30 neighborhoods, and 19 are featured here.I was last in Brooklyn in the mid 1990s.  I walked across the Brooklyn bridge, I walked along the riverwalk facing Manhattan, I even did the 50-mile bike route that starts in Manhattan and, with connecting routes, circumnavigates around Brooklyn before crossing back into Manhattan.  While there are some bike routes mentioned, there isn't much focus on outdoorsy things besides the Coney Island boardwalk, river views, a few small parks and rooftop gardens. Brooklyn is a labyrinth of neighborhoods and all have their unique landmarks which the authors want to stress, so take a walk through the streets and grab some grub and brew afterwards.  This guide is aimed for people like me who do just that.  Locals (mostly business people) are briefly interviewed about their hood or their business to add that local flair.Photos are needed to show the architecture, the colors, the ethnic diversity that is Brooklyn. Brooklyn truly is beautiful but one doesn't get a sense of that from this book. But, all aside, this guide is a nice start and there are some unique facts mentioned throughout this book (ever heard of the Brooklyn wild monk parrots?), but despite all the knowledge in this guide, without enticing photographs of the landmarks, this is nothing more than a barhopper's brew guide.

Think of these as dog biscuits with Glucosamine-Chondroitin in them.  The primary ingredient is wheat flour, which one of my GSDs will not touch.  The biscuits are two inches long and about a half-inch wide and crumble into smaller pieces when broken apart, so best to give these whole to Fido.  They smell of baked dough flavored with chicken.  The bag is resealable, which is always a plus, and can fit in a pouch when out training a dog.  Dogs that are used to getting dog biscuits will surely love these bars and do cart wheels for them, but for prissy GSDs, perhaps not so much.

My sample is a pretty blue with black highlights, a color combination that goes well with anyone.Initially I thought these were rather small, but each pack does hold quite a bit, and make traveling easier.  The largest pack can holdtwo pairs of heavy pants, or a heavy jacket.  Imagine if your luggage is ripped open, or breaks apart and all your clothes spill out.  At least with these, your clothes are separated into smaller bits and press into smaller cubes.  They do add some weight to the total luggage, so if you have a 50-pound weight limit like American Airlines tends to enforce on its passengers and you are close to that limit, it's best to use a lighter carrying device.The smallest pack is indeed very small, but can be used for socks and undies.  The laundry bag is best for dirty/soiled clothes that doesn't need to be compressed, but can also be used for boots or shoes.The included silk eye mask was a surprise.  That thing fits well around my head but I get claustrophobic wearing one.  I know, call me odd.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

What a neat device for anyone with limited arm mobility or other mobility issues.  This hook tool is the length of an average human palm.  Just place the button between the wire and pull through the button hole.  No more twisting and turning the hand!  This still works best when another person does this for you, however, that's not always possible.  Like a shoehorn for shoes, this is nice to have for buttons.  The handle is plastic with ridges near the wire for added grip.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This is a beautiful, heavy coffee table book with beautiful photographs of some of the country's most unique gardens.  Many of them once started out as private gardens on estates, others were always public.  The photographs show close and far shots, so one can get an idea of texture and color composition, although this book does not describe the planting and care of each garden.This book comes wrapped in clear plastic.  It's a book one can page through for hours just looking at the garden designs, reading up on some of the gardens' histories, or just to look through for planting ideas.This is a great book for a gardener.

This is a small bottle with very small pills.  These pills dissolve quickly under the tongue and leave no bitter aftertaste.  I've used these myself this past week, trying to calm down in the evening after busy work days.  This works even better after some chamomile tea.  It's a product I would buy again for restlessness.  Adults take four pills a day.

This is a very nice facial steamer.  It works much like a standard diffuser, with a water tank inserted that quickly heats up for steam.  The big difference is that this thing does not run continuously like a diffuser.  This thing gets hot fast to open the pores.  The instructions are in poorly-written English but anyone who has used a diffuser will know how to use this thing.The instructions say not to add any oils to it or else it shortens the lifespan of the steamer. Distilled water is suggested, since most water contains minerals that can quickly corrode or clog tubings. The steamer shuts off after ten minutes. It's not to be used as a humidifier for long, either.This steamer helps open up and clean pores and sinuses.I received a free sample in exchange for a review

We always have a lot of batteries in our closet because we have a lot of flashlights and other electronics that use various batteries.  This helps organize various sized batteries for quick use, but I did find the AAA slots too large. It has room for ten AAA batteries, but there is enough room to squeeze almost an 11th battery. Since most AAA batteries are sold in packs of four, having room for 12 batteries would have been ideal.  Subsequently, the AAA batteries don't fit as they should.  The 26 x AA battery slots are a little bit snugger, but still allow some wiggling. The slots for C and D cell batteries also don't feel very snug. I did not bother mounting this due to the weight of a full rack and instead have this organizer flat on a shelf.The battery tester is a nice addition.  Note that the fresher the battery, the brighter ALL THREE LIGHTS will shine.  This can test all the batteries in the organizer.  For 9V batteries, just place the ends on the right side of the tester.  For botton batteries, they are placed within the circle.I received a free copy in exchange for a review

Like other True Chews treats, these are very popular with my dogs.  These treats are big enough for big dogs to take, and soft enough to break apart effortlessly with the creases in these treats.  They don't crumble, snap or create sharp edges because the vegetable glycerin and dried cane syrup in these give these that "moist" feel to it.  The ingredients in these are like the other chicken-based treats by this company and contain chicken, ground rice, black beans, dried apples, tapioca starch, salt, distilled vinegar and natural flavors and the previously-mentioned items.

I have five dogs and you get five antler pieces in this bag.  Antlers are dense and dogs can gnaw on them for hours, which is what mine do.  These have been cleaned of any debris and felt and don't have any odor to them.  They are bone and are painful when stepped on.  My dogs gnawed on their piece for a few hours yesterday, but now are abandoned in the back yard.  I've brought home antlers from the forest that got more attention than the ones in this bag, so these weren't as big a hit as other BBS products.

I ordered a pair of these in grey when they were a Gold Box deal, but what I received was not as shown.  Instead, I got a Gold Toe Women's Missy Mule slippers which aren't as comfortable as slip-on featured in the ad.  I didn't return them because I needed new slippers today and not four days from now.Interestingly, when I went over to the Gold Toe Women's Missy Mule slippers page, a customer stated that she got these slipons instead, so there must be a big mix-up at the warehouse for these.The slippers I have are basic fake fur slippers that fit well but still need some breaking-in time as the soles are flat and not quite smooth enough.  The slippers fit well around the foot.  I only paid USD10.60 for these so I didn't return them, but for the full price I'd have complained.

My dogs are big fans of all chicken and beef treats and these are no exception.  You get around 32 pieces of these semi-moist treats  They have ridges in them from which to break off smaller bits, which is perfect for training.  These leave no residue in the hand, nor give the dog bad reactions.  My dogs are all over 50 pounds and I'm allowed to give them each three pieces a day, according to the instructions.  The bag is resealable. which I appreciate..Top ingredients are chicken, ground rice, vegetable glycerin, dried cane syrup, natural flavors, tapioca starch, salt, distilled vinegar, natural smoke flavor and caramel for color.

Glass infusers are the big rave at my school.  Even students bring them to class and sip from them.  This glass is tall and narrow, perfect for most hands, and holds well, albeit it's a tad heavy being glass.  The top is plastic and silicone.  The diffuser is also plastic with a silicone top as well.A silicone bottom keeps this from slipping off a level surface.  The handle is also silicone that is attached to a plastic ring around the top..  One drinks from this plastic top, but it doesn't leave a weird plastic aftertaste like all-plastic bottles do that have been in the sun all day.  It also fits well in a car's cup holder.This is an attractive water bottle to have in an office setting, where glass can easily be kept on a level surface while working.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This is a steady preventative against joint inflamation that takes effect a few weeks after taking it on a regular basis.  The capsules are on the small size but require water to swallow as the capsules are dry.  These leave no bitter aftertaste or give any other side effects.  I take one of these a day with a glucosamine capsule.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

My dogs seem to like all the True Chews.  These are like the beef version, with the same size and consistency and ingredients.  These contain chicken, rice, vegetable glycerin, whole grain rolled oats, black beans, chickpeas, pea protein, dried cane syrup, dried apples, tapioca starch, salt, distilled vinegar, natural flavors, colored with paprika and caramel.  These are semi-soft and break apart easily without crumbling or sticking.

These are very comfortable, knee-length socks.  They glide on easy over the legs and hold up well.  They are ideal for cold-weather climates as this is a thick, stretchable yet compressable fabric.  The feet are reinforced, the seam goes just over the toes  They keep the feet warm.  I ordered a size M and they fit perfectly.  The 25% Spandex is noticeable.  This stretch fabric also prevents the material from soaking up moisture and allowing it to air dry rather quickly.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

This bra is more comfortable than expected.  The material all around is soft and pliable. The fit is perfect.  It comes with three sets of hooks with an additional three-hook extender, making the expandability three inches wide.  This is ideal for nursing mothers who experience bloating.  The shoulder straps are also adjustable.The nursing pads are easily removed from the top of each cup.  The cups are soft and would fit an A-C cup well.  The design is very attractive, with the polka dots and lace up front.A big turn-off for me is the tag.  It's entirely in Chinese.  I'm a M in US sizes but I ordered an XL and it fit me perfectly.  If a US audience is the target audience, sizes should reflect American sizes and tags should be written in English, just as customers would expect to see when shopping in local stores.  This would guarantee a wider customer base.I received a free sample in exchange for a review.

These were surprisingly a big hit for all five of my dogs.  The aroma of carrots envelopes you when you open the bag.  The treats are semi-moist and break apart easily without crumbling, so you can make smaller training treats for the dogs.The strips are about two inches by a half-inch in size.  Top ingredients are beef, chicken, vegetable glycerin (that adds the moistness), whole grain ground brown rice, whole grain rolled oats, rice, black beans, pea protein, dried carrots, chickpeas, dried cane syrup, natural flavors, tapioca starch, salt, distilled vinegar, colored with caramel.

I was given a fluorescent green band with my sample.  I didn't care for the color but I did like the band's snug wrap-around qualities. It felt comfortable against the skin and didn't slide up and down the arm.The watch itself kept great time and the large screen made it easy to read.  Once I figured out the sequence of the buttons (time-date-year) it was easy to figure out the rest.  The backlight helped read time early in the morning.  The watch seemed water resistant as I showered with it on several times. My only trouble was getting accurate mileage readings.  The watch was consistently giving me high mileage.However, the silicone pocket this fit in was too loose for the watch.
