But in a gaming headset, I guess okay audio is indeed okay,  The headset cups fold in at 90 degrees, which makes these slightly easier to carry in a bag .  I don’t have enough experience with sound surround headsets to compare this one with any others, but this one does sound pretty good.Jerry

It will take a while until I’ve used this mouse extensively to render a conclusive opinion, but so far, I like what I’ve experienced. I’ve been using a Logitech MX for a few years and I like it. I should point out that my primary usage is for graphics, not gaming. Key for me is size. I have relatively large hands and I like the mouse to pretty much fill my hand. This one does. It’s a bit more than 5 inches long, more than 3 inches wide and just over 1.5 inches high. It is, indeed, a handful. It has switches galore: 9 programmable buttons, most of which I will never use because I can’t remember from one time to the next what functions I’ve assigned to them. (You download a Windows only app to program the buttons.) There are weights that you can add to tune the mouse to your preference. On the Logitech, it took me only a couple of rounds to do this. The real key for me, aside from feel, is DPI. There are four DPI settings. It will take me a while before I can tell how this is going to do as a graphics mouse over the long haul. I should probably have graduated to a tablet ages ago, but for most of the kind of graphics work I do, a highly controllable mouse works fine. Now I have to see how controllable this mouse is. Ergonomically I am uncomfortable with the sharply sloping contour of the mouse. It is a dramatic change from the shape of the Logitech. Most likely, I just have to become accustomed to it. So far, so good. It will be a bit before I can reach a determination, ut we’re off to a pretty good start.Jerry

For almost all, aging brings a variety of maladies including hearing impairment. That makes for  a lot of “Huhs’, “what did they say?”, “make it louder,  please”. And that’s for the spoken word. Music is another story altogether. That’s part of the reason I was so eager to get these speakers hooked up, which took only minutes. They’re roughly 9x 15 inches and 10 inches deep.  The weight, after so many years of low-cost and frankly lower quality speakers was a surprise, about 15 pounds each. Lacking speaker stands – an absolute must in my opinion, particularly if you have neighbors downstairs – I placed these on the floor, connected them with bare metal stripped wires= ends and let it rip. Wow! I have a pair of pretty good vertical speakers that I purchased many, many years ago and have always considered pretty good. The B6 is a whole different world. To my decrepit ears, the bass was great – maybe even fantastic – and the highs (what I can hear of them) were brilliant. Orff’s “Carmina Burana” had a sparkle and resonance  that I hadn’t heard well in years. Obviously, it’s love at first decibel. If they make a center speaker specifically for pairing with these, I’m getting it. (They have one for another series: I don’t know how it will work with these.Jerry

I’ve had a long time love/hate with Pinnacle. I started using it when it was an independent company and gave up on it when it was acquired by Avid, who (in my opinion) practically destroyed the application and provided simply awful customer support. Like many others, I abandoned Pinnacle. It was bought by Corel and I didn’t have high hopes for it. Much to my surprise, Corel after years of flailing is making a concerted effort to rejuvenate their acquired product lines. PaintShop Pro which was on a downhill path is really a great program in its present iteration. I skipped sever iterations of Pinnacle Studio, but when offered the opportunity to evaluate Pinnacle Studio 19 Ultimate, I figured why not. Overall I think Pinnacle Studio 19 Ultimate is vastly improved since my past outing with the product. But I will be sticking with Cyberlink Director. The feature list is on the Amazon web page, but I suggest you also look at the Pinnacle Systems website as well. Pinnacle does not offer a trial download of Pinnacle Studio 19, but the manual is available. If you’re a Cyberlink Director or Adobe Premiere Elements user considering a switch, I recommend downloading and perusing the manual before purchase. Ultimately it comes down to a user’s preferences. This is probably not a program for absolute beginners, but like Cyberlink Director and Adobe Premiere Elements, it is a good place to continue after using Windows MovieMaker. It installs easily, interfaces are a bit cluttered – which can be said of all its competitors as well – and has some features like 4K that few people will use right now. The New Blue Effects package is nice. In toto, Pinnacle Studio 19 Ultimate is a nice serviceable video editing suite. With all the choices in the market, though, I would advise careful consideration.Jerry

My grandson is getting older. He’s probably on the very outside edge of the age group that this model appeals to – unless you’re an old scale modeler like me. To my regret, the scale modeling bug hasn’t taken root in my grandson and probably never will. But he still enjoys the occasional model when he visits and this one will be fun, though I think he will allow zero participation from me, aside from being permitted to watch him. I haven’t put it together, though I have closely examined the parts and try-fit them. The parts are beautiful. They are detailed and painted. They fit better than any snap-together model I’ve ever built and I have built practically all of them with kid. The one detail I really don’t like is that the rear landing gear don’t retract. My other misgiving is about the size: it’s small. But I suspect that is to keep the cost down and make it more amenable to the younger kids this model is really aimed at. In terms of ease-of-build, I’m relying on other reviews and eagerly anticipating my grandson’s next visit. Overall, this is a very cool odel and the sounds are an added bonus. I have a strong hunch that by the time my grandson gets here, I’ll have bought the companion tie-fighter as well.Jerry

I enjoy test prep books for a variety of reasons. Some (not this one) are excellent references. All of them allow you to test the extent of your own knowledge. And some, like this one, provide insight into the state of public education in this country. The knowledge content of this test prep guide is abominable and frightening. It is disgustingly politically correct and reflects certain intellectual biases and a certain political persuasion. The authors and editors, of course, aren’t in the business of correcting errors in te content: their goal is to prepare young people to be tested on what the public education establishment is foisting upon them. This task, they fulfill well with succinct reviews of what passes for world history, example questions and answers and practice examples. Given its purpose, the guide is successful’ What is to be mourned, however, is the death of objectivity and honesty in the teaching of world history in American schools. Rather, it appears, children are being fed propaganda, not history.Jerry

Back when Windows was young, almost every new release required a book like this. But Windows has long been the most used Operating System on the planet and the changes from one eversion to another are more evolutionary than revolutionary. Windows 10 Bible apparently is the descendant of versions that have gone before. If you are inexperienced with Windows, the book could be useful It is well written, covers all the basics of using and managing Windows and has lots of examples and illustrations. But it is incomplete. For example, Cortana, Microsoft’s response to Apple Siri and Google Now receives only a brief mention. Office Online is covered in some detail, but there are no instructiosn for application like Outlook. I found no mention whatsoever of Bing and Microsoft Edge, the replacement for Internet Explorer is covered in scant detail. On the plus side,  generally neglected subjects like managing the desktop and advanced searching techniques are covered in some detail. Overall, if you’re an experienced Windows user, there’s nothing in this book tah you can’t quickly find on the web – and many subjects pertaining to Windows 10 in particular and Microsoft’s application universe aren’t covered at all. If you’re a less-experienced user, the book is worth the price.Jerry

This caught my eye because I thought it would be useful in the shower. My immensely better half saw it, appropriated it and put it to a different, but no less beneficial use, holding the assortment of external batteries and battery chargers that had been accumulating on a counter. She is so clever!The manufacturer’s advertising has so far proven true: these are well made, durable and hold a lot of weight.Having seen how versatile these caddies can be, I intend to get at least two more. One for the trunk of the car and another to hold other small electronics.I very much recommend this product.Jerry

This is, essentially, a self-help book, intended to assist its reads in discovering their true-self and helping them understand, hone and deploy their capacity for leadership. The underlying premise is that everyone has the “right stuff” buried somewhere within them – they just have to find it, feed it and deploy it. The vehicle is interviews with successful people. Lots of them. This is a classic technique, originally honed in the modern era by Napoleon Hill. And it is effective. “To thine own self be true” was Shakespeare’s advice and it is both true and hard to achieve. Getting a group to buy into your faith and vision is even harder. Much harder. Not everyone who follows Bill George’s distilled advice will become an effective and productive leader. That’s human nature: not everyone is equally endowed. But reading this book and absorbing the dozens of life lessons will definitely give  you a leg up.Jerry

This book is particularly valuable if the S6 is your first Samsung Galaxy smartphone. If you’ve used any of the Galaxy models since the S3, there are lots of tidbits here, but nothing revolutionary or that you can’t learn on your own if you want to invest the time. In general, this is a very detailed, very well illustrated instruction manual covering most – not all – aspects of ordinary usage of the Galaxy S6. You won’t find any “hacks” here, no instructions on rooting your phone or making it turn somersaults. Nor, to its detriment, will you find much in the way of instructions on apps competing with Samsung’s own offerings and its TouchWiz interface. I consider this to be an unfortunate omission. Still, this book is a useful reference, especially for someone new to Samsung Galaxy smartphones.Jerry

I’ve been using Olympus (and Sony) digital recorders for a long time. The prices keep coming down and the audio output quality keeps going up. The WS-852 and its more expensive sibling WS-853 are little wonders of technology. Both are certified to the 6 star level of compatibility with Dragon Naturally Speaking, the vest voice to text program currently available in the consumer market. (Fpr best results, use the recorder with a compatible headset.) The feature set on these recorders has always intrigued me. The only  feature I constantly use on older models is the scene selection, where you can choose between solo dictation, small meetings, conference room, auditorium and so on. Now, according to Olympus, you can choose an “Intelligent Auto Mode” which will set the microphone sensitivity automatically or choose one of the seven “scenes”. Olympus has also introduced a “simple” display mode, which presents only those functions that are frequently used. This is a good idea that certainly reduces the confusion factor for first-time users – and old pros as well. I suspect it is a result of the competition Olympus faces from smart phones, but whatever the reason it’s a good idea. A new addition is a flip-up stand, intended to reduce vibration when using the microphone on as tablet. One very unwelcome change is moving the external microphone and headphone jacks to the side of the unit. This is extremely bothersome to me since I almost always have an external microphone plugged into the unit. Most often it is the Olympus ME51S Stereo Microphone which I find extremely effective for recording small meetings. Possibly the new built-in Olympus stereo microphone will do as well, but I am a bit skeptical. The unit will accept a 32GB microSD card that will give you umpteen million hours of storage. The  4GB will suffice for most  people: just use the built-in USB connector to transfer your recordings to your computer. Finally, bear in mind that this is intended to be a voice recorder: the frequency range is quite limited and music doesn’t come off too well. Also new is a filter that lops off the lowest and highest frequencies in a recording. It can be useful in getting rid of ambient noise. Overall, for those who appreciate the versatility of a dedicated digital voice recorder, you won’t go wrong with the WS-852.Jerry

One reason why I enjoy study guides like this is that they permit me to test my knowledge by seeing how much of the test subjects I know. A second reason is because I am a critic of American public education. I think it is ineffective and highly politicized. My local school boards are always launching new and always expensive programs to help the so-called disadvantaged. And while the school boards never say anything about it, standardized test scores in the districts are falling. Finally, guides like this give me insight into what public schools are teaching – and in this regard AP U.S. History is nothing less than frightening. However, this review is about whether this book is an effective study guide for those preparing to take this test. And the answer to that is an unequivocal yes. This provides a straight-forward methodology to preparing for and taking the A. P. U.S. History exam. The practice tests cover Document-Based, Short-Answer and Long-Essay questions. There is also a five-page section on stress management before and during the etst which some may find helpful. In short, this is a solid test preparation guide, just as most Kaplan study aids are. They do a good job. My argument, which I will not engage in here, is what public schools are teaching as “American history”. I won’t begin to critique it, for once I begin it wil be a long time before I stop.Jerry

First of all, Turtle Beach does not manufacture headsets that will please audiophiles. No way. If you are looking for the most accurate rendition of music or such. But for online chat, Skype, even dictation with a program like Dragon Naturally Speaking, Turtle Beach headsets are perfectly suited for the job. They’re tough. I have a Turtle Beach Ear Force ZLa that I’ve used for several years. The headband still fits snugly. The foam ear cushions haven’t started shredding. The boom microphone stays were you put it. And the performance continues to be excellent. The Recon 50 offers  some modest and some significant refinements. The boom microphone is removable, which is a mixed blessing: removable components can be misplaced. The over the ear cups are very comfortable and an improvement over the ZLa, where the earphones are merely cushioned. The headband is adjustable and, most importantly, comfortably for long periods of wear, which in my case is typically two or three hours. I know avid games can go for far longer, but if my experience is a guide, these are comfortable. The 40mm  “ Neodymium speakers” promise to “deliver great stereo sound with crisp highs and thundering lows”. The highs sound fine to me, but the lows are short of thundering, but still fine by me.. I don’t use the inline controls, but they’re there for those who do. Audio quality is excellent. I’ve recorded test messages on Skype, Ustream and Audacity. Best of all, my speech using this headset is recognized with high accuracy by Dragon. Overall, this is a step-up from my existing Turtle Beach ZLa headset and I truly like the Recon 50.Jerry

I first ran across PNY years ago in a big-box store. I needed RAM and it was less expensive than the better known brands. PNY has gained significant market share and is now a major player. And their products are solid performers. RAM is a product that must meet or exceed industry-wide specifications. The quality of the materials and assembly are the keys. I’ve never had a PNY RAM module go bad. In choosing RAM, you have to find out what type fits your laptop. There are many places where you can do this, including Amazon. Be careful about voltage. The standard is 1.5v, though some laptops require a lower-voltage RAM module. Next, if you’re new to this, check your laptop manual to find out how to install the RAM. Typically it’s a task requiring only a few minutes, but some manufacturers make it very difficult. That’s it. These modules from PNY are well-made and, as noted, I’ve never had one go bad. PNY is well priced, well made and a good choice.Jerry

I love this. Years ago, there was a system known as X-10 that was going to bring remote control to every household,. X10 is still around, though it never really caught on. But it and its competitors were too early for the internet and in most cases have never tried to become internet capable. Now the internet of things is upon us. Home thermostats and every other appliance can be monitored and controlled via the internet. I wanted this item because I have a small fan which is perfectly suited for use in the bedroom, but it has no remote. Well, it didn’t have a remote. Now, with the TRENDnet THA-101 (I love those exotic product names) I can get close to remote control by turning the power on and off, no matter where I might be as long as I am connected to the internet with an iOS or Android device. The THA-101 also can act as a WiFi repeater, bringing a strong WiFi signal into areas of you home with no or weak WiFi signal stren. Depending on your knowledge and willingness to follow directions, the THA-101 can be simple to install or a nightmare. There are three paths to installation. The first is WPS (Wi-Fi Protected Setup), which if it works, is as simple as it gets. The second is through a Web browser. And the third uses an iOS or Android app. I cannot over-emphasize how important it is that you follow the instructions laid out in the Quick Installation or, preferably, the User’s Guide. Do that and you will most likely have a trouble free, painless installation. His is not a super-sophisticated device or system. Once you set it up properly, you can switch the power to a device on or off. You can set up a schedule to turn devices on and off, for example, to give the appearance that your house is occupied when you are off traveling the world. The THA-101 will work with 802.11 G and N routers. It also acts as a 802.11 N range extender, which can cause problems in some systems. When you are troubleshooting something other than the extender function, turn it off. Overall, this is a simple device with limited functionality. Be patient, carefully follow the directions and you too can turn off a lamp, fan or other small electrical appliance from anywhere in the world. Now, that is cool.Jerry

I am a long-time Adonit user, which isn’t really that long since the company is pretty young. I swear by their Jot Pro stylus. Except for a horrendous and continuous problem with the tips falling off, they are, in my opinion, the greatest phone and tablet styluses ever made. I also have several Adonit products that work only with iOS which have left me less enthusiastic, but still a fan. Now my fan loyalty has just shot up a notch or two with the Adonit Jot Dash. First, it’s a product I can use with my Android phones and tablets. Second, the fine is almost as precise as the disc on the tip of the Jot Pro. You have to practice a bit with any stylus, some like this one requiring more effort than others. Ii don’t like the fact that is a powered device and, even less, I don’t like the proprietary charger which is just one more thing to remember to use and, if you travel, pack. I do like the integrated clip: the first Adonit devices came without a clip and I guess the wailing was loud,, because they introduced a cap with a clip. Subsequent products have incorporated clips. Like every Adonit device I’ve used, it is beautifully designed and perfectly balanced in my hand. It is effortless to hold, position and use. I don’t draw on phones and tablets. I have no ambition to create great art (nor do I have the talent to do so). I print: cursive is not my8 strong suit. So the final analysis: does the Adonit Dash work? Yes. Is it perfect? No. I use it for convenience: I am much more productive with the Swiftkey and Google onscreen keyboards. But for really quick notetaking, I think the Adonit Jot Dash will be in my pocket for a long time to come.Jerry
Very poor quality. One snap closure separated on first use. Contacted Xhorizon who asked for pictures, which I sent. Promised replacement never received. Poor product. Poor seller.
Relatively thin material, but generously sized. The shoulder straps are too short.Expensive when compared to what you can get at your big stores, if you don't mind their logo.Jerry

Short cables like this are perfect for hooking up external batteries. Like many products in the Amazon Basics line, this is a high-quality product at a substantially lower price than Apple and other vendors demand. Time will tell, of course, but this cable seems durable and promises to be long-lasting.Jerry

My face has been graced with a beard and mustache for the past forty-five or so years. Back in the day, no barber, as they were called in those long ago days, ever touched my long and ever-growing hair. A banker once remarked to me that he never thought he’d be dealing with one of the Smith Brothers, one of two really hairy guys whose drawings graced the boxes of their eponymous cough drops, which just yesterday bit the dust again. So why I am interested iin trimmers? My beard and mustache, the glory and bane of my existence. Like must bearded men, I have a collection of cutting implements which haven’t made the grade. I want a beard that looks silky smooth – but don’t want to be bothered with time-consuming maintenance. An impossible challenge, of course, but the Panasonic ER-GB80-S (I love those awe-inspiring product names!) helps me get closer to my goal. First of all, this feels good to hold. It is beefy, brawny, masculine in the old school. And the size helps in terms of being able to control it, something I have never been able to do well with smaller trimmers, including my beloved tiny Panasonic beard trimmer. It has 39 settings for length, plus specialized combs, that provide infinite control, a must for detailing and shaping fussy areas. It is remarkably gentle along the beard line under my chin, an attribute I greatly appreciate. I don’t like rechargeable batteries because they require me to remember to charge them, but there’s no way you will power this motor on AAA cells for very long, if at all. If I were a daily user, I’d question the idea of extended trips with this trimmer and the possible need to pack the charger as well. It cleans easily with a chute to funnel water into, through and out of the blades. Neat idea! Best of all, I love the slide up trimmer. It is absolutely great for trimming my often unruly moustache and detailing the edges of my beard. This feature alone makes eh ER-GB80-S worth its premium price tag. I can’t speak to its use as a hair and body hair trimmer, but for my beard and mustache, I love this.Jerry

I have been very happy with my Asus gaming laptop that I use primarily for image, video and audio editing. That is, until I ran CrystalMark on my internal 7200RPM hard drive and the Western Digital My Book. CrystalMark measures my C drive at a respectable (at least I thought it was) 107.2 MB/s READ speed and 100.4 MB/s WRITE. The My Book running over a USB 3.0 interface scored 4119 MB/s READ and 354.2 MB/s WRITE in RAID 1 configuration. I am awed. In fact, I think I want to go out and dance in the streets. Editing stills and video is going to be a lot faster. I tested moves and copies with a folder containing 275,000 items aggregating 319 GB back and forth. About 90 minutes for each run. This is local, not network storage (though you can designate it as a network drive in Windows, it will not be a NAS). It’s a small, fairly light box that you can fit on your desltop. It is deathly silent. It runs cool. In fact, I kept checking for air flow and heat. Nada. Creepy. There are two Thunderbolt and one USB 3.0 Ports on the back. On the front there are two power only USB 3.0 ports that you can use to charge phones, tablets and such. Nice, helpful touch. The drives are easily replaceable. RAID is handled internally, so no additional load is place on your computer’s CPU. All in all, a little bit pricey, but absolutely worth it. I love it.Jerry

Three decades back or so, I started doing legal research. Since the books containing case digests (legal opinions) were very expensive, I had to to trek to the law library, an hour or more each way, during the hours it was open. I had to then use digests of digests to find cases supporting and opposing my point. It was a burdensome task. Today, 24/7, I have access to one of the largest law libraries in the world. I can search for relevant case law, treatises and articles in seconds. And the cost per month is substantially less than it would have been were I obtaining this information in book form and subscribing to update services. Legal publishing did not die, but it no longer is what it was. Other industries weren’t so fortunate. At one time, little print shops existed in the thousands. Today nearly all of them are gone, vaporized in author Robert Tercek’s lexicon. Now anyone can operate the equivalent of a print shot – that is, if they ever need to print anything on paper. Right now in most major cities, the traditional taxi cab industry is being vaporized by Uber,  Lyft and other ride sharing services. Tercek has written a history and a chronicle of the future as software assumes a dominant role in society. For many of us, who have come of age in the Information technology industry, much of this is common knowledge. For most in the population at large, however, much of the content of his book will come as a shock, even a threat. As Tercek puts it “[t]he future of companies is lean and leaner”. Technology will “vaporize” ever more companies and even industries. Many will be transformed, buy many others will be essentially destroyed. It is simultaneously a grim future and a brilliant future. For the individual, it depends on how they adapt. Tis is a marvelous book, especially for those who haven’t caught on that technology is changing the world in more weays than they ever imagined possible. It is general, as any book of this kind must be, but it is specific enough to retain the reader’s interest. It is a book for everyone. For parents who want to help guide their children; for young adults n the workforce who want to exploit the opportunities around them and for anyone who just wants to know what’s going on. In fact, I am tempted to say that anyone who doesn’t read this runs the risk of being “vaporized” themselves, their experience and skills rendered meaningless as software and robots replace them.Jerry

Before opening this book, my knowledge of Scrum and Agile Project Management was pretty much limited to knowing the words and little more. Neither Scrum nor Agile Project Management are necessarily simple. “At its barest, scrum is an empirical exposure model, which means knowledge is gained from real-life experience, and decisions are made based on that experience.” Got that? Don’t worry if you don’t. for the author spends the next 361 pages explaining in considerable detail what Scrum is and how the methodology can be applied to various business and personal roles. Scrum is an approach to getting things done, including “Dating and Family Life”” and “Life Goals”, which came as quite a surprise to me. I would strongly urge the newcomer to Scrum to read “Agile Project Management For Dummies”, by the same author, first. Having struggled with “Scrum For Dummies”, I can see that I need the underpinning first in understanding Agile. This is not a criticism of “Scrum For Dummies” or Mark C. Layton, the author of both books. Rather it is my recognition that Scrum is not an easy concept to grasp in significant depth straight out the gate. There is a great deal of depth in “Scrum For Dummies”, far more than I would have expected in a “Dummies” book. Sometimes it takes on sort of a mystical tone: “Scrum is a focusing tool. One of the biggest reasons that scrum is so successful is that it edits out the noise of trying to do everything all at once.Instead of doing all projects poorly, scrum focuses to do one project at a time, with a higher level of quality than if thrashing around.” Since I am often guilty of the former, I want to consistently do the latter. Adopting Scrum can definitely help, but  you have to first comprehend what Scrum is. This book does that, but I think famialiarizing yourself with Agile will be helpful. At least that’s what I’m going to do.Jerry

I occasionally am invited to be a guest lecturer, but I don’t teach any classes and haven’t been in a classroom as a student in decades. But I am concerned with what I perceive as the not-very-slow death of discussion in the public square. From where I stand, people don’t engage in discussion these days. On television, in social media, in public meetings, you don’t hear or see discussion any more, you see or hear rants, diatribes, shouting, hating, Civilized discussion, including the exchange of opposing views seems to be largely a dead issue. In the classroom environment, to my surprise, the problem is silence – students have to be coaxed into productive participation in discussions, except for the always present few who never stop talking and are uninterested in letting others have their say. While the writing style is bit tedious, the author does an excellent job of discussing the obstacles to creating a productive classroom (or group) discussion environment. Methodologies to promote positive group discussions are offered, but this is no compendium of tips and tracks to facilitate discussion. The author is clearly engaged with the idea of discussion as a teaching tool. I think the book has somewhat wider applicability and includes people like myself who present to professionals. When I speak to audiences, I try hard to encourage discussion. I did gain a better understanding of the mechanics of facilitating discussion from this book.Jerry

Winter is approaching Chicago. It’s chilly and gray today and not the best day for testing a circular polarizing filter outdoors. So no sky shots, no waterfalls or flowing rivers, although had I been adventurous, I suspect Lake Michigan would have provided some pretty good wave action and water motion. Anyway, I tested this very fine polarizer using a Nikon D5200 on reflections. Reflections on glass, on metal, plastic surfaces, LCD screens, anything around with reflections. This filter is definitely a reelection killer. If I muster up the ambition this year to photograph Christmas windows at the stores, this polarizer will definitely be on my lens. I need to do some research on how to determine the effective f-stop loss. B+W says 1 – 1.5 stops: it looks like more, but that is the point of B+W’s claim – that this polarizer passes more light than run-of-the-mill polarizers. I didn’t notice any color deterioration, but I am working with limited subject matter here. So far, very impressive.Jerry

The very first thing that impressed me about this trimmer is its hand-filling size. Compared to the diminutive trimmer (also Panasonic) that I’ve used for several years, this is a literal brute. It is big, it fills my hand, it is fairly heavy – all qualities that help make this a precision grooming tool. The second is power. My existing trimmer is powered by a couple of AA batteries. The GB60 has a powerful motor powered by rechargeable Ni-MH batteries. In terms of working on my beard, it’s like moving from a scythe to a John Deere. Shame on me, but I sometimes put off trimming my beard and as beards do, it quickly gets long and scraggly. Cutting it down to length with this trimmer is like taking a hot knife to butter. In fact, you have to be very careful not to get too aggressive. Snap on the beard trimming comb attachment and adjust it for your preferred length of 1/32 to 13/32 inch. Trimming the edges and shaping the beard is almost a joy with this. But again, don’t be too aggressive. I don’t trim my hair, so I can’t comment on using the GB60 for that purpose. Panasonic suggests you clean the trimmer after every use, an inherently tedious process. A water inlet is provided to assist iin this process, but it doesn’t make it less tedious. A cleaning brush is also provided along with a small container of oil. Happily, Panasonic provides clear instructions on how to perform these processes. An AC adapter is provided for charging the trimmer’s internal batteries. It takes about an hour to charge the battery, which will keep it running for about 50 minutes. Finally, a faux fabric carrying case is included. Overall, a brawny trimmer that fits large hands and has more than enough power to deal with any beard.Jerry

Judith Flanders is an excellent researcher, a competent historian and an adequate writer. If you come to this book expecting an exciting time, you’ll probably be disappointed – it is a slow trudge through the 350 or so pages of this book. On the other hand, if you are interested in learning how we in Western society came to understand “home” as you and I probably do, this is a fascinating book. Flanders traces the minutiae of what makes a home through the eyes of householders, tax collectors, merchants, artists and others. For example, at one time, often more than half a family’s wealth might be invested in beds, bedding and clothing. Curtains on windows didn’t become popular until the 18th century, In the Low Countries, far more homes than you might expect were adorned with original paintings. The development of each of our contemporary rooms – kitchen, bedroom, living room and so on – is traced in some detail. Bedrooms, for example, were once the main rooms of a home. If you love historical detail, this is an enthralling book. For example, the development of the Argand lamp in 1780 was a revolutionary change in oil lighting which, in turn, helped to end the reign of lighting with candles. Overall, an engaging history of how what we today call home developed over the past five centuries – and a powerful reminder that we have lives that are incredibly richer than those of even three generations past.Jerry

I’ve been using a Plantronics Voyager Pro Bluetooth headset for about 2.5 years. I’ve tried other Bluetooth headsets during that time, but none equaled or surpassed the Voyager Pro.  Until now.  The big feature drawing me in is real compatibility with Google Now. I am a big, big fan of voice-controlled computing and this device is a big step toward that, in my opinion.  Google Now works pretty well with this phone, which is good because the headset lacks physical buttons and most commands are intended to be given by voice. (Siri and Cortana compatibility is claimed, but I haven’t tried either.) It will be a bit before I have fully tested the Google Now limits of this headset. Google Now has a surprisingly large set of voice commands that most people aren’t familiar with.  Instead of buttons to press, there’s a tap area that I am not particularly happy with. There aren’t a lot of tap commands, such as tapping twice to answer or hang up a call, I’d rather have voice equivalents for all of them or buttons. But that’s just my preference.  Voice quality is okay. I don’t have high expectations in this area. I listen to a lot of audiobooks and have no difficulty understanding them with this headset and the few people I called didn’t complain about my voice quality.  Battery life is not very good. Three hours talk time in the headset – and another seven accessible via the charger. The charger is a little cradle you’re supposed to carry around with you. When the headset is in the charger, it recharges the headset battery! I had a case like this for the Plantronics and stopped using it because it proved to be inconvenient. The headset cannot be charged except when it is in the charging cradle. I’d rather have a microUSB port in the headset. Again, a personal preference.  Four Ear Gels are supplied – and you’d better find the one that fits you best because it will play a role in the fit of the headset. You just put the headset in your ear (right ear only) and hope for the best. There are no loops, wings or other auxiliary devices to keep the headset in place. So far, so good, but I have been careful not to jog it in any way.  Overall, I reasonably impressed with Eclipse. But, as with so many other thingfs, time will tell.Jerry

I’m an aging male who doesn’t have much hair left, much less long hair. However, that doesn’t stop me from observing a young woman with long hair using this product.  This is a beautifully designed product, as it should be considering its price. Construction is reasonably substantial and with normal care, it should last, though I can’t speak to the hidden heating and electrical components inside the wand.  That a heat resistant glove and pad are included should provide all the warning you need that there is significant danger of burning yourself if you are careless.  Use is straight forward. There are five heat settings. Use the one appropriate setting for your hair as described in the very brief instruction manual.  Part your hair into sections and then wrap a strip of hair fairly tightly around the barrel for a few seconds and release.  The result is a lock of wonderfully curled hair. The effect of the tapered barrel is very evident in the finished curl.  The unit has an automatic shut off and small feet you can rest it on, hopefully on the included heat-resistant pad.  All that is to the good.  The unit is expandable with attachments – expensive attachments.  I don’t know the market well enough to determine if this product is intended for heavy-duty salon use or by affluent consumers, if not both.  On the whole, as it comes out of the box, it makes fluffy, pretty curls and probably will be suited for most people. But the attachments look like they greatly expand the usefulness of the unit, though at a significant cost.Jerry

This is the newest version of the well-known and highly regarded SanDisk Extreme microSDHC card line. SanDisk claims it is suitable for 4K recording. While I have a couple of cameras that record 4K,  I have no screen that resolves 4K, so I don’t shoot a lot of 4K. I did try this out for burst shooting on a GoPro Hero 4 Silver and the writes are clearly faster. The same is true of video. Because the difference between this and the earlier version is so apparent, I haven’t run CrystalMark or any other speed testing tool on it. Instead I’m going to be aggressive with the GoPro over the next few days and then compare results with the earlier card. Personally, I have had good experiences with almost all my SanDisk devices, except for their Cruzer flash drives which had a tendency to fall apart. You’re definitely not going to go wrong choosing this card for your microSDHC imaging devices.Jerry

Prior to sighting this book, I had never heard of Steve Tobak. Having attempted to read “Real Followers Don’t Follow”, I doubt that I will ever hear of Steve Tobak again in any substantive way. Tobak is involved with something called Invisor Consulting and he says of himself “[t]hat’s probably why he’s been interviewed, quoted, and referenced by pretty much every major business media outlet at one time or another”. Well, so what? Get yourself a publicist or be an aggressive self-promoter and within a year you can probably make a similar claim. Anyway, in this book, Tobak claims to “show readers what it takes to become successful entrepreneurs and exceptional business leaders in today’s highly competitive world”. Immodest to the core, Tobak declares “[e]ntrepreneurialism is broken and I’m going to fix it”. In my estimation, his 20 page introduction establishes that this book is about Steve Tobak, what he does and what he thinks. And, frankly, there’s not much there. One assertion after another, usually unsourced, doesn’t make for convincing reading. For example, Tobak writes: “I once read that two-thirds of the Dow Industrial Average was formed during recession or in the Great Depression. I’ve no doubt that’s true”. Uhmm, some people have heard if you step on a crack in the sidewalk, it will rain – and they believe that’s true. This is, I think, a really weird book. It’s all about him with bon mots like “ On nice days I work outdoors. If I’ve got a tight deadline, I’ll have a second cappuccino to provide a boost. If I’m working at night, I have a glass of wine or two”. And “I’ve gotten on a plane, flown to a dinner meeting with an important customer, and flown right back that night”. Who cares? Everything he says has been said – often more effectively – by someone else. Some of his advice is puzzling. For example: “[w]hen a company is in trouble, that’s when the boss needs to get hands-on wherever the trouble lies”. I don’t pretend to be nearly as experienced as Tobak claims to be, but in my experience – particularly in smaller companies of the kind Tobak is addressing, it is the boss who is responsible for the problems. Anyway, some people may find this book helpful. I didn’t.Jerry

If you’ve ever lived in the Upper Midwest, most notably in Minnesota, or listened to Garrison Keillor’s Prairie Home Companion show, you know that potluck meals are a way of life. As Keillor put it: “We used to have a potluck culture in Minnesota—the sharing of food as a way of life, you do your best for me, I do my best for you. “ This beautiful – yes, I said beautiful – Stanley Vaccum Crock would be the hit of any potluck. It really is a wonderful piece of design. A stainless steel bottom and polycarbonate top and edge lip. For very brawny clips secure the top to the pot – properly snapped shut, that top will stay attached and your championship chili will not be sloshing about the back seat. On the inside of the lid is a clever little hook to hang the lid from the side of the pot – smart thinking. Stanley says hot food will stay warn for up to 12 hours and cold food for up to 16. I have every reason to believe it. Stanley invented the vacuum thermos in 1913. The pot walls are a double wall vacuum. The pot has a 3 quart capacity. You can fill it with food, such as chili, soup, stew or such, or use it as a container for packs of food – hamburgers for grilling, smaller portions in containers and so on. In some cases, this will easily replace larger Igloo style containers – and do a better job of it. My ice-loving incredibly significant other immediately laid claim to this to hold her iced tea and other beverages on our road trips. The wide top makes serving simple and also allows it to be easily used for storage of packaged items. Obviously as you can tell from the pictures, this is a cinch to clean. Overall, this is a great product and it will definitely get a lot of use in our household – especially when we attend family reunions in Minnesota.Jerry

Dependable, moderately priced RAM. I discovered PNY when it was first being distributed in the US. Took what was then a chance and bought some. I've been buying it ever since.There's nothing remarkable about this product.It is exactly as described and does precisely what you would expect of it.No surprises and no problems. That's the way it should be with RAM.Jerry

This book is written in a breezy, entertaining style, reminiscent of the tourist promotion movies of the 1940s and 50s. Everything is light and bouncy. “Rocket” seems like a promotional piece, though the name of the employer of the book’s four authors, Boston Consulting group, is barely mentioned. The treatment of the 16 entrepreneurs “interviewed” is an exercise in hagiography. The lessons the 16 have to impart, according to the doyens of Boston Consulting Group, are what you would expect to find in any book about creating a successful business. Most of the “ideas” presented are suitable only for established large scale businesses, who just happen to be the kind of business Boston Consulting Group would like to serve. There’s more than a touch of “magical special sauce” claims by the authors. You must, for example, create your “demand-space map”. You know, the kind of thing that worked wonders for Frito-Lay. Just imagine what it can do for your little bead store or office supply emporium. Nothing to it, really: Just “describe the 30 most important technical, functional, and emotional factors. Broadly discuss  the findings in your organization. Use the demand-space map as the starting point for all development activities.” There are a number of large and small factual errors in the book that, to my eyes, indicate a surprising lack of knowledge on the part of the authors and their editors. For example, “[Ronald] Reagan’s chief fund-raiser asked the Four Seasons [a corporation] for a donation. Instead of a contribution, Four Seasons graciously offered the former governor a complimentary suite whenever he was staying in Washington”. I am deliberately ignoring the issue of a political campaign seeking a contribution from a corporation, but the fact is that the offer of service – the offer of a hotel suite – would be a contribution-in-kind. The authors present it as if it were an alternative to a contribution, when in fact it is indeed a contribution. Small potatoes to be sure, but a surprising error on the part of the authors. In another place, the authors describe how Amazon, with its “powerful data-storage capability” “became a rival to IBM in cloud computing”.  In fact, Amazon and its primary cloud service competitors Microsoft and Google were in the market before IBM and may have larger revenues from these services. But “Rocket” shouldn’t be considered as a serious history of any business. The interviews are, in fact, interestin and you will learn something qabout the businesses of the interviewees. Whetehr any of this will help you grow your small business is another story altogether.Jerry

I don’t think you’ll be seeing psychiatrists running ads offering treatment for “Dominate” addiction. It isn’t an addicting game. It’s a fun game in small doses, but not something that people will stay up all night playing. And for grandparents whose grandchildren visit occasionally, it’s a great addition to the kid entertainment arsenal. Setup is very quick. Game play is simple. Games move fast and don’t require a great deal of thought. And the kids, with their very nimble fingers, will probably win more often than not, which is great. (For them.) The game is simple: draw a path with your tiles from Point A to Point B and do it before your opponent. Basically it’s dominoes with modern artwork and less flexibility. For the money, it’s a nice thing to have available for occasional use.Jerry

First, exercise caution in reading the advertising for this series of cards. While the claimed Read speed is constant across all the cards at 90aMB/s, the claimed Write speed is only 40MB/s for the 16, 32 and 64GB cards with 60MB/s allegedly available on the 126 and 256GB cards I ran speed tests on my 64GB card with Crystal Disk Mark on an i7 based computer running under Windows 10. Read speeds maxed at 34MB/s. Write speed hit only 27MB/s. Both marks are substantially below the advertised speeds. I don’t know why the speeds on my computer are so low. Is it the card? Is it the computer? I don’t know. Yet. Using the card in a 4K capable Panasonic camcorder resulted in nice looking video – which is hardly a scientific assessment. I did a little testing in burst mode on a mid-range Nikon and got good images – but the same is true for the Class 10 card currently in the camera. It will take substantially more testing for me to determine if there is an appreciable difference in image quality on this card ini comparison to my existing cards. If and as I discover appreciable differences, I will amend this review. In the meantime, there is no question that this card is fully the equal of my existing Class10s.Jerry

I have a Dell Venue 8. It is a fully capable Windows computer in a very small package with an 8 inch screen. It is fast enough for ordinary purposes such as email, browsing, general productivity (word processing, etc.) and, surprisingly, light duty video switching and editing. I also have an Asus Windows tablet with a 10 inch screen and an attached keyboard that holds a 500GB hard drive. As I get older I want to carry less. CPUs have become smaller and more powerful. Prices for Ultrabooks and Sub-Compact form factors are plummeting. Still, these lightweight machines aren’t well suited for productivity off the shelf. They’re powerful enough in terms of CPU and sorage, but you really need something close to a full sized keyboard and mouse and perhaps more storage than the device natively has. The Trendnet Universal USB 3.0 Docking Station is relatively small (but not as small as I dream of) unit that massively expands your Input/Output (I/O) capabilities. The device provides two USB 3.0 ports, 4 USB 2.0 ports, a Gigabit CAT5 cable socket,  HDMI and DVI/VGA connectors that allow you to output to two separate HD monitors and separate audio and microphone jacks. (Physically, by the way, there’s a DVI port on the device and a DVI-to-VGA adapter included. Phenomenal. Everything works. You can now have a powerful system with a keyboard you can type on, a Terabyte or two of storage and more in a set-up weighing less than three pounds that will fit in your messenger bag or backpack. There are some design and packaging points I am not totally overjoyed with. The unit is larger than I would like. By the same token, I don’t know if all these functions could be put into a smaller package. The ergonomics, however, are great: plenty of room around each port making it easy to attach and detach peripherals. The AC adapter is a too large, in my opinion, wall wart that plugs directly into a socket. In some motels, you’ll go nuts with this. I think it should have been an inline adapter with an AC cord. I would suggest carrying an extension cord, if you already do this. They don’t include a carrying bag. And the big one: all those USB ports and none can be used go charge a device. So don’t think you can leave  your phone or tablet chargers at home. Overall, a really great accompaniment to your little computers.Jerry

Given the perverse logic of eugenicists and other proponents of logical Darwinism, the anti-capitalist political strains roiling through Europe from the 1850s onward and the open animosity of both Catholic and Protestant denominations toward the Jews, is it any wonder that the Europe of the 1930s was more than willing to accept the Jew hatred of a long line of European nationalists, culminating with Hitler? To the Jew-haters of the day, it wasn’t a psychological, philosophical or religious issue: it was biological. The Jews were a virus, parasites, and had to be destroyed. German leadership quickly learned “in 1941, that almost every every German who was ordered to shoot a civilian, Jewish or otherwise, would obey that order – even though asking to be spared from such duties brought no consequences beyond peer pressure”. Several million Germans and other Europeans engaged in such murders, with only a few prosecuted, much less punished, for their crimes. Timothy Snyder has written a fascinating Holocaust history, focusing on how the destruction of the concept of the state liberated Germans and Europeans to commit murder on a scale never before seen. Snyder’s thesis is fascinating – and, he argues, industrialized mass murder can happen again. Many will reject Snyder’s theories and perhaps not unreasonably so. Much of his hypothese rests on assertions that cannot be proven, such as some of Hitler’s private thoughts and speculation on Hitler’s theories. On the other hand, no one else has  convincingly explained why so many Germans and other Europeans were so willing to murder so many millisons.Jerry

The pieces are on the small side and often not fitted well. But the frustration level isn’t all that high and its’s got lots of fun value once you build it. And after you build it once according to the instructions, any child worth their salt will immediately set forth designing and building their own creations – and have a lot of fun doing it. Like the legendary Lego blocks, this is a toy that allows the imagination of the builder to rule. There is simply no way a kid can’t have fun with this (especially if they can snatch it from grandpa’s hands).Ierry

Long after your kids stop playing with this, there is one thing you may remember – the lack of a volume control. It’s always on high. With the repetitive sounds and tinny speakers, you’ll hear it forever. This is essentially a balance board with lights and sound. There are three balance games to play. Unfortunately, the charm wears off pretty fast and I suspect a majority of kids will give it  up sooner rather than later. But while it holds their interest, it’s a lot of fun. I didn’t try putting my adult weight on it, but I sure wanted to.Jerry

I first heard some of Viktor Kosenko's music with the release of the first CD in this series, his  Études in the Form of Old Dances. I reviewed it and append it at the end of this note because it gives some biographical information about the all-but-unknown Kosenko.This disc contains three sonatas, two of them in one movement. The disc only lasts about 50 minutes, short for a CD;  this is concentrated late Romantic music, the only piano sonatas Kosenko wrote, that will in fact make you wish for more . One takes what one can get here. Natalya Shkoda is a fine pianist whose abilities were evident in the earlier release, and she does not disappoint. For those who like Rachmaninoff, Medtner and that ilk, this music will be down your alley.Here's my earlier review of the Études disc; much of what I say about my reaction to it holds for the present disc:Occasionally one hears unfamiliar music and immediately falls in love with it. That has been my experience with these eleven piano pieces by a Ukrainian composer I'd never even heard of before, Viktor Stepanovych Kosenko (1896-1938). If it weren't for the adventuresome spirit of Toccata Classics' guiding light, Martin Anderson, I certainly never would have come across this music which has been in my player almost constantly since I got this CD a week or so ago. This has so often been the case for me with Toccata Classics releases that I've recently joined their 'Toccata Discovery Club'. One can explore and hear mp3 excerpts of all the tracks on the label's CDs at [...] The label specializes in worthy music not otherwise available on disc.Kosenko was himself a virtuoso pianist who began composing early in life. His 'Eleven Etudes in the Form of Old Dances, Op. 19', written in the late 1920s, is a collection of pieces using the dance forms familiar to us from the baroque -- gavotte, allemande, minuet, courante, sarabande, bourrée etc. They flow so nicely that one could think that they are predictable, but indeed none of them is; there are surprises, lovely ones, in every one of the études. Although they sound technically only moderately advanced, on closer listening one hears that they are not; they truly are studies that would pay the ambitious pianist's attention. They are unfailingly melodious, often with what we are told are Ukrainian folk-like melodies, sometimes making use of modal scales. The harmonic language is, for the most part, familiar from such composers as Tchaikovsky or early Scriabin, but occasionally one runs into jazz-inflected or impressionist harmonies, or Bach/Busoni baroqueries. Somehow this all fits together and sounds inevitable and 'right'.There is not space here to describe all eleven études. Some highlights: No. 1, a gavotte, is perky, sassy, and has a particularly gorgeous set of melodies. No. 6, a bourrée in A major, is virtually a two-part invention with parallel or contrary motion in both hands, and with a folk-tinged middle section in the corresponding minor key. No. 10, a passacaglia, is the longest étude, lasting over eighteen minutes. It consists of an eight-bar ground bass followed by thirty-eight variations and a coda. This étude sounds both Bachian and Tchaikovskian. It features a dizzying array of technical challenges including trills, octaves, dynamic contrasts, challenging pedaling and variations in touch and rhythm. An impressive work. The set concludes with hyperlegato presto gigue in sonata form, a virtual perpetuum mobile.Natalya Shkoda, the marvelous pianist on this disc, is herself a Ukrainian currently living in Texas. She makes a convincing advocate for this wonderful music. We are told this is 'Volume 1' of Kosenko's piano music and I for one am eager to hear more.Scott Morrison

Rossini's Petite Messe Solennelle was a late work -- he called it 'the last mortal sin of my old age' -- and is a quirky thing. Scored originally for two pianos and harmonium -- this recording seems to use one piano and harmonium, however -- it was premièred in a private home and has had a strange trajectory ever since. Unlike the roughly contemporaneous 'Stabat Mater', which is scored for full orchestra, full chorus and operatic soloists and is sometimes called 'Rossini's last opera', this is a delicate piece that requires a chorus of only twelve singers of whom four double as soloists.This performance recorded in Tallinn, Estonia, simply won't do. The soloists are, in a word, weak, and although the massed twelve voices can make a pretty sound, they don't really measure up to earlier recordings. Frankly they sound like amateurs much of the time. The tenor soloist in the 'Quoniam' is painful to hear. And so on.There is a budget price twofer that couples the Messe with the Stabat Mater and features the likes of Ruggero  Raimondi (who, however, was not in his best voice) in the Messe, and Pavarotti in the Stabat Mater's 'Cujus animam' that must be heard to be believed, it's so good.Skip this one.Scott Morrison

I've loved this performance for many years, owning it originally on LP. It is performed with large forces and modern instruments, not the current fashion for Bach performances, but it is magnificent. Richter was a great Bach conductor.However, you can get it for less -- at least at the date of this notice -- in the version on Archiv, also available here at Amazon Bach: Mass in B minor .Scott Morrison

John Barbirolli included Haydn symphonies in many of his concerts throughout his long career. The very first one he ever recorded -- in 1949 with the Hallé orchestra, which he led for more than twenty-five years -- was Haydn's Symphony No. 83, called 'The Hen' for the clucking sounds in the first movement's second subject. The present recording was made in 1969 in a live concert of the SWR Sinfonieorchester Baden-Baden, one of the really good radio symphonies in the Germany of the time. Strangely he uses the first movement exposition repeat in the finale but not in the first movement; perhaps this was the practice at the time. I actually wanted to hear that first movement repeat because of Barbirolli's delicious shaping of the music. Although Barbirolli is known primarily as a 'romantic' conductor, there is little indication of that in his classically proportioned Haydn. True, he uses a larger orchestra than we hear these days in concert, but the playing of the SWR is delicate yet spirited.The Hallé had given the very first English performance of Berlioz's Symphonie fantastique in 1879 and when Barbirolli conducted it with them the first time, in 1933, older members of the orchestra remembered the approach of Sir Charles Hallé, the conductor of the first and subsequent performances. Hallé had been friends with Berlioz in Paris. Over the years Barbirolli conducted the Symphonie many times and often programmed it on celebratory occasions as when the Hallé moved into their new Free Trade Hall in Manchester in 1951. He had recorded it twice before this live performance was recorded, also in 1968. To say that this is an emotionally intense performance is more than just. Even in the slow (and in other hands sometimes boring) third movement, Scène aux champs, we are wrung out. The Marche au supplice actually comes almost as a relief until we then realize that this is the March to the Guillotine with its attendant horror . The finale, 'Songe d'une nuit du Sabbat', builds to an almost unbearably febrile temperature. This is a great reading of this great symphony.Recorded sound is quite good. I was not really aware of its age, now 40-odd years. Those bells in the fifth movement of the Symphonie are startling in their lifelike sound.This is not just a recording for Barbirolli fans. It's for everyone who loves this music.Recommended.Scott Morrison

I had mixed feelings about this recording before I listened to it. On the one hand, I love the music -- and as a pianist have played two of the three pieces on the CD -- and on the other I was a little unsettled at the notion of these pieces being played by a wind quintet. I ordinarily like transcriptions and arrangements, often finding things in a piece when it is presented in different instrumental garb. But particularly with the String Quartet the differences in tone quality are striking, even alarming. And then there is slight confusion with the name of the ensemble; one of my favorite recordings of the Ravel String Quartet is by the Orlando String Quartet, but this one is by the Orlando Wind Quintet.Indeed the String Quartet is the piece that is hardest to accept initially. But after a couple of hearings it grew on me. True, there is nothing like a string quartet playing softly diaphanous passages, but amazingly the Orlando Quintet manages to achieve something similar in appropriate spots. And one gasps at the virtuosity in spots, as in the helter-skelter final movement where these Dutch wind players astonish. The arrangements of the String Quartet and of the Mother Goose Suite that follows are by Mark Popkin, a noted bassoonist and arranger (and physicist!) who was based in North Carolina and who, alas, died not long after these arrangements were made.The Mother Goose Suite (Ma mère l'oye) exists in two forms made by Ravel, the original for piano four-hands and the subsequent arrangement for orchestra. Since winds play a dominant part in the orchestral sound-world of the Suite, it is not such a far cry for the entire thing to be played by winds and indeed one can sometimes forget, when listening to it, that one is not hearing the original. As in the String Quartet, the Orlando Quintet play like the masters they are. In fact, I'm impressed enough that I want to name these five Dutch musicians, who are all orchestral players and teachers in various parts of the Netherlands: Marieke Schneemann (flute), Pauline Oostenrijk (oboe), Lars Wouters van den Oudenweijer (clarinet), Bram van Sambeek (bassoon), and Ron Schaaper (horn).The final piece is a joyous performance of the three-movement Sonatine, originally for solo piano. This arrangement was made in 1989 by another American arranger, now-86-year-old Wayne Peterson, a distinguished composer long at the San Francisco State University and recipient of the 1982 Pulitzer Prize in music for his orchestral work 'The Face of the Night, The Heart of the Dark'. Completely sympathetic to the qualities of the wind quintet sound, the arrangement is brilliant, and brilliantly played.The booklet notes include charming paragraphs written by each of the musicians. Unfortunately, other than their names there is nothing about the arrangers, hence my comments in this review.As I sometimes say, I like this CD enough that I have put it on my iPod, one of my highest accolades.Scott Morrison

James Gilchrist, a British tenor of some reputation, offers Schubert's Die Schöne Müllerin and although his voice qua voice is quite lovely -- he actually sounds like a young love-sick man, as the text requires -- his mannerism of swelling on each longish note becomes irritating after a few minutes. I found that I could not listen to more than a couple of the songs before needing to stop listening. A shame because he really does have the goods otherwise.Scott Morrison

'Herr Feska ist ganz Herr und Meister über das, was er auszusprechen unternimmt.' ('Herr Fesca is entirely lord and master of what he undertakes to express') -- Carl Maria von WeberFriedrich Ernst Fesca (1789-1826) was a German composer and violinist who was enormously popular in his day. His quartets come after those of Haydn and Mozart (and to which they owe a debt) and before the later quartets of Beethoven (and before those quartets overcame their early non-acceptance by the quartet-loving public). So for a period of perhaps thirty years Fesca's quartets were among the most-played in Germany and Austria. But after Beethoven's late quartets and those of Schubert, Mendelssohn and Schumann became fixtures of the repertoire, those of Fesca lapsed into obscurity. And there they have remained. I had never heard any of them before, either in concert or on recording. This disc, the first of two planned by the Diogenes Quartet and the cpo label, is a revelation. These are marvelously constructed quartets that have immediately memorable themes and a generally serious import. This is not to say that there aren't humorous or witty moments, but overall these are works of convincing sincerity. Fesca wrote most of his quartets when he was quite young; he didn't live beyond age 37 when he died of what was probably tuberculosis. The first twelve of sixteen total were published in 1815 when he was 26, but there is speculation that he wrote the earliest of them while still in his teens.On this disc we hear Quartets Nos. 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 13 & 15, plus a single movement 'Potpourri' which elaborates on a rondo theme found in the First Quartet. The quality of the writing is consistently expert and memorable throughout. There is clever manipulation of themes and, something not found in his Haydn/Mozart models, frequent modulations which remind one of Schubert at times. Although there are not the daring and sudden contrasts of later Beethoven there are a few spots where one gasps at Fesca's harmonic surprises.The Diogenes Quartet, whose Schubert quartet recording I reviewed earlier this year Schubert: Complete String Quartets, Vol. 1, are a Munich-based group whose reputation is growing at home and abroad. I have also reviewed their recording of string quintets by Cherubini and Onslow Cherubini/Onslow: String Quintets.Recommended.Scott Morrison

Even though I have played tons of four-hand music going all the way back to my earliest piano lessons, I had only ever played (or even heard) one of the three sonatas on this disc, Mozart's Grande Sonate in F Major, K. 497. It is an undeniable masterpiece and has been recorded any number of times before, most prominently by Ingrid Haebler and Ludwig Hoffmann Piano Duets / Mozart Edition 16 from 1971. This recording is easily the equal of that one and additionally is in impeccable modern sound. Although I had never heard of the Piano Duo Danhel-Kolb, they are a wonderful duo with absolute virtuosity and sensitive musicianship.The big surprise here, though, is what is on the remainder of the disc: four hand sonatas by Johann Baptist Cramer and by George Onslow.Cramer (1771-1858) was fifteen years younger than Mozart and outlived him by almost seventy years. His style is rather like Mozart's or early Beethoven. The Sonata in G Major dates from 1815 and has never been recorded before, which is a real shame; it is a true masterpiece. The first movement is a sprightly romp with sparkling fireworks that involve brilliant runs by the right hands of both players. The second movement is a theme and variations that juxtaposes variations in wildly differing styles and then concludes, oddly but effectively, with a chorale followed by two further variations and an extended coda. The finale, a rondo, is every bit as fun-filled as the first movement and Danhel-Kolb infuse it with their own joy at getting to play it. I cannot imagine why this work has never been recorded before but I'm certainly grateful for this performance. I think I've now listened to it about half a dozen times and it has gone on my iPod, too.George Onslow (1784-1853) was a Frenchman in spite of his name; his father was an Englishman living in France. His Second Sonata for Piano Duo was published in 1823 and sounds a good deal like middle-period Beethoven with a goodly amount of Sturm und Drang. (One could actually say the same about the Mozart sonata; it is one of the more dramatic of Mozart's piano works.) It is clearly advanced for its era in that there is a cyclic use of thematic material, similar to that in Schubert's Wanderer Fantasy written a year earlier. There is darkness and angst aplenty leavened with periods of lightheartedness and tender lyricism. The sonata is in four movements; the third movement Largo is actually a slow introduction the the Allegro finale. And in that movement there is Haydnesque humor along with heightened drama and dark foreboding that nevertheless ends with an exhilarating stretto.I could not ask any more of these performances. They are simply masterful. This is a recording that I'll be playing repeatedly through the years.Strongly recommended.Scott Morrison

I agree with the previous review that Vincenzo Maltempo is a pianist with all the goods necessary for this marvelous, quirky, insanely difficult music. But since the onset of the Alkan renaissance forty-five years ago with recordings by Raymond Lewenthal and Ronald Smith, there have followed incendiary CDs by Marc-André Hamelin and Jack Gibbons which set the bar so high that it is almost humanly impossible to equal or top them. And although Maltempo is a fine pianist, he misses the mark -- pace Ethan James McCollum -- precisely where ardor and understanding are most needed: in the mysteriously appealing Trois Morceaux. His playing in these odd pieces is dull. That said, his performance of Festin d'Ésope and the Sonatine is excellent, if still a little short of Hamelin's. As for the Ouverture (the eleventh of the minor key études), he again makes it dull when compared with Hamelin or Gibbons.Scott Morrison

Lukas Geniusas is a 23-year-old Muscovite of Lithuanian background who has medaled in a number of international piano competitions including the Gina Bachauer in Salt Lake City (2nd place, 2003, at the age of 13). His father is pianist Petras Geniusas and his uncle is conductor Julius Geniusas. Apparently his musical genes (and a great deal of hard work) stand him in good stead because this recording of the Opp. 10 and 25 études by Chopin are really quite good. Clearly he has the fingers to negotiate the often very daunting intricacies of these works, but he also makes satisfying music of them as well, something that is not always done by young pianist firebrands. For instance, he plays the languidly lovely Op. 10, No. 3 in E Major stunningly. His playing is somewhere between the extremely polished approach of Murray Perahia Chopin: Etudes, Op. 10 & Op. 25 and the glittering first recording of of the Études by Augustin Anievas Augustin Anievas, Piano, Chopin: The 24 Etudes, Opp. 10 & 25. (Anievas has also recently re-recorded them at age 75 but I have not heard that version; it has garnered very good reviews.) The recording Maurizio Pollini made in his twenties is transcendent and impeccable but the sound is now dated Etudes.Given the recommendations I can say that Geniusas doesn't quite match the performances of his older colleagues but I'm glad I have it. It has given me several hours of intense pleasure.Scott Morrison

To those who don't know of her, Janina Fialkowska is a 60ish Canadian pianist who was born and educated primarily in Montréal. She also studied in Paris with Yvonne Lefébure and in New York with Sasha Gorodnitski. In 1974 she won the Arthur Rubinstein competition in Israel. She has had a busy career but has not had the kind of enormous international acclaim that her musicianship deserves. I typically obtain just about everything she records and have heard her in recital a number of times. Her playing reminds me of that of Wilhelm Kempff in that it is unfailingly elegant, songful, often quieter than some more bombastic players (although she is perfectly capable of dramatic playing as well), and consistently apt. Her style is perfectly suited to these two Schubert piano sonatas which are among the most lyrical he wrote. (Not surprisingly she has also done a fair amount of collaborative work with singers of lieder.)These two sonatas -- No. 13 in A Major, D.664; and No. 18 in G Major, D.894 -- are among Schubert's loveliest and most popular. The fairly brief (18 minutes) No. 13 is unusually in three movements. It was written in the same year, 1819, as the composer's Trout Quintet and shares some of its happy pastoral quality. It was written when Schubert was in the Austrian countryside and one can imagine that the tranquility of that scenery influenced his writing. Fialkowska captures the peaceful atmosphere of the work as well as any pianist I've ever heard.No. 18 came nine years later and is in the usual four movements. Its first movement is nearly as long as the entire No. 13 but its mood is of a piece with the earlier sonata in that it never raises its voice, has long lyrical lines and conveys a sense of peace and contentment. The Andante begins in much the same mood but the second theme is stormy. The movement ends as it began. The Minuetto is in B minor and has an extraordinarily rapt Trio section that reminds one of Schubert's E flat piano trio. The finale is a Rondo in whose nave joy one hears echoes of 'Das Wandern' from Die Schöne Müllerin. Again, Fialkowska captures the loveliness, naïveté, joyfulness and songfulness of this marvelous sonata as well as I've ever heard it.This one is a winner.Scott Morrison

Charles Rosen recorded this Goldbergs in 1967 (issued in 1969) -- with the legendary producer Thomas Z. Shepard at the controls -- and it was a best-seller in its day, then on LP. I owned it and loved it but when we all converted to CDs I didn't seek out a CD reissue. I see that it was actually reissued on SONY Classical in 1992 Bach: Goldberg Variations BWV 988 / Charles Rosen but I never heard it in that version. Newton Classics seems to be reissuing worthwhile recordings these days and I have in fact never heard a bad performance from them.Charles Rosen (1927-2012) is not as well-known these days as he was several decades ago. And even then he was probably better known for his musicological writings, primary of which was his amazingly helpful 'The Classical Style' (1971) still a model of its type. But he was always sterling pianist and his performances and recordings always worth hearing.Rosen never performed the Goldberg Variations in recital and is quoted in George Hall's excellent liner notes as having said that it 'was meant for home study and could not be played as Bach would have intended except in solitude'. This is as may be, but it is also possible that Rosen realized that this monster of a piece is difficult to pull off in live performance, especially for a pianist even the least little bit nervous, as Rosen could be. And it says something that this recording was made over a period of a week, not in one or two or three 'takes'. This is no criticism because the variations, meant for a two-keyboard harpsichord, are a veritable bitch to play without the pianist's fingers tripping over each other. And of course each variation is complete in itself, thus made for this piecemeal recording process. In the end, though, this recording is one for the ages and has something to say that others do not. Rosen laid out the architecture of this amazingly cogent set of variations over a ground bass -- a giant chaconne, if you prefer -- with grace and sharply etched lines. There is no taffy-pulling or romantic mooning in this recording. Rosen plays it 'straight' but also makes poetry of its structure. All the lines are crystal clear without the idiosyncratic staccato playing one hears from Gould and his imitators. Recorded sound is exemplary.This recording is definitely one for lovers of the Goldbergs and also for those coming to them anew.Scott Morrison

I'm of that generation that was hit between the eyes by the 1955 Glenn Gould recording of the Goldbergs and I've been collecting recordings ever since. Last time I counted I had more than twenty-five. As well, I've played it on the piano for my own edification and amusement. For a number of years I've owned a CD of the two-piano elaboration of the Goldbergs by Josef Rheinberger, revised by Max Reger, played by the French team of Stephan Paulello and Gérard Marie Fallour, and recently pulled it out to give it a listen, for comparison with this recording.A word about the elaboration of the hallowed Goldbergs. Unlike Robin Holloway's complete rewriting of the Variations, Gilded Goldbergs Gilded Goldbergs, this version sticks pretty much to Bach's original except that there are many additions of countermelodies, doubled octaves, displaced octaves and the like. One never feels, though, that Bach is being desecrated, but rather that this version is a loving enlargement of the original, and always done with charm and lightness. One of the odd things about it is that Rheinberger/Reger calls for no ornaments; this is likely due to the Bach performance practices of the late 19th/early 20th century. Appoggiaturas are played before the beat, which sounds quaint to modern ears, and there are so many missing ornaments that the Aria almost sounds like a new melody. The duo pianists Luis Magalhães and Nina Schumann, a married couple who met when studying with Vladimir Viardo at North Texas State University, have concertized all over the world and currently teach at a university in Stellenbosch, South Africa. They play and breathe as one. Compared to the version by Paulello and Fallour, their playing has more brilliance and fire. I have not heard any other recordings of the Rheinberger/Reger and thus cannot compared this one with those.If you know the Goldbergs and perhaps own several recordings, this one is for you. I would not advise that it be the first Goldbergs recording one owns but it adds to one's enjoyment of the original if you already know it.Enthusiastically recommended for the target audience.Scott Morrison

This is the second of a two-volume set of all of Dvorák's chamber works. This volume contains seven CDs, most of them in excellent performances. And it contains works you are not likely to have heard before, e.g., arrangements of several Slavonic Dances for either violin and piano, or cello and piano. The musicians on both Volume I and II are all Czech, and that makes some difference, I think, in how the music is played.
