The music on this disc is quintessential late Romantic chamber music, all of it springing from the influence of Brahms. For me at least, this is comfort music, like fresh hot rolls or, better, fresh Sacher torte. Yum.The Dohnányi Piano Quintet No. 1 (amazingly, his Opus 1!) is such a confection that is topped off by one of the most infectious movements in all of Romantic chamber music, the finale which is a rondo and fugue in 5/8 time. I defy anyone hearing this to go away without it playing in your head. It is one of my very favorite movements from that era. I imagine I've played it from this disc at least ten times. It's that good. There are other marvelous recordings of the Quintet by such groups as the Takacs Quartet with András Schiff Dohnanyi : Piano Quintet No. 1 in C minor/Sextet in C major, the Schubert Ensemble of London Dohnanyi: Piano Quintets, and the Vanbrugh Quartet with Martin Roscoe Dohnányi: The 2 Piano Quintets: No. 1 in C minor, Op. 1 / No. 2 in E flat minor, Op.26 / Suite in old Style, Op. 24 and several others. This one is right near the top.The Dvorák Second Piano Quartet, Op. 87, has also been recorded many times. One of my favorites (actually above this one) is that by the now disbanded Domus with pianist Susan Tomes Dvorák: Piano Quartets Nos. 1 & 2, Opp. 23, 87, and includes the less-familiar First Piano Quartet as well. But the absolute top of the list is the one by the Emerson Quartet and Menahem Pressler Dvorak: Piano Quintet in A Major, Op. 81; Piano Quartet in E Flat Major, Op. 87 which also includes Dvorák's Piano Quintet. Such lovely music. It's given an excellent reading here but not quite of the same quality as that of the Dohnányi.The short Élégie by Josef Suk rounds out the disc. It is wonderful, serene, nostalgic. This is not a performance that tips the balance in favor of this disc if only because it is so short, but every chamber music lover should own at least one performance of it.The Ensemble Raro, with violinist Andrej Bielow, play wonderfully. It is of note that a member of the talented Sitkovetsky family, violinist Alexander Sitkovetsky, is in the group. He is the nephew of Dmitry Sitkovetsky and the grand-nephew of legendary violinist Julian Sitkovetsky and pianist Bella Davidovich. Some bloodline!This is a good CD and if this repertoire appeals, it's worth buying.Scott Morrison

The Schuncke family is second only to the Bachs in producing generations of remarkable musicians. Over four generations they produced 23 professional musicians, most of them horn players and a number of them composers. Members of the family were, in the mid-nineteenth century, called 'the greatest horn virtuosos of their time'. This disc presents music composed by three of the Schunkes. I first became aware of the family from hearing a CD containing music of yet another Schunke, Louis SCHUNCKE:WORKS FOR PIANO. All the pieces on the present disc are given their first recordings.First is the Concertante for Violin, Cello and Orchestra by third-generation Hugo Schunke (1823-1909). It is an early Romantic work whose forebear is clearly the violin/cello sinfonia concertante by Mozart but it sounds rather more like Mendelssohn or Spohr. The first movement is a rather loose sonata-allegro based on two complementary themes that are given thorough development. The second movement is an ABA Adagio with Bellini-esque melodies. It concludes with extensive cadenzas for both soloists before a rather perfunctory closing tutti paragraph. The finale (Allegro agitato) is entitled Rondo polacca; strangely, given this title, one section is titled 'Bolero'. There are, however, mazurka-like rhythms in the outer sections. Violinist Yasushi Ideue and cellist David Pia are able soloists.Next comes the Horn Concerto by second-generation Johann Christoph Schunke (1791-1856, Hugo's uncle). Johann Christoph was himself a horn virtuoso and wrote the concerto for himself. It is one of the first concertos written for the newly developed valved chromatic horn. The first movement is a truncated sonata-allegro with virtually no development section but with bravura themes for the soloist. The second movement is a serene piece with a long arching cantilena for horn solo. It ends on a dominant seventh chord which leads directly into a joyously playful, even humorous, finale. Hornist Robert Langbein, principal horn in the Staatskappelle Dresden, is strikingly assured; it is hard to imagine this music being better played.Finally we have the Symphony in B Major for Large Orchestra by third-generation Herrmann Schuncke (1825-1898). Little is known about him because pertinent records were lost in the Dresden fire-bombing in World War II. The symphony's first movement follows classic form: slow introduction leading to a sonata-allegro. The melodic content sounds to be derived from folkmusic. There is some rather awkward use of counterpoint. The Andante second movement sounds for all the world like something by Haydn, no criticism surely but perhaps bit anachronistic since it was written in 1850. The Minuet is a genial thing with bumptious accented chords, melodic leaps and chains of trills. The Rondo finale makes use melody over droning open fifths in the bass and reminds one of similar passages in Beethoven's 7th Symphony. The second subject continues the Beethovenian reminiscence which is then subjected to contrapuntal treatment.None of these pieces of great music, but they are enjoyable for their own sake and certainly make us familiar with the work of a remarkable family of musicians. The performances by the Baden-Baden Philharmonic under Pavel Baleff are excellent.Scott Morrison

This is a reissue of a recital that, as far as I know, has never been on CD before. It was originally issued on LP in 1975, when Emanuel Ax was a new figure on the international stage. The year before he was the grand prize winner in the very first Arthur Rubinstein International Piano Master Competition in Tel Aviv. When it was issued Ax's recording was given high praise with good reason. Although Ax was only 25 when he recorded it, his playing has all the hallmarks of a seasoned master.As you can see the CD contains the magnificent B Minor Sonata No. 3 by Chopin, followed by five Schubert transcriptions by Liszt and then Liszt's own Gnomenreigen and his Paganini Etude, based on that ubiquitous Paganini theme so beloved by numerous composers.The Chopin Sonata is given a fiery reading but with all its lyricism intact. This is a reading that ranks up there with those by Rubinstein, Ann Schein, Cherkassky, Lipatti, Cortot and others. There is tasteful and effective use of rubato, varied dynamics, phrasings dictated by the internal logic of the music itself. This is a great performance.The Schubert transcriptions are lovable in their simplicity and songfulness. Liszt did not trick them out with unnecessary fireworks but, rather, treats them as the melodic gems they are. Ax does them proud. His legato is like butter. (Perhaps too evocative a simile, forgive me.) Finally we have two of the virtuosic blockbusters from Liszt's pen, played with joyous abandon.This one is a keeper.Scott Morrison

There are some record-buyers who complain that record labels keep reissuing old recordings with new covers, leading some to buy the same performances twice. I've complained about that myself a few times, although Amazon makes it easier to figure out which new releases are actually reissues, at least partly because Amazon carries old releases for a long time and one can suss out which of the new are old wine in new bottles. That being said, I will point out that this marvelous disc of Emanuel Ax playing the four Chopin Ballades and the Second Piano Sonata 'Funeral March', Op. 35 has been issued a number of times before. They were originally recorded in 1985 at Walthamstow Assembly Hall, London, issued initially by, I believe, RCA in 1986, no longer available but one can find it on eBay if one wishes. The Ballades were reshuffled onto a disc that also included Scherzos and some Mazurkas 4 Ballades / Scherzos / Mazurkas. And then four years ago the contents of this CD were reissued on RCA Red Seal Chopin: 4 Ballades  / Piano Sonata No. 2 / Funeral March (where, strangely, a couple of Amazon resellers are currently offering it for $0.01!). This issue is on Newton Classics, a small Dutch company that re-releases often outstanding recordings from the past, and they typically remaster them, too, although this one does not claim to be remastered.The bottom line is that these performances are among the best I've ever heard, and I've been collecting Chopin recordings for about sixty years. I was a little surprised, frankly, and this is my first time to own these particular performances, because I was not pleased with an early Ax recording of the two Chopin piano concertos and decided, wrongly, that Ax was not a great Chopin player and so had not bought any subsequent Ax/Chopin discs. I am SO glad I got this one, then, because my erroneous opinion flew right out the window. Ax's performances are full of fire, poetry, feeling and risky choices that feel right once you hear them. His way with all of the pieces is magnetic, alluring, charming, deeply felt. There is not a weak moment on this entire 62 minute disc.Others have felt the same way, and I would refer you to others' reviews at the other product sites whose links I provided above. You will not be disappointed if you choose to add this one to your collection.If I could give this more than five stars I would.Scott Morrison

Alessandro Deljavan first popped up on my musical radar screen when he competed in the most recent Van Cliburn International Piano Competition where he wowed me and many others. He was a semi-finalist but did not place. I suspect that was partly because of his idiosyncratic wild-man platform behavior: he sings subvocally and has a variety of behavioral tics that some find distracting. He is, however, a marvelous musician as well as pianist. For instance, his performance with the Brentano String Quartet of the Dvorák Piano Quintet in the chamber music portion of the Cliburn was simply first-rate.On this disc, devoted to some of the ferociously difficult piano music of Charles-Valentin Alkan, I hear no vocalizing, and of course one cannot see his quirky behavior at the keyboard. What I do hear is, plain and simple, great playing of these immediately attractive works. Further, the disc contains the first performance on CD of the Deux petites pièces, Op. 60, two lieder-inspired works that are delicious, and deliciously played.The biggest works here are the 'Grande études pour les deux mains séparées et réunies' ('Grand Études for both hands separated and reunited'), Op. 76. They consist of a long Fantasie for left hand alone, a longer Introduction, Variations and Finale for right hand alone, and then a Concert Study for both hands together. Each of these works is a marvel. The two works for a single hand beggar belief that they could be handled by a single hand, but beyond that they are tuneful, artfully clever, thematically varied, and constantly surprising. The last movement is for the two hands playing in unison two octaves apart in unceasing sixteenth notes and faster than the wind. It reminds one of the 'wind whistling over a graveyard' of the last movement of Chopin's Second Sonata, 'Funeral March', Op. 35. Except it is even faster than Chopin's movement. Deljavan plays these études as well as I've ever heard them.The other big work on the disc is the more familiar 'Sonatine, Op. 61', whose four movements are all more or less fast; the second movement, Allegramente, is perhaps more Andante but it moves along, too. The Scherzo goes like the wind, although it has a minuet-like middle section. If anything Deljavan plays the Scherzo more leggiero and prestissimo than even Marc-André Hamelin. The finale combines two dissimilar themes, one furiously insistent, the other like a nocturne, a movement both clever and engaging.I've been a devotee of Alkan's piano music for nigh on forty years, going back to pianists like Ronald Smith, e.g., Alkan: Piano Works and Raymond Lewenthal Piano Music of Alkan, through Marc-André Hamelin, e.g., Alkan: Grande sonate 'Les quatre ges', Sonatine, Le festin d'Esope, and Jack Gibbons Alkan: 12 Etudes Op. 39 and others, and Deljavan's playing belongs on the shelf with the best of them.Strongly recommended.Scott Morrison

Jean Françaix (1912-1997; pronounced frahN-SECKS, not frahN-SAY as one sometimes hears) was the prankster of 20th-century French music. Although he wrote some serious works (e.g., 'The Apocalypse of St. John') he is best known for his light-hearted, even funny works. I've rarely heard a work of his without at the very least chuckling and sometimes laughing out loud. The Clarinet Concerto is, in spots, laugh-out-loud funny. Françaix treats the clarinet as a jokester and puts it through some of the strangest and most appealing didos. It consists of four movements -- fast, fast, slow, fast. One of the most striking moments is in the final Alegrissimo movement where the clarinet soloist urges his instrument higher and higher in spiraling filigree until he reaches the highest reaches of the instrument whereupon the piccolo takes over and goes even higher for several measures before it comes down and the clarinet takes over again seamlessly. The first time I heard that I thought I was mishearing it, but replayed it to find it was indeed as I'd heard it. And each time I hear it I chuckle and think how clever (and effective) it is. One reads that when he was a youngster Françaix would often become bored at concerts and that he, already making attempts to compose music, vowed never to bore his audience. And I think he succeeds. His music is melodic, sparkling, easily grasped and always enjoyable. The clarinetist here, Radovan Cavallin, is a Croatian who has played all over Europe. His command of the instrument is complete; both the Françaix and Mozart demand the utmost of the soloist. His tone is like velvet except when he is playing the fast, glittering bits when it sounds like a rapier of sound. Wonderful!The Mozart Concerto is, of course, THE clarinet concerto and one cannot praise it highly enough. (It has been one of my most frequent earworms since I first heard it as a boy.) There have been easily fifty recordings of the work. My own favorites remain the ones with Antony Pay or Karl Leister, both still available here at Amazon. But make no mistake, Cavallin is a very good clarinetist and his comes a close second to my longtime favorites. He is capable of the crucial and brutally difficult articulated allegro parts and he really sings the lyrical parts.The orchestra is the regional Orquestra Filarmonica de Gran Canaria (the most populous of the Canary Islands, part of Spain) under two excellent conductors, Gabriel Chmura and Ernest Martinez; strangely, the booklet and jewel box do not precisely indicate which conductor led conducted which work although order of the listing suggests Chmura led the Françaix.Scott Morrison

I don't know what I expected when I got this book. I certainly didn't expect that it would be set in the part of the country where I grew up, and consequently the sense of familiarity I experienced was a welcome surprise. But even more I was surprised and heartened by the ingenious plotting and the evocative feeling for words and how they are put together by a really talented writer. Other reviewers have talked about the plot and the characters. I second what those who praised them have said. I was a little uneasy by the magic realism (or skeptical religiosity, if you prefer) but still found it alluring. This writer knows how to weave a tale and he also knows how to leave you in suspense so that, given that the chapters alternate between present and twenty-years-past, you keep leap-frogging from one wished-for resolution to another.I hope this writer is working on another novel. I'll be on the lookout for it, for sure.Scott Morrison

This disc is a remastered reissue of one that was initially released in the late 1970s. It is important because it contains Pavarotti in his finest period singing arias you might never had heard him sing before. And he is accompanied by the marvelous Claudio Abbado and the La Scala Orchestra. Indeed, there are two orchestral selections: the discarded original Prelude to 'Simon Boccanegra' and potpourri Overture to 'Aïda' which was never used at the premi1ere, and only very rarely since.The arias include:1. Odi il voto from 'Ernani'2. Oh dolore! from 'Attila'3. Io la vidi from 'Attila'4. Dal più remoto esilio from 'I due Foscari',5. followed by its alternative cabaletta, Sì lo sento, Iddio mi chiama6. Ô toi que j'ai chérie from 'Les Vêpres siciliennes'Of greatest interest to me were the arias from 'I due Foscari' and 'Vêpres sicilienne'. In the Foscari cabaletta there is some awkward falsetto for some very high notes and they are a bit startling, but to tell the truth Pavarotti handles them as well as is possible.Meanwhile, one must know that these recordings were done when Pavarotti's young, plangent tenor was at its very finest. His is the most attractive tenor voice of my lifetime. I can still remember hearing, at the insistence of my Argentine friend Antonio Paschino, Pavarottis very first recording, in 1964, and I was struck dumb by the beauty of the voice. And I've never recovered!Scott MorrisonP.S. I just discovered, after I'd written the above, that the original issue is still available from some of Amazon's resellers. Premieres Rare Verdi Arias I have not heard them and cannot vouch for their recorded sound. I can say that the sound on this remastered CD is quite good.

After the first thirty seconds of the first work on this CD I really thought I was in for an hour of undiluted pleasure. That first selection is the title track, 'An Amerikaner in Danmark', and it is a joyous, quirky and clever assemblage of musical snippets from the music of George Gershwin, its title an homage to Gershwin's 'An American in Paris'. Andy Pape, the composer, is an American who moved with his parents to Copenhagen when he was fifteen. He studied music there and has remained. The piece is refreshingly different and yet based on snips and snatches enough of Gershwin's music to leave a listener smiling at the familiar bits and even more so at the wonderful orchestration, harmony and sass. It has infectious joie de vivre and is marvelously played and recorded.However, after the first fourteen minutes of this disc we move on to 42 minutes of unrelieved boredom. No, I lie, some of those moments are irritating enough to relieve the boredom, but not the way one might want. The Tuba Concerto, the only one I've ever heard besides the wonderful Vaughan Williams concerto, is twenty-four minutes of tunelessness clothed in unremitting pedal points that underpin long, long held notes by the tubist with interjections of secundal harmonies in the brass and winds. There are also assaults by the percussion section that make one reach either for the volume control or the fast-forward button. One can admire the playing of the Odense Symphony Orchestra but magisterial playing in the service of such twaddle still doesn't amount to much. The actual title of the concerto is 'Suburban Nightmares', although I'm not sure why anyone would write such a thing which Pape describes as what one feels living in the suburbs -- 'man's eternal attempt to surround himself with security' -- it does not limn either security nor comfort. Unless, of course, those endless non-melodies and harmonic stasis are meant to describe the boredom of the suburb, in which case he succeeds.This is followed by what is essentially a bassoon concerto called 'Traces of Lost Time'. It is a three movement work -- The Echoes of Time, The Spiral of Time, and Traces of Time -- whose raison d'etre seems to be to provide, as Pape says, 'an echo valley' (which I frankly don't hear), an endless bassoon 'spiral' in the second movement; then in the third movement Pape says 'the bassoon' moves out of the eye of hurricane of time and out into the actual flow of time'. Say what? The bassoonist is good, though.I loved 'An Amerikaner in Danmark'. I hated the other two pieces. 'An Amerikaner in Danmark' will go into my iPod. The other two will be buried without any regrets.Scott Morrison

My title implies that one can be the one without the other. And there are numerous examples of that. Benjamin Grosvenor, though, is both and at the tender age of 20. His playing is not only absolutely secure, it is musicianly, nuanced, sparkling, and attention-holding. The program, of course, is made up of, with one exception, what would generally be called encores. The exception is the Book 1 or Albéniz's 'Iberia', which I'm bound to say gives the classic recording by Alicia de Larrocha a run for its money.I am tickled to see that the recital starts off with jazz-inflected music by a Russian composer, Nikolai Kapustin, whose music seems lately to be getting lots of recordings after decades of neglect. Marc-André Hamelin has recorded all eight of the concert études -- Grosvenor gives us only three -- and I believe does a better job with them. Nikolai Kapustin: Piano Music Still, these are more than acceptable. Then the pianist plays a couple of familiar Scarlatti sonatas with grace and élan, using just right amount of pedal when required; so many pianists try to play Scarlatti without pedal and usually that doesn't work.Following the 'Iberia' tracks we get Moritz Moszkowski's étude on repeated notes and chords, the 'Caprice Espagnol'. It is not played here for virtuosic show but for the drama it presents. Two Chopin nocturnes are given good, but not field-beating renditions; but then the competition is horrendously stiff. I did love how he presented the D flat Nocturne, Op. 27, No. 2, with its dreamy melodies. Then we get two transcriptions by the great Hungarian pianist, Georges Cziffra, with their knuckle-busting difficulties. Grosvenor handles them without breaking a sweat.And finally the only weak piece on the disc, namely Percy Grainger's arrangement of Gershwin's late evergreen, 'Love Walked In'. But the problem is with Grainger, not Grosvenor. I'm sure there are those who will disagree with me about the value of the arrangement, but much of it simply sounds corny to me. Grosvenor plays it beautifully, though.Make no mistake, Grosvenor is a comer, and perhaps indeed he has already arrived. His earlier disc Chopin, Liszt, Ravel is a winner. And he has a new one coming out next month Rhapsody in Blue: Saint-Saens, Ravel & Gershwin.Try it, you'll like it.Scott Morrison

Sequeira Costa (b. 1928) is a Portuguese pianist long on the faculty of the University of Kansas. I had the opportunity to hear him play a number of times when I lived near KU's Lawrence campus. And I often heard his student (and stepson) Artur Pizarro who has gone on to a major international career. This disc of the three earliest Beethoven piano sonatas is labeled as the first of ten discs to present all of the Beethoven sonatas. It was recorded in 1999. I believe he has now completed that series. They were originally issued on the Claudio label and were underwritten by the Vianna da Motta Foundation. The connection there is that Costa founded the Vianna da Motta Foundation in honor of his teacher who was a student of Franz Liszt and Hans von Bülow. The discs are now in the process of being reissued on Claudio's offshoot label Claudio Bohema. I had never heard any of these discs before this one came my way.Probably the main thing I can say about Costa's playing is that it is very direct, very communicative, very clear, usually quite extroverted (and this is true even in the slow movements; that is not to say there is no poetry but it is never veiled, hinted at, or mysterious). In the outer movements the forward motion is compelling and sometimes it comes across as somewhat brusque. There are also moments that are a bit too much so. Still, this is a player who has definite ideas about how these sonatas should go and he stays true to his vision. If I hadn't known Costa was in his seventies when he recorded this disc, I would have guessed this was the playing of a very much younger man. The prestissimo finale of Op. 2, No. 1 is particularly exciting.Presentation is minimal, to say the least. The only thing in the jewel box is a single page with a picture of a frowning Beethoven and a young smiling Costa. There is nothing printed on the back of that page; no notes, nothing. The back of the jewel box shows just the contents of Opp. 2, Nos. 1-3, with timings of the individual movements.Scott Morrison

[Strangely, as of the date of this review the price for the CD is less than for the mp3 download. I wonder what that's all about!]This three CD set is a compilation of three previously issued separate single CD sets. For those of us who love Freni's singing and who don't own them, this is a no-brainer. Most of the recordings were made in the early 1970s. The exceptions are the selections from Sonnambula, I Capuleti e i Montecchi, L'Amico Fritz, Suor Angelica and Carmen from 1959 (Freni was only 24 then) which make up most of the third disc. If you're looking at this on the CD page you cannot see the contents of the three CDs, but it you go to the mp3 page and see which arias and ensembles are included. (Just go to the top of this page and click on the link 'mp3 music, 23 songs, 2013'. As you'll be able to see there are familiar arias from Traviata (actually quite a few, including a glorious Violetta/Germont scene that lasts almost twenty minutes, with Sesto Bruscantini), Bohème, Turandot, Butterfly, Manon Lescaut, Gianni Schicchi (a delicious 'O mio babbino caro'), Falstaff, Otello (a lovely and touching first act duet ['Gia nella notte densa'] with tenor Franco Bonisolli) et al.There are other singers involved where required. Primarily the tenor is Franco Bonisolli whose voice, while appealing, is occasionally stretched to capacity; his Otello, though, is surprisingly pretty darn good. The conductors are the virtually unknown Leone Magiera and Ino Savino; the Traviata excerpts are led by Lamberto Gardelli. The orchestras are all respectable German ensembles (Staatskapelle Berlin, Hamburg Philharmonic, Munich Rundfunkorchester).There is a brief set of notes about Freni, but no lyrics are supplied. The sound is remastered but still shows its age, but not jarringly so.I suspect this issue is primarily for collectors of all things Freni, but for someone who is attracted to this repertoire, or someone coming to these arias and scenas for the first time, one could certainly do worse.Scott Morrison

I first owned these performances in the 1990s when they originally came out Bartok: Violin Concertos, No. 1 & 2 but apparently lost that CD at a time when we moved from Kansas to Vermont. So I was delighted to see this reissue on the budget Brilliant Classics label. I gather it has been reissued a couple of times in between. The reason for this is simple: these are brilliant performances. Iván Fischer conducts surely one of the better European ensembles, the Budapest Festival Orchestra, and is in total synch with Zehetmair who is surely one of the shining stars among current violinists. Zehetmair brings a little more edginess to these concertos and that's precisely what they need as compared with the softer outlines of, say, James Ehnes's recent recording. There is an old Isaac Stern recording but it is let down both by its aged sound and by the somewhat dispirited playing of the Philadelphia Orchestra. I have not heard the recordings by Arabella Steinbacher or Isabelle Faust but can imagine that they, too, are competitive.At any rate, these performances are excellent and I can recommend them unreservedly. We don't often get to hear the First Concerto (which, written in 1907, had to wait 51 years for its first performance in 1958) yet it has its charms which, for me at least, have grown to be a favorite.Recommended.Scott Morrison

The biggest work on this disc is the amazing Fantasie, Op. 17 of Schumann which was, as far as I know, not any sort of 'Homage to Brahms' as the CD's title suggests. But it's a masterful piece of music, possibly Schumann's best piano work, and it pains me to say that Ignacy Lisiecki's performance of it is a desecration. If it weren't for the modern sounding recorded sound -- and more about that in a moment* -- I might have been tempted to think this was a performance by that bad boy of pianism of yesteryear, Vladimir de Pachmann. The willfulness and downright misplaying of the music is barely tolerable to my ears. There is such pushing and pulling of the tempi, sometimes rushing here, sometimes slowing down to a crawl there that one gets seasick. It is clear that Lisiecki has technique sufficient to play the work as it should be played, although there are occasional smudged passages. Further he tends to bang in the loud passages rather than get deeply into the keys to render a thunderous but musical sound. His legato is tenuous and sometimes simply lacking. And when we get to the 'lento sostenuto - sempre piano' third movement it is neither lento sostenuto nor sempre piano; this delicate and deeply felt movement roars as if it were the typical allegro final movement of a sonata which it decidedly is not.The miniatures, Schumann's Romance Op. 28, No. 2, Brahms's Rhapsodies Nos. 1 and 2 from Op. 79, as well as Lisiecki's own 'Fantasy on a Theme from the (organ) Chorale Prelude of Brahms, Op. 122, No. 2, suffer from much the same treatment.Understand, I do not gainsay an artist's right to put his own stamp on a piece. In fact, one almost demands it. But the wild and willful depredations of this young pianist in these works is a disgrace.*The recorded sound is clattery and downright ugly at times. Part of that is, of course, due to the pianist, but much of it is surely due to the engineering from Dux.Scott Morrison

The title is a bit of a misnomer because practically all of Brahms's late piano music is more or less miniature in length. This is not to say that there is no profound music here. But none of these pieces from Opp. 76, 116 and 117 lasts longer than seven minutes. Granted the capriccios and intermezzi (as all of these works are titled) are gathered into three 'suites' but in fact Brahms didn't really expect them to be played as such, but rather as individual works. And indeed that is how they are most often heard in recital. One interesting thing about them is that there are knotty works alongside rather simple lyrical works. And that is what tends to cause music lovers to have disparate reactions to them. Some love them all, others love some of them only. All of them are in more or less ABA form but oftimes expanded or elaborated upon. There is nary a sonata allegro form among them, nor a rondo. Still the diversity Brahms finds within this simple format is astonishing.Peter Longworth is a fiftyish pianist born in England who studied primarily in the US and England and is known primarily as a teacher at the Glenn Gould School in Toronto, but he does concertize and perform in chamber music concerts primarily in North America. He is a gifted pianist whose approach to Brahms is rather straighforward. There are no pushing-and-pulling nor outré effects. But his playing does tend to have a somewhat grayish aspect. He is much more appealing in the lyrically attractive or light-hearted works, e.g. Op. 76 Nos. 2, 6 & 7; Op. 116, Nos. 3, 4 6; and Op. 116, Nos. 1 & 2. He is somewhat less successful in the denser, more dramatic works. These are acceptable performances overall but don't eclipse other better-known recordings, e.g. Julius Katchen (a magnificent 6CD set at a very budget price) Solo Piano Works. There are recordings of some of these works by such sterling pianists as Murray Perahia, Steven Kovacevich and Hélène Grimaud, among others. I can only manage a lukewarm recommendation then.Scott Morrison

I really like this fish oil preparation in gummy form largely because for some reason the regular capsules tend to get caught in my throat and they are then the devil to get down (or back up). The problem is that I discovered that they are actually cheaper at my local drug store and a lot more at Costco. You might want to check the price out in your locale. They certainly solved a problem for me; I was about ready to give up in fish oil before I found these.Oh, and they're pretty good tasting, too.Scott Morrison

I don't eat these bars too often but when I'm in a hurry and have missed a meal I grab one because I know I'm getting 20 grams of protein. The taste is merely OK. I find that it goes down better if I sip coffee as I eat it. And it does tend to get a little soft in the heat, so don't leave bars in your car if it's hot outside. But as a convenience, it's helpful.Scott Morrison

I have enjoyed the recordings of the Trio di Parma, a group formed at the Boito Conservatory in Parma twenty years or so ago. Their recording of piano trio music by the woefully under-represented composer, Ildebrando Pizzetti, was very satisfying: Trio in La / Tre Canti. But this two-CD set of Dvorák's piano trios is somewhat less than the best because there are some truly outstanding Dvorák complete piano trio collections out there, and for the most popular two (Nos. 3 and 4 'Dumky') there are many excellent performances. I imagine that the reason most people would be buying this or any other complete collection would be because they are curious about Dvorák's first two trios. The First and Second were written in 1875 and 1876 and they are much less likely on first hearing to be recognized as by Dvorák, but they are more than student works, too. The Third and Fourth Trios are masterpieces of the first rank, and indeed although No. 4 'Dumky' is the much better-known work, the No. 3 is possibly the greater work. In any event these performances by the Trio di Parma are mostly unexceptionable, but they also don't have much new, different or enlightening to add; indeed, at times the playing is a little wooden. Further, the recorded sound is just a bit shrill in spots.My preferred sets of the complete Dvorák piano trios are those by the Beaux Arts Trio Dvorák: Complete Piano Trios, the Suk Trio Dvorak: Complete Piano Trios and the Trio Fontenay (no longer available at Amazon but as a used set from one of their resellers) Antonin Dvorak Complete Piano Trios 1-4 (2 CD Box Set) (Teldec).Scott Morrison

Think about it: where, except for a set containing Saint-Sans' piano concertos, have you ever seen a CD with four, count 'em, four French piano concertos? These are excellent works which, except for the Ravel G Major Concerto, are rarely heard in concert or even on disc. Odder still, this is a CD with a German pianist and a German orchestra.So, how are they? Well, it's definitely a mixed bag. There is a definite lack of poetry in the Debussy Fantaisie for Piano and Orchestra. This proto-impressionist work by the twenty-year-old Debussy is a lovely, dreamy thing which in this reading is rather too literal. I lay most of the blame for that one the orchestra, the Deutsche Radio Philharmonie under conductor Pablo González. There is some lovely individual playing here and in the other concertos, most notably by the double reeds, but the whole thing just sounds like a casual saunter along the high street.Things are different in the sassy Françaix Concertino -- whose four movements last all of eight minutes -- because the orchestration is lighter and clearer. Françaix had a way of tossing off musical witticisms that catch one offguard and then make one chuckle. Uhlig, whose recordings I've tended to enjoy, is superb here.The Poulenc concerto seems to just miss the Gallic wryness that is so necessary to convey. The notes are all there -- although there are some decidedly odd tempo choices from the conductor -- but there doesn't seem to be the enjoyment that one wishes for in this piece that shows us both the light-hearted and the lyrically sentimental sides of Poulenc.Uhlig's performance of the Ravel is first-rate, but again the orchestra lets him down a bit. He is sprightly in the outer movements and appropriately understated in the melancholy middle movement. Again, there are some very odd tempo choices by the conductor. Further, there has never been a recording of this concerto that comes close to matching that of Arturo Benedetto Michelangeli Ravel: Piano Concerto in G / Rachmaninov: Piano Concerto No. 4 (Great Recordings of the Century).This CD is a near-miss when compared to other individual recordings of these concertos. But as a collection of all four concertos on one disc I suppose one might be tempted, for cost reasons alone, to acquire. Your choice.Scott Morrison

Arturo Benedetti Michelangeli was 36 when these two live performances were recorded by Sudwest Rundfunk of Cologne. The SWR symphony orchestra is under a virtually unknown conductor, Antoine de Bavier, best known as a clarinetist. And the orchestra is not in top form, with a few sour notes and with almost running away with itself in the first movement of Concerto No. 15. However, this is full-blooded Mozart, recorded before 'historically-informed performance practice' began insisting on reduced orchestras, and because tempi tend to be very forward-looking, these are spirited, exciting readings. Michelangeli IS in top form with gorgeous tone and impeccable technique. I have rarely come across a D Minor Concerto with such sass. One tends to think of this concerto as being just a tad serious but Michelangeli makes one almost laugh with the way he tosses off the almost Haydnesque turns of phrase, particularly in the final Rondo. The Romanze is tender and yet not sappy. The opening of the D Minor does not take itself as seriously as some readings do; rather, the emphasis is on dramatic excitement, partly due to Bavier's and Michelangeli's choice of faster tempi than ordinarily used.Another highlight is the light-heartedness of the final Rondo of No. 15. Michelangeli, a rather dour man in person, seems to be having a great time.This is masterful, personal playing of the highest order. It's a shame Michelangeli is not quite equalled by the orchestra but the soloist makes up for any disappointment from the orchestra. This is, for me, a set of performances to treasure. (And it will immediately go onto my iPod so we can take it with us when we go on an auto trip next week.)Scott Morrison

The thing that makes this issue worth hearing -- aside from some terrific playing by the Trio Testore -- is a chance to hear, side by side, the two versions Brahms made of his Piano Trio in B Minor, Op. 8. He wrote the first version when he was 20 (1854), the second version 35 years later. Both versions were published but in the modern world we only ever hear the revised version. I'd never encountered a recording of the original version, and certainly never heard it in live performance. Scores of both versions are available for download at imslp dot org, and they make for interesting comparisons. (I do understand that there was an earlier recording of the 'Urfassung' ['original version'] made in the 1990s by the Arcadia Trio but I never heard it.)Brahms, from the very first, was dissatisfied with his first version and said even at the time that he would probably want to revise it sometime. Neither he nor anyone else realized he wouldn't get around to it until 1889, after he had written almost all his music. If it had been numbered in sequence (rather than retaining the Op. 8 designation, which he insisted on when it was published in 1890) it would have been Op. 108.One of the primary differences is the first version's prolixity, as well as a overabundance of rather prosaic material. It is really jarring to hear tightly organized, emotionally powerful sections cheek-by-jowl with what seems like mindless wanderings, particularly in the first movement but also in the finale. The timing for the first movement in the original version is 21:22, in the revised version 15:44; for the finale the original is 11:15, the revision 7:03. The Scherzo second movement is pretty much the same in both version except for the endings, each of which is effective; in the first version the ending more or less dissolves into sparsely voiced pizzicato strings, the second has some wonderful vigorous piano interjections. One wonders why Brahms thought he needed to change the original ending since each ending has its considerable merits. The Adagio third movement differs primarily in that in the original there is a sudden burst of allegro toward the end that, because it has been a quite slow movement, tends to quicken one's pulse and lead one to expect the brilliant finale. The composer took that irruption out in the final version of the Adagio, perhaps to its detriment. The finale Allegro molto, like the first movement, is extensively revised. In the first version there is a good deal of wandering about with stops and starts and inclusion of perhaps too many differing ideas. The revision tightens things considerably, drops some of the more mundane material, and creates a much more powerful conclusion to the work. There is, however, a lovely lyrical theme, or set of themes, that Brahms drops from the original in which I hear echoes of in his later Second Symphony. Perhaps he knew he had a good thing but needed to drop it from the original in order to make it more effective. Whatever the case, I'm glad it's in the original and that we get to hear it in this recording.The other two trios are given inspiriting readings by the Trio Testore but frankly nothing makes them stand out from other easily available recordings. My own personal favorites are the performances by Julius Katchen, Josef Suk and Janos Starker Brahms: Piano Trios Nos. 1 - 3 / Cello Sonata No. 2 / Scherzo for Violin & Piano and by Eugene Istomin, Isaac Stern and Leonard Rose Brahms: Piano Trios Nos. 1- 3, Opp. 8,87,101 / Schubert: Piano Trios Nos. 1 & 2, d. 898, 929 (Isaac Stern Collection- Trio Recordings, Vol. 1).I can recommend this two-SACD set for both performances and for sound. And for the wonderful experience of being able to compare those two versions of the Op. 8.Scott Morrison

[When I first saw this CD cover I thought Anagnoson and Kinton were modestly calling THEMSELVES 'piano titans'. Then I realized they were referring to Clementi, Beethoven and Schubert.]We seem to be getting a Clementi boomlet lately, which is good because for many of us he is best known either as the composer of music for students (études and the like) or as a manufacturer of pianos. But he was indeed a good composer of music intended for public performance and these two sonatas demonstrate that. There is plenty of virtuosity, of course, but there is also interesting music with pleasant melodies, sudden harmonic twists, and fluent forms.The marches by Beethoven were written for piano duet (four hands at one piano) and were intentionally not particularly serious or complex, intended as they were for amateur pianists. They are filled with march-like effects, imitating drum rolls and fanfares. They are among the most negligible of Beethoven's piano works, but they are charming for all that.In an entirely different category is Schubert's Fantasie in F Minor, D940, for piano duet. This is, in the opinion of many (including me), the most important piano duet work of its time. I would even suggest it is the most important piano duet of all time. There is much to admire in this performance -- the admirable legatos, the apt phrasing, dynamics that are in absolute synch between to two pianists. I would not rank it as highly as I do the classic performance by Radu Lupu and Murray Perahia which has never been out of the catalog since it was originally issued in 1987 Mozart: Sonata, K.448; Schubert: Fantasia, Op. 103, D.940. But it comes damn close, which is high praise.James Anagnoson and Leslie Kinton have been performing as a piano duo since shortly after they met at the Aspen Music Festival and School thirty years ago. Both of them teach in Ontario where they are on the faculty of The Glenn Gould School; Anagnoson is Dean. They are among the most highly regarded piano duos currently before the public. Their synchronicity is among the best one will ever hear.The playing on this disc is admirable. The music, aside from the Schubert, is not deathless but certainly pleasant, even inspiriting. As for the Schubert, I'm on record about it.Recommended.Scott Morrison

For this paltry sum you can own twelve complete recordings of Verdi operas on DVD in mostly marvelous, recent (the oldest from 1998) productions. Look at the fine print on the picture of the back side of this huge box and you'll see. Consider:From Covent Garden:Simon Keenlyside in 'Macbeth'Christine Schäfer and Marcelo Álvarez in 'Rigoletto  (the Rigoletto, Paolo Gavanelli, I'd never heard of but he's good)José Cura, Veronica Villarroel and Dmitri Hvorostovsky in 'Trovatore'Renée Fleming, Joseph Calleja and Thomas Hampson in 'Traviata'Placído Domingo, Marina Poplavskaya, Ferruccio Furlanetto and Joseph Calleja in 'Simon Boccanegra'Bryn Terfel and Barbara Frittoli in 'Falstaff'From the Netherlands Opera:'Sicilian Vespers' with singers I didn't know but who carry this difficult opera off admirablyRobert Lloyd, Rolando Villazon, Amanda Roocroft in 'Don Carlo'From the Teatro Real in Madrid:Marcel Álvarez and Violeta Urmana in 'Ballo in maschera'The Liceu in Barcelona:Daniela Dessi and Fabio Armiliato in 'Aida'José Cura, Krassimira Stoyanova, and Lado Ataneli in 'Otello'From the Mariinsky Opera in St. Petersburg:Galina Korchakova, Nikolai Putilin and Gegam Grigorian (Valery Gergiev, conductor) - La Forza del DestinoAll of these productions have been reviewed here at Amazon in their single-opera format. You might want to look them up to see what others say about them.The DVDs are packed in three boxes with swing-out sleeves; there are seventeen DVDs in total (some of the operas take up two DVDs). There is a thick book of notes and synopses (with terrific pictures of the productions). Even if you already own one or two of these, for this price you simply can't go wrong.Snap this one up.Scott Morrison

There have already been three reviews here that laud these performances of Prokofiev's 'War Sonatas', Nos. 6, 7 & 8. I want to add my praise. With the minor exception of what I consider to be a rather too fast tempo in the finale of the 7th, one that somewhat smudges the alternating chords, these are examplary performances. (For what it's worth, the pianist writes in his notes that he consciously takes a wild tempo here rather than the somewhat more moderate tempo taken by the sonata's dedicatee, Sviatoslav Richter.) Giltburg manages to convey the ferocity,  dread, veiled sarcasm, and tenderness of these heartfelt works, written by Prokofiev at a time when Russian artists were experiencing brutal repression by Stalin's cultural police. The 7th, in fact, was almost certainly written in reponse to the arrest and exile and ultimately murder of his close friend, the theatrical director Vsevelod Meyerhold and his wife.Sound is absolutely first-rate and this helps make this a stunning listening experience.Scott Morrison

I did not realize when I ordered this 2CD set that it was played on period instruments: gut-strung violin, viola and cello, and four different fortepianos, a different one for each of the four works here. My review will be colored, therefore, by my own mild dislike for the sound of the fortepiano. For those who love the fortepiano this may be a revelation as to the variation in sound from the different instruments.In order:Felix Mendelssohn: Piano Trio No. 1 in D Minor, Op. 49. This is rather tame performance of this wonderful trio. This is true not only because of the milder sound of the older instruments but also because of the style of playing that these musicians present. There are many, many recordings of this trios (often coupled with the Second Piano Trio) and in no particular order I much prefer the recordings by Perlman/Ma/Ax Mendelssohn: Piano Trios Nos. 1 & 2, Opp. 49,66, Kalichstein/Laredo/Robinson Mendelssohn Trios - Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio CD, Istomin/Rose/Stern Mendelssohn: Piano Trios Nos. 1 & 2, Opp. 49,66, and the Florestan Trio Mendelssohn: The Piano Trios as well as newcomers Gilad/Müller-Schott/Fischer Mendelssohn: Piano Trios Nos. 1 & 2 [Hybrid SACD]. All of these listed recordings feature both Mendelssohn Trios. In this set the Second Trio is on CD 2 and the same comments apply although I found the performance rather more enjoyable, at least partly because pianist Hrvoje Jugovic is using a different piano (the individual pianos used are listed below) and the playing sounds more in keeping with the Trio's often brilliant piano writing.Also on CD 1 is the astonishingly assured trio written by the 11-year-old Mendelssohn using the unusual instrumentation of violin, viola and piano. It is clearly a work by an unformed talent, borrowing as it does from Mozartean models, but there is much to admire. There is a hint of the Midsummer Night's Dream 'fairy music' in the trio's Scherzo.CD2 begins with the Second Trio by Felix mentioned above and is followed by Fanny Mendelssohn Hensel's Piano Trio in D Minor, Op. 11. This work is new to me and is, quite frankly, pleasantly well-crafted, if not quite as graciously tuneful as the two trios by her brother. The bravura first movement is really virtuosic for the pianist. There are some unusual harmonic twists that make one catch one's breath; they sound like the kind of thing Schumann was to do later.The instruments:Hrvoje Jugovic plays four different pianos:Felix's Piano Trio No. 1 -- Johann Baptist Streicher, Vienna, 183611-year-old Felix's Trio -- Paul McNulty, made in Divisov, Czech Republic, 2006, after Walther und Sohn, Vienna, c. 1805Felix's Piano Trio No. 2 -- John Broadwood & Sons, London, 1838Fanny's Piano Trio -- Johann Michael Schweighofer, Vienna, 1854Maria Bader-Kubizek plays a violin made by Johann Rombach, Vienna, 2002, after Giuseppe Guarneri, Cremona, 1734Dorothea Schönweise plays a cello made by Georg Klotz, Mittenwald, c. 1770Silvia Schweinberger plays a viola made by Caspar Strnad, Prague, 1793CD1 42'30CD2 53'01The three-star rating is admittedly colored by my own feelings about period pianos. Others will surely disagree and give it a higher rating.Scott Morrison

This set of performances was originally issued on LPs back in the early 1950s and then issued in 1992 on CD by Deutsche Grammophon Beethoven: Die Klavierkonzerte. It has rarely been out of print and has been uniformly praised throughout all these years. Kempff was a superb interpreter of these concertos, among the best on record. In Concertos 1-4 he uses his own musically apt cadenzas. Although these recordings were made in the 1950s and thus are in mono, the sound is very clear and one is barely aware of their being almost sixty years old. The Dutch conductor, Paul van Kempen, is hardly remembered today but he was prominent from the 1930s to his death in 1955. He suffered some bad publicity because he conducted in Holland during the German occupation while others had refused to conduct or had fled. Still, he was a marvelous conductor and these performances demonstrate that.There is something odd about this release on United Classics in that only Kempff's name appears on the jewel box or the cover of the enclosed booklet. One has to hunt to find that this is the Berliner Philharmoniker under van Kempen. The rather generic booklet notes confine themselves to an essay about Kempff and were not proofread very accurately; e.g. 'Potsdam', where Kempff lived, is 'Postsdam'). One wonders if this is an unauthorized release. Strangely, or perhaps not, the DG set is still available here at Amazon for a slightly lower price and includes the original liner notes. Thus I am inclined to give the overall release only four stars as opposed to the five stars for the original DG release.Scott Morrison

I ordered this because our local opera company is doing a production of Eugene Onegin. I am not in the production but am an active board member who does the pre-curtain talks for some of the performances, so I have been going to rehearsals. The vocal score itself is fine in terms of the piano reduction of the orchestral score. But a big  drawback is that the sung text is only in Russian (using the Cyrillic characters) and in English. It would have been helpful if the Cyrillic had also been romanized, that is in western letters. But even more bothersome is that there are no rehearsal numbers or even bar numbers. It makes it difficult to discuss with others, during the rehearsal process, 'where we are' or 'where we will begin', etc. For these reasons I can't really recommend it except for those who already read the Cyrillic (Russian) alphabet and have no need of markers for locations in the score.Scott Morrison

As the foremost Estonian composer of his era, Heino Eller (1887-1970) is revered in his country. To those of us from elsewhere he is probably best known as the teacher of Arvo Pärt, the current leading light of Estonian music. Thanks to critic turned music entrepreneur Martin Anderson, the founder of Toccata Classics, we are now getting a slew of recordings of music from the Baltic states and discovering some laudable works. This is the third in a series of CDs -- there will be seven -- of Eller's complete works for piano, all played by Estonian pianist Sten Lassmann, an artist in his early thirties.On this disc are works from what are roughly Eller's early, middle and late periods, including Three Studies (1917-1919), Five Préludes (1929-1930), Ten Lyric Pieces (1942-1943) and his Fourth Piano Sonata (1957-1958).In their order on the CD:The Ten Lyric Pieces, formally inspired by Grieg's Lyric Pieces, are mostly somber, even melancholy, pieces written in the period immediately after Eller's Jewish first wife was taken by the SS and a few months later executed. The music here is, in the main, gripping, heart-rending. Interestingly there is a seemingly inappropriate mazurka-like piece, No. 8, which however is secretly apt as a Chopin mazurka was one of the last pieces Eller heard his wife, a pianist, play. The last, and longest, Lyric Piece is a set of variations ending in a quadruple fugue.The early Three Studies are rather more lyrical than the Lyrical Pieces, sounding to some extent like Grieg or Christian Sinding. Most effective is the third one, in G Flat Major, which has ceaseless sixteenth notes throughout. The second study, also in G Flat, is brief and somewhat jocular. The first, in A Flat Major, is navely pastoral, describing dawn with the rising of a brilliant sun.The Five Préludes are considerably more spare than the Studies, even cryptic in style. Almost diffident, only one of them even has a key signature or easily discernible pulse. There is an underlying angst in all of them.The Piano Sonata No. 4, Eller's last, was written in the late 1950s after the composer had gone through the 'Social Realism', 'anti-Formalist' phase in Soviet music during which he had to conform to cultural czar Andrei Zhdanov's edicts about what kind of music was allowed. Modern-sounding without being atonal, the three-movement sonata is somewhat neoclassic, with a first movement in modified sonata-allegro form. The second movement is contemplative, musing, often lyrical. It leads without pause into the vivo finale, a rondo whose themes are graceful, lilting, and light-hearted until sforzando chordal passages lead to a dramatic coda on a pedal point, what the booklet writer, the pianist Sten Lassmann, calls a 'tragic outcry'.Many of the pieces here are receiving their first recordings. Sten Lassmann is a fine pianist doing a major service to the memory of a composer whose music deserves to be heard.Scott Morrison

This is a reissue of the 1999 Nimbus 2CD set of a performance Vladimir Feltsman gave in Moscow. That set has had a long, illustrious life and it's not clear to me why it has been reissued as that one is still available, especially since this one does not include the Two-Part Inventions that were on the original issue. Vladimir Feltsman. J.S. Bach  Six Partitas / Two Part Inventions (2 CDs) Whatever the case, though, this is a valuable traversal of these dance-inspired suites by Bach. They have been recorded by just about every major pianist* over the years but Feltsman brings something of his own to them and they are definitely worth hearing. He never forgets that most of the individual movements of the partitas are based on dance forms, e.g. Minuet, Gavotte, Sarabande, Courante, Allemande, Gigue.Feltsman's style probably most closely resembles that of Gould with much use of staccato or detaché playing but his phrasing and dynamics are much more varied and full of life. He brings startlingly pleasant and convincing variation to some of the repeats which sound almost improvised. His obvious enjoyment in conveying rhythmic vitality is palpable, making these some of the most brilliantly charged readings on records. Add to that the current budget pricing and you have a complete winner.Total playing time: 2 hrs.Enthusiastically recommended.Scott Morrison*Glenn Gould Partitas 1 2 & 3 - Anniversary Edition & Partitas 4 5 & 6 - 70th Anniversary Edition, Murray Perahia Bach: Partitas No. 1, 5 & 6 & Bach: Partitas Nos. 2-4, András Schiff Bach: Six Partitas, Angela Hewitt Bach: The Six Partitas, Richard Goode Bach: Partitas Nos. 1, 3 & 6 & Bach: Partitas Nos. 2, 4, 5, and Craig Sheppard J.S. Bach: The Six Keyboard Partitas, to name some of my favorites.

I have mixed feelings about this disc. On the one hand it features brilliant playing by Martha Argerich and her frequent duo-piano partner Alexandre Rabinovitch. But on the other hand it is a reissue of a Teldec disc still-available here at Amazon Mozart: Piano Sonatas, K448, K501, K521, K381 at whose product site  you can read some other customer reviews. The Teldec costs about the same but has the original notes which this disc does not have. All one gets in this issue's jewel box is a page listing contents and a page of ads. I suppose if you don't want the notes this has a very slight price advantage.But for those are coming to these delightful Mozart piano four-hand duets and two piano works for the first time, it might be helpful to have the notes. It's for you to decide.Scott Morrison

My mother was using Durkees sixty years ago and that's what I felt I had to have on things like hamburgers, grilled cheese sandwiches and the like. But after I grew up and married we lived where it wasn't easy to find. Now, after moving to Vermont, we find it again. But in the meantime we bought it from Amazon and that was, for me, a life-saver (well, maybe I'm being a bit hyperbolic to say that, but you know what I mean). This is one of the tastes of my childhood and as such is one of my comfort foods.Terrific sauce. Trust me.Scott Morrison

This CD is now part of a 9CD budget-priced box-set Nikolai Lugansky containing music of Chopin, Rachmaninov and Beethoven, as well as this disc of Prokofiev's 4th and 6th sonatas and the ten pieces from Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet Ballet arranged for piano by Prokofiev himself. The box set is a definite recommendation and since it only costs about what two regular-priced CDs would cost, that's a real bargain.Scott Morrison

For those who like Lugansky's playing (as I do) you might be interested to know that this CD with the Paganini Rhapsody plus the Variations on a Theme by Corelli and that on a Theme by Chopin, as well as the two CDs containing the four concertos are now part of a budget-priced 9CD box costing about the same as two CDs at full price. It is here: Nikolai LuganskyCheck it out.Scott Morrison

For those who like Lugansky's playing (as I do) you might be interested to know that this CD and the ones with the other concertos plus the Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini are now part of a budget-priced 9CD box (whose total cost as I write this is about what you'd pay for two CDs otherwise) here: Nikolai LuganskyScott Morrison

For those who like Lugansky's playing (as I do) you might be interested to know that this CD and the ones with the other concertos plus the Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini are now part of a budget-priced 9CD box (whose total cost as I write this is about what you'd pay for two CDs otherwise) here: Nikolai LuganskyScott Morrison

If you're interested in Nikolai Lugansky -- and who wouldn't be; he's one of the finest pianists to emerge in the last twenty years -- you can get this disc as part of a 9CD box set at a super-budget price: Nikolai Lugansky. Check out this amazing collection of Lugansky playing Chopin, Beethoven, Rachmaninov and Prokofiev.Scott Morrison

Just a word to those who are interested in this CD (and in Lugansky who, in my opinion, is one of the finest pianists to come to attention in the last twenty years): This CD is part of a bargain-priced 9CD box from Erato that includes lots of Rachmaninov, Chopin, Prokofiev and Beethoven: Nikolai Lugansky. The price for this set is really amazing.Scott Morrison

I am adding my praise to this CD some years after its release because it has just been rereleased in a 9CD set of Lugansky's playing at a ridiculously low price: Nikolai Lugansky. The new set contains music by Beethoven -- searing accounts of the 'Appassionata' and 'Moonlight', and others -- as well as all the Rachmaninov concertos (including the Paganini Variations) plus the Preludes and the Corelli and Chopin Variations. And for lagniappe there are two Prokofiev sonatas (Nos. 4 & 6) and the Romeo and Juliet piano pieces. And then there are the Chopin and Rachmaninov cello sonatas. A brilliant collection of Lugansky's playing for a pittance.Scott Morrison

Nikolai Lugansky is one of the most exciting pianists to come to fore in the last two decades. His performances of pieces as different as Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata and Rachmaninov's Second Sonata are equally stunning. The Beethoven works on this disc are simply amazing in their poetry and fire.But better yet: this disc is now collected with eight other CDs in a box set available here at Amazon at a truly budget price. The other discs contain works by Chopin, Rachmaninov and Prokofiev. Check it out: Nikolai Lugansky. I only recently got this box set and am going from treasure to treasure as I get familiar with its contents.Scott Morrison

This Newton release is the same as the previous release on Sony Classical from 1990 Schumann: Schumann: Carnaval; Papillons; Toccata, which is still available here at Amazon for only a pittance more. I'm not clear why the decision was made to bring out this new release at essentially full price while the other release is still available. But I guess that's not for me to say.The reason I got this one is that Licad is the last pianist I heard in recital with my mother before her death. My mother had been my first piano teacher and she was awed by Licad's artistry. Licad is a Filipina who was a prodigy in her native country and came to the Curtis Institute in the US to study with Rudolf Serkin and Mieczyslaw Horszowski as a young woman. She is an elegant pianist whose touch is velvet but who is capable, as in the Toccata and the Paganini movement in 'Carnaval' of technical brilliance.An easily recommendable disc.Scott Morrison

First, let me say that the clarinetist on this disc, Julien Hervé, is a fantastic musician with quick fingers and a velvety tone that can turn sassy as needed. I've known all these pieces for many years and these performances are right at the top. I'm even one of that dwindling number of people who actually heard Benny Goodman and Joseph Szigeti play Bartók's 'Constrasts', and this performance by Hervé, Lovett and Sugitani does not take a back seat to their classic recording made with Bartók at the piano.The other works here are certainly classics for the clarinetists of their era. Poulenc's sonata was the very last thing he wrote before his death in 1963. He was in poor health and yet the outer movements have all the sauciness Poulenc was famous for. The middle movement, however, is one of Poulenc's cries of the soul, reminiscent of some things from his opera, 'Dialogues of the Carmelites'. The work was premièred a couple of months after Poulenc's death by Goodman with Leonard Bernstein at the piano.Aptly then, the next piece is by Bernstein himself, one of his very early works. He was 23 when he wrote it and it was his first published piece. It was not written for Goodman and I don't know if he ever played it. It wasn't as well known in the 1940s as it is now; every student now plays it at least partly because it is jazzy and 'modern' sounding in the sense of being mildly dissonant.I have to admit that I had a small problem with hearing Gershwin's Three Preludes, largely because for years I played them in their original piano-only form, had not heard them as arranged for clarinet and piano, and could not get the sound of piano-alone out of my ears. On relistening, though, I hear that the arrangement by James Cohn is expert and easy to like. The jazzy portamenti do remind one of that famous gliss at the beginning of Gershwin's 'Rhapsody in Blue.'Stravinsky's 'Three Pieces' for solo clarinet were written in 1918, long before Goodman (b. 1909) was playing. But Stravinsky became a fan of jazz clarinet and wrote his 'Ebony Concerto' for Woody Herman in 1945; Benny Goodman recorded it a few years later under the baton of Stravinsky himself. The brief 'Three Pieces' are given soulful readings here by Hervé.Morton Gould wrote 'Benny's Gig', eight duos for clarinet and double bass (!); seven of them were written for Goodman in 1962 to take on tour to Russia, the eighth was written for Goodman's 70th birthday in 1979. The eight pieces take just under fifteen minutes and are a real workout for both instrumentalists. A good word must be put in for bassist Ying Lai Green.This is definitely a keeper. And it has already gone on my iPod, a thumbs up from me.Scott Morrison

I might as well put my two cents in. This set of Haydn includes some absolutely classic performances and mostly from an era when orchestras were full-sized and vibrato was actually used. (I'm not a huge fan of 'original instruments' or 'historically informed performances'.) And then there are the marvelous voices from one of opera's golden ages (even though they're not singing opera per se).Since I had gotten a $1 credit for buying other CDs and mp3s at Amazon, I got this 180+ band set for a grand total of 9 cents. Can't beat that!Scott Morrison

As I said in a review some years ago, I yield to no one in my love for the Brahms String Quintets. These late flowers from Brahms's pen are simply magnificent works that don't get played in recital as often as they should be because they require a string quartet to add a second violist. Thus touring quartets don't get to play it as often as they might like; most performances, then, are heard by groups from a local orchestra or university. And indeed this recording is made by principals from the Uppsala Chamber Orchestra in Sweden. It is an entirely creditable performance albeit a little scrawny at times, a no-no when playing these lush Brahms works. Still, the group plays with fervor and obvious love for these works and since this is a review of the mp3 version of this recording -- it is also available on CD -- it is at a lower price than a CD would cost.My own favorite recording of the works is that by principals of the Boston Symphony on the Nonesuch label Brahms String Quintets Opus 88 & 111 - Boston Symphony Chamber Players but there are others that are somewhat better than this one from Uppsala: the Hagen Quartet with violist Gerard Caussé Brahms: String Quintets, op. 88 & 111 (Hagen Quartet, Gerard Causse), the Ludwig Quartet with Bruno Pasquier Brahms: String Quintets Nos. 1 & 2 (on Naxos, and thus less pricey), and the Raphael Ensemble Brahms: String Quintets Nos.1 & 2 (also at a budget price). All the cited recordings are on CD, rather than mp3.Scott Morrison

This works out fantastically for me. My last soap dish that I had in my shower was getting super yucky. I decided to switch out my yucky one for this one. What makes this holder superior to me is that it has the convenient holes on the bottom of it. All the water and most of the soap residue just slips down through the holes. I wouldn't recommend putting this on your sink because it will just get all wet underneath with the water having nowhere to go but everywhere around it. It looks great in my shower and I am so glad to have this. I was provided a free sample in return for my honest opinions and observations on this product. All opinions are my own.

This plate is so cute! The finish on the wood is gorgeous and I wanted it as a small candy dish. You could also use it for eating small desserts. This would be excellent to have in a pair or group of four for guests. There is a slight curve to the plate as well so you don't have to worry about syrups or juices running off of it. It's adorable and I am glad to have it for my use. I was provided a free sample in return for my honest opinions and observations on this product. All opinions are my own.

I wanted this to hold my wooden cooking utensils. The fit is absolutely perfect. I really do hope they make this same holder in a darker wood color at some point but I am happy with it for sure. There are holes in the bottom so you can wash and dry it easily. The finish of the wood is smooth and the holder is weighted. You can feel and see the high quality of it in person. It looks great in my kitchen and I am happy with it. I was provided a free sample in return for my honest opinions and observations on this product. All opinions are my own.

I have been reviewing for Amazon for a long time. I received these glasses for testing and review purpose. I have probably tested around 10 pairs of different brands of sunglasses which were all over the quality spectrum. Looking at the price, I honestly didnt expect these glasses to be of substantial quality.These glasses arrived well packaged and included a nice microfiber pouch as well as a microfiber cloth to clean the lenses. The lenses are polarized which are great for wearing in the sun, but I would prefer non polarized as all my devices look psychedelic while wearing these glasses. Other than that, I highly recommend these glasses if you are looking for an affordable pair of glasses. These are comfortable and have a nice rubber coating by the bridge of the nose and on the arms.

We received this scarf about 3 days ago. I immediately gave it to my wife who was ecstatic. She loves the Tahari brand and could not wait to try it out. Everything she has ever owned from this brand has been extremely high quality and long lasting all while maintaining the upmost comfort. Today was a very windy day, so she finally had the opportunity to wear this scarf in some adverse weather. The scarf did an exceptional job at keeping her neck warm. She said she the wind was a non factor, and we had winds in excess of 40 mph due to a November storm here in the Midwest with a current Tornado watch. That really says something right there.The scarf itself is a very comfortable and soft fabric. It is machine made, but it gives the appearance of an expensive hand knit scarf. The material is 100% acrylic which is a good material for avoiding smells and odors. Acrylic scarves are known to keep their shape, color and also resist staining etc. Acrylic is also extremely lightweight and a good option if you have allergic reactions to wool, or are just someone who has sensitive skin.Style wise this scarf is superb. It fits her neck perfectly, protects her neck and just exudes an elegant appearance. If you are in the market for a winter scarf, look no further. This is literally the best scarf at an unbelievable price. Local big box stores sell a lesser quality version of this scarf for double the price.

I have been using this diffuser for about a week. This product is exceptional compared to other diffusers I have used. The color of the LEDS are very nice and I like the fact you can see the water moving a bit in the unit while it is operating. It adds to the depth of the color.To use the product is simple. Merely twist off the top, fill the unit with water up to the max fill line. By some concentrated essential oil, and add 2-4 drops depending on the strength of the aroma you are after. Instructions state 1-2 drops, we tried it with one drop and the aroma was not as strong as we would like.The best feature is the auto off feature. This feature shuts the device off when it senses there is not anymore water left to evaporate. This provides a sense of security that you can leave it on and fall asleep in bed. For that I recommend the Lavender oil, it really helps to relax you.Overall a great diffuser and an exceptional product.Product was received for testing and review purposes.

I received the Sentey Headphones about a week ago and I immediately opening the shipping box.  The headphones themselves come in an extremely elegant packaging, the packaging rivals that of Beats or Sennheiser headphones.  This packaging allows people to purchase these for a gift, because it gives off the appearance of a headphone 4x its price range.Upon removing the headphones from their box, I immediately was drawn to the design of these headphones.  They are extremely sleek and modern looking in appearance.  Also the brushed stainless steel finish is superb, it really makes these headphones look elegant.  The ear cups each reside below a hinge that allows you to fold up the headphones for easy storage in an included hard case.  The hard case is a huge benefit as you can now travel with your headphones with piece of mind that no damage will come about.  These headphones do connect via a 3.5mm jack, and have in inline mic along the cable for chatting.These heaphones have ear pads that encompass your entire ear, or Over the Ear earcups.I have a fairly large head, 7 5/8, and these were not tight at all on my head.  I do wish these came with an alternative velour ear pad as I find the velour material easier to use for prolonged time as my ears stay drier.The sound quality of these headphones are easily an 7.5/10.  I own dozens of headphones.  My everyday headphones are Sennheiser HD 600, I game with Sennheiser G4ME Zero/mixamp combo, I also have the Audio Technica AD700 for gaming with modmic.  I then have 4-5 sub 50 dollar headphones that I would all rate around a 4/10 or less.  These are substantially better than the cheap Sony headphones that I thought were a good budget buy.  I did not experience any distortion and I was quite happy with all three levels of sound, Highs, mids and lows.  These are a closed headphone, so sound leakage is kept to a minimum when you are in a public space. Of course you obviously must keep volume lower to achieve greater success at reducing sound leakage, but it is substantially less than an open back design.Overall probably the best headphones I have heard under 50 dollars.  They feel high quality and sound high quality.  The hinges are well built, and feel better than the Playstation Gold Headset hinges.Product was received for testing and review purposes.

We received this hat about 3 days ago.  I immediately gave it to my wife who was ecstatic.  She loves the Tahari brand and could not wait to try it out.  Everything she has ever owned from this brand has been extremely high quality and long lasting all while maintaining the upmost comfort. Today was a very windy day, so she finally had the opportunity to wear this hat in some adverse weather.  The hat did an exceptional job at keeping her head and ears warm. She said she the wind was a non factor, and we had winds in excess of 40 mph due to a November storm here in the Midwest with a current Tornado watch.  That really says something right there.The hat itself is a very soft and comfortable hat.  It is machine made, but it gives the appearance of an expensive hand knit hat.  The material is 100% acrylic which is a good material for avoiding smells and odors.  Acrylic hats are known to keep their shape, color and also resist staining etc. Acrylic is also extremely lightweight and a good option if you have allergic reactions to wool, or are just someone who has sensitive skin.Style wise this hat is superb.  It fits her head perfectly, protects her ears and just exudes an elegant appearance.  If you are in the market for a winter hat, look no further.  This is literally the best hat at an unbelievable price.  Local big box stores sell a lesser quality version of this hat for double the price.

I received this LED Touch Lamp about 2 weeks ago from iRULU.  The lamp itself is a very futuristic design and it is very sleek.  It has a bright LED light that is emitted and it is plenty bright with the available different lighting options present.The lamp itself is comprised of 3 pieces that are interlocked by hinges.  The top light can be moved up and down to aim the direction of light to where it is needed.  The lamp has 3 different settings on it for light temperature.  It has a 2700k, 3500k and 5000k light output mode.  On top of the options, you can adjust the light brightness by using one of the five available levels of brightness.The lamp itself has no buttons and has a touch sensitive base.  I havent really seen a touch lamp since the 1980's and it was a pleasant surprise.  It really makes using the lamp simplified. There is a LCD screen that has a blue backlight.  On the LCD you have a the time, date and temperature.  There is an alarm but I would not really rely on it as I found the volume to be a bit insufficient for a medium to heavy sleeper.Overall this is a great product and I am happy that iRULU provided me a sample to test and review.

So I recently came to a revelation.  I need new clothes.  My style has been stuck in the 90's with cargo shorts and baggy shirts that dont fit.  We are going on vacation this winter so I decided it was time to get back into style. A little about myself, I am 6'6" and currently weigh 235lbs.  Finding clothes that fit takes hours upon hours going from store to store to find clothing that fits. That is part of the reason why I never wanted to buy new clothes.  The clothes are either really baggy because of needed length or if you buy big and tall, its normally boxy due to being more big than tall.You tall guys know what I am talking about so I will leave it at that.  This shirt fits great thought.  It does have a slight slim fit to it that makes it less boxy, which is the look you want.  By no means is this shirt skin tight.  Like I said I am 6'6" and 235lbs.  I first bought size XXL and it was boxy and wide.  I then ordered a XL to compare in my house before returning one of them.  The XL is exactly the fit I needed. The arms themselves are shorter than I am used to, but the length of the shirt itself is PERFECT for tall people.  I highly recommend trying this shirt if you are having trouble finding shirts that actually fit your tall body.Overall this is a great shirt,  fit is good and feels comfortable.  Hope this makes the shopping process easier for other tall people.
