A key element differentiating this unit from competitors is the substantial side latch.  Very heavy duty and nearly toddler proof (nearly).The smoker did a great job out of the box.  We simply set the initial temp.  Once the unit achieved that temp, it cooks as set, then drops to 120 to keep it warm.  The smoke (on one fill) went for over 5 hours.  The cubic capacity is more than sufficient for a family of 10, even around holidays.  We found the digital gauge mostly accurate.  However, we like to use a second thermometer anyway.If you are a first time smoker, you cannot go wrong with this product.  Just follow the directions.  We keep the smoker on our back porch (unenclosed- open on one side, with roof) and have experienced no issues with the ceiling.  The smoker just does not cook at the high temps that would cause concern.

We have extensive experience with Proactiv products and we swear by them.  This product is good - if you need it.  Using as a regular shave cream in the context of prevention is both cost prohibitive and not as good as regular shave cream in my opinion.  This product applies like a thick cream and was prone to clogging my razor.  The product is best equated to a thick shaving gel combined with benzoyl peroxide.I want to emphasize that if you have a need, this product will fulfill that need at a high cost.  However, my son's friend uses this product without an acne issue, as a means of prevention, and they go through at least a tube a month.  In my case (shaving every day), I would go through two or three tubes a month.

This doll was an instant hit (after fighting to get it out of packaging) with our daughter and her friends.  The doll appears well constructed and designed very good.  While she eats (food included- you can also use play dough), she does not drink.  The doll is interactive (Spanish and English) and responsive.  Making and feeding the food can get messy and there may be times you have to clear the mouth out.  The doll will "poop" but not "wet" her diaper.  This actually works out good because you do not need to replace the diapers.Perhaps the biggest issue with the doll is the food.  When it comes out of the doll into the diaper, kids take off the diaper and the food then usually falls onto the floor and gets ground into the carpeting.  It can be a pain.  So, plan to regulate that aspect to some degree.  Otherwise, we like the doll.  Oh, also, there is an on off switch for when you get sick of hearing the doll.

I am not in a position to micro-analyze this product.  I have used various forms of protein supplementation throughout the years to either power lift, body build, or (now) to lose and maintain weight.  As I am seriously trying to lose weight, protein supplementation is critical.This product has a good 22 gram protein profile at 110 calories with good levels of BCAA's and Glutamine.  The powder mixes very well in a blender or a handshaker.  The taste profile is creamy and works especially well when mixed with peanut butter (in a blender of course).  The non-GMO Vegan profile of the product will appeal to lactose intolerant people and people with food allergies.  For example, this is on of the few protein powders my daughter can handle and she has tried quite a few.  No added sugar is another huge incentive of the product.This product is (currently) on the expensive side.  However, you do get what you pay for in this instance.

I was in for a surprise.  This snack actually tastes very good.  The seaweed taste, while there, is not as pronounced as you would expect.  I found them crunchy and not too heavy.  The gochujang seasoning on these chips is very good (I never had it before).  The chips are sweet, sort of like a cookie in many respects.  I liked them so much, I found myself eating the whole bag.  In fact, I found them addictive.

We typically use all the Crayola products and are generally very pleased with them.  This product is no different provided you understand it is best for younger kids.With this product you get three color wonder markers and three stamp pads, plus a book of blank Color Wonder paper.  Like the other Wonder products, you do not need to worry about staining carpets or walls as the products only work on the Wonder paper.  Like another reviewer noted, children over 6 will lose interest quickly compared to those younger than six.  The product does not need batteries to operate but the younger kids seem to like when it lights up (batteries are not provided).  Overall a very simple toy with limited application in that you stamp the Wonder paper with the stamps and then color in the stamps with a Wonder marker.

Like most of the Proactiv products, this product does exactly what it says it will do, and without burning or otherwise being overly harsh.Our teenage daughter intermittently experiences minor acne breakouts.  Within two treatments, the acne was gone with absolutely no harsh effects.  The cream is thick, which makes application easier and less stressful and provides only a slight tingling sensation on contact.  You leave it on overnight and of course wash off in morning.  The cream does not have that greasy feeling normally associated with stringent of this type. Also, the smell is acceptable!

The microscope came packaged very well, which was a relief compared to some prior experiences I have had.  Packed inside the box is the USB microscope, stand, USB cable, an installation software (CD) a manual, a quick start guide, and calibration chart.  However, if you do not have a CD< you can get the manual and software online.  Assembly was easy and intuitive, taking about one minute.  The software installed on my Dell Windows 7 system with no issues.Simply plug the microscope into the computer and you are off and running.  The software of course interfaces with the computer and does so exceedingly well.  You can even open the interface software to a full window. To view objects, one knob provides general control and the other provides fine tuning.  This is perhaps where a more expensive unit might be better suited for some.  The fine tuning takes effort.  A variable light adjustment is provided on the cable, as well as a trigger/shutter control for the camera. The shutter button works very well and the software provides a means of organizing your images.  It is important to remember that there is no viewing piece on the microscope.  Instead, you view images on your computer.  Magnification, up to 330x, is controlled through the software.The general design of the microscope is good for the intended purpose.  The base is heavy enough and seems secure.  Enough control points are provided, allowing you to hold down slides.  Note-  I was provided a sample for a no obligation review.

Our daughter just entered high school and the TI-84 plus calculator was a requirement.  Of course we purchased the calculator and panic sort of ensued right afterwards.  Our daughter has come to rely on this book to use the calculator.This book covers the TI-84, TI-84 Plus CE and TI-84 Plus C Silver Edition graphing calculators.  There is absolutely no need to read the book from cover to cover.  Instead, we use it as a reference, similar to how you would use a "Dummies guide."  The book is needed because there is a significant learning curve to mastering a TI-84.  Even, as in our case, parents used a similar calculator in the past, those skills are likely long gone.  So, we jumped around the book as needed to learn tasks as they were instructed in school, rather than trying to study and memorize the book.  Especially helpful were the screen shots and the error table provided in the back of the book.It is also worth noting that purchasing the book also gets you the e-book (via download), making it that much more convenient.

I agree with other reviewers that depending on your preference, you are likely to find the tines spaced too far apart.  However, I found the comb "good enough" as something I can easily carry around for a quick comb.  The flip side, they are easy to lose.

This is a roomy and well constructed sleeping bag with some limitations.  This bag is clearly intended for use above 20 degrees and I would opine, probably closer to 30 and 40 degrees or above.  Much of that opinion is of course personal preference as back in the day I could sleep on the ground in 30 degree temperature with nothing but a poncho liner.  In other words, this bag is very well suited for mid spring to early fall usage in temperate climates.  Anything colder than that, and you will need to move to a bag better rated for the cold.  Alternatively, you could simply wear layered clothing to adjust to the local climate.The bag design is roomy but more importantly has a cinch string around the head.  This significantly reduces the rate of heat loss as it takes the true form of a "mummy bag."  Overall construction seems very good and the bag actually fits into the stuff sack.

This unisex apron is 100% cotton and fits very well ( 5'7" ).  Construction is nice and strap around the neck is adjustable, making custom sizing based on your torso length very easy (one size doe snot fit all in this regard).  Waist ties are long enough that assistance will not be required for most people.  The pocket turns out to be very useful.  I did find the fabric a little thin compared to my previous apron's.  However, I also do not get as hot when using it.This apron is well priced and very adequate.  It's a perfect solution either in the home kitchen, or for high school students taking a culinary class, which is how we ended up using it.

I am using this for my goatee as I am bald (by choice) on top.  The product works very well with a great scent.  A little product is all that is needed unless you like the wetter look.  There is no greasy feel to the product at all and it works well out of the jar; rub into palms then distribute evenly through beard or goatee. The product also washes out very easily.

The Barbie horse was a huge and immediate hit out of the box (8 ear old).  Barbie (included) stays on the horse very well.  However, the Barbie doll seems to be specifically designed to be used with the horse and therefore has limited use aside from the horse.  You will need the directions to learn how to use the horse.  The horse can be posed, stand on its own, and do a number of tricks. The mane of the horse cannot be brushed.  However, the tail can be brushed with included brush.  The horse requires four AAA batteries which are increasingly becoming uncommon so be prepared- they are NOT included.  I has to run out to the store and get them.Bottom line- this was a huge hit with our 8 year old and her friends.  First time use resulted in at least 90 minutes of play.  She  has repeatedly gone back to it.

This scoop is replacing another scoop that we had for 10 years.  The old scoop started flaking metal.  This scoop however provides a solid stainless construction, which is an improvement over other types that may only have a coating.  Unlike other scoops we used, this is a much more compact design that I like better.  There is a silicone insert on the backside of the handle.  I do not believe it's needed.The finish is very nice on this product and I like it much better than scoops with a plastic handle.  Note, I was provide a sample for evaluation and review.

I tried previous jump ropes of this type.  However, in all the instances, the rope itself was usually too light.  Not the case with these ropes.The rope is a good length at about nine feet.  The foam core handles are very comfortable and feel durable with thick handles with a non-slip surface that will prevent slipping even when you are really sweaty.  Adjustments are easy by unscrewing the handle.  The rope seemed a little stiff to start but loosened up fairly quickly and seems to become increasingly flexible, unlike many other types I have used in the past.I have used the jump rope for over a month now with no issues at all.

It is difficult to tell from the product images; however, it is a large accessory.  It is also built and designed very well and it should be for the price frankly.  The camper provides quite a few options for play.  It includes kitchen, jacuzzi, water slide ouch, upstairs deck (3 stories), bedroom, (fits 3 dolls), bathroom, campfire, and more.  Initial setup and first use can be a bit confusing.  However, our 8 year old and her friends quickly overcame that.  I highly recommend parents place the stickers, otherwise you can end up with a mess.Our daughter and friends spent quite a bit of time playing with the camper and integrated it into other Barbie play and accessories.  They have gone back to it over the last few days and I predict it will get some serious use.  This camper is a solid accessory for any Barbie lover.  However, the real turn off is the price.  They are seriously expensive for what you get and I am not sure why.  This camper is bigger than previous versions however.Remember, the camper does not come with any Barbie dolls.

This is a fantastic party pack for those teenage get togethers at about $1.45 an item at $45 product price .  The package includes: 8 packs of Original Skittles, 4 packs of Wild Berry Skittles, 3 packs of Tropical Skittles, 3 packs of Sour Skittles, 6 packs of Original Starburst, 3 packs of Tropical Starburst and 3 packs of Starburst FaveReds.  All items come in a large single partitioned box, packed and shipped inside another box.  Interestingly, the product survived the high heat (about 105 degree heat index), in the sun at my door for about 6 hours.

Simply a great doll, sort of throwing back to the old days but with a contemporary look.  The material and stitching on this doll is top notch.  The mop of hair is tough and will withstand abuse from using it as a handle.  The pacifier is permanently attached (sewn) to a string on the doll and has a magnet to attach to the mouth (sealed). Personally, I elected to cut it off at the hand.  One less thing to worry about (string and magnet).  Probably one of the most important points is that the product is 100% washable unlike many other dolls.  This will make cleanup easy.

Like the Fintie ipad mini case, this case is one of our favorites as it is nearly the same style. The construction is solid and tight and the stand options are really unbeatable in such a slim design. There are no signs of any glue on the cover. The functionality/usability of the case is simply impressive and includes a magnet for auto off, which has not failed yet. The case also provides what I believe is optimal protection in a slim and usable form factor. Also, once you use the handhold on the back, even if you think (now) it is something you do not need, you will wonder how you did without it for so long.This is the #1 case (once again, like the Fintie) we recommend to all our friends. This case should work for nearly everyone.

We love the simplicity and convenience of this grinder set, even compared to the single unit variation (salt and pepper in one unit). Each grinder has its own stainless steel lid, which to me is a little inconvenient but necessary as some salt or pepper inevitably spills out when placed on the table. The grind can be adjusted with the black grinder knob at each end. I do have concerns in that there are no provided disclosures regarding the type of material used or country of origin. There is also no declaration that the product is food safe. These are serious issues for our family given legitimate concerns regarding these issues- hence the 2 stars. Note- I was provided a sample for evaluation and review.

We love the simplicity and convenience of this grinder set. The dual grinder is great for saving space.  Each side has its own stainless steel lid, which to me is a little inconvenient but necessary as some salt or pepper inevitably spills out when placed on the table.  The grind can be adjusted with the black grinder knob at each end.  I do have concerns in that there are no provided disclosures regarding the type of material used or country of origin.  There is also no declaration that the product is food safe.  These are serious issues for our family given legitimate concerns regarding these issues- hence the 2 stars.  Note- I was provided a sample for evaluation and review.

This is a rugged MFI certified cable, far more rugged than Apple OEM cables and most other cables we have tried.  This cable provides rugged aluminum connectors on either end that can be used with the 3 cases I alternate on my Iphone 6.  There were no compatibility issues and this cable seems to charge my Iphone 6 as fast as any OEM cable.  Plus, the 6 foot length really pays off especially bedside where you may not have an outlet nearby.  Note-  a sample of this cable was provided to me for evaluation and review.

The last cheap set of sunglasses handed over to the tots didn't last very long.  The arms were yanked off and/or bent within a couple weeks.  The RIVBOS model though seems to be holding up much better.  They even come in a little sack with cleaning cloth.  Something to use for teaching the tots to care for their glasses, and thanks for thinking about it RIVBOS, but my tots aren't interested.

The last cheap set of sunglasses handed over to the tots didn't last very long.  The arms were yanked off and/or bent within a couple weeks.  The RIVBOS model though seems to be holding up much better.  They even come in a little sack with cleaning cloth.  Something to use for teaching the tots to care for their glasses, and thanks for thinking about it RIVBOS, but my tots aren't interested.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for WeiHeng and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*Here in CA, the requirement to pay for bags at the grocery store or bring your own came into effect a couple years ago, and people are still adjusting.  At this point, my very mismatched collection consists of bags from two or three local grocery stores, a few different ones from Target, and on from Trader Joe's.  These Flatworld totes are much more comparable to the more expensive ones from Target/Trader Joe's in terms of quality and assumed reliability.  I've tossed in as many canned goods as could fit into them, and then set them out to hang, so as to see how long they could handle that much weight.  A week later, and they were still hanging there, none the worse.  I washed them a few times and repeated the same test with the same results. The printing on the front doesn't seem to be flaking off, but I'm going to guess that eventually it will start cracking and/or coming off.  Really, I'd be much happier without the designs, but, more females have commented on how cute the bags are that I'd suggest that it's just me that doesn't like the designs.  One more thing to note, the bottoms of these aren't flat like grocery bags, but instead are narrow like book bags.  Again, something I wasn't fond of, but doesn't seem to be a problem for the gals I gave the bags to after I finished trying them out for a month.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for Tayogo and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*I was pretty skeptical about this little cube, but as each of the Tayogo products I'd reviewed previously were pretty good, I held out some hope.  The Magic Cube it turns out, did not disappoint.  While many other brands tack on extra features to justify the price, such as TF card and motion control, Tayogo's design sticks to the basics.  The Magic Cube plays music, and that's about it.  I tested the Bluetooth functionality across 8 different devices, and had zero problems getting them to connect with the Magic Cube consistently.  The controls built into the top worked with all the common apps found on the device (forward/backward track & play/pause).  As with other similar items, the Magic Cube has an independent volume control from your device, something to remember if you're thinking it's not loud enough.  Between using the Bluetooth mode and straight pumping music in through the 3.5mm AUX port, there was a noticeable difference in the max sound level, which is common.  Further testing showed that the max level varied based on the device, meaning when Device A was connected to the Magic Cube, output from the Magic Cube was louder or quieter than when Device B was connected.  When connected the the AUX port, the output level from the Magic Cube was consistent across all devices.  No specs are currently listed, but in my testing, the Magic Cube was able to produce 98db worth of distortion free (measured by ear) sound.  The sound quality itself was good.  Not Bose quality, but superior to many of the other Bluetooth speakers I've reviewed.  A fair about of bass, which got even better depending on where Magic Cube was placed.At the current price of twenty-five, I'd call the Magic Cue a winner.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for Tayogo and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*Alright, lets get down to heart of the matter.  This is a very basic media player with an FM receiver, wrapped in a waterproof shell.  Nothing more, nothing less.  If you follow the instructions, which I must say are about the best I've seen in a while, you should do ok.  It comes with a number of extra earbud tips for differing sized ears, in both standard and water sport types, as well as a USB extension cable should you need one.  As a whole, it does seem like Tayogo put some thought into what they are selling.In practice, the unit performed rather well.  Everything functioned as it should, though getting at the controls was a pain.  That's probably what I disliked the most about these.  Then again, if I were in a constant workout out or swim routine, I'd not be fiddling with it much.  Sadly, no playlist option with these, so if you want your music in a specific order, you'll need to fool about with the naming of your files to get them to queue up in the order you want.  As I said before, it's all very basic.  The FM mode too is just as Spartan.  Whatever it can scan and find, you can listen to.  No presets allowed here. The battery lasted 8 hours on average for me, doing MP3s at max volume.My wear and tear test comes in the form of two tots.  I tossed them the unit and stood back.  These two are professionals, and whoa be to anyone that gets in the way of their work.  In about a week, I snagged the unit back, charged up the battery, and gave a listen.  Though the cables looked to be intact, both speakers cut in and out.  Fiddling with it, I found the break in the line to be close to where the cord entered the body of the headband.  Too much twisting and bending resulted in the wires inside breaking or shorting together.I dunno, for the price I'd like a little more functionality out of these, and more robustness.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for DBPOWER and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*Fitness related wearables are currently at an all time high for desirability.  Heck, Apple's new iWatch is aimed squarely at this market, trying to take down the likes of Fitbit.  This smart bracelet is aimed at the price conservative crowd, with a lower price and claims of all the same features.  How does it do?  Meh.  It's just ok.Let's start with the band itself.  It's really comfy to wear, adjustable to accommodate differing wrist sizes, and holds the electronics pretty darn snug.  The big problem is that it doesn't want to stay put.  Wearing it about for a few days myself, as well as another few by my test victim, the darn thing refused to stay clasped.  Slight brushes against the end of the band would cause it to come apart and hit the floor.  At first, I thought it was a fluke, but on the average, it came apart 3-4 times a day for me, regardless of which wrist I had it on.  Really, it needs a better clasp design.Ok, now the actual electronics.  Waterproof?  No.  At least, it makes no claims to be, so I didn't drop it into a glass of water.  When inside the band, the buttons are still easy to operate.  The display isn't too difficult to read in direct sun, but, it could be better.  The pedometer feature works pretty well.  When matched up a couple others, there were within 5% of each other.  The Bluetooth is tricky, but I'll get to that in a bit.  Oh yeah, and, it does tell time too.So, without the companion app, this band is little more than a watch with a built-in pedometer.  There wasn't a CD in the box, but, there was a QR code for a website where one could get the app.  No thanks, I'm not installing an app from an unknown source.  At least not on my primary phone.  Using a disposable, I loaded the app up and was very underwhelmed.  It was ugly and getting it to sync with the band was next to impossible.  In theory, there was copy in Google Play too, and sure enough, I located it.  (Wristband by GZGAMUT)  This one looked much better, but still had issues with things working correctly, or at all.  Alarm?  Didn't happen.  Notifications?  Didn't happen.  Sustain a Bluetooth connection with my phone?  Nope.  Syncing relied on me toggling the Bluetooth enable in the app off and then on again.  Sleep tracking was difficult to judge, as the band kept falling off in the night.  Further, it assumes that you go to bed at the exact time you set the app to.  Having used Sleep As Android, both with just the phone as well as with a Pebble smartwatch, this DBPower model lags way behind in what it's supposed to do.  It works, yes, but overall the app is finicky and only partially functional.When it comes right down to it, if they fixed the app, and the wristband, this wouldn't be half bad. As is though...nah.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for DBPOWER and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*Unlike the other cameras I have about, from generics, to FOSCAMs, to old smartphones I've converted, this DBPower model uses a different protocol, ONVIF. The hardware itself is pretty good. Image is clear, night and day. The materials feel like quality stuff, and the construction doesn't leave the impression that it the cam is about to fall apart if you sneeze on it. Out of the box, it looks great! When working with it though, that's another story. First off, you have to use Internet Explorer to get at the web interface. Mac users? Linux users? Yeah, you're out of luck. The interface itself has a habit of being slow, for no apparent reason. Though all the software is supposed to be on the mini CD that comes with the camera, it's old stuff. The newer and better functioning stuff can be downloaded via link provided by the web interface itself. Instructions are minimal, so beyond getting a picture, you're going to have to either know how to use it, or, start playing with it. There is an Android app also available on the CD, but, I personally don't install apps from an unknown source like this. If it doesn't come from Google Play or Amazon Appstore, chances are I won't install it. Too much of a security risk, thanks. Perhaps that is why iOS owners are out of luck? I was however able to get generic ONVIF compliant apps from Google Play. The one I settled on was Onvifer, which is free. The camera worked fine with it, with more options available than the camera had to offer. Speaking of, I really wish these could pan and tilt. Perhaps too much to ask from a device this cheap.I mentioned on security risk already, and now it's time for another one. I noticed none of the other reviewers have mentioned it, and it's pretty !%$%@t important. This camera comes with a built-in ability to stream live over the internet, no special options needed. No DDNS, no port forwarding, or any of the other stuff one usually needs to access a device behind your router/firewall. Cool, huh? Just go to the web page, type in your serial #, use a blank password, and there you go! While that may sound really good, think about it for a second. How hard would it be for a nefarious someone to use a script to try out serial numbers and thereby gain access to your camera? Not difficult. Who is running that website? Some outfit in China. Where is their privacy policy? They don' have one, or a way to contact them, posted. Are you really comfortable handing over video streaming direct from your place to these folks? Yeah, I'm not. And until you go in and find the obscure entry for disabling the service, it's active.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for DBPOWER and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*Unlike the other cameras I have about, from generics, to FOSCAMs, to old smartphones I've converted, this DBPower model uses a different protocol, ONVIF.  The hardware itself is pretty good.  Image is clear, night and day.  The materials feel like quality stuff, and the construction doesn't leave the impression that it the cam is about to fall apart if you sneeze on it. Out of the box, it looks great!  When working with it though, that's another story.  First off, you have to use Internet Explorer to get at the web interface.  Mac users?  Linux users?  Yeah, you're out of luck.  The interface itself has a habit of being slow, for no apparent reason.  Though all the software is supposed to be on the mini CD that comes with the camera, it's old stuff.  The newer and better functioning stuff can be downloaded via link provided by the web interface itself.  Instructions are minimal, so beyond getting a picture, you're going to have to either know how to use it, or, start playing with it.  There is an Android app also available on the CD, but, I personally don't install apps from an unknown source like this.  If it doesn't come from Google Play or Amazon Appstore, chances are I won't install it.  Too much of a security risk, thanks.  Perhaps that is why iOS owners are out of luck?  I was however able to get generic ONVIF compliant apps from Google Play.  The one I settled on was Onvifer, which is free.  The camera worked fine with it, with more options available than the camera had to offer.  Speaking of, I really wish these could pan and tilt.  Perhaps too much to ask from a device this cheap.I mentioned on security risk already, and now it's time for another one.  I noticed none of the other reviewers have mentioned it, and it's pretty !%$%@t important.  This camera comes with a built-in ability to stream live over the internet, no special options needed.  No DDNS, no port forwarding, or any of the other stuff one usually needs to access a device behind your router/firewall.  Cool, huh?  Just go to the web page, type in your serial #, use a blank password, and there you go!  While that may sound really good, think about it for a second.  How hard would it be for a nefarious someone to use a script to try out serial numbers and thereby gain access to your camera?  Not difficult.  Who is running that website?  Some outfit in China.  Where is their privacy policy?  They don' have one, or a way to contact them, posted. Are you really comfortable handing over video streaming direct from your place to these folks?  Yeah, I'm not.  And until you go in and find the obscure entry for disabling the service, it's active.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for Gearist and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*This is certainly not my first FM transmitter, nor my first bluetooth version.  This Gearist unit, the GB01, has gone for a small footprint while maintaining functionality.  For the purposes of this review, I am going to compare it against another recently reviewed item, the MPOW Streambot Y.  In terms of looks, it's a toss up for me.  The GB01 is nice and small, plus you can stick it where you like.  The Streamboy however is easier to read and operate, but it has to be located near your power port.  Both power on and off with you vehicle, which is nice.  I found that the GB01 paired up with my phone much quicker than the Streambot, up to 10 seconds different.  An annoyance with the GB01 is that it consistently forgot the volume level it had been set to previously, which is not flaw shared by the Streambot.  The GB01 also includes a dual USB port adapter, from which it can operate on either.  I'd put it in the 1A port, using the 2A port for your phone or other device. The Streambot on the other hand only offers a 1A port, which may make newer devices charge more slowly.  The GB01 also ups the ante for Apple device owners in that it works with Siri, while the Streambot does not.  Myself, I had no problem using Google Now with either device. For some reason, the GB01 changes frequency at half steps, like 83.1, 83.2, and then 83.3 instead of the standard frequencies for US radios (83.1, 83.3, and then 83.5).  A small irritant.  Call quality was ok for the most part, depending on where the unit was placed.  And speaking of placement, in my car, placement is very important.  Why?  Because until I found a sweet spot, the static on nearly every frequency was too much to be listened to.  The transmitter inside the GB01 just isn't able to pump out enough juice to override even the faintest stations.  Here in the SF Bay Area, I don't think it's possible to find an unused frequency, so the weak transmitter is a big problem.  Even after finding the sweet spot for placement, I have to change frequency once along my 45min commute.  I should note that even under the best circumstances, there is static.  The Streambot on the other hand does have similar problems, but not to this extreme.  The Satechi SoundFly View, which is my usual unit, doesn't have this issue at all.When it comes right down to it, the GB01 isn't a horrible unit, but, I'd opt for something else, something with a stronger transmitter.

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for Eachine and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*Alright, yeah, the mushroom is cute.  The package includes instructions, which are a cut above the common half understandable stuff one gets with cheap products.  The touch interface for turning the lamp on and off is nice and works well.  The light emitted isn't overly intense, suitable for a night light, but not something one would be reading by.  The dimming level is adjustable, depending on how long you hold your hand/finger to the top.  This function was hit and miss for me, working only some of the time.  Pairing up via Bluetooth is easy, step by step as usual.  Though not mentioned here, it operated off a rechargeable battery, which I measured to run at least 4 hours with light and sound at max.  Speaking of the sound, the output gets up to almost 90dB (measured at 5 feet).  The quality of that sound isn't great, with more than a touch of tin to it.  If your input source is too high, distortion comes through at even low volume levels.  Note, the mushroom has it's own volume control, operated by long pressing the << and >> buttons.  Operation with the TF card is very basic, just play/pause and jump forward/back.  Taking away from the aesthetics, a little red light glows from an off center position on the base near the buttons.  Overall, it's not bad, but, buying this will be exchanging looks for function.

For any user of GoPro cameras a desire to use it in different ways and in different environments is a constant. When a purchase of the GoPro is made, often one is not aware of the many accessories, different types of clamps, other bits and pieces that you will need and want in the future. I have been using GoPros since their first model and have every one of their subsequent models except for the 3+ so the need for various accessories and straps is mandatory for me.This small kit will provide the straps you need that will enable you to take hands free video.  It doesn't provide many of the other accessories you may eventually need but these straps are as good as gold for most activities and are well made.Chest Belt Strap Mount and head mount straps-I have used the strap as a drummer getting a unique type of footage to be mixed in with standard footage. This strap is a must accessory and can be used by boaters, skiers, horseback riders, skydivers...you name it.Head Strap...Good for many activities including filming while scuba diving.  However, you will be aiming blindly as to your video composition. The quality of each piece definitely meets the same standards as what GoPro provides with their own accessories.I do hope that this brief review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase.Thanks for reading.

With this, his eighth album, Bob Malone offers a rollicking CD release touching on many of blues bases batting a solid average of tunes mixing hard core blues with rock tinged numbers, spirited songs with contemplative ones.  With his classical training and jazz background, Bob Malone makes Ray Charles’ ‘Hard Times’ his own, his voice stretching his resolve not to bend to the rough periods that life brings with it.  ‘Looking for the Blues’ has that Louisiana feel to it that makes you just want to dance.  Backed by a strong band of players and backup vocalists, this song and ‘Rage and Cigarettes’ are strong blues numbers anyone would want to cover for themselves.  There is no questioning his prowess on the keyboards but he keeps his integration within the song to balanced input until a keyboard lead is called for, and even then, you can feel him restraining from going over the top.  Who knows what might be your favorite tune, but mine is his ‘Toxic Love’, a song of addiction to someone he knows can only bring him down.  Written by Bob Malone & Bob DeMarco, the lead guitarist on most of the songs on this album, the tune is enhanced by the soulful harmonica playing of Stan Behrens.If you are unfamiliar with Bob Malone’s previous CD releases, despite his having performed in the past with the Neville Brothers, Bruce Springsteen, Rev. Al Green, and Dr. John, than the release of ‘Mojo Deluxe’ will be a surprisingly enjoyable treat for your ears.

It seems as if everyone has one or more devices that constantly need recharging. Whether they are laptops, cell phones, different pads of one kind or another, music players and bluetooth devices....they all need recharging eventually.Unfortunately, we are not always in a position or place where recharging is convenient.  We might be in the car, in the field on a trip or any other number of circumstances.It is fortunate that has been a proliferation of external chargers that serve as recharging devices and can charge your personal device no matter where you are.  So for this situation the Idaye power bank fits all your needs.  The Idaye power bank has two "smart" USB ports”, which deliver 1 A and 2.1 A at 5 Volts alternatively and interchangeably.  Basically, this means that whether it is a laptop that needs recharging as mine always does or just a cell phone or iPad, iPod or kindle, the Idaye power bank comes in very handy.It weighs in at slightly over 3 oz. and is small enough to fit in a pocket, the glove compartment of your car or a woman's purse.  From a complete discharge of my laptop, it took slightly over 2 hours to bring the laptop's battery up to full charged.  A smaller device will charge considerably quicker.If the Power bank itself is fully discharged, it will take several hours to recharge it to full off your computer's USB port or a USB hub.  This is true for all power banks I have used and reviewed.  The good thing is that these power banks do a great job of holding their charge over time.  You can go for weeks with this power bank and discover that its charge has been retained.  I have had this power bank for a month now and it is still almost fully charged.So why holding onto it for so long before I write a review. Even tho I received it in exchange for a review, I take these seriously and do not like fake or hyperbolic reviews. Thus, true  testing and reviews are important to me.While there are many good power banks on the market and  in this price range, I wouldn't hesitate to recommend this to some or to give it as a gift which is what I plan to do this weekend.I do hope that this review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase. Thanks for reading.

I have reviewed several earbuds in the past and some clearly do stand out while others are just so-so. These earbuds are the exact same earbuds I reviewed awhile ago called the Matone QY7s. They are strictly a rebranding of the headset.  You can tell this by looking at your Bluetooth connection settings where they also come up at QY7s.  This does not mean they are a poor product, in fact, these are really quite good.Set Up....as most Blu Tooth earbuds and headsets I have found, these paired and connected very quickly and easily. Initially, a blue and red light on the right earbud flashes and, once connected and paired, switches to solid blue before going out completely. These earbuds do come with a few different sized ear pieces should the ones already attached be too small or large for your ear canal.With your device's volume set to its highest, these earbuds will go even louder with the volume up/down button. Therefore, be careful, if giving these to a kid, that you and they are aware of possible ear damage caused by setting volumes too loud.Each earbud is marked for the right and left ear but the marking is uber small and you have to look for it. The right ear bud is the one with the power on button. I do like that the entire side of the earpiece is the on/off button so I do not have to search around with the earbuds in to find and separate it from any other tiny buttons. When turned on a voice comes on saying 'Power On'. When the earbuds are going to be fully discharged, there will be an audible beep and a voice warning as well. When charging, the red light will come on on the right earbud showing that they are charging. Of course, a charging cable, the aforementioned extra size ear pieces and a decently, if not tiny, manual is supplied.Ergonomically, these are great buds. They fit comfortably in my ears and, like most buds, are connected by a strong enough plastic connecting string. If one drops out of your ear, you won't lose both.For me, the audio quality is the most important thing and while these are not $1,000.00 audiophile ear pieces, they do a fine job of reproducing your music. I am wearing them now as I write, listening to James Brown's ' I Feel Good' and there is excellent transient response and bass reproduction with just a hint of bass muddiness. Most people will not ever notice this as they will be listening while working or exercising and not sitting there for critical listening. Now listening to ZZ Top's 'Just Got Paid' and the sibilance of the high hat hits and cymbals is spot on and well balanced.Since I am the last human on Earth who does not use a cell phone, I was not able to test this area of the earbuds but they are enabled to be used as both a receiver and transmitter connected via blue tooth to your phone.As I am sent many products for review, I usually donate them after testing to different charities. However, these really are darn good so I will probably keep them for myself.I do hope that this brief review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase.Thank you for reading.

It seems that I have been reviewing a great many blue tooth speakers and earbuds lately and I basically knew what to expect these earbuds came in. Let me make it clear that these were sent to me by the company in exchange for a review but, if you are familiar with any of my reviews, I do not hesitate to point out any negatives I find as well as praise the positive. I have lived with this speaker for over a week and don't buy into the hyperbole of using a product for an hour and thinking it is absolutely great just because it was free.Not everyone has a blue tooth connection so these buds are connected to your device via the supplied cable. The connector is quite small so even if you have a tight fitting cell phone or iPod case, you should have no problems with the connection. Extras ear pieces are supplied should you have larger or smaller ear canals but I found that the ones on them were already pretty comfortable.Audio quality is the most important thing and the Mengo Bumps stand out in a few categories and fall short in one as well. The transparency of the music reproduction is quite excellent. There is no veil over the audio you are hearing, no muffling and excellent transient response throughout the entire frequency range. Though VOIX says that these ear bumps have Ultra Bass, I did not find that to be the case. The bass, while very decent in its response when I was listening to an audiophile jazz recording of Charlie Byrd as well as some ZZ Top tunes, does not go any lower in bass reproduction than the great majority of ear buds, bluetooth or cable connected, than any others I have listened to and reviewed.This does not mean that these aren't quite good, they are good but do not expect audiophile type earpieces for this very inexpensive cost. For yourself or as gifts, they are some of the better looking buds I have seen, if not the best. They certainly do not appear cheap and plastic-like as most of the others on the market. They look far more expensive than they are.Personally, I do prefer the convenience of blue tooth ear pieces so I do not have cables hanging down to be caught on an exercise machine or something, but if this is your choice than you shouldn't be unhappy with them at all. They sound fine, just do not expect an explosive bass and deep bottom end.I do hope that this review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase.Thank you for reading.

I did receive this small bottle of Respire Oil in exchange for a review which in no way obligates me to write something positive or negative. I hate reading nothing but hyperbole,Keeping things simple, there is a very subtle and extremely pleasant spicy aroma that just a few drops of this oil in one of our diffusers emanates. I do not have the scent palate that some do but it smelled to me of peppermint, and eucalyptus with a whiff of lemon. There are ingredients listed on the label but they were printed way too small for me to read.If you are feeling stuffy, this is the oil to use either in your diffuser or just to put a drop beneath your nostrils.  It does clear the sinuses quite well and, in that, it meets its objectives.My wife put in only about 3 or 4 drops of this oil in a diffuser and the fragrance that filled the bedroom was very pleasing. She loves this stuff. The oil is very concentrated and by cutting down on the number of drops, the bottle of oil will last longer. No real need to add more than 4 drops and it should last a goodly amount of time.I really have nothing negative at all to say other than that the oils produced by Prime Cosmetics are really high quality.I do hope that this very brief review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase. I think you will be quite happy with this oil.Thank you for reading.

I did receive this Titanium Men's bracelet in exchange for a review but that doesn't obligate me to write one way or the other.  The bracelet arrived very quickly after ordering from Amazon and comes in a handsome box, nicely packaged and protected.There is no false advertising with this bracelet that appears to look like a bike chain.  They say it is heavy, and it is.  I never considered my wrists to be excessively large but the large size bracelet is what they sent me and actually fits as it should with a little play up and down the wrist area.  It is not choking or catching on the skin at all and really does look quite nice.There are no instructions whatsoever about how to attach the clasp and after 20 minutes of my trying, I brought it to my wife who figured it out in about 5 minutes.  That is why I cut it down to 4 stars.  The clasp holds on solidly so losing it shouldn't be an issue. To  be honest, it might take some time to get used to the weight of it on my wrist.Never the less, it does look cool, though with the weight of the thing, I doubt I will keep it on when playing drums at a gig.  Drumming is tiring enough without your arms holding up a weight.I do hope this brief review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase.Thanks for reading.

I did receive this small bottle of Thief  Essential Oil in exchange for a review which in no way obligates me to write something positive or negative. I hate reading nothing but hyperbole,Keeping things simple, there is a very subtle and extremely pleasant spicy aroma that just a few drops of this oil in one of our diffusers emanates.  I do not have the scent palate that some do but it smelled to me of clove, and eucalyptus with a whiff of lemon.My wife put in only about 3 or 4 drops of this oil in a diffuser and the fragrance that filled the bedroom was very pleasing. She loves this stuff.  The oil is very concentrated and by cutting down on the number of drops, the bottle of oil will last longer. No real need to add more than 4 drops and it should last a goodly amount of time.I really have nothing negative at all to say other than that the oils produced by Prime Cosmetics are really high quality.I do hope that this very brief review has been of some help to you in deciding upon your purchase. I think you will be quite happy with this oil.Thank you for reading.

I have had and used this bag for a while now and I can safely say that it is really well made and durable.  There is plenty of room in the inside lined pockets that have both a zipped pocket and two smaller pockets as well as a larger area.  The outside pocket is ok except that it lays flat against the main bag; there is no additional width extension on the outside pocket so, if the main enclosure were completely filled, the outside pocket would be essentially useless. There is also a small zippered pocket on the backside of the canvas bag and it also has no width extension.  While the canvas material of the main bag will stand up to a great deal of wear, the lining material feels a bit on the cheap side and I do not know just how long both the material and  the stitching will last.The wide strap is unpadded so that after long hikes it may feel as if it is digging into your shoulders.Bottom line, this is a handsome bag and should fit the need for most people who do not overload it.  If all you are putting in it is a cell phone, some makeup, purse, money and change than my bet is that many will compliment you on its appearance.  However, if you are going to overload the bag, the zippered pockets on both sides of the bag will not serve much of a purpose.I hope this brief review has been of some help to you.Thanks for reading.

I have reviewed a great many bluetooth headsets, ear buds and speakers and, while I received this one in exchange for a review, I am not inclined to judge a product either positively or negatively based on getting something for free. Most items I donate to a charity and do not keep.My first impression of this DB Power speaker was very positive.  It looks impressive and, even more importantly, feels solid and well made.  All necessary cables are supplied as well as the users manual with its typical horrendous English and confusing verbiage for those who are not familiar with Blu Tooth products.Unlike an on/off power button,  this speaker has a switch on the side of it laying underneath a protective rubber cover which also protects in the USB charging port.Pairing and Connecting to my device went super quick with an Asian voice saying so.  The woman's accent and pronunciation is so strong it makes me laugh each time.The speaker had a small charge on it when received and I did need to recharge it from a full discharge. This took only a couple of hours and  there is a small red LED indicating charging and a blue LED when the speaker is in use.The round tube of a speaker has a flat side side that it can rest securely and not roll around.The most important thing to me is the audio reproduction quality and when I first listened to it, I thought it was the best I had heard from these inexpensive speakers in some time.  After repeated listening on multiple days, I can say it is still up there with the best, but is not heads and tails above the best.  I listened to several genres of music, which is what I always do for testing.  For classical music, I used Ravel's Bolero.  In most cases, the beginning of the Bolero can not be readily heard with Blu Tooth speakers as the volume is too low to reproduce.  This speaker made me aware of the Bolero from the beginning...a strong point.  Then on to a regular test number by jazz player, Charlie Byrd's 'Old Hymm' which features an amazing drum solo as well as other instruments demanding only the best reproduction.  This is where this speaker's  strengths and weaknesses showed up.The DBPower BX-400 had excellent transient response...it shifted gears very quickly in terms of staccato notes and there was a clear transparency to the music.  Toms and cymbals during the drum solo were reproduced beautifully......however, deep bass. as from a kick drum, was severely  lacking.  Bass in its higher registers, during a bass solo, came across nicely, but the speaker simply can't get down that deep.  Blues Rock from ZZ Top was nicely played but the frequency response for their numbers is not quite as wide or demanding as classical music can be.  On the negative side...while the volume it can reach is pretty decent, I have tested several other blue tooth speakers that could get to considerably louder volumes.The speaker has the power to raise the volume even above your devices volume max, however, bring it up too much and you might get a shriller sound with some distortion.I still maintain that, for the price, this speaker is well worth the money and one of the best of its type out there and here on Amazon.I do hope that this review has been of some help to you.Thanks for reading.

This, faithful readers, is not an easy book to read.It is frustrating, demanding, heartbreaking, provoking, and anxiety-filling. It is also compelling, and it inveigles itself into your head before you realize what’s happening.You will not be able to stop reading it, even though you dearly want to at times, because you will want – you will NEED – to know how it ends.Julia and Julian are separated by one letter, yet also years of missteps and mistakes. They meet by chance, and their attraction is immediate and intense. Not only is Julia married, she’s also eight years older than Julian. Neither gives him much pause, although his friends and family are more nonplussed by the relationship.At first, all is well for the couple. They have a baby girl, Mira, and their lives in London bring them happiness. He’s a writer, she’s an artist, and they are content.Which means something is about to go horribly wrong. Or, in this case, several somethings.First is the availability of Firdaws, Julian’s boyhood home. It’s now for sale and he purchases it, somewhat to Julia’s consternation and regret. She’s a city girl, and a country lifestyle does not hold interest for her. She loves Julian, though, and she allows herself to hope that Firdaws will further tighten their bond.When Mira falls ill, though, Firdaws does not provide the balm Julian desperately seeks. Nothing does.And then some secrets are revealed, and things begin to fall apart.Polly Samson’s writing sinks into you before you know what’s happening, rendering you unable to put down her book. But goodness does she make it hard on you to keep reading. Samson crafts her story with such intimacy that you sometimes feel uncomfortable reading it. You want a break from its intensity and sadness. Just when you think that Julia and Julian will be okay, whether together or apart, Samson introduces another fissure, making you wonder if any of the cracks can be filled.This is a case of a reader needing to trust the writer to tell her tale the way it must be told. You will not always like Julia or Julian or their friends and families. You will not always be on their sides. You will not always enjoy spending time with them. But you will always want the best for them, even as they make you feel conflicted. Samson knows exactly what she’s doing, and you absolutely must have faith that she knows Julia and Julian and what they need.Samson slowly reveals The Kindness in question, making it evident that one person’s kindness is another’s cruelty. That opposition is greatly at play here, not only for Julia and Julian, but for their family and friends as well. When you perform a kindness for someone, Samson avers, you impart a cruelty for someone else.I didn’t always like reading this book, but I could not stop thinking about it. The ending …. we must discuss this, faithful readers. Please read this book and come back to tell me what you think about what Polly Samson means by its ending.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

In the conclusion to The Fowler Sisters trilogy, Monica Murphy lets you get to know Lily, the oldest and wildest of the girls. You've seen her in passing in previous books, but this is your chance to discover the woman beneath the reputation.The book opens with Lily on a plane to Hawaii, to which she is both escaping and hiding. It seems that she has provoked the wrong person, and she thinks she might be in danger. Lurking several rows behind her is Max, hired by the person Lily angered to steal her laptop.If you read Owning Violet and Stealing Rose, it will take you all of a minute to figure out who is upset with Lily. Fortunately, the identity of this character is secondary to the story of Lily and Max. If their relationship begins in a manner that seems awfully similar to Rose and Caden's, rest assured that the similarities do not end there. Caden and Max could be twin brothers of different mothers: each is using (somewhat) a Fowler sisters, each feels guilty about it, and each enjoys a little spanky panky when rocking the headboard.Oh, and one more thing they have in common: both of these men are exemplary headboard rockers. Strap on your vibrators, girls. You will give them quite the workout.So, yeah. A lot of this book will have a "been there, read that" feeling to it.Rose and Lily, though, are quite different. Rose was timid and good, determined to always comport herself in a manner that brought pride to the girls' father. Lily, on the other hand, is a hot mess. She drinks too much, she parties too much, she engages in the sexy times with too many men. She is, in a word, wild.Hence the need to be "tamed," although Lily would never see it that way. Tame her? No. Give her the freedom to tame herself? Yes.The subplot involving Lily's enemy controls too much of the book to be relegated to such a simple dismissal. It is dispatched with far too quickly and easily, which hurts the story. You are fully on Lily's (and Max's) side by this point, and you expect the conflict Lily faces to not be given such short shrift.Then again, this is an erotic romance novel. It is what it is. Lily is fun, Max is hot, and the headboard rocking is delicious.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

3.5 starsThank GOODNESS Jessie K, who is a high school teacher, understands that Romeo and Juliet are not the great romance for the ages. Yes, Matthew refers to Lynn as his "Juliet," but he means it in the spirit of Shakespeare's play: she's the (young) woman with whom he is obsessed, and he senses that his obsession will wind up as happily-ever-after as Juliet and her husband.As an aside: Taylor Swift set us back decades, if not centuries, with her little Romeo and Juliet ditty, which, while toe tappingly delightful, nonetheless imparts an incorrect understanding of the happy couple.Back to this book.It's the first of a three-parter, and it introduces us to Matthew (our narrator), a good looking man on the cusp of turning thirty. He's an itinerant actor who teaches and substitutes to supplement his income. During an audition, he meets Lynn, a young woman with whom he is immediately smitten. They enjoy some passionate exchanges involving their naughty bits, and poof! Off they split into two different directions.About those passionate exchanges: gird thyself with thy vibrators, girls, because Jessie K all but demands that you use to to relieve tension caused by how hot her sex scenes are. Scorching hot. Blisteringly hot.Matthew seems like a nice guy, given what little we know about him, and Lynn remains a mystery. This is largely due to the scant size of this book.Which brings me to why I give it 3.5 stars instead of 4 or more: I am beyond aggravated by this tendency to split up books into smaller sections that end with cliffhangers. I feel as if a money grab is occurring, and I am not amused. I understand piquing your readers' interests and I understand wanting to sell books, but sixty-four pages? That veers mighty close to being insulting, and I am not amused. If you write well enough, people will buy your books. If you entertain your readers with one reasonably sized tome, people will buy the next book you write. Trust us and don't split up an otherwise fun, hot read into piecemeal.My rant is over.Until the necessity for it arises again.Will I read the next one? Yes. I want to know what happens between Matthew and Lynn. I like him, so far, and I want to get to know her better. Will I be happy about it? Yeah, probably. I like the way Jessie K writes, from what little I saw ...Review copy provided by the author in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

There are those who fall under the spell of celebrity, and then there is Emma, who goes (nearly) cold at the thought. She makes it a point to be blithely unaware of people who are in People, and she finds her friends' obsessions with the hot and famous annoying, if not a bit tedious. Perhaps, then, no one is more surprised than Emma herself when she finds herself inextricably drawn to John Davies, the gorgeous, wildly famous, and utterly mesmerizing movie star.They meet when Emma is out with her pals, celebrating her thirty-second birthday. She and John strike up a conversation, and when they run into each other later, it seems like kismet, non? They decide to continue their evening by getting to know each other through their naughty bits, although it is also clear that these two connect on a deeper level than just sexually. Their night in Room 702 is, as Mary Poppins would say, practically perfect in every way.Except it has to end, with John heading to a film set in Iceland and Emma back to her job.The two keep in sporadic touch, and events conspire to bring them together and pull them apart. Paloma Aínsa does a fantastic job of keeping you wondering whether Emma and John will find a way to stay together or if you even want them to do so. John's career sends him hither and yon, frequently in the company of attractive women, and Emma's life in Valencia, Spain, is simple (although increasingly complicated by her relationship, such as it is, with John Davies). There are times when I thought she'd be happier with a different man, and I think Emma herself wonders this, as well. Perhaps she needs to learn that some sacrifices aren't worth it.Aínsa writes engaging characters, giving them depth and breadth. It would have been easy for Emma to wait for John, pining for him until he rode in and whisked her off to Hollywood. But Aínsa takes a different approach, making Emma a character with real substance. This isn't to say that I always liked Emma; she occasionally acts selfishly and even childishly but, if anything, this makes her more real. I'm all for a fairytale, but it helps when it feels as if the dream could come true.Don't expect any detailed sexy times. Sex really isn't the point here anyway because the focus is more on Emma and the woman she wants to be. Will she take risks? Will she settle? Will she realize that her time in Room 702 was wonderful and lovely and entirely blissful but decidedly not reality - and will she not let that deplete her?I enjoyed this book because of the way Paloma Aínsa writes it. Give it a try, and then come back in the comments and let me know what you thought.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

This is one of those books that I tried so hard to like. I got about 25% through it, had an iPad mishap, thought I lost it, frantically tried to contact NetGalley and even Lexi Maxxwell about getting a replacement copy, and then was able to reload it, thanks to a somewhat precipitous backup I had happened to do. I thought - I hoped - that it would get better.Aaaannnnndddd ... not so much.It isn't that this is a bad book as much as it just feels rather lifeless and uninspiring. It feels overly familiar, in a "where have I read you before" kind of way.Let's look at the synopsis: Ella works with (but really for) her mother in a job she hates, is in a relationship with a guy she doesn't like all that much, gets dumped by text, has a glass of wine too many to salve her wounded heart, and winds up confiding in a gorgeous stranger with whom she feels an instant connection. Only - whoopsie! - he's the son of the man her mother is about to marry, and the gorgeous stranger is engaged to be married himself.So, yeah, that sounds like something you've already read, doesn't it? I'd be okay with that if Maxxwell had interesting characters or something to add through her writing. Neither is there, though, and that's a disappointment.Ella herself is annoying and immature, to the point where I prayed she would get dumped by everyone and have to start over. I think I'm supposed to feel for her because she isn't doing what she wants to do with her life and she isn't in a relationship. But she's so whiny and unappealing that I felt as if she had what she deserved. Another weakness is her sister Carly, who contradicts herself at every turn. I could not figure out why Carly was so awful to Ella (aside from Ella being such a pill), but it turns out that there is an answer for that, and, in fact, that answer is the best part of the book. Nathan, our hero, is likable and interesting, and I wish this had been told from his perspective because he is by far most interesting character.Maxxwell uses a lot of humor in her writing, which helps make Ella a bit more endearing than she actually is. I liked what Maxxwell tried to do more in theory than in practice. The idea - a girl falls for a guy she can't have - is cute and ripe for romantic writing. I just couldn't get past Ella and Carly. They seemed too rote for me.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

4.5 starsI like these. I like them a LOT.The MUSE Kegel Balls Exercise Kit is the fourth - yes, fourth - Kegel balls set I've tried. I've gone with the stainless steel variety, and others made by "adult toy" companies. This kit is by far the best I've used.For one thing, the shape of the balls is unique. Thanks to the pointy end, they are easy to insert. The silicone covering is soft and feels very comfortable sliding in, and the string is the perfect length. I followed with the directions, starting with the solo one, and then worked my way up to the twosome. A small mini vibe is included, but the battery was dead in mine, so I can't speak to its effectiveness. That's the only reason I am not giving these five stars.A carrying pouch comes with the balls, making storage work well.Now, about how they feel. You are aware that you have something inserted Up There, although I felt the single ball wasn't as effective. The two balls worked better for me, giving just the right amount of pressure to remind me to do Kegel exercises. I can't speak to whether bladder issues are cured because I don't have bladder problems, but I can say that if you're using these to increase arousal, they work very nicely.I liked this product. I wish the battery in the vibe had been charged, but other than that, this is a solid, fantastic product.I received this product for a discounted fee in exchange for an unbiased review.

Matt and Grace meet when he decamps from Los Angeles to New York his senior year of college, having forced his attorney father to realize that he will not follow in the family business but rather will pursue photography. Matt moves into a dorm and the first person he encounters is Grace. Theirs is an instant attraction, but one they keep at bay while they form a friendship. Eventually, though, their friendship becomes more.All college romances face one common issue: what will the couple do after graduation? Grace is a cellist and has an offer to tour Europe with an orchestra, while Matt has the opportunity to spend the summer in South America with National Geographic. Their careers aren't just taking them to different locations; they are headed to opposite ends of the earth. Grace isn't sure, though, that she will go on tour. For one thing, she feels responsible for helping her family surpass their almost Dickensian existence. And for another, Grace is astute enough - or pessimistic enough - to realize that she and Matt may not last through the separation.And now, fifteen years later, Matt and Grace see each other in a flash. She's boarding a subway in New York while he stands on the platform. They acknowledge each other. And Matt leaves a note in the Missed Connections section of Craigslist. Will Grace see it?I think you know the answer to that.Fortunately, Renee Carlino makes the answer almost superfluous. Sure, Matt and Grace will reconnect, but what happened to cause them to disconnect? And what will happen when they find each other again?This, faithful readers, is a story that you will love reading. Matt and Grace are interesting, intriguing, and engaging, even through the mistakes they make. Matt is occasionally a bit too clueless, while Grace sometimes can be defensively difficult and intractable. They are opposites in so many ways, yet they share fundamental similarities. They are artists, drawn to beauty, fantasy, grit, and turmoil. They understand a certain peripatetic nature to their art, even as they crave stability and a sense of home.When Carlino brings her couple back together, she does so with care and passion, even as she plays a card that causes even more drama and angst for Matt and Grace. Not a surprising card - careful readers will know what's coming - but one that will necessitate communication and empathy. After fifteen years apart, can Matt and Grace give that to each other?Carlino peppers the story with some hot headboard rocking, scenes that have just the right amount of detail and spice. It's important that we see Matt and Grace connect sexually as well as emotionally and intellectually, and connect sexually they do. Oh, yes, they do. One of the things I was curious about was how they would react to that spark when they find each other after all that time apart. Even though their relationship began (somewhat) platonically, an intense attraction existed. What will come of it now that they are in their thirties?If you like love stories featuring characters who know they belong together but have to make choices that keep them apart, this is for you. If you like reading love stories with hot sexy times and characters you wish you knew in real life, this is for you. It's for anyone who enjoys good writing.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

This is one of those books that made my life miserable. I hated having to put it down, and the bad moods caused by needing to work or feed my family rather than read caused endless fun for friends, loved ones, and my students. (I will admit, since we're all friends and you won't tell on me, that I gave assignments that would keep my students busy so that I could read while they worked. Yes. I did.)Catherine and Zoe are sisters, but aside from blonde hair and a shared bloodline, that's about all they have in common. The older sister, Catherine is responsible, independent, level-headed, and stable. She's a nurse practitioner, married to her college sweetheart, and lives in a cozy home in a Boston suburb. She's happy and content, despite being unable to conceive a child. Zoe, on the other hand, is the wild child, the one who always bucked constrictions. The drinking and partying of her youth led to an unplanned pregnancy, and, in the midst of a harrowing addiction, she abandoned her daughter Willow in a bus station, calling Catherine to come get the child. Now, five years later, Catherine and husband Russell are Willow's legal guardians and consider themselves her parents.Catherine always felt loved and cherished by her father, and insecurely lacking by her mother Eve, who seemed (and continues to seem) to prefer Zoe's recklessness, labeling it "brave." Eve's husband - the girls' father - died, and now she's facing the task of selling their vacation home in Chance Harbor, Nova Scotia.Told through Catherine, WIllow, and Eve's perspectives, this is the story of a family in a state of flux. Catherine's seemingly loving marriage turns out to be anything but; she receives heartbreaking news from Russell that sends her spiraling. Willow adores her aunt, struggles with adoring her uncle, loves her grandmother, but, more than anything, misses her mother. She's a teenage girl who appreciates what she has but yet feels a yawning gape where her mother belongs. As the matriarch, Eve knows that she is the caretaker of her husband's memory, but she's hiding her own secrets that will rock her daughters. She also has to come to terms with certain realities of her marriage, and part of that means forgiving herself.Of all of the characters, including the reprehensible Russell, I found Eve to be the most dislikable. In fact, I did not enjoy the parts told by her, and I sort of wished that she would be miserable and unhappy. I don't think she was a good mother, certainly not to Catherine. When the truths about her marriage come out, it is clear why she prefers Zoe to Catherine, something she never bothered to try and minimize around her eldest daughter. Sure, she tells herself that Catherine doesn't need her like Zoe does, but her failure to recognize the power she has to hurt Catherine is deplorable. Catherine has a memory of her and Zoe playing in the ocean and getting ensnared by an undertow. Eve comes to help them and it is Zoe who she tugs to the shore; Catherine is left to an uncle. That act gutted me. It isn't that Catherine is perfect - she's prickly, insecure, and an occasional harridan, but I sympathized with her. To be expected to be the "good" child is a burden. So to be jettisoned aside like something disposable when the "bad" child returns can crush you.Willow, on the other hand, is utterly adorable. Her conflicted feelings toward her mother are understandable, as are her feelings about Catherine and Russell. Her adoration of Eve ... well, I forgive her for that because she can't see how awful Eve truly is when it comes to Catherine.This is an utterly engrossing book that slowly infiltrates you till you can't let it go. There are occasional pacing problems, and there are a few moments that seem a wee tad overwrought, but those are negligible. Holly Robinson makes you care about her characters, and she doesn't take quick, easy shortcuts.Read this and then come back and let me know what you thought, particularly about Eve. Maybe I'm wrong about her. But I don't think I am.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Jennifer Weiner, how much do I love the way thee writes?A considerable amount, as it turns out.My love is so tremendous that I will forgive you for The Feels that Who Do You Love provoked, for the wads of tissues that littered the floor around me as I read, for the puffy red face I got as I ugly cried, and for the times I had to wipe off my iPad when I had a spit-take from laughing.I will forgive you because I loved - and I mean LOVED - this book.When Andy and Rachel are sixteen, she tells him that she knows what it feels like to be the only one, She knows because she's always been the only one. Born with a heart defect, she spent the first eight years of her life in and out of hospitals, sporadically attending school, and feeling lonely and isolated. The one person who understood her died, leaving her "the only one." She tells Andy she understands this because he, too, feels like the only one. The son of a black father and white mother, Andy grows up poor but not impoverished, wearing hand-me-downs and solving problems with his fists. In Rachel, he feels he has found someone who does, in fact, understand what being the only one means.The two met when they were eight and Rachel happened upon him in a hospital lobby. In that moment, they connected in a way that true soulmates do. But of course the path of true love never runs smoothly, and over the next few decades, these two come together, break apart, come together, break apart, and so on. Do they belong together? Absolutely. Do they know that? I think they do. But their connection is almost too intense, almost too overwhelming.Jennifer Weiner uses the motifs of Rachel's broken heart and Andy's inability to know where he belongs throughout the book. Rachel and Andy, in many ways, are twin souls. They each suffer from heart defects, even though Rachel's is actually physical, and they each struggle to find a place where they fit in, even though Andy's stems from his parents' racial differences.On the surface, Rachel ought to be settled and content. She's from a wealthy family, she's pretty, she's intelligent, and she has the unconditional love of her parents and grandmother. She has everything, and yet she lacks what she wants more than anything: a full, deep, complete love. Andy did not grow up in such financially secure circumstances. His single mother struggled, oftentimes keeping her affection for her son at a distance. Andy may not have had a father physically present, but he did have a father figure, a neighbor who taught him how to be a man. Andy learned to channel his anger and frustration into running, earning a college scholarship. The longer and faster he ran, the more he gained confidence. Andy races his way to having everything, and yet he, too, lacks what he wants more than anything: a full, deep, complete love.Weiner lets you see the parts of her characters that are not lovable, that are not endearing. Both of them suffer from vanities, and both are terribly insecure. There were times I wanted to scream at Rachel, and there were times - oh, there were times, faithful readers - when I was disgusted with Andy. But I always, always wanted them happy, content, and together.What makes Jennifer Weiner's writing so exceptional is how well she understands her characters and their stories. She respects them and does not give them easy paths. You never feel manipulated when reading her books, and when you get to the last page, you feel as if you lost a friend or two. After I finished this book, I went back and re-read certain chapters, so loath was I to say good-bye to Rachel and Andy.Get ready to laugh, cry, and beg for more.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris
