I've had these straps (there are two in the package) for a couple of weeks now, and I have no complaints about them. They are long enough for me (I'm 5'10") and my husband, who is 6'4", to use with ease. They are sturdy, functional, and help me stretch out my hamstrings and back. I haven't used them for yoga, but rather just in daily stretching exercises. They are constructed in a durable fashion, and I can tell that I will get a lot of wear out of them. At the same time, though, they are lightweight, so don't assume that just because they're sturdy and durable that they somehow weigh more than your average strap.Give these a try. They're functional, durable, and get the job done.Disclaimer: I received this product in exchange for an unbiased review.

This book has been compared to We Were Liars, and that makes me want to scream, "YOU WISH YOU WERE LIKE We Were Liars!"We Were Liars is evocative and heartbreaking and bittersweet, and it makes you think and feel. E. Lockhart's characters are unforgettable, and she knows how to craft a mystery that keeps you fully engaged because even if you think you know how this will play out, you can't be fully certain.And then there is Damage Done, which all but telegraphs the solution to the "mystery" right from the first page. Worse, you won't be all that interested.The central problem is Julia, now christened Lucy. She is a detestable character, and it is nearly impossible to get close to her. She's mourning the loss of a family member and the tragedy that caused it, as well as bits and pieces of the life she left behind when her family had to move to avoid fallout from the tragedy. She doesn't miss much, actually, about her time as Julia Vann, and she might even be happier as Lucy Black.But someone is determined to bring Julia Vann back to life, and that someone presents a threat to Lucy Black and her parents.And so there is this whole "what does this person want and why" and "what really happened" thing that you're supposed to care about. Maybe you would, if you could care at all about Julia/Lucy. You may not even mind the fact that Amanda Panitch gives away the big mystery right at the start. It would take the blindest, most unaware reader to not figure out what's going on, and I found that a little offensive. It felt as if Panitch thought I was so stupid that I needed such obvious clues.Fortunately, you have Michael and Alane, Lucy's new boyfriend and friend respectively. Those two deserve far better than Lucy Black, that I can assure you. In fact, I spent most of this book not wondering what happened during the 22 minutes of hell that Julia suffered "before," but rather wondering why on earth Alane was friends with Lucy and what in the hell Michael saw in her that made him want to date her.In We Were Liars, E. Lockhart made sure we bonded with her main character, and she kept us guessing. It isn't necessary that you always like characters (Nick and Amy Dunne, I'm looking at you and Gone Girl), but it is necessary that you become invested in their story. I could not have given a fiddler's fart about Julia/Lucy or her mystery. The only reason I kept reading this was to see if Michael and Alane ever realized how much better they would be without Lucy Black in their lives. So I suppose the fact that Amanda Panitch could create characters like Michael and Alane gives me hope that I will enjoy her next book more than this one.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

There is a lot to like about this book, or should I say that there is one character to truly enjoy: Adam. It would be easy for him to come across as pathetic and weak, but Natalie Martin makes him completely empathetic. He's a man who fell in love with the person he thought was his soulmate, ignoring along the way things to which he should have given stronger attention. Sarah closes off parts of her life from him, not revealing much, if anything, about her childhood. But Adam loves her, and love, as they say, is blind.It isn't until he proposes to her while on holiday that he realizes how much he should have noticed, how many questions he should have demanded she answer. Sarah rejects his proposal, and Adam is left reeling and brokenhearted.Due to certain issues with their housing, they are forced to continue living together for months. Sarah largely hides herself away, refusing to say any more to Adam about her rejection aside from telling him that he's better off without her. Adam reacts with anger and pain, attempting to soothe his hurt through alcohol and hook-ups. He tries to exorcise his love for Sarah, even as he has to come home to her.Desperate to understand the woman he loves, Adam stumbles upon Sarah's journals, dating back to her girlhood. The more he learns, though, the more questions he has. Why didn't he already know these things about her? Why did she keep so many secrets from him?This is a somewhat frustrating book because you find yourself questioning Adam's judgment, and since he's the only likable one of the pair, you need to be on his side. It is nearly impossible to figure out why he's drawn to Sarah. She's cold, she's remote, and she's abhorrently selfish. When you find out why she's kept herself removed from him, I think you're supposed to sympathize with her. I didn't. It made her actions even more of a head scratcher. I didn't mind when Adam messed around with other women because I hoped he would realize that there was someone far better for him out there.Natalie Martin's story is interesting, and Adam is a wonderful character. The weakness here is Sarah. She's just irredeemable, and in order to buy in to Adam's love for her, we need to find something about her to like ourselves.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

There is something about these Fool's Gold romances that makes me want to move to this fictional town and find myself a man. Even if I'm already married.Maya isn't a Fool's Gold native. She moved in her teens when her mother married a wealthy man with two sons. For the first time, Maya had stability and a family, but of course it didn't last, following the dissolution of her mother's marriage. Maya moved to Los Angeles, where she worked as a television reporter and then a news producer. Now, ten years later, she's back, working as a public relations agent of sorts for the town. The spokesman hired to star in the ads happens to be the handsome Del, Maya's first love and the man she abandoned.You might say that their first meeting is a wee tad awkward.One thing quite apparent is that the attraction between them has not dimmed at all, even with a decade between Maya quitting Del and Fool's Gold. Sure, he's still nursing a grudge, but he can't ignore the spark that remains.When you don't know what commitment looks like, as is the case with Maya, it makes it even more difficult to actually try it. When she left Del, she had - she believed - valid reasons for doing so, the strongest of which was her fear. Maya knew she loved Del, but she was afraid that her love would not be enough, that she would not be enough. It's the pattern she observed with her mother throughout her life.Del's family life was more stable than Maya's only in that he and his siblings were close and his parents remained married. But there were instabilities, too, and, like Maya, Del left town. In fact, he's continued to roam, far and wide. He isn't sure he wants to stay in one place, even if it is the nirvana of Fool's Gold.You know that these two are meant to be together, but how can they? What if Maya is finally ready to put down roots, but Del still wants to travel the world? How can they reconcile that?Susan Mallery serves up fun, engaging characters, as well as some hot headboard rocking. Surely the sexual chemistry between Del and Maya will be enough to keep them together, right? i know I'd have a difficult time leaving his prowess.You will reconnect with some past stars in the Fool's Gold series, and you will welcome Del and Maya to the fold. I enjoyed their story, and it did not diminish in the least my dreams of moving to Fool's Gold myself.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

I have a long, deep attachment to Kristan Higgins. I want to be her best friend (even if she's a Yankees fan), and, even more, I want to live in her books. I love the way she writes. Love stories that break my heart and leave me feeling happy and crushing on her heroes.This one, though, gave me pause. For one thing, it's about two sisters, one of whom clearly is going through a terrible time in her marriage. Rachel has been with Adam for years, struggled through infertility with him to become parents to preschool triplet girls, and loves him and her life deeply. She's the perfect homemaker, making sure that fresh flowers are in a vase, dinner is simmering, and that the house and children are clean and tidy when he comes home. She is proud of the life they have crafted together, so when she happens to see an incriminating text on his cell phone, she chooses to believe that it is not a photo of someone's lady parts but rather, in a burst of Higgins humor, that of a tree.Younger sister Jenny does not have the happy home or beautiful children. She's been divorced from Owen for a little over a year, but has managed to stay close friends not only with him but her successor. She's even delivered their first born child. But it's difficult. She feels unfulfilled, so when the opportunity to open up her wedding dress making business in her hometown of Cambry-on-Hudson, she leaves Manhatten and heads home, where she meets her building's superintendent, the mysterious - and wildly snarky - Leo.Rachel and Jenny each face turning points in their lives. Rachel has to decide if she can stay married to Adam. Or rather, she has to decide if not being with him is worth the cost of breaking up her family. Maybe this photo was a one-off, something Adam didn't intend on happening and will not allow to happen again. She loves him, and she knows he loves her. Marriages go through this sort of thing, don't they? Doesn't she owe the girls and their family life a mind open to second chances?Jenny, meanwhile, has to figure out where she wants to be in this world. Is she content to be Owen's buddy, on the outside of his happy marriage? Doesn't she want one of her own? And what of Leo? He's private and closed off, yet she can't be wrong about the spark between them, can she?For all of the humor in this book, typical of what Kristan Higgins does, there is a greater sense of the bittersweet. This is a heavier, more emotionally intense book than what you're used to from her. She breaks your heart and puts it back together, leaving you hopeful that Rachel and Jenny are on their way to the happiness and contentment they crave.Told in the sisters' alternating voices, you get to know the sisters and you become immersed in their stories. It took about two chapters for me to realize that I could not, even if I wanted, put this book down. I desperately wanted to know what would happen between Rachel and Adam, which Higgins keeps as the bigger mystery than that between Jenny and Leo. At the same time, Higgins addresses life moments that you can relate to - the busyness of parenting, the occasional lapses in a marriage, the longing for emotional commitment.My love of Kristan Higgins' books knows no bounds. If You Only Knew does nothing less than entrench my adoration for her, showing me that she can make me cry and laugh in equal measure.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

The Sinclairs, a Kennedy-esque New England family, summer together at the family's private island off the coast of Massachusetts. Two parents, three daughters, and the daughters' six children. One of the grandchildren, Cadence, narrates this story of what happened one a sultry summer evening between her, her two oldest cousins Johnny and Mirren, and a family friend named Gat.The problem is that Cady can't remember the events that led to her illness, a debilitating case of headaches that send her to bed. She is desperate to recall how she wound up with the headaches, just as her divorced mother and father, aunts and grandfather, are to keep her safe and healthy. Cady begs Johnny and Mirren to tell her what happened, as she also asks Gat, a boy whom she loves desperately. No one will tell her, though. They wait for her to remember on her own.Cady's memories detail the events leading up to that night, revealing her parents' divorce, how Gat came to join them, and the evolution of her love for him. Together with Gat, Mirren, and Johnny, Cady forms a quartet that calls itself The Liars, largely because they are teenagers and, as such, none too keen on full disclosure. They take care of themselves first, and if the occasional fib is needed to cover their tracks, so be it.The King Lear allusions are in full force, with the patriarch of the family causing friction between his three daughters. With the death of their mother, the sisters begin drinking and fighting, their arguments escalating to the point that The Liars become increasingly frustrated by and disenchanted with the women and their grandfather.Relationships between the characters are every bit as integral to this book as its central mystery. The grandfather and his daughters is but one. Mothers and children is equally as important, whether between Cady and her mother or the other two sisters and their kids. Cady and The Liars is another important relationship, especially that between Cady and Gat. She loves him, in that first teenage love way, and, in doing so, hands him the power to hurt her. She relies on The Liars to help her. They know, even as she does not, that her memories must come back to her without their help. She has to do this on her own.And yet Cady cannot remember. What happened the night she got hurt?E. Lockhart leaves you clues, laying them out in a way that escalates tension and mystery while building empathy for Cady. Lockhart ensures that you never lose sight of the fact that The Liars are four teenagers, kids who may know better but yet are still too young to truly discern the questionable wisdom of knee-jerk reactions to their elders. The revelation of what did happen that awful night is surprising, even if Lockhart gives you plenty of hints.This is a wholly engrossing, evocatively written book. You will feel the isolation of that island and Cady's frustration and her family's fractured, tenuous truce. There is an overaching sense of despair and grief, but why? When Cady does remember, that sense of sadness becomes even more intense. And yet there is also a bittersweet sense of completion and contentment. Cady and her fellow Liars have to re-establish peace between them and their families, and it all hinges on Cady's memories.I loved this one. I could not put it down, and when it was over I missed the characters and story terribly. It's a young adult story that appeals to all adults, regardless of whether they are teenagers or not.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Compared to other nail dryers out there, this one is pretty top notch. It dries your nails evenly and quickly, and my hands didn't feel like they were burning (this has happened with other dryers). I like that it's a little bigger, although I didn't feel comfortable putting my whole hand in it. I still just put my fingers and then did my thumbs separately.It feels sturdy, and I think it will be reliable. I've only had it a week, though, so I can't fully attest to that, hence the four stars instead of five.Overall, it's a good, solid dryer.I received this product free in exchange for my unbiased review.

This is one of those "opposites attract" kind of stories that warms my cold hard heart and makes the blood flow at the same time.If you know what I mean.Ryan's one of those guys whose family only understands love and support. They are almost too good to be true. Brandon, on the other hand, is one of those guys whose family is catastrophically homophobic. They are almost too awful to be true.When they meet, it isn't quite instantaneous love, largely because Brandon isn't just in the closet, he is absolutely petrified and in the closet. For them to be together, it's going to take a lot of love and patience on Ryan's side and a lot of bravery and courage on Brandon's.Some people like the F/F romances, but I am all about the M/M. Something about that combo and some hot headboard rocking really piques my interest. Z.B. Heller sure knows how to deliver the sexy times because this book has some scorching scenes. Strap on your vibrators, girls. If you're into M/M hotness, this book takes you to DEFCON 5.At the same time, the love story itself is gentle and occasionally bittersweet. Ryan and Brandon have a lot to work through, and those issues won't be solved quickly or easily. This isn't a fairytale. It's the story of two people who make mistakes and who have to suffer the consequences of those mistakes. At the center, though, is a connection that can't be fractured.I liked this one quite a bit.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

3.5 starsNina knows nothing about life except that she must always be the responsible person. With an alcoholic mother and a young teen sister, the maintenance of her family falls to her. Unfortunately, her mother's alcoholism causes her younger sister to be sent to foster care, her mother to rehab, and Nina to the arms of the man who was her beloved father's boss. Her beloved dead father, who died in an accident while in the employment of this man.But Nina is nothing if not practical, and so she gets a job, working in a nightclub, with someone she suspects should be her enemy. She meets Alex, a young, wealthy profligate and finds herself irresistibly drawn to him. Nina, the young woman with a ground, practical sensibility, can't fight the attraction.The one thing Nina has always known is that she can trust her instincts. They tell her to RUN from Alex, but she can't. They also tell her to be far more suspicious of her boss than she is, but she can't. As strong as her practical, common sense may be, her need to live a little supersedes it. She's nineteen, and she's spent most of her life taking care of others. Isn't it time she get a chance to live a little?If only her heart wasn't involved.There is a sweetness to this story that isn't evident at first. Nina is tough, both on the outside and the inside. She does not suffer fools, least of which herself, and her BS radar is finely tuned. Yet when she meets Alex, she finds herself letting go of all of those rules, all of those worries. Alex gives her a chance to breathe and to feel free. What girl her age wouldn't jump at that, even with every cell in her brain screaming at her to play it smart and cautious?The thing about Alex, though, is that Nina can sense a vulnerability to him that he wants to keep on lockdown. He's every bit as wary of Nina as she is of him, and he's also every bit as drawn to her as she is to him.Like I said, there is a sweetness to this story that takes a while to develop. Alex presents himself as a Dionysian kind of man, one for whom responsibility is an anathema. Nina, on the other hand, needs stability. Alex's lifestyle will not help her get her sister back, nor will it help her mother stay sober.So what will happen between these two? Well, I suspect you have an idea. Even with that sort of predictability, Tara Bond invests you in Alex and Nina's relationship and takes you on a few unexpected detours.Oh, and she also writes some panty dropping sexy times. Strap on your vibrators, girls. Alex, for all of his self-indulgence, knows how to please a woman. BLESS HIM. Outside of the bedroom, though, is he the right man for Nina? Is she the right woman for him?The ending may seem a tad too neatly tied, but the rest of this is sheer fun. Nina's story is a sad one, as is Alex's, which means you will root for these two to find happiness together.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Do you think men and women can be best friends without one of them wanting the sexy times with the other? Before I got married, most of my friends were male. I was always more comfortable with men than women, and I enjoyed hanging out with guys. But as good of friends as I was with those dudes, none of the friendships was as close and emotionally deep as the one that Parker has with Ben.And, really, those two ought to be smart enough to figure out that the friendship they have is so rich and complete because they love each other. And I don't mean platonically, although that certainly exists too.They have spent six years of friendship stubbornly trying to prove to one and all that they can be friends without the benefits, and it's worked out well for them. When Parker's boyfriend dumps her, though, she thinks she wants to "be like Ben" and have a string of sex-only encounters. Except that isn't Parker. It isn't the person she is.Ben tries to teach her how to sex and sex only, but .... well .... you can probably predict how that turns out. Thank goodness Lauren Layne gets you to the ending with heart and emotion, making you care about Ben and Parker. She writes with respect for her characters and their story, never manipulating you or forcing a happy ending where there might not be one.And the sexy times. Strap on your vibrators, girls, because Lauren Layne writes some juicy delicious hot headboard rocking. Ben is, um, adept, let's just say.I enjoyed this book so much. It's fun, it's emotional, and it has characters I liked spending time with. Ben and Parker are people you will want to get to know, so give this one a chance.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

First things first: you will not go all Cheryl Strayed Wild with this one, although you might suspect you will.With her thirtieth birthday barreling ever closer, ever quicker, Liz decides she will take off on the 200-mile John Muir Trail, a hike that will last about two weeks. She intends on going by herself, not with her boyfriend Dante. She loves Dante, sure, but she isn't convinced that her love for him is of the everlasting, lifetime commitment sort. She's also hiding a big fat secret from him, one that undoubtedly will upset him and possibly lead to their breakup. The thing is, Liz might just want that breakup to happen.When she and Dante begin, she is somewhat disgusted by his new high-end hiking boots and gung-ho demeanor. Dante is almost like an overgrown puppy, so earnest is he in trying to make Liz happy. More than once while reading this, I wondered why. Why, Dante, do you want to stay with this woman? Liz is about as enjoyable as a bad cough, and she makes it undeniably clear that Dante's companionship is not what she wants on this trek.Liz's hike is equal parts self-discovery and suspense, the latter due to the arrival of a Deliverence-type duo of brothers that makes her Spidey Sense tingle with distrust. Are these two up to no good, or is Liz perhaps projecting her own harmful traits onto them? And what of Dante? Will he stick around despite Liz's inhospitable demeanor, or will he head back to civilization?Sonja Yoerg does a nice job of balancing the various dynamics at play. On the one hand, you have Liz's attempt to understand herself and to make peace with some of her selfish decisions. Liz is one of those people whose first thought is of herself (again, WHY, Dante?) and others second. I think she'd be surprised at that assessment, though, because she can justify any hurts she inflicts by pointing out that they benefited her at the time. She also feels that the world owes her something, largely because she's a widow. With a dead husband in her life, she's surely entitled to indulging in self-interest, right? As she puts one foot in front of the other on her hike, though, she is forced to face the reality of the pain she causes. She begins to understand the mistakes she has made, and she might - just might - also realizes the depths of her selfishness.There is also the mystery surrounding the brothers. Are they as dangerous as Liz suspects, or are they merely strange and odd? Liz's relationship with Dante is also part of the mix. Dante is lovable and sweet, but he's also fairly rigid in his religious beliefs. Liz finds his lack of tolerance frustrating at best, and she knows that he will react with extreme anger and hurt when he finds out what she's done.Her time on the trail helps Liz forgive herself for her mistakes, but I'm not sure that process would have been all that tedious under any circumstances. She's a selfish woman at this point in her life. She needs to hike that tendency out of herself, so those 200 miles are an opportunity to reflect and grow.I enjoyed the story, even if I didn't enjoy Liz. I understand why she did what she did, but, like I said, her selfishness is so extreme that I don't think she could excise it with a long hike. I liked Dante, but the fact that he was so devoted to Liz made me question his wisdom. Like, a lot. The subplot with the Deliverance boys is a bit much at times, although it does provide a workable mechanism for Liz's adventures.In the end, I just wish I'd liked Liz more.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Anna Geneva (I love that name) left Haven, Michigan, in disgrace five years ago after it was revealed that she and Mack, a married father of one, were rocking the headboard. Well, "were rocking" implies that they rocked it more than once, which was not the case. But that sole experience was enough to besmirch both Anna's and Mack's reputations, made all the more humiliating for Anna when Mack told her he wanted to stay with his wife and try to rebuild his marriage.Now, a half decade later, Anna has returned to town for her mother's wedding. Maeve Geneva has spent the last twenty-some years pining for the idiot husband who abandoned her and her daughter, a man cruel enough to send her an occasional postcard, just to keep her hooked. Thankfully, she met a kind man whose patience and devotion won her over ... or so it seems.Anna's return agitates Haven, even if Mack and his wife are over. He knows he treated Anna badly, and he wants to make it up to her, but as deeply as Anna cared for him, she isn't sure that this is a smart move for her.This novella is a companion piece to Kristina Riggle's The Life You Imagined, in which you revisit not just Mack and Anna but other characters from that book as well. I didn't read The Life You Imagined, and I suspect that's why this book was just sort of meh to me. It's sweet and cute, but it didn't really leave any lingering impression on me. Mack and Anna are nice characters, but I felt an emotional disconnect from them.My suggestion is to read The Life You Imagined and then pick up this one. Perhaps you will have a better experience.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

What happens when your mother abandons her family to run off with a famous playwright? Perhaps it goes without saying that you would have some adjustment issues, which no doubt are exacerbated by your father deciding he isn't up to the task of raising you, either.When Sara dies, her grown children Nigel and Louise return to the country "estate" where she decamped after her marriage to Patrick, a man as revered as he is reviled for his talents. (One of his plays receives excoriating reviews, to which Patrick takes extreme - and hilarious - umbrage.) Nigel and Louise encounter not a sprawling home but a house in extreme disrepair. Nothing seems to work as it should in this home that should be far grander, far more opulent. If Sara left them for this, not to mention the irascible Patrick, then what does that say about her love for her children?The pair manage their, let's face it, minimal grief, by focusing on what the house could be. They are determined to restore it to its glory, and, along the way, make it theirs. Of course, each of them has singular motives: Nigel and his wife would like to make it a second home, while Louise flat out wants to live there with her ill-begotten teenage children. But what of Patrick? He never liked them anyway, as flashbacks display with hilarity, so he's on his own.Into this hot mess comes Mia, a somewhat scattered grad student who wants to interview Patrick as part of her thesis. For Mia, this house represents the chance to reinvent herself in a new career as a bed and breakfast owner and hostess. Of all the parties at play, Mia is the most transparent, but in a good way. Sure, she has ulterior motives, but she doesn't hide them.One thing that everyone can agree on is that each of them sketches a very different character of Sara. For Nigel, she tried to compensate for leaving him by footing the bill for his schooling. Louise felt distinctly like an outsider, watching her mother choose Patrick to the point of never defending or supporting her while in his presence. And Patrick views his wife as his passionate lover, a woman who devoted herself to him in absolute fullness.Even together, these three do not know the real Sara. As they come together after her death, though, they, with the aid of Mia, begin to form a fuller, truer picture.The house in the story symbolizes Sara: what she should be is not what she in fact was, her supporting beams fractured in ways not apparent on the surface. Together with Mia, Sara's survivors are able to renovate (so to speak) their visions of her.There is much to like and enjoy in this book, not the least of which is its humor. Amanda Coe writes some laugh-out-loud moments that are dearly needed in the midst of characters who are, on the whole, rather unpleasant. Nigel is a somewhat spineless man completely directed by his overbearing wife, Louise is just flat out pathetic and annoying, and Patrick is a complete boor. Only Mia is presented as someone you would want to know, and, even then, she makes a couple of decisions that are less than impressive.Fortunately, Coe's writing is entertaining enough to overcome a rather sparse, rushed ending. Enjoy the wit she delivers.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

1.5 starsUnfortunately, this book fell flat for me. As I read it, I kept thinking it seemed like other books I've read, and when I finished it, I couldn't remember much in particular about it.Chloe Bennet (yeah ... you've got some metafiction on your hands) is a teenage girl desperate to understand Boys. They make no sense to her. Why are they drawn to Mean Girls, rather than intelligent, talented, pretty - if not all together beautiful - girls like her and her friends? Whyyyyy?To understand this, Chloe and her chums devise a data collection process involving spreadsheets and other stuff, and they set out to 'boywatch.' The girls attend an all girls' school, and they somewhat eagerly, somewhat anxiously, somewhat fearfully anticipate the annual dance held between their school and St. Thomas', an all boys' school. Last year, the girls were roundly humiliated by a Mean Girl, and while they are determined that it won't happen again, they are also savvy enough to acknowledge that it very well might. In order to forestall it, though, they have to be able to anticipate and appropriately respond to those St. Thomas boys.And now a bunch of stuff that's happened in hundreds of other YA novels happens. Was I supposed to feel charmed by Chloe stepping in dog poo? Or was I supposed to sympathize with her? Empathize? My reaction was more one of vigorous eye rolling. One of the girls has an alcoholic, absentee mother. Gosh. I've never encountered that before in a YA book.Sometimes there is loving, respectful humor directed at Chloe and her friends, as well as Boys and the Mean Girls, and, of course, parents and other out-of-touch adults. The girls have a little band, called Overgrown Throttle and the Tempted Obscurity, which should give them some sort of coolness points, but doesn't. At least not to the extent that they wish it would. I enjoyed those scenes, largely because the girls' interaction and dialogue in those had more originality than the rest of the book.The thing is, I did like Chloe. She's occasionally abrasive, and she is almost comically self-absorbed, but both of those are very real attributes in teenage girls. She felt real to me, and I commiserated with her insecurities and her frustrations over finishing second (or third or fourth) behind the queen of the Mean Girls. You can't help but hope that Chloe will get her boy.I wanted to like the book as much as I liked Chloe, but it all felt so predictable and familiar.Review copy provided from the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on voxlibris.net@VoxLibris

Where there are three sisters, tears and drama are sure to follow, right?The Herington sisters fall into their own defined categories. Firstborn Maggie is the captain, the organizer, the one who maintains order and tradition. Jess, sandwiched between the older and youngest, is adrift. She doesn't cause trouble and tends to play it safe. The baby, Virgie, lives on the other side of the country and, as the youngest tend to be, is a bit more free-spirited than her sisters.The girls and their families gather every year at Maggie's house, or their parents', for a summer holiday. This year, though, they face something new: their parents' divorce.Things change, people change, and the measure of your emotional health is how you respond. Each of the sisters is facing her own personal adjustments, even as they still attempt to come to terms with the dissolution of their parents' marriage. Maggie is at that stage where her babies aren't babies any more, and she thinks she might want another one. But what of Mac, her husband? What does he want? Jess isn't even sure she wants to be married any longer. It isn't that she doesn't love her husband so much as she isn't in love with him. And Virgie (my favorite of the three) is at a professional standstill. Is she willing to stick with the job she's had, or is it time to move on? She's also in a new romantic relationship, although she has no idea where it is headed.Of course there are dramatic moments. One family member faces a health scare, another one is in the grips of a health crisis, and two have to confront emotional crises. The sisters' mother no longer lives in the family home, but she's very present, offering observations and guidance when she can. She comes across as a sort of benevolent god, mostly adored by her daughters (despite being the one to terminate her marriage), and fairly grounded. Maggie, Jess, and Virgie need her, and she makes the effort to be a presence in their lives.There are humorous moments and times of sadness in this book, as you would expect. In many ways, it's straight out of Central Casting for Chick Lit. It has such a strong sense of familiarity that you feel like you've read this book before. There are no big surprises (well, one of the storylines was dispatched with far quicker than I thought), and the overall sense is that of one big warm fuzzy.I don't have much to say about this book. If you're a fan of traditional women's fiction, this is a solid choice. I was just left wishing there was more to it than the predictable.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

2.5 starsSomewhere in this book lies a fantastic YA mystery. It's in there. The hope of discovering it kept me reading and reading.And yet ...Lena and Charlie dated for years. Granted, they were apart for a good amount of time, attending colleges in different countries and each traveling hither and yon. But she met his family, for goodness sake. It was a serious relationship, and she loved him. Imagine her shock while at his funeral, when she discovers that Charlie had been dating another girl: Aubrey, a midwestern American girl whom he'd been seeing for about a year. Aubrey had not met Charlie's family, and the Charlie she dated seems quite different from Lena's. One Charlie loved olives, the other Charlie hated them, amongst other things.And then there is his death. No body was found, and Lena is suspicious. Is Charlie really dead? Or did he fake his death? And if he faked it, why?The two girls team up to find out what happened to their boyfriend, a partnership that takes them from France to England to India. Along the way, they discover that there was a third Charlie, and they begin wondering if either of them ever really knew him.The girls do not immediately trust each other, which adds another layer of mystery. Are their motives pure? Aubrey is honest about hers (Charlie took something of hers that she wants back), but is Lena? There is an undercurrent of "who do you trust" to this book, which makes you question every character you encounter.The problem is that as a reader, you have to trust someone in a mystery. One of them must appear to be legitimate, even if that turns out not to be the case. These people are so transparently selfish and self-serving that you can't be sure that any of them are legitimate. Then again, that's one of the ongoing motifs of Heltzel's story: we partition ourselves out of necessity. For one audience, we put on one face. For another, a different one. But what happens when you can't keep track of who you're supposed to be?Charlie is presumed dead, but that is not the only presumption in this book. Aubrey appears to be an innocent victim, especially in light of the far worldlier Lena, but is she? And is Lena the victimized girlfriend, or was she up to something as well? Then there is Charlie. You do learn about him, although not nearly enough.The big plot twist that comes is not such a shock because the build up to it leads you there. But - and this is a biiiig but - it makes no sense. The "why" is not answered with any effectiveness whatsoever. In fact, what appears to be a justification for why this happened turns out to be every bit as obfuscating as the rest of the book.What Charlie, Presumed Dead needs is some answers. All of the vagueness adds up to a book that doesn't leave much of an impression. The intended audience for this is teens, and teens don't do well with the nebulous. With no clarity of character (or plot, for that matter), you're left without a firm investment in the story. When you get to the end, I doubt Anne Heltzel intends for your reaction to be, "So?"I wanted to like this. I really did.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Beth and Jack met eight years ago while on vacation in Corsica. She thought both felt love; she was certain of it, in fact. Yet she has heard nothing from him since he put her on a plane to leave, despite his promises that he loved her and would come for her.When she interviews with him for a job, the betrayal she felt all those years ago comes back full force. Beth isn't sure she can work for Jack, yet she needs the job, and it's something she's good at doing. Jack is glad - and relieved - to have Beth working with him. He knows he has some apologizing to do, and he wants to help her understand what happened when she left Corsica.This is a sweet, adorable romance novel that might just make you cry. (I did. I had to grab more than one tissue.) Beth and Jack are enjoyable and likable, the sort of chick lit couple you want to be together. He tries to do the right thing, even if the right thing hurts him most of all, and she somehow manages to maintain hope that she will get the love she wants.There is one scene with some sexy times, and it isn't wildly detailed. No Red Rooms of Pain here, kids. Sometimes you want a romance novel that makes you smile (and occasionally cry), and this book fits that perfectly.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

How good is this book? Well, first of all, "good" is an insult. Let me see if I can come up with something more effective. How compelling? How intoxicating? How sublime? How FREAKING TRANSCENDENT is this book?It is so compelling and intoxicating and sublime and transcendent that I am worried about writing this review for fear that I will not do Jandy Nelson justice.Noah and Jude are twins who look nothing alike. He's dark and awkward and socially withdrawn, while she is golden and bright and open to friends and engagement. The two have an ongoing barter system of sorts in which, believing that they own the universe, they offer its various parts in exchange for something. When Noah, an artist who draws and paints, sketches a cubist-style portrait of a mysterious - and naked - British male model, Jude offers him the sun in exchange for the drawing. It magnetizes her, and she must have it.This turns out to be one of the last friendly exchanges between the two.It isn't that Noah and Jude are combative or competitive with each other. Quite the opposite, in fact. Noah acknowledges certain truths: their father loves Jude more, and their mother shows no preferences. The latter point, in fact, becomes the chisel that causes the first fracture. Remember that Rod Stewart lyric? The first cut is the deepest? Such is the case between Noah and Jude.Exacerbating the situation is the appearance of Brian, the boy next door. That first cut? It has a partner now, and so strong is the resentment that Noah and Jude hold against each other that their relationship might never overcome the onslaught.Told from both Noah and Jude's perspectives, the time frame jumps back and forth between Noah's story, the "before," and Jude's, the "after." You see what divided the twins, and you see what might tear them asunder for the rest of their lives.This novel is an ode to art and the power it has over us. Jandy Nelson uses magical realism to show the depth and breadth of art - the way you can actually see someone's spirit in the colors and bursts and flares that emanate from them. Jude is an artist, too, only her form is sculpture. One twin draws and paints, the other molds. Separately they create beautiful parts, but together they could create stunning fullness. Noah, however, is not inclined to any sort of partnership with his sister. As he observes, "Revolutionaries aren't team players."Noah certainly is a revolutionary, although he heads in a direction he does not anticipate. The same goes for Jude, who is every bit as revolutionary as her brother. She does not see art as her future, yet it is there, within her grasp. She needs Noah to help her find her way, though, just as he needs her.As much as this is a book about the power of art, it's also about the power of love. Jude and Noah each realize love's destructive power; for the most part during their sixteen years, destruction is what they know best. But as Jude comes to see, "Love does as it undoes. It goes after, with equal tenacity: joy and heartbreak."Yes, twins joy and heartbreak are as physically present as Noah and Jude. You can't have one without the other. You can't know joy unless you've experienced heartbreak, and vice-versa. Jude puts it this way: "We are, each one of us for the other, a key to a door that otherwise would've remained locked forever." What she and Noah need to understand is that they are the keys for each other, and without each other, parts of them - important, vital parts - will never be opened.I could go on and on about symbolism (the names 'Jude' and 'Noah' alone) and subtext and all that sort of stuff. The literature geek in me is so excited about this book that I made it part of the reading list for my AP seniors this year. I cannot wait to analyze and discuss it.You need to read this book is you appreciate lyrical writing. You need to read it if you like characters who make you feel, all the way to your toes. You need to read this if you want to experience joy and heartbreak yourself.It's that .... good.Published on VoxLibirs.net@VoxLibris

3.5 starsLadies, meet Derek Block.Eschewing suits for flannel and deference for dominance, Derek is a man of mystery yet is also accessible. He knows what he wants and he gets it.And what he wants is Frankie Jordan.She's the daughter of a successful real estate broker, although she resolutely refuses to allow nepotism to be the cause of her success. This is a woman who began in the mailroom and has held nearly every job at her father's business. Now she is on the cusp of earning a top managerial spot. What she needs is Derek Block's brand new high rise as her account.At first theirs is a strictly professional relationship, but COME ON. You know that won't last. Frankie discovers that Derek is even more adept at pleasuring a woman than he is at designing buildings. Strap on your vibrators, girls. When Derek starts rocking that headboard, he will rock it right into next week.Clearly neither Derek nor Frankie reads romance novels because these two think - they really believe - that they can have a sex only, no strings attached relationship. Yeah .... no. Not that either is open to disclosing that they are seeing each other. Frankie doesn't want to risk her father's censure, and Derek is blocking certain truths from Frankie. (GET IT? Blocking truths?)Across this series of novellas, you will find some corporate intrigue, some romantic intrigue, jealousy, passion, romance, emotional cruelty, professional malfeasance, and, occasionally, True Love. And a whole lot of sexy times.It's a fun, hot series, even if it feels a bit drawn out. The occasional lapses in pacing and somewhat predictable storyline are overcome, though, by the romance between Derek and Frankie. Neither is too good to be true, and you know, as you read this book, that they are mean to be together.Just don't forget to have that vibrator handy ...Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

You know the story of Sleeping Beauty, right? Rose gets pricked by a needle and takes a nice, long nap, until a handsome prince gives her a sweet kiss (I'm thinking he slipped her some tongue), after which she wakes up and the two live happily ever after.Well, in this retelling, you have Amelia, who wakes up not knowing who she is, where she is, or anything about her life. Fortunately, Ian, the handsome prince, is there to fill her in. Amelia is a clone of his dead lover Susannah, who made sure that Amelia looks like her but doesn't share any of her memories. Amelia likes foods that Susannah didn't like, and she (apparently) enjoys submissive sexy times.Ian is worried that Amelia is programmed to like him and submit to him, when he'd really rather these things be her choices. Meanwhile, there is a sect of the population that is vehemently opposed to clones, which means that Amelia is in danger.So there is a lot going on.I tried, faithful readers, to get into this book. But Amelia was a little too dull for me, the whole anti-clone thing was a bit over-the-top, and Ian is a bit too unknown. This is the first of a three-part series, and I don't knkow if I will read beyond this because I don't know if I'm interested enough in Amelia and Ian's story.But. The sex? The sex scenes are pretty awesome. For a virgin-clone, Amelia knows what she likes, and she knows that she enjoys experiencing these things with Ian. And who can blame her? I pictured him as older than he is (he's in his late twenties), which seemed to fit his back story better, but that really doesn't have anything to do with anything and I'm not even sure why I'm including that observation.Anyway.The sex scenes are pret-ty awesome, so you girls will need to strap on your vibrators while you read this one.Unfortunately, the rest of the book isn't so hot. Amelia is a tabula rasa to some degree, and the people around her try to mold her to what they think she should be. You are told (more than once) that she resembles Susannah but has her own look, which I guess fits with cloning? I thought clones were supposed to be precise copies, but, when you think about it, each copy loses some of the sharpness and clarity of the original. Perhaps there is no such thing as an exact replica.I think part of the problem with this book is that it doesn't know what it wants to be. Is it an erotic romance? A damning commentary on the dangers of cloning? A sort of exploration of how we expect people to be the way we want them to be as opposed to how they are?If you read it, let me know what you thought. What is this book really about?Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

This book defies any quick categorization or labelling. It also defies any quick and easy review.It is Senna's thirty-third birthday, and she wakes up in a strange room in a strange house in a strange place. She has no idea where she is or why she is there. All she knows for sure is that she is trapped.Senna quickly discovers that she is not alone; someone else is held captive as well. This person has a particular significance to Senna, yet she cannot figure out what commonality shared between them is cause to kidnap them. The two form a somewhat easy alliance, born more of a desperate need to survive than of any lingering affection. There will be no escaping this jail, that much is certain. What the two prisoners must determine is whether they can, indeed, survive.I always tell my students that writers never give their characters the age of thirty-three accidentally. If you are told that a character is thirty-three, you must expect that something cataclysmic will happen to that person. It is an age that demands some sort of spiritual death, some sort of reawakening and rebirth. Such is the case with Senna. She has to revisit particularly painful parts of her life in order to stay alive. She has to confront certain pains and agonies, and she has to kill off parts of herself in order to be reborn.The immediate problem is that neither she nor her fellow inmate realize this. At first, their sole goal is to get through the first day, and then the second, and then the third. They take care of each other, instinctively becoming strong when one is weak, and allowing each other the space and forgiveness to have moments of weakness.Throughout her captivity, Senna slowly comes to realize that her past is the true jailer. She needs to rid herself of the ugliness that holds her captive. That's where the title comes in: a mud vein is the dark vein that runs through the outer edge of a shrimp, otherwise known as its digestive tract. "Senna," in fact, is an herbal supplement that aids in digestion. In other words, this is a book about purging yourself of that which poisons you. In Senna's case, it's a lifetime of hurt, abandonment, grief, and loneliness. Not that she isn't occasionally the architect of her own misery; she certainly is at times. But aren't we all? Who amongst us glides through life without making mistakes? The problem for Senna is that she lacks the ability to react to her mistakes in a healthy way because she internalizes them. She has convinced herself that she deserves all of the ugliness - all of the mud in that vein.This is not a perfect book, despite my gushing. The 'who' and 'why' behind Senna's captivity is a bit of a stretch, especially the 'why.' As big of a head scratcher as this is, it nonetheless feels like a minor quibble in the face of such stunning writing. The good news is that Senna's fellow prisoner is also her path to salvation. She cannot free herself without this person's help, not in any aspect or fashion.Tarryn Fisher wrote a powerful, visceral book, one that will affect you and stay with you long after you read it. Its power lies in Senna. Much like Dorothy in The Wizard of Oz, Senna has had the keys to release her all along. She just doesn't realize it until it is very nearly too late. But as with Dorothy, Senna can't free herself until she is ready. She has to learn for herself that she is not her mud vein. It is a part of her, yes, but it does not define her.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Nothing has come easily in Cassie's life except her friendship and relationship with Graham. Her father died when she was a toddler, and her mother suffers from bipolar disorder, which means Cassie is genetically predisposed to get it herself.At eighteen, Cassie found herself trying to decide between colleges, acting as a caretaker for her mother, and newly engaged to Graham. Its all too much for her, though, especially the fear that she, too, could develop bipolar disorder. So she does the only thing she can think to do: she runs away in the middle of the night.Now, nearly a year later, she receives a phone call from Graham. Her mother nearly burned the house down, and Cassie needs to come home.Whereas Cassie's mother almost burned down the house, Cassie absolutely did burn some bridges. Her friends can't and won't forgive her for hurting Graham, and he has spent their time apart desperately trying to get over her. He has a new girlfriend, and he has plans separate from anything related to Cassie.Their first few interactions are awkward, to say the least. Each has lingering feelings for the other, but whereas Cassie's feelings don't affect another relationship, Graham's do. He has Molly, and he's quite fond of her. Cassie is the girl next door, though, and that proximity, coupled with the way his heart (and body) responds to Cassie, means that Graham faces a world of trouble.Then there is the matter of Cassie's mother. Cassie recalls some fairly harrowing events from her childhood of what it was like to live with her mother's manic and depressive moods. The responsibility she felt for her mother permeated everything in her life, even adding a stronger sense of need for Graham than might have existed otherwise. Through Graham, we hear that Cassie as a child was full of energy and light, but the Cassie in the book is sad, reclusive, and dark. It's hard to see the Cassie that Graham recalls, and I think you need that to have a stronger connection with this book.Fortunately, Cassie and Graham are likable and empathetic. This doesn't mean that you will always like them. Each of them does and says things that make you cringe and cause you to question them. Danielle Ellison very wisely follows these scenes with those in which Cassie and Graham redeem themselves, establishing you firmly on their sides.The crux of the conflict is Cassie's abandonment of Graham and her home. Why did she leave? Graham never asks, largely out of fear. Does he want to hear that he wasn't going to be enough for her? What reason could she give that would justify her leaving him? Is there anything she can say that will make him hurt less? It isn't that she doesn't have her reasons, at least in a way she can justify it to herself. And this is another weakness. Cassie's rationale for leaving Graham just doesn't click. I think it's because life with her mother never seems so awful that she would need to hurt Graham the way she does. I get that she's afraid, but is that enough of a reason for her to leave in the middle of the night?Despite those issues, this is a pretty decent read. I wondered if and how Graham and Cassie would come together, and Ellison makes this happen in a natural way, one that doesn't feel forced. This is labeled as a New Adult book, which I guess it is. There are a couple of sex scenes that have just enough detail to move them out of YA. I doubt many parents want their thirteen-year-old daughters reading the sexy times.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

When last we saw Jax and Lizzie, she had met someone, and, in the interest of seeing what might develop, she ceased her sexual tutelage under Jax. He is, to put it simply, shocked.In Part 2, Jax must come to terms with a couple of truths that leave him unsettled: he wants an actual relationship with Lizzie, and he doesn't know how to go about it.Whereas Part 1 was a breezy, sexy romp, this one has more emotional depth. You still don't know as much about Lizzie as I would have liked, but you do learn more about Jax - his childhood, his family, the origins of his business. He becomes a more fully developed character, not simply because he shows his vulnerability, but because you get to see more of him than just Jax the Architect and Jax the Sex God.Whereas Lizzie is still a bit too two-dimensional, she does become far more sympathetic than she did in Part 1. JD Hawkins gets us into her head and lets you understand why she's drawn to this new guy. You know why she's drawn to Jax, but this new man. What is it he offers that Jax does not?If you learned anything about Jax from Part 1, it's that he usually gets what he wants. Lizzie, though, defies all of his assumptions.Of course you want to know about the sex. If Jax and Lizzie are apart, how can there be any hot headboard rocking? Oh, faithful readers. Rest assured. JD Hawkins knows how to get these two in the sack, and he most certainly puts them there. Strap those vibrators back on, because you'll need them for Part 2.Again, I find myself wishing this were one book instead of two. But, again, I am alone in that sentiment.JD Hawkins shows that men can write hot romance novels. He knows how to create heroes women swoon over and heroines women want to be.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

If you want a fast, hot book, this is the one for you.The first in a two-part novella series, Insatiable introduces you to Jax, a man for whom the word "cocky" is a wild, vast understatement. And I mean that in every sense of the word. (wink wink)Jax's idea of a relationship is two hours spent rocking the headboard, after which he will (a) not remember her name and (b) not call. For one thing, he's got a successful business to run. Jax is a self-made man whose architecture skills beckon the rich and famous in Los Angeles. He will not permit a relationship to interfere with his professional successes.And for another, he's Jax! When he walks into a room, women converge on him like kittens to catnip. He chooses which lucky girl will benefit from his carnal craft.Then Lizzie shows up, and Jax's world as he has constructed it begins to crack.She's gorgeous, feisty, and ... resistent.This book is so much fun to read because JD Hawkins writes not just hot headboard rocking (and, oh, does he ever do that ...) but romance too. In Jax, Hawkins has more than a sex god hero, he has a romantic leading man, and he instinctively knows what women want and how to write it.Strap on your vibrators, girls. JD Hawkins is going to leave you a quivering, needy wreck who very likely will wear out the motor in your favorite toy. Or, better yet, wear out your lover. You will feel inspired after reading Jax and Lizzie's adventures.There are a few weaknesses, largely in terms of character development, but those are addressed in the second book. Readers of this blog know how I feel about one good book getting split up into smaller installments; I am not a fan. I wish this was one substantial read instead of two novellas, but it isn't always about me. (Even thought it should be, really.)At under 150 pages, this won't take you long to read. It ends on a cliffhanger, so make sure you have Insatiable #2 locked and loaded. You will want to know what happens between Jax and Lizzie.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Pull up a chair and make yourselves comfortable, faithful readers, for I am about to gush, and gush unabashedly.I loved this book.You know how you're coming up on the last few chapters and you don't want the book to end? That was me! Reading Miss Match! I did not want to say goodbye to Andy and Blake because I liked them so much!Andy isn't so much at a crossroads in her life as she has taken out residence on one and does not seem inclined to move any time soon. She lost her job under cloudy circumstances, she has no man friend, she is sponging off her struggling musician sister, and her idea of a good time is eating name brand cereal.What is she doing to change things? Nothing.It isn't until her sister insists that she apply for a rather unusual job that she sluggishly proceeds to do so.Wealthy (and oh-so-gorgeous) businessman Blake Donovan is successful in every aspect of his life, except finding a wife. He places an want-ad for a matchmaker, promising a substantial financial payoff when he gets married. Andy is perfect for this job because she has the ability to read people quite intuitively. She can divine, based on how you line up the ink pens on your desk, all sorts of clues about your personality.Blake offends Andy on so many levels. He can't be bothered to use her name - he shortens Andrea to Drea, rather than Andy - and his requirements for a wife lean heavily toward the superficial. Yet she agrees to work for him. She needs the money, yes, but she also finds herself uncomfortably interested in him.In order to buy into this premise, you have to like Blake and Andy, and YOU WILL LOVE THEM. Andy is a real woman. She's flawed, she's got a heart, she is sexual, she is leery, she is confident, she is self-conscious, she is bold, she is reluctant. She is someone I wish existed in real life because I want to be her best friend. Blake could have been a one-note character, yet another billionaire with a heart the size of a pomegranate seed who learns to love under the tutelage of his soul mate. But in the hands of Laurelin McGee, Blake is interesting and empathetic. He's as well-developed as Andy is, and nothing he does seems out of his character or manufactured for plot.Told from Blake and Andy's alternating points-of-view, this book has far more depth than your typical romance novel. Blake is more fragile than he wants you to think. He endeavors to protect himself by choosing a bland, attractive wife who will pose no challenge or, really, interest to him, beyond her service as a homemaker and hostess. He believes his life will be easier if it's free from emotional obligations. While Andy welcomes emotional involvement, she nonetheless leads a life that requires very little from her. It isn't until she meets Blake that she begins giving more of herself, both professionally and personally.You know I love some hot headboard rocking, and this book succeeds spectacularly in providing some deliciously arousing sexy times. Strap on your vibrators, girls, as Laurelin McGee delivers searing sex scenes that will melt the panties right off you. But - and this is an important distinction - for all of the hotness of the headboard (or desk or wall or whatever) rocking, it's made even more satisfying because the emotional hook is every bit as powerful as the sexual.This is the debut novel from Laurelin McGee, who is actually two writers, Laurelin Paige and Kayti McGee, and I can't wait for their next endeavor. Like, seriously can't wait.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

The synopsis for this book is almost as long as the novella itself.So Sophie has been with Scott since, like, five-ever (as the kids today like to say), and their relationship is as stale as your grandma's saltine crackers. The couple are headed in different directions, have diverging goals, and it's time for a break-up.Fortunately, Sophie's transition from girl-living-with-boyfriend to girl-dating-hot-dude comes simply and easily when she is enlisted by her boss to accompany Nick, a big Hollywood star, to an awards show. Before you can say, "Cinderella," Sophie is gussied up in a designer dress and hanging on Nick's arm.She isn't convinced that there is anything more than the fulfillment of a work obligation between them, but Nick has other ideas. He wants a relationship. But can he give Sophie what she wants and needs? He's constantly working, which means he travels a LOT. And then there is the matter of tabloid photos of him playing tonsil hockey with costars and starlets.Tasha Cotter moves her romance along at a brisk pace. While she doesn't give much depth to Nick or Sophie, she does know how to tell a fairytale. There is a fairy godmother (of sorts), an evil stepsister, a prince, and the sweet, kind-hearted heroine. There is not one bit of realism here, but you won't care. The romance is sweet and adorable, and that suffices.My biggest quibble is with the New Adult labeling. NA lit typically means that there is some (super) hot headboard rocking, and that, I am sad to report, is absent entirely from here. Most of the sexy times have a "fade to black" sense about them, in which Coleman ends the scene right when it starts to get hot. I felt a distinct case of blue boobs while reading this. There is one scene that has a little more detail, but even that needs more in order to justify the NA label.This is a cute, breezy romance, one you can read in its entirety during a trip to the pool.Review copy received from publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

If you could find out whether you are going to battle a terminal illness (or even a potentially terminal illness), would you? This question holds particular resonance for those susceptible to genetic illnesses. My grandfather had Alzheimer's, and I know that every time my father forgets something he knows that he knows, there is an attendant fear. Do I have it?Claire's father had Alzheimer's and died of complications related to it, so she knew there was a chance she would suffer from it, too. She also knows that hers will be the lesser suffering; her husband Greg, her two daughters, and mother will all bear far more trials and agonies than she will. Now in her early forties, she receives the crushing diagnosis: she has early-onset Alzheimer's, and it is progressing with great aggression.Told from Claire's perspective, as well as that of Greg and her oldest daughter Caitlin, The Day We Met gives you the frightening and devastating effects of a degenerative brain disease wreaks on a family.Claire remembers some things with clarify, such as her relationship with Claire's father, a man she hasn't seen since she was newly pregnant with their daughter. She knows who Esther is, her three-year-old daughter with Greg. She knows her mother, and she has some memories of her father.She is slowly forgetting Greg, though. The two met when he did some construction work on her house, and, undeterred by a ten-year age gap, they fell in love. Theirs has been a happy, contented, passionate relationship, and Claire is becoming further and further removed from it. Greg will lose his wife twice: emotionally first, physically last.At twenty, Caitlin faces particular fears that no child wants to consider. She knows that her mother and grandfather had Alzheimer's. She could get it, or pass it on to a child she may have. She also feels the immediate push and pull of her mother's illness. Should she leave school and help care for Claire, or should she live her life, knowing that she could be struck with this disease in a couple of decades?At times the story is intimate and deeply emotional. Claire begins a friendship with a man she meets in a coffee shop, and her behavior shocks and saddens. Can she be blamed, though, for something that is out of her control? She is held hostage to Alzheimer's. The disease dictates her behavior, but what of her family?So much of this book is emotionally gripping and demanding. Claire's relationships with her mother and Caitlin are moving and affecting. But the relationship intended to be the emotional center of the book - Claire and Greg's marriage - feels oddly distant and removed. Part of this is due to the disease, but part is also due to storytelling. I needed more Greg. Rowan Coleman tells us how he met Claire and how their courtship began, but she skims the surface when we need more depth. Clearly Greg is intended to be the magnetic pole. His mother-in-law and stepdaughter direct you to be concerned about him, and Claire frets over the burden she knows she will become. Perhaps if Caitlin's story had been less significant or detailed, more attention would be paid to Greg's, giving his greater emphasis and emotional significance.This is a difficult book to read because the ending you want - for Claire to be cured - is not going to happen. How can Rowan Coleman end this book in a way that you don't lose hope for her characters? As she takes you closer to the ending, that need to know Greg better intensifies. If he had been a stronger, more dynamic character, this would have been a better book.As it is, it's a good book, one that you will enjoy. You just may not be as emotionally invested as you should.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Sometimes life offers you a do-over. But rarely does that do-over come without cost.Amber realizes this when she returns home to Australia to help care for her father after he suffers a stroke. She leaves behind her husband Ned, with whom she is struggling to find the passion and affection that connected them when they first met. Part of her has always thought that she settled in marrying Ned, believing that her heart lay somewhere else.That 'somewhere' is right where she lands, shortly after arriving back home: Ethan. He and Amber were friends from childhood, best friends even. Although she wanted more, she made peace with the fact that Ethan did not. He was a bit of a cad, always dating and discarding gorgeous women. Like Amber, he is married. Unlike Amber, he has two children.As Amber finds herself drawing closer to Ethan - and to the possibility of discovering what might have happened - she also recalls her mother, who died in a car accident when Amber was a toddler. Amber was in the car, too, and survived, and she has fractured memories of what happened. What role, she wonders, did she play in her mother's death?She receives a letter from a woman who was on the scene of the accident, asking if Amber would come see her. The woman wants Amber to know what her mother's final words were.The title is a play on several factors. First, there is the car accident. Was Amber's mother distracted by something? Or someone? Then there is Ethan. Is he distracting Amber from what truly does make her happy?The thing with distractions is that sometimes you need them. When you're struggling with serious emotional challenges, a distraction can help clear your head, in a way. It can help you refocus, recommit. Distractions can be more sinister, of course. They can sidetrack you from what you need to such a degree that you allow yourself to believe in the distraction rather than the truth.Amber has to realize these things. She has to accept her father's illness and his long-term relationship with the woman he became involved with several years after the death of his wife. Amber also must determine which man is her truth and which her distraction, Ethan or Ned. And of course she needs to understand and process her mother's death.My favorite part of this book was Amber's relationship with Ethan. Maybe you have an Ethan in your life; I sure do. That one person about whom you find yourself occasionally wondering 'what could have been.' Of course, in doing so, a certain romanticization occurs as you forget the hurts and pains, preferring to recall the joys and blisses. Amber does this, to a degree, but she does acknowledge and reflect on the many times Ethan hurt her, however inadvertently. For her it isn't so much a wistful wondering of what might have been, but more of a question of how Ethan would respond if he knew she loved him for so many years. Even though she is a married woman, she finds it easy to forget about Ned. He's in England; she's in Australia. He hasn't been making her happy lately, and she uses this as an excuse to let her thoughts wander to Ethan. The little things in her marriage that bother her become amplified in her mind, justifying her renewed interest in another man.I really enjoyed how Paige Toon wrote about Amber's marriage and relationship with Ethan. There was no attempt to glorify either one, and both men are presented roundly and fully. We see their strengths and weaknesses, and Toon makes you change your mind several times over which man is the right man for Amber. Amber, too, is drawn with flaws. She does some things that could alienate a reader, but Toon crafts her in a way that you don't want to abandon her.The part of the book I found a tad overwrought was that relating to the death of Amber's mother. Too often those scenes felt intrusive, throwing off the pacing. I wonder if the book needs that subplot.More than anything, this is a romance, and it is not limited to just one. Those were the book's strengths, and those are why you should read it.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

Fabulous job? Check.Designer wardrobe? Check.Scion of a Cape Cod dynasty? Check.Complete fraud? Checkmate.TifAni FaNelli (that's how it's spelled) lives a lie from top to bottom. So immersed is she in manufacturing the perfect faade that she almost forgets who she really is.Almost.It's hard to put your unappealing past behind you when a documentary filmmaker wants to interview you for a film he's putting together focused on a tragic, horrific event from your past. But as desperate as TifAni, who has rechristened herself Ani (pronounced like the last two syllables of "Tiffany"), is to refashion herself as a beacon of flawlessness, she nonetheless agrees to participate in the documentary.No one in her life wants her to do this film. Not her social climbing mother, not the fiancé she marked and claimed, and not her closest friend. They all think that dredging up this event is unsavory, but the greater the resistance she faces, the more determined Ani becomes to be interviewed.Ani takes us through her present time - preparing for her wedding and that interview - while also taking us back into her Bradley School years, the time in which the event in question occurred. TifAni FaNelli was desperate to fit in with her new, wealthy, entitled classmates, and she was willing to promote whatever alliances necessary to achieving that goal.As Jessica Knoll makes clear, TifAni (and Ani) is always focused on achieving her goals.When you're in high school, though, especially when you feel unworthy, awkward, lonely, and self-conscious, you might find your perception compromised. What appears to be a friend may be an enemy; what appears to be a kind gesture may be something far more nefarious. Like most teenagers, TifAni will do some things that clearly will not end the way she anticipates. The difference is that her actions lead to terrible, awful actions on the parts of others.Recalling her childhood steels Ani as she prepares to revisit those days with the filmmaker. She redoubles her efforts to be a size 0, both for the interview and for her wedding. Her relationship with food, in fact, serves as a metaphor for how she sees herself. She desperately wants to be thin, believing that dropping pounds will make her look good on camera and as she walks down the aisle. Yet she regularly binges, voraciously stuffing herself and sabotaging her diet goals. She does not recognize this behavior for what it is: an attempt to fill a gawping void within her.From the opening pages, Jessica Knoll displays that void with unflinching rawness. As Ani considers her job, clothes, and fiancé Luke, she also imagines plunging a knife into the Luke's neck. She loves him, or at least the idea of him, yet she hates the part of herself that needs Luke to feel better about herself. Luke represents what she strived for in high school. He embodies her social compulsion to be an object of envy, to have (and be) the best there is.This drive for perfection is a rebuke against how society defines 'perfect.' Ani's life is every bit as airbrushed as models in magazines, and every bit as fake. But people want to be like her. They envy her - they use her as the standard for them to reach - and she loves that. It validates her. And it makes her a wickedly unlikable character. (Not many characters in this book are people you want to know in real life, by the way, and you can tell that Jessica Knoll had a lot of fun creating them.)What makes Ani the luckiest girl alive? Is it Luke? The fancy duds? The job that causes young women to regularly ask her for advice so that they, too, can have a job like hers? Ani might be the first person to tell you that none of that involves luck. She worked - she works - resolutely and tenaciously to achieve those things. Yet she is the luckiest girl alive, and as you read her story, you will see how and why.TifAni FaNelli has worked assiduously to create Ani FaNelli, the future Mrs. Luke Harrison IV. When she introduces herself on the documentary, she uses her future husband's last name, further removing herself from her past. Confronting and revealing the truth about what happened at Bradley, though, requires confronting and revealing the truth about herself.It requires understanding what being the luckiest girl alive means.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

This is the damnedest book.The beginning feels as if it were shot out of a cannon. A nameless woman writes a letter to Deb, the wife of the man with whom she has been having an affair. The letter taunts and shames, its intention clearly to devastate Deb and wreck her marriage to Jack because included with the letter are print-outs of text messages and emails that Jack and the woman exchanged.The couple's eleven-year-old daughter Kay opens it, however, and reads its contents, page after page of sexual exchanges between her father and another woman. Kay's instinct is to protect both of her parents, but she's only eleven. She acknowledges that she doesn't understand what all of this means, so she shares the box with her brother Simon.Julia Pierpont's story details the destruction of a marriage. She introduces you to Deb and Jack at a critical juncture of their relationship and then retraces their beginnings, letting you see how they started and how they built a life together. Jack is an artist; a man who views his life as a constant series of urges, some artistic, some emotional, some paternal, and some sexual. He compartmentalizes these urges, not believing that his infidelity is a threat to his marriage. It's part of his work, and whereas Deb may see his cheating as something that distances him from her, he sees it as something that spurs his art.Ever present are Kay and Simon, who are as much a part of this marriage as Deb and Jack. It is impossible for a couple's marital trials and tribulations not to affect their children. Simon is fifteen, not a kid any more, but not an adult, either. His emotional immaturity dictates how he responds to challenges that come his way.
