He lashes out, he retreats, and he tries to process what Jack's infidelity means to his mother, his sister, and himself.At eleven, Kay is more precocious, although she disguises it well. She comes across as fragile and easily wounded, but she processes her anger and fears more productively, for lack of a better word, than her brother does. Part of her wonders what would have happened if she hadn't been the one to open the box, and another part certainly resents her brother for what he did with it when she showed the box to him. Kay still views her father as a bit of a hero, even as she is disappointed in him.The first part of this book is fantastic. And then, about halfway through, Pierpont tells you how it will end. I was gobsmacked by that maneuver. Why would she do that? What function does this serve in the novel? I can't say that I ever was able to answer either question. It still makes no sense to me, and it made the backtracking that came after it somewhat nonsensical. We know what will happen, and it doesn't take a huge leap of imagination to figure out how and why it does. I kept wondering what the book would have been like if Pierpont had followed a more traditional timeline. I'm all for mixing things up in terms of plotting, so long as there is a purpose for it. That's what is missing here.For all of the frustration this causes, the wonky timeline cannot detract from Pierpont's ability to create interesting, sympathetic characters. It should be easy to dislike Jack, yet I found myself unable and unwilling to choose him over Deb. Not that I forgive him - he disrespects and disregards his wife in an awful, hurtful way - but his rationale for his behavior strikes a chord. Pierpont takes care to show that Deb is not merely the scorned wife; there is far more to her than that. She makes mistakes as a wife and as a mother, and she is fully aware that she does.I think this book would be a good choice for a book club. There is a lot to discuss, whether regarding Deb and Jack's marriage or what happens with Simon and Kay. Also worth discussing is Pierpont's plot choice. How would the book have been different if she waited to tell you what happens to her characters?Review copy provided by publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

The only thing worse than being a teen, I should think, is being a teen who thinks she's invisible.In every part of her life, Sarah is eclipsed by someone, whether her glamorous older sister Scarlett or the popular and gorgeous cheerleader whom Sarah's boyfriend is tutoring. (And, yes, if your Spidey Sense is tingling over that one, you have a far better understanding of Sarah's relationship than she does.) Even her nickname - Bean - seems inferior. Beans are commonplace and utilitarian, not sparkly and shiny.Every summer, Bean and her family head to Cape Cod to spend their vacation with crotchety great aunt who - shocker - favors Scarlett over Bean. This summer, though, Bean is determined to study Scarlett, much as she studies the stars every night. If Bean can plot and predict the arrival of a comet, surely she can crack Scarlett's code and become the center of someone's universe.Bean quickly determines that she has to appear older. A not-quite-sixteen-year-old is not going to cut it in Scarlett's social world, so Sarah ages up. She is now a high school graduate, headed to MIT. Her ruse works well: she attracts the attention of Andrew, a handsome college student and buddy of a guy Scarlett is seeing. As Bean applies her findings from what she observes of Scarlett, she and Andrew become closer and closer.The question for Bean is whether Andrew loves her or if he loves the person she pretends to be. She has to ask herself if, aside from using Scarlett's clothes and mimicking her confidence, she is different with Andrew than with her other friends.As she struggles with this, she realizes that she isn't so sure that she likes attention. She is the scientist; she is the one who places others under the microscope and studies them. Sure, there are benefits to being noticed - Andrew's attraction to her, for one thing - but she doesn't like the fear that comes with the pretense.Then there is her family. There is a heartbreaking scene in which Bean has to confront her place in her family. Scarlett is a sort of black hole of attention. Her parents and great aunt aim their telescopes straight at her, viewing Bean as more of an orbiting satellite than a star herself. The only person in her family who seems to value her is her grandmother, and she feels as far away as the comet Bean waits for.This is a coming-of-age book, and what sets it apart from its brethren is that it feels so real. Beans anxiety about her place in her family and amongst her friends is utterly relatable, as is the first love she experiences with Andrew. She desperately wants to matter to someone, yet the only way she can figure out how to make that happen is by pretending to be someone else. What she doesn't fake are her feelings. She loves Andrew, and she wants to experience everything that comes with being with a college boy.Rebecca Maizel's storytelling is lovely, and it is as bittersweet as adolescence can be. There were parts of this book that I read with only one eye on the page, uncomfortable with how much I could relate to what was happening to Bean. She's such a likable, adorable character that I dearly wanted her to somehow get out of the mess of her own making. As much as I wanted her and Andrew to have their happy ending, I knew that Bean was only just sixteen. She has too much in front of her to have found her Mr. Forever right now. Right? Maybe?The Universe, though, is expansive, and within it are constellations we will never discover. Bean's fascination with stars and space marks her as an observer, but what people don't understand is that she also actively, passionately participates with those stars. She learns about them and knows them, and she feels a kinship with them. Bean does not keep herself at a distance, not with the stars and not with Andrew.I loved this book. I liked Bean, I liked Andrew, I liked the story, and I liked the way Rebecca Maizel wrote it. I even liked Scarlett, who could be one-note in another writer's hands. In Maizel's, she's a girl who takes advantages of the opportunities that come her way. Even when you're hating her, you kind of like her. The only weakness is the pacing. There were parts that dragged a little.I especially liked the ending. This book ends the way it should for Bean.Review copy provided by the publisher in exchange for an unbiased review.Published on VoxLibris.net@VoxLibris

When this tripod arrived, it came packaged with some other products I had ordered.  The tripod is so small that I didn't even notice it among the other items.  The tripod is so small, I doubted it could hold a large, heavy camera.I was wrong.  Though it's only about six inches long when folded up, it is sturdy enough and the legs are spread far enough to provide stable support even for heavier cameras.  The locking ball head allows me to position my camera at about any angle I want, without my needing to worry about the tripod tipping over.So, if you are looking for a way to stabilize your camera, and if you would like a tripod that you can just toss into a backpack, this is an excellent choice.  It is priced a bit higher than other tripods its size, but for good reasons: solidy, sturdy, metal construction make it worth a few extra bucks.Reviewer's note: I received this tripod free for the purpose of testing and reviwing.

I had incorrectly assumed that since these were "hearing protection", the music quality would be sub-par.I was pleasantly surprised to find that music actually sounds very good on these headphones.  Besides using these while mowing the lawn, they are equally good for casual listening in the living room...the sound is that good.  Surely, they are no match for some of the high-end headphones out there.  But they are a perfect balance between protection and sound quality.I also found the controls very easy to use.  Without even referring to the instructions, I was able to figure out how to connect to my phone (Galaxy S6) using Bluetooth.  Switching from line-in to radio to Bluetooth listening was all quite simple.One other thing that I like: some Bluetooth headsets control the "master volume" of your phone.  These, on the other hand, operate independently of the master volume.  That's a good thing.  It means you can set a maximum acceptable volume on your phone, and then use the headphone volume control to stay within that maximum range.One minor complaint: I'm not a fan of needing AA batteries to operate this.  I would much prefer the ability to have a built-in rechargeable battery.  Of course, that would increase the cost of the headphones.  I guess a reasonable compromise is for me to purchase rechargeable AA batteries.All in all, these are quite impressive...good functionality paired with good music quality!

I got this for shredding hard cheeses such as Parmesan.  It is perfect for that purpose.Previously, I had been using a Cuisipro grater.  I liked it, but found that the Cuisipro's shred was sometimes too fine for my needs.This grater from Erayco is slightly longer, and produces a slightly coarser shred.  With the Erayco, shredded Parmesan roughly resembles the texture of coconut flakes.  I would still call it a "fine" grind, but it's not so fine that the shreds lose their definition.I still like my old grater, but find myself turning to the Erayco when I need a fine grind rather than an "extra fine" grind.Reviewer's note: I received this grater free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

Whether or not you plan to purchase any of the colorful "Symmetry" inserts, this is a decent case that offers good protection.  Its main drawback is that after a short time, you will begin to notice light scratches on the clear plastic.I got this case with the intention of not adding any of the Symmetry inserts.  I liked the idea of the clear back that showed off the phone itself.  Overall, I'm happy with the result. But after a couple weeks, I have begun to see light scratches all over that clear plastic back.  That kind of cheapens its appearance.  Perhaps I would not notice the scratches as much if I had one of the colorful inserts.  Note that I am not particularly rough and abusive with my phone.  It spends most of its time in my pocket, which is probably where it picked up those scratches.  Note too that I may just be a bit too fussy about those scratches...maybe you won't care.  But I just figured that a couple weeks of light use should not reveal such scratches.As far as functionality is concerned, I have no complaints.  I like the plastic/rubber edge around the phone.  It feels solid (I expect it will offer sufficient protection against minor drops).  I also like that the rubber on the edge means that I can lay the phone face down on a smooth surface and it won't slide around...even if that surface has a slight incline.The case feels nice in my hand...quite comfortable, again thanks to the rubberized edge.All in all, a decent case.  If you can put up with the scratches, you are likely to be happy with it.

Lately, I've become a big fan of Epson's line of multifunction printers.  In the past month, I've had the opportunity to test both the XP-830 and now this XP-960.  Both are solid performers...which should you choose?  It depends on your needs.The main strength of the XP-960 is its photo quality.  The 960 uses six ink cartridges, as opposed to five in the 830.  Both printers have black, cyan, yellow, and magenta cartridges.  The 960 has two extra: light cyan and light magenta.  By contrast, the 830 has one extra: "photo black".  What does all this mean?  Better rendering of colors in my printed photos.  I particularly notice the 960's more realistic skin tones in portraits.  On the 830, skin tones seem a bit more "splotchy".  On the 960, they are more smooth and realistic.  To be fair, though, "splotchy" overstates the problem.  I'm actually quite happy with the photos from the 830.  But when held side-by-side with those from the 960, I notice a difference (my wife did not notice the difference though, so your results and satisfaction may vary).The weakness of the XP-960 is simply this: unlike the XP-830, the 960 does not have an auto document feed.  This means that you cannot scan in a stack of papers.  The XP-830 is better for high volume scanning and copying.  The 960 also lacks fax functionality...not a problem for me, but could be for you.So, the XP-960 is a perfect choice if your primary need is photo printing.  If you are looking for a good all-around small office workhorse, this is not it (the XP-830 would be a better, less expensive choice).As for me, the XP-960 is now my go-to photo printer.  I'm really happy with the quality.

Despite its light weight, this is a solid kitchen performer.I had an old colander that drained slowly because it did not have sufficient holes in it.  The Codream has holes everywhere, making it much better when I'm straining pasta.I also really appreciate the light weight of this.  I was concerned that the stainless steel might make it bulky, but it's not.  The stainless steel construction also does a nice job of keeping the heat from the handles, so the colander is immediately safe to handle even if I've just poured boiling water through it.All in all, a great colander!Reviewer's note: I received this colander free for the purpose of providing an unbiased review.

I had been using another iPad Mini case for a while, and had been happy with it.  When given the opportunity to test and review a different case, I hesitated.  Why switch?  Given my trust in Urban Armor Gear, having used their iPhone cases, I took a chance.I'm glad I did.After a week of use, I have a new favorite case.  A few noteworthy points:* The texture is amazing.  Really.  I love the feel of this case.  The rubberized grippy material makes it easy to hold on to.  The grooves on the front cover feel good, too.  And, the case has a black accents throughout that give the case an overall solid feel.* The UAG case offers great protection.  I liked my old case, but it didn't do much to protect it from drops and bumps.  The UAG case has solid protection on all sides, including thicker reinforced corners.* The case is highly functional.  The little magnetic latch has kept the case from popping open at incovnient times.  The auto-on/off works flawlessly, and the multiposition stand works fine (though it is not a feature I use much).  If I could voice one small complaint: the little magnetic latch sometimes gets in the way when I flip the case open and hold it with one hand, portrait-style.  I've learned to tuck it out of the way, but it is a bit of an annoyance at times.The Urban Armor Gear case seems perfectly matched to my iPad Mini 4 (note: it is specifically for the latest version 4, and is unlikely to fit previous versions).  I highly recommend it if you are looking for solid protection with a good look and feel.Note: I received this case free from UAG for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

Do you realize that set-top boxes such as Roku, AppleTV, and Amazon Fire TV, are all just small computers with interfaces that make it easy to browse for media?  For example, Roku is a computer that runs a version of the Linux operating system.  Those set-top boxes do their best to hide away the complexities of a typical desktop or laptop computer so that they are simple to use.What I like about this MXQ Smart TV is that it has the "expected" simple interface (browse Netflix and other apps with a remote control), but also exposes the operating system enough (in this case, Android) that I can do some normal computer things with it that I can't so easily do with Fire TV and Roku.  If you are a tinkerer, and like to play around a bit "under the hood" of your electronic devices, then try this: plug in a mouse and keyboard to the MXQ Smart TV, and see what you can get away with.  I find that menu and app navigation is far simpler with the mouse than with the remote control, and the keyboard greatly speeds up searching for titles.But that's not all...Since this is just another Android OS device, I can go to its app store and download apps that I want to use.  I can also surf the web, send and receive GMail, and more.When you start to ponder all that you can actually do with this "media box", you begin to realize that the price tag is amazingly low.  You get an Android computer with HDMI output, along with all the features you expect from a set-top box, all with a sub-fifties price tag.If you prefer the ease and polished interface of one of those "polished" set-top boxes, then this MXQ offering might not be for you.  But if you like tinkering under the hood to see what can be accomplished, then this is exactly the way to go.Reviewer's note: I received this device for free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.

This is a winner for two good reasons:1) It is so very simple to use.  I managed to get it up and running without the instruction manual.  Just plug it in, mount it on your windshield, and start your car.  The camera begins recording automatically, saving a file to the included memory card every few minutes.  Shut off the car, and the camera saves the last bit of data before shutting down.  In other words, no need to push any of the buttons or fumble through menus to get up and running.  If you do want to make changes, the configuration menu is there for modifying exposure, video quality, frequency of file saving, and more.  One minor complaint, there is an "OK" button on the camera, but you can't tell which button it is since none of them actually say "OK".2) The video quality is really good.  I kept it on the default video setting (one step down from the highest 1080pHD setting), and found that the video quality was great.  Cars, people, street signs...everything was quite clear during playback.  Note that the files produced by this are easily viewed either on the device itself, or on a computer.Overall, I am very pleased with this, and recommend it for anyone looking for an inexpensive way to record your driving.Reviewer's note: I received this camera free for the purpose of testing and reviewing.Those two reasons...ease and video quality...are reason enough to recommend this.  But add to that a good suction cup windshield mount, lots of configuration options for fine tuning my recordings, and an overall nice look and feel, and you've got a great little camera here.

When season 1 of Fargo came out, I was hesitant: how could they make a series from that movie?  And yet...success!  Season 1's story was not the same story as that of the movie, but it had enough similarities that it was fairly easy to map certain key movie characters to their TV counterparts.So, what about season 2?  Success!  Now that I am 4 episodes deep, I must say that I love season 2 even more than season 1.  I literally am counting days until I can watch the next episode.  This is the only show I care about right now.  And, I have become a huge fan of Bokeem Woodbine who plays the smooth talking Mike Milligan.  Oh, and Jesse Plemons (whom you may recognize from Breaking Bad).What not to expect...Do not expect the same characters.  Look, however, for the name "Solverson".  That was a clever touch.Do not expect the same plot.  Unlike the movie and season 1, this is not about a man killing or kidnapping his wife.Do not expect the same time period.  Here, we find the characters in 1979, where the calm town of Fargo is even calmer without the distraction of internet and cell phones.What you should expect...The same great atmosphere, where the light cheerful manner of speaking will stand in contrast to the dark subject matter.Amazing music...both the score, and song selections.Clever nods to other Coen Brothers creations.  Look for the names "Mundt" (as in the movie Barton Fink) and "Solverson" (as in season 1).  Look for a UFO (as in The Man Who Wasn't There).  And, is it just me, or is there a pair of characters who are very much like John Goodman and Steve Buscemi in The Big Lebowski?Good people in desperate situations.Great storytelling.Sorry I'm gushing over a TV series, but Fargo has won me over.
